passage_content: שמות שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה את יעקב איש וביתו באו. יש לדקדק טובא , אומרו את יעקב מה משמיענו בזה הלא כבר ידענו שיעקב בא למצרים ובניו עמו. ב) למה שינה הכתוב דרכו דמתחלה קורא אותו ישראל ואח"כ יעקב. ג) אומרו איש וביתו באו מיותר,
translation: The names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each man and his household, came. It is necessary to examine this well: what does the mention of Jacob teach us here? Did we not already know that Jacob came to Egypt with his sons? 2) Why does the text change its way, first calling him Israel and then Jacob? 3) The phrase "each man and his household came" is superfluous.
summary: The passage reflects on the significance of the names "Jacob" and "Israel" in the context of the Israelites' descent into Egypt, emphasizing the duality of identity in the Jewish experience. It questions the choice of the name "Jacob" after initially referring to him as "Israel," suggesting a deeper spiritual meaning behind this transition. The mention of "a man and his household" underscores the importance of family and community in the journey of faith, highlighting the collective nature of the Jewish people's relationship with God. Overall, the text invites contemplation on the complexities of identity and the communal aspects of spiritual life.

passage_content: ד) רבה הבאים מצרימה, וכי היום באים והלא ימים רבים היו להם שבאו למצרים אלא כל זמן שהי' יוסף קיים לא היו להם משוי של מצרים, מת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי, לפיכך כתיב הבאים כאילו אותו היום נכנסו למצרים, מבואר דמשמת יוסף התחיל השעבוד, ובפ ' ויחי פרש"י ז"ל למה פרשה זו סתומה, לפי שכשמת יעקב נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד שהתחילו לשעבדם, ולהלן עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא דרשו רז"ל ללמדך שכל זמן שהי' אחד מהם קיים מאותן שירדו למצרים לא שיעבדו המצרים בישראל הרי לך ג' סתירות בדברי רז"ל בזמן התחלת השעבוד.
translation: D) Many came to Egypt, and did they come today? Were there not many days for them to come to Egypt? Rather, as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt upon them. When Joseph died, they placed the burden upon them; therefore, it is written "the coming" as if they entered Egypt that very day. It is clear that from the moment Joseph died, the servitude began. And in Parashat Vayechi, Rashi, of blessed memory, explains why this section is closed: because when Jacob died, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed to the distress of the servitude that began to oppress them. And further, regarding the verse "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," our Sages expounded to teach you that as long as one of those who descended to Egypt was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel. Here you have three contradictions in the words of our Sages regarding the time the servitude began.
summary: The passage discusses the onset of the Israelites' enslavement in Egypt, emphasizing that it began only after the death of Joseph. It highlights that as long as Joseph was alive, the Israelites were not burdened by the Egyptians, suggesting a protective influence of righteous individuals. The text also notes that the death of Jacob led to a spiritual blindness among the Israelites, marking the beginning of their suffering. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the connection between the presence of righteous leaders and the spiritual and physical well-being of their communities.

passage_content: ה) את יעקב כל אלו מכוחו של יעקב שסגל מצות ומעשים טובים וזכה להעמיד י"ב שבטים. ויש לתמוה דהפסוק בא לספר התחלת הגלות והשעבוד ואיך שייך לומר ע"ז שהוא בזכות יעקב, אדרבה בזכות יעקב זכו ישראל לישועה וגאולה, והו"ל להזכיר זכותו של יעקב אצל פסוקי הגאולה.
translation: 5) All of these [tribes] are from the strength of Jacob, who acquired the commandments and good deeds and merited to establish the twelve tribes. It is puzzling, for the verse comes to recount the beginning of the exile and servitude, and how can it be said that this is due to the merit of Jacob? On the contrary, it is through the merit of Jacob that Israel merited salvation and redemption, and it would have been appropriate to mention Jacob's merit in the verses of redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's merit in establishing the twelve tribes of Israel through his good deeds and commandments. It raises a question about the connection between Jacob's righteousness and the onset of exile and oppression, suggesting that one might expect his merit to be associated with redemption rather than suffering. The text implies that Jacob's spiritual legacy is foundational for Israel's eventual salvation and redemption, highlighting the enduring impact of his virtues even in times of hardship.

passage_content: ו) מלך חדש על מצרים אשר לא ידע את יוסף ובתרגום אונקלס פי' דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף וצ"ב ואינו מבואר ענין גזירה זו מהו.
translation: "And a new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph, and in the translation of Onkelos it is explained that he did not uphold the decree of Joseph, and it is questioned what this decree is, and the matter of this decree is not clarified."
summary: The passage discusses the emergence of a new king in Egypt who did not recognize Joseph, symbolizing a departure from the legacy of divine providence and the covenant established through Joseph's leadership. This new ruler's failure to uphold Joseph's decree raises questions about the nature of divine decrees and their relevance in the face of changing circumstances. The text invites reflection on the continuity of faith and the challenges posed by new leadership that may disregard the foundational values of the past. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between human authority and divine will within the context of Jewish history.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין ולהשוות הג' זמנים הנ"ל שלא יהיו סותרין זה את זה, נקדים דברי רז"ל עה"פ ויעבידו מצרים את בני ישראל בפרך, פרש"י ז"ל בעבודה קשה המפרכת את הגוף ומשברתו , ובגמ' סוטה (י"א ע"א) בפרך בפה רך, פרש"י משכום בדברים ובשכר עד שהרגילום לעבודה. ובעלי התוס ' הביאו מדרש רז"ל עה"פ ערי מסכנות לפרעה, בתחלה אמר להם פרעה, לכל אחד מכם אני נותן שכר מכל לבנה שיעשה, ובאו כולן ודחקו עצמן מפני חימוד השכר ועשו יותר מדאי , וכוון שראה פרעה כך, אמר להם השלימו חקכם ללבון כאשר בהיות השכר נתן לכם והכי איתא נמי בגמ' (פסחים ל"ט ע"א) למה נמשלו מצרים למרור, לומר לך מה מרור זה תחלתו רך וסופו קשה, אף מצרים תחלתן רכה וסופן קשה, פרש"י בתחלה נשתעבדו להן ע"י שכר ששכרו אותן עיי"ש. ובמדרש הובא בבעלי תוס ' עה"פ לכו לסבלותיכם שבט לוי אמרו עתידין אנו לעבוד עבודת משא של הקב"ה, חלילה שלא נעבוד שום עבודה לרשע זה בשום שכר שיתן לנו, וענו הלוים ואמרו כולם שאינם יודעים לעשות לבנים, ומאותו היום והלאה לא הי' לו פתחון פה לשאול להם שום דבר עבודה עכ"ד המדרש, לכאורה ראוי להבין הרי לבסוף שעבד פרעה לישראל בכפי' ובכח גזירת המלכות, וכמו"כ הי' בידו להכריח את בני לוי לשעבד בהם ומדוע נמנע מעשות כן, ואין בזה טעם מספיק, מפני שבני לוי לא רצו לקבל עליהם בתחלה עבודתו של פרעה ברצונם, דלענין כפי' אין נפק"מ אם רצו או לא רצו, ואפשר להסביר עפי"ד הרמב"ן הק ' עה"פ הבה נתחכמה לו, וז"ל שלא ראה פרעה וחכמי יועציו להכותם בחרב, כי תהי' בגידה גדולה להכות חנם העם אשר באו בארץ במצות המלך הראשון וכו ', אבל אמר שיעשו דרך חכמה שלא ירגישו ישראל כי באיבה יעשו בהם, ולכך הטיל בהם מס, כי דרך הגרים בארץ להעלות מס למלך וכו' עכ"ל עיי"ש. ועד"ז התחכם שמתחלה נתן להם שכר, והיו ישראל עובדים עבודתו ברצונם להרויח שהיו נותנין עיניהם בממון, ועי"כ הי' לו פ"פ ושליטה, לשעבד בהם אח"כ, משא"כ שבע לוי שמעיקרא לא קבלו עבודתן, לא רצה להכריח אותם גם אח"כ לטעם הנ"ל.
translation:
To clarify the matter and to reconcile the three aforementioned times so that they do not contradict each other, we will begin with the words of our Sages on the verse "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor." Rashi explains that it refers to hard labor that breaks the body and crushes it. In the Gemara in Sotah (11a), it states that "with rigor" means with soft words, as Rashi explains, they would entice them with words and rewards until they became accustomed to the work. The Tosafists brought a Midrash from our Sages on the verse "Cities of treasure for Pharaoh," that initially Pharaoh said to them, "I will give each of you a reward for every brick you make," and they all pressed themselves due to their desire for the reward and worked excessively. When Pharaoh saw this, he said to them, "Complete your decree to make bricks as you did when the reward was given to you." It is also stated in the Gemara (Pesachim 39a) why the Egyptians are compared to bitter herbs, to tell you that just as this bitter herb starts off soft and ends hard, so too the Egyptians began soft and ended hard. Rashi explains that initially, they were enslaved by the reward they were given. In the Midrash, it is brought by the Tosafists on the verse "Go to your burdens," that the tribe of Levi said, "We are destined to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He, and God forbid that we should serve this wicked one for any reward he may give us." And the Levites answered and said that they did not know how to make bricks, and from that day onward, Pharaoh had no opening to ask them for any work. 

At first glance, it is appropriate to understand that ultimately Pharaoh enslaved the Israelites by the decree and power of the monarchy, and similarly, he had the ability to compel the children of Levi to serve him, so why did he refrain from doing so? There is no sufficient reason for this, as the children of Levi did not want to accept Pharaoh's work willingly at first. Regarding compulsion, it makes no difference whether they wanted to or not. It is possible to explain according to the words of the Ramban on the verse "Let us be wise with him," that Pharaoh and his wise counselors did not see fit to strike them with the sword, for it would be a great betrayal to strike the people who came to the land at the command of the first king, etc. Rather, he said they should act wisely so that the Israelites would not feel that they were being harmed, and therefore he imposed a tax on them, as it is the way of the strangers in the land to pay a tax to the king, etc. Thus, he cunningly initially gave them a reward, and the Israelites worked for him willingly to earn money, and through this, he had an opening and control to enslave them afterward. However, since the Levites did not initially accept his work, he did not want to compel them afterward for the aforementioned reason.
summary: The passage discusses the initial enslavement of the Israelites by Pharaoh, emphasizing the deceptive nature of their labor, which began with the allure of reward but ultimately led to harsh oppression. It highlights the distinction of the Levites, who refused to accept Pharaoh's work willingly, thereby avoiding his control and manipulation. The text illustrates a theological insight into the nature of free will and divine providence, suggesting that true servitude should be directed towards God rather than earthly rulers. Ultimately, it reflects on the importance of intention and the spiritual implications of labor in the context of faith.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר עוד טעם פנימי, מדוע לא שיעבדו המצרים בבני לוי בכפי', דהנה אף שהגלות היתה גזירה מן השמים, אבל לא בשעבוד קשה כ"כ, אלא שהמצרים העדיפו השעבוד והעינוי ולכך נענשו, והשיג פרעה שלא יוכל לשעבד בהם שעבוד קשה בלתי אם יחטיאם תחילה וכן עשה, וכמ"ש השלה"ק (מאמר מצה עשירה) וירעו אותנו המצרים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים לד' ולזה התחכם להמשיכם לדעתם ולדרכיהם בפה רך, כמש"כ רש"י ז"ל משכום בדברים ובשכר, גם נתן להם שררות ופטרונין , עד שנמשכו לדרכיהם הרעים לעבוד ע"ז והחטא גרם אח"כ לשעבד בהם שעבוד קשה בכפי' ובאונס, ולפי שמעיקרא התאוו תאוה להרויח ממון ע"כ אותו הרצון שיחדה אותם, דאין לך משוחד יותר ממי שמשוחד לתאוותיו ורצוניו , והשוחד יעור עיני חכמים, ולכן לא השיגו נכונה, שימשכו לדעתם עי"כ להחטיאם בע"ז, אבל שבט לוי לא רצו לקבל מהם שכר ולא נעשו משוחדים, וע"כ השיגו האמת מה שעתיד לצמוח מזה השכר, ולכך נמנעו מתחלה מלעבוד להם, ושוב לא הי' לכוחות הטומאה שליטה עליהם.
translation: And it is possible to say another inner reason why the Egyptians did not enslave the children of Levi in such a manner. Behold, although the exile was a decree from Heaven, it was not with such a harsh servitude, but rather the Egyptians preferred the servitude and the affliction, and for this they were punished. Pharaoh realized that he could not impose upon them a harsh servitude unless he first caused them to sin, and so he did, as it is written in the Shlah HaKadosh (in the essay on Matzah Ashirah), "And the Egyptians afflicted us," meaning they made us wicked and sinful before God. For this reason, he cunningly sought to lead them according to their desires and ways with soft words, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains, "He spoke to them in words and with rewards." He also gave them authority and patronage, until they were drawn to their evil ways to serve idols, and sin later caused them to be subjected to harsh servitude in a manner of coercion and oppression. Since initially they desired to gain wealth, that very desire separated them, for there is no bribe greater than one who is bribed by his own desires and wants. And the bribe blinds the eyes of the wise, and therefore they did not perceive correctly that they would be led by their desires to sin with idolatry. However, the tribe of Levi did not wish to accept rewards from them and did not become corrupted by bribes. Therefore, they grasped the truth of what the reward that would arise from this would be, and thus they refrained from working for them from the beginning, and again, the forces of impurity had no control over them.
summary: The passage discusses the unique status of the Levites during the Egyptian enslavement, emphasizing that their refusal to engage in hard labor stemmed from their spiritual integrity and rejection of material temptation. It suggests that the Egyptians preferred to impose harsh servitude, but their attempts to corrupt the Levites through rewards and idolatry were unsuccessful. The Levites' commitment to truth and their avoidance of bribery allowed them to remain free from the influence of impurity, ultimately protecting them from the harshness of slavery. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the power of spiritual resilience and the importance of maintaining one's values in the face of external pressures.

passage_content: והנה הכלל הוא שהסיבה הגורמת נחשבת כמעשה וע"ד שכתב הב"י ( באו"ח סי' תר"ד) לפרש אמרם ז"ל (ר"ה ט.) כל האוכל ושותה בתשיעי מעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו התענה תשיעי ועשירי, וז"ל מדכתיב בערב ע"כ לא מקפיד אעינוי דט ', והכי משמע קרא כלומר התקן עצמך בט' שתוכל להתענות בעשירי, ומדאפקה קרא בלשון עינוי ילפינן דהרי הוא כאילו התענה בט' עכ"ד, מבואר שהאכילה בתשיעי על שהוא סיבה והכנה המסייעתו להתענות בעשירי נחשבת ג"כ כאלו התענה, ועד"ז לענינינו דמה שהתחילו לעבוד בשביל ממון גרם שעבודם אח"כ, א"כ גם זמן ההוא שעבדו בשכר נכלל בזמן השעבוד כי דין גרמא בנזקין להשתעבד בהם אח"כ באונס, ולפי"ז אין סתירה בזמן השעבוד, דכ"ז שהי' יע"א קיים השפיע והאציל מאור קדושתו על כל ישראל ע"כ לא התאוו תאוה להשפעת הממון של המצריים, והשיגו וראו את הנולד מה שעתיד לצמוח מזה אם יסכימו לעבוד בשכר, אבל אחר הסתלקות יע"א נחלש כח הקדושה, ונתעורר אצלם הרצון להרויח ממון ולעבוד אצל המצריים בשכר, ועל כי היו משוחדים אל התאוה לא ראו את הנולד כי השוחד יעור , אולם יוסף הצדיק שהי' מלך ומושל עליהם ועל המצריים, לא הניחם לעבוד אף בשכר כי ראה את העתיד לצמוח מזה. ע"כ גזר שלא יעבדו עבודת המצריים אף בשכר.
translation: And behold, the principle is that the cause that brings about is considered as an action, and according to what the Ba'al HaTurim wrote (Orach Chaim 584) to explain the words of our Sages (Rosh Hashanah 9), "Anyone who eats and drinks on the ninth, the verse considers it as if he fasted on the ninth and tenth," as it is written, "in the evening," therefore he is not particular about the fasting of the ninth. And this is the meaning of the verse, that one should prepare oneself on the ninth so that he can fast on the tenth. And since the verse uses the language of fasting, we learn that he is as if he fasted on the ninth. Thus it is clear that eating on the ninth, as it is a cause and preparation that assists him to fast on the tenth, is also considered as if he fasted. Similarly, in our matter, that the fact that they began to work for money caused their subsequent servitude, therefore even that time they worked for wages is included in the time of servitude, because the law of causation in damages applies to be enslaved by them later in a case of coercion. According to this, there is no contradiction in the time of servitude, for as long as Joseph was alive, he influenced and bestowed from the light of his holiness upon all of Israel, therefore they did not desire the allure of the wealth of the Egyptians, and they understood and saw the outcome of what would sprout from this if they agreed to work for wages. But after the departure of Joseph, the power of holiness weakened, and the desire to earn money and work for the Egyptians for wages was awakened within them. And because they were blinded by the desire, they did not see the outcome, for bribery blinds the eyes. However, Joseph the righteous, who was king and ruler over them and over the Egyptians, did not allow them to work even for wages because he saw the future that would sprout from this. Therefore, he decreed that they should not work the work of the Egyptians even for wages.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that actions taken in preparation for a spiritual state are considered significant in themselves, as illustrated by the idea that eating on the ninth of Tishrei is akin to fasting on the tenth. It emphasizes that the initial desire for material gain led the Israelites into servitude, but during the presence of divine influence, they were not tempted by the allure of Egyptian wealth. After the departure of this divine presence, their spiritual strength weakened, leading to a desire for monetary gain. Joseph, recognizing the potential consequences of their labor for the Egyptians, prohibited them from working even for pay, highlighting the importance of maintaining spiritual integrity over material temptation.

passage_content: נמצא דבני עלי' ושבע לוי שהשיגו ירידת מדרגתם של ישראל, שבשביל הרווחת ממון רוצים לעבוד למלכות הרשעה, ושמזה יומשך אח"כ השעבוד. הם הרגישו בחי' השעבוד מיד בהסתלקות יעאע"ה , ואף שלא עבדו ישראל עדיין עבודת המצריים בפועל, דכ"ז שיוסף קיים גזר עליהם ועל המצריים שימנעו מזה, אבל עצם ידיעה זו שישראל מתאוים לזה בשביל הרווחת ממון הי' להם שעבוד רוחני, גם השיגו שאם יוסר כח המונע אחר הסתלקות יוסף הצדיק לא יקיימו עוד גזירת יוסף וסופם להשתעבד בהם, ולכן נחשב להם מיד להתחלת השעבוד, אולם השעבוד הי' רק בכח ולא בפועל, אבל כשנסתלק יוסף הצדיק הוסר מהם כח המושל, כי להשבטים לא הי' כח הממשלה ומי שרצה להרויח ממון לא מנע את עצמו מזה אחר פטירת יוסף, ועי"כ התחיל השעבוד בפועל, אלא שעדיין לא עבדו רק בשכר, דכ"ז שהיו השבטים הקדושים וכל הדור ההוא קיימים היו המצריים בושים לשעבד בהם בכפי', ואחר שנסתלק יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא נסתלקה הבושה מהם והתחילו לשעבד בהם בכפי' בלא שכר, ומעתה כל אלו הזמנים שארז"ל בהתחלת השעבוד כולן איתנייהו , אלא שכל א' בחינתו שונה מחבירו ואין בהם סתירה.
translation: It is found that the sons of Eli and the seven Levites who perceived the decline of the status of Israel, that for the sake of monetary gain they wished to serve the wicked kingdom, and from this would subsequently follow the servitude. They felt the aspect of servitude immediately upon the departure of our father Jacob, and although Israel had not yet actually served the Egyptians, as long as Joseph was alive he decreed upon them and upon the Egyptians that they should refrain from this, yet the very knowledge that Israel desired this for the sake of monetary gain was for them a spiritual servitude. They also understood that if the power of prevention were to be removed after the departure of Joseph the Righteous, they would no longer uphold Joseph's decree, and their end would be to be enslaved by them. Therefore, it was considered for them immediately the beginning of the servitude, although the servitude was only in potential and not in actuality. However, when Joseph the Righteous departed, the power of the ruler was removed from them, for the tribes did not have the power of government, and whoever wished to gain wealth did not refrain from this after the passing of Joseph. Thus, the servitude began in actuality, but they had not yet worked except for wages, as long as the holy tribes and that entire generation were alive, the Egyptians were ashamed to enslave them forcibly. But after Joseph and all his brothers and that entire generation departed, the shame was removed from them, and they began to enslave them forcibly without wages. From now on, all those times that our sages of blessed memory spoke of at the beginning of the servitude are all present, but each one in its own aspect is different from the other, and there is no contradiction among them.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual decline of the Israelites, highlighting their desire for material gain which led them to consider serving the oppressive Egyptian regime. The departure of Joseph, who had protected them, marked the beginning of their actual subjugation, as the fear of shame that had previously restrained the Egyptians was removed. This transition from potential to actual servitude illustrates a deeper theological insight into the consequences of spiritual disconnection and the loss of divine protection, emphasizing that the nature of their bondage varied over time but was fundamentally rooted in their own choices and desires.

passage_content: ועד"ז יל"פ דברי התרגום אונקלס עה"פ אשר לא ידע את יוסף די לא מקיים גזירת יוסף ולדרכנו ר"ל דיוסף גזר על המצריים שלא יעבידו בבני ישראל אפי' בשכר, וגם על ישראל גזר שלא יקבלו עליהם עבודתם של המצרים, ואחר הסתלקות יוסף הצדיק קם מלך חדש די לא מקיים גזירת יוסף הנ"ל והתחיל לעבוד בהם בשכר כדי להמשיכם לתועבת מצרים. וזה יהי' סיבה אח"כ להכריחם ולשעבדם בכפי', ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ( בקושיא ד') כ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים לא הי' להם משוי של מצרים, מת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי, לפיכך כתיב הבאים כאילו אותו יום נכנסו למצרים, דהתחלת השעבוד בפועל הי' משמת יוסף כנ"ל, וע"כ נחשב להם כאילו אותו יום נכנסו למצרים.
translation: And similarly, it can be explained regarding the words of the translation of Onkelos on the verse "who did not know Joseph," that he did not uphold the decree of Joseph. According to our way of understanding, Joseph decreed upon the Egyptians that they should not work the children of Israel, even for wages, and he also decreed upon Israel that they should not accept the labor of the Egyptians. After the passing of Joseph the righteous, a new king arose who did not uphold the aforementioned decree of Joseph and began to work them for wages in order to draw them into the abomination of Egypt. This would later be the reason to compel them and enslave them harshly. This clarifies the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in the question) that as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt upon them; when Joseph died, they placed a burden upon them. Therefore, it is written "the coming" as if on that very day they entered Egypt, for the beginning of the actual enslavement was from the time Joseph died, as mentioned, and thus it is considered as if on that day they entered Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's leadership and the subsequent oppression of the Israelites in Egypt after his death. It emphasizes that Joseph had decreed that the Egyptians should not enslave the Israelites, even for wages, but after his passing, a new king arose who disregarded this decree and began to exploit the Israelites. This shift marked the beginning of their actual enslavement, illustrating the theological concept that the absence of righteous leadership can lead to spiritual and physical bondage. The text highlights the idea that the Israelites' entry into Egypt and their suffering began with the death of Joseph, symbolizing a loss of divine protection and guidance.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הזוה"ק (שמות ב' ע"ב) מה כתיב ואלה שמות בנ"י וגו' כיון דכתיב בנ"י מהו את יעקב, הבאים אתו אצטרך למימר , אלא אלה שמות בנ"י אינון רתיכין ומשריין עילאין דנחתו עם יעקב בהדי שכינתא בגלותא דמצרים עכ"ד הזוה"ק , ופי' בהג ' מהרח"וו ז"ל עם יעקב בהדי שכינתא , שהשכינה נקראת יעקב עכ"ל, וירמוז עוד בשם יעקב עפי"ד ק"ז זלה"ה בתפלה למשה עה"פ לולי ד' שהי' לנו יאמר נא ישראל, שיש עוד טעם על אמירת יעקב, כי היו"ד אות משמו יתברך, ויעקב הוא לשון שפלות רומז על הגלות, ור"ל שבגלות ג"כ ד' אתנו, ובכל צרתם של ישראל לו צר כביכול עייש"ד , וזה ירמוז כאן את יעקב איש וביתו באו, שבאו עמו שכינתא ופמלי ' דילי' כמו שפי' בזוה"ק , ובכח זה נתקיימו ישראל בקדושתן וזכו להגאל משם, וז"ש במדרש את יעקב כל אלו מכוחו של יעקב שסגל מצות ומעשים טובים, ר"ל בכח זכותו ומידתו ירדה שכינה הק ' עמהם למצרים, גם כי שם יעקב ירמוז על בחינה זו כנ"ל, וכמו"כ בכל הגליות כביכול עמנו בצרה. והוא שעמדה לנו, ולולי זאת לא הי' נשאר ח"ו שריד ופליט אחר כל המאורעות שעברו עלינו, ובכח זה נשאר לנו בחי' קדושה, אעפ"י שזעיר הוא מאוד מ"מ השתלשלות הקדושה לא נפסק, וממנה תתרחב ותתפשט עד שימלא הארץ דעה את ד' ונזכה לגאולה שלימה בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Zohar (Shemot 2:72) regarding what is written, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. Since it is written "the children of Israel," what is the meaning of "with Jacob"? It is necessary to say that these are the names of the children of Israel, they are the righteous and the elevated ones who descended with Jacob alongside the Shechinah in the exile of Egypt, thus says the Zohar. And the explanation in the commentary of the Mahra"ch is that "with Jacob alongside the Shechinah," for the Shechinah is called Jacob. And it hints further in the name Jacob according to the verse (Psalms 124:1) in the prayer of Moses, "If it had not been for the Lord who was with us, let Israel now say," that there is another reason for mentioning Jacob, for the letter Yud is a letter from His blessed name, and Jacob is a term of humility, hinting at the exile, meaning that in the exile, too, the Lord is with us, and in all the troubles of Israel, He is not troubled, as it were. This hints here that Jacob and his household came, that the Shechinah came with him and his family, as explained in the Zohar. And through this, Israel was sustained in their holiness and merited to be redeemed from there. This is what is said in the Midrash, "To Jacob, all these are by the power of Jacob who acquired commandments and good deeds," meaning that by the merit of his righteousness and his attribute, the Holy Shechinah descended with them to Egypt. Also, the name Jacob hints at this aspect as mentioned, and likewise in all the exiles, as it were, He is with us in trouble. And this is what has stood for us, and were it not for this, there would not have remained, Heaven forbid, a remnant or survivor after all the events that have befallen us. And by this, we have retained a measure of holiness, even though it is very small, nevertheless, the chain of holiness has not been interrupted, and from it, it will expand and spread until the earth is filled with the knowledge of the Lord, and we will merit complete redemption with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Jewish people and the Divine Presence (Shekhinah) during their exile in Egypt, emphasizing that the Shekhinah accompanies them, symbolized by the name Jacob, which represents humility and the experience of suffering. It highlights that despite the challenges faced, the merit of Jacob and the observance of commandments sustain the Jewish people's sanctity and connection to God. The text asserts that this divine presence is crucial for their survival and eventual redemption, reinforcing the belief that God is with them in their suffering. Ultimately, it expresses hope for a complete redemption and the revelation of God's glory in the future.

passage_content: ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה את יעקב איש וביתו באו, יל"ד שהתחיל הבאים בלשון הוה ומסיים איש וביתו באו בלשון עבר, גם מתחלה הזכיר בני ישראל הבאים, וגמר אומר איש וביתו באו והי"ל לכללינהו יחדיו בנ"י הבאים מצרימה את יעקב איש וביתו.
translation: And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each man and his household came. It is noteworthy that it begins with the present tense "coming" and concludes with the past tense "came." Additionally, it initially mentions the children of Israel who are coming, and concludes by saying "each man and his household came," and it would have been fitting to include them together as "the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each man and his household."
summary: The passage reflects on the transition from the present to the past in the narrative of the Israelites coming to Egypt, emphasizing the significance of individual and collective identity. It highlights the duality of the community as both a unified entity ("Bnei Yisrael") and as distinct individuals ("Ish u'Beito"), suggesting that each person's journey contributes to the collective experience. This interplay underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of both communal and personal spiritual journeys, illustrating how individual actions and identities shape the broader narrative of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המדרש ילקוט ותמלא הארץ אותם א"ר יוחנן מלאו את מצרים, והכוונה עפ"י פשוטו דכ"ז שהי' יע"א בחיים חיותו היו בנ"י מופרשים ומובדלים בארץ גושן ולא נכנסו לארמ"צ כלל, ואחר שנסתלקו יע"א ויוסף בקשו לעשות התחברות עם המצריים ויצאו מגושן ומלאו את ארץ מצרים, וכמו הפירוש השני שבמדרש שנתמלאו בתי טרטיאות וכו ', שלא הי' זה בחיי יע"א , כי אז היו כולם גדורים בעריות והתרחקו ממקומות אלו, וכמו"כ גם למצרים לא הלכו, ואחר הסתלקות יע"א ויוסף מילאו את ארמ"צ , ואף שהי' קביעותם בארץ גושן כמקדם, אבל יצאו גם לארץ מצרים ולא נבדלו מהם.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Midrash Yalkut: "And the land was filled with them," said Rabbi Yochanan, "They filled Egypt." The intention, according to its simple meaning, is that as long as Yaakov Avinu was alive, the Children of Israel were separated and distinct in the land of Goshen and did not enter Egypt at all. And after Yaakov Avinu and Yosef passed away, they sought to connect with the Egyptians and left Goshen, filling the land of Egypt. This is similar to the second interpretation in the Midrash that they filled the houses of the theaters, etc. This did not happen during the lifetime of Yaakov Avinu, for then they were all guarded against immorality and distanced themselves from such places, and likewise, they did not go to Egypt. After the passing of Yaakov Avinu and Yosef, they filled the land of Egypt, and even though they had their settlement in the land of Goshen as before, they also went into the land of Egypt and were not distinct from them.
summary: The passage discusses the separation of the Israelites in the land of Goshen during the lifetimes of the patriarchs, emphasizing their distinctiveness from the Egyptians. After the passing of Jacob and Joseph, the Israelites sought to integrate with the Egyptians, leading to their filling of the land of Egypt. This shift signifies a departure from their previous spiritual and moral boundaries, highlighting the dangers of assimilation and the loss of their unique identity. The text reflects on the importance of maintaining spiritual separation and the consequences of failing to do so.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד עפמ"ש הרד"ק ז"ל עה"כ (יהושע י"א ט"ז) ויקח יהושע את כל הארץ הזאת וגו' ואת כל ארץ הגושן וגו' וז"ל אין זה גושן של מצרים, ובדרש אומר כי הי' גושן של ארמ"צ , והוא נבלעת בתוך ערי ישראל, כמ"ש ויעל לקראת אביו גושנה , מלמד שהוא בעלי' כלפי ארץ ישראל, ובזכות שהלך יהודה בשליחות אביו להורות לפניו, זכה שיהי' לחלקו ארץ גושן שהיא טובה עכ"ל, ובש"ך עה"ת כתב ואפשר באומרו ואת יהודה שלח לפניו, רמז כאן שנשתלחה אותה רצועה מא"י לגושן וכו ', ואותה רצועה היתה נעלמת ולא היתה נודעת אלא ליעקב ובניו, ולזה אמרו ועתה ישבו נא עבדיך בארץ גושן וכו ', ולפי"ז יע"א לא נכנס באויר חו"ל כלל שלא להיטמא מאויר ארץ העמים, אלא היתה רצועה של א"י מתקפלת והולכת לפניו והוא בתוכה, וכן כשהוליכוהו לאחר מיתה היתה מתקפלת והולכת עמו, וזהו שרמז לו אנכי ארד עמך מצרים ואנכי אעלך גם עלה וכו' עכ"ל. והסבר הענין במ"ש שנשתלחה רצועה מא"י לחו"ל, הכוונה על פנימית הארץ, וכל יושבי הארץ בודאי לא הכירו ולא ראו שום השתנות בארץ, (עי' בספרי ויואל משה מאמר ב' סי' קכ"ט) עכ"פ מבואר בדבריו דכ"ז שהי' יע"א בארץ גושן הי' שם א"י ממש, ולא ביאר מתי נסתלקה קדושת א"י מארץ גושן, ואפשר דכ"ז שיוסף קיים עדיין הי' שורה שם קדושת א"י, ואחרי הסתלקותו פנה הרצועה של א"י משם.
translation: And even though it is said according to the words of the Radak, may his memory be blessed, on the verse (Joshua 11:16) "And Joshua took all this land... and all the land of Goshen," he states that this is not the Goshen of Egypt. And in the Midrash, it is said that there was a Goshen of Aram, which was absorbed within the cities of Israel, as it is said, "And he went up to meet his father in Goshen," teaching that it was elevated towards the land of Israel. And due to the merit that Judah went on his father's mission to instruct before him, he was privileged to have the land of Goshen, which is good. Thus far the text. And in the Shach on the Torah, it is written that perhaps in saying "And he sent Judah before him," it hints here that that strip was sent from the land of Israel to Goshen, etc. And that strip was hidden and was not known except to Jacob and his sons. Therefore, they said, "And now let your servants dwell in the land of Goshen," etc. According to this, it can be said that he did not enter the air of foreign lands at all, so as not to become impure from the air of the lands of the nations, but rather a strip of the land of Israel was folding and going before him, and he was within it. And likewise, when they brought him after death, it was folding and going with him. And this is what he hinted to him, "I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also bring you up," etc. Thus far the text. And the explanation of the matter in saying that a strip was sent from the land of Israel to foreign lands refers to the inner part of the land, and all the inhabitants of the land certainly did not recognize or see any change in the land (see in the Sefer Vayoeil Moshe, Article 2, Section 129). In any case, it is clear from his words that as long as he was in the land of Goshen, it was truly the land of Israel, and he did not explain when the sanctity of the land of Israel departed from the land of Goshen. It is possible that as long as Joseph was still alive, the sanctity of the land of Israel was present there, and after his departure, the strip of the land of Israel turned away from there.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the land of Goshen, suggesting that it was not merely a region in Egypt but rather a part of the holiness of the Land of Israel that extended into foreign territory. It emphasizes that this connection was maintained as long as Joseph was alive, indicating that the sanctity of the Land of Israel was present in Goshen. The text implies that the spiritual essence of the land could be concealed and that the Jewish people, through their connection to their homeland, were able to maintain their identity and sanctity even in exile. Ultimately, the departure of this holiness is linked to the absence of Joseph, marking a significant theological insight into the relationship between the Jewish people and their land.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הבאים מצרימה וכו' מת יוסף וכו' כאילו אותו היום נכנסו למצרים וכי תימא הלא כבר באו, לזה אמר את יעקב איש וביתו באו, שמתחלה כאשר באו עם יע"א גס ביתו הלך עמו מא"י והי' שם קדושת א"י, ורק עכשיו נכנסו למצרים, ובזה יובן דברי המדרש ילקוט ותמלא הארץ אותם שמלאו את מצרים, דאף שנשארו בארץ גושן כמקדם, מ"מ עד עכשיו לא הי' המקום ההוא ארץ מצרים רק א"י, והי' נרגש להם הבדל הרוחני בין גושן למצרים, ע"כ לא רצו ישראל לצאת כלל מא"י למצרים, אבל אח"כ נסתלקה קדושת א"י משם ע"כ מלאו את כל ארמ"צ כי לא הי' עוד הבחנת גבול ביניהם.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash that say they came to Egypt, etc., that Joseph died, etc., as if on that day they entered Egypt. And if you should say, "But they had already come," to this it says, "Jacob and his household came," for initially, when they came with Joseph, his household went with him from the Land of Israel, and there was the sanctity of the Land of Israel. Only now did they enter Egypt, and with this, the words of the Midrash will be understood: "And the land was filled with them," meaning they filled Egypt. For although they remained in the land of Goshen as before, nonetheless, until now that
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual significance of the Israelites' entry into Egypt, emphasizing that their initial arrival was marked by the sanctity of the Land of Israel, which they carried with them. It highlights that even while residing in Goshen, they experienced a distinct spiritual difference from Egypt. However, as the sanctity of the Land of Israel diminished, the boundaries between the two lands blurred, leading to the Israelites fully integrating into Egypt. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of spiritual awareness and the impact of divine presence in different locations.

passage_content: ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה וגו', הקשו המפרשים ז"ל הרי כבר מנה שמות השבטים לעיל בפ ' ויגש ולמה חזר ומנאן כאן.
translation: "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt, etc." The commentators, may their memory be blessed, questioned: behold, the names of the tribes were already counted above in Parashat Vayigash, so why does it repeat them here?
summary: The passage discusses the repetition of the names of the tribes of Israel as they enter Egypt, questioning the necessity of this recounting after it was already mentioned earlier. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the importance of identity and continuity within the Jewish people, emphasizing that each name carries spiritual significance and a unique connection to the collective destiny of Israel. The act of naming serves to reinforce the bond among the tribes and highlights the divine providence guiding their journey, suggesting that every detail in their narrative is imbued with meaning and purpose.

passage_content: ב) א"ר אבהו כל מקום שנאמר אלה פוסל את הראשונים, ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים וכו ', ואלה שמות הוסיף שבח על שבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם היו צדיקים ע"כ דברי המדרש, וצ"ב הרי אלו האמורים כאן הם עצמן נזכרו למעלה ובמה יתוסף שבחם בהזכירם עוה"פ .
translation: B) Rabbi Abahu said: Wherever it is stated "these" it disqualifies the earlier ones, and "these" adds to the earlier ones, etc. And "these are the names" adds praise to the seventy souls mentioned above, who were all righteous. Thus are the words of the Midrash. However, it is puzzling: these mentioned here are the same ones referred to above, and how is their praise enhanced by mentioning them in this world?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, Rabbi Abahu discusses the significance of the term "these" in relation to the righteous individuals mentioned earlier, emphasizing that their mention adds praise to their already established virtues. The text raises a question about how the same individuals, already recognized for their righteousness, can receive additional commendation in this context. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the ongoing nature of spiritual elevation and the idea that even the righteous can attain greater levels of holiness through continued recognition and remembrance.

passage_content: ג) תנחומא ואלה שמות בני ישראל זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך ., ראוי להבין קישור פסוק זה לכאן.
translation: 3) Tanchuma and these are the names of the children of Israel, as it is written: "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise." It is fitting to understand the connection of this verse here.
summary: The passage connects the names of the children of Israel to the divine attributes of God, emphasizing that just as God's name reflects His essence, so too do the names of the Israelites embody their spiritual identity. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the intrinsic connection between the individual and the divine, suggesting that each person's name carries a unique spiritual significance. The verse underscores the importance of recognizing the holiness inherent in every individual, as they are reflections of God's glory. Ultimately, it invites a deeper understanding of the relationship between humanity and the divine, rooted in the recognition of one's spiritual purpose.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הגמ ' סוטה (ל"ד ע"ב) א"ר יצחק דבר זה מסורת בידינו מאבותינו, מרגלים על שם מעשיהם נקראו, ואנו לא עלה בידינו אלא אחד סתור בן מיכאל. סתור שסתר מעשיו של הקב"ה מיכאל שעשה שונאו מך וכו ', ולכאורה יש להבין הלא כתיב במרגלים כולם אנשים, ואמרו רז"ל כל אנשים שבמקרא לשון חשיבות: ובאותה שעה כשרים היו ואיך אפשר לומר שנקראו על שם מעשיהם, ועדיין הי' הבחירה בידם להטיב.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Gemara in Sotah (34b): Rabbi Yitzchak said, "This is a tradition we have from our ancestors, that the spies were called by the name of their actions, and we have only one, Sator ben Michael, who is called Sator because he contradicted the actions of the Holy One, blessed be He, Michael, who made his enemy weak, etc. And at first glance, one must understand, is it not written about the spies that they were all men? And our sages have said that all men in the Scriptures implies a language of importance: and at that time they were righteous, and how can it be said that they were called by the name of their actions? Yet, they still had the choice to do good.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of the spies sent by Moses, emphasizing that they were called "spies" due to their actions, which contradicted God's intentions. It highlights the tension between their initial righteousness and their subsequent failure, suggesting that despite their status as "men of importance," they ultimately chose to act against divine will. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of free will and the moral responsibility individuals hold in their choices, even when they possess a noble status. The mention of one spy, Sator ben Michael, serves to illustrate the complexity of human actions in relation to divine purpose.

passage_content: ונראה לבאר בהקדם דברי הגמ ' סנהדרין (ק"ט ע"ב) ויקח קרח א"ר לקיש שלקח מקח רע לעצמו, קרח שנעשה קרחה בישראל, בן יצהר וכו ', בן לוי שנעשה לוי' בגיהנם , וליחשוב נמי בן יעקב שעקב עצמו לגיהנם וכו ', יעקב ביקש רחמים על עצמו שנאמר וכו' עכ"ד הגמ ', וכתב האוה"ח הק ' ( בפ ' קרח) וזל"ק ובעיני יפלא למה יכנה דברים הרעים לשמות הצדיקים. ולא די זה אלא שמקשה בעל הדרשה וליחשוב בן יעקב וכו ', ותירץ דע כי כשברא ה' את האדם ברא נטע אחד שבו כלולים כל ענפי הקדושה, וכשחטא ונפגם נפגמו כל הנשמות שהיו תלוים בו: וכל שיצאו ממנו פגומים היו, עד שיצתה נפש אברהם וכו ', ויצתה נשמת יעקב בלא שום דופי וכו ', נמצינו אומרים שהאילן הוא יעקב ויצאו ממנו י"ב ענפים ואחד מהם הוא לוי, ענף זה העניף ג' ענפים וכו' וקהת העניף ד' ענפים עמרם יצהר וכו ', וענפי יצהר הוא קרח וכו ', קרח בתחלה הי' נקרא קרח טהור וכו' בן לוי שנתלוה מיום לידתו להקב"ה בכמה מעלות, ועכשיו הענף עצמו שנקרא קרח נפגם ועשה בו קרחה , ולא ענפו בלבד אלא גם שורש הענף שבא ממנו וכו ', ולא זו בלבד אלא גם שורש הענף הראשון שיצא מיעקב שורש של נפש קרח אשר משם נעקרה, נפגמה ועשתה בו נקמה ללוותן לגיהנם , וממה שלא הזכיר הכתוב בן יעקב וכו ', לפי שהתפלל על עצמו וכו' וזהו היתה תפלתו של יעקב שלא יגיע כח החטא עד עיקר השורש שביעקב, ולא ינתק חבל הכסף מעיקרו ויש תקוה לאחריתם וכו' עכלה"ק . ועד"ז יובן אצל המרגלים דאם לא היו עושין המעשה הרע הזה, הי' מורה שמותיהם לטובה, אך ע"י מעשיהם נשתנה פירוש שמותיהם ונקראו לגנאי ע"ש מעשיהם, כי שם האדם מאיר לפי מעשיו, וכ"ז שהי' מעשיהם טובים הי' מאיר שמותיהם לטובה ואח"כ נשתנה שמותיהם בערך מעשיהם.
translation: And it seems necessary to explain in advance the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin (K109b) that Korach took a bad deal for himself, Korach who became a bald spot in Israel, son of Yitzhar, etc., son of Levi who became a Levi in Gehenna, and also to consider the son of Yaakov who caused himself to go to Gehenna, etc. Yaakov prayed for mercy for himself as it is said, etc. Thus concludes the Gemara. And the Ohr HaChaim (in Parshat Korach) wrote, and it is astonishing in my eyes why the bad things are referred to by the names of the righteous. Not only this, but the author of the drashah also questions considering the son of Yaakov, etc., and he answered that when Hashem created man, He created a single tree in which all branches of holiness are included, and when he sinned and was blemished, all the souls that were dependent on him were also blemished: and all that came out from him were flawed, until the soul of Avraham came out, etc., and the soul of Yaakov came out without any blemish, etc. Thus we find that the tree is Yaakov, and from him came twelve branches, and one of them is Levi. This branch produced three branches, etc., and Kehat produced four branches: Amram, Yitzhar, etc., and the branches of Yitzhar are Korach, etc. Korach was initially called Korach the Pure, etc., son of Levi who was attached from the day of his birth to the Holy One, Blessed be He, with many virtues, and now the branch itself that is called Korach became blemished and made a bald spot in it, not only its branch but also the root of the branch from which it came, etc. And not only this, but also the root of the first branch that came from Yaakov, the root of the soul of Korach from which it was uprooted, became blemished and took revenge to lead them to Gehenna. And from the fact that the scripture did not mention the son of Yaakov, etc., it is because he prayed for himself, etc. And this was the prayer of Yaakov that the power of sin should not reach the very root that is in Yaakov, and that the cord of silver should not be severed from its source, and there is hope for their end, etc. Thus concludes the words. And similarly, it can be understood regarding the spies that if they had not committed this evil act, it would have indicated their names for good, but through their actions their names were changed and they were called for disgrace according to their deeds, for a person's name shines according to his actions, and as long as their deeds were good, their names shone for good, and afterwards their names were changed in relation to their deeds.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual implications of actions and their impact on one's identity, using the example of Korach and the meraglim (spies). It emphasizes that when God created humanity, He embedded within each person the potential for holiness, but sin can corrupt this potential, leading to a tarnished legacy. The text highlights that names reflect one's deeds; thus, Korach, initially a pure descendant of Levi, became associated with negativity due to his actions. Additionally, it notes that Jacob's prayers protected his essence from the corruption of sin, ensuring a hopeful future for his descendants.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי המדרש (שמו"ר פ"ג ס"ו) ויאמר אלקים אל משה א"ר אבא בר ממל א"ל הקב"ה למשה שמי אתה מבקש לידע לפי מעשי אני נקרא, פעמים שאני נקרא בקל שד"י בצבאות, באלקים , בד', כשאני דן את הבריות אני נקרא אלקים , וכשאני עושה מלחמה ברשעים אני נקרא צבאות, וכשאני תולה על חטאיו של אדם אני נקרא ק"ל וכו' ע"כ דברי המדרש, וכמו"כ שבחיו ותואריו ית ' הם ע"ש פעולותיו, כמ"ש בגמ' (ברכות ל"ג ע"ב) ההוא דנחית קמי' דר' חנינא אמר הקל הגדול הגבור והנורא האדיר והעזוז וכו ', כי סיים א"ל סיימתינהו לכולהו שבחי דמרך , למה לי כולי האי, אנן הני תלת דאמרינן אי לאו דאמרינהו משה רבינו באורייתא ואתו אנשי כנה"ג ותקנינהו בתפלה לא הוינן יכולין למימר להו, ואת אמרת כולי האי ואזלת, משל למלך בשר ודם שהי' לו אלף אלפים דינרי זהב והיו מקלסין אותו בשל כסף. והלא גנאי הוא לו עכ"ד הגמ ', ולכאורה לפי הנחה זו איך תיקנו אנשי כנה"ג לומר הקל הגדול הגבור והנורא, וקשה כמו"כ וכי סיימתינהו לכולא שבחי', אך נראה דלשבח את השי"ת בתואר עצמי אסור, כי הבוי"ת לית מחשבה תפיסה בי' כלל, אולם תוארים אלו הקל הגדול וכו' דאמרינהו משרע"ה הם ע"ש פעולותיו ומדותיו ית ' ותליא במעשי בנ"א כידוע, והוא דבר שיש לו קצבה ויתכן בו לשבח את השי"ת, ומשה רבינו ואנכה"ג השיגו פעולותיו ומדותיו ית ' השולטים בעולם, וע"ש זה תקנו לומר הקל הגדול הגבור והנורא, וכדאי' בגמ' (יומא ס"ט ע"ב) למה נקרא שמן אנשי כנה"ג שהחזירו עטרה ליושנה, אתא משה ואמר הקל הגדול הגבור והנורא, אתא ירמי' ואמר נכרים מקרקרין בהיכלו אי' נוראותיו לא אמר נורא, אתא דניאל ואמר נכרים משתעבדים בבניו או' גבורותיו לא אמר גבור , אתו אינהו ואמר אדרבה זו הוא גבורותיו וכו' עכ"פ מבואר שתואריו ושבחיו ית ' הם ע"ש פעולותיו ית ' וכמו"כ שמותיו ית ' כמבואר במד"ר הנ"ל.
translation:
And we will precede the words of the Midrash (Shemot Rabbah 3:6) "And God said to Moses," Rabbi Abba bar Mammal said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "My name that you seek to know is according to My actions, I am called by different names: sometimes I am called by the simple name Shaddai, sometimes by the name Elokim, sometimes by the name Hashem. When I judge the creatures, I am called Elokim, and when I wage war against the wicked, I am called Tzva'ot, and when I suspend the punishment for a person's sins, I am called K'l. Thus are the words of the Midrash. Likewise, His praises and titles are according to His actions, as it is stated in the Gemara (Berakhot 33b), "That one who came before Rabbi Chanina said: The great, mighty, and awesome God, the mighty and strong, etc." When he finished, he said to him, "You have completed all the praises of the Master." Why do I need all this? We have these three that we say; if not for what our teacher Moses said in the Torah, and the men of the Great Assembly came and established them in prayer, we would not have been able to say them. And you say all this and go on? It is like a king of flesh and blood who had a thousand thousand golden dinars, and they praised him with silver. Is it not a disgrace to him? Thus said the Gemara. 

And at first glance, according to this assumption, how did the men of the Great Assembly establish to say "the great, mighty, and awesome God"? And it is also difficult: did they complete all the praises? However, it seems that to praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, with a self-title is forbidden, for the human mind cannot grasp Him at all. However, these titles, "the great God," etc., that were said by Moshe Rabbeinu are according to His actions and attributes, which depend on the deeds of man, as is known. This is a matter that has a limit, and it is possible to praise the Holy One, Blessed be He. Moshe Rabbeinu and the men of the Great Assembly grasped His actions and attributes that govern the world, and for this reason, they established to say "the great, mighty, and awesome God." And as it is stated in the Gemara (Yoma 69b), "Why are they called the men of the Great Assembly? Because they returned the crown to its former glory." Moshe came and said, "the great, mighty, and awesome God." Jeremiah came and said, "The foreigners are crawling in His temple," and he did not say "awesome." Daniel came and said, "The foreigners are subjugating His children," and he did not say "mighty." They came and said, "On the contrary, this is His might." In any case, it is clear that His titles and praises are according to His actions, as well as His names, as explained in the aforementioned Midrash.
summary: The passage discusses the various names and attributes of God as they relate to His actions and interactions with humanity. It emphasizes that God's names, such as Elokim and Tzva'ot, reflect His roles in judgment and warfare, respectively, and that His praises are derived from His deeds. The text highlights the importance of understanding God's attributes in the context of His actions, suggesting that while one cannot fully grasp the essence of God, one can appreciate His qualities through His manifestations in the world. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of recognizing God's greatness through the lens of His deeds and the limitations of human understanding.

passage_content: ועפי"ז נראה לפרש הפסוק כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך , היינו כשמו של הקב"ה שנקרא ע"ש פעולותיו כן תהלתך , שגם תהלותיו ית ' ע"ש מעשיו ופעולותיו, והנה כבר אמרנו לעיל כי שמותיו של אדם נשתנה ג"כ לפי מעשיו, וכלל הוא שהאדם אינו עומד במדריגה א' רק הולך, ואם אינו הולך ח"ו למעלה אזי יורד חלילה למטה, ובשום פנים אינו עומד במקום אחד, והצדיקים עולים תמיד במדריגתם ולפי מעשיהם נשתנה שמותיהם לטובה. ועפי"ז יובן המדרש ואלה שמות בנ"י וגו' מוסיף שבח על הראשונים וגו' ולכאורה הלא הם עצמם כבר נזכרו למעלה וכשנמנו למעלה היו ג"כ צדיקים, ומה מוסיף עליהם, אבל באמת ע"י שהיו צדיקים עלו תמיד במדריגתם , ולפי מעשיהם נשתנה שמותיהם לעילוי, ואינם כמו שנמנו למעלה, כי פנימיות שמותיהם נשתנה לטובה, ולזה כפל כאן עוה"פ שמותיהם להוסיף שבח על הראשונים, ולהורות שבשמותיהם נעשה תוספת שבח, וזה שהסמיכו במדרש תנחומא לכאן הפסוק כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך , דכמו"כ אצל הבוית"ש כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך כנ"ל ששמו ותהלותיו יתברך ע"ש מעשיו ומדותיו .
translation: And according to this, it seems appropriate to interpret the verse "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise," meaning that according to the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is called after His actions, so is Your praise, that His praises are also according to His deeds and actions. And behold, we have already said above that a person's names also change according to their actions, and it is a general principle that a person does not remain in one level but rather ascends, and if they do not ascend, God forbid, then they descend, Heaven forbid, to a lower level, and in no way do they remain in one place. The righteous always ascend in their levels, and according to their actions, their names change for the better. And according to this, the Midrash can be understood: "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc., adds praise to the earlier ones, etc. And at first glance, they themselves were already mentioned above, and when they were counted above, they were also righteous, so what does it add to them? But in truth, because they were righteous, they always ascended in their levels, and according to their actions, their names changed for elevation, and they are not as they were counted above, for the inner essence of their names changed for the better. And therefore, it repeats here, "the names" to add praise to the earlier ones, and to indicate that in their names, an addition of praise was made. This is why it is connected in the Midrash Tanchuma to the verse "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise," for similarly, regarding the Holy One, blessed be He, "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise," as mentioned, that His name and praises are according to His actions and attributes.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between God's names and His actions, emphasizing that just as God's name reflects His deeds, so too do the names of individuals change according to their actions. It highlights the idea that a person's spiritual state is dynamic; one either ascends or descends in their spiritual journey. The text also explains that the righteous continually elevate their status, leading to a transformation of their names for the better. This concept is illustrated through the mention of the names of the Israelites, which signify their ongoing spiritual growth and merit.

passage_content: במסיבה (פ' א' סי' ב') ואלה שמות בנ"י וגו', א"ר אבהו כ"מ שנאמר וכו' ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים וכו' ואלה שמות הוסיף שבח על שבעים נפש וכו' שכולם היו צדיקים עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב .
translation: In the gathering (Parashat Va'eira, Section 2), "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. Rabbi Abahu said: Wherever it is stated, etc., "And these" adds to the first ones, etc. "And these names" adds praise to the seventy souls, etc., for they were all righteous. Thus concludes the Midrash, and there is a question.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the phrase "And these are the names of the children of Israel," emphasizing that it adds merit to the previous mention of the seventy souls who descended to Egypt. The commentary highlights that all these individuals were righteous, suggesting a continuity of holiness and virtue among the Jewish people. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the inherent sanctity within the Jewish soul and the importance of lineage and spiritual legacy. The passage invites contemplation on the collective righteousness and the divine favor bestowed upon the Jewish people throughout their history.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי קדוש זקיני הייטב לב זלה"ה ריש פרשתינו וזה לשון קדשו, על פי מה שפירש מוזלה"ה וזרח השמש ובא השמש וגו', דאיתא בגמרא ריש פ"ק דברכות (דף ב' ע"א) ממאי דהאי ובא השמש ביאת שימשא הוא דילמא ביאת אורו הוא, ופרש"י שיאיר השמש וכו ', והקשו התוס ' עלי' אי בזריחה הו"ל לכתוב וזרח השמש, או לשון יציאה כמו השמש יצא על הארץ ומדנקט קרא ובא השמש היינו שקיעת החמה עכ"ד. ויש להבין טעם הדבר למה נקט זריחת השמש בשם יציאה ושקיעת השמש בשם ביאה, איפכא מסתברא לקרוא זריחתה בשם ביאה שמאיר ובא לכאן. ושקיעתה בשם יציאה שיוצא מכאן, אבל יתבאר עפימ"ש חכז"ל (סנהדרין צ"א ע"ב) מפני מה חמה יוצאת במזרח ושוקעת במערב, כדי ליתן שלו' לקונה פרש"י שהשכינה במערב עיי"ש, וא"כ כשיוצאת מקונה נקרא יציאה וכשבא לקונה שזו מקומה נקראת ביאה, וז"ש וזרח השמש (היינו במזרח) ובא השמש (היינו במערב) ולמה נקרא שקיעתה במערב בשם ביאה, עז"א הטעם ואל מקומה שואף זורח הוא שם שהשכינה במערב וזו מקומה ולכן נקרא ביאה עכ"ד הישמח משה זלה"ה , וז"ש עם ה' אלה ומארצו יצאו, כי בארץ ישראל שם משכן כבודו ית ', ע"כ כשגלו משם נקרא יצאו ממקומם, וא"כ קשה אהא דכתיב כאן בנ"י הבאים מצרימה, הכי זה מקומם שנקרא באים, אבל יובן כי הקשה הזוה"ק מ"ש יעקב ושכבתי עם אבותי וגו', תמן תנינא וכו' אר"י שאני יעקב דשכינה אחידא בי', כדכתיב אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה ואנכי אעלך וגו' וזש"ה וישבע יוסף וגו' ועז"א ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה וא"ו מוסיף על ענין ראשון ששם השכינה ע"כ שם מקומם ולכך נקראו באי"ם את יעקב (שנאמר לו אנכי ארד עמך וגו') איש וביתו בא"ו קב"ה ופמליא דילי' וכו' עכל"ק בייטב לב.
translation:
And we will explain at the outset the words of my holy grandfather, the good-hearted Zal, at the beginning of our portion, and this is his holy language: According to what he explained, "And the sun rose and the sun set," etc. It is stated in the Gemara at the beginning of Berakhot (2a) from where do we know that "and the sun set" refers to the coming of the sun, perhaps it refers to the coming of its light. Rashi explains that the sun will shine, etc., and the Tosafot ask, if it is referring to sunrise, it should have been written "and the sun rose," or in the language of going out, like "the sun went out over the land," and since the verse states "and the sun set," it refers to the setting of the sun. 

And we must understand the reason why it uses the term "going out" for sunrise and "coming" for sunset. It seems more logical to refer to its rising as "coming," since it shines and comes here, and to refer to its setting as "going out," since it leaves here. However, it will be explained according to what our sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 91b) regarding why the sun rises in the east and sets in the west, in order to give peace to the Creator, as Rashi explains that the Shekhinah is in the west, as stated there. Therefore, when it goes out from its place, it is called "going out," and when it comes to its place, which is called "coming." This is what is meant by "and the sun rose" (meaning in the east) and "and the sun set" (meaning in the west). 

And why is its setting in the west called "coming"? The reason is that it aspires to its place, which is where the Shekhinah is in the west, and this is its place, and therefore it is called "coming," as stated by the happy Moshe, of blessed memory. And this is what is meant by "with the Lord God and from His land they went out," for in the land of Israel is where His glory dwells. Therefore, when they were exiled from there, it is called "they went out from their place." 

And thus, it is difficult regarding what is written here about the Children of Israel coming to Egypt; is this their place that is called "coming"? But it will be understood that the Zohar asks about what is written, "And Jacob said, 'I will lie down with my fathers,' etc.," there it is stated, "I am different," etc. Rabbi Yitzhak said, "Jacob is unique because the Shekhinah is united with him," as it is written, "I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will surely bring you up," etc. And this is what is meant by "And these are the names of the Children of Israel who came to Egypt," and the "and" adds to the first matter that the Shekhinah is there; therefore, that is their place, and thus they are called "those who come" with Jacob (who was told, "I will go down with you, etc.")—a man and his household, with the Holy One, blessed be He, and His entourage, etc. All this is explained in the good-hearted Zal.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the terms "coming" and "going" in relation to the sun's rising and setting, linking these concepts to the presence of the Divine. It explains that the sun's rising in the east symbolizes the Shechinah's presence, while its setting in the west represents a departure from that presence. The text further connects this idea to the Israelites' journey to Egypt, emphasizing that their movement is framed as a "coming" due to the Divine presence accompanying Jacob. Ultimately, it highlights the intimate relationship between the Jewish people and the Shechinah, underscoring the theological notion of God's constant companionship with them.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפ"י דרכו באופן אחר קצת, בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ ( בפ ' ויגש ) ויאמר אלקים לישראל וגו' אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, פירש"י לפי שהי' מיצר על שנזקק לצאת לחו"ל ע"כ, וכן איתא ג"כ בפרקי דר"א כששמע יעקב על יוסף שהוא חי, הי' מהרהר בלבו ואמר אעזוב את ארץ אבותי ואת ארץ מולדתי ואת ארץ מגורי אבותי ואת ארץ ששכינתו של הקב"ה שרוי' בתוכה, ואלך לי אל ארץ טמאה אל תוך ערלים שאין יראת שמים ביניהם, אמר לו הקב"ה אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם ואנכי ארד עמך וגו' ע"כ, ומקשים דאיך התנחם בהבטחת כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, על מה שנתיירא לירד למצרים ארץ טמאה ומקום ערלים שאין יראת שמים ביניהם, ואף אם יהי' לגוי גדול עדיין יראתו במקומה עומדת, ויתבאר עפי"מ דאיתא במדרש רבה (איכה א' ל"ג) אר"י בא וראה כמה חביבין תינוקות לפני הקב"ה, גלתה סנהדרין ולא גלתה שכינה עמהם גלו משמרות ולא גלתה שכינה עמהם, וכיון שגלו תינוקות גלתה שכינה עמהם, הה"ד עולליה הלכו שבי לפני צר מיד ויצא מן בת ציון כל הדרה עכ"ד המדרש, מבואר שבמקום תשב"ר שם הוא השראת השכינה: והנה מעת שנמכר יוסף למצרים ועד עכשיו עברו כ"ב שנים, ובכל אלו השנים לא העמיד יע"א יותר משבעים נפש, ורק אחר שירד למצרים פרו ורבו מאוד, ואמרז"ל במד"ר פ' וישלח (פ' ע"ט א') לא נפטר יעקב אבינו עד שראה ששים רבוא מבני בניו, ובוודאי ישנם ע"ז טעמים כמוסים לפניו ית ' (עי' בדברינו לעיל פ' וישב ע' רס"ו) ועכ"פ כך הי' רצון המקום ית"ש , ובאלו י"ז שנים שהיו במצרים נתחנכו שם ששים רבוא תינוקות של בית רבן על ברכי התורה והיראה בחינוך קדוש, והי' שם השראת השכינה בבחי ' גדולה שלא הי' דוגמתו בא"י, ולזה כשהי' יעקב אבינו מהרהר ואמר איך אעזוב ארץ ששכינתו של הקב"ה שרוי בתוכה ואלך אל ארץ טמאה, א"ל הקב"ה אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם ועי"ז תזכה לבחי ' גדולה של השראת השכינה.
translation:
And even though according to his way it is somewhat different, it is appropriate to explain from the verse (in Parashat Vayigash) "And God said to Israel, 'Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you a great nation there.'" Rashi explains that he was distressed about having to leave his homeland. Thus, it is also stated in Pirkei de-Rabbi Eliezer that when Jacob heard that Joseph was alive, he was pondering in his heart and said, "Shall I leave the land of my fathers, the land of my birth, the land where my ancestors lived, and the land where the Divine Presence dwells, and go to a defiled land among the uncircumcised, where there is no fear of Heaven among them?" God said to him, "Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you a great nation there, and I will go down with you," etc. It is difficult to understand how he was consoled by the promise of "for I will make you a great nation there," regarding what he feared about going down to Egypt, a defiled land and a place of uncircumcised people where there is no fear of Heaven among them. Even if it will be for a great nation, his fear remains in its place. 

It can be explained according to what is stated in Midrash Rabbah (Lamentations 1:33) that Rabbi Yochanan said, "Come and see how beloved are children before the Holy One, Blessed be He. The Sanhedrin was exiled, but the Divine Presence did not go into exile with them; the watchmen were exiled, but the Divine Presence did not go into exile with them. But when the children were exiled, the Divine Presence went into exile with them," as it is written, "Her children have gone into captivity before the enemy." And from the daughter of Zion went forth all her splendor. Thus, it is clear that where there is suffering of the Jewish people, there is the resting of the Divine Presence.

Now, from the time Joseph was sold into Egypt until now, twenty-two years have passed, and during all those years, Jacob did not have more than seventy souls. Only after he went down to Egypt did they multiply greatly. And our sages say in Midrash, Parashat Vayishlach (Parashat 79:1) that Jacob our father did not pass away until he saw six hundred thousand from his grandchildren. Certainly, there are hidden reasons for this before the Holy One, Blessed be He (see our words above in Parashat Vayeshev, page 256). Nevertheless, this was the will of the Omnipresent, Blessed be He. 

And during those seventeen years that they were in Egypt, sixty myriads of children of the house of study were raised there on the knees of the Torah and fear in holy education, and there was the resting of the Divine Presence in a great manner that was not comparable to that in the Land of Israel. Therefore, when Jacob our father was pondering and said, "How shall I leave the land where the Divine Presence dwells and go to a defiled land?" God said to him, "Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you a great nation there," and through this, you will merit a great level of the resting of the Divine Presence.
summary: The passage discusses Jacob's fear of leaving the holy land for Egypt, a place perceived as impure and devoid of divine presence. God reassures him not to fear, promising that he will become a great nation there and that His presence will accompany him. The text emphasizes that even in exile, particularly in Egypt, the divine presence can be profoundly felt, as the children of Israel flourished and were nurtured in their faith. Ultimately, it highlights the idea that God's presence can manifest even in the most unlikely places, transforming them into sites of spiritual growth and divine connection.

passage_content: ובזה יובן במאמה"כ ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה וגו', דלכאורה הו"ל למימר לשון ירידה ע"ש שירדו למצרים ערות הארץ, ובדרך הטבע זהו ירידה גדולה לבחי ' הנפש, כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל ( בפ"ו מהל' דעות ה"א) דרך ברייתו של אדם להיות נמשך בדיעותיו ובמעשיו אחר רעיו וחבריו, נוהג כמנהג אנשי מדינתו וכו ', ואיך יתכן לקרוא ירידתם למצרים הבאים, אבל מפני שהיו את יעקב איש וביתו באו, שיעקב אבינו לחם נגד כוחות הטומאה, והדריך את בני ביתו וס"ר מישראל בחינוך קדוש וטהור אף בתוך מצרים ערות הארץ ולכן לא היו בבחי ' יורדים רק באים, ונקרא בשם ביאה שהשכינה שם הוא במקום תשב"ר.
translation: And with this, it will be understood in the verse, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," that seemingly it should have used the term "descent" because they descended to Egypt, the nakedness of the land. Naturally, this is a great descent for the level of the soul, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, writes (in the sixth chapter of the Laws of Opinions, halacha 1) that it is the way of a person to be influenced in his thoughts and actions by his friends and companions, behaving according to the customs of his country, etc. How can it be that their coming to Egypt is referred to as "coming"? But because Jacob and his household came, as our forefather Jacob fought against the forces of impurity and guided his household and the leaders of Israel with holy and pure education even within Egypt, the nakedness of the land, therefore they were not in a state of descent but rather in a state of coming, and it is called "coming" because the Shechinah was there, which is the place of the Divine Presence.
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," emphasizing that their arrival should not be viewed as a descent but rather as an ascent. Despite the natural inclination to see their entry into Egypt as a significant spiritual decline, the presence of Jacob and his family, who maintained a holy and pure upbringing amidst the impurity of Egypt, transformed their experience into a positive one. This highlights the Hasidic concept that even in challenging environments, one can elevate their spiritual state through strong faith and righteous conduct, thus making their coming a manifestation of divine presence.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד דברי המכילתא (פ' בא) והי' כי יאמרו אליכם בניכם מה העבודה הזאת לכם וגו', בשורה רעה נתבשרו ישראל באותה שעה, שסוף עתידה תורה להשתכח ע"כ, ולכאורה צ"ב הרי מצות הלילה כן הוא שישאלו הבנים, ואין זה לסיבת שכחת התורה, ואיך נרמז בזה שכחת התורה, גם יל"ד דכל מקום שנאמר והי' הוא לשון שמחה וכאן לשמחה מה זו עושה, עוד שם במכילתא ויש אומרים בשורה טובה נתבשרו ישראל באותה שעה שהן עתידין לראות בנים ובני בנים, וגם זה צ"ב הכי יעלה על הדעת שכללות האומה לא יהי' להם בנים ובני בנים, ומה צורך לבשורה זו, ועו"ק דשאלה זו מה העבודה הזאת לכם הוא שאלת בן הרשע כמ"ש לכם ולא לו וכפר בעיקר, ומהו הבשורה טובה שיהי' להם בנים שישאלו כן.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Mechilta (Parashat Bo): "And it shall be when your children say to you, 'What is this service to you?' etc." At that time, Israel received bad tidings, that in the end, the Torah would be forgotten. Therefore, it is puzzling, for the commandment of the night is indeed that the children will ask, and this is not due to the forgetting of the Torah. How is the forgetting of the Torah hinted at in this? Furthermore, it is known that wherever it says "and it shall be," it is a language of joy, and here, what joy does this bring? Additionally, there in the Mechilta, it is said that Israel received good tidings at that time, that they would see children and grandchildren. Yet, this too is puzzling; how could it be that the entire nation would not have children and grandchildren? What need is there for this good tidings? Moreover, this question, "What is this service to you?" is the question of the wicked son, as it is written "to you" and not "to him," and he denies the essence. What is the good tidings that they will have children who will ask this?
summary: The passage discusses the dual interpretations of the verse from the Mekhilta regarding the question posed by children about the Passover service. It highlights the tension between the fear of the Torah being forgotten and the hope of future generations, suggesting that the inquiry reflects a deeper concern about faith and continuity within the Jewish people. The text emphasizes that the question arises from a place of skepticism, particularly from the "wicked son," and questions the significance of the promise of future offspring in light of potential spiritual decline. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of faith, tradition, and the assurance of continuity in Jewish identity.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה בביאת הגואל ב"ב יהי' השפעת הקדושה בישראל בבחי ' גדולה מאוד, שנזכה להתגלות משה רבינו ודור המדבר וצדיקי הדורות, ויזריחו בלבות בנ"י קדושה נפלאה ורוממה, ואותן שהיו משוקעים בגשמיות עולם הזה, ובפרט מי שאינו נקי מחטא הידוע יהי' קשה להם לקבל השפעת הקדושה הנפלאה, ובעוה"ר מי יוכל לומר זכיתי לבי טהרתי מחטאי, אולם תשב"ר שלא טעמו טעם חטא ולא נשתרש בהם דעות ומדות רעות. הם בוודאי יוכלו לקבל השפעת הקדושה בבחי ' גדולה יותר מאבותיהם, וכמו"כ בזמן הגלות שנתפזרנו בעוה"ר במקומות הטמאים, ורוב בנ"א מבלים ימיהם בהבלי העוה"ז ועוסקים בעניני החומר יום ולילה לא ישבותו , עכ"ז אם יתאמצו לחנך בניהם על טהרת הקודש בדרך ישראל סבא, יש לצפות שיגיעו בניהם למעלה ממדריגת מעשה אבותיהם, ועי"ז גם האבות ייטיבו מעשיהם שלא יבושו ולא יכלמו מהם, ובזה יש לפרש דברי המכילתא והי' כי יאמרו אליכם בניכם מה העבודה הזאת וכו' בשורה טובה נתבשרו ישראל וכו ', שהם עתידין לראות בנים וב"ב שישאלו ככה, וענין הבשורה שיתגדל השגת בניהם בעבודת השי"ת ובמעשה המצות, ויתמהו על מהות וערך העבודה של אבותיהם, ויאמרו מה העבודה הזאת לכם, שהעבודה שלכם הוא בבחי ' מה המורה על קטנות כמ"ש ונחנו מה, ובשורה טובה הוא זה שידרשו הבנים הדרכה ישרה ומעולה והלואי שנזכה לזה, אמנם יש בזה גם בשורה רעה, שעתידה תורה להשתכח מישראל, דע"כ ישאלו הבנים כן לצד מיעוט עבודת אבותיהם, ובזה יובנו ב' הדיעות שבמכילתא הנ"ל.
translation: And it is understood that with the coming of the Redeemer, there will be a great outpouring of holiness upon Israel, that we should merit the revelation of Moshe Rabbeinu and the generation of the desert and the righteous of the generations, and they will illuminate in the hearts of the Jewish people a wonderful and exalted holiness. And those who were immersed in the materiality of this world, especially those who are not free from the known sin, will find it difficult to receive the outpouring of the wonderful holiness. However, those who have not tasted the taste of sin and have not been rooted in bad thoughts and traits will certainly be able to receive the outpouring of holiness in a greater measure than their ancestors. Likewise, during the exile, when we have been scattered in impure places, and most people spend their days in the vanities of this world and engage in material matters day and night without rest, nevertheless, if they strive to educate their children in the purity of holiness in the way of Israel's ancestors, we can expect that their children will reach a level above the deeds of their ancestors. And through this, the ancestors will also improve their deeds so that they will not be ashamed or embarrassed by them. In this, we can explain the words of the Mechilta: "And it will be when your children say to you, 'What is this service?' etc., good tidings were announced to Israel," that they are destined to see children and grandchildren who will ask like this. The matter of the good tidings is that the understanding of their children in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and in the performance of the commandments will grow, and they will wonder about the essence and value of the service of their ancestors, and they will say, "What is this service to you?" since your service is in a manner that indicates smallness, as it is said, "And we are what?" And the good tidings is that the children will seek a straight and excellent guidance, and may we merit this. However, there is also a bad tidings in this, that the Torah is destined to be forgotten from Israel, therefore the children will ask this due to the diminished service of their ancestors. And in this, the two opinions in the aforementioned Mechilta will be understood.
summary: The passage discusses the anticipated arrival of the Messiah and the profound spiritual impact it will have on the Jewish people, particularly through the revelation of Moses and the righteous of past generations. It emphasizes that those who have not been tainted by sin will be better able to receive this divine influence, while those entrenched in worldly matters may struggle. The text also highlights the hope that the next generation will surpass their ancestors in their devotion to God, despite the potential for a decline in Torah observance, as indicated by the questions their children will ask about their forebears' practices. Ultimately, it reflects on the dual nature of this future, containing both promise and concern regarding the continuity of Jewish tradition.

passage_content: והנה גם בן הרשע שואל שאלה זו עצמה על כוונה אחרת, וצריך להבחין מי הוא השואל, ואם הבן מתנהג בדרך הישר וודאי כוונתו לטובה ע"ד הנ"ל, משא"כ אם הוא רשע וודאי כוונתו להוציא את עצמו מן הכלל כמ"ש לכם ולא לו לפיכך הקהה את שיניו, וז"ש הפסוק והי' כי יאמרו אליכם "בניכם" דייקא , ר"ל בנים שמתנהגים בדרך ישראל סבא וראויים להיות נקראים בניכם, ואם הם ישאלו שאלה זו מה העבודה הזאת לכם. בשורה טובה הוא לכם כרמוז בתיבת והי' לשון שמחה, שהבנים יתחנכו בדרך זה שישאלו מה העבודה הזאת לכם, ובעוה"ר הדורות מתמעטים והולכים וכמו שרואין בעוה"ר הירידה הגדולה מבחי ' דור הקדום, אבל עכ"פ על הבנים צריכין להשתדל שיתנהגו בדרך אבותינו ורבותינו הקדושים ולא יהיו ח"ו "יתמי דיתמי " שהאבות הם כיתומים עזובים ממעשה אבותיהם, ואם ח"ו גם הבנים לא יחזרו לדרכי אבוה"ק ה"ה יתמי דיתמי , וע"כ צריכין להשתדל שהבנים עכ"פ יחזרו לחינוך הקדום.
translation: And behold, even the son of the wicked asks this very question with a different intention, and it is necessary to discern who is the questioner. If the son behaves in the way of the righteous, certainly his intention is for good, as mentioned above. However, if he is wicked, his intention is certainly to exempt himself from the community, as it is said to you and not to him; therefore, he has dulled his teeth. And this is what the verse means when it says, "And it will be when they say to you, 'Your children'"—specifically, sons who behave in the way of our forefather Israel and are worthy of being called your children. If they ask this question, "What is this service to you?" it is good news for you, as hinted in the word "and it will be," which is a language of joy, that the children will be educated in this way to ask, "What is this service to you?" In our current situation, the generations are diminishing, and as we see in our time, the great decline from the days of the ancient generation. Nevertheless, concerning the children, we must strive that they behave in the way of our holy ancestors and teachers, and not be, Heaven forbid, "orphans of orphans," where the fathers are like orphans abandoned from the deeds of their forefathers. And if, Heaven forbid, the children also do not return to the ways of our holy ancestors, they are indeed orphans of orphans. Therefore, we must strive that the children at least return to the ancient education.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of discerning the intentions behind questions asked by children, particularly in the context of faith and tradition. It emphasizes that if a child behaves righteously, their inquiry about religious practices is a positive sign of engagement, whereas a wicked child may seek to distance themselves from the community. The text highlights the need for the next generation to be educated in the ways of their ancestors to avoid becoming "orphans" of tradition. Ultimately, it calls for a commitment to instilling the values and practices of the holy forefathers in the youth to ensure the continuity of faith.
