passage_content: ונקדים עוד דברי האוהחה"ק עה"כ ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים, ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים מה הראשונים ידעו והכירו בגלות וקבלו עליהם ועל זרעם, כמו"כ אלה וכו ', ואמר ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה, פי' הבאים לסבול עול הגלות במצרים, את יעקב אתו בדומה לו. בהסכמה אחת לפרוע שטר חוב הגלות וכו ', עוד ירצה אומרו הבאים וגו' שבא לומר מופת חותך כי ברצונם באו, והראי' שאחר מות אביהם ועלו ארצה כנען. חזרו פ"ב כאמור בפ ' ויחי, והוא אומרו הבאים מצרימה את יעקב מחדש איש וביתו באו, אחר שעלו משם חזרו למצרים איש וביתו, ומנה הכתוב מי הם בעלי צדקות זה ראובן וגו', הא למדת כי ענפי האילן כאילן עצמו, שוים לחפוץ בגזירת מלך ויכתב בספר זכרון לפניו ליראי ה' וגו' עכל"ק , ועד"ז אפ"ל גם על הדור השני אחר פטירת יוסף שהרגישו השיעבוד הקשה בחומר ובלבנים, וגזירות הקשים בגשמיות וברוחניות, כמבואר בשלה"ק וירעו אותנו המצריים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים ואף עליהם רמז הכתוב באמרו הבאים מצרימה לשון הוה , ר"ל שקבלו עליהם לסבול עול הגלות וחיכו לגאולה בעת שיעלה רצון הבוית"ש , ובזה יל"פ במאמה"כ וירא אלקים את בני ישראל וידע אלקים , ר"ל שיש להם אמונה בידיעת השגחתו ית ' ובטחו בישועתו והקב"ה שמע לקולם כמ"ש וישמע אלקים את נאקתם וגאל אותם משם, וגם בגלות החל והמר הזה יש לחכות לישועת השי"ת בכל יום אף שנתארך הרבה מאוד עד שקשה כח הסבל, וכמש"כ הרמב"ם ז"ל אעפ"י שיתמהמה אחכה לו בכל יום שיבוא, ולכאורה וכי מי הוא אשר יסתפק בזה ח"ו להאמין בביאת המשיח שהוא מעיקרי האמונה, אמנם בא לזרז ולעורר כי אף אם ימים יבואו ויתגבר החושך וערפל יכסה ארץ ויתארך הגלות ויתמהמה הרבה ועי"ז הנסיונות באמונה יהיו גדולים וקשים מאוד: עכ"ז צריך להתחזק באמונה ביתר שאת ויתר עז ולדעת כי הכל הוא בהשגחתו ית '.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the holy author, blessed be He, and these are the names of the children of Israel who came, and these add to the first ones what the first ones knew and recognized in the exile and accepted upon themselves and upon their descendants, likewise these, etc. And it says, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," meaning those who came to bear the yoke of the exile in Egypt, with Jacob with him, similar to him. With one agreement to pay off the debt of the exile, etc. Furthermore, it is intended by saying "the coming" that it is to say a decisive proof that they came willingly, and the evidence is that after the death of their father they ascended to the land of Canaan. They returned, as stated in Parashat Vayechi, and this is the meaning of "the coming to Egypt with Jacob," anew each man and his household came, after they ascended from there they returned to Egypt, each man and his household, and the scripture counts who are the righteous ones, this is Reuben, etc. Thus you have learned that the branches of the tree are like the tree itself, equal in their desire to fulfill the decree of the King and to be written in the book of remembrance before Him for those who fear the Lord, etc. Similarly, it can also be said about the second generation after the passing of Joseph, who felt the hard servitude in clay and bricks, and the harsh decrees in physical and spiritual matters, as explained in the holy book, "And the Egyptians afflicted us," that they made us evil and sinful, and even about them the scripture hinted by saying "the coming to Egypt" in the present tense, meaning that they accepted upon themselves to bear the yoke of the exile and awaited redemption at the time that the will of the Blessed One would arise. And in this, it can be explained in the verse, "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew," meaning that they had faith in the knowledge of His providence and trusted in His salvation, and the Holy One, blessed be He, heard their voice, as it is said, "And God heard their groaning and redeemed them from there." And even in this bitter and harsh exile, one should hope for the salvation of the Blessed One every day, even though it has been prolonged very much to the point that the strength of endurance is difficult, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote, "Even though He may delay, I will wait for Him every day that He will come." And seemingly, who would doubt this, God forbid, to believe in the coming of the Messiah, which is one of the fundamentals of faith? However, it comes to urge and awaken that even if days come and darkness prevails and a cloud covers the earth and the exile is prolonged and delayed greatly, and as a result, the trials in faith become very great and difficult: nevertheless, one must strengthen oneself in faith with greater strength and greater might and know that everything is under His providence.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the names of the Israelites who came to Egypt, emphasizing their conscious choice to endure the suffering of exile as a collective act of faith. It highlights the continuity of faith from the patriarchs to their descendants, illustrating that even in the face of severe oppression, the Israelites maintained their trust in God's providence and awaited redemption. The text underscores the importance of steadfast belief in divine oversight, even amidst prolonged hardship, encouraging a deepened commitment to faith despite challenges and darkness. Ultimately, it reaffirms the essential belief in the coming of the Messiah as a fundamental tenet of faith.

passage_content: וז"פ דברי המדרש כל אלה מכוחו של יעקב, ר"ל באיזה כח עמדו ישראל בנסיון במצרים והתחזקו באמונה בהקב"ה, בכוחו של יעקב שהנחיל כח השפעה זו לדורות הבאים שיהיו חזקים באמונתם ובידיעת השי"ת, וכן אנחנו צריכים להתחזק באותו הכח ובכח הצדיקים הקדושים הקודמים לפנינו. ולאורם נסע ונלך ומכוחם ישפיעו גם עלינו ובזכותם נתחזק בבטחון בהשי"ת , ויעזור הבוי"ת שנזכה בימים אלו ימי השובבי"ם להשים על הלב ולקדש ולטהר את עצמינו לשמור המחשבות והדיבורים והמעשים ולילך בדרך האמת לדבק בהקב"ה ובתורתו הקדושה, והשי"ת ישפיע עלינו רוח טהרה ממרום להתקרב אל הקדושה ואל ישטפו אותנו ח"ו המים הזדונים ופגעי הזמן, והקב"ה רואה ומביט בצערן ובצרתן של ישראל בכל פרט ופרט הן בגשמיות והן ברוחניות, כי באמת לבו של אדם עליו דוי שרוצה לדבק עצמו אל הקדושה ולעשות תשובה אבל חשכות המצב והמאורעות המה בעוכריו ולכן הבוכ"ע חפץ בהצדקו , ונזכה להתקרב אל האמת להיות דבוק בתורה ומצות ומע"ט , והקב"ה יחיש לגאלינו וירומם קרן התוה"ק וקרן עמו ישראל ונזכה לישועה שלימה מתוך נחת ושמחה ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And as the Midrash says, all of this is through the power of Jacob, meaning that it is by his strength that Israel stood firm in the trial in Egypt and strengthened their faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, through the power of Jacob who bequeathed this influential strength to future generations, so that they would be strong in their faith and in their knowledge of the Blessed One. Likewise, we need to strengthen ourselves with that same power and with the strength of the holy righteous ones who came before us. And by their light, we will travel and go, and through them, they will also influence us, and by their merit, we will strengthen ourselves in our trust in the Blessed One. May the Creator help us that we merit in these days, the days of Shovavim, to place upon our hearts to sanctify and purify ourselves to guard our thoughts, words, and deeds, and to walk in the path of truth, to cleave to the Holy One, blessed be He, and to His holy Torah. And may the Blessed One bestow upon us a spirit of purity from on high to draw closer to holiness, and may the wicked waters and the tribulations of time not sweep us away, Heaven forbid. And the Holy One, blessed be He, sees and observes the pain and suffering of Israel in every detail, both in physical and spiritual matters, for truly the heart of a person is pained when he wishes to cleave to holiness and to repent, but the darkness of the situation and the events are against him. Therefore, the Blessed One desires his justification, and may we merit to draw closer to the truth, to be attached to the Torah and commandments and good deeds. And may the Holy One, blessed be He, hasten to redeem us and uplift the horn of the holy Torah and the horn of His people Israel, and may we merit complete salvation with tranquility and joy, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the enduring spiritual strength imparted by Jacob to the Jewish people, enabling them to withstand trials and maintain faith in God, particularly during their time in Egypt. It calls for individuals to draw upon this strength and the merit of previous righteous leaders to enhance their own faith and commitment to God and His Torah. The text highlights the importance of self-purification and adherence to divine commandments, while expressing a deep yearning for redemption and divine assistance in overcoming spiritual and physical challenges. Ultimately, it conveys a hopeful vision of achieving closeness to holiness and experiencing a complete redemption filled with joy and divine revelation.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש והדקדוקים הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה (בפרשה זו) לפרש אמרם ז"ל בזכות ד' דברים נגאלו אבותינו ממצרים, וא' מהם שלא שינו את שמם, עפי"מ שכתב הר"מ אלשיך ז"ל עה"פ וכל אשר יקרא לו האדם נפש חי' הוא שמו,. כלומר מהיכן ידע מה שמו, אלא שראה מקום מקור חיותו למעלה בכ"ב אותיות התורה שבהן נברא העולם, וזה שמו אשר קרא לו, וז"ש נפש חי' הוא שמו דייקא (עכ"ד האלשיך זלה"ה ) ואיתא בספרים כל איש שם הקודש שלו הוא מקור חיותו, וזה לעומת זה בסט"א חלילה יש לו שם להיפך, וצריך כל אדם לתקן עצמו כפי שורש חיותו היינו שמו דקדושה , וז"ש שלא שינו את שמם, ר"ל שתיקנו עצמם כפי שמם דקדושה , שזה הוא שורש נשמתם, ולא שינו ח"ו לשם דסט"א , דאם אינו מתקן עצמו כפי השם דקדושה הוי שינוי השם, כי איננו כפי מה ששמו מורה על מהותו ואיכותו וכו' עכלה"ק ק"ז זלה"ה .
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the Midrash and the aforementioned grammatical points, by prefacing the words of K.Z. HaYitav Lev, may his merit protect us (in this section), to explain what our Sages, of blessed memory, said: "In the merit of four things our ancestors were redeemed from Egypt," and one of them is that they did not change their names. According to what the Ram"m Alshich, of blessed memory, wrote on the verse "And whatever the man calls it, that is its name," meaning from where did he know what its name was, except that he saw the source of its vitality above in the twenty-two letters of the Torah through which the world was created, and that is the name which he called it. This is what is meant by "the living soul is its name" precisely (thus said the Alshich, of blessed memory). And it is stated in the books that every person’s holy name is the source of their vitality, and this is in contrast to the other side, Heaven forbid, which has a name to the contrary. Every person needs to rectify themselves according to the root of their vitality, which is their holy name. This is what is meant by "they did not change their names," meaning they rectified themselves according to their holy name, which is the root of their soul, and they did not change, Heaven forbid, to the name of the other side. For if one does not rectify themselves according to the holy name, it is considered a change of name, because it is not in accordance with what their name indicates about their essence and quality, etc. Thus concludes K.Z. may his merit protect us.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of names in relation to one's spiritual essence, emphasizing that the names of individuals reflect their divine source and vitality, as derived from the twenty-two letters of the Torah. It highlights that the ancestors of the Jewish people were redeemed from Egypt in part because they did not change their names, which signifies their adherence to their holy identity. The text warns that altering one's name or failing to align with its sanctity represents a deviation from one's true spiritual essence. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of self-correction and maintaining one's connection to the divine through the sanctity of one's name.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר התכת הכתוב וטעם שינוי הלשונות, ואלה שמות בני ישראל "הבאים" מצרימה בלשון הוה , לפי שאחר הסתלקות יוסף הצדיק התגברו המצריים לעומתם בכח טומאתם, ונדמה להם כאילו אותו היום באו למצרים כאמרם ז"ל במד"ר , משא"כ כ"ז שיוסף הצדיק קיים לא יכלו המצריים להרים ראש נגד גאון קדושתו, וזהו טעם הכתוב שחזר לומר ואלה שמות בני ישראל, אע"פ שכבר נמנו בשמותם לעיל, אמנם כוונת הכתוב להורות על בחי' הנ"ל, שאף אחר ההתגברות הנורא מצד כוחות הטומאה שהתגברו לעומתם אחר הסתלקות יוסף הצדיק, מ"מ לא שינו את שמם המקושר בשורש הקדושה, ולא נשתנה ע"י גרמת החטא לשם דסט"א ר"ל, וז"א את יעקב איש וביתו באו שנתקיימו בבחי ' שהיו כאשר את יעקב איש וביתו באו בעבר ולא נשתנה בחי' שמותם, וז"ש במדרש ואלה מוסיף שבח על הראשונים, אף שהם בעצמם אותם שנזכרו לעיל ( בפ ' ויגש ) בעת ירידתן למצרים, עכ"ז יש להם תוספת שבח בהזכרתן כאן במאמר הבאים מצרימה, כי אף אחר התגברות כוחות הטומאה עליהם נשארו בקדושתן, ואלה הם שמות בני ישראל כאשר באו עם יעקב אבינו, וכמ"ש רז"ל במד"ר ראובן ושמעון נחתין ראובן ושמעון סלקין.
translation: And this will clarify the writing and the reason for the change in the languages, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt" in the present tense, because after the passing of Joseph the righteous, the Egyptians strengthened themselves against them with the power of their impurity, and it seemed to them as if they had come to Egypt on that very day, as our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash. However, as long as Joseph the righteous was alive, the Egyptians could not raise their heads against the glory of his holiness. This is the reason the text returns to say, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," even though they were already counted by their names above. Nevertheless, the intention of the text is to indicate the aforementioned aspect, that even after the terrible strengthening of the forces of impurity that rose against them after the passing of Joseph the righteous, nonetheless, they did not change their names, which are connected to the root of holiness, nor were they altered by the cause of sin to the name of the other side, may it be said. And it says, "Jacob and his household came," which indicates that they were sustained in the aspect of being as when Jacob and his household came in the past, and their names were not changed. And this is what is said in the Midrash, "And these" adds praise to the earlier ones, even though they themselves are the same ones mentioned above (in Parashat Vayigash) at the time of their descent to Egypt, nevertheless, they have an added praise in their mention here in the phrase "who came to Egypt," for even after the strengthening of the forces of impurity against them, they remained in their holiness. And these are the names of the children of Israel as they came with our forefather Jacob, as our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash, "Reuben and Simeon descended, Reuben and Simeon ascended."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," emphasizing that despite the rise of impurity and the challenges faced after Joseph's departure, the Israelites retained their holy identity and names. It highlights that their connection to holiness remained intact, illustrating that even in the face of adversity, their essence was not altered by sin. The text underscores the enduring sanctity of the Israelites, affirming that they came to Egypt as they were, rooted in their divine lineage. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the resilience of spiritual identity amidst external challenges.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש הנ"ל ואלה שמות הוסיף שבח על ע' נפש וכו ', בהקדם דברי האוהחה"ק עה"פ הבאים מצרימה וז"ל בא לומר מופת חותך כי ברצונם באו (לקבל גזירת מלך לסבול עול הגלות), והראי' שאחר מות אביהם ועלו ארצה כנען, חזרו פעם ב' כאמור בפ ' ויחי, והוא אומרו הבאים מצרימה וכו' אחר שעלו משם חזרו למצרים עכ"ד, ולכאורה דבה"ק צ"ב דמהו רבותי' דביאה שני' טפי מביאה הראשונה, ומדוע צריך הכתוב בשביל הודעה זו לכפול לשונו ולומר הבאים וחזר אומר באו, אמנם חילוק גדול ביניהם דבביאתם הראשונה היו סמוכים לקדושתו הרם של יעקב אבינו, ואין רבותא שהי' רצונם להשלים רצון הבוי"ת בגזירת הגלות, וע"ד שפי' במפרשים מ"ד בגמ' (ברכות ל"ג ע"ב) אטו יראה מילתא זוטרתא הוא, ותירצו אין לגבי משה מילתא זוטרתא היא, ולכאורה עדיין קושית הגמ ' במקומה עומדת, דהרי פסוק זה ועתה ישראל מה ד' אלקיך שואל ממך כי אם ליראה אמרה משה לכל ישראל, ועדיין קשה דלגביהם יראה לאו מילתא זוטרתא היא, ופירשו דהכוונה אין לגבי משה, ר"ל כל ישראל באותו הדור שהיו דבוקים וסמוכים לגבי קדושתו של משרע"ה : יראה אצלם מילתא זוטרתא היא, ועד"ז יתבאר לעניננו ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה את יעקב, זו ביאה ראשונה שבאו ברצונם לקבל ע"ע גזירת הגלות, אמנם הי' את יעקב ואין בזה רבותא כ"כ, וחזר לומר באו, שאחר שעלו משם לקבור את יעקב חזרו ובאו לסבול עול גלות, וז"פ המדרש ואלה שמות הוסיף שבח על ע' נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם היו צדיקים, ואף שהם הם האמורים למעלה: אמנם עכשיו הוסיף הכתוב בשבחם, שתחלת ביאתם הי' את יעקב ובחי' היראה לגבי' מילתא זוטרתא, ורמז הכתוב שאף אחר הסתלקות יע"א חזרו ברצון עצמם לקבל על עצמם גזירת הגלות, והיא אומרו איש וביתו באו, ובזה הוסיף שבח על ע' נפש שנאמרו למעלה לגלות צדקתם שקיבלו גזירת הגלות ברצון נפשם, ובכל דור ודור עומדים עלינו לכלותינו וכח זה עמדה לנו מה שמקבלים ע"ע לסבול גזירת הגלות, והשי"ת ישפיע בלבות בנ"י כח קדושה וטהרה וכח האמונה בשלימות, ונזכה במהרה לקבל פני משיח צדקנו באנפין נהירין , ונזכה במהרה לגאולה וישועה ואמיתית בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation:
In another way, one can say the words of the aforementioned Midrash and these are the names, which adds praise for the seventy souls, etc. This is preceded by the words of the holy Baal Shem Tov on the verse "the coming to Egypt," and it is said to indicate a decisive proof that they came willingly (to accept the decree of the king to bear the yoke of exile), and the proof is that after the death of their father, they ascended to the land of Canaan, and they returned a second time as mentioned in Parashat Vayechi. This is the meaning of "the coming to Egypt," etc., after they ascended from there, they returned to Egypt. 

However, it is puzzling regarding the holy Baal Shem Tov, what is the significance of their second coming more than the first coming, and why does the text need to repeat its language to say "the coming" and "returned" to say "came"? However, there is a great distinction between them: in their first coming, they were close to the exalted holiness of our forefather Jacob, and there is no wonder that they desired to fulfill the will of the Blessed One in the decree of exile, as explained by the commentators in the Gemara (Berakhot 33b) regarding the statement, "Is fear a small matter?" and they answered that it is not a small matter regarding Moses. 

However, the question of the Gemara still stands, for this verse "And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God ask of you but to fear" was said by Moses to all Israel, and it is still difficult that for them, fear is not a small matter. They explained that the intention is not regarding Moses, meaning all Israel in that generation who were attached and close to the holiness of Moshe Rabbeinu: fear is a small matter for them. 

In a similar manner, it can be explained regarding our matter, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob," this is the first coming when they came willingly to accept upon themselves the decree of exile. However, they were with Jacob, and there is not so much wonder in this. And it returned to say "came," that after they ascended from there to bury Jacob, they returned and came to bear the yoke of exile. This is the meaning of the Midrash, "And these are the names," which adds praise for the seventy souls mentioned above, that they were all righteous, and even though they are the ones mentioned above: now the text adds praise for them, that at the beginning of their coming, they were with Jacob, and in the aspect of fear regarding him, it is a small matter. 

The text hints that even after the passing of Jacob, may he rest in peace, they returned willingly to accept upon themselves the decree of exile, and this is indicated by the phrase "each man and his household came." In this, it adds praise for the seventy souls mentioned above to reveal their righteousness that they accepted the decree of exile willingly. And in every generation, they rise up against us to destroy us, and this strength stands for us in that we accept upon ourselves to bear the decree of exile. May the Holy One, blessed be He, inspire in the hearts of the children of Israel a spirit of holiness and purity and a complete faith, and may we merit soon to receive the face of our righteous Messiah with shining faces, and may we soon merit redemption and true salvation with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' return to Egypt, emphasizing their voluntary acceptance of the exile as a fulfillment of divine will. It highlights the distinction between their initial arrival, which was under the influence of Jacob's holiness, and their subsequent return after his burial, showcasing their commitment to endure suffering for the sake of God's decree. The text underscores the righteousness of the seventy souls who entered Egypt, affirming their willingness to accept the burden of exile with faith and devotion. Ultimately, it expresses a hope for divine assistance and the imminent redemption through the coming of the Messiah.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש הנ"ל, בהקדם להעיר במאמה"כ ויהי כל נפש יוצאי ירך יעקב וגו', ראוי להבין מה משמיענו הכתוב באומרו יוצאי ירך יעקב וידוע הוא ויספיק לומר כל הנפש לבית יעקב הבאים מצרימה שבעים, כמו שהזכיר בפ ' ויגש , או כל זרעו הבאים מצרימה שבעים נפש, ובודאי יש בזה עוד כוונה נוספת מלבד הפשוטו .
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the aforementioned Midrash, prefacing to comment on the verse, "And all the souls that came out of the thigh of Jacob," etc. It is fitting to understand what the verse is conveying by saying "the souls that came out of the thigh of Jacob." It is known that it would suffice to say "all the souls of the house of Jacob that came to Egypt, seventy," as mentioned in Parashat Vayigash, or "all his seed that came to Egypt, seventy souls." Certainly, there is an additional intention in this beyond its simple meaning.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "yotzei yerek Yaakov" (those who came from the loins of Jacob) in the context of the biblical account of Jacob's descendants entering Egypt. It suggests that this expression carries deeper meaning beyond simply stating the number of Jacob's family members. The author implies that the emphasis on "yotzei yerek" highlights the spiritual lineage and connection to Jacob, reflecting a Hasidic understanding of the importance of heritage and the divine purpose behind their journey. This insight invites contemplation on the spiritual implications of identity and continuity within the Jewish tradition.

passage_content: ב) מלך חדש על מצרים אשר לא ידע את יוסף, ובתרגום אונקלוס פי' דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף, וצ"ב דאינו מבואר ענין גזירה זו מהו.
translation: A) A new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph, and in the translation of Onkelos it is explained that he did not uphold the decree of Joseph, and it is to be wondered why the nature of this decree is not clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the emergence of a new king in Egypt who did not recognize Joseph, interpreted by Onkelos as one who did not uphold Joseph's decree. This raises a question about the nature of this decree and its implications. The Hasidic perspective emphasizes the importance of recognizing and honoring the contributions of righteous individuals, suggesting that forgetting their legacy can lead to spiritual and moral decline. The theological insight highlights the interconnectedness of leadership, memory, and the continuity of divine purpose in the world.

passage_content: ג) תנחומא אשר לא ידע את יוסף. וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף וכו ', א"ר אבין משל לאחד שרגם אקונין של דוכוס , אמר התיזו את ראשו עכשיו שלמחר עושה בי כך. וכך פרעה עכשיו לא ידע את יוסף למחר הוא אומר לא ידעתי את ה' עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דעדיין קושית המדרש במקומה עומדת, וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, גם מה שסיימו למחר הוא אומר לא ידעתי את ה', איך יתכן להשוות עניניהם וצ"ב כוונת המשל.
translation: 3) The Tanchuma states that he did not know Joseph. And was he not familiar with Joseph, etc.? Rabbi Avin said: It is like a certain person who killed the duke's servant; he said, "Cut off his head now, for tomorrow he will do this to me." And so Pharaoh, at this moment, did not know Joseph; tomorrow he will say, "I did not know the Lord." Thus concludes the Midrash. However, the question of the Midrash still stands: How could he not know Joseph? Also, what they concluded, that tomorrow he will say, "I did not know the Lord," how can their matters be compared? And the intention of the parable is also in question.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of forgetting and recognition, using the example of Pharaoh not knowing Joseph. It compares Pharaoh's ignorance of Joseph to a ruler who dismisses a servant, suggesting that such forgetfulness can lead to dire consequences. The underlying theological insight emphasizes the importance of remembering one's past and the divine, as forgetting God leads to a disconnection from spiritual truth. The midrash highlights the cyclical nature of recognition and oblivion, urging a deeper understanding of one's relationship with God and history.

passage_content: ד) מארי זלה"ה בקדושת יו"ט הביא מדרש וזה תוארו הבה נתחכמה לו פן ירבה שרצה לבטל את השבת, ראוי להבין מ"ט רצה לבעל את השבת דייקא , ואיך נרמז ענין זה במשמעות הכתוב.
translation: 4) Our master, may his memory be a blessing, in the sanctity of the festival brought a Midrash, and this is its interpretation: "Let us be wise against him, lest he increase," referring to the desire to annul the Sabbath. It is fitting to understand why he specifically wanted to "marry" the Sabbath, and how this matter is hinted at in the meaning of the verse.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the Sabbath and the potential threat to its sanctity. The text highlights the need to understand the deeper reasons behind the desire to undermine the Sabbath, suggesting that this reflects a broader spiritual struggle. The reference to the Midrash emphasizes the importance of wisdom and discernment in recognizing and countering such challenges to holiness. Ultimately, the passage invites reflection on the profound relationship between time, sanctity, and divine intention.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה ירך רומז על מצות מילה וקדושת היסוד, כמ"ש בתרגום יוב"ע (פ' חיי) עה"פ שים נא ידך תחת ירכי, שוו כדון ידך בגזירת מהולתי , גם מצינו שכינה הכתוב לגיד הנשה בשם ירך סתם כמ"ש בפ ' וישלח ויגע בכף יריכו . ואפשר להסביר קישור ענינם עפימ"ד בזוה"ק (פ' וישלח ק"ע ע"ב) כי שס"ה מלאכים ממונים על שס"ה ל"ת, ועל גיד הנשה ממונה הס"ס, ואמאי איקרי גיד הנשה דאיהו מנשה לבני נשא לפולחנא דמאריהון , ותמן הוא יצר הרע רביע, ויגע בכף יריכו דאיהו זיני' ואתרי', ומתמן אתי יצר הרע על בני נשא עכ"ד הזוה"ק , ולפי ששם משכנו ואתרי' של הס"מ, ע"כ מתגבר מאוד להכשיל ח"ו בפגם הברית באבר הסמוך לו, ואמרו רז"ל בזוה"ק דהפוגם בריתו שריא הס"ס על האי ברית ר"ל, וע"כ נרמז הברית ג"כ בשם ירך להיותו סמוך אליו דאיהו אתרי', ומשם הוא לוחם ומתגבר על האדם להכשילו ח"ו וצריך התגברות גדול ומסנ"פ וסייעתא דשמיא להנצל ממנו.
translation: And it is known that the thigh alludes to the commandment of circumcision and the sanctity of the foundation, as stated in the Targum Yonatan (Parashat Chayei) on the verse "Please place your hand under my thigh," which is equivalent to saying "your hand in the decree of my circumcision." We also find that the Shechinah is referred to as the sinew of the thigh, as stated in Parashat Vayishlach, "And he touched the hollow of his thigh." It is possible to explain the connection of their matter according to the Midrash in the Zohar (Parashat Vayishlach, 190b) that there are 365 angels appointed over the 365 prohibitions, and over the sinew of the thigh is appointed the evil inclination. And why is it called the sinew of the thigh? Because it is a source for the children of man to serve their Master. And there, it is the evil inclination that is the fourth, and he touched the hollow of his thigh, which is the sustenance and the place, and from there the evil inclination comes upon the children of man, thus said the Zohar. And since there is the dwelling place and the place of the evil inclination, therefore he becomes very strong to cause a person to stumble, God forbid, in the blemish of the covenant in the organ that is close to him. And our sages, of blessed memory, said in the Zohar that one who blemishes his covenant, the evil inclination rests upon this covenant, God forbid. Therefore, the covenant is also hinted at by the name thigh, being that it is close to it, which is the place, and from there he fights and strengthens himself against a person to cause him to stumble, God forbid, and one needs great strength and assistance from Heaven to be saved from him.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the concept of the "thigh" and the mitzvah of circumcision, emphasizing its sanctity and the spiritual significance of the "girdle of the thigh" as a representation of divine presence. It references the Zohar, explaining that the "girdle of the thigh" is associated with the evil inclination, which seeks to lead individuals astray, particularly in matters of sexual purity. The text highlights the need for significant spiritual strength and divine assistance to overcome these challenges, as the evil inclination is closely linked to the sanctity of the covenant. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of vigilance and spiritual fortitude in maintaining one's commitment to holiness.

passage_content: והנה אמרו רז"ל בגמ' ב"ב (דף י"ז ע"א) ג' לא שלט בהם היצה"ר אלו הן אברהם יצחק ויעקב דכתיב בהו בכל מכל כל, וכתבו התוס ' אין לפרש שלא שלט כלל דא"כ היכי קבלו עלי' אגרא, אלא כדאמר (יומא ל"ח ע"ב) מ"ד רגלי חסידיו ישמור כיון שעבר אדם רוב שנותיו ולא חטא שוב אינו חוטא, הכא נמי כיון שראה הקב"ה שהיו דוחקין עצמן כ"כ להתרחק מן העבירה, סייעם הקב"ה מכאן ואילך שלא שלט בהם היצה"ר עכ"ל התוס '. ובספה"ק באר מים חיים פי' שלא שלטה בהם היצה"ר , פי' שברו והכניעו וכתתו כל כוחי מורשי תאוות לבבם וגופם במסירת נפש לה' תמיד וכו ', והגוף אצלם בבחי ' הנשמה כי הפכו אותו לרוחניות ממש עכ"ל, ובזה יתבאר דברי אאע"ה לאליעזר בעת ששלחו לבקש זויגו של יצחק אמר לו שים נא ידך תחת ירכי, רמז לו שמלחמה כבידה מוכן לנגדו מצד הס"מ שיתגבר מאוד למנוע השתלשלות אומה הישראלית, וע"כ יאחז דרכו ויתדבק במידתו לכפות יצרו ולהכניעו, כמו שעשה הוא בבחי ' הירך. כי גרש גרשהו להס"מ משם ועשאו משכן לסטרא דקדושה , וכמ"ש ז"ל בזוה"ק דמאן דנטיר ברית שריא עלי' שם שד"י , ומאמר תחת ירכי ירמוז על כפיית הרצון וכפיית היצה"ר השוכן במקום הירך, וע"ד שדרשו רז"ל (שבת פ"ח ע"א) ויתיצבו בתחתית ההר א"ר אבדימי ב"ח בר חסא מלמד שכפה הקב"ה עליהם הר כגיגית וכו ', והקשו התוס ' למה הי' צורך לכפי' וכבר הקדימו נעשה לנשמע עיי"ש, ובמפורשים. תירצו כי הן אמנם לפי מדריגתם הגדולה במעמד הנבחר קבלו עליהם לשמור ולעשות כל התורה ומצוותי' ברצון נפשם. אבל הבוי"ת מגיד מראשית אחרית שיהי' זמן שיחלש בחי' הרצון הזה, ויצטרכו ישראל לכפיית הרצון וכפיית היצה"ר בענין שמירת התומ"צ , וע"כ כפה עליהם הר כגיגית, ומאז קבלו ישראל הכח הזה ושמורה להם לנצח, שיהיו מוכנים ועומדים למלחמה זו, לקבל עליהם התומ"צ בכפי' אם יצטרכו לזה, ועד"ז ירמוז תחת ירכי על כפיית היצר השוכן במקום הירך.
translation:
And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in the Gemara Bava Batra (17a) that the evil inclination did not have dominion over three individuals: these are Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, as it is written about them "in all, from all, and everything." The Tosafot wrote, "It should not be interpreted that it did not have any control at all, for if so, how could they have received reward? Rather, as it is said (Yoma 38b), 'He who guards the feet of His pious ones'—once a person has passed the majority of their years without sinning, they will not sin again. Here too, since the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that they were striving so hard to distance themselves from sin, He assisted them from that point onward so that the evil inclination did not have dominion over them." Thus far are the words of the Tosafot. 

And in the holy book "Be'er Mayim Chaim," it is explained that the evil inclination did not have dominion over them, meaning that they broke and subdued it and crushed all the powers of their heart's desires and their bodies with self-sacrifice for the Lord always, etc. The body for them was in the aspect of the soul, for they transformed it into true spirituality. Thus, the words of our father Abraham to Eliezer when he sent him to seek a wife for Isaac are clarified: he said to him, "Put your hand under my thigh," hinting to him that a heavy battle was prepared against him from the side of the evil inclination, which would greatly strive to prevent the continuation of the Jewish nation. Therefore, he should hold fast to his path and cling to his character to subdue his inclination and bring it low, as he did in the aspect of the thigh. For he cast out the evil inclination from there and made it a dwelling place for the side of holiness, as our Sages of blessed memory said in the Zohar that "whoever guards the covenant, the name Shaddai rests upon him." 

And the phrase "under my thigh" hints at the subjugation of the will and the subjugation of the evil inclination that dwells in the place of the thigh. And according to what our Sages of blessed memory expounded (Shabbat 88a), "And they stood at the foot of the mountain," Rabbi Abdimy bar Chasa teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, forced the mountain upon them like a tub, etc. The Tosafot asked, "What was the need to force them, since they had already preceded with 'We will do and we will hear'?" They answered that indeed, according to their great level in the chosen assembly, they accepted upon themselves to keep and do all the Torah and its commandments willingly. But the Holy One, blessed be He, foretold from the beginning of the end that there would be a time when this aspect of will would weaken, and the Jewish people would need to force their will and the evil inclination regarding the observance of the Torah and commandments. Therefore, He forced the mountain upon them like a tub, and since then, the Jewish people received this strength, which is preserved for them forever, to be prepared and standing for this battle, to accept upon themselves the Torah and commandments with force if they need to do so. And similarly, "under my thigh" hints at the subjugation of the inclination that dwells in the place of the thigh.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob were not dominated by the evil inclination (yetzer hara) due to their intense efforts to distance themselves from sin, which led God to assist them in overcoming these temptations. It emphasizes the idea that their physical bodies were transformed into a spiritual essence through their devotion to God. The text also highlights the importance of actively suppressing one's desires, as illustrated by Abraham's instruction to Eliezer to place his hand under his thigh, symbolizing the struggle against the yetzer hara. Furthermore, it reflects on the necessity of coercing one's will to uphold the Torah and commandments, as demonstrated by God's imposition of the mountain upon the Israelites, ensuring they would be prepared for future challenges in their commitment to divine law.

passage_content: ועד"ז צוה יע"א ליוסף שים נא ידך תחת ירכי רמז לו ג"כ על מלחמה עם הס"ס, עפימ"ד בילקוט ראובני (פ' חיי) שקיום אומה הישראלית תלוי בזה שיע"א יהי' נקבר במערת המכפלה דייקא , שכל הנשמות אחר שנפטרין מעולם הזה עוברין דרך שם לגן עדן, ואלמלא הי' יעקב קבור שם. לא הי' יכול שום אחד מישראל לעבור דרך שם, ופי' בזה מה שאמרז"ל לבן ביקש לעקור את הכל , שרצה בכח כשפיו להעתיק את אהל יעקב שלא יזכה למערת המכפלה, וכן הס"מ נלחם עם יעקב ורצה לעשותו בעל מום שלא יזכה להקבר במערת המכפלה עיי"ש, ולזה צוה יעקב אבינו ליוסף שיתגבר וילחם לעומתו ולז"א שים נא ידך תחת ירכי, ירמוז על כפיית והכנעת הס"מ השוכן במקום הירך, ויאחוז ויתדבק במעשהו כמו שפעל הוא בהכנעת יצרו וכנ"ל.
translation: And similarly, the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded Joseph, "Please place your hand under my thigh," hinting to him also about the battle with the Sitra Achra. As it is explained in the Yalkut Reuven (Parashat Chayei), the existence of the Jewish nation depends on the fact that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will be buried specifically in the Cave of Machpelah, for all souls, after they depart from this world, pass through there to Gan Eden. And if Jacob had not been buried there, no one from Israel would have been able to pass through there. This explains what our Sages said, that Laban sought to uproot everything, as he wanted with all his might to move the tent of Jacob so that he would not merit the Cave of Machpelah. Likewise, the Sitra Achra fought with Jacob and wanted to make him a blemished one so that he would not merit to be buried in the Cave of Machpelah, as explained there. Therefore, Jacob our father commanded Joseph to strengthen himself and fight against him, and thus he said, "Please place your hand under my thigh," hinting at the subjugation and overcoming of the Sitra Achra that dwells in the place of the thigh, and he should hold on and cling to his actions just as he acted in subduing his own evil inclination, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's burial in the Cave of Machpelah, emphasizing that the continuity of the Jewish people is linked to this location. It highlights the spiritual battle against the forces of evil, represented by Esau and the Satan, who sought to prevent Jacob's burial there. Jacob instructs Joseph to strengthen himself and fight against these adversarial forces, symbolized by placing his hand under Jacob's thigh, which represents the struggle against temptation and the Yetzir Hara (evil inclination). This act signifies the importance of overcoming spiritual challenges to ensure the passage of souls to the World to Come.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר במאמה"כ ויהי כל נפש יוצאי ירך יעקב שבעים נפש להורות בא שאף אחר שירדו למצרים מקום המזוהם מכל הארצות, מ"מ נתקיימו כולם נוטרי הברית בשלימות, עד שהיו ראויים להקרא יוצאי ירך יעקב. וז"פ דברי המדרש הנ"ל ואלה שמות הוסיף שבח על השבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה, אף שהם הם אותם אשר נזכרו למעלה, אולם השמיענו הכתוב דאחר שירדו למצרים ואחר הסתלקות יע"א ויוסף הצדיק, אעפ"כ נשארו בקדושתם בבחי ' יוצאי ירך יעקב, ע"כ אמר הכתוב ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה מוסיף על הראשונים שתוס ' שבח הוא להם שכולם היו צדיקים ונוטרי הברית אף אחר שירדו למצרים והנה יוסף הצדיק רצה להכין מקום לישראל במצרים שיתקיימו בקדושתם ויגדרו עצמם מן העריות, ולטעם זה השפיע גם על המצרים קצת בחי' הקדושה, שלא יהיו משוקעים כ"כ בתאוות העריות כמקדם, ולכך צוה להם שימולו וע"ד שכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל בטעם מצות מילה שהוא להחליש כח תאוות עריות, אמנם אחר שמת יוסף הצדיק קם מלך חדש על מצרים וביטל גזירתו של יוסף, וז"ש ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים אשר לא ידע את יוסף, פי' בת"א דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף, ר"ל גזירת מהולתא , וכוונתו הי' להוסיף טומאה על טומאתם ולהרבות זימה בארץ, ובזה רצה להשפיע גם על ישראל לעשות אותם רעים וחטאים. ובכל שיוסיפו לחטוא יוכל יותר למשול עליהם ולעשות בהם כרצונו. דבאמת שעבוד הקשה הגיע להם רק בסיבת החטאים, דאע"פ שהי' גזירה קדומה על שעבוד הגלות, אבל לא שעבוד קשה כ"כ, כמבואר במד"ר פ' זו (פ"א סי' י') כשמת יוסף הפרו ברית מילה אמרו נהי' כמצריים, וכיון שעשו כן הפך הקב"ה האהבה שהיו המצרים אוהבין אותם לשנאה, שנאמר הפך לבם לשנוא עמו להתנכל בעבדיו
translation: And according to our path, it will be clarified in the Holy Scriptures that all the souls that came from the thigh of Jacob were seventy souls, to teach that even after they descended to Egypt, the most defiled place of all the lands, nevertheless, they all remained as guardians of the covenant in completeness, to the extent that they were worthy of being called the descendants of Jacob. Thus, the words of the aforementioned Midrash and these are the names add praise to the seventy souls mentioned above, even though they are the same ones mentioned earlier. However, the scripture informs us that after they descended to Egypt and after the passing of our father Jacob and Joseph the righteous, nevertheless, they remained in their holiness in the aspect of "the descendants of Jacob." Therefore, the scripture states, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," adding to the first ones that it is a praise for them that they were all righteous and guardians of the covenant even after they descended to Egypt. And behold, Joseph the righteous wanted to prepare a place for Israel in Egypt so that they would maintain their holiness and separate themselves from immorality. For this reason, he also influenced the Egyptians somewhat with a degree of holiness, so that they would not be so immersed in the desires of immorality as before. And for this, he commanded them to circumcise, and as the Rambam wrote regarding the reason for the commandment of circumcision, which is to weaken the power of the desires for immorality. However, after Joseph the righteous died, a new king arose over Egypt who did not uphold Joseph's decree, meaning the decree of circumcision, and his intention was to add impurity to their impurity and to increase promiscuity in the land, and in this, he wanted to influence Israel to make them wicked and sinful. And in all that they would increase in sin, he would be able to rule over them more and do with them as he wished. For indeed, the harsh servitude came upon them only because of their sins, for although there was an ancient decree regarding the servitude of exile, it was not such a harsh servitude, as explained in the Midrash of this portion (1:10) that when Joseph died, they violated the covenant of circumcision and said, "We will be like the Egyptians." And since they did so, the Holy One, blessed be He, turned the love that the Egyptians had for them into hatred, as it is said, "He turned their heart to hate His people, to deal craftily with His servants."
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual integrity of the seventy souls descended from Jacob, who maintained their covenantal purity even after entering the morally corrupt land of Egypt. It highlights that despite the challenges posed by the new Egyptian king who sought to increase immorality, the legacy of Joseph's righteousness initially provided a protective influence. However, following Joseph's death, the Israelites' own sins led to a harsher enslavement, illustrating the connection between moral behavior and divine favor. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the importance of maintaining holiness and the consequences of straying from the covenant.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר ענין המשל שבמדרש (הנ"ל קושיא ג') עפימ"ש ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה ( בפ ' וישב) לפרש אמרם ז"ל דיוקנו של אביו נראית לו ופירש, שהי' זיו איקונין שלו דומה לשל יעקב, על שהי' שומר הברית וגוף וברית כחדא חשבינן וכו ', ושפט בדעתו שאם יחטא יאבד צורתו ודמותו הדומה לאביו, וזהו רמז אמרם דיוקנו של אביו נראית לו ופירש עיי"ש, ובפ ' ויחי פי' בזה ראה פניך לא פללתי , כי חששתי אולי נשתנה מכח איזה חטא חלילה, והנה הראה אותי אלקים , היינו את עצמי דמותי וצלמי גם את זרעך, שגם להם דמות דיוקנו של יוסף הדומה ליעקב עכת"ד ז"ל, ובזה יובן דמיון המשל לא' שרגם איקונין של דוכוס , כך פרעה ע"י שהחטיא את ישראל במדת היסוד, איבד וקלקל מהם צורתו של יוסף והאבוה"ק , וזהו רמז המשל שרגם איקונין של מלך, וז"ש אשר לא ידע את יוסף ר"ל שעשה פעולות שלא יוודע ולא יוכר בחי' יוסף שלימות מידתו וצורתו, ול"ק עוד קושית המדרש וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, דלפי דרכנו הכוונה על ידיעה פנימית במדתו של יוסף וזה לא ידע ועוד גרם בפעולותיו שלא יוודע גם לאחרים, וסיום המאמר למחר עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ה', שהפוגם במידה זו גורם ח"ו קלקול באמונה כמ"ש הה"ק ר' אלימלך זלה"ה שנסמית עינו של אדם מלראות דרך האמת, וכך דרכו של יצה"ר היום אומר לו עשה כך וכו' עד שאומר לו לך ועבוד ע"ז.
translation: And this will clarify the matter of the parable in the Midrash (the aforementioned question 3) according to what is said in K.Z. (in Parashat Vayeshev) to explain their words, that the likeness of his father was seen by him, and he explained that the radiance of his icon was similar to that of Jacob, because he was a guardian of the covenant, and body and covenant are considered as one, etc. He judged in his mind that if he were to sin, he would lose his form and likeness that resembled his father. This is hinted at in their saying that the likeness of his father was seen by him, and he explained there. And in Parashat Vayechi, he explained this: "I did not pray to see your face," for I was concerned that perhaps I had changed due to some sin, Heaven forbid. And behold, God showed me, meaning my own self, my form and image, and also your offspring, who also have the likeness of the icon of Joseph that resembles Jacob, as stated by them. And thus, the similarity of the parable is to one who has the icon of a duke. So Pharaoh, by causing Israel to sin in the attribute of foundation, lost and corrupted from them the form of Joseph and the holy father. This is the hint of the parable that he has the icon of the king. And this is what is meant by "who did not know Joseph," meaning that he acted in ways that would not allow the completeness of Joseph's measure and form to be known and recognized. And the Midrash's question is not difficult: how could he not recognize Joseph? According to our approach, the intention is an internal knowledge of Joseph's measure, and this he did not know, and furthermore, his actions caused that he would not be known even to others. And the conclusion of the statement is that tomorrow he will say, "I did not know the Lord," for one who damages this attribute causes, Heaven forbid, a corruption in faith, as stated by the holy Rabbi Elimelech, that a person's eye is blinded from seeing the path of truth. And thus is the way of the evil inclination: today it tells him to do this, etc., until it tells him, "Go and serve idols."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of maintaining one's spiritual and moral integrity, as exemplified by Joseph's resemblance to his father Jacob. It emphasizes that sin can lead to a loss of one's true identity and connection to the divine, as seen in Pharaoh's actions that obscured Joseph's true nature. The text warns that neglecting this awareness can result in a disconnection from faith, ultimately leading to a spiritual blindness that prevents one from recognizing the truth of God. The underlying message is the importance of upholding one's character and faith to preserve one's divine likeness.

passage_content: ויובן בזה דברי המדרש הנ"ל שרצו לבעל מהם השבת, דלפי שרצונם הי' להרבות חטאים בישראל ולעשותם רעים וחטאים, התחכמו להכשילם גם באיסור חילול שבת, עפימ"ש חז"ל (שבת קי"ח ע"ב) כל המשמר שבת כהלכתו אפילו עובד ע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו, ולפי"ז לא הועילו המצריים במעשיהם, שע"י שמירת שבת כהלכתו נמחל להם הכל , ע"כ רצו לבטל מהם גם את השבת, ונרמז כן בכתוב עפימ"ש התוס ' במס' פסחים (קי"ז ע"ב) אהא דאמרו שם בגמ' צריך להזכיר יציאת מצרים בקידוש היום, הטעם בזה בשם מהר"ם שיש במדרש לפי שבמצרים עבדו בהם בישראל בפרך, ופר"ך בא"ת ב"ש " וג"ל ' שהם מלאכות ארבעים חסר אחת. וכשנגאלו ממצרים הזהירם על השבת לשבות מאותן ל"ט מלאכות עכ"ל, ולכאורה יש להבין מדוע בחרו לעבוד בהם הל"ט מלאכות דייקא , ויש ביניהם מלאכות קלות שאין בהם טורח כלל, כגון להוציא ולהכניס מחט, וכדומה מלאכות שאין בהם טורח, רק שחז"ל למדו מהפסוקים שכך גזרה חכמתו ית ' שזה נקרא מלאכה בשבת ואסור, ולהיפך המפנה כלים ממקום למקום בבית, אפילו גדולים וכבדים מאוד ונתייגע בהם כל היום כולו לא עבר איסור דאורייתא, אלא שחכז"ל גזרו עלי' דמיחזי כעובדא דחול , ומה הי' כוונת פרעה לשעבד בהם בל"ע מלאכות דייקא .
translation: And this explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash regarding the desire of Pharaoh to burden them with the Sabbath, for since their intention was to increase sins among Israel and make them wicked and sinful, they cunningly sought to ensnare them also with the prohibition of desecrating the Sabbath, as our Sages have said (Shabbat 118b), "Anyone who observes the Sabbath properly, even if he worships idols like the generation of Enosh, he is forgiven." According to this, the Egyptians did not succeed in their actions, for through the proper observance of the Sabbath, everything was forgiven them. Therefore, they wanted to abolish the Sabbath from them, and this is hinted at in the verse, as mentioned by the Tosafot in Pesachim (117b) regarding the statement made there in the Gemara that one must mention the Exodus from Egypt in the Kiddush of the day. The reason for this, as stated in the name of the Maharam, is that in Egypt they worked the Israelites with hard labor, and "פרך" (Perek) in Atbash is "ג"ל" (Gimel Lamed), which are the forty labors minus one. And when they were redeemed from Egypt, they were warned about the Sabbath to cease from those thirty-nine labors. Now, it is necessary to understand why they specifically chose to work them with these thirty-nine labors, as there are among them lighter labors that do not involve any effort at all, such as taking out and putting in a needle, and similar labors that do not require toil. However, our Sages learned from the verses that this is how the wisdom of the Blessed One decreed that this is called labor on the Sabbath and is forbidden, while conversely, moving items from place to place in the house, even large and very heavy ones, and toiling with them all day long does not transgress a biblical prohibition, except that our Sages decreed upon it because it appears like a weekday activity. What, then, was Pharaoh's intention to enslave them specifically with these labors?
summary: The passage discusses the intent of the Egyptians to increase sin among the Israelites by compelling them to violate the Sabbath, as it is a means of atonement for their sins. It highlights the significance of observing the Sabbath, which can lead to forgiveness even for severe transgressions, such as idolatry. The text also reflects on the specific choice of the 39 prohibited labors, emphasizing that these were divinely ordained as a means to elevate the spiritual state of the Israelites and to distinguish between sacred and mundane activities. Ultimately, it underscores the theological concept that adherence to the Sabbath is a crucial element of Jewish identity and divine favor.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בספר המורה שכל מצות התורה הם הרחקה מע"ז, עפי"מ שמצא בספריהם שהאומות עשו לע"ז כל הדברים שצותה התוה"ק לנו שלא לעשות, והסבר הענין הוא כי כל מצוה ממצות התורה משפיעה קדושה על האדם המקיימה, וזה לעומת זה העושה להיפך ממצות התורה ממשיך על עצמו כח הטומאה ר"ל, ועוע"ז בדורות הקודמים היו חכמים להרע והשיגו כוחות הטומאה בשורשה, לכן עשו היפך מצות התורה כדי להמשיך על עצמן כוחות הטומאה, וע"כ פרעה שכל כוונתו הי' להרבות טומאה בישראל, שיעבד בהם בל"ט מלאכות דייקא היפך מצות התורה והתחכם לבעל מהם שמירת שבת כדי שלא יהי' נמחל חטאם ע"י שמירתו, וז"ש במדרש הנ"ל הבה נתחכמה לו שרצו לבטל השבת כנרמז במלת בפרך ל"ט מלאכות, ובחר במלאכות אלו דייקא , כדי לבטל מהם שמירת שבת שמשפעת קדושה על השומרם ומקיימם.
translation: And even though, according to the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in the Guide for the Perplexed, all the commandments of the Torah are a distancing from idolatry, as he found in their books that the nations did for idolatry all the things that the Holy Torah commanded us not to do, the explanation of the matter is that every commandment of the Torah imparts holiness to the person who fulfills it. Conversely, one who acts contrary to the commandments of the Torah draws upon himself the power of impurity, Heaven forbid. And in previous generations, the wise ones sought to do evil and attained the powers of impurity at their root; therefore, they acted contrary to the commandments of the Torah in order to draw upon themselves the powers of impurity. And thus, Pharaoh, whose entire intention was to increase impurity among Israel, enslaved them with thirty-nine labors, precisely the opposite of the commandments of the Torah, and he cunningly sought to prevent them from observing the Sabbath so that their sins would not be forgiven through its observance. This is what is said in the aforementioned Midrash: "Let us be cunning against him," as they wanted to abolish the Sabbath, as hinted in the word "with rigor" (בפרך) referring to the thirty-nine labors, and he specifically chose these labors in order to nullify their observance of the Sabbath, which imparts holiness to those who observe and fulfill it.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that all commandments in the Torah serve to distance individuals from idolatry, as the nations historically engaged in practices contrary to these commandments. Each mitzvah imparts holiness to the individual who observes it, while violating these commandments draws impurity upon oneself. The text highlights Pharaoh's intention to increase impurity among the Israelites by enforcing labor that directly opposes the Torah's commandments, particularly the observance of the Sabbath, which is a source of holiness. This reflects a deeper struggle between the forces of holiness and impurity, emphasizing the importance of adhering to divine commandments to maintain spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה את יעקב איש וביתו באו, דקדק האלשיך הק ' למה חזר הכתוב להזכיר שמותם וכבר הוזכרו לעיל בפ ' ויגש , ואם הכוונה להודיע חבתם כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל שנמשלו לכוכבים לכולם בשם יקרא, למה לא פרע בשמות כל הע ' נפש כאשר פרטם בפ ' ויגש , ומדוע לא פרט כ"א את הי"ב שבטים וטעמא בעי.
translation: And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each man and his household came. The Alshich asks, why does the text return to mention their names when they were already mentioned above in Parashat Vayigash? And if the intention is to inform us of their beloved status, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that they are compared to the stars, all of them are called by name, why does it not enumerate the names of all the seventy souls as detailed in Parashat Vayigash? And why does it not specify each of the twelve tribes, and what is the reason for this?
summary: The passage discusses the repetition of the names of the sons of Israel as they come to Egypt, questioning the necessity of this mention since they were already listed earlier. It highlights the significance of their names, likening them to stars that are called by name, reflecting their unique spiritual essence. The inquiry also raises the issue of why not all individuals are named, particularly the twelve tribes, suggesting a deeper connection to their collective identity and purpose within the divine plan. This reflects a Hasidic emphasis on the importance of individual and communal identity in the context of divine love and purpose.

passage_content: ב) מצרימה וגו' במד"ר הקשו וכי היום באים, והלא ימים רבים היו להם שבאו למצרימה , אלא כ"ז שיוסף הי' קיים לא הי"ל משוי של מצרים וכו ', לפיכך כתיב הבאים כאלו אותו יום נכנסו למצרים עכ"ד המדרש, ועדיין צ"ב דהתחיל לומר הבאים לשון הו' וסיים איש וביתו באו לשון עבר, גם למה כפל הבאים ואמר עוד באו ויספיק בא'.
translation: B) "To Egypt" etc. In the Midrash it is questioned: "Do they come today?" But they had many days when they came to Egypt. Rather, as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt, etc. Therefore, it is written "the coming" as if they entered Egypt that very day, thus concludes the Midrash. Yet, it still requires clarification why it begins with "the coming" in the present tense and concludes with "a man and his household came" in the past tense. Also, why does it repeat "the coming" and say "and they came" when it would suffice with just "came."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the term "the coming" in relation to the Israelites entering Egypt, emphasizing that their arrival was not merely a physical journey but a profound spiritual transition. It highlights that as long as Joseph was alive, the Israelites did not fully experience the burdens of Egypt, suggesting that their suffering began only after his death. The use of both present and past tense in describing their arrival indicates a deeper theological insight into the continuity of their identity and experience, reflecting the duality of their situation as both a collective and individual journey. The repetition of "coming" underscores the importance of this moment in their history, marking a pivotal shift in their relationship with Egypt and their destiny.

passage_content: ג) יעקב איש וביתו באו: דקדקו המפרשים דמיותר הוא וכבר נזכר זאת בפ ' ויגש : גם הו"ל להסמיך איש וביתו אל בני ישראל הסובב עליו, ויאמר הכתוב אלה שמות בנ"י איש וביתו הבאים את יעקב מצרימה, ומדוע הפסיק בין בני ישראל ואיש וביתו במלת הבאים.
translation: 3) Jacob, a man and his household, came: The commentators have noted that this is superfluous, as it has already been mentioned in Parashat Vayigash. It would have been appropriate to connect "a man and his household" to "the children of Israel" surrounding him, and the verse should have stated, "These are the names of the children of Israel, a man and his household, who came with Jacob to Egypt." And why does it interrupt between "the children of Israel" and "a man and his household" with the word "coming"?
summary: The passage discusses the arrival of Jacob and his household in Egypt, questioning the necessity of mentioning "a man and his household" separately from the children of Israel. It highlights the significance of this distinction, suggesting a deeper connection between Jacob's personal lineage and the collective identity of the Israelites. This separation emphasizes the individual and familial aspects of faith within the broader community, reflecting key Hasidic themes of personal devotion and the importance of family in spiritual life.

passage_content: ד) ואלה שמות א"ר אבהו כ"מ שנאמר ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים וכו' אף כאן הוסיף שבח על שבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם היו צדיקים עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב מה הוסיף על הראשונים הלא הם הן שנזכרו למעלה.
translation: D) And these are the names, Rabbi Abahu said: wherever it is stated "and these" it adds to the first ones, etc. Here too, it adds praise to the seventy souls that were mentioned above, for they were all righteous, thus concludes the Midrash. And it is to be questioned what it adds to the first ones, for they are indeed those that were mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "and these are the names," emphasizing that it adds praise to the seventy souls mentioned earlier, all of whom were righteous. This highlights the idea that each subsequent mention serves to elevate and honor the initial figures, reinforcing the notion of their sanctity and virtue. The inquiry posed reflects a deeper exploration of the relationship between the initial and subsequent names, suggesting a continuous unfolding of holiness and righteousness within the lineage. Ultimately, it underscores the Hasidic belief in the inherent value and spiritual elevation of each individual within the community.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המדרש תנחומא בפ ' תשא וז"ל אמר הקב"ה למשה לך מנה את ישראל. אמר משה לפני הקב"ה כתיב והי' זרעך כעפר הארץ. וכתיב והי' מספר בני ישראל כחול הים: ואתה אומר לך מנה את ישראל, איני יכול לעמוד על מנינם , ופי' הזית רענן איני יכול ר"ל איני רשאי למנאם , דבאמת יכול הי' למנאם ע"י חצאי שקלים שנתן כ"א בקע לגלגולת , אבל טענתו של משרע"ה הי' שהבטחתם שלא ימנו מרוב, ואתה אומר לי לך ומנה את ישראל, א"ל הקב"ה משה לא כשם שאתה סבור, אלא אם בקשת לעמוד על מנינם של ישראל, טול ראשי אותיות של שבטים ואתה עומד על מנינם וכו' ר' מראובן מאתים אלף, נ' מנפתלי חמשים אלף וכו' ובהצטרף כולם עולה החשבון ת"ק אלף וצ"ז אלף כמנין בני ישראל עיי"ש, לכאורה צ"ב כוונת התשובה, ועדיין התמי' במקומה עומדת, דכבר הובטחו ישראל שלא ימנו ולא יספרו מרוב, ומאי קמשני לי' דראשי אותיות של השבטים עולה ס' רבוא , והלא סוכ"ס הי' להם מספר ונמנו ע"י חצאי שקלים, גם מהו הכוונה במה שא"ל ית ' משה לא כשם שאתה סבור וכו' אלא טול ראשי אותיות וכו ', והלא נוסף לזה נצטו ' ג"כ למנותם ע"י חצאי שקלים ולא נשתנה ציווי ואופן המנין ממה שהי'.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Midrash Tanchuma in Parashat Tisa, and it says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Go count the Israelites." Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "It is written, 'Your seed shall be as the dust of the earth,' and it is written, 'And the number of the children of Israel shall be as the sand of the sea.' And You say to me, 'Go count the Israelites,' I cannot stand to count them." And the explanation of the fresh olive is that I cannot, meaning I am not permitted to count them, for in truth, he could have counted them by the half-shekels that each one gave, a bekah for each head. But Moses' argument was that they were promised that they would not be counted due to their multitude, and You say to me, 'Go and count the Israelites.' The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Not as you think, but if you wish to know the number of the Israelites, take the initials of the tribes and you will know their number, etc. Reuben has two hundred thousand, Naphtali has fifty thousand, etc., and when they all come together, the total comes to six hundred thousand and three thousand, as the number of the children of Israel, as stated there. At first glance, the intention of the response is questionable, and the question still stands, for the Israelites were already promised that they would not be counted or enumerated due to their multitude, and what does it help me that the initials of the tribes add up to six hundred thousand? After all, in the end, they had a number and were counted by half-shekels. Also, what is the intention in what He said to Moses, 'Not as you think, etc., but take the initials, etc.,' and besides this, they were also commanded to be counted by half-shekels, and the command and manner of counting did not change from what it was.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the tension between the divine promise that the Israelites would not be counted due to their multitude and the command to take a census. Moses expresses his reluctance to count the people, citing God's assurance of their vast numbers. God instructs Moses to consider the initials of the tribes, suggesting that this method allows for a count without contradicting the promise. This exchange emphasizes the complexity of divine commands and the interplay between faith and obedience in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ויובן עפימ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה ( בפ ' זו) בשם המפרשים לתרץ סתירת המקראות דכתיב (הושע ב') והי' מספר בני ישראל וגו' וכתיב אשר לא ימד ולא יספר, ותירצו דמצינו דא' מישראל שקול כנגד כמה וכמה, כמ"ש משה שקול כנגד כל ישראל, וכן אמרז"ל (ב"ב קכ"א) ביאיר בן מנשה שהי' שקול כנגד רובן של סנהדרין, וכן בדור המדבר דבר צו' לאלף דור, שכל א' מהן הי' שקול כאלף איש ומשה כנגד כולן, א"כ לפי"ז אין ברי' יכולה לידע משקל החשיבות של איש ישראל כי זה נשקל רק בדעתו של קל דיעות ב"ה וב"ש, וא"ש דלא ימד ולא יספר, אף אם יספר מנין גלגלותם , אבל משקל חשיבותם וערכם לא יצוייר שיספר עכת"ד המפרשים, וכתב ק"ז זלה"ה דבזה נדחה טענת אומה"ע דישראל בעלין ברוב לגבייהו , דהפחות שבישראל אפשר שקול כנגד כולן ואומה"ע לאו רובא נינהו עייש"ד .
translation: And it is understood according to the words of the holy Rabbi (in this chapter) in the name of the commentators to resolve the contradiction in the verses, as it is written (Hosea 2) "and the number of the children of Israel shall be like the sand of the sea" and it is written "which cannot be measured or counted." They explained that we find that one of Israel is considered equal to many, as it is said that Moses is equal to all of Israel, and so our sages said (Baba Batra 121) regarding Jair son of Manasseh, who was equal to most of the Sanhedrin, and likewise in the generation of the wilderness, it is said that one of them was equal to a thousand generations, and Moses was equal to all of them. Therefore, according to this, no creature can know the weight of the importance of a Jewish person, for this is only weighed in the mind of the light-minded, blessed be He, and blessed be His name. And it is clear that "cannot be measured or counted," even if one counts the number of their wheels, but the weight of their importance and value cannot be conceived to be counted, thus said the commentators. And the holy Rabbi wrote that with this the claim of the nations of the world against Israel is rejected, that the least among Israel may be considered equal to all, and the nations of the world are not a majority.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that each individual Jew holds immense value, often equated to many others, as illustrated by examples from the Torah where figures like Moses and Jair ben Menashe are considered equal to large groups. It emphasizes that the true worth of a Jew cannot be measured by mere numbers, as their significance is understood only by the Divine perspective. This understanding counters the argument of other nations that Jews are merely a minority, asserting that even the least among them can outweigh the majority of others. Ultimately, the text highlights the unique and unparalleled spiritual stature of each Jew in the eyes of God.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי התנחומא הנ"ל, שטען משרע"ה לפני הקב"ה כתיב והי' זרעך כעפר הארץ וגו' ולא ימנו מרוב, ואיך אתה אמר לי לך ומנה את ישראל, א"ל הקב"ה משה לא כשם שאתה סבור וכו' ר"ל שע"י שתמנה חצאי שקלים תוכל לעמוד על תכלית מנינם , אלא אם בקשת לעמוד על מנינם טול ראשי אותיות של שבטים וכו ', שכ"א עולה כנגד כמה אלפים. ובי"ב שבטי ישראל יש בהם בכח כל הס' רבוא ישראל, ועד"ז אתה עומד על מנינם לידע שלא ימנו מרוב כמאמר הכתוב, נמצא לפי"ז דבי"ב שבטי ד' שירדו עם יעקב היו כלולים בהם בכח נשמת ס' רבוא ישראל כמבואר בתנחומא הנ"ל
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Tanchuma, that Moshe Rabbeinu argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He, it is written, "And your seed shall be as the dust of the earth... and they shall not be counted for multitude," and how can You say to me, "Go and count Israel"? The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "Not as you think..." meaning that by counting half-shekels, you can ascertain the ultimate count, but if you wish to know their number, take the initials of the tribes, etc., for each one corresponds to several thousands. And in the twelve tribes of Israel, there is the potential for all six hundred thousand of Israel, and similarly, you ascertain their number to know that they shall not be counted for multitude, as the verse states. Thus, according to this, the twelve tribes of the Holy One, Blessed be He, who descended with Yaakov were included within them in the potential of the soul of six hundred thousand of Israel, as explained in the aforementioned Tanchuma.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between Moses and God regarding the counting of the Israelites, emphasizing that the true essence of their multitude cannot be captured by mere enumeration. Instead, it suggests that by counting the heads of the tribes, one can understand the spiritual significance and the inherent potential of the entire Israelite nation. The twelve tribes, representing the collective soul of the six hundred thousand Israelites, embody a deeper unity that transcends numerical limitations, highlighting the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of the Jewish people and their divine purpose.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ד במד"ר (פ' וישלח) לא נפטר יע"א מן העולם עד שראה ס' רבוא מיוצאי חלציו, וביפ"ת שם הרבה להקשות שהוא נגד הטבע להיות רבוי עצום כזה בי"ז שנה שהי' יע"א במצרים, ואף אם נאמר שהיו מולידין ששה בכרס אחד וגם שהולידו בני ח' וט' שנים באותן הדורות, מ"מ קשה שהפסוק עומד ומכחיש את זה שנאמר וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא ובני ישראל פרו וישרצו וגו' נראה שהרבוי הי' רק אחר מיתת יוסף וכל הדור ההוא אבל לא קודם לכן. ונדחק לתרץ שהכוונה בדברי המדרש שראה יע"א ברוח הקודש שעתיד להיות כן, ולא נתקיימה בימיו בפועל ממש, ובנזה"ק כתב שאין צריך לדוחק זה והקושיא מפסוק ובנ"י פרו וישרצו וגו' ל"ק כלל, דאז הי' רבוי מופלג יותר, אבל גם קודם לכן פרו שלא כדרך הטבע עיי"ש.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Midrash (Parashat Vayishlach) that Yisrael did not depart from this world until he saw 600,000 from his descendants. And in Yefet there is much to challenge, as it is against nature to have such a vast multiplication in the 17 years that Yisrael was in Egypt. And even if we say that they gave birth to six from one womb and that they bore children at the ages of eight and nine in those generations, nevertheless it is difficult, as the verse stands and contradicts this, which states, "And Yosef died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," and "And the children of Yisrael were fruitful and multiplied," etc. It seems that the multiplication occurred only after the death of Yosef and all that generation, but not before. And one is forced to explain that the intention of the Midrash is that Yisrael saw with the Holy Spirit that it would be so in the future, and it did not materialize in his days in a tangible way. And in the Zohar it is written that this difficulty is not necessary, and the question from the verse "And the children of Yisrael were fruitful and multiplied," etc., is not a question at all, for then there was an even greater multiplication, but even before that they multiplied in a way that was not according to nature, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous population growth of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that Jacob (Yaakov) foresaw this increase through divine inspiration before his death. It addresses the tension between natural laws and the extraordinary fertility of the Israelites, suggesting that their growth was not limited by natural constraints. The text ultimately asserts that even before the death of Jacob and his generation, there was a significant, albeit supernatural, increase in their numbers, highlighting the theme of divine intervention in the natural order.

passage_content: ול"נ דקושיא מעיקרא ליתא עפימ"ד במד"ר ובנ"י פרו וישרצו וגו' אע"פ שמת יוסף ואחיו אלקיהן לא מת אלא ובנ"י פרו וישרצו וגו' נראה פירושו שמצד הסברא הי' מקום לחשוב שאחר שמת יוסף וכל אחיו, נפסק ברכה זו מישראל להיותן פרין ורבין שלא כדרך הטבע, ע"כ בא סמיכת הפסוק ללמדנו. שלא נפסק הברכה אלא ובנ"י פרו וישרצו, ולפי"ז אין כוונת הכתוב להודיע שאחר מיתת יוסף התחיל הריבוי, דאדרבה כ"ז שיע"א והשבטים הק ' היו בעולם הי' ראוי שיהנו מזכותם הגדול, אבל השמיענו הכתוב שגם אחר הסתלקותם לא נפסק הברכה מהם אלא פרו וישרצו וגו'.
translation: And it seems to me that the initial question is not valid according to the interpretation of the Midrash and "the children of Israel were fruitful and multiplied," even though Joseph and his brothers died, their God did not die. Rather, "the children of Israel were fruitful and multiplied" indicates that from a logical perspective, one might think that after the death of Joseph and all his brothers, this blessing ceased from Israel, that they should be fruitful and multiply contrary to the natural way. Therefore, the verse is juxtaposed to teach us that the blessing did not cease, but rather "the children of Israel were fruitful and multiplied." According to this, the intention of the text is not to inform us that after the death of Joseph the multiplication began, but rather, as long as Joseph and the holy tribes were in the world, they were worthy of enjoying their great merit. However, the text informs us that even after their departure, the blessing did not cease from them, but rather they were fruitful and multiplied, etc.
summary: The passage emphasizes that despite the death of Joseph and his brothers, the blessing of fertility and growth for the Israelites did not cease. It counters the assumption that their passing would halt this divine blessing, affirming that the Israelites continued to thrive and multiply. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the enduring nature of divine blessings and the idea that spiritual merit can sustain a community even after its leaders are gone. Ultimately, it highlights the continuity of God's favor towards the people of Israel.

passage_content: והנה הנזה"ק שם כתב שאותן ס' רבוא שראה יע"א בימיו, הם הן שיצאו ממצרים עיי"ש, ולכאורה הוא פלא דהרי מהסתלקות יע"א עד יציאת מצרים הי' קרוב לב' מאות שנה, ואפשר לומר הכוונה שנתגלגלו עוה"פ וחזרו למצרים שנית והם עצמם שיצאו ממצרים. דבלא"ה צריך לומר כן מטעם אחר עפי"מ דאיתא בגמ' (סוטה י"ב ע"ב) ראו שמושיען של ישראל במים הוא לוקה, עמדו וגזרו כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו, כיון דשדי ' למשה אמרו תו לא חזינן כי האי סימנא , בטלו לגזירתי' וכו' והיינו דקאמר משה שש מאות אלף רגלי וגו', אמר להן משה לישראל בשבילי נצלתם כולכם, ובמד"ר פ' ויחי איתא א"ר לוי ס' ריבוא תינוקות עיברו נשותיהן של ישראל בלילה אחת, וכולם השלכו ליאור ועלו בזכותו של משה, הוא שמשה אומר שש מאות אלף רגלי העם כולם לרגלי עלו, וקשה דלפי"ז שהדור ההוא שיצאו ממצרים היו אותן שהשליכו ליאור עם משה, א"כ היו צריכין כולם להיות בני שמונים שנים כמו משה רבינו, והוא דבר שאי אפשר שהרי מנו אותם מבן עשרים שנה אלא צ"ל שחזרו בגלגול, ונשמותיהם היו מאותן שהושלכו עם משה ליאור, וזה כוונת הזוה"ק באומרו בנ"י עלו בנ"י נפקו על דרך שפי' האר"י הק ' אמרם ז"ל (ע"ז ט') בעוונותינו יצאו מה שיצאו ועדיין בן דוד לא בא, דאין בן דוד בא עד שיכלו כל הנשמות שבגוף, ובעונותינו אין יוצאים נשמות חדשות, אלא אותן שיצאו כבר חוזרים בגלגול עוה"פ וזה מעכב ביאת המשיח עכת"ד, וכמו"כ יאמר כאן בנ"י עלו בנ"י נפקו, פי' אותן שעלו הם בעצמם נפקו שחזרו ונתגלגלו עוה"פ , והם בעצמם היו יוצאי מצרים.
translation: And behold, the Zohar there writes that those 600,000 that the righteous one saw in his days, they are the very ones who went out of Egypt, as stated there. And seemingly, it is a wonder, for from the passing of the righteous one until the Exodus from Egypt was close to two hundred years. It can be said that the intention is that they were reincarnated and returned to Egypt again, and they themselves were the ones who went out of Egypt. Moreover, it must be said for another reason, as it is stated in the Gemara (Sotah 12b) that they saw that the savior of Israel in the water was stricken, and they stood and decreed that every son that is born should be cast into the river. Since they said to Moses, "We no longer see this sign," they nullified their decree, etc. And this is what Moses said, "Six hundred thousand foot soldiers," etc. Moses said to Israel, "For my sake, you were all saved." And in the Midrash, in Parashat Vayechi, it is stated that Rabbi Levi said that 600,000 infants were born to the wives of Israel in one night, and all were cast into the river and ascended through the merit of Moses. This is why Moses says, "Six hundred thousand foot soldiers, the entire people ascended at my feet." It is difficult, for according to this, the generation that went out of Egypt were those who were cast into the river with Moses; therefore, they should all be eighty years old like our teacher Moses, which is impossible, as they counted them from twenty years old. Rather, it must be that they returned in reincarnation, and their souls were from those who were cast into the river with Moses. This is the intention of the Zohar in saying that the children of Israel ascended, the children of Israel went out, in the manner explained by the holy Ari, as our sages said (Avodah Zarah 9) that due to our sins, those who went out are what they are, and still the Messiah has not come, for the Messiah does not come until all the souls in the body have been completed. And due to our sins, new souls do not go out, but those who have already gone out return in reincarnation, and this delays the coming of the Messiah. Thus, it can also be said here that the children of Israel ascended, the children of Israel went out, meaning that those who ascended are themselves who went out, having returned and reincarnated, and they themselves were the ones who went out of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of reincarnation within Hasidic thought, suggesting that the souls of the Israelites who left Egypt were the same souls that had been cast into the Nile. It emphasizes that the redemption of the Jewish people is linked to the return of these souls, which must occur before the arrival of the Messiah. The text highlights the idea that the souls of those who were thrown into the water are reincarnated and ultimately participate in the Exodus, illustrating a deep connection between past and present spiritual journeys. This cyclical understanding of souls underscores the ongoing struggle and hope for redemption in Jewish theology.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר התכת הפסוקים ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה, היינו הי"ב שבטי ד' שמנה הכתוב שמותם להלן, ובכח היו כלולים בהם כל הס' ריבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל, ומ"ש הבאים מצרימה לשון הוה , ר"ל שבאו דור אחר דור בגלגול עד שנצטרפו ונשלמו להיות כולם כשרים וצדיקים, ואמר עוד את יעקב איש וביתו באו, ר"ל השבעים נפש היינו השבטים וכל א' איש וביתו עמו הם באו כבר עם יעקב בעת ירידתן למצרים, ובהן הזכיר באו לשון עבר שכבר באו, וע"כ פלגינהו הכתוב לתרי בבי, דברישא דקרא הזכיר השבטים לבד הכוונה בהם על שרשי נשמות כל ישראל הכלול בהם, וזה אומרו הבאים לשון הו', ר"ל עתידין לבוא מצרימה בגלגול דור אחר דור, ובסיפא שהזכיר איש וביתו והם אשר באו בפועל עם יעקב, ע"כ אמר הכתוב באו בלשון עבר.
translation: And this will clarify the connection of the verses: "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," meaning the twelve tribes of the Holy One, blessed be He, whose names are written below. And in their essence, all the six hundred thousand root souls of Israel were included within them. And the phrase "who came to Egypt" is in the present tense, meaning that they came generation after generation through reincarnation until they were gathered and completed to be all righteous and just. It also states, "Jacob and his household came," meaning the seventy souls, which are the tribes, and each one, a man and his household, came with Jacob at the time of their descent to Egypt. In this, it mentions "came" in the past tense, as they have already come. Therefore, the text divides them into two categories: at the beginning of the verse, it mentions the tribes alone, intending to refer to the root souls of all Israel included within them. This is indicated by the phrase "who are coming," meaning they will come to Egypt in reincarnation generation after generation. And at the end, where it mentions "a man and his household," it refers to those who actually came with Jacob, thus the text states "came" in the past tense.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the names of the twelve tribes of Israel as representative of the entire Jewish soul, encompassing all generations. It emphasizes the concept of reincarnation, suggesting that the souls of Israel come into the world in cycles, ultimately achieving righteousness and completion. The text contrasts the future potential of the tribes to come to Egypt with the historical reality of Jacob and his family arriving there, highlighting the duality of past and future in the spiritual journey of the Jewish people.
