passage_content: ויובן בזה דברי המד"ר ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים וכו ', הוסיף שבח על ע' נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם היו צדיקים, ולדרכינו נכללו כאן בשמות השבטים כל הס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שיצאו ממצרים, וזה שהוסיף הכתוב שבח על הע ' נפש שנזכרו לעיל בפ ' ויגש , ללמדך שאף אלו היו כולם צדיקים כמבואר במדרשי חז"ל, שהרשעים מתו ונשארו במצרים, ואותן שיצאו היו כולם צדיקים. ומתורץ קושית האלשיך הקדוש (עיין קושיא א') מה שלא חזר הכתוב לפרט כל הע ' נפש כ"א הי"ב שבטים, ואם חזר והזכירן הכתוב כאן מפני חיבתן כפירש"י , הי"ל להזכיר כולן, ולדרכינו ריבה הכתוב בחיבתן וחשיבותן במה שחזר ומנה שמותם, להודיע שכלול בהם כל נשמות ישראל ושכולם צדיקים כנ"ל, וכח זה אינו אלא בשמות י"ב שבטים ולטעם זה נמנו אלו לבד. וחזר הכתוב לפרט שמותם לצד הכח הסתום שנכלל בהם, שאינו בשבעים נפש.
translation: And it is understood from this the words of the Midrash, and these add to the earlier ones, etc. It adds praise for the seventy souls that were mentioned above, that they were all righteous. And according to our path, all the root souls of Israel that went out of Egypt are included here in the names of the tribes. This is what the text adds praise for the seventy souls mentioned above in Parashat Vayigash, to teach you that even these were all righteous, as explained in the Midrashim of our Sages, that the wicked died and remained in Egypt, and those who went out were all righteous. This resolves the question of the holy Alshich (see question 1) regarding why the text did not return to detail all seventy souls, but if it did mention them here due to their belovedness, as Rashi explained, it should have mentioned them all. According to our path, the text increased in their belovedness and importance by returning and counting their names, to inform that all the souls of Israel are included in them and that they are all righteous, as mentioned above. And this power is only in the names of the twelve tribes, and for this reason, these alone were counted. And the text returned to detail their names due to the hidden power that is included in them, which is not in the seventy souls.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the forty souls mentioned in the context of the tribes of Israel, emphasizing that all who left Egypt were righteous, as the wicked perished there. It highlights that the names of the twelve tribes encapsulate the essence of all Jewish souls, reinforcing their inherent righteousness. This notion addresses a question regarding why the text does not list all forty souls, suggesting that the tribes' names carry a unique spiritual weight that encompasses the entirety of Israel's souls. Ultimately, the text underscores the special status and importance of the tribes in relation to the collective identity of the Jewish people.

passage_content: או"י עפי"מ דאיתא במדרש ילקוט ( סו"פ תצא) זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק ר' תנחום פתח זכרוניכם משלי אפר וגו', אמר הקב"ה לישראל בני הוו זהירין בשתי זכירות שכתבתי לכם בתורה, תמחה את זכר עמלק וכו ', אם זכיתם הרי אתם בניו של אברהם, אותו שהמשיל עצמו באפר שנא' ואנכי עפר ואפר, ואם לאו לגבי חומר גביכם, התקינו עצמיכם לשעבודה של מצרים וכו' ולכאורה הלא שעבודה של מצרים כבר חלף ועבר, וכתיב כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תוסיפו לראותם עד עולם, אמנם הכוונה על שאר הגליות שכולם באים להשלים שעבודה של מצרים כמבואר בדרז"ל , וע"כ נקראים ע"ש מצרים, ועד"ז יתפרש הכתוב ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה לשון הוה , שבאים בתמידות גולה אחר גולה למצרים, שכל הגליות נקראים ע"ש מצרים, את יעקב איש וביתו באו, ובמד"ר כל אלו מכוחו של יעקב שסגל מצות ומע"ט , ר"ל שבכוחו של יע"א שכבש הדרך לבניו בגלות מצרים, בזכות זה ישראל מתקיימים גם בשאר הגליות עד שירחם השי"ת עלינו ויגאלינו גאולת עולם בב"א.
translation: In the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Parashat Tetzaveh), "Remember what Amalek did to you." Rabbi Tanchum opened with "Remember your memories, dust and ashes," etc. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Israel: "My children, be careful with the two remembrances that I have written for you in the Torah: 'You shall blot out the memory of Amalek,' etc. If you merit it, you are the children of Abraham, he who likened himself to dust, as it is said, 'And I am dust and ashes.' If not, regarding the materiality of your backs, prepare yourselves for the servitude of Egypt, etc." And at first glance, the servitude of Egypt has already passed and gone, as it is written, "As you have seen Egypt today, you shall never see them again forever." However, the intention is regarding the other exiles, which all come to complete the servitude of Egypt, as explained by our Sages, of blessed memory. Therefore, they are called by the name of Egypt. Similarly, the verse "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt" is in the present tense, indicating that they come continuously, exile after exile, to Egypt, as all exiles are called by the name of Egypt. "Jacob came, a man and his household," and in the Midrash, all of these are by the merit of Jacob, who acquired the commandments and good deeds, meaning that by the merit of Jacob, he paved the way for his children in the exile of Egypt. By this merit, Israel is sustained even in the other exiles until the Holy One, Blessed be He, has mercy on us and redeems us with an eternal redemption, speedily in our days.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of remembering Amalek and the two key reminders in the Torah for the Jewish people. It emphasizes that if they merit this remembrance, they are considered the children of Abraham, who identified with dust and ashes. The text also explains that the experience of Egyptian bondage is a metaphor for all subsequent exiles, as they are all seen as extensions of the original Egyptian oppression. Ultimately, it highlights that through the merit of Jacob, who upheld the commandments, the Jewish people are sustained in their exiles until the ultimate redemption arrives.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפשר לפרש דברי המדרש הנ"ל עפי"מ דאיתא בזוה"ק פרשה זו (דף ט"ז ע"א) ת"ח לא אמר קרא היורדים מצרימה את יעקב וגו' אלא הבאים, אוליפנא דאתו עמי' דיעקב ואזלי להון וגו', ר' דוסתאי אמר בכל יומא ויומא אתיין ואזלין להון. הה"ד הבאים מצרימה ולא כתיב אשר באו וכו' שבטין נחתין חיין עם אבוהון ושבעין נחתין מתין עם אבוהון , הה"ד ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה וגו' וכתיב ראובן שמעון לוי וגו' ת"ח מתים הוו ונחתו וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק , ויתכן שירדו למצרים אחר הסתלקותם בשביל להגין על ישראל בזכותם, דגדולים צדיקים במיתתן כמארז"ל , ובזה יתיישב שינוי הלשון שבכתוב דמ"ש הבאים בלשון הוה ר"ל שבאו למצרים אחר הסתלקותם מעוה"ז, ולכך הזכיר הכתוב לשון הוה דכל יום ויום הוו אתיין ואזלין כמ"ש בזוה"ק , ואמר עוד את יעקב על הזמן שבאו בחיים חיותם למצרים איש וביתו באו בעבר, ואחר פטירתם לא באו איש וביתו רק השבטים הקדושים עם יעקב אביהם, והנה אמרו רז"ל (חולין ז' ע"ב) גדולים צדיקים במיתתן יותר מבחייהן וכו ', לזה אמה"כ כאן ואלה שמות בנ"י מוסיף על הראשונים אף שהם עצמם כבר נמנו למעלה, אפ"ה שייך למימר בהו מוסיף על הראשונים לפי שנתעלו בקדושתם ובצדקתם יותר מבחייהם .
translation:
In another way, one can interpret the words of the aforementioned Midrash according to what is stated in the Zohar for this portion (page 16a): "The Tana'im did not say the verse 'the ones going down to Egypt with Jacob' but rather 'the ones coming,' for they learned that they came with Jacob and went to them, etc. Rabbi Dostai said that every day they come and go to them." This is as it is written, "the ones coming to Egypt," and it is not written "the ones who came," etc. The tribes descend alive with their father, and seventy descend dead with their father. This is as it is written, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who are coming to Egypt," etc., and it is written, "Reuben, Simeon, Levi," etc. The Tana'im were dead and descended, etc. Thus far the Zohar. 

It is possible that they descended to Egypt after their passing in order to protect Israel through their merit, for great are the righteous in their death as our sages have said. And with this, the change in language in the verse is clarified, for what is meant by "the ones coming" in the present tense is that they came to Egypt after their departure from this world. Therefore, the verse mentions the present tense, that every day they would come and go, as stated in the Zohar. 

It also says "to Jacob" regarding the time they came in their living days to Egypt, each man and his household came in the past, and after their passing, they did not come, each man and his household, but only the holy tribes with their father Jacob. And behold, our sages said (Chulin 7b) that the righteous are greater in their death than in their life, etc. Therefore, it is written here, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," adding to the first ones, even though they themselves were already counted above; nevertheless, it is appropriate to say that it adds to the first ones because they were elevated in their holiness and righteousness more than in their life.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the term "the coming" in relation to the descent of Jacob and his family into Egypt, emphasizing that the righteous maintain their influence even after death. It suggests that the righteous, like Jacob and his sons, continue to protect and advocate for Israel posthumously, highlighting the idea that their spiritual elevation in death surpasses their life. The text also reflects on the notion that the names of the tribes are mentioned again to signify their increased sanctity and righteousness after their passing, reinforcing the Hasidic belief in the enduring power of the righteous.

passage_content: באופן אחר יתבארו דקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר עוד בדברי המדרש הנ"ל הבאים מצרימה וכי היום באים, והלא ימים רבים היו להם לישראל שבאו למצרים אלא כ"ז שיוסף הי' קיים לא הי' להם משוי של מצרים, מת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי, לפיכך כתיב הבאים כאילו אותו יום נכנסו למצרים עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דלפי"ז מיירי הכתוב בזמן שאחר הסתלקות יוסף, ומה ענין אומרו הבאים את יעקב, ולא הי' יע"א קיים בזמן ההוא.
translation: In another way, the aforementioned nuances will be clarified by first noting the words of the aforementioned Midrash that speaks of coming to Egypt, and that today they come. But were there not many days for the Israelites who came to Egypt? Rather, as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt. Upon Joseph's death, they placed a burden upon them; therefore, it is written "the coming" as if they entered Egypt on that very day, thus concludes the Midrash. However, it is puzzling that according to this, the text refers to a time after Joseph's passing, and what is the significance of saying "the coming of Jacob," when Joseph was not alive at that time.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the term "coming" in relation to the Israelites entering Egypt, emphasizing that their subjugation began only after Joseph's death. It highlights the idea that as long as Joseph was alive, the Israelites were not burdened by the yoke of Egypt. The text raises questions about the timing of their arrival and the mention of Jacob, suggesting a deeper connection between the patriarchs and the fate of their descendants. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine providence and the spiritual implications of historical events.

translation: In the name of our master, may his memory be a blessing, regarding the sanctity of the festival, he brought a Midrash: "Let us be wise against him," that Pharaoh wanted to abolish the Sabbath from them. It is fitting to understand why he specifically wanted to undermine the Sabbath.
summary: In Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is noted that Pharaoh sought to abolish the Sabbath, highlighting the significance of this day in Jewish spirituality. The desire to undermine the Sabbath reflects a deeper struggle against divine sanctity and the spiritual freedom it represents. This passage invites contemplation on the importance of maintaining the sanctity of time and the inherent connection between the Jewish people and their covenant with God. Ultimately, it emphasizes the need to resist forces that seek to diminish spiritual observance and connection.

passage_content: ג) ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים, ר"ת וס"ת מילה, את יעקב איש ס"ת שבת, לומר לך שבשביל שבת ומילה ששמרו במצרים נגאלו ע"כ, ראוי להבין מה ענין הרמז לכאן, ומקומו הנכון בפרשת הגאולה.
translation: 3) And these are the names of the children of Israel who came, the initials and the final letters spell the word "milah" (circumcision), and "Shabbat," to tell you that because of the Shabbat and the circumcision that they observed in Egypt, they were redeemed. Therefore, it is fitting to understand what the significance of the hint is here, and its proper place in the portion of redemption.
summary: The passage highlights the significance of the names of the sons of Israel as an acronym for "Shabbat" and "Milah" (circumcision), emphasizing that their observance of these commandments in Egypt was a key factor in their redemption. It suggests a deeper connection between the observance of these mitzvot and the process of spiritual liberation. The reference to Shabbat and Milah underscores the importance of maintaining Jewish identity and practices even in times of oppression. This insight reflects a central Hasidic theme of finding divine presence and purpose in the observance of commandments.

The reference to the Midrash indicates a deeper exploration of the significance of names in the context of divine revelation and human experience. Ultimately, it underscores the profound theological insight that our understanding of God shapes our spiritual expressions and communal identity.

passage_content: ונ"ל ביאור הענין דהנה ישראל למדו תורה במצרים כמ"ש ז"ל (יומא כ"ח) מימיהן של אבותינו לא פרשה ישיבה מהם וכו ', היו במצרים ישיבה עמהם וכו' עמרם זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' ע"כ, ויעקב אבינו בבואו למצרים יסד להם בתי מדרשות להורות בהן תורה והוראה, כמ"ש רז"ל עה"פ ואת יהודה שלח לפניו להורות לפניו, ובתרגום יונתן פי' סו"פ ויגש עה"פ וישב ישראל בארץ מצרים בארץ גושן ויאחזו בה, ובנו להון בתי מדרשין וכו ', והנה אמרז"ל במס' יבמות (צ"ו ע"ב) אר"י מ"ד אגורה באהליך עולמים וכי אפשר לו לאדם לגור בשני עולמות, אלא אמר דוד לפני הקב"ה, רבש"ע יה"ר שיאמרו דבר שמועה מפי בעוה"ז, דאר"י משום רשב"י כל ת"ח שאומרים דבר שמועה מפיו בעוה"ז שפתותיו דובבות בקבר עכ"ד הגמ ', וכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה בהפטורת תולדות וז"ל ראיתי בס' א' דכשאומר דבר בשם אומרו א"כ שפתותיו דובבות בקבר, דהיינו שמעורר חיות להצדיק, וע"כ נחשב להדור, והיינו שדרשו אגורה באהליך עולמים, דהוי כדר בעוה"ז עכ"ל וכן איתא בתנחומא (ר"פ תשא ) והשבע לעשיר איננו מניח לו לישון, בעשירי תורה מדבר, כיצד הי' עשיר בתורה ולמד תלמידים הרבה ושבע מהתורה, אע"פ שהוא מת אין התלמידים מניחין לו לישן אלא הם אומרים הלכות ושמועות משמו ומזכירין שמו שנא' דובב שפתי ישנים, וכן משה וכו' ובפ ' שקלים אמר משה לפני הקב"ה שמא משאני מת איני נזכר, א"ל הקב"ה חייך כשם שאתה עומד עכשיו וכו ', כך בכל שנה ושנה שקוראין אותם לפני, כאילו אתה עומד שם באותה שעה וזוקף את ראשן עכ"ד המדרש, והנה בודאי שישראל במצרים כשלמדו תורה, היו מזכירים שמועותיו של יע"א שלמדו מפיו וה"ה כאילו יעקב אבינו חי ושרוי בתוכם, וא"ש משה"כ הבאים מצרימה את יעקב, ואף שמיירי הכתוב מזמן שאחר הסתלקות יעקב ויוסף כמו שדרשו ז"ל במדרש הנ"ל, אבל לפי שהזכירו שמועותיהם הו"ל כאילו חזרו ובאו בכל יום ויום, וזה אומרו הבאים בלשון הוה , אבל איש וביתו באו בלשון עבר, ר"ל נשיהם ובנותיהם שנכללו במלת ביתו, באו כבר בעת ירידתם למצרים ונסתלקו לעולם העליון ולגביהם לא שייך בחי' זו להזכיר שמועותיהם, דנשים אסורים בת"ת כדרשת חז"ל ולמדתם אותם את בניכם ולא בנותיכם, ע"כ הזכיר בהם באו בעבר.
translation: And it seems to us an explanation of the matter: Behold, Israel learned Torah in Egypt, as it is said (Yoma 28) "From the days of our forefathers, the study of Torah did not depart from them," etc. They had a yeshiva in Egypt with them, etc. Amram was an elder and sat in the yeshiva, therefore. And our forefather Jacob, upon coming to Egypt, established houses of study to teach Torah and instruction in them, as our sages said regarding the verse "And he sent Judah before him to teach before him." And in the Targum Jonathan, it explains at the end of Vayigash regarding the verse "And Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen, and they acquired it," and they built for themselves houses of study, etc. And behold, our sages said in Yevamot (76b) that Rabbi Yochanan said, "What is meant by 'dwelling in your tents of eternity'? Is it possible for a person to dwell in two worlds? Rather, David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, 'Master of the Universe, may it be Your will that they say a teaching in my name in this world,' for Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai, 'Any Torah scholar who says a teaching in his name in this world, his lips move in the grave.'" Thus said the Gemara. And Rabbi Shmuel of Lubavitch, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the haftarah of Toldot: "I saw in a certain book that when one says a teaching in the name of the one who said it, then his lips move in the grave," meaning that he arouses life for the righteous, and therefore it is considered as if he is dwelling, and this is what they expounded regarding "dwelling in your tents of eternity," that it is as if he dwells in this world. Thus it is also stated in the Tanchuma (Parashat Tisa) that "the wealthy do not allow him to sleep," meaning the wealthy in Torah speak. How was he wealthy in Torah? He taught many students and was satisfied with the Torah; even though he is dead, the students do not allow him to sleep, but they say laws and teachings in his name and mention his name, as it is said, "The lips of the dead speak." And likewise, Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Perhaps since I have died, I am not remembered." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "By your life, just as you stand now," etc., "so every year when they read them before Me, it is as if you are standing there at that moment and raising their heads." Thus said the Midrash. And behold, certainly when Israel was in Egypt and learned Torah, they were mentioning the teachings of the righteous one whom they learned from his mouth, and it is as if our forefather Jacob was alive and dwelling among them. And this explains what is said, "the ones coming to Egypt, Jacob," and even though the verse speaks of a time after the passing of Jacob and Joseph, as our sages expounded in the aforementioned Midrash, since they mentioned their teachings, it was as if they returned and came every single day. This is the meaning of "the ones coming" in the present tense, but "a man and his house came" is in the past tense, meaning their wives and daughters who are included in the term "his house" came already at the time of their descent to Egypt and departed to the upper world, and regarding them, this aspect of mentioning their teachings does not apply, for women are forbidden to study Torah, as our sages have taught, "and you shall teach them to your children," and not to your daughters. Therefore, it is mentioned about them "came" in the past tense.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Jewish people's study of Torah in Egypt, emphasizing that even in exile, they maintained a connection to their ancestors, particularly Jacob and Joseph, through the teachings they transmitted. It highlights the concept that when Torah is taught in the name of its original teachers, it revives their spiritual presence, allowing them to continue influencing the living. The text also notes the distinction between men and women in the context of Torah study, reflecting traditional views on gender roles in religious education. Ultimately, it illustrates the enduring impact of the righteous on their descendants, even after their physical departure from the world.

passage_content: והנה השיג פרעה שבזכות לימוד התוה"ק עתידין ישראל להגאל , וכמ"ש רז"ל אין הגלויות מתכנסות אלא בזכות תנויי , שנא' גם כי יתנו בגוים עתה יקבצם, ולזה רצה לבטל מהם לימוד התורה, וכ"כ בש"ך עה"ת עה"פ הבה נתחכמה לו, שרצה פרעה לבטל בתי מדרשים שלמדו בהם ישראל תורה עיי"ש, ואולי דלכוונה זו רצה לבטל מהם גם את המילה, עפימ"ד במד"ר (פ' משפטים) א"ל עקילס לאדריינוס המלך רוצה אני להתגייר ולהעשות ישראל וכו ', אמר לו לך ולמוד תורתן ואל תמול, אמר לו עקילס אפי' חכם שבמלכותך וזקן בן מאה שנה אינו יכול ללמוד תורתן אם אינו מל עכ"ד המדרש, ועד"ז חשב פרעה מחשבתו הרעה שאם יבטל מהם המילה, בהכרח יתבטלו מן התורה ולא יגאלו משם לעולם
translation: And behold, Pharaoh realized that through the merit of studying the Torah, the Jewish people are destined to be redeemed, as our Sages have said, the exiles do not gather except through the merit of the Torah, as it is stated, "Even if they give themselves among the nations, now I will gather them." Therefore, he wanted to abolish their study of the Torah. And so it is written in the Shach on the Torah, on the verse "Come, let us outsmart him," that Pharaoh wanted to abolish the houses of study where the Jews learned Torah, as mentioned there. And perhaps for this intention, he also wanted to abolish the circumcision from them, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Mishpatim), that Akilas said to King Hadrian, "I want to convert and become a Jew," etc. The king said to him, "Go and study their Torah and do not circumcise." Akilas replied, "Even the wisest in your kingdom and a man aged one hundred years cannot learn their Torah if he is not circumcised." Thus said the Midrash. Similarly, Pharaoh thought his evil thought that if he would abolish circumcision from them, they would necessarily cease from the Torah and would never be redeemed from there.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's realization that the Israelites' study of the Torah is essential for their eventual redemption. He sought to undermine this by abolishing their Torah learning and possibly even the practice of circumcision, as both are seen as vital to their identity and connection to God. The text emphasizes that without these practices, the Israelites would be unable to maintain their covenant with God and would remain in exile indefinitely. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the importance of Torah study and mitzvot in achieving spiritual redemption.

passage_content: ולכוונה זו רצה לבעל מהם את השבת ג"כ, דהנה הב"י ( באו"ח סי' רפ"ח) הביא בשם הירושלמי, ר' חגי אמר לא ניתנו שבתות וי"ט אלא לאכילה ושתי', ר' ברכי' אמר לא ניתנו אלא לעסוק בהם בדברי תורה, ובתנחומא מפרש לא פליגין מה דא"ר ברכי' לתלמוד תורה, אלו הפועלים שהם עסוקין במלאכתן כל ימות השבוע, ובשבת הם באים ועוסקין בד"ת , ומה דא"ר חגי להתענג אלו ת"ח וכו' ע"כ, וישראל במצרים כל ימות השבוע היו עובדים עבודת הפרך מקרות הגבר, ע"כ ביום השבת שהי' נוחין ממלאכה היו עוסקין כל היום בתורה, ולזה רצה פרעה לבעל מהם את השבת כדי לבטלם מן התורה הגורם לגאולתן, ומבואר כן במד"ר ( סו"פ זו) עה"פ תכבד העבודה על האנשים, מלמד שהיו בידן מגילות, שהיו משתעשעין בהן משבת לשבת, לומר שהקב"ה גואלן, לפי שהיו נוחין בשבת, א"ל פרעה תכבד העבודה על האנשים ויעשו בה ואל ישעו וגו'. אל יהיו משתעשעין ואל יהיו נפישין ביום השבת, ופי' המפורשים מגילות היינו דברי תורה שהיו משתעשעין בהם, ע"ד הכתוב לולי תורתך שעשועי, וסובר כמ"ד התורה מגילות ניתנה, והי' בידן מגילות של ספר בראשית וסיפורי האבות וההבטחות שהתנבאו, ולכוונה זו התחכם פרעה לבטל מהם השבת, כדי שיתבטלו מדברי תורה.
translation: And for this intention, Pharaoh wanted to take the Sabbath away from them as well. Behold, the Ba'al HaTurim (Orach Chaim 248) brings in the name of the Jerusalem Talmud, Rabbi Chagai said that Sabbaths and festivals were given only for eating and drinking, Rabbi Berachiah said they were given only to engage in words of Torah. And in the Tanchuma, it explains that they do not disagree; what Rabbi Berachiah said refers to the study of Torah, those laborers who are occupied with their work all week long, and on the Sabbath they come and engage in words of Torah. And what Rabbi Chagai said about delighting refers to the Torah scholars, etc. Therefore, the Israelites in Egypt worked hard all week long under harsh labor, and thus on the Sabbath, when they were free from work, they engaged all day in Torah. For this reason, Pharaoh wanted to take the Sabbath away from them in order to prevent them from studying Torah, which is the cause of their redemption. This is made clear in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era) on the verse "Let the work be heavier upon the men," teaching that they had scrolls in their hands, which they would occupy themselves with from Sabbath to Sabbath, to say that the Holy One, blessed be He, would redeem them, since they were at rest on the Sabbath. Pharaoh said to them, "Let the work be heavier upon the men, and let them do it and not pay attention," etc. They should not be occupied and should not be engaged on the Sabbath. And the interpreters explain that the scrolls refer to words of Torah that they were occupied with, in accordance with the verse "If not for Your Torah, my delight." And he holds like the one who says that the Torah was given in scrolls, and they had scrolls of the Book of Genesis and the stories of the Patriarchs and the promises that were prophesied. For this intention, Pharaoh schemed to take the Sabbath away from them, so that they would be prevented from words of Torah.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Shabbat and its connection to Torah study, highlighting differing views on its purpose: for enjoyment or for spiritual engagement. It emphasizes that the Israelites in Egypt, who were burdened with hard labor, used Shabbat to immerse themselves in Torah, which was essential for their redemption. Pharaoh's attempt to intensify their work aimed to prevent them from engaging in Torah study, as he understood its power in facilitating their liberation. The text illustrates the deep relationship between rest, spiritual nourishment, and the divine promise of redemption.

passage_content: ובזה נבין ענין הרמז שכתב בבעל העורים בני ישראל הבאים את יעקב איש, נרמז בהם שבת ומילה, דזה גרם להם ללימוד התורה ובזכות התורה ישראל נגאלין כאמרז"ל , וא"ש ענין הרמז לפסוק זה הבאים מצרימה את יעקב, שהי' יע"א עמהם אף אחר הסתלקותו ע"י שלמדו תורתו והזכירו שמועותיו, ובזכות התוה"ק נגאלו, ולז"א ואלה שמות מוסיף על הראשונים מפני שנרמז כאן באומרו הבאים מצרימה את יעקב, שהי' יע"א עמהם אף אחר הסתלקותו וגדולים צדיקים במיתתם יותר מבחייהם , וע"י שהזכירו ישראל שמועותיו נהנו מזכותו הרם, וזה שעמדה להם להתגבר על הנסיונות שנתחדשו ונתעצמו עליהם אחרי הסתלקות יע"א , וז"ש ואלה מוסיף שבח על הראשונים, אע"פ שהן הן הם עצמם שנזכרו לעיל, אבל עכשיו נתוספה שבחן וגדלה זכותם כנ"ל.
translation: And with this, we will understand the matter of the hint that he wrote in Ba'al Ha'Urim about the children of Israel coming to Jacob, a man, which hints at Shabbat and circumcision. For this caused them to engage in the study of Torah, and through the merit of the Torah, Israel was redeemed, as our Sages have said. And I understand the matter of the hint to this verse, "the ones coming to Egypt, to Jacob," that he, may his merit protect us, was with them even after his passing, because they studied his Torah and mentioned his teachings. And through the merit of the Holy Torah, they were redeemed. Therefore, it says, "And these are the names," adding to the first ones, because it is hinted here in the saying, "the ones coming to Egypt, to Jacob," that he, may his merit protect us, was with them even after his passing, and great are the righteous in their death more than in their lifetime. And by mentioning his teachings, Israel benefited from his great merit, and this stood for them to overcome the trials that were renewed and intensified against them after the passing of Jacob, may his merit protect us. And this is why it says, "And these" adds praise to the first ones, even though they are indeed the same ones mentioned above, but now their praise has been added, and their merit has grown, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the connection between the Jewish people and Jacob, emphasizing that their adherence to the Torah and the practices of Shabbat and circumcision were pivotal for their redemption. It highlights that even after Jacob's passing, his teachings and legacy continued to inspire and protect the Israelites, illustrating the idea that the righteous have a greater impact after their death. The text underscores the notion that the remembrance of the righteous enhances their merit and provides strength to the community in times of trial, thus affirming the enduring influence of their spiritual legacy.

passage_content: ויל"פ לדרכנו דברי הילקוט הנ"ל (קושיא ד') עפימ"ש החיד"א זלה"ה ביוסף תהלות עה"פ דימינו אלקים חסדך בקרב היכלך, וז"ל חשבנו שבמקדש לבד היו נסים, כמשז"ל עשרה נסים נעשו לאבותינו בביהמ"ק , וז"ש דמינו אלקים חסדך, לעשות נסים בקרב היכלך לבד, אך אני רואה כשמך אלקים שהוא חי וקיים לעד, כן תהלתך על קצוי ארץ, שאתה עושה נסים ונפלאות לישראל, ואם אינם גלוים כ"כ המשכיל יבין תוקף הנסים עכ"ל, ואפשר להוסיף נופך על דבה"ק , כי עכשיו בגלות המר אין לנו שיור רק התורה הזאת, וע"כ בזכות התוה"ק נעשו נסים לישראל, וידוע דכל התורה כולה שמותיו של הקב"ה כמ"ש אמרת אלקי צרופה, וז"פ הפסוק דימינו אלקים חסדך בקרב היכלך ע"ד שפי' החיד"א זלה"ה חשבנו שבמקדש לבד נעשו נסים, אבל כשמך אלקים היינו התוה"ק שהיא שמותיו של הקב"ה כן תהלתך על קצוי ארץ ובזכות שלמדו בני ישראל תורה במצרים כנרמז באומרו הבאים מצרימה את יעקב וכנ"ל, ע"כ זכו לנס וגאלם הקב"ה משם ביד חזקה, וז"פ דברי הילקוט ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה את יעקב, שלמדו שם תוה"ק והי' זכותו של יע"א עמהם כנ"ל, זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך על קצוי ארץ. שעי"ז זכו לנסים גם בהיותם במצרים. השי"ת יעזור לנו שנזכה להיות דבוקים בדרך התורה והאמת בקדושה ובטהרה, ובמהרה נזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בנחת ובשמחה, בהתרוממת קרן התורה וישראל, ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation:
And it is possible to elaborate on our path the words of the aforementioned Yalkut (question 4) according to what the Chida, may his memory be blessed, said regarding Joseph's praises on the verse "Your mercy, O God, is in the midst of Your temple." He wrote: "We thought that miracles occurred only in the Temple, as our Sages of blessed memory said that ten miracles were performed for our ancestors in the Holy Temple. And this is what is meant by 'Your mercy, O God,' to perform miracles in the midst of Your temple alone. However, I see that as Your name, O God, is alive and enduring forever, so is Your praise to the ends of the earth, for You perform miracles and wonders for Israel, and if they are not so revealed, the wise will understand the strength of the miracles." Thus far his words. 

And it is possible to add a nuance regarding the Holy Temple, for now, in this bitter exile, we have no remnant except for this Torah. Therefore, by the merit of the Holy Torah, miracles were performed for Israel. It is known that the entire Torah is the names of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "The words of God are pure words." And this is the meaning of the verse "Your mercy, O God, is in the midst of Your temple," according to the explanation of the Chida, may his memory be blessed, who thought that miracles occurred only in the Temple. But as Your name, O God, which is the Holy Torah, which is the names of the Holy One, blessed be He, so is Your praise to the ends of the earth. And by the merit of the fact that the children of Israel learned Torah in Egypt, as hinted at in the saying "the coming of Jacob to Egypt," and as mentioned above, they merited a miracle, and the Holy One, blessed be He, redeemed them from there with a strong hand. 

And this is the meaning of the words of the Yalkut: "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob," that they learned the Holy Torah there, and the merit of the righteous one, may his memory be blessed, was with them, as mentioned above. This is the meaning of "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise to the ends of the earth," that through this they merited miracles even while they were in Egypt. May the Holy One, blessed be He, help us to merit being attached to the path of the Torah and truth in holiness and purity, and may we soon merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy in peace and happiness, with the upliftment of the crown of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes that while miracles were traditionally associated with the Temple, God's presence and miraculous acts extend beyond it, as reflected in the Torah, which embodies God's names. It highlights that the study of Torah, even during exile, serves as a source of merit for the Jewish people, enabling them to experience divine intervention, as seen during their time in Egypt. The text calls for a deep connection to the Torah and a hope for redemption and joy for all of Israel, culminating in the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בדברי המדרש הנ"ל הבאים מצרימה וכו' כאילו אותו יום נכנסו למצרים. דלכאורה קושית המדרש עדיין במקומה עומדת, דהול"ל באו בלשון עבר, דהרי בזמן כתיבת התוה"ק כבר באו, ועכ"פ לא יצדק הבאים בלשון הוה , כי אין זה דבר ההוה תמיד, ויתבאר בהקדם לבאר סתירת דברי רז"ל בענין התחלת השעבוד, דבמדרש הנ"ל אמרו כיון שמת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי, ובפ ' ויחי דרשו ז"ל כיון שמת יעקב נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, ובמקו"א אמרז"ל דכ"ז שא' מן השבעים קיים לא התחילה השעבוד, ועוד אמרו דכ"ז שא' מן הדור קיים לא התחילה השעבוד, ובפרדר"א שלא התחילה השעבוד כ"א משעה שיצאו בני אפרים, שהוא ל' שנה קודם הגאולה, וצ"ב ליישב דברי רז"ל שלא יהיו סותרין זא"ז , וכבר ביארנו בזה אופנים שונים ועוד לאלקי מילין .
translation: It can also be said regarding the words of the aforementioned Midrash that they came to Egypt, etc., as if on that day they entered Egypt. For seemingly, the question of the Midrash still stands, for it should have said "they came" in the past tense, since by the time the Torah was written, they had already come. And in any case, it would not be correct to say "the coming" in the present tense, as this is not a matter that is always present. It will be explained in advance to clarify the contradiction in the words of our Sages regarding the beginning of the servitude. For in the aforementioned Midrash, they said that once Joseph died, they imposed burdens upon them, and in Parashat Vayechi, our Sages expounded that once Jacob died, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed to the pain of the servitude. And in another place, our Sages said that as long as one of the seventy was alive, the servitude did not begin, and they also said that as long as one of the generation was alive, the servitude did not begin. And in Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer, it is stated that the servitude only began from the time the children of Ephraim left, which is thirty years before the redemption. It is necessary to reconcile the words of our Sages so that they do not contradict one another, and we have already explained this in various ways and still to the Divine matters.
summary: The passage discusses the timing and nature of the Israelites' enslavement in Egypt, highlighting a tension in rabbinic sources regarding when this oppression began. It notes that the enslavement is linked to the deaths of key figures like Joseph and Jacob, and emphasizes that as long as any of the original seventy descendants of Jacob were alive, the oppression had not yet commenced. The text seeks to reconcile these differing interpretations, reflecting on the theological implications of divine timing and the significance of leadership in the context of suffering and redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"ל בדרך פשוט דהנה מצינו ראינו אף בדורות שלפנינו הרבה מאות שנים התאוננו על שפלות מצב דורם ואמרו בתפלתם ומפגיע אין בעדנו, ועוד בימי הנביאים כתיב אבד חסיד מן הארץ, ומכ"ש כמה מעלות ירדנו אחורנית בדור האחרון הזה שאין לנו על מי להשען אלא על אבינו שבשמים, אמנם כולהו איתנייהו דגם בדורות הקודמים לפי ערך גדולתם וגדולת הדור שקדם להם, הרגישו ירידה בערך השגתם, והתאוננו על שנתמעט כח הקדושה בערך הדור שקדם להם, ואח"כ בדור שלאחריהם נתמעטו הצדיקים וחסרה כח הקדושה יותר, הרגישו הירידה לפי ערכם, עד שבעוה"ר בדור הזה אף לפי קוצר השגתינו נרגש הירידה הנוראה, הגדולה באיכותה על כל אשר קדמונו בדורות שלפנינו דבודאי לא הרי זה כהרי זה ומי יתן שנזכה אל מדריגת דורות הקודמים, שירידה שלהם עלי' הוא בערכנו.
translation: And even if we take it in a simple way, behold, we find that even in the generations before us, for many hundreds of years, they complained about the low state of their generation and said in their prayers, "There is no one to plead for us." Furthermore, in the days of the prophets, it is written, "The faithful have perished from the earth," and how much more so have we descended in levels in this last generation, where we have no one to rely on but our Father in Heaven. However, all of them, even in the previous generations, according to their greatness and the greatness of the generation that preceded them, felt a decline in the value of their attainment and complained that the power of holiness had diminished compared to the generation that preceded them. And then, in the generation that followed them, the righteous were diminished, and the power of holiness was even more lacking; they felt the decline according to their value, until, woe to us, in this generation, even according to the shortness of our understanding, we feel the terrible decline, the great one in its quality compared to all that preceded us in the generations before us, for certainly this is not like that, and who would give that we merit the level of the previous generations, for their decline is an ascent in our value.
summary: The passage reflects on the spiritual decline observed across generations, emphasizing that even in earlier times, people lamented the diminishing holiness and righteousness in their era compared to previous generations. It highlights a continuous descent in spiritual stature, with each generation feeling the loss of the divine presence and the strength of the righteous. The author expresses a yearning for the spiritual heights of past generations, acknowledging that the current generation experiences a profound and unprecedented decline in holiness. Ultimately, it underscores the reliance on divine mercy in the face of this spiritual degradation.

passage_content: ועד"ז נבין עפ"י פשוטו להשוות סתירת דברי רז"ל דמשמת יעקב נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל וכו ', שהי' נרגש ירידה זו לזכי הראות ובני עלי' שבישראל לפי ערך מדריגתם, ומשמת יוסף הרגישו עוד ירידה בערך הזמן הקדום, ועד"ז בכל אלו הזמנים שנתנו רז"ל ניתוסף בחי' הירידה בערך הזמן שקדם אלי', והי' נרגש אף לקטני הערך ולזה אמר הכתוב ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה בלשון הוה , כי מצרים שורש כל הגלויות, וכולם הם תשלום לגלות מצרים שלא השלימו ישראל זמנם שם כידוע, ואמר הבאים בהוה לרמוז על כל הגלויות, שיתחדש בחי' הגלות ובחי' הירידה מדרגא לדרגא , עד שבכל פעם יהי' נדמה כאילו אותו יום באו, ולא הי' כבחי' גלות הזה מעולם.
translation: And similarly, we will understand according to its simple meaning the contradiction in the words of our Sages, that from the time of Jacob, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed, etc. This descent was felt by the pure of vision and the elevated ones among Israel according to their level. From the time of Joseph, they felt an additional descent in relation to the earlier time, and similarly in all those times that our Sages mentioned, an additional aspect of descent was added in relation to the time that preceded them. This was felt even by those of lesser stature. Therefore, the scripture says, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt" in the present tense, for Egypt is the root of all exiles, and they are all a fulfillment of the exile of Egypt, as Israel did not complete their time there, as is known. And it says "the coming" in the present tense to hint at all the exiles, that the aspect of exile and the aspect of descent from level to level will be renewed, until it will seem each time as if they came on that very day, and that this type of exile has never existed before.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual decline experienced by the Jewish people, particularly after the deaths of Jacob and Joseph, which is perceived as a loss of clarity and insight. It emphasizes that each subsequent generation feels a deeper descent in spiritual status, reflecting on the nature of exile as a continuous process rooted in the original Egyptian exile. The use of the present tense in the phrase "the names of the children of Israel coming to Egypt" signifies that each exile is a renewal of the original experience, suggesting that the struggles of the past are perpetually relevant and felt anew in every generation. This highlights the cyclical nature of exile and redemption in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר קישור דברי המדרש ילקוט, ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים וגו' זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך על קצוי ארץ וגו'. דהנה נשבע הקב"ה שלא יהי' השם שלם וכסאו שלם עד שימחה זרעו של עמלק, ולעתיד כשיהי ' השם שלם לא יהי' גלות וירידה עוד, כמ"ש ומלאה הארץ דיעה וגו' וז"פ ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה בהוה, שבעוה"ר ירדנו ירידה אחר ירידה, זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך , כשיתגדל ויתקדש שמו' רבא ויהי' שמו ית ' וכסאו שלם, על קצוי ארץ מלאה ימינך והכל יאמרו אין קדוש כד', ולא יהי' ירידה עוד.
translation: And this will clarify the connection of the words of the Midrash Yalkut, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who are coming," etc. This is as it is written, "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise to the ends of the earth," etc. Behold, the Holy One, blessed be He, has sworn that His name will not be complete and His throne will not be complete until the seed of Amalek is erased. In the future, when the name will be complete, there will be no more exile and descent, as it is said, "And the earth will be filled with the knowledge," etc. And this is the meaning of "And these are the names of the children of Israel who are coming to Egypt" in the present tense, that in our times we have descended, descent after descent. This is as it is written, "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise," when His great and holy name will be magnified and sanctified, and His name will be complete, and His throne will be complete, to the ends of the earth filled with Your right hand, and all will say, "There is none holy like the Lord," and there will be no more descent.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the names of the Israelites and the divine name, emphasizing that God's name and throne will not be complete until the seed of Amalek is eradicated. It suggests that in the future, when God's name is fully sanctified, there will be no more exile or descent, as the earth will be filled with knowledge of God. The text highlights the current state of decline and the hope for a future redemption where God's holiness will be universally acknowledged.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בפי' הכתוב כשמך אלקים וגו'. עפימ"ד בזוה"ק שהנוטר בריתו שריא עלי' שם שד"י , וח"ו הפוגם בריתו שריא עלי' ס"מ, וכבר נתבאר לעיל בדברנו מפי צדיקים אמיתיים שכל עבודת האדם בתורה ותפלה ותהלה לאלקינו ית ' תליא בתיקון מידה זו, וז"פ כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך ר"ל כפי בחי' השם השורה על האדם, כן ביכולתו להלל ולשבח לפניו ית '.
translation: And even further, in the interpretation of the verse "As Your Name, O God, so is Your praise," it is explained in the Zohar that the one who guards his covenant has the Shechinah resting upon him, while, Heaven forbid, the one who damages his covenant has the Sitra Achra resting upon him. It has already been explained above in our words from true tzaddikim that all of a person's service in Torah, prayer, and praise to our God, blessed be He, is dependent on the rectification of this attribute. Thus, as Your Name, O God, so is Your praise, meaning that according to the aspect of the Name that rests upon a person, so is his ability to praise and glorify before Him, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of maintaining one's covenant with God, as reflected in the Zohar, where the divine name Shaddai represents the sanctity of this covenant. It emphasizes that those who uphold their covenant are under the influence of divine protection, while those who violate it are influenced by negative forces. The text further explains that a person's spiritual work, including Torah study and prayer, is directly linked to the rectification of this covenantal relationship. Ultimately, the ability to praise and glorify God is contingent upon the divine presence that rests upon the individual, reflecting their spiritual state.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרשים הנ"ל בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק (ר"פ זו) תלתא אינון דדחיין שכינתא מעלמא וכו ', זכאין אינון ישראל דאע"ג דהוו בגלותא דמצרים אסתמרו מכל הני תלתא מנדה ומבת אל נכר ומקטול זרעא וכו ', בנ"י עאלו ובנ"י נפקו הה"ד ואלה שמות בני ישראל וגו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק , וצ"ב איך נרמז כל זה במאמה"כ ואלה שמות בנ"י , גם מדוע בא הרמז הזה כאן בהתחלת שעבודה של מצרים, והי' ראוי להיות מקומה בפ ' היציאה שבזכות אלה זכו להוציאם ממצרים.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the aforementioned Midrashim in advance of the words of the Zohar (in Parashat Va'era), "Three are those who drive away the Shechinah from the world," etc. The Israelites are worthy, for although they were in the exile of Egypt, they were preserved from all these three: from the curse and from the daughter of a foreigner and from the slaughter of seed, etc. The children of Israel went in and the children of Israel went out, as it is written, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. Thus far the Zohar. And it is to be questioned how all this is hinted at in the verse "And these are the names of the children of Israel," and also why this hint comes here at the beginning of the servitude in Egypt, when it would have been appropriate for it to be placed in the section of the Exodus, that because of these they were worthy to be taken out of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the Zohar's interpretation of the resilience of the Jewish people during their Egyptian exile, emphasizing that despite their suffering, they remained spiritually intact and were not influenced by three negative forces: idolatry, assimilation, and violence. It questions how this resilience is hinted at in the verse "These are the names of the children of Israel," and why this hint appears at the beginning of the narrative of their enslavement rather than at the moment of their redemption. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the intrinsic connection between identity and divine protection, suggesting that the essence of the Jewish people is preserved even in the depths of exile.

passage_content: ב) כתב רמז עה"פ ואלה שמות בני "ישראל הבאים" ר"ת וס"ת מילה, את יעקב איש ס"ת שבת, לומר לך שבשביל שבת ומילה ששמרו במצרים נגאלו עכ"ל, ראוי להבין ענין הרמז לפסוק זה דוקא .
translation: B) He wrote a hint on the verse "And these are the names of the children of Israel who are coming" (Exodus 1:1), the initials and the final letters spell "Milah" (circumcision), "Shabbat" (Sabbath), to tell you that because of the observance of Shabbat and Milah that they kept in Egypt, they were redeemed. It is fitting to understand the significance of the hint to this particular verse.
summary: The passage highlights the significance of the Hebrew letters in the phrase "ואלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים" (And these are the names of the children of Israel who came) as an acronym for "Shabbat" and "Milah" (circumcision). It emphasizes that the observance of these two commandments was a key factor in the redemption of the Israelites from Egypt. The text suggests a deep connection between the spiritual practices of Shabbat and circumcision and the divine favor that led to their liberation. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the transformative power of mitzvot in the life of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ג) מלך חדש על מצרים אשר לא ידע את יוסף, בת"א פי' דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף וצ"ב ענין הגזירה מהו.
translation: A new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph, meaning that he did not uphold the decree of Joseph, and the question remains: what is the nature of this decree?
summary: The passage discusses the emergence of a "new king" in Egypt who did not recognize Joseph, symbolizing a departure from the previous recognition of divine providence and the legacy of righteousness. This shift signifies a rejection of the covenant and the spiritual insights that Joseph represented. The mention of the decree implies a deeper theological inquiry into the nature of divine judgment and the consequences of forgetting one's spiritual heritage. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between worldly power and the enduring influence of faith and righteousness.

passage_content: ד) הביא מדרש ויקם מלך הוא פרעה הראשון, אמרו לו בא ונזדווג על אומה זו, אמר להם עד עתה אנו חיים משלהם האיך נזדווג להם ולא שמע אליהם, הורידוהו מכסאו ג' חדשים, כיון שראה כך א"ל אשמע לכם לכך כתוב חדש, וצ"ב טעם טענה זו שאמר פרעה עד עתה אנו חיים משלהם, וכבר פסק הרעב מזמן ביאת יע"א למצרים. וי"ז שנה הי' יעקב במצרים, וכ"ז שא' מן השבטים קיים לא הי' שעבוד ולוי האריך ימים על כולם כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל להלן, א"כ כבר חלפו ועברו הרבה שנים מעת שפסק הרעב. ומה זו טענה שאמר פרעה עד עתה אנו חיים משלהם, גם אין זה ממדת רשעים שלא להיות כפויי טובה וימנעו מלשלם רעה תחת טובה אחרי רבות שנים שחלפו ועברו מעת קבלת טובתם וצ"ב .
translation: D) It brought a Midrash: "And a king arose, who was Pharaoh the first." They said to him, "Come, let us unite with this nation." He said to them, "Until now we have lived off them; how can we unite with them?" And he did not listen to them. They removed him from his throne for three months. When he saw this, he said to them, "I will listen to you; therefore it is written 'new.'" And the question remains regarding the reason for this claim that Pharaoh said, "Until now we have lived off them," when the famine had already ceased since the time of Joseph's arrival in Egypt. Jacob was in Egypt for seventeen years, and as long as one of the tribes was alive, there was no servitude, and Levi outlived them all, as Rashi explains later. Therefore, many years had already passed since the famine ceased. What is this claim that Pharaoh made, "Until now we have lived off them"? Moreover, it is not characteristic of the wicked to be ungrateful and to refrain from repaying evil for good after many years have passed since they received their benefit, and the question remains.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's reluctance to ally with the Israelites, despite their previous contributions to Egypt's prosperity. It highlights the theological concept of gratitude and the expectation that one should not forget past benefits, even after many years. Pharaoh's claim that they had been living off the Israelites' contributions raises questions about the nature of ingratitude and the moral obligations that arise from past kindness. The text emphasizes the importance of recognizing and repaying good deeds, a key theme in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ה) מפני בני ישראל פרש"י ז"ל קצו בחייהם וצ"ב שהכתוב אומר מפני בני ישראל, ובודאי שהמצריים אהבו חיי עצמן רק את חיי בני ישראל לא יכלו נשוא כמשה"כ וימררו את חייהם וגו' ומהו הכוונה שקצו בחייהם.
translation: 5) "Because of the children of Israel," Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that they were fed up with their lives. And it is puzzling why the verse states "because of the children of Israel." Certainly, the Egyptians loved their own lives; it was only the lives of the children of Israel that they could not bear, as it is written, "and they embittered their lives," etc. What is the meaning of their being fed up with their lives?
summary: The passage discusses the Egyptians' hatred for the lives of the Israelites, suggesting that their animosity stemmed from a deep-seated inability to tolerate the existence of the Jewish people. The phrase "they were weary of their lives" indicates a profound spiritual conflict, where the Egyptians, despite valuing their own lives, could not bear the vitality and divine purpose embodied by the Israelites. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the struggle between the forces of holiness and the forces of impurity, emphasizing the existential threat that the righteous pose to those who are spiritually corrupt. Ultimately, it highlights the theological insight that the suffering of the righteous can provoke intense opposition from the wicked.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי המד"ר פ' מקץ (צ' ס"ו) ותרעב כל ארץ מצרים וגו' אשר יאמר לכם תעשו, ר' אבא ב"כ אמר שכפאן למול, ר"ש ב"ר נחמן אמר חייתנו אין כתיב כאן אלא החייתנו נתת לנו חיים בעוה"ז וחיים בעוה"ב עכ"ד המדרש, ופי' רש"י ז"ל דהמילה נקרא חיים כמו שדרז"ל בדמיך חיי עכ"ל, והיפ"ת הקשה על פירושו דמאי חיותייהו בעוה"ב משום מילה כיון דהם עובדי ע"ז אדרבה ראויים ליענש כגוי ששבת שחייב מיתה וכו ', ואין סברא לומר שגיירם לגמרי, דא"כ הם רבים עבדי ד' ואיך נתנו כולם כתף סוררת במות יוסף להשתעבד בישראל עיי"ש שנדחק לפרש דברי המדרש החייתנו בעוה"ב.
translation: And we will explain in advance the words of the Midrash in Parashat Miketz (chapter 66) "And the whole land of Egypt will be famished," etc. "What they tell you, you shall do." Rabbi Abba, son of Kahana, said that they were compelled to circumcise. Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Nachman, said, "We do not find 'He gave us life' written here, but rather 'You gave us life'—You granted us life in this world and life in the World to Come." Thus far the Midrash. And Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that the circumcision is called life, as our sages have said, "In your blood, live." Thus far his words. And the Yip'ta questioned his explanation, asking what life they have in the World to Come because of circumcision, since they are idol worshippers; on the contrary, they are deserving of punishment like a gentile who violates the Sabbath, for which he is liable to death, etc. And it is not reasonable to say that they were completely converted, for if so, they would be many servants of God, and how could they all have turned their backs against Joseph to enslave Israel? Therefore, he was forced to explain the words of the Midrash, "You gave us life in the World to Come."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of life as it relates to the Jewish people and their relationship with God, particularly in the context of the Midrash on the famine in Egypt. It highlights the idea that the act of circumcision (mila) is associated with life, both in this world and the next, as indicated by the interpretation of the term "life" in the context of the Jewish covenant. The text also raises questions about the spiritual status of those who worship idols, suggesting that despite their actions, they are still granted a form of life in the afterlife, which leads to a deeper exploration of divine justice and mercy. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of faith, redemption, and the nature of God's relationship with His people.

passage_content: ויתבאר עפימ"ש האריז"ל בשער הפסוקים (פ' שמות) כי נשמות של דור המבול והפלגה נטבעו בקליפות באומת מצרים וכו' וב' בחי' היו כי יש נשמות שנתקנו לגמרי ונתגלגלו בבני ישראל שבדור ההוא וכו ', ויש בהם נשמות שלא נתקנו ונתגלגלו בבני המצרים עצמם אותן שמל יוסף וכו' והם בחי' הערב רב שעלו עם ישראל עיי"ש, ובס' הליקוטים (פ' שמות) כתב שיחזרו הערב רב להתגלגל בדרא בתראה ומשרע"ה עמהם להשלים תקון נפשם עיי"ש.
translation: And it is explained in the words of the Arizal in the Gate of Verses (Parashat Shemot) that the souls of the generation of the Flood and the Tower of Babel were immersed in the klipot in the nation of Egypt, etc. And there were two categories: there are souls that were completely rectified and were reincarnated in the children of Israel of that generation, etc., and there are souls that were not rectified and were reincarnated in the Egyptians themselves, those who were circumcised by Joseph, etc. And they are the category of the Erev Rav who ascended with Israel, as mentioned there. And in the book of Likutim (Parashat Shemot) it is written that the Erev Rav will return to be reincarnated in the last generation, and Moshe Rabbeinu will be with them to complete the rectification of their souls, as mentioned there.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of reincarnation of souls, specifically those from the generation of the Flood and the Tower of Babel, which became trapped in spiritual klipot (shells) in Egypt. It distinguishes between souls that have been fully rectified and reincarnated into the Jewish people of that generation, and those that remain unrectified, which reincarnated into the Egyptians, including the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) that joined the Israelites. Additionally, it suggests that the Erev Rav will return in a future generation, accompanied by Moses, to complete the rectification of their souls.

passage_content: ולפי"ז יובן כפשוטו מ"ש המצריים החייתנו וכדרשתם ז"ל נתת לנו חיים בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב, דע"י יוסף הצדיק נתקרבו תחת כנפי השכינה ולבסוף ע"י גלגול יהי' תקון לנפשותם ויזכו לעוה"ב, ויוסף הצדיק כפאן כולם למול, ומהם נתברר אח"כ הטוב מן הרע ונדבקו בשורש אומה הישראלית, וז"א ויקם מלך חדש אשר לא ידע את יוסף ות"א דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף דאלו שנתבררו להיות מחלק הרע לא רצו לקיים גזירתו של יוסף להמול להם כל זכר, וקצו ומאסו בחיות דקדושה אשר השפיע עליהם יוסף ע"י המילה, גם לא רצו בחיים של עוה"ב, וע"כ בטלו גזירת המילה של יוסף ולחצו כח הקדושה שבישראל, וז"פ ויקוצו מפני בני ישראל קצו בחייהם שקצו ומאסו בחיות דקדושה וחיות דעוה"ב שהשפיע עליהם יוסף, וע"י שנתרוקנו ועורטלו מכל זיק חיות דקדושה , השפיע זה עליהם לשעבד בבני ישראל.
translation: According to this, it will be understood literally what is said, "The Egyptians made us live," and as your sages have interpreted, "You gave us life in this world and in the World to Come." Through Joseph the Righteous, they drew close under the wings of the Shechinah, and ultimately, through reincarnation, there will be a rectification for their souls, and they will merit the World to Come. And Joseph the Righteous circumcised them all, and from them the good was later distinguished from the bad, and they were attached to the root of the Jewish nation. And it is said, "And a new king arose who did not know Joseph," meaning he did not uphold the decree of Joseph, for those who were clarified to be part of the bad did not want to uphold Joseph's decree to circumcise every male. They were disgusted and rejected the life of holiness that Joseph had imparted to them through circumcision; they also did not want the life of the World to Come. Therefore, they nullified Joseph's decree of circumcision and pressed against the holy power within Israel. And it is said, "And they were distressed because of the children of Israel," meaning they were distressed in their lives because they were disgusted and rejected the life of holiness and the life of the World to Come that Joseph had imparted to them. And by being emptied and stripped of any spark of holy life, this influenced them to enslave the children of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual significance of the Israelites' connection to Joseph, who brought them under the wings of the Divine Presence and facilitated their potential for redemption and eternal life. It highlights that those who rejected Joseph's covenant of circumcision also turned away from the sanctity and vitality of holiness, leading to their spiritual decline. Consequently, this rejection resulted in their oppression of the Israelites, as they distanced themselves from the divine life that Joseph had imparted. Ultimately, the text illustrates the profound impact of spiritual choices on communal identity and destiny.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד במאמה"כ החייתנו וגו', עפי"מ שפירשתי ( בפ ' לך ח"א עמוד ש') על הפסוק ויתן לו מעשר מכל על פי מה שכתב קדושת זקיני הישמח משה זלה"ה כי המעשר שנתן אברהם אבינו ע"ה למלכי צדק לא רצה ליתנה מנכסי סדום, אף שהיו שלו מדינא דמציל מן הנהר ומן הגייס ה"ה שלו, כ"א נתן את המעשר משלו, וז"ש אם אקח מכל אשר לך ואף כדי המעשר לא אנכה, ולא תאמר אני העשרתי וגו' שהמעשר סיבה להתעשר עכת"ד ז"ל, והנה אמרז"ל (ב"ב י"ז ע"א) שלשה הטעימן הקב"ה בעוה"ז מעין עוה"ב אלו הן אברהם יצחק ויעקב וכו' דכתיב בי' בכל מכל כל, פרש"י כל משמע שלא חסרו שום טובה עכ"ל ר"ל דבעוה"ז א"א שיהי' כולל כל הטובות כולן, והנה הנהנה מממון הרשעים קונה קנין רע בנפשו שכח הפועל בנפעל, ואף אם נהנה מהם בעוה"ז, אבל יגרום לו ח"ו אבדון בעוה"ב, וזה ירמוז ויתן לו מעשר "מכל" שנתן לו מעשר משלו, וממון של צדיקים מסוגל להשפיע חיות דקדושה וחיות דעוה"ב הנרמז בתיבת כל כאמרז"ל , וכמו"כ ביוסף הצדיק שכל אדמתם וקנינם של מצרים נקנו אליו, ונהנו מצרים מאוצרותיו הרבה שנים ועי"ז נשפע בהם חיות דקדושה וחיות דעוה"ב , וז"ש החייתנו בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב, ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל (הובא בבעה"ת ) שאמר פרעה עד עתה אנו חיים משלהם האיך נזדווג להם, ר"ל שנשפע עלינו בחי' חיות דקדושה "משלהם" על שנהננו מממונם ותבואתם, וכח זה נלחם בהם ולא הניחם להזדווג בישראל, וז"פ קצו בחייהם שקצו ומאסו בחיות דקדושה .
translation: And even though it is written in the Holy Scriptures, "You have revived us," etc., according to that which I explained (in Parashat Lech Lecha, Part 1, page 26) on the verse "And he gave him a tithe of everything," based on what was written by the holiness of my grandfather, may he rest in peace, that the tithe which our forefather Abraham, peace be upon him, gave to Melchizedek, he did not want to give from the possessions of Sodom, even though they were his by the law of saving from the river and from the army, they were indeed his. Rather, he gave the tithe from his own possessions, and this is what he meant when he said, "If I take anything from all that is yours, even a tithe I will not take," and you should not say, "I have made you rich," etc., for the tithe is a cause for becoming wealthy, thus he said, may his memory be blessed. And behold, our sages said (Baba Batra 17a) that the Holy One, blessed be He, has given three tastes in this world that are a taste of the World to Come; these are Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, etc., as it is written about them, "in all, from all, everything," Rashi explains that "everything" means that they lacked no good. This means that in this world it is impossible for it to include all the good things. And behold, one who benefits from the money of the wicked acquires a bad acquisition for his soul, for the power of the doer is in the acted upon, and even if he benefits from them in this world, it will cause him, Heaven forbid, destruction in the World to Come. This is hinted at in "And he gave him a tithe 'from all,'" that he gave him a tithe from his own, and the money of the righteous is capable of imparting vitality of holiness and the vitality of the World to Come, which is hinted at in the word "everything," as our sages have said. Likewise, with Joseph the righteous, all the land and possessions of Egypt were acquired by him, and the Egyptians benefited from his treasures for many years, and through this, they received vitality of holiness and the vitality of the World to Come. This is what is meant by "You have revived us in this world and in the World to Come." And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash (brought in the Baal HaTurim) that Pharaoh said, "Until now we live from their possessions, how can we be joined with them?" meaning that we receive upon us a kind of vitality of holiness "from their possessions" since we have benefited from their money and their produce. And this power fought against them and did not allow them to be joined with Israel, and thus it is written, "They were weary of their lives," for they were weary and rejected the vitality of holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Abraham's tithe to Melchizedek, emphasizing that he chose to give from his own possessions rather than from the spoils of Sodom, highlighting the importance of purity in giving. It explains that enjoying the wealth of the wicked can lead to spiritual detriment, while the wealth of the righteous imparts divine vitality and blessings in both this world and the next. The text also illustrates how the righteous, like Joseph, can channel holiness and life through their possessions, impacting others positively. Ultimately, it conveys that true spiritual life comes from engaging with the righteous and their resources, rather than the corrupt.

passage_content: ולבאר יתר הדקדוקים נקדים דברי המדרש (הובא ברש"י ז"ל) אע"פ שמנאן בחייהן בשמותם , חזר ומנאן במיתתן להודיע חיבתן שנמשלו לכוכבים שמוציאן ומכניסן במספר ובשמותם שנא' המוציא במספר צבאם לכולם בשם יקרא עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין מהו אות החיבה בקריאות שמותם, הלא כמו"כ האומה"ע נקראו בשמותם , ונקדים עוד דברי הגמ ' ברכות ז' ע"ב) מאי רות א"ר יוחנן שזכתה ויצא ממנה דוד שריוהו להקב"ה בשירות ותשבחות, מנא לן דשמא גרים. אר"א דאמר קרא (תהלים מ"ו) לכו חזו מפעלות אלקים אשר שם שמות בארץ אל תקרי שמות אלא שמות עכ"ד הגמ ', וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל מנלן דשמא גרים כי הכא דשמה רות גרם שיצא ממנה דוד, וקמייתי לה מדכתיב לכו חזו מפעלות אלקים אשר שם שמות בארץ וכו ', שפעולות ד' נמשכים אחר השם של אדם שהוא גרם עכ"ל, ומצינו גם להיפך שאמרז"ל מרגלים ע"ש מעשיהם נקראו, סתור בן מיכאל שסתר דבריו של הקב"ה וכן כולהו , הרי דשמא גרם לריעותא , והנה בודאי שאין השם מכריח לבטל הבחירה, ועדיין הבחירה באדם להרע או להטיב. והמרגלים מעיקרא צדיקים גמורים היו ואפשר שהוא כבחי' הידיעה והבחירה, שאין הידיעה מבטל ומשולל הבחירה מבנ"א, כמו"כ השם הוא בבחי ' ידיעתו ית ' ואינו מבטל הבחירה.
translation: To explain the additional nuances of the grammar, we will precede with the words of the Midrash (as brought by Rashi, may his memory be blessed) that although they were counted in their lifetime by their names, they were counted again at their death to indicate their belovedness, as they are compared to the stars, which are brought out and brought in by number and by their names, as it is said, "He brings out their host by number; He calls them all by name" (Isaiah 40:26). Thus said the Midrash. It is fitting to understand what is the sign of affection in calling their names, for similarly, the nations of the world are called by their names. We will also precede with the words of the Gemara (Berakhot 7b): "What is Ruth? Rabbi Yochanan said: She was worthy, and from her came David, and they sang to the Holy One, blessed be He, with songs and praises. From where do we know that they are called 'converts'? Rabbi Abba said, as the verse states (Psalms 46:8), 'Come, behold the works of God, who has made desolations in the earth.' Do not read 'desolations' but 'names.'" Thus said the Gemara. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote: From where do we know that they are called 'converts'? Because here, Ruth caused that David should come from her, and I bring it to you from the verse, "Come, behold the works of God, who has made names in the earth," etc. For the actions of the Holy One, blessed be He, follow the name of a person, which he has caused. And we also find the opposite, as our Sages said: The spies were called after their deeds, as in the case of Sefor ben Michal, who contradicted the words of the Holy One, blessed be He, and so with all of them. Thus, it is that perhaps the name caused a negative outcome. And behold, certainly the name does not compel the cancellation of free will, and the choice remains with a person to do evil or good. And the spies were originally completely righteous, and it is possible that it is like the aspect of knowledge and choice, that knowledge does not negate or remove the choice from a person. Similarly, the name is in the aspect of His knowledge, blessed be He, and does not negate choice.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of names in relation to divine love and choice, drawing parallels between the naming of individuals and the nation of Israel, likening them to stars that are counted and called by name. It emphasizes that while names reflect one's essence and actions, they do not negate free will, as individuals still possess the choice to do good or evil. The text also highlights that even those who may have initially been righteous can choose to act contrary to their nature, illustrating the coexistence of divine knowledge and human free will. Ultimately, it affirms that God's knowledge of a person's name does not compel their actions, preserving the integrity of human choice.

passage_content: וביאור הענין עפימ"ש בספה"ק דבחי ' השם הוא לערך הנפש שבו, והשם זה הוא חיותו, וסמכו לי' אהאי קרא וכל אשר יקרא לו האדם נפש חי' הוא שמו, וכתב הבאר מים חיים זלה"ה (פ' בראשית) שמעתי מפי אדמו"ר נזר ישראל וקדושו אור עולם המפורסם מו"ה יחיאל מיכל זצוקללה"ה , שאמר לי בפירוש שחלילה לשנות שם אדם החולה, אם לא אדם שכל מעשיו כמעט ברוה"ק, כי שם הנקרא לאדם בעת הוולדו ודאי רובו ככולו מזדמן מאת הקב"ה באשר הוא שמו למעלה והוא חיותו של אדם כל ימיו וכו ', והנה החולה ודאי צריך לחיזוק ביותר ולפעמים אין לו חיזוק אחר כ"א זה החיזוק של השם, ואם עוקרין אותו כדרך שאומרין ומעתה לא יעקב יקרא עוד שמך וכו ', והשם השני אפשר כי לא מחיותו הוא ונשאר בלא מחזיק החיות שלו עכדז"ל , ופי' הכתוב וכל אשר יקרא לו האדם נפש חי' הוא שמו. כלומר לא קרא להן שמות לפי שכל אנושי וכו ', כי אם עיקר קריאת השמות הי' לנפש חי' שבהן, כי הביט למקור שורש חיותן במרכבה העליונה וכו ', ע"כ סיים הוא שמו כלומר הוא שמו למעלה באמת עכ"ד הבמ"ח זלה"ה , ואפשר דאין קפידא כ"א לעקור שם הראשון ולהחליפו באחר, אבל להוסיף עוד שם על שם הראשון שפיר דמי וכבר נהוג עלמא הכי דאין גורעין ועוקרין שם הראשון כלל.
translation: And the explanation of the matter, as it is written in the holy books, is that the name corresponds to the soul within it, and this name is its vitality. And support me with this verse: "And whatever the man calls each living creature, that is its name." And I heard from my teacher, the Rebbe Nazer Yisrael, and his holiness, the renowned light of the world, Rabbi Yechiel Michal, may his memory be blessed, who explicitly told me that it is forbidden to change the name of a sick person, unless the person is one whose actions are almost entirely guided by the Holy Spirit, for the name given to a person at birth is certainly mostly determined by the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is his name above, and it is the vitality of the person throughout his life, etc. And behold, the sick person certainly needs strengthening, and sometimes he has no other support except for this strengthening of the name. And if one uproots it, as it is said, "And from now on your name shall no longer be called..." the second name may not be from his vitality, and he remains without the support of his vitality, as it is said. And the explanation of the verse, "And whatever the man calls each living creature, that is its name," means that he did not call them names according to human intellect, etc., but rather the essence of naming was for the living soul within them, for he looked to the source of their vitality in the upper chariot, etc. Therefore, it concludes, "He is his name," meaning he is truly his name above. Thus said the holy one, may his memory be blessed. And it is possible that there is no prohibition except to uproot the first name and replace it with another, but to add another name to the first name is permissible, and it is already customary in the world that one does not diminish or uproot the first name at all.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of a person's name in relation to their soul, emphasizing that a name is divinely ordained and represents the individual's life force. It warns against changing the name of a sick person, as their original name provides essential spiritual support. The text highlights that names are not merely human constructs but reflect the deeper spiritual essence of a person, rooted in a higher divine source. While it is permissible to add names, the original name should remain intact, as it is integral to the person's identity and vitality.

passage_content: עוד כתבו ז"ל דכמו שיש נפש דקדושה ונפש דסט"א זלע"ז , וע"י מעשה הטוב נמשך ונדבק בו נפש דקדושה , וחלילה ע"י מעשה הרע ממשיך עליו נפש טמא מסטרא דקליפות . כמו"כ יש שם דקדושה שנקרא בו למעלה דמאתו ית ' לא תצא הרעות וזהו חיותו בנפש דקדושה , ואם ח"ו מקלקל מעשיו ממשיך על עצמו ר"ל נפש דסט"א , וגם בחי' השם נשתנה לשם דסט"א , דבחי ' השם הוא לערך הנפש שבו, ( וכעי"ז הבאנו לעיל בשם ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה עיי"ש) ובזה א"ש אמרם ז"ל שמא גרים, דבאיכות השם תליא מהות המעשים וכמו"כ להיפך, וז"פ שלא שינו את שמם, ונכלל בו ג"כ שלא שינו את מעשיהם, דאל"כ ישתנה גם שמותם בהכרח, וזהו הכוונה בזוה"ק בני ישראל עאלו בני ישראל נפקו שנשארו בשם דקדושה על דאסתמרו מהני תלתא וכו'
translation: They also wrote, may their memory be blessed, that just as there is a holy soul and a soul from the other side, one corresponding to the other, through good deeds a holy soul is drawn and clings to him, and God forbid, through evil deeds a defiled soul from the side of the klipot is drawn upon him. Likewise, there is a name of holiness that is called above, from His blessed essence, "the evil shall not go forth," and this is the vitality in the holy soul. And if, God forbid, he corrupts his deeds, he draws upon himself, so to speak, a soul from the other side, and also the aspect of the name changes to the name of the other side, for the aspect of the name is in relation to the soul within it. (And similarly, we brought above in the name of K.Z. Heitev Lev, may his memory be blessed, see there.) And in this, it is understood what they said, may their memory be blessed, that perhaps they are converts, for the quality of the name depends on the essence of the deeds, and likewise the opposite, and it is clear that they did not change their name, which also includes that they did not change their deeds, for otherwise their names would necessarily change as well. This is the intention in the Zohar that "the children of Israel ascended," "the children of Israel went out," that they remained with a name of holiness because they guarded themselves from these three things, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the duality of the soul, emphasizing the existence of both a holy soul (Nefesh Kedushah) and an impure soul (Nefesh St'ah). It explains that through good deeds, one can connect to the holy soul, while sinful actions draw upon the impure soul. The text also highlights the significance of one's name, which reflects the quality of their actions; a change in behavior would necessitate a change in name. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that maintaining a holy name is contingent upon adhering to righteous conduct.

passage_content: ואגב נל"פ מ"ש בברכות שלאחר המילה קיים את הילד הזה וכו' ויקרא שמו בישראל פלוני בן פלוני ישמח האב וכו ', ראוי להבין מ"ע להפסיק בקריאת השם באמצע התפלה, והי"ל להקדימו או לאחרו, גם היל"ל ונקרא שמו, גם מלת בישראל מיותר ומובן מאליו שבישראל יהי' קורין לו בשם זה ולא באומה"ע , אמנם כל זה הוא תפלה להבוי"ת , ויתבאר עפימ"ד בזו"ח מדרש הנעלם (דף י"ג ע"א) א"ר יוחנן מה דכתיב אל הנער הזה התפללתי, הול"ל אל הבן הזה התפללתי, אלא אמרה חנה יהי רצון בשעה שיגדל ישתדל בעבודת המקום כמו עכשיו שהוא נער, וכל אדם שיזכה להיות בזקנותו כמו בנערותו יזכה למעלת שמואל הנביא עיי"ש, וז"פ קיים את הילד הזה שיתקיים בבחי ' ילד להיות נקי מחטא גם בזקנותו, וע"ד שדרשו ז"ל בן שנה יהואש במלכו שהי' נקי מחטא כבן שנה, ויקרא שמו בישראל וכו' שזה השם אשר קראו לו למעלה הוא מזדמן מהקב"ה לאביו כנ"ל, ואנו מתפללין שכל ימי חייו יקרא שמו גם בישראל כן ולא ישתנה בחי' השם ע"י פעולת המעשים לרוע ח"ו.
translation: And by the way, it is necessary to understand what is mentioned in the blessings after the circumcision, "You have established this child," etc., and "His name shall be called in Israel so-and-so, son of so-and-so; may the father rejoice," etc. It is appropriate to understand the obligation to pause in the naming during the prayer, and it would have been fitting to either precede it or follow it. Also, it should have said, "And his name shall be called," and the word "in Israel" is superfluous and self-evident that in Israel he will be called by this name and not by another nation. However, all of this is a prayer for the future. It will be explained according to the teachings of the Zohar, Midrash HaNe'elam (page 13, side A), where Rabbi Yochanan said, "What is written, 'For this boy I prayed'? It should have said, 'For this son I prayed.' Rather, Hannah said, 'May it be Your will that when he grows up, he will strive in the service of the Holy One, just as he is now a boy.' And any person who merits to be in his old age as he was in his youth will merit the status of Samuel the Prophet, as mentioned there. Thus, 'You have established this child' means that he should remain in the aspect of a child, being pure from sin even in his old age, in accordance with what our sages have taught regarding Yehoash, who was king at the age of one and was pure from sin like a one-year-old. And 'His name shall be called in Israel,' etc., this name that was called for him above is ordained by the Holy One, Blessed be He, for his father, as mentioned above. And we pray that all the days of his life, his name shall be called in Israel as such, and that the aspect of the name should not change through the actions of deeds for the worse, Heaven forbid.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of naming a child during prayer, emphasizing the importance of maintaining a pure and righteous character throughout one's life, akin to the innocence of youth. It references Hannah's prayer for her son Samuel, expressing a desire for him to remain devoted to God as he matures. The text highlights that the name given to the child is divinely ordained and should reflect a lifelong commitment to holiness, suggesting that one's actions should not alter this divine identity. Ultimately, it conveys a deep theological insight into the relationship between a person's name, their spiritual journey, and the hope for their continued righteousness.
