passage_content: נחזור לראש דברינו לבאר דברי המדרש ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים, ואפ"ל ע"ד שדרשו רז"ל עה"פ ויתן לך האלקים , יתן ויחזור ויתן , וכתב הרא"ם ז"ל בפ ' תולדות, לפי שמשפט הוא"ו מורה על התוספת בהכרח, ולא קדמה ברכה אחרת קודם ברכת ויתן לך, ולפיכך הוכרחו רז"ל לדרוש יתן ויחזור ויתן , ר"ל שהתוספת הנרמז בוא"ו יתקיים לאחרי' ובלי הפסק לעולם עכת"ד ז"ל, ועד"ז יתפרש כאן ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים דא"א לדרשו שזהו תוס ' על הקדום אליו דהם הם אשר נזכרו למעלה, ובהכרח לפרש שנתקיים התוספת לאח"כ ונמשך שלשלת הקדושה לדורות, וסמכו זה להפסוק ואלה שמות בני ישראל, שנשארו בשמות דקדושה כל זמן היותם במצרים וכמ"ש בזוה"ק בנ"י עאלו ובנ"י נפקו ובזכות זה נגאלו, וז"פ דברי המדרש ואלה שמות בנ"י זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתיך , דאם מקושר האדם בשם שניתן לו מהקב"ה, אזי נדבק במקור חיותו בקדושה ואז יכול להלל להקב"ה, משא"כ להיפך ח"ו דשמא גרים כנ"ל.
translation: We will return to the beginning of our discussion to explain the words of the Midrash, and these [words] add to the earlier ones. And I could say, according to what our Sages have interpreted on the verse "and God will give you," that He will give and will return to give. And the Ra'ah"m wrote in Parashat Toldot that since the letter "vav" indicates an addition necessarily, and there was no other blessing that preceded the blessing of "and He will give you," therefore our Sages were compelled to interpret "He will give and will return to give," meaning that the addition hinted at by the "vav" will be fulfilled afterwards and will continue without interruption forever, thus he concluded. And similarly, it can be explained here that "and these" adds to the earlier ones, for it cannot be interpreted that this is an addition to what preceded it, which are those mentioned above. It is necessary to interpret that the addition was fulfilled afterwards and the chain of holiness continued for generations. They supported this with the verse "and these are the names of the children of Israel," who remained in names of holiness as long as they were in Egypt, as it is written in the Zohar that the children of Israel ascended and the children of Israel descended, and by virtue of this, they were redeemed. This is the meaning of the words of the Midrash "and these are the names of the children of Israel," as it is said, "as Your name, O God, so is Your praise," for if a person is connected to the name given to him by the Holy One, blessed be He, then he is attached to the source of his life in holiness, and then he can praise the Holy One, blessed be He. However, the opposite is true, God forbid, that perhaps they are strangers, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine blessing and continuity in the context of the names of the Israelites, emphasizing that the addition of "ו" (vav) signifies an eternal connection to holiness. It highlights that the names given by God maintain their sanctity, allowing the Israelites to remain spiritually linked to their source of life and enabling them to praise God. The text underscores the importance of one's name as a reflection of their divine connection, suggesting that this connection is crucial for spiritual redemption and continuity through generations.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל עפימ"ש הבעה"ט דנרמז כאן שבת ומילה שבזכות אלו נגאלו ישראל עיי"ש, ואיתא בזוה"ק מאי שבת שמא דקוב"ה וכו ', ומילה ג"כ ירמוז על זה כמ"ש האוהחה"ק (פ' תזריע) עה"פ וביום השמיני ימול וגו' עפימ"ש בתיקונים כי ג' בחי' יש במצוה זו, והמעולה שבכולן הוא מילת בניהם של צדיקים בני קל חי, מילה זו הוא להם גילוי שמו ית ' החתום בבשר קודש והוא עטרת היסוד וכו ', וז"פ ימול יו"ד מול כי הוא מגלה רשימו קדישא אות י' וכו' בשמו ית ' עכ"ד, וז"פ כשמך הרמוז כאן כן תהלתיך על קצוי ארץ, כי השומר שבת נותנין לו נחלה בלי מצרים, צדק מלאה ימינך, דעי"ז יזכו ישראל לביאת המשיח שהוא בימינו של הקב"ה כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש ילקוט (תהלים ק"ו) עה"פ שב לימיני עיי"ש.
translation: It can also be said according to the words of the Baal HaTanya that it is hinted here to Shabbat and circumcision, by virtue of which Israel was redeemed, as mentioned there. And it is stated in the Zohar, "What is Shabbat? It is the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He," etc. And circumcision also hints at this, as it is written in the holy teachings (Parashat Tazria) regarding the verse "And on the eighth day, he shall be circumcised," according to what is said in the Tikkunim, that there are three aspects in this commandment, and the most exalted of all is the circumcision of the sons of the righteous, children of the living God. This circumcision is for them a revelation of His blessed name, which is sealed in the holy flesh, and it is the crown of the foundation, etc. Thus, it is said, "He shall be circumcised," the letter Yud, for it reveals the holy impression of the letter Yud, etc., in His blessed name. Therefore, it is said, "As Your name, so is Your praise to the ends of the earth," for one who observes Shabbat is given an inheritance without measure, "Righteousness is full in Your right hand." Through this, Israel will merit the coming of the Messiah, who is in the days of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash Yalkut (Psalms 106) regarding the verse "He has returned to my right hand," as mentioned there.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Shabbat and circumcision as key mitzvot through which the Jewish people were redeemed. It highlights that both practices reveal divine attributes, with circumcision symbolizing a deeper connection to God's name and essence. The text emphasizes that observing Shabbat grants a person a boundless inheritance, and through these mitzvot, the Jewish people can merit the coming of the Messiah, aligning with God's ultimate plan.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד עפי"ד המדרש ואלה שמות בנ"י , ע"ש גאולתם נזכרו כאן ונרמז בשמותם גם גאולה העתידה ב"ב, כמ"ש יוסף ע"ש יוסיף ה' שנית ידו וגו', ולזה סמכו כאן לואלה שמות בנ"י שנרמז בו גאולה העתידה, זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתיך , דגאולה העתידה תהי' למען שמו ית ' כמ"ש למעני למעני אעשה, וז"פ כשמך אלקים בשביל שמך ית ' שלא יתחלל בגוים, כן תהלתיך על קצוי ארץ, ראוי שתשלח משיח צדקינו במהרה, ואז יהי' גדול ה' ומהולל מאוד בכל הארץ ומלאה הארץ דעה את ה', ונזכה במהרה לראות הישועה האמיתית בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And even according to the interpretation of the Midrash and these are the names of the children of Israel, concerning their redemption they are mentioned here, and their names hint at the future redemption, as it is said, Joseph, because He will add, the Lord will add His hand again, etc. Therefore, they are connected here to "these are the names of the children of Israel," which hints at the future redemption. This is as it is written, "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise," for the future redemption will be for the sake of His name, as it is said, "For My sake, for My sake I will act." And the verse is clear: "As Your name, O God, for the sake of Your name, so shall be Your praise at the ends of the earth." It is fitting that You should send our righteous Messiah speedily, and then the Lord will be great and greatly praised throughout the earth, and the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the Lord. May we merit soon to see the true salvation with the upliftment of the horn of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between the names of the Children of Israel and their future redemption, suggesting that their names hint at the ultimate redemption to come. It highlights the idea that God's future salvation will be for His name's sake, ensuring that His name is not desecrated among the nations. The text expresses a longing for the coming of the righteous Messiah, which will lead to a universal recognition of God's greatness and the fulfillment of His glory on earth. Ultimately, it calls for a swift realization of true salvation, marked by the elevation of the Torah and the Jewish people.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרשים הנ"ל ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה וגו', וכי היום באו, והלא ימים רבים הי' להם שבאו למצרים, אלא כל זמן שיוסף הי' קיים, לא הי' להם משוי של מצרים, מת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי וכו' וצ"ב , עוד במדרש ואלה שמות וגו' הוסיף שבח על שבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם היו צדיקים וצ"ב (וכבר נזכרו הדקדוקים לעיל). ב)
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the aforementioned Midrashim and these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt, etc. And did they come today? But they had many days that they came to Egypt. Rather, as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt. When Joseph died, they imposed a burden upon them, etc. And this requires further investigation. Additionally, in the Midrash, regarding "And these are the names," it adds praise for the seventy souls mentioned above, that they were all righteous, and this requires further investigation (and the nuances have already been mentioned above).
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "These are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt," emphasizing that the Israelites' arrival in Egypt was not merely a physical journey but also a spiritual transition. It suggests that as long as Joseph was alive, the Israelites did not bear the burdens of Egypt, indicating that his presence provided them with protection and dignity. The text also highlights the righteousness of the seventy souls who descended to Egypt, underscoring their spiritual stature and the importance of maintaining a connection to their heritage amidst adversity.

passage_content: ויקם מלך חדש אשר לא ידע את יוסף בת"א דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף וצ"ב הכוונה. ונל"פ בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פרשה זו (דף ט"ז ע"ב) ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים א"ר שמעון בההוא יומא אתיהיב לי' רשותא לשרו של מצרים על כל שאר עמין , דתנא עד דלא מית יוסף לא אתיהיב שלטנו לשלטנא דמצרים על ישראל, כיון דמית יוסף כדין ויקם מלך חדש. ויקם כמאן דהוה מאיך וקם עכ"ד הזוה"ק , וביאור הענין דהנה כך הטביע היוצר ב"ה במעשה בראשית שלכל אומה נתן שר ומושל בשמים, ומסר הבוי"ת הנהגת האומה ושלטנותה בידו, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל ( בפ ' ואתחנן) עה"פ אשר חלק ד' אלקיך אותם לכל העמים, כי לכולם כוכב ומזל ושר ידוע, וגבוהים עליהם מלאכי עליון, כגון הנאמר בדניאל שר מלכי פרס ושר מלכות יון וכו' עכ"ל, אולם יוסף הצדיק הכניעו לשר של מצרים ולא אתיהיב לי' רשותא ושלטנא, ואף שהוא מתנאי וחוקי הבריאה להיות השר מושל על בני מדינתו, אבל הצדיק בכחו לבעל זאת ע"ד מי מושל בו צדיק וצדיק גוזר הקב"ה מקיים, ואחר שמת יוסף ויקם מלך חדש, שחזר לשלטנותו , וז"ש בזוה"ק כמאן דהוה מאיך וקם, שהי' נכנע והורד משררותו כ"ז שיוסף קיים, ועכשיו קם וחזר לגדולתו, וז"ש בת"א דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף, ר"ל גזירת צדיק גוזר שהי' מכניעו עד עכשיו, וזהו טעם ויקם מלך חדש שחזר לשלטנותו , ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל הבאים מצרימה, כ"ז שיוסף הי' קיים לא הי' להם משוי של מצרים מת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי, דעד עכשיו לא הי' לשר של מצרים שלטנות עליהם כלל, שניטל שררותו ע"י גזירת יוסף, ואחר שמת יוסף תקומה הי' לו וחזר לשררותו , ולפי"ז אומרו ויקם מלך חדש הכוונה על השר של מצרים, וע"כ לא כתיב וימת וימלוך והבן.
translation:
And a new king arose who did not know Joseph, in the sense that he did not uphold the decree of Joseph, and the intention is unclear. It seems that we should first consider the words of the Zohar in this section (page 16b): "And a new king arose over Egypt." Rabbi Shimon said, "On that day, permission was given to the minister of Egypt over all the other nations, for it was taught that until Joseph died, our sovereignty was not given to the sovereignty of Egypt over Israel. Once Joseph died, then 'a new king arose.' He arose as one who was already there and stood up." Thus far the Zohar. 

The explanation of the matter is that the Creator, blessed be He, instilled in the act of creation that for every nation, He appointed a minister and ruler in the heavens, and He entrusted the governance and sovereignty of the nation into their hands, as it is written by Ramban (in Parashat Va'etchanan) regarding the verse "which the Lord your God has divided to all the nations," for each has a star, a constellation, and a known minister, and above them are the high angels, as mentioned regarding Daniel, the minister of the kings of Persia and the minister of the kingdom of Greece, etc. 

However, Joseph the righteous subdued the minister of Egypt and did not give him permission and sovereignty, and although it is a condition and law of creation for the minister to rule over his nation, the righteous has the power to possess this, as it is said, "Who rules over him? The righteous, and the Holy One, blessed be He, fulfills the decree of the righteous." And after Joseph died, "a new king arose," who returned to his sovereignty. This is what is meant in the Zohar by "as one who was already there and stood up," that he was subdued and removed from his authority as long as Joseph was alive, and now he arose and returned to his greatness. 

And this is what is meant by "who did not uphold the decree of Joseph," meaning the decree of the righteous that had subdued him until now. This is the reason for "a new king arose" who returned to his sovereignty. And this clarifies the words of the aforementioned Midrash that when they came to Egypt, as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt; when Joseph died, they placed a burden upon them, for until now the minister of Egypt had no sovereignty over them at all, as his authority was taken away by the decree of Joseph. And after Joseph died, he had a revival and returned to his authority. Therefore, it is said "and a new king arose," referring to the minister of Egypt, and thus it is not written "and he died and reigned," understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the emergence of a new king in Egypt after the death of Joseph, emphasizing that Joseph's righteousness had previously subdued the Egyptian ruler, preventing him from exercising authority over the Israelites. It highlights the Hasidic belief that each nation has a celestial ruler, but a righteous individual like Joseph can diminish that ruler's power. With Joseph's death, the Egyptian ruler regained his authority, illustrating the concept that the presence of a tzaddik (righteous person) can significantly influence spiritual and worldly governance. The text underscores the idea that divine decrees made by the righteous can shape the fate of nations.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר עפ"י דברינו לעיל (פ' מקץ עמוד ש"פ) בטעם גזירת יוסף שגזר על כל מצרים שימולו כמ"ש במד"ר פ' מקץ עה"פ אשר יאמר לכם תעשו. ופירשנו עפי"ד הילקוט ראובני (פ' וישלח) בשם גליא רזיא , שכשהרגו השבטים את אנשי שכם, בא ס"מ ותבע דין עליהם לפני ב"ד של מעלה, והשיבו לו ב"ד של מעלה שאין לו רשות רק על הערלים שהם מסיטרא דילי', ולפי שאנשי שכם נימולו כולם בעטו בך ואין לך עוד רשות עליהם, ויצא מלפני הב"ד אבל וחפוי ראש עכת"ד ואולי לזה הטעם התחכמו בני יעקב ואמרו להם להמול , כדי שלא יוכל הס"מ להתגבר עליהם בקטרוגו, וז"א ויענו בני יעקב את שכם וגו' במרמה, ופי' התרגומים בחוכמתא , כי הי' בזה חכמה נפלאה להסיר מהם קטרוגו של הס"מ ראש השטנים, ועד"ז אפ"ל בטעמו של יוסף הצדיק שגזר על כל מצרים שימולו, כדי להוציאם מרשותו של הס"מ שהוא ראש כל שרי האומות, ועי"ז יוסר כוחו מלהתגבר גם על ישראל הדרים בארצם, אמנם אחר שמת יוסף ביטלו המצרים גזירתו של יוסף ולא מלו א"ע עוד, ועי"ז חזרו תחת רשותו של הס"מ, וז"א ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים היינו שהס"מ נעשה למלך עליהם, והטעם דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף, לפי שביטלו גזירת המילה שגזר יוסף עליהם ולפי"ז דברי רב ושמואל ופי' התרגום מתאימים ובקנה א' עולים, דלפי שנתחדשו גזירותיו לבטל מהם גזירת יוסף עי"ז קם מלך חדש ממש והבן.
translation: And I can also explain it in another way according to our words above (Parashat Miketz, page 85) regarding the reason for Joseph's decree that all of Egypt should be circumcised, as it is written in the Midrash, Parashat Miketz, on the verse "which he will say to you, you shall do." We explained according to the words of the Yalkut Reuveni (Parashat Vayishlach) in the name of Galya Razia, that when the brothers killed the men of Shechem, the Satan came and demanded judgment against them before the heavenly court, and the heavenly court responded to him that he has no authority except over the uncircumcised, who are from his side. And since all the men of Shechem were circumcised, they kicked you out, and you have no more authority over them. And he left the heavenly court but with a bowed head. Perhaps for this reason, the sons of Jacob were clever and told them to circumcise, so that the Satan would not be able to overpower them with his accusations. And it says, "And the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and his father deceitfully," and the translations explain it as wisdom, for there was a wonderful wisdom in this to remove from them the accusation of the Satan, the head of the accusers. Similarly, it can be explained regarding the reason of Joseph the righteous who decreed that all of Egypt should be circumcised, in order to remove them from the authority of the Satan, who is the head of all the princes of the nations, and thereby his power would be removed from overpowering also the Israelites dwelling in their land. However, after Joseph died, the Egyptians annulled Joseph's decree and did not circumcise themselves anymore, and as a result, they returned under the authority of the Satan. And it says, "And a new king arose over Egypt," meaning that the Satan became a king over them, and the reason is that they did not uphold Joseph's decree, for they annulled the decree of circumcision that Joseph had decreed upon them. According to this, the words of Rav and Shmuel and the explanation of the translation align and rise in one measure, for since his decrees were renewed to annul the decree of Joseph from them, a new king truly arose. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's decree for the Egyptians to circumcise themselves, which was intended to remove them from the influence of the Satan, who has authority over the uncircumcised. It suggests that the sons of Jacob acted wisely by encouraging the Shechemites to circumcise themselves to avoid the Satan's accusations. After Joseph's death, the Egyptians abandoned this decree, thereby returning under the Satan's dominion, which is symbolized by the rise of a new king in Egypt. This reflects the theological concept that adherence to divine commandments can protect individuals and nations from spiritual adversaries.

passage_content: או"י עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בטעם מצות מילה שהוא להחליש כח התאוה עיי"ש, והאריז"ל כתב בסודן של דברים שכח מצוה זו מצלת מיצרא דעריות , ואמרז"ל במד"ר עה"פ כמעשה ארץ מצרים וגו' מלמד שהיו מעשיהם מקולקלין יותר מכל האומות, ובפרט ביצרא דעריות , שהיו שטופי זימה מאוד ומזוהמים ומקולקלים מכל האומות, ע"כ חשש יוסף שיהי' קשה לישראל מאוד להתגבר על יצרא דעריות לצד היותם בארצם, וטבע האדם להימשך אחר אנשי מדינתו, ולטעם זה גזר עליהם להמול , כדי להחליש כח תאותם , אמנם אחר שמת יוסף. לא הי' מקיימים מצות מילה עוד, וז"א דלא מקיים גזירת יוסף היינו גזירת המילה, ונעשו מקולקלים יותר, ועי"ז ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים, שהמליכו הס"מ עליהם. והתגברו המצריים על ישראל מאוד להחטיאם, וזלע"ז התגברו בני ישראל לנגדם ועמדו בקדושתם, כמ"ש בזוה"ק דאסתמרו ישראל מעריות מנדה ובת אל נכר וכו '.
translation: The Rambam, may his memory be blessed, explains the reason for the commandment of circumcision is to weaken the power of desire, as mentioned there. The Arizal wrote in the secret of these matters that the power of this commandment saves from the evil inclination of immorality. The sages said in the Midrash on the verse "like the deeds of the land of Egypt," teaching that their actions were more corrupt than all the nations, especially in the evil inclination of immorality, as they were very lustful and defiled and corrupted more than all the nations. Therefore, Joseph was concerned that it would be very difficult for Israel to overcome the evil inclination of immorality due to their being in their land, and it is human nature to be drawn after the people of their nation. For this reason, he decreed upon them to circumcise, in order to weaken the power of their desires. However, after Joseph died, they no longer fulfilled the commandment of circumcision. The meaning of "they did not fulfill Joseph's decree" refers to the decree of circumcision, and they became more corrupt. As a result, "a new king arose over Egypt," who appointed the evil inclination over them. The Egyptians became very strong against Israel to lead them astray, and in response, the children of Israel strengthened themselves against them and stood in their holiness, as it is written in the Zohar that Israel guarded themselves from immorality, from the daughter of a foreign god, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the commandment of circumcision (Brit Milah) as a means to weaken the power of lust, particularly in the context of the Israelites' struggle against immorality in Egypt. It highlights the concern of Joseph that the Israelites would find it difficult to resist the temptations of the Egyptians, who were deeply corrupt and immoral. After Joseph's death, the Israelites neglected the commandment, leading to increased moral decay and the rise of a new oppressive king in Egypt. Despite this, the Israelites managed to maintain their sanctity and resist temptation, as noted in the Zohar, emphasizing the importance of spiritual vigilance against external influences.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ש בספ"ק נועם מגדים (פ' זו) לפרש הפסוק הבה נתחכמה לו וגו', דהרשע ע"י שמיצר להצדיק, הצדיק בא לידי הכנעה וענו' יותר ומתחזק הנשמה יותר, וזהו מאמר פרעה אחר אומרו הבה נתחכמה לו להצדיק, ושמא תאמר מה צריך חכמה, נתחיל להצר לו כדרך אנשי רשע, לז"א כי זה הבל מהיות, והי' כי תקראנה מלחמה ונוסף גם הוא וכו ', ר"ל שהמלחמה תוסף עוד צדקת הצדיק, ובהיות כן המלחמה שנלחם וכו ', הרי זה כלוחם עם עצמו וזהו ונלחם בנו ר"ל אנחנו נלחם עם עצמינו וכו ', שע"י מלחמתינו ונשגב צדיק בצדקתו יותר, ולזה צריך התחכמות כאומרו הבה נתחכמה עכת"ד ז"ל, נמצא שע"י המלחמה שלחמו המצרים נגד בני ישראל לבטלם מקדושתם, התגברו הם לעומתם ביתר שאת וניתוסף צדקתם וקדושתם, ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש ואלה שמות וגו' הוסיף שבח על ע' נפש שנאמרו למעלה, שכולם צדיקים היו, עפימ"ש במדרש הבאים מצרים כאילו היום באו, דעד עכשיו לא היו עליהם משוי של מצרים, וע"י שהתגברו המצריים לעומתם, נתוסף צדקתם וקדושתם יותר.
translation: And we will precede what is stated in the first chapter of Noam Megadim (this section) to explain the verse "Come, let us be wise against him," etc. For the wicked one, by oppressing the righteous, causes the righteous to come to greater humility and to strengthen their soul more. This is the statement of Pharaoh after he said, "Come, let us be wise against the righteous." And perhaps you might ask, what is the need for wisdom? We will begin to oppress him like the way of wicked men. Therefore, it is said that this is nonsense, and it will be that when war is called, it will add also to him, etc. This means that the war adds another aspect of righteousness to the righteous. And since the war that they fought, etc., it is as if he is fighting with himself, and this is "and he fights with us," meaning we fight with ourselves, etc. That through our struggle, the righteous is exalted in his righteousness even more. And for this, cleverness is needed, as it is said, "Come, let us be wise." Thus, it is found that through the war that the Egyptians waged against the Children of Israel to nullify them from their sanctity, they strengthened themselves against them with greater strength, and their righteousness and sanctity were increased. And this will clarify the words of the Midrash, "And these are the names," etc., which added praise for the seventy souls that were mentioned above, that they were all righteous, as it is stated in the Midrash, "The ones coming to Egypt as if they came today," for until now they did not have the burden of Egypt upon them, and by the Egyptians strengthening themselves against them, their righteousness and sanctity were increased even more.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the oppression faced by the righteous (tzaddikim) from the wicked (resha'im) ultimately leads to their spiritual elevation and increased sanctity. It emphasizes that the struggles and challenges, likened to a battle, serve to strengthen the righteous, allowing them to rise in their righteousness and holiness. The text highlights that the more the Egyptians oppressed the Israelites, the more the latter's righteousness and sanctity were enhanced, illustrating a profound theological insight into the transformative power of adversity in the pursuit of holiness.

passage_content: ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה וגו' בזוה"ק איתא ר' חייא פתח אתי מלבנון כלה אתי מלבנון תבואי תשורי מראש אמנה מראש שניר וחרמון ממעונות אריות מהררי נמרים, האי קרא על כנס"י אתמר , בשעתא דנפקן ישראל ממצרים וקריבו לטורא דסיני לקבלא אורייתא וכו ', מראש שניר וחרמון דא טורא דסיני דקריבו לגבי' ואתעתדו תחותי ' דכתיב ויתיצבו בתחתית ההר, ממעונות אריות אלין בני שעיר קוב"ה זמין לון באורייתא ולא בעו לקבלה, מהררי נמרים אלו בני ישמעאל דכתיב ה' מסיני בא וזרח משעיר למו הופיע מהר פארן וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק , ראוי להבין קישור דרשתם ז"ל לפרשה זו דמיירי בהתחלת שיעבודם של ישראל במצרים, ומקומה היותר נכון בפרשת יציאת מצרים וקרבתם להר סיני לקבל התורה.
translation: And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt, etc. In the Zohar it is written: Rabbi Chiya opened, "Come from Lebanon, my bride, come from Lebanon, and you shall look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the dens of lions, from the mountains of leopards." This verse refers to the Congregation of Israel, as it is stated, at the time when Israel went out from Egypt and approached the mountain of Sinai to receive the Torah, etc. "From the top of Shenir and Hermon" refers to the mountain of Sinai that they approached, and they were prepared "at the foot of the mountain," as it is written, "and they stood at the foot of the mountain." "From the dens of lions" refers to the children of Seir, whom the Holy One, blessed be He, prepared for them in the Torah, but they did not wish to receive it. "From the mountains of leopards" refers to the children of Ishmael, as it is written, "The Lord came from Sinai and shone forth from Seir for them; He appeared from Mount Paran," etc. Thus far the Zohar. It is fitting to understand the connection of their teaching to this section, which deals with the beginning of the enslavement of Israel in Egypt, and its most appropriate place in the section of the Exodus from Egypt and their proximity to Mount Sinai to receive the Torah.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the connection between the Israelites' enslavement in Egypt and their eventual receiving of the Torah at Mount Sinai. It highlights the spiritual journey of the Jewish people, emphasizing their preparation and elevation as they approach the divine revelation. The references to various mountains and locations symbolize the spiritual ascent and the readiness of the Israelites to accept the Torah, illustrating the profound relationship between suffering, redemption, and divine instruction in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ונראה לפרש עפימ"ד בזוה"ק (פ' יתרו) דבשעת מתן תורה פקד ה' את עמו וראה כלהון בני מהימנותא בני קשוט אין בהם אחד שנולד בפסול ולכך נתן להם התוה"ק , ועפי"ז פי' ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה (פ' ויגש ) במאמה"כ וישלחני אלקים לפניכם וגו' להחיות לכם לפליטה גדולה, דמבואר במדרש שבזכות יוסף שעמד בנסיון נגדרו כל ישראל בעריות, וא"כ הוא הי' היסוד והגורם לנתינת התורה עכת"ד יעיי"ש , ולכאורה קשה הלא מצינו שהקב"ה החזיר התורה על בני ישמעאל ובני עשו שיקבלו אותה, כמ"ש חכמז"ל עה"פ ה' מסיני בא וזרח משעיר למו הופיע מהר פארן, והם בוודאי אינם מיוחסים וכולם מעורבים זה בזה ונולדו בפסול, ואעפ"כ רצה הקב"ה ליתן להם התורה, אמנם זה ברור שמה שרצה הקב"ה ליתן התורה לאוה"ע הוא רק פשטות דיני התורה והלכותי ', אבל פנימיות וסודות התורה שבשבילה נתקנאו המלאכים ואמרו תנה הודך על השמים, למעלה זו לא היו יכולין אף ישראל להגיע אלמלי היו ח"ו מעורבים באומות ונולדים בפסול, אלא ע"י שהיו כולם בני מהימנותא ובני קשוט זכו לפנימיות התורה, ועפי"ז יש לפרש מה דאיתא במדרש ילקוט (ריש פ' במדבר) בשעה שקיבלו ישראל את התורה נתקנאו בהן אוה"ע מה ראו אלו להתקרב יותר מכל אומה"ע , מיד סתם הקב"ה את פיהם ואמר להם הביאו לי ספר יוחסין כשם שבני מביאים וכו ', והקושיא מפורסמת הלא רצה הקב"ה ליתן התורה גם להם ולא אבו לקבלה, ומה טענה היתה בפיהם על ישראל שקבלוה, וגם איך תלה הבוי"ת קבלת התורה ביחוס , והרי רצה ליתן התורה גם לאומה"ע אע"פ שאינם מיוחסין, אך לדרכינו ניחא שנתקנאו על פנימיות התורה שזכו בה בנ"י מה שלא רצה הקב"ה ליתן להם, ועל זה טענו מה ראו אלו להתקרב יותר מכל אומה"ע שניתן להם גם פנימיות התורה, וע"ז השיבם הקב"ה הביאו לי ספר יוחסין כשם שבני מביאין . דלזכות לפנימיות התורה א"א רק אם הם בני מהימנותא בני קשוט , ואף בנ"י לולי מעלה זו לא היו יכולין לקבל פנימיות התוה"ק . ויתבאר בזה קישור דברי הזוה"ק שהסמיכו לכאן הענין של קבלת התורה אתי מלבנון כלה וגו' עפי"מ שדרשו בזוה"ק ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה בנ"י עאלו ובנ"י נפקו וע"כ זכו לקבל פנימיות התוה"ק , ממעונות אריות אלין בני שעיר וכו ', מהררי נמרים אלו בני ישמעאל שלא זכו לקבלה רק בנ"י ע"י שהיו כולם בני מהימנותא בני קשוט .
translation:
And it seems appropriate to explain according to the words of the Zohar (Parashat Yitro) that at the time of the giving of the Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, took account of His people and saw that all of them were sons of faith, sons of purity, and there was not one among them who was born in disqualification, and therefore He gave them the Torah. Based on this, the holy Rabbi Kook (Parashat Vayigash) explained the verse, "And God sent me before you to preserve for you a remnant," as it is stated in the Midrash that in the merit of Joseph, who stood firm in his trial, all of Israel were safeguarded from immorality. Thus, he was the foundation and cause for the giving of the Torah, as stated there. 

However, it is difficult to understand, for we find that the Holy One, blessed be He, offered the Torah to the children of Ishmael and the children of Esau to accept it, as our sages of blessed memory said regarding the verse, "The Lord came from Sinai and shone forth from Seir for them; He appeared from Mount Paran." And they are certainly not of noble lineage, and all are mixed together and were born in disqualification. Nevertheless, the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to give them the Torah. 

It is clear that what the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to give the Torah to the nations of the world was only the simple laws and halachot of the Torah. But the inner secrets of the Torah, for which the angels envied and said, "Give Your glory to the heavens," above, they could not attain, even Israel, had they been mixed with the nations and born in disqualification. Rather, because they were all sons of faith and sons of purity, they merited the inner Torah. 

Based on this, we can explain what is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (at the beginning of Parashat Bamidbar) that at the time Israel received the Torah, the nations of the world envied them, saying, "What did these see to draw closer more than any other nation?" Immediately, the Holy One, blessed be He, closed their mouths and said to them, "Bring me a genealogical record, just as My children bring." 

And the well-known question arises: Did not the Holy One, blessed be He, want to give the Torah to them as well, and they refused to accept it? What claim did they have against Israel for having accepted it? And how did the Holy One, blessed be He, connect the acceptance of the Torah to lineage, when He wanted to give the Torah to the nations of the world even though they are not of noble lineage? 

However, according to our path, it is understandable that they envied the inner Torah that the Jewish people merited, which the Holy One, blessed be He, did not want to give to them. And on this, they claimed, "What did these see to draw closer more than any other nation, that they were also given the inner Torah?" To this, the Holy One, blessed be He, responded, "Bring me a genealogical record, just as My children bring." For to merit the inner Torah, one cannot be anything but sons of faith and sons of purity, and even the Jewish people, without this merit, would not have been able to receive the inner Torah. 

This will clarify the connection of the words of the Zohar that associate the matter of the giving of the Torah with "Come from Lebanon, O bride," according to what is expounded in the Zohar, "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt: the children of Israel went in and the children of Israel went out." Therefore, they merited to receive the inner Torah, from the dwellings of the lions, these sons of Seir, etc., from the mountains of the nimrods, these sons of Ishmael, who did not merit to receive it, only the Jewish people, because they were all sons of faith and sons of purity.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Jewish people's purity and lineage in receiving the Torah, emphasizing that they were all "children of faith" and "children of integrity," which qualified them for the inner secrets of the Torah. It contrasts this with the nations of the world, including Ishmael and Esau, who, despite God's willingness to offer them the Torah, were not granted access to its deeper meanings due to their lack of proper lineage. The text highlights that the essence of the Torah, which the angels envied, could only be attained by those who are truly righteous and connected to their heritage. Ultimately, it asserts that the Jewish people's unique status allowed them to receive the inner teachings of the Torah, which others could not access.

passage_content: ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה את יעקב איש וביתו באו, במד"ר א"ר אבהו כ"מ שנאמר אלה פסל את הראשונים, ואלה מוסיף שבח על הראשונים וכו' אף כאן הוסיף שבח על שבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם היו צדיקים. עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב הלא הן הן האמורים למעלה, והן בצדקתן מתחלתן ועד סופן. ומה הכוונה בתוס ' שבחם.
translation: And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each man and his household came. In the Midrash, Rabbi Abahu said: Wherever it is stated "these," it excludes the first ones, and "these" adds praise to the first ones, etc. Here too, it adds praise to the seventy souls mentioned above, that they were all righteous. Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is puzzling: are they not the same as those mentioned above, and are they righteous from the beginning to the end? And what is the intention of the addition of their praise?
summary: The passage discusses the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, emphasizing that they were all righteous from beginning to end. It highlights a Hasidic interpretation that the phrase "these" adds praise to the previous mention of the seventy souls, suggesting a deeper acknowledgment of their righteousness. The inquiry raised is about the purpose of this additional praise, indicating a theological reflection on the nature of their merit and the significance of their collective identity as righteous individuals.

passage_content: ב) ואלה שמות בנ"י זש"ה כשמך אלקים כן תהלתך וגו' שמותיו של הקב"ה בכל מה שמקלסין אותו הוא יתר וכו' וכן אמר דוד מי ימלל גבורות ד' ישמיע כל תהלתו , וצ"ב קישור דרשא זו אל שמות בנ"י .
translation: B) And these are the names of the children of Israel, as it is written, "As Your name, O God, so is Your praise," etc. The names of the Holy One, Blessed be He, in all that they praise Him are greater, etc. And thus David said, "Who can tell of the mighty acts of the Lord? Let all His praise be heard." And it is to be questioned how this interpretation connects to the names of the children of Israel.
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between the names of the Jewish people and the names of God, suggesting that just as God's names reflect His glory and attributes, so too do the names of the Jewish people embody their spiritual essence and mission. It references the idea that praising God is an essential aspect of understanding His greatness, as expressed in the words of David about proclaiming God's mighty deeds. The inquiry posed highlights the deeper relationship between the identity of the Jewish people and the divine, suggesting that their names carry a profound significance in the context of their connection to God.

passage_content: ג) מלך חדש על מצרים וגו' במסכת סוטה (י"א ע"א) פליגי רב ושמואל, ח"א חדש ממש, וחד אמר שנתחדשו גזרותיו מדלא כתיב וימת וימלוך, אשר לא ידע את יוסף דהו' דמי כמאן דלא ידע לי' כלל, וכן איתא במדרש רבה על דעתי' דמ"ד שנתחדשו גזרותיו מאי לא ידע את יוסף, דהוי דמי כמאן דלא ידע לי' ליוסף כלל, וצ"ב דעדיין אינו מתורץ משמעות הלשון, דבאמת ידע לי' ליוסף, ומאי דדמי לי' כמאן דלא ידע, הדמיון לא ישנה את המציאות, ולא הו"ל להכתוב לומר אשר לא ידע, אם האמת לא היה כן. ובמדרש רבה הקשו כן וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף א"ר אבין משל לא' שרגם אוהבו של מלך אמר המלך התיזו את ראשו כי למחר יעשה בי כך, לכך כתב עליו המקרא כלומר היום אשר לא ידע את יוסף, למחר הוא עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד' ע"כ, ולכאורה קושית המדרש במקומה עומדת, וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, גם מה שסיימו למחר עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד', צ"ב השתוות עניניהם להדדי.
translation: 3) A new king arose over Egypt, etc. In the tractate Sotah (11a), there is a dispute between Rav and Shmuel; one says it was a completely new king, and the other says that his decrees were renewed since it is not written "and he died and he reigned," and that he did not know Joseph is like one who does not know him at all. And so it is stated in Midrash Rabbah regarding the opinion of the one who says that his decrees were renewed: what does it mean that he did not know Joseph? It is like one who does not know Joseph at all. However, it is puzzling that the meaning of the language is still not resolved, for he truly knew Joseph, and what does it mean that he is like one who does not know? The similarity does not change the reality, and it should not have been written "that he did not know" if the truth were not so. And in Midrash Rabbah, they ask: Was he not acquainted with Joseph? Rabbi Avin said: It is like a certain minister who hated the king's beloved, and the king said, "Behead him, for tomorrow he will do such to me." Therefore, the verse wrote about him, meaning today he does not know Joseph; tomorrow he is destined to say, "I do not know the Lord." Thus, at first glance, the question of the Midrash stands firm: Was he not acquainted with Joseph? Also, the conclusion that tomorrow he is destined to say, "I do not know the Lord," raises the question of the equivalence of their matters to one another.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of a "new king" in Egypt who did not recognize Joseph, exploring the implications of this lack of recognition as a theological metaphor. It highlights a debate between Rabbi and Shmuel regarding whether this king was genuinely new or if his decrees were simply renewed, suggesting that the king's ignorance of Joseph symbolizes a deeper spiritual disconnection from divine knowledge. The text emphasizes that true recognition of Joseph, representing divine providence, is essential for understanding one's relationship with God, and the failure to acknowledge this leads to a future denial of God's presence. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the importance of awareness and recognition of divine influence in one's life.

passage_content: ד) קשה גם מ"ש לא ידעתי את ד', הרי ידע את ד', כמ"ש במד"ר הבה נתחכמה לו, להם לא נאמר אלא לו, וכו' נתחכמה לאלקיהם של אלו, וידעו שמדותיו של הקב"ה מדה כנגד מדה. והתחכמו לדונם במים, שכבר נשבע שאין מביא מבול לעולם וכו ', וא"כ לא יוצדק לומר לא ידעתי את ד', שהרי ידע והתכוין למרוד בו ולגודל רשעתו העלים עינו מהידיעה ההוא, והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב דחכם גדול הי' פרעה ויודע את האלקים ומודה בו, כמ"ש הוא או מורישו ליוסף אחרי הודיע אלקים אותך וכו' אבל לא הי' יודע את השם המיוחד וענה לא ידעתי את ד' וכו' עכ"ל. ולפי"ד יקשה איך לא הי' מתיירא מפחד אלקים ומהדר גאונו, אחרי שהשכיל שם אלקים המורה על דינים, ומשרע"ה נתראה אליו בשם אלקים כמ"ש כה אמר ד' אלקי ישראל, והזהירו פן יפגענו בדבר או בחרב, עיין פרש"י , א"כ הזהירו על דין הקשה, ומדוע לא פחד ממנו אם ידע שם אלקים ומודה בו כדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל וצ"ב .
translation: d) It is also difficult regarding what he said, "I did not know the Lord," for he did know the Lord, as it is stated in Midrash Rabbah, "Let us be wise against Him," it was said to them but not to him, etc. "Let us be wise against the God of these," and they knew that the attributes of the Holy One, Blessed be He, are measure for measure. And they were clever to judge Him with water, for He had already sworn not to bring a flood upon the world, etc. Therefore, it would not be justified to say, "I did not know the Lord," since he did know and intended to rebel against Him, and due to his great wickedness, he concealed his eyes from that knowledge. And Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote that Pharaoh was a great wise man and knew of God and acknowledged Him, as it is said, "Is it he or his heir to Joseph after God made known to you," etc. But he did not know the special Name and answered, "I did not know the Lord," etc. Thus far his words. According to this, it is difficult how he was not afraid of the fear of God and the greatness of His glory, after he understood the Name of God which indicates judgments, and since Moshe Rabbeinu revealed Himself to him in the Name of God, as it is said, "Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel," and warned him lest we be struck by a word or by the sword, see Rashi's commentary. Therefore, he warned him about the severe judgment, and why was he not afraid of Him if he knew the Name of God and acknowledged Him, as Ramban, of blessed memory, said, and this is a question.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's claim of not knowing God, despite his awareness of divine authority and acknowledgment of God's existence. It highlights the concept of divine justice, where God's attributes operate in a measure-for-measure manner, suggesting that Pharaoh's willful ignorance and rebellion stemmed from his wickedness. The text also questions how Pharaoh, despite recognizing God's power and being warned by Moses, could lack fear of divine retribution, emphasizing the complexity of human understanding and the nature of divine revelation.

passage_content: ה) ד' ראה ראיתי את עני עמי אשר במצרים ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו כי ידעתי את מכאוביו, הקשה האור החיים הק ' דהול"ל ואת צעקתם מפני נגשיו שמעתי, דהצעקה הי' מפני נגשיו ולא השמיעה.
translation: 5) The Lord said, "I have seen the affliction of My people who are in Egypt, and I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters, for I know their pain." The holy Or HaChaim questions why it states, "and I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," as the cry was indeed because of their taskmasters and not the other way around.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on God's awareness of the suffering of the Jewish people in Egypt, emphasizing that God not only sees their affliction but also hears their cries, which arise from their oppression. The question posed highlights the distinction between the source of their cries and God's response, suggesting that the cries themselves were not vocalized but rather a deep, internal anguish. This underscores the Hasidic belief in God's intimate knowledge of human suffering and the idea that divine compassion is activated by the heartfelt pain of the oppressed. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between God and His people, affirming that He is attuned to their struggles even when they cannot fully articulate them.

summary: The passage emphasizes God's intimate awareness of human suffering, as expressed in the phrase "I have seen the affliction of my people." It highlights the theological concept that God not only observes pain but also deeply understands and empathizes with the struggles of His creation. This understanding serves as a foundation for divine intervention and support, reinforcing the belief in a compassionate and responsive God who is attuned to the cries of the oppressed. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic idea of a personal relationship between the Divine and humanity, where God is present in both joy and suffering.

passage_content: ז) ואשלחך אל פרעה וגו' צ"ב כפל הלשון כי מן הסתם כשיאמר לו השי"ת לכה, ידוע כי הוא ית ' המשלחו, והאר"י ז"ל בשער הפסוקים כתב ביאור ע"ז ויבואר עוד להלן בעז"ה .
translation: And I will send you to Pharaoh, etc. (Exodus 3:10) The repetition of the language is because, undoubtedly, when the Holy One, Blessed be He, says to him, "Go," it is known that He is the One sending him. And the holy Ari, may his merit protect us, wrote an explanation on this in the Gate of Verses, and it will be further explained below, with G-d's help.
summary: The passage discusses the divine command to Moses to go to Pharaoh, emphasizing the repetition of the phrase as a sign of God's authority in sending him. It highlights the understanding that when God instructs someone, it is inherently known that He is the one sending them. The reference to the teachings of the Arizal suggests a deeper mystical interpretation of this command, which will be elaborated upon later. This reflects key Hasidic concepts of divine mission and the interconnectedness of God's will with human action.

passage_content: ח) משה מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה וכי אוציא את בנ"י ממצרים פרש"י מי אנכי מה אני חשוב לדבר עם המלכים, ואף אם חשוב אני, מה זכו ישראל שתעשה להם נס ואוציאם ממצרים. ראוי להבין איך יתכן שהתחכם משה רבינו על דברי ד', וכיון ששלחו השי"ת לגאלם בודאי יש מקום לגאולתם, והשליחות יהי' לתכלית הנרצה, ואין מקום לחקור ולהסתפק בדברי השי"ת, ואם לא ראה משרע"ה זכות מספיק לישראל היה לו ללמד עליהם זכות, גם יש בכחו יתברך להוציאם אפילו בלי זכות ע"ש העתיד וכמו שהיה באמת כן. וטענת משרע"ה נראה כקטרוג ח"ו על ישראל, גם הרי היה להם לישראל במצרים זכותים , והיו מצוינים במדות טובות כמ"ש חז"ל במדרש בשביל ד' דברים נגאלו ישראל ממצרים שלא שינו את שמם ואת לשונם. ולא אמרו לה"ר, ולא נמצא ביניהן פרוץ בעריות, ואחת היתה ופירסמה הכתוב, ואיתא בזוה"ק פ' שמות דף ג' זכאין אינון ישראל דאע"ג דהוו בגלותא דמצרים אסתמרו מכל הני תלתא מנדה ומבת אל נכר ומקטול זרעא ואשתדלו בפרי' ורבי', ומשרע"ה ידע בכל אלו זכיותיהם, א"כ מדוע טען מה זכו ישראל להוציאם ממצרים וצ"ב .
translation: (8) Moses said, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that I should bring out the Children of Israel from Egypt?" Rashi explains, "Who am I? What am I worthy to speak with kings? And even if I am worthy, what merit do the Israelites have that You should perform a miracle for them and bring them out of Egypt?" It is fitting to understand how it is possible that our teacher Moses questioned the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and since the Holy One sent him to redeem them, there must certainly be a place for their redemption, and the mission will be for the desired purpose, and there is no room to investigate or doubt the words of the Holy One. If Moses did not see sufficient merit for Israel, he should have taught merit for them. Also, the Blessed One has the power to redeem them even without merit, as it was indeed the case. And the argument of Moses seems like a slander, Heaven forbid, against Israel. Moreover, the Israelites in Egypt had merits, and they were distinguished by good traits, as our Sages said in the Midrash, "For four things the Israelites were redeemed from Egypt: they did not change their names, nor their language, they did not speak slander, and there was no promiscuity among them." And it is stated in the Zohar, Parashat Shemot, page 3, "The Israelites are worthy, for although they were in the exile of Egypt, they preserved themselves from these three things: from slander, from marrying foreign women, and from killing offspring, and they strove for fruitfulness and multiplication." And since Moses knew all of these merits, then why did he claim, "What merit do the Israelites have to be brought out of Egypt?" This remains a question.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores Moses' hesitance to accept God's mission to free the Israelites from Egypt, questioning his own worthiness and the merits of the people. The text emphasizes that despite Moses' concerns, the divine plan for redemption is assured, as God possesses the power to redeem even without the Israelites' merits. It highlights the inherent righteousness of the Israelites, who maintained their identity and moral integrity in Egypt, suggesting that their virtues were sufficient for their redemption. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the tension between human doubt and divine assurance in the context of salvation.

passage_content: ט) אהיה עמך וזה לך האות כי אנכי שלחתיך בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, פרש"י השיבו על ראשון ראשון וכו' וזה לך האות מראה הסנה לך לאות שתצליח בשליחותי ואינך ניזוק, כאשר ראית הסנה עושה שליחותי ואיננו אוכל וכו ', דבר אחר זה שתצליח בשליחותי יהיה לך אות על הבטחה אחרת, שבהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון אותי על ההר הזה שתקבלו התורה וכו' עכ"ד רש"י ז"ל. וב' הפירושים צ"ב, לפי' ראשון שהסנה יהיה אות שתצליח בשליחותי ואינך ניזוק, קשה וכי הי' משרע"ה ח"ו מסופק ביכולת ד' היכול יוכל להציל, ולמה הוצרך לאות הסנה, ויספיק דיבורו של הקב"ה שצוהו לילך בשליחותו, וראוי לבטוח בו יותר מכל האותות שבעולם, ועל פי' הב' שהי' האות על מתן תורה ג"כ קשה למה היה הצורך ליתן לו אות ע"ז, ועדיין לא הובטח בכך ולא שאל אות על זה.
translation:
9) "I will be with you, and this shall be the sign for you that I have sent you: when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." Rashi explains that they responded to the first sign, etc. "And this shall be the sign for you" indicates that the burning bush will be a sign that you will succeed in My mission and will not be harmed, just as you saw the bush fulfilling My mission and it is not consumed, etc. Another interpretation is that this sign of your success in My mission will also be a sign of another promise, that when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve Me on this mountain, where you will receive the Torah, etc. Thus far Rashi, may his memory be blessed. 

And both interpretations are difficult. According to the first interpretation, that the bush will be a sign that you will succeed in My mission and will not be harmed, it is hard to understand: was Moses, heaven forbid, in doubt about God's ability to save? Why did he need the sign of the bush? His words should have sufficed, as God commanded him to go in His mission, and he should trust Him more than any signs in the world. And according to the second interpretation, that the sign was regarding the giving of the Torah, it is also difficult to understand why there was a need to give him a sign for this, as he was not yet assured of it and did not ask for a sign regarding this.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the sign given to Moses through the burning bush, which serves as a reassurance of his successful mission to lead the Israelites out of Egypt. The text raises questions about why Moses would need a sign to affirm God's ability to protect him and why an additional sign was necessary for the receiving of the Torah. These inquiries highlight the Hasidic emphasis on the interplay between divine assurance and human faith, suggesting that signs serve to strengthen trust in God's promises and the unfolding of His plan.

passage_content: הרמב"ם ז"ל בספר היד ( בפ"ח מהל' יסוה"ת ) ביאר הכתוב הנ"ל שהוא יסוד מוסד בענין האמנת דברי הנביא, וז"ל בקיצור משה רבינו לא האמינו בו ישראל מפני האותות שעשה, שהמאמין עפ"י אותות יש בלבו דופי, שאפשר שיעשה האות בלט ובכישוף, וכל האותות שעשה משה רבינו לפי הצורך עשאם , לא להביא ראיה על הנבואה וכו ', ובמה האמינו בו במעמד הר סיני שעינינו ראו ולא זר וכו ', ואנו שומעים הקול מדבר אליו. משה משה לך אמור להם כך וכך וכו' ומעמד הר סיני לבדו הוא הראיה לנבואתן, שנאמר שם וגם בך יאמינו לעולם וכו ', ומשרע"ה כל ישראל עדים לו אחר מעמד הר סיני, וא"צ לעשות להם אות, וז"ש לו הקב"ה בעת שנתן לו האותות לעשותן במצרים, וא"ל ושמעו לקולך, ידע משה רבינו שהמאמין עפ"י האותות יש בלבבו דופי, והיה נשמט מלילך ואמר והן לא יאמינו לי, עד שהודיעו הקב"ה שאלו האותות אינו אלא עד שיצאו ממצרים, ועיקר האות שידעו באמת שאני שלחתיך ולא ישאר בלבבם הרהור, יהי' במעמד הר סיני, ע"כ א"ל וזה לך האות כי אנכי שלחתיך בהוציאך וכו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, שזה יהי' האות האמיתי שאין אחרי' הרהור ומחשבה עכת"ד.
translation: The Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in the Book of Knowledge (in chapter 8 of the laws of the foundations of the Torah), explained the aforementioned verse, which is a fundamental principle regarding the belief in the words of the prophet. In short, the Jewish people did not believe in Moses due to the signs he performed, for one who believes based on signs has doubt in his heart, as it is possible that the sign is done through sorcery and witchcraft. All the signs that Moses performed were done as needed, not to provide proof of prophecy, etc. And how did they believe in him at the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai? For our eyes saw and not a stranger, etc., and we hear the voice speaking to him: "Moses, Moses, go say to them such and such," etc. And the event at Mount Sinai alone is the proof of their prophecy, as it is stated there, "And also in you they will believe forever," etc. And from that time, all of Israel were witnesses to him after the event at Mount Sinai, and there was no need to perform signs for them. This is what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him when He gave him the signs to perform in Egypt, and He said to him, "And they will listen to your voice." Moses knew that one who believes based on signs has doubt in his heart, and he hesitated to go and said, "But they will not believe me," until the Holy One, blessed be He, informed him that these signs are only until they leave Egypt, and the main sign that they should truly know that I have sent you, and that no doubt will remain in their hearts, will be at the event of Mount Sinai. Therefore, He said to him, "And this shall be the sign to you that I have sent you: when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain," for this will be the true sign that leaves no doubt or thought. Thus is the word.
summary: The passage discusses the fundamental belief in the words of the prophet, emphasizing that the Israelites did not believe in Moses due to the signs he performed, as belief based on signs can lead to doubt. True faith was established at Mount Sinai, where the people witnessed God's presence and heard His voice, providing a definitive proof of Moses' prophecy. The signs given in Egypt were merely a precursor, with the ultimate confirmation of divine authority occurring at Sinai, ensuring that there would be no lingering doubts in their hearts. Thus, the Sinai experience serves as the true and lasting evidence of Moses' mission from God.

passage_content: י) והקשו עליו הלחם משנה והמהרלב"ח (סימן ל"א), דאין סידור הפסוקים מורים כדבריו, דפסוק וזה לך האות הוא מוקדם לפסוק והן לא יאמינו לי, ואחר שנתן לו הקב"ה האות דמתן תורה שהוא אות אמיתי וברור, למה שאל עוד אות ואמר והן לא יאמינו לי, ובמה נתקררה דעתו אח"כ כשנתן לו הקב"ה ג' האותות, ושמא לא יאמינו ישראל גם באותות אלו, כי המאמין לנביא עפ"י אותות יש בלבו דופי, ואם לא יועילו ג' האותות אלו, למה צוהו השי"ת לעשות האותות לעיני העם בלי תועלת.
translation: 10) And they questioned him, the second bread and the Maharal of Prague (Siman 31), that the arrangement of the verses does not support his words, for the verse "And this shall be the sign to you" is prior to the verse "And they will not believe me." And after the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him the sign of the giving of the Torah, which is a true and clear sign, why did he ask for another sign and say "And they will not believe me"? And how was his mind calmed afterwards when the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him three signs? Perhaps Israel will not believe even in these signs, for one who believes in a prophet based on signs has doubt in his heart. And if these three signs will not be effective, why did the Blessed One command him to perform the signs before the people without any benefit?
summary: The passage discusses the tension between Moses' request for signs and God's provision of them, highlighting a key Hasidic concept that true faith should not rely solely on miraculous signs. It suggests that even after receiving clear signs, doubt may still linger, indicating that belief based on miracles can be flawed. The text emphasizes that genuine faith transcends the need for proof, as reliance on signs may reflect a lack of true conviction. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of inner faith over external validation.

passage_content: יא) קשה על הרמב"ם ז"ל איך החליט לומר דכל האותות שעשה משה לפי הצורך עשאם , ולא להביא ראיה על הנבואה, ואין להאמין לשום נביא על פי אותות לבד וכו ', הרי מפורש בפסוק שצוהו הקדוש ברוך הוא לעשות האותות לעיני העם למען יאמינו כי נראה אליך ד', והבטיחו הקב"ה שיאמינו בו בשביל האותות, שנאמר והיה אם לא יאמינו לקול האות הראשון והאמינו לקול האות האחרון, הרי שהאות לבד היתה ראיה מספקת שיאמין העם בנבואת משה, והוא לכאורה סתירה למ"ש הרמב"ם.
translation: 11) It is difficult on the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, how he decided to say that all the signs that Moses performed were done according to necessity, and not to bring proof of prophecy, and that one should not believe any prophet based solely on signs, etc. For it is explicitly stated in the verse that the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded him to perform the signs before the people so that they would believe that God appeared to you. And God promised that they would believe in Him because of the signs, as it is said, "And it shall be, if they do not believe the voice of the first sign, they will believe the voice of the last sign." Thus, the sign alone was sufficient evidence for the people to believe in the prophecy of Moses, which seemingly contradicts what the Rambam said.
summary: The passage critiques Maimonides' assertion that Moses performed miracles solely for practical purposes and not as proof of prophecy, arguing that this contradicts biblical texts where God commands Moses to perform signs to instill belief in the people. It emphasizes that the miracles were indeed intended as evidence of divine communication, as God assured Moses that the people would believe because of these signs. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that faith can be reinforced through tangible experiences of the divine. The tension between rationalism and the necessity of miraculous signs in fostering belief is a central theological insight in this discussion.

passage_content: יב אחר שא"ל הקב"ה האות דמתן תורה, עוד בא משה רבינו בטענתו ואמרו לו מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, והרמב"ם ז"ל בספר המורה (ח"א פרק ס"ג) הקשה ע"ז כי למה חשש משה רבינו שישאלוהו ישראל על שמותיו יתברך, כי זאת השאלה אינה ראויה לשום משכיל לשאול את פי הנביא, כדי שיהיה אות על נבואתו, וכי ההכרח לאמונת הנביא לידע שמותיו יתברך. ועוד איך יתברר עי"ז אמיתת הנביא, וממנ"פ אם כבר ידעו ישראל השם ההוא, א"כ אין ראיה ממה שיגיד אותו להם, כי תהי' ידיעתו בו כידיעתם, ואפשר שגם הוא שמע וידע ולא ד' שלחו, ואם הי' בלתי נודע אצלם, מה הראיה שזה שמו יתברך.
translation: After the Holy One, blessed be He, told him the sign of the giving of the Torah, Moses our teacher came back with his argument and said to Him, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" And the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in the Guide for the Perplexed (Part 1, Chapter 63), questioned this, for why did Moses our teacher fear that Israel would ask him about His blessed names? For this question is not worthy of any wise person to ask the prophet, in order for it to be a sign of his prophecy. And is it necessary for the belief in the prophet to know His blessed names? Furthermore, how would the truth of the prophet be established by this? And if they already knew that name, then there is no proof from what he would tell them, for his knowledge of it would be like their knowledge, and it is possible that he also heard and knew, and that the Holy One did not send him. And if it was unknown to them, what proof is there that this is His blessed name?
summary: The passage discusses Moses' concern about the Israelites asking for God's name when he is sent to them, questioning why this inquiry would be significant for validating his prophecy. It references Maimonides' perspective, suggesting that knowing God's name does not inherently prove the authenticity of a prophet, as the people may already be familiar with it. The text highlights the complexity of divine revelation and the nature of belief, emphasizing that understanding God's essence transcends mere knowledge of His names.

passage_content: יג הקשה האברבנאל ז"ל דממנ"פ אם הי' משה רבינו עצמו יודע זה השם, א"כ למה שאל עליו, כי אם העם ישאלהו על שמו יתברך, משה יודיעם להם מפי ידיעתו, ואם אמרנו שמשה רבינו לא הי' יודע זה השם, היה ראוי שישאל עליו מעצמו, לא שיעשה השאלה בשם העם, ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ועוד שהרי אמרו חז"ל במד"ר פ' שמות ויך את המצרי, במה הרגו רבנן אמרו הזכיר עליו את השם והרגו ורש"י ז"ל כתב עה"פ הלהרגני אתה אומר, מכאן אנו למדים שהרגו בשם המפורש, הרי ידע השם המפורש כבר, וא"כ למה שאל מאתו יתברך, ואם העם ישאלוהו יודיעם עפ"י ידיעתו.
translation: The Abarbanel, may his memory be blessed, posed a difficult question: if Moshe Rabbeinu himself knew this name, then why did he ask about it? For if the people were to ask him about the Name of the Blessed One, Moshe would inform them from his own knowledge. And if we say that Moshe Rabbeinu did not know this name, it would have been appropriate for him to ask about it on his own, rather than making the inquiry in the name of the people. Furthermore, as our Sages have said in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Shemot, regarding "he struck the Egyptian," the Rabbis said that he mentioned the Name and killed him, and Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote on the verse "Are you going to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?" From here we learn that he killed in the Name of the Explicit Name, thus he already knew the Explicit Name. So why did he ask about it from the Blessed One? And if the people were to ask him, he would inform them according to his knowledge.
summary: The passage discusses a theological dilemma regarding Moses' knowledge of the Divine Name. It questions why Moses would ask God about His name if he already possessed the knowledge to convey it to the people. The text highlights the tension between Moses' potential awareness of the ineffable name and the necessity of seeking divine revelation, emphasizing the importance of humility and reliance on God in understanding sacred truths. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the relationship between human knowledge and divine wisdom.

passage_content: יד) אלקים אל משה אקי' אשר אקי' ויאמר כה תאמר אל בנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם, במסכת ברכות (דף ע') דרשו חז"ל אהיה עמהם בצרה זו ואהיה עמהם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , אמר לפניו רבש"ע די' לצרה בשעתה וכו ', א"ל יפה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם, הקשו המפרשים איך יתכן שמשה רבינו שאל קושיא לאלוקינו, ומלמד למי שמלמד לאדם דעת. וברש"י במוסגר יש גירסא כי מ"ש לו הקב"ה בתחלה אקי' אשר אקי' למשה לבדו הגיד, ולא שיגיד לישראל כן, וכן מבואר במדרש רבה שהשיב לו הקב"ה לך אני מודיע, להם איני מודיע, אבל לפי זה אין התשובה מענין השאלה, שמשרע"ה שאל ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, והשי"ת השיבו אקי' אשר אקי', והוא הודעה למשה לבדו, ולא שיגידה לישראל.
translation: God said to Moses, "I Am that I Am," and He said, "Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I Am has sent me to you.'" In the tractate Berakhot (page 20), our Sages expounded that I will be with them in this distress and I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms. He said before Him, "Master of the Universe, let it be that You will be with them in their time of distress," etc. He said to him, "You have spoken well; thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I Am has sent me to you.'" The commentators have posed the question of how it is possible that our teacher Moses asked a question of our God, who teaches knowledge to man. And in Rashi's commentary, there is a version that what the Holy One, Blessed be He, initially told Moses, "I Am that I Am," was revealed only to Moses and not to be told to Israel. And it is also explained in Midrash Rabbah that the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "To you I will make known, but to them I will not make known." However, according to this, the answer is not relevant to the question, since Moses asked, "What shall I say to them? What is His name?" and the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him, "I Am that I Am," which is a revelation to Moses alone, and not to be conveyed to Israel.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the profound relationship between the divine and the human experience of suffering and redemption. God assures Moses that He will be with the Israelites during their hardships and enslavement, emphasizing His constant presence in times of trouble. The discussion raises theological questions about the nature of divine communication, suggesting that certain revelations are meant for specific individuals, like Moses, rather than the broader community. This reflects a deeper understanding of God's guidance and the unique role of leaders in conveying divine messages to their people.

passage_content: טו) עוד אלקים אל משה כה תאמר אל בנ"י ד' אלקי אבותיכם אלקי אברהם יצחק ויעקב שלחני אליכם זה שמי לעלם וזה זכרי לדר ודר, יל"ד דהרי כבר השיב לו השי"ת על שאלתו. באמרו כה תאמר אל בנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם, ומדוע השיבו שני' באופן אחר שיאמר להם השליחות בשם הוי' ובשם אלקי , ורז"ל דרשו במסכת פסחים (נ' ע"א) סבר רבא למדרשה בפירקא ( פרש"י קרי' דשם הוי', דרשי' וטעמי' התלוים בו) א"ל ההוא סבא לעלם כתיב וכו' ( פרש"י חסר ו' לשון העלמה) אמר הקב"ה לא כשאני נכתב אני נקרא, נכתב אני ביו"ד ה"א ונקרא אני בא' ד', פרש"י ב' שמות לימדו, שם הכתיבה ושם הקריאה, ואם הי' כוונת רצונו יתברך שיאמר להם שם הוי', למה אמר למשה רבינו מתחלה כה תאמר לבנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם בכל אופן על שאלתו מה שמו מה אומר אליהם השיבו השי"ת ב' תשובות שונות וצ"ב .
translation: 15) Furthermore, God said to Moses, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: 'The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, has sent me to you. This is My name forever, and this is My memorial to all generations.'" It is known that the Holy One, blessed be He, had already answered him regarding his question. By saying, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I Am has sent me to you,'" and why did He respond in a different manner, instructing him to tell them the mission in the name of the Lord and in the name of God? Our Sages taught in the tractate Pesachim (60a) that Rava intended to teach in the chapter (as Rashi explains, it is called the name of the Lord, and the interpretations and reasons that are connected to it). An elder said to him, "It is written forever," etc. (as Rashi explains, lacking the letter 'vav' is a language of concealment). The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Not as I am written, am I called; I am written with Yud and Heh, and I am called with Aleph and Dalet." Rashi explains that two names are taught: the name of writing and the name of reading. And if it was the intent of the Blessed One that he should tell them the name of the Lord, why did He initially say to our teacher Moses, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I Am has sent me to you'"? In any case, regarding his question of what is His name, the Holy One, blessed be He, answered with two different responses, and this is puzzling.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the duality of God's names as revealed to Moses, emphasizing the distinction between the written name (YHWH) and the spoken name (Elohim). This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of God, suggesting that His essence transcends human understanding and language. The passage highlights the importance of both names in conveying different aspects of God's relationship with the Jewish people, illustrating the complexity of divine revelation and the multifaceted nature of God. Ultimately, it raises questions about the significance of God's names and their implications for faith and understanding.

passage_content: טז ז"ל כתב מצאתי מדרש אגדה מהו אקי' אשר אקי', כשם שאתה הוו' עמי כך אני הוו' עמך, אם פותחין את ידיהם ועושין צדקה, אף אנו אפתח את ידי וכו , וכעין זה איתא במדרש רבה ובתנחומא שלפנינו בשינוי קצת וז"ל א"ל הקב"ה למשה שמי אתה מבקש לידע לפי מעשי אני נקרא וכו ', כשאני דן את הבריות אני נקרא אלקים וכו' וכשאני מרחם על עולמי אני נקרא ד', שאין ד' אלא מדת הרחמים, הוי אקי' אשר אקי', אני נקרא לפי מעשי, ולפי זה פסוק זה הוא הודעה על כל שמותיו יתברך המפורשים בתנ"ך, שנקרא שמו יתברך כפי המעשה אשר עושה, וכפי הבחינה אשר ממשיכים ישראל בעבודתם כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בשם המדרש. אבל לפי"ז לא יובן מה ששינה הוא יתברך, שא"ל מתחלה אקי' אשר אקי', ואח"כ כה תאמר לבנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם, ולפי דרשת המדרש מה נפקמ"נ בין ב' בחינות אלו, וצ"ב .
translation: 16. Blessed be His memory, I found a Midrash Aggadah on the phrase "I will be what I will be." Just as you are "I will be" with Me, so I will be "I will be" with you. If they open their hands and do charity, I too will open My hands, etc. And similarly, it is stated in Midrash Rabbah and in Tanchuma before us with some variation, as follows: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "What is My name that you seek to know? According to My deeds, I am called..." When I judge the creatures, I am called God, etc. And when I have mercy on the world, I am called Lord, for there is no Lord except the attribute of mercy. Thus, "I will be what I will be," I am called according to My deeds. According to this, this verse is a declaration of all His names, blessed be He, that are mentioned in the Torah, for His name is called according to the action He performs, and according to the level that Israel brings forth in their service, as the Ramban, blessed be his memory, states in the name of the Midrash. However, according to this, it is not understood why He changed, for He initially said "I will be what I will be," and afterwards said, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be has sent me to you.'" And according to the Midrash's interpretation, what is the difference between these two aspects? This requires clarification.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of God's names and attributes as reflective of His actions and the relationship with Israel. It emphasizes that God's name is revealed according to His deeds, such as being called "Elokim" when judging and "Hashem" when showing mercy, highlighting the divine attribute of compassion. The text also raises a question about the apparent change in God's self-identification from "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh" to "Ehyeh sent me to you," suggesting a deeper understanding of the divine nature and its manifestations based on human actions and spiritual engagement. This reflects a key Hasidic idea that God's presence and names are intimately connected to the moral and spiritual state of the people.

passage_content: יז (פרק מ') איתא אמר משה לפני הקב"ה רבון כל עולמים הודיעני שמך הגדול והקדוש שאקרא לך בשמך ותענני, והודיעו שנאמר ויאמר אלקים אל משה אקי' אשר אקי' וכו' וראו העליונים שמסר הקב"ה סוד שם המפורש וענו בא"י חונן הדעת, ע"כ. מבואר בפדר"א הנ"ל שבאמרו יתברך אקי' אשר אקי' מסר בזה למשה רבינו סוד שם המפורש והוא כדעת ר' יצחק במדרש שפירושו אני שהייתי ואני הוא עכשיו ואני הוא לעתיד לבוא וכ"כ האור החיים הקדוש שכאן הודיע יתברך למשה סוד השם הגדול הי' הו' ויהיה, וע"כ דרשו רז"ל אהי ' עמהם בצרה זו, אשר אהי ' עמהם בצרה אחרת וכו '. אבל צ"ב שמשמעות הפסוקים מוכיחים ששאל משרע"ה מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ועל דעת שיאמרנה לישראל היתה שאלתו, ובפדר"א אמרו ששאלו משה לצורך התפלה לעצמו כמ"ש שאקרא בשמך ותענני, והוא שלא כמשמעות הפסוק.
translation: 17 (Chapter 40) It is stated that Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of all worlds, make known to me Your great and holy name, so that I may call upon You by Your name and You will answer me." And it was made known to him, as it is said, "And God said to Moses, 'I will be that I will be,' etc." And the heavenly beings saw that the Holy One, Blessed be He, entrusted Moses with the secret of the Ineffable Name and they responded, "Blessed are You, who grants knowledge." Thus, it is explained in the aforementioned Pesiqta de-Rav Kahana that when He, blessed be He, said "I will be that I will be," He entrusted to Moses our teacher the secret of the Ineffable Name, and this is in accordance with Rabbi Yitzchak's opinion in the Midrash, which interprets it as "I was, I am, and I will be." And so too, the Holy Ohr HaChaim writes that here the Holy One, Blessed be He, revealed to Moses the secret of the great name, which is "was, is, and will be." Therefore, our Sages expounded, "I will be with them in this distress, just as I will be with them in another distress," etc. However, it is puzzling, for the meaning of the verses indicates that Moses asked what His name is and what he should say to them, and according to the understanding that he would say it to Israel, this was his question. And in Pesiqta de-Rav Kahana, it is said that Moses asked for the purpose of prayer for himself, as he said, "so that I may call upon You by Your name and You will answer me," which is not in accordance with the meaning of the verse.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, Moses asks God to reveal His great and holy name so that he can call upon it in prayer and receive answers. The response, "I am that I am," signifies the eternal and unchanging nature of God, encompassing past, present, and future. This revelation is understood as a profound secret of the ineffable name, emphasizing God's presence with His people in times of trouble. The discussion highlights the dual purpose of Moses' inquiry: both for personal prayer and for guiding the Israelites.

passage_content: יח פרשת בא אמרו מנין שאומרים בא"י אלקינו ואלקי אבותינו אלקי אברהם אלקי יצחק ואלקי יעקב בתפלה, שנאמר ויאמר עוד אלקים אל משה כה תאמר אל בנ"י ד' אלקי אבותיכם אלקי אברהם יצחק ויעקב וכו' וצ"ב שנראה שהוציאו בדרשתם הפסוק ממשמעותו, דפשטות הכוונה מורה ששאל משה ואמרו לו מה שמו, שישאלו ישראל על בשורת הגאולה אות, ובאיזה בחי' השם יהי' גאולתם, ולפי דרשת המכילתא היתה תשובתו יתברך מה שיזכירו בתפלתם, ותפלה מאן דכר שמיה.
translation: 18. In Parashat Bo, they said, from where do we know that we say "Blessed are You, our God and the God of our forefathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob" in prayer? As it is said, "And God said further to Moses, 'Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: The Lord, the God of your forefathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob...'" And it is difficult, for it seems that they have taken the verse out of its meaning in their interpretation, for the simple intention indicates that Moses asked and they told him what His name is, that the Israelites should ask about the tidings of redemption, a sign, and in what aspect of the name their redemption will be. And according to the interpretation of the Mekhilta, His Blessed Name's response was what they should mention in their prayer, and prayer is the one who remembers His name.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of invoking the names of the patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—in prayer, as indicated by God's instruction to Moses. It highlights the connection between the mention of these names and the theme of redemption, suggesting that the way the Israelites refer to God in their prayers reflects their understanding of His role in their salvation. The text emphasizes the importance of prayer as a means of invoking divine presence and assistance, aligning with Hasidic teachings on the power of intention and the spiritual connection to the ancestors.

passage_content: יט ואספת את זקני ישראל ואמרת אליהם וגו' פקד פקדתי אתכם וגו' ושמעו לקולך וגו' פרש"י ז"ל והוא במדרש רבה אמור להם פקד פקדתי מיד ושמעו לקולך, למה שמסורת גאולה הוא בידם מיוסף שכל גואל שיבוא ויאמר להם פקודה כפולה גואל של אמת הוא ע"כ. ואחר מאמר השם אליו ויען משה ויאמר והן לא יאמינו לי ולא ישמעו בקולי כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד', והוא מאמר מתמיה מאוד. כי איך יכחוש משרע"ה הדיבור האלקי , אחר שכבר יעדו השם ושמעו לקולך, ודיבורו יתברך אינו חוזרת ריקם, איך יאמר ההיפך ולא ישמעו בקולי, וצ"ב .
translation: 19 And you shall gather the elders of Israel and say to them, etc. "I have surely visited you," etc. "And they shall heed your voice," etc. Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains, and it is in Midrash Rabbah: "Tell them, 'I have surely visited you' immediately, and they shall heed your voice." The reason is that the tradition of redemption is in their hands from Joseph, for any redeemer who comes and tells them a double command is a true redeemer. Therefore, after the word of the Lord came to him, Moses answered and said, "But behold, they will not believe me and will not heed my voice, for they will say, 'The Lord did not appear to you.'" This is a very puzzling statement. For how could Moses deny the divine speech, after the Lord had already promised and they shall heed your voice? And His blessed word does not return empty; how could he say the opposite and that they will not heed my voice? This is indeed a question.
summary: The passage discusses the divine command given to Moses to gather the elders of Israel and convey God's message of redemption, emphasizing the importance of belief in the prophetic word. It highlights a Hasidic interpretation that the true redeemer must deliver a double proclamation, indicating authenticity. The text raises a theological question regarding Moses' doubt about the people's faith, despite God's assurance that they would listen, suggesting a deeper exploration of faith and divine promise in the context of redemption.

passage_content: כ) מה נתינת טעם הוא זו, כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד', ויספיק במה שיאמר לא יאמינו לי ולא ישמעו בקולי, ומובן שלא יאמינו שהוא שליח השם, ומה הוסיף הכתוב בכוונת אמרו כי יאמרו לא נראה וגו'.
translation: What is the reason for this? For they will say, "We have not seen the Lord," and it will suffice for what he says, "They will not believe me and will not listen to my voice," and it is understood that they will not believe that he is the messenger of Hashem. And what does the verse add by intending to say, "For they will say, 'We have not seen'..."
summary: The passage discusses the challenge of faith and belief in divine communication, highlighting the skepticism that arises when people claim they have not seen God. It emphasizes that the lack of direct revelation leads to doubt about the legitimacy of a messenger from God. The text suggests that this skepticism is a significant barrier to faith, illustrating the struggle between divine authority and human perception. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper theological implications of belief and the necessity of faith in the unseen.
