passage_content: כא פלא שהבוי"ת הסכים עמו שלא יאמינו בו עד שיעשה האותות לעיני העם, באמרו והי' אם לא יאמינו לקול האות הראשון והאמינו לקול האות האחרון, והי' אם לא יאמינו גם לשני האותות וגו', וה"ז כחזרה ח"ו בדבריו יתברך, שכבר אמר הקב"ה שתאמר להם פקד פקדתי וגו' ומיד ישמעו לקולך. כפרש"י שאחר שתאמר להם פקידה כפולה מיד ישמעו לקולך. ולבסוף נראה כהודאה לדברי משה שלא ישמעו אפילו אחר שיאמר להם הסימן של פקידה כפולה, ואחר שיעשה שני האותות עד האות השלישי.
translation: It is a wonder that the one who is to be sent agreed with him that they would not believe in him until he performs the signs before the people, as it is said, "And it shall be, if they do not believe the voice of the first sign, they will believe the voice of the last sign," and "And it shall be, if they do not believe even the two signs, etc." This is as if to say, G-d forbid, a reversal of the words of the Blessed One, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, already said that you should tell them, "I have surely remembered," and immediately they will listen to your voice. As Rashi explains, after you tell them of the double remembrance, they will immediately listen to your voice. And in the end, it seems like an acknowledgment of Moses' words that they will not listen even after he tells them the sign of the double remembrance, and after he performs the two signs up to the third sign.
summary: The passage discusses the divine agreement that the people would not believe Moses until he performed signs before them, highlighting a tension between God's promises and the people's skepticism. It reflects on the idea that even after witnessing miraculous signs, the people may still doubt, suggesting a profound struggle with faith and belief. This underscores the complexity of divine communication and human response, emphasizing that faith is not solely based on miracles but also on deeper spiritual understanding. Ultimately, it illustrates the challenge of fulfilling God's will in the face of human doubt.

translation: If they do not believe the two signs and do not listen to your voice, and you take from the waters of the river and pour them on the dry land, etc., the Abarbanel questions that if they were doubting and not believing in the first two signs due to their weakness, how will they believe in the third sign, which was not as strong as the first two.
summary: The passage discusses the challenge of belief in divine signs, specifically referencing the skepticism faced by Moses regarding the miracles he was to perform. The Abarbanel questions how the Israelites could doubt the first two signs due to their weakness, yet expect them to believe in a third sign that is not as powerful. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of faith, emphasizing the struggle between doubt and belief in the face of divine intervention. Ultimately, it highlights the necessity of faith in God's presence and the transformative power of belief, even amidst uncertainty.

passage_content: כג למה מיאן משה רבינו עוד, ואחר שהבטיחו השי"ת שיאמינו ישראל לקול האותות ויאמר משה וגו' לא איש דברים אנכי וגו' כי כבד פה וכבד לשון אנכי, ויאמר ד' מי שם פה לאדם וגו', ויאמר שלח נא ביד תשלח, והיתכן ח"ו שמיאן לעשות שליחותו יתברך, ורז"ל דרשו במדרש והובא ברש"י ז"ל עה"פ גם מתמול גם משלשם, ז' ימים קודם, הי' הקב"ה מפתה למשה שילך בשליחותו וכו' עד שחרה בו ואח"כ קבל עליו לילך, כמ"ש ויחר אף ד' וגו' ואיך יתכן בחי' זו בצדיקים. והלא כל תשוקתם לעשות רצונו יתברך, וששים ושמחים לעשות רצון קונם, ואיך יובן מה שסירב משרע"ה כ"כ לעשות מצות ד' שצוהו בפירוש.
translation: 23. Why did Moshe Rabbeinu still refuse, after the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured him that Israel would believe in the voice of the signs? And Moshe said, "I am not a man of words," for "I am heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue." And Hashem said, "Who has made man's mouth?" And he said, "Please send by the hand of whom You will send." Is it possible, Heaven forbid, that he refused to fulfill the mission of the Blessed One? And our Sages expounded in the Midrash, as brought by Rashi, on the verse "Also yesterday, also the day before," that seven days prior, the Holy One, Blessed be He, was enticing Moshe to go on His mission, until He became angry with him, and then he accepted to go, as it is written, "And the anger of Hashem burned." How can such a state be possible in the righteous? After all, their entire desire is to fulfill the will of the Blessed One, and they are joyful and happy to do the will of their Creator. How can it be understood that Moshe Rabbeinu so adamantly refused to carry out the commandments of Hashem that He explicitly commanded him?
summary: The passage discusses Moses' initial reluctance to accept God's command to lead the Israelites, despite God's assurance that they would believe in the signs. It raises the question of how a righteous figure like Moses could refuse to fulfill God's will, given that the essence of a tzaddik (righteous person) is to joyfully carry out God's desires. The text highlights the tension between human hesitation and divine purpose, illustrating the profound struggle within the soul of a righteous individual when faced with a divine mission. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of obedience and the complexities of faith in the face of divine command.

passage_content: כד) ז"ל כתב והוא במדרש (פר' סכ"א ) רבנן אמרי סבור אתה שהי' מעכב משה לילך, אינו כן אלא כמכבד לאהרן, שהי' משה אומר עד שלא עמדתי הי' אהרן אחי מתנבא להם במצרים וכו' עכשיו אכנס בתחומו של אחי ויהיה מיצר, בשביל כך לא הי' מבקש לילך, מיד ויחר אף ד' במשה וכו ', א"ל הקב"ה מה שאתה סבור שהוא מיצר, לא כן אלא שמח שנאמר וראך ושמח בלבו וכו '. ראוי להבין אם זה היה טעם המניעה, מה שמיאן משה רבינו לילך, הלא הקב"ה בוחן כליות ולב, וכל המחשבות הוא חוקר, ומדוע לא א"ל הקב"ה מיד וראך ושמח בלבו , ומדוע המתין יתברך להודיעו עד סוף ז' ימים.
translation: (24) It is written in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot) that the Rabbis said: Do you think that Moses was prevented from going? It is not so, but rather as one who honors Aaron, for Moses said, "Before I stood up, my brother Aaron was prophesying to them in Egypt, etc. Now I will enter into the domain of my brother, and it will be a source of distress." For this reason, he was not seeking to go. Immediately, the anger of the Holy One, blessed be He, burned against Moses, etc. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "What you think is a source of distress is not so, but rather he is happy," as it is said, "And you shall see him and he will rejoice in his heart," etc. It is fitting to understand if this was the reason for the prevention, why Moses our teacher refused to go, for the Holy One, blessed be He, examines the innermost thoughts and hearts, and He investigates all thoughts. Why did He not say to him immediately, "And you shall see him and he will rejoice in his heart," and why did the Blessed One wait to inform him until the end of seven days?
summary: The passage discusses the reluctance of Moses to go to Egypt, interpreting it as a sign of respect for his brother Aaron, who had been prophesying in Egypt before Moses' arrival. It highlights the idea that God understands the true intentions of the heart, suggesting that Moses' hesitation was not due to a lack of faith but rather a concern for Aaron's feelings. The text raises questions about why God did not immediately clarify Aaron's joy at Moses' arrival, emphasizing the complexity of divine communication and human emotions in the context of leadership and prophecy.

passage_content: כה) ז"ל כתב הסיבה למשה בכל הסרבנות הזאת, ענותנותו הגדולה מכל האדם, שלא הי' מוצא את לבו להתגדל ולהתפאר לאמר ד' שלחני, ולא על ישראל להוציאם ממצרים ולהיות עליהם מלך עכת"ד, וגם טעם זה צ"ב כי מה מקום לענו ' אצל מצותו יתברך שצוהו להדיא , והרי צ"ל ויגבה לבו בדרכי ד', והגם שחשב לצד ענותנותו שאינו כדאי וראוי מצד עצמו להיות גואלם של ישראל, אבל הרי יש לו כח המשלחו יתברך, והבטיחו השי"ת ואנכי אהיה עם פיך וא"כ אין מקום לענוה בכאן וצ"ב
translation: The reason for Moses in all this refusal, his great humility above all men, was that he did not find it in his heart to exalt himself and boast, saying that the Holy One, blessed be He, sent me, nor to claim that it was for the sake of Israel to take them out of Egypt and to be their king, as stated. This reason is also questionable, for what place does humility have in relation to the command of the Blessed One who commanded him explicitly? And it is written, "And his heart was lifted up in the ways of the Lord." Although he thought, due to his humility, that he was not worthy and suitable in himself to be the redeemer of Israel, he indeed has the power of the One who sent him, blessed be He, and the Holy One, blessed be He, promised him, "And I will be with your mouth." Therefore, there is no place for humility here, and this is also questionable.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' profound humility, which prevented him from taking pride in his divine mission to lead the Israelites out of Egypt. It questions the appropriateness of his humility in light of God's explicit command and assurance of support, suggesting that Moses' self-doubt was unwarranted given his role as a chosen leader. The text highlights the tension between humility and the necessity of embracing one's divinely appointed responsibilities. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of recognizing one's capabilities as granted by God, rather than solely through personal merit.

translation: "Thus, Moses and Aaron, you shall disturb the people from their deeds. In the Midrash, what is the reason? summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the text discusses the role of Moses and Aaron in guiding the people away from their actions, emphasizing the importance of their words and intentions. The phrase "you" refers to the leaders' personal responsibility, while "your words" signifies the power of their teachings. This highlights the Hasidic concept that true leadership involves both action and the transformative potential of speech. Ultimately, it underscores the necessity of aligning one's deeds with divine guidance to elevate the community spiritually.

passage_content: כח בפדר"א (פרק מ') אמר לפניו רבון כל העולמים שלח נא ביד תשלח, ביד אותו האיש שאתה עתיד לשלוח דהוא אלי', כמ"ש הנה אנכי שולח לכם את אלי' הנביא, א"ל הקב"ה לאותו האיש שאתה אומר, אני שולח לע"ל אל ישראל וכו ', וכ"כ התרגום יוב"ע שלח נא ביד תשלח, ביד פנחס דעתיד למשתלחא בסוף יומיא , והוא ע"ד שאמז"ל פנחס זה אלי'. וראוי להבין דברי חכמים וחידותם . ומה היה כוונת משרע"ה שהגואל העתיד יהיה השליח דוקא .
translation: In the 20th chapter of the Midrash (Pederan), it is said that Moses spoke before the Master of all worlds, "Please send by the hand of him whom You will send," referring to that man whom You are destined to send, who is Elijah, as it is written, "Behold, I send you Elijah the prophet." The Holy One, blessed be He, responded to that man you are speaking of, "I will send him in the future to Israel," etc. And so too the translation of Yov"an says, "Please send by the hand of him whom You will send," by the hand of Pinchas who is destined to be sent at the end of days, and this is in accordance with what our sages have said, "This Pinchas is Elijah." It is fitting to understand the words of the sages and their riddles. And what was the intention of Moses that the future redeemer would specifically be the messenger.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between Moses and God highlights the concept of divine messengers, specifically the future role of Elijah the Prophet as a redeemer. Moses requests that God send the future redeemer through a specific individual, emphasizing the belief that the ultimate redemption will be facilitated by a chosen emissary. The text also connects this idea to the figure of Pinchas, suggesting a continuity in the role of messengers throughout Jewish history. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of redemption and the importance of human agency in fulfilling divine plans.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים מה דאיתא במד"ר (פ"ג ס"ד) וז"ל ויאמר משה מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה, א"ר יהושע בן לוי אמר משה לפני הקב"ה, כשירד יעקב למצרים לא כך אמרת לו, אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, ועכשיו אתה אומר לו לכה ואשלחך אל פרעה, לא אנכי הוא שאמרת לו ואנכי אעלך גם עלה עכ"ד המדרש, והנה טען משרע"ה בזה טענה עצומה, שיקיים השי"ת הבטחתו מה שהבטיח ליעקב אבינו ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, ולא מצינו שהשיבו הקב"ה על טענה זו. ונראה דזה היתה עיקר טענתו וטעם סרבנותו במה שמיאן ללכת בשליחות, ובזה יתבאר כל הענין , דידע משרע"ה דא"א שיהיה גאולת עולם וגאולה נצחית, אא"כ הבוי"ת בעצמו יגאלם כמו שיהיה לעתיד שלא על ידי שלוחי בשר ודם.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin with what is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, Section 4): "And Moses said, 'Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh?' Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said, Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, 'When Jacob descended to Egypt, did You not say to him, "I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also bring you up"? And now You say to him, "Come, and I will send you to Pharaoh"? Is it not I who You said to him, "And I will also bring you up"?'" Thus far the Midrash. And behold, Moses raised a tremendous argument in this, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, should fulfill His promise to our forefather Jacob, "And I will also bring you up." And we do not find that the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to this argument. It seems that this was his main argument and the reason for his refusal to go on the mission, and through this, the entire matter will be clarified, for Moses knew that it is impossible for there to be a redemption of the world and an eternal redemption unless the Blessed One Himself redeems them, just as it will be in the future, not through the agency of flesh and blood.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, Moses expresses a profound concern regarding God's promise to Jacob that He would accompany him to Egypt and later bring him back. Moses argues that if God had made such a commitment, it should be fulfilled directly rather than through human intermediaries. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that true redemption must come from God Himself, emphasizing the belief in a future, ultimate redemption that transcends human efforts. Moses's reluctance to accept the mission reflects a deep understanding of the nature of divine intervention and the necessity of God's direct involvement in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ומבואר כן במדרש ילקוט זכרי' (רמז תקע"ז) אשריך ישראל מי כמוך עם נושע בד', אמר הקב"ה בעוה"ז הייתם נושעים ע"י בני אדם, במצרים ע"י משה ואהרן, בימי סיסרא ע"י דבורה וכו ', וע"י שהיו שלוחי בשר ודם הייתם חוזרים ומשתעבדים, אבל לע"ל אני בעצמי גואל אתכם, ועוד יותר אין אתם משתעבדים, שנאמר ישראל נושע בד' תשועת עולמים עכ"ד המדרש, מבואר דע"י שלוחי בשר ודם א"א שיהיה גאולה נצחית, ומשרע"ה ראה וידע כל העתיד לבוא עליהם בשעבוד מלכיות , ע"כ רצה להמתיק ולקרב את הגאולה שלימה, שיהיה מיד ע"י הבוי"ת לבדו, ולא יצטרכו עוד להשלים גזירת הגלות ע"י שעבוד מלכיות , וזה הי' טעם הסרבנות שלא רצה להיות השליח, ויבואר להלן שכל טענותיו היו תפלה ותחנונים לפני הקב"ה, והלביש תפילתו בטענות וסברות, אבל עצם כוונתו הי' למסור נפשו עבור ישראל, שיהיה גאולתן גאולת עולם, וע"כ טען לא כך אמרת ליעקב ואנכי אעלך גם עלה. ועד"ז הי' כל טענותיו שיגאלם הקב"ה בעצמו.
translation: And it is explained thus in the Midrash Yalkut Zechariah (Remez 871): "Fortunate are you, Israel, who is like you, a people saved by the Lord." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "In this world, you were saved by human beings, in Egypt by Moses and Aaron, in the days of Sisera by Deborah, etc. And because they were agents of flesh and blood, you would return and be enslaved. But in the future, I Myself will redeem you, and even more, you will not be enslaved, as it is said: 'Israel is saved by the Lord, a salvation of worlds.'" Thus, it is clear that through agents of flesh and blood, an eternal redemption cannot be achieved. And since Moses saw and knew all that would come upon them in the subjugation of kingdoms, he therefore wanted to sweeten and bring about the complete redemption, that it should be immediately through the Holy One, Blessed be He, alone, and they would no longer need to complete the decree of exile through the subjugation of kingdoms. This was the reason for his refusal to be the messenger, and it will be explained below that all his arguments were prayers and supplications before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and he clothed his prayer in arguments and reasoning, but his true intention was to give his life for Israel, that their redemption should be an eternal redemption. Therefore, he argued: "Is this not what You said to Jacob, 'And I will surely bring you up again'?" And similarly, all his arguments were that the Holy One, Blessed be He, should redeem them Himself.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of redemption in Jewish thought, emphasizing that true and eternal redemption can only come directly from God, rather than through human intermediaries. It highlights that while past redemptions involved human leaders like Moses and Deborah, these were ultimately temporary and led to further subjugation. Moses' reluctance to be a messenger stemmed from his desire for a complete and everlasting redemption for Israel, which he believed could only be achieved through God's direct intervention. His prayers and arguments were aimed at ensuring that the future redemption would be a final and ultimate salvation.

passage_content: אמנם לא הי' אפשר להיות כן מכמה טעמים, שלא הגיע הזמן עדיין שיגאלו גאולת עולם גם לא היו ישראל ראוים ולא הי' זכותם כדאי, להיות הגאולה בבחי ' זכו אחישנה , הגם שהיו ישראל מצוינים במדות טובות כמ"ש במדרשי חז"ל ובזוהר הק ', דאסתמרו מנדה ומבת אל נכר ולא נמצא ביניהן פרוץ בעריות אף שהי' קודם מתן תורה, אעפ"כ היה גדול הקטרוג עליהם לצד שעבדו ע"ז, כמ"ש שר של מצרים הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו עוע"ז , ואפשר שזה גרם גם לשאר עבירות דעבירה גוררת עבירה. ועיקר טעם המניעה הוא למעלה מהשגתנו, שלא היה עדיין גמר בירור הניצוצות, הגם שבמצרים נתקנו כל הניצה"ק כמ"ש וינצלו את מצרים, אבל בכל העולם היו עדיין הניצה"ק מפוזרים בשבי ביד הקליפות, וע"כ הי' ההכרח שיהיו ישראל עוד בשאר גליות לברר וללקט הניצה"ק מארצות פזוריהם, ואלמלי זכו ישראל הי' להם הכח למשוך הניצה"ק אליהם מכל העולם, ולבררם ולתקנם במקום שהם, כמ"ש האר"י ז"ל וכמ"ש האוחה"ק בפ ' בהר. אבל לא הי' זכותם מספיק לזה, ואפשר לומר עפ"י דרך הרמב"ן ז"ל שהסיבה למשרע"ה בכל הסרבנות הזאת, הי' לצד ענותנותו הגדולה מכל אדם, ותלה החסרון בעצמו, שאין זכותו כדאי שיגאלו על ידו גאולת עולם, וע"כ בקש והתפלל שיהיה הגאולה ע"י שליח אחר שזכותו גדול ממנו, ואפשר שיסייע זכות השליח שיגאלו ישראל גאולת עולם.
translation: Indeed, it was not possible for this to happen for several reasons: the time for the ultimate redemption had not yet arrived, and the Jewish people were not worthy, nor was their merit sufficient for the redemption to occur in the manner of "if they are worthy, I will hasten it." Although the Jews were distinguished by good traits, as stated in the teachings of our Sages and in the Zohar, that they were careful from the impure and from the daughter of a foreign god, and there was not found among them one who was promiscuous, even though this was before the giving of the Torah, nevertheless, there was a great accusation against them because they served idols, as it is said, "the minister of Egypt, these are idol worshippers, and these are idol worshippers." It is possible that this also caused other transgressions, for one sin leads to another. The main reason for the prevention is beyond our comprehension, as the final rectification of the sparks had not yet been completed. Although in Egypt all the holy sparks were rectified, as it is said, "and they plundered the Egyptians," in the rest of the world, the holy sparks were still scattered in captivity in the hands of the klipot. Therefore, it was necessary for the Jews to remain in other exiles to clarify and gather the holy sparks from the lands of their dispersion. Had the Jews been worthy, they would have had the power to draw the holy sparks to themselves from all over the world and to rectify them in their place, as the Ari"zal teaches and as is stated in the holy writings in Parashat Behar. But their merit was not sufficient for this, and it can be said according to the way of the Ramban that the reason for Moshe Rabbeinu's entire reluctance was due to his great humility, greater than any other person, and he attributed the shortcoming to himself, feeling that his merit was not sufficient for the ultimate redemption to be accomplished through him. Therefore, he requested and prayed that the redemption be through another messenger whose merit was greater than his, and perhaps the merit of the messenger would assist in redeeming the Jewish people with the ultimate redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons for the delay in the ultimate redemption of the Jewish people, emphasizing that they were not yet worthy of such a significant salvation due to their past sins, particularly idolatry. Despite their commendable qualities, the spiritual rectification of the divine sparks scattered throughout the world was incomplete, necessitating their continued exile. It highlights the humility of Moses, who believed his own merits were insufficient for the redemption and sought a more worthy messenger to lead the people to salvation. This reflects a deep theological insight into the interplay of human merit, divine timing, and the process of spiritual rectification in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל בדברי הזוה"ק פ' תצא בר"מ (דף רע"ח) וז"ל ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש, דכלהון חייבין ולא אשכחת בהון איש זוכה לאפקא מן גלותא, ובגין דא סרב למיזל תמן ואמר שלח נא ביד תשלח, ע"כ. ואפשר שלכוונה זו רצה שיהיה אהרן השליח, שלגודל ענותנותו חשב שאהרן זכותו גדול, ויסייע זכותו שיגאלו גאולת עולם. ועד"ז יבואר הפדר"א שאמר משה שלח נא ביד תשלח ביד אלי', ומ"ש התרגום יוב"ע ביד פנחס דעתיד למשתלחא בסוף יומיא , והכל הולך לכוונה א', דחשב משה רבינו דע"י זכותם יזכו ישראל להגאל גאולת עולם, כמו שיהיו שלוחים לעתיד בבחי ' זו, ושורש הענין שלא היה ח"ו מסרב במצות השי"ת, אלא שהיו כל אלו הטענות בדרך תפלה ובקשה לפני הבוי"ת , שיהיה הגאולה ע"י שליח אחר, ובבחינה אחרת שיהיה גאולת עולם ונצחית. אבל הבוי"ת המגיד מראשית אחרית, ידע שעדיין לא הגיע זמנם שיגאלו גאולת עולם, והיה ההכרח לגאלם מיד בלי איחור, כמ"ש האר"י ז"ל בפי' הכתוב ולא יכלו להתמהמה, כי אלמלא נשארו עוד רגע היו משוקעים ח"ו בשער הנ ' של טומאת מצרים, ולא הי' יכולים לצאת משם עוד לעולם, ע"כ הי' ההכרח לגאלם גאולת שעה, ולהשלים הבירור בשאר גליות.
translation: And similarly, it can be said in the words of the Zohar, Parashat Tetzaveh, in the section of Remez (page 218), and it says: "And he turned this way and that and saw that there was no man," for all of them are liable, and he did not find a man worthy to take them out of exile. And because of this, he refused to go there and said, "Please send by the hand of him whom You will send." It is possible that for this intention, he wanted Aaron to be the messenger, for due to his humility, he thought that Aaron's merit was great, and his merit would assist in redeeming them with an eternal redemption. Similarly, it will be explained in the Peder Avot, where Moses said, "Please send by the hand of him whom You will send," and what the translation says, "by the hand of Pinchas who is destined to be sent at the end of days," and all goes to one intention, for Moses our teacher thought that through their merit, Israel would merit an eternal redemption, just as they would be messengers in that aspect in the future. The root of the matter is that he was not, Heaven forbid, refusing the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, but all these arguments were in the manner of prayer and request before the Blessed One, that the redemption should be through another messenger, and in another aspect, that it should be an eternal and everlasting redemption. But the Blessed One, who declares the end from the beginning, knew that their time had not yet come for them to be redeemed with an eternal redemption, and it was necessary to redeem them immediately without delay, as the Ari, of blessed memory, explained in the interpretation of the verse, "And they could not delay," for if they had remained even for a moment longer, they would have been sunk, Heaven forbid, in the fiftieth gate of the impurity of Egypt, and they would not have been able to leave from there ever again. Therefore, it was necessary to redeem them with a temporary redemption, and to complete the clarification in the other exiles.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption in the context of the Jewish people's suffering in exile, emphasizing the importance of merit and the role of intermediaries in achieving salvation. It highlights Moses' request for a different messenger, reflecting his humility and belief that the merits of others, like Aaron, could facilitate a more profound redemption. However, it acknowledges that divine knowledge dictates the timing of redemption, necessitating an immediate, albeit temporary, salvation to prevent further spiritual degradation. Ultimately, the text underscores the tension between human agency and divine providence in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ועתה נבאר הפסוק ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו כי ידעתי את מכאוביו וגו' והדקדוקים שבענין כבר נפרטו לעיל, דהנה אף שהיו ישראל גדורים בעריות במצרים, אעפ"כ לגודל טומאת מצרים, אם מידי עבירה יצאו מידי הרהור לא יצאו, וזה גרם אח"כ לשאר עבירות כמ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל דממחשבה רעה נברא מלאך רע. המכריחו אח"כ להשלים ולהוציא מכח אל הפועל מחשבתו הרעה אשר חשב, גם שהיו משוקעים בע"ז, והיה הקטרוג גדול עליהם מאוד, כמ"ש ז"ל שטען שר של מצרים הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז , אולם היה לימוד זכות גדול על ישראל, עפימ"ש האוהחה"ק בפ ' תבוא וירעו אותנו המצרים, שעשו אותנו רעים כמותם, וירא את ענינו הוא אפיסת כח הלוחם, שאין בנו כח המספיק להלחם נגד היצה"ר ולהתגבר עליו, ואת עמלינו, הוא העמל שאנו צריכין לעמול במלחמתו, ואת לחצנו זו הדחק, שדוחק היצר את האדם לחטוא בע"כ , ואין אדם שליט ברוחו להנצל ממנו, ולולי הקב"ה עזרו אין יכול לו. ועוד כתב האוהחה"ק בפ ' שופטים עה"פ עם רב ממך, כי אחר שנכשל אדם בעבירות ר"ל, יתוספו כחות הרע בקרבו, והן אלו שנולדו ממעשיו הרעים ויכריחו אותו לחטוא עוד ר"ל. וכי ירבה לחטוא ירבו המקטריגים האלה, ויגדל בו כח ההסתה, וזהו סוד מאמר עבירה גוררת עבירה עכלה"ק וזהו לימוד זכות על ישראל, דכמעט אנוסים היו במצרים, ומוכרחים היו ע"י כח המסית המחטיאם, ולא הי' בהם כח לעמוד נגדו כי חזק הוא ממנו.
translation: And now we will explain the verse "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters, for I know their pain," etc. The nuances of the matter have already been detailed above. Behold, even though the Israelites were guarded against immorality in Egypt, nevertheless, due to the great impurity of Egypt, if they were freed from sin, they were not freed from evil thoughts. This later caused them to commit other sins, as the Maharsha, of blessed memory, stated that from an evil thought, an evil angel is created. This then compelled them to complete and bring forth into action the evil thoughts they had. Also, they were steeped in idolatry, and there was a great accusation against them, as it is said that the minister of Egypt claimed, "These are idol worshippers, and those are idol worshippers." However, there was a great merit for Israel, as the holy author writes in Parashat Ki Tavo, "And the Egyptians dealt harshly with us," that they made us evil like them. And He saw our affliction, which is the exhaustion of the warrior, that we do not have the strength sufficient to fight against the evil inclination and to overcome it, and our toil, which is the effort we need to exert in its war, and our oppression, which is the pressure that the evil inclination exerts on a person to sin against his will, and no person has control over his spirit to escape from it, and were it not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping him, he would not be able to withstand it. Furthermore, the holy author wrote in Parashat Shoftim on the verse "With a mighty one from you," that after a person has stumbled in sins, may it be erased, the forces of evil within him increase, and these are those that were born from his evil deeds and will compel him to sin again, may it be erased. And as he increases in sin, these accusers will multiply, and the power of temptation will grow within him, and this is the secret of the saying "A sin brings another sin," as the holy text states, and this is a merit for Israel, for they were almost coerced in Egypt, and they were compelled by the power of the tempter that caused them to sin, and they did not have the strength to stand against it because it is stronger than them.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual struggles of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that despite their moral failings, they were almost coerced into sin by the overwhelming influence of their environment and the evil inclination. It highlights the concept that negative thoughts can lead to further transgressions, creating a cycle of sin that is difficult to escape without divine assistance. The text also points out that the Israelites' suffering and weakness in resisting temptation were recognized by God, who understood their plight and the external pressures they faced. Ultimately, it conveys a message of compassion for the struggles of the Jewish people, portraying them as victims of circumstance rather than willful sinners.

passage_content: ופרשתי בזה מ"ד בילקוט פ' בשלח (רמז רל"ד) והוא במדרש אבכיר עה"פ והמים להם חמה, חמה כתיב שירד ס"מ, ואמר לפניו רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים. ואתה עושה להם נסים וכו ', מיד השיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם, וכי לדעתם עבדוה והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף דעת, ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון, כיון ששמע שר של ים, אותה חמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירה על מצרים, וכו' עכ"ד הילקוט. ולכאורה יש לתמוה על טענה זו דאונס , דלא מצינו שהיו ישראל אנוסים לע"ז במצרים, ועוד הרי בע"ז ליתא התנצלות אונס כלל, דדינו ביהרג ואל יעבור, והפרשת דרכים דקדק עוד מה שקרא ד' לס"מ שוטה שבעולם, שלא יצדק לו תואר זה ואינו אלא חכם להרע, וחז"ל מכנים אותו בשם רשע, עיי"ש תירוצו בדרך פלפול.
translation:
And I have explained this in the Midrash, as found in Yalkut Parashat Beshalach (Remez 244), which is in the Midrash Abkir on the verse "and the waters were hot for them." It is written that it descended as a hot wind, and he said before Him, Master of the Universe, did Israel not serve idols in Egypt? And You perform miracles for them, etc. Immediately, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world, do you think they served it willingly? They did not serve it except out of servitude and madness, and you judge a mistake as if it were intentional and coercion as if it were desire." When the minister of the sea heard this, that hot wind which was directed against Israel was turned back upon Egypt, etc. Thus far the Yalkut. 

At first glance, one might wonder about this claim of coercion, for we do not find that Israel was coerced into idol worship in Egypt. Moreover, in the case of idol worship, there is no excuse of coercion at all, as its ruling is to be killed rather than transgress. And the separation of paths further emphasizes what he called the minister of the sea a "fool of the world," for this title does not befit him; he is rather wise in doing evil, and our Sages refer to him as wicked. See there for his resolution in a manner of pilpul.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses a midrashic interpretation regarding the Israelites' relationship with idolatry in Egypt, emphasizing that their worship was not genuine but rather a result of oppression and mental turmoil. The text highlights the distinction between intentional sin and actions taken under duress, suggesting that God rebukes the accuser for misjudging the Israelites' intentions. The passage also critiques the notion of divine justice, questioning the fairness of attributing blame to those who act under compulsion, and underscores the complexity of moral responsibility in the context of suffering and coercion.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר דאין הכוונה שהיה האונס ע"י המצרים, הגם שגרמו להרע ועשו פעולות להרבות כחות הטומאה בישראל ונתקלקלו ישראל על ידם כמ"ש השלה"ק במסכת פסחים וירעו אותנו המצרים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים, אבל לא הי' בדרך כפי' ואונס ע"י המצריים, והכפיה היה ע"י כחות הטומאה, דאם חוטאים ר"ל הרבה פעמים מתגברים כחות הטומאה על האדם, ונאבדה הימנו בחי' הדעת, כמ"ש ז"ל אין אדם חוטא אא"כ נכנס בו רוח שטות, ואח"כ הוא כנאנס בחטאו, שאין לו כח ודעת לעמוד נגד יצרו ולהתגבר עליו. ואין בכח אנושי לעמוד נגד היצה"ר , כמ"ש ז"ל אלמלא הקב"ה עזרו אין יכול לו וא"כ ה"ה כאונס יחשב, והנה אמרו חז"ל דיצה"ר מניח כל האומות ואינו מתגרה בהן אלא בישראל, וזה היה טענת לימוד זכות ממנו יתברך על ישראל, דהללו באונס והללו ברצון, דאונס הכפי' מצד התגברות היצר אינו אלא בישראל, וע"כ הם נחשבים לגבי החטא כאונס, אבל המצריים ואומות העולם אין היצה"ר מתגרה בהם כמ"ש ז"ל, וא"כ כל חטאתם ברצון ובלי כפיה.
translation: And it can be said that the intention is not that the coercion was by the Egyptians, even though they caused harm and took actions to increase the forces of impurity in Israel, and Israel was corrupted by them, as it is written in the Shlah HaKadosh in Tractate Pesachim: "And the Egyptians made us evil and sinful." However, it was not in the manner of coercion and force by the Egyptians, and the compulsion was by the forces of impurity. For if one sins, so to speak, many times the forces of impurity gain strength over a person, and the aspect of knowledge is lost from him, as our Sages of blessed memory said: "No person sins unless a spirit of folly enters him," and afterwards he is like one who is coerced in his sin, as he has no strength or knowledge to stand against his evil inclination and to overcome it. And there is no human power to stand against the evil inclination, as our Sages of blessed memory said: "If not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping him, he cannot prevail," and thus it is considered like coercion. And behold, our Sages said that the evil inclination leaves all the nations and does not provoke them except for Israel, and this was the argument for merit from Him, blessed be He, regarding Israel, that these are coerced and those are willing, for the coercion of the evil inclination's strength is only against Israel, and therefore they are considered regarding sin as coerced, but the Egyptians and the nations of the world do not have the evil inclination provoke them, as our Sages of blessed memory said, and thus all their sins are willingly and without compulsion.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of sin and temptation, emphasizing that the Israelites' transgressions are often a result of overwhelming forces of impurity rather than direct coercion by the Egyptians. It suggests that when individuals sin, they may feel as if they are compelled, akin to being forced, due to the overpowering influence of the evil inclination (yetzer hara). In contrast, the nations of the world do not experience this same level of spiritual struggle, leading to the conclusion that their sins are committed willingly, without the guise of compulsion. Thus, the Israelites' sins are viewed as akin to being coerced, highlighting a unique spiritual challenge faced by the Jewish people.

passage_content: ומ"ש לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם אפ"ל הכוונה, עפי"מ שאמרו חז"ל אין אדם חוטא אא"כ נכנס בו רוח שטות, ולכאורה הרי אנו רואין דרוב פעמים נעשית העבירה בתחבולות שונות, ובהתחכמות נפלא ובעצה ומזימה, ואיך יוצדק לומר דמקור החטא הוא ע"י רוח שטות. אמנם עצם הרעיון הוא שטות גדול שאין כמוהו, למרוד בבורא עולם ית"ש , ומקור הרעיון הזה מכחו של הס"מ והשטן המשטהו, ואח"כ נותן לו היצה"ר עצה ותחבולה והתחכמות, להוציא מכח אל הפועל את השטות הזה ולהביאו לידי גמר, אבל מקור החטא הוא ע"י רוח שטות המשטהו ומאבד הימנו בחי' הדעת, ועי"ז מתפתה בעצת יצרו הרע ואח"כ נותן בו היצה"ר התחכמות להרע לגמור מעשהו ולכך השיב הקב"ה לס"מ שועה שבעולם, ר"ל שכל הרוח שטות שבעולם הוא ממך וע"י כחך, וא"כ ידוע לך עוצם התגברות כחות הטומאה, ושהעבירה נעשה מבלי דעת ובבחי ' אונס, וא"כ בטלה טענתך מה בין אלו לאלו, שהללו באונס והללו ברצון.
translation: And what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "a fool in the world," can be understood in light of what our Sages have said, that no person sins unless a spirit of folly enters them. At first glance, we see that most of the time, the sin is committed through various cunning strategies, with wonderful cleverness and advice and schemes. How can it be justified to say that the source of sin is through a spirit of folly? However, the very idea is a great folly without equal, to rebel against the Creator of the world, blessed be He. The source of this idea comes from the power of the accuser and the Satan who misleads him, and then the evil inclination gives him advice and cunning and cleverness to bring this folly from potential to actual, to bring it to completion. But the source of sin is through a spirit of folly that misleads him and causes him to lose the aspect of knowledge, and thereby he is tempted by the advice of his evil inclination, and then the evil inclination gives him cleverness to do evil and complete his act. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, responded to the accuser, "a fool in the world," meaning that all the spirit of folly in the world comes from you and through your power. Thus, it is known to you the great strength of the forces of impurity, and that the sin is done without knowledge and in a state of coercion. Therefore, your claim is nullified, what is the difference between these and those, that these are in a state of coercion and those are willingly.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that sin originates from a "spirit of folly" instigated by the forces of evil, particularly the Satan and the evil inclination (Yetzer Hara). It emphasizes that while individuals may employ cunning and strategy to commit sins, the root cause is a loss of awareness and understanding, leading to misguided actions. The text asserts that the power of temptation and sin is ultimately a result of this folly, which is a manifestation of the forces of impurity. Thus, the distinction between sins committed willingly and those done under duress is challenged, as both stem from this underlying spiritual confusion.

passage_content: ולכאורה ראוי להבין דמעיקרא למה ברא הקב"ה את היצה"ר באופן זה, ונתן לו כח חזק כ"כ שלא יהא בכח אנושי להתגבר עליו, כמ"ש ז"ל אלמלא הקב"ה עזרו לא יכול לו דהרי ודאי שהבוי"ת נתן לו הכח , דאין כאן ב' רשויות ח"ו, ולמה קבל כח חזק כזה, הלא עי"ז אין קו המשקל שו ' לבחור בטוב או ברע, ואפשר לומר ב' טעמים ע"ז, טעם הא' כדי שידע האדם כי אין בכח אנושי להנצל ממנו ואלמלא הקב"ה עזרו אין יכול לו, ועי"ז יפנה תמיד אליו יתברך, ויתפלל להבוי"ת שינצל מכוחות היצר ותחבולותיו, וכולי האי ואולי יועיל לו. וטעם הב' כדי שיהיה לימוד זכות נגד המקטריגים , דהוא המקטרג והוא המסית כמ"ש ז"ל הוא שטן הוא יצה"ר , ויורד ומסית ועולה ומקטרג: ומעתה יש טענה כנגדו דהוא הגורם ע"י כח ההתגברות החזק שמכביד על האדם, עד שאין בו כח לנשוא ולעמוד כנגדו, וכמ"ש חז"ל במסכת ברכות (דף ל"ב) אלמלא ג' מקראות הללו נתמוטטו רגליהם של שונאי ישראל, חד דכתיב ואשר הרעותי , וחד דכתיב והסירותי את לב האבן מבשרכם וגו'. ועוד אמרו שם שהודה הקב"ה ואמר ואשר הרעותי , פרש"י כלומר אני גרמתי להם שבראתי יצה"ר , ופי' בזה בספה"ק זרע קודש בפ ' נצבים, ושב ד' אלקיך את שבותך, שע"י תשובתך יעשה הקב"ה ג"כ תשובה ויגאלנו מיד היצה"ר , נמצא שזו לימוד זכות גדול דכח היצר הוא הגורם כנ"ל.
translation: And seemingly, it is appropriate to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, created the evil inclination in this manner from the outset, and gave it such strong power that it would not be within human ability to overcome it, as our sages of blessed memory said, "If not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping him, he could not prevail." For it is certain that the Creator gave it the power, as there are not two authorities, Heaven forbid. And why did it receive such strong power? After all, through this, there is no balance to choose between good and evil. It is possible to say two reasons for this. The first reason is so that a person knows that it is not within human power to be saved from it, and if not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping him, he cannot prevail. And through this, he will always turn to the Blessed One and pray to the Creator to be saved from the forces of the evil inclination and its tricks, and perhaps this will be of help to him. The second reason is so that there will be a merit against the accusers, for he is the accuser and he is the tempter, as our sages of blessed memory said, "He is the Satan, he is the evil inclination," and he descends and tempts and ascends and accuses. From now on, there is a claim against him that he is the cause, through the strong power of overcoming that weighs heavily on a person, until he has no strength to bear and stand against it, as our sages of blessed memory said in Tractate Berakhot (32a), "If not for these three verses, the legs of the enemies of Israel would have collapsed," one that is written, "And I have caused them to be evil," and one that is written, "And I will remove the heart of stone from your flesh," etc. And they also said there that the Holy One, blessed be He, admitted and said, "And I have caused them to be evil," which Rashi explains means, "I caused them because I created the evil inclination." And this is explained in the holy book Zera Kodesh in Parashat Nitzavim, "And the Lord your God will return your captivity," that through your repentance, the Holy One, blessed be He, will also repent and redeem us immediately from the evil inclination. Thus, it turns out that this is a great merit that the power of the evil inclination is the cause, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the purpose behind God creating the evil inclination (yetzer hara) with such overwhelming strength that humans cannot overcome it without divine assistance. It suggests two main reasons for this: first, to compel individuals to turn to God in prayer for help against the yetzer hara, and second, to provide a basis for defense against accusers by highlighting that the yetzer hara itself is a divine creation that serves as a test. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of human repentance and reliance on God for redemption from the yetzer hara's influence.

passage_content: ואפשר שזה הפשט ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו , אעפ"י שלא היו ראוין להגאל עדיין, שלא היתה תשובתם שלימה, כמ"ש במכילתא פ' בא אמר הקב"ה אם עושין תשובה אני גואלם לדורות ואם לא אני גואלם לשעה, נראה מזה שלא עשו תשובה הגונה ושלימה, ולא היו כדאי להגאל , אבל לימוד זכות הי' עליהם, מצד התגברות כחות הטומאה וכחות מצרים, ועי"ז היו כל החטאים בבחי ' כפי' ואונס כנ"ל, וז"ש ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו , וזהו נתינת טעם על שמעתי, דע"כ שמעתי מפני שהיה הגורם לחטאם ע"י נגשיו , היינו כחות היצר וטומאת מצרים, וכאונס נחשבו, ומתורץ קושית האוהחה"ק הנ"ל ( בקושיא ה').
translation: And it is possible that this is the explanation: "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," even though they were not yet worthy of redemption, as their repentance was not complete, as it is stated in the Mekilta, Parashat Bo: "The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: If they repent, I will redeem them for generations, and if not, I will redeem them for the moment." It appears from this that they did not make a proper and complete repentance, and they were not worthy of redemption. However, there was a merit for them due to the overwhelming forces of impurity and the powers of Egypt, and as a result, all their sins were considered as if they were coerced, as mentioned above. And this is what is meant by "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," which provides a reason for "I have heard," for indeed I heard because their sin was caused by their taskmasters, meaning the forces of the evil inclination and the impurity of Egypt, and they were considered as coerced. This resolves the question of the holy author mentioned above (in question 5).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption in relation to the Israelites' cries for help, emphasizing that although they were not yet worthy of redemption due to their incomplete repentance, their suffering under the oppression of Egypt was a mitigating factor. It suggests that their sins were considered as coerced actions, influenced by the overwhelming forces of impurity and the evil inclination. This perspective highlights the idea of divine compassion and the potential for redemption, even in the face of imperfection, as God listens to their cries due to the circumstances of their oppression. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interplay between human agency, divine mercy, and the challenges posed by external forces.

passage_content: ובדרך זה אפ"ל כי ידעתי את מכאוביו עפימ"ש ז"ל במסכת מו"ק (כ"ז ע"ב), א"ר הונא כיון שעבר אדם עבירה ושנה בו הותרה לו, הותרה לו ס"ד, אלא אימא נעשית לו כהיתר עכ"ד הגמרא. ולכאורה איך אפ"ל נעשה לו כהיתר, והלא יודע בודאי שהתוה"ק אסרתו , אלא שאין בו כח לעמוד נגד יצרו המתגבר עליו, אמנם הכוונה דרוב ישראל הכשרים אם נכשלו ח"ו בעבירה מצטערים עלי' אחרי עשייתה, אבל בעבר ושנה אינו מרגיש עוד באבדן נפשו, ונדמה לו האיסור כהיתר, ואעפ"י שיודע באזהרת האיסור אין לו הרגשה בו, והרגשת היתר ואיסור שווין אצלו, וז"ש כי ידעתי את מכאוביו, שהקב"ה למד זכות על ישראל, ונמשך אדלעיל שמעתי מפני נגשיו , שכל חטאם הי' ע"י גודל ההתגברות ובכפי' ואונס, ואע"פ שנכשלו בחטאים פעמים הרבה ע"י נגשיו , אבל לא נעשה אצלם הרגשת החטא כהיתר, אלא עדיין לבם כואב על שעברו רצונו יתברך ואין הפגם גדול כ"כ, ואין הכוונה כי ידעתי את מכאוביו של שעבוד מצרים, שכבר נאמר ראה ראיתי את עני עמי במצרים, אבל כ"ז הי' ללימוד זכות מאתו יתברך, אע"פ שלא עשו ישראל תשובה שלימה עדיין, אמנם צירף הקב"ה להם זכות זה שגם חטאם לא הי' בשלימות, וז"א כי ידעתי את מכאוביו שגרם להם הכשלת החטא, וע"כ שמעתי צעקתם.
translation: And in this way, I can say that I know their pain, as it is stated by our sages, of blessed memory, in Tractate Mo'ed Katan (27b), Rabbi Huna said: Once a person has sinned and repeated it, it is permitted to him. It is permitted to him, one might think; rather, say that it becomes to him as a permit. Thus concludes the Gemara. And at first glance, how can it be said that it becomes to him as a permit? Surely he knows that the Torah has forbidden it! Rather, he does not have the strength to stand against his overpowering inclination. However, the intention is that most of the righteous of Israel, if they unfortunately stumble into sin, they feel pain over it after committing it. But once they have sinned and repeated it, they no longer feel the loss of their soul, and the prohibition seems to them as a permit. And even though they know of the warning of the prohibition, they do not feel it, and the feeling of permit and prohibition is equal to them. Therefore, it is said, "For I know their pain," that the Holy One, blessed be He, judges favorably for Israel, and it is drawn from above, "I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," that all their sin was due to the great overpowering and coercion. And even though they stumbled into sins many times because of their taskmasters, the feeling of sin did not become to them as a permit; rather, their hearts still ache for having gone against His will, blessed be He, and the flaw is not so great. And the intention is not that I know their pain of the servitude in Egypt, for it has already been said, "I have surely seen the affliction of My people in Egypt," but all this was for the purpose of judging favorably from Him, blessed be He, even though the Israelites did not yet do complete repentance. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, combined for them this merit that their sin was not complete. And this is what is meant by "For I know their pain," which caused them the stumbling of sin, and therefore I have heard their cry.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of sin and its psychological impact on individuals, particularly within the Jewish community. It highlights that while a person may commit a sin and feel a diminished sense of guilt over time, this does not negate their inherent sorrow for having strayed from God's will. The text emphasizes that God understands the pain of His people, recognizing that their transgressions often stem from overwhelming temptation rather than a complete disregard for divine law. Ultimately, it conveys a message of compassion, suggesting that even in their failings, the Jewish people retain a connection to their spiritual essence and a longing for redemption.

passage_content: ובזה אפ"ל מ"ש הכתוב ויקם מלך חדש וכו' אשר לא ידע את יוסף ודרשו חז"ל דהו' דמי כמאן דלא ידע ליוסף כלל, (עיין קושיא ג') ויבואר עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בהל' תשובה (פ"ב ה"ד ) וז"ל מדרכי התשובה להיות השב צועק תמיד לפני השם וכו ', ומתרחק מן הדבר שחטא בו, ומשנה שמו כלומר אני אחר ואיני אותו האיש שעשה אותן המעשים, ומשנה מעשיו כולן לטובה וכו' עכ"ל, הכוונה בזה שע"י שמתרחק מן החטא ומשנה מעשיו לטובה, משתנה ג"כ הרגשותיו ופנימיות בחי' נפשו, ואינו אותו האיש שחטא אלא אחר הוא, וכמו"כ ח"ו להיפך אם יתרגל אדם בעבירה ועבר ושנה עלי' ישתנה בחי' נפשו ונעשית מגושם ומלוכלך כ"כ עד שנהפך לאיש אחר, ואפילו ידע באיסור נעשה ההרגש אצלו כאלו לא ידע, כמו"כ פרעה מתחלה לא רצה להרע לישראל, כמ"ש במד"ר שאמר למצריים שוטים אתם, עד עכשיו משלהם אנו אוכלים, אלולי יוסף לא היינו חיים, והאיך נזדווג להם וכו ', ואח"כ כשנתרגל ברשעתו נהפך לאיש אחר, וע"כ אמר הכתוב ויקם מלך חדש, שהיה פרעה אחר, והו ' דמי כמאן דלא ידע את יוסף, ר"ל בהתרגשות לבו דמי ליה כאלו לא ידע את יוסף כלל, וכמו"כ מ"ש לא ידעתי את ד', הגם שידע מתחילה והי' מתיירא מעונש מדה כנגד מדה, כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש הבה נתחכמה למושיען של ישראל כנ"ל, אבל אחר שנתרגל ברשעתו ועבר ושנה על אולתו , אפסו הרגשותיו ואמר לא ידעתי את ד', וכמ"ש בגמרא דעבר ושנה הותרה לו, ונשתנו הרגשותיו כאלו לא ידע מהאיסור כלל, וכמו"כ פרעה אחר שעבר ושנה באולתו למרות פי ד' ושלוחו, נעשה אצלו ההרגשה כאלו לא ידע את ד', וא"ש מה שהשוו במדרש עניניהם , וז"א היום לא ידע את יוסף למחר הוא עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד', דשניהם משורש א' ובחי' א' להם, דע"י שנתרגל ברשעו הו' דמי לי' כאלו לא ידע את יוסף, ומפני זה הטעם עצמו אמר לא ידעתי את ד', ומתורצת שפיר קושית המדרש שהקשו וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, בהמשל שהביאו לא' שרגם אוהבו של מלך, דע"י שפקר כ"כ עד שרגם אוהבו של מלך, מעתה נתברר שאין לו שום הרגשה ביראת המלך, ע"כ אמר המלך למחר יעשה בי כך, ולכך כתב עליו המקרא אשר לא ידע את יוסף, ולמחר הוא עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד' דבחי ' א' ושורש א' להם.
translation: And in this, one can explain what the verse states, "And a new king arose who did not know Joseph," etc. The sages have interpreted that he was like one who did not know Joseph at all (see question 3). It will be clarified according to what the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, writes in Hilchot Teshuvah (Chapter 2, Halacha 4), and I quote: "Among the ways of repentance is that the penitent cries out constantly before the Lord, etc., and distances himself from the thing in which he sinned, and changes his name, meaning, 'I am another, and I am not that man who did those deeds,' and changes all his actions for good, etc." End of quote. The intention here is that by distancing oneself from sin and changing one's actions for good, one's feelings and inner essence of the soul also change, and he is not the same person who sinned but rather another. Likewise, God forbid, the opposite is true; if a person becomes accustomed to sin and transgresses and repeats it, his essence of the soul changes and becomes so coarse and defiled that he turns into another person. Even if he knows the prohibition, the feeling becomes for him as if he did not know at all. Similarly, Pharaoh initially did not want to harm Israel, as it is said in the Midrash that he told the Egyptians, "You are foolish; until now we have been eating from their produce. Were it not for Joseph, we would not be alive. How can we intermarry with them?" etc. And afterwards, when he became accustomed to his wickedness, he turned into another person. Therefore, the verse states, "And a new king arose," meaning that Pharaoh was another person, and he was like one who did not know Joseph, meaning in the stirring of his heart, he was as if he did not know Joseph at all. Likewise, when he said, "I do not know the Lord," even though he initially knew and was afraid of punishment measure for measure, as our sages have said in the Midrash, "Come, let us outsmart the Redeemer of Israel," as mentioned above. But after he became accustomed to his wickedness and transgressed and repeated his evil, his feelings were extinguished, and he said, "I do not know the Lord." As it is stated in the Gemara, "If one transgresses and repeats, it is permitted to him," and his feelings changed as if he did not know the prohibition at all. Similarly, Pharaoh, after he transgressed and repeated his evil despite the word of the Lord and His messenger, his feeling became as if he did not know the Lord. And it is understood why they compared their matters in the Midrash, saying, "Today he does not know Joseph; tomorrow he will say, 'I do not know the Lord,'" for both stem from one root and one essence for them. That by becoming accustomed to his wickedness, he was like one who did not know Joseph, and for this very reason, he said, "I do not know the Lord." Thus, the question of the Midrash is well resolved: "Was he not familiar with Joseph?" with the parable they brought of one who killed the beloved of the king. For by becoming so accustomed to wickedness until he killed the beloved of the king, it is now clear that he has no feeling of fear of the king. Therefore, the king said, "Tomorrow he will do such to me," and thus the scripture wrote about him, "who did not know Joseph," and tomorrow he is destined to say, "I do not know the Lord," for they are of one essence and one root.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's character and consciousness, illustrating how repeated sinful actions can lead to a complete detachment from moral awareness, akin to not knowing Joseph or God. It emphasizes that through repentance, one can change their inner self and emotions, distancing themselves from past sins. Conversely, habitual wrongdoing can corrupt one's soul to the point where they feel as if they never knew the truth of their actions. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of the dynamic relationship between one's actions, emotional state, and spiritual identity.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יבואר הענין מה שאמר משה מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה וכי אוציא את בנ"י ממצרים, ומה שהשיב לו השי"ת בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ויובן עפימ"ש המפרשים דעיקר הנס דיציאת מצרים ויסודו, הי' להוציאם מטומאת מצרים שהיו משוקעים בה, ואין הכוונה רק על היציאה כפשוטו, ועפי"ז פירשתי מאמר הכתוב או הנסה אלקים לבוא לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי וגו' ככל אשר עשה לכם ד' וגו' הכוונה שהוציא השי"ת מקרבם ומפנימיות לבבם טומאת מצרים, שנשתרש בקרבם במשך ימי גלותם, וזה גוי מקרב גוי, וזה הי' עיקר היציאה, וז"ש משה רבינו להשי"ת שאתה שולח אותי להוציא את בנ"י ממצרים על בחי' זו להוציאם מטומאת מצרים. אבל דבר זה תלוי בבחירת הלב, וכבר הורגלו ונמשכו אחר טומאת מצרים ומדותיהם הרעים, ואיך אוציא את בנ"י ממצרים, ולא שקטרג ח"ו עליהם לשאול באיזה זכות, אבל רצה לידע איך ובאיזה אופן יעשה זאת להוציאם מטומאתם ולהוציא טומאת מצרים מקרבם.
translation: And according to this, the matter will be explained regarding what Moses said, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that I should bring out the children of Israel from Egypt," and what the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "When you bring out the people from Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." It will be understood according to what the commentators say, that the essence of the miracle of the Exodus from Egypt and its foundation was to take them out from the impurity of Egypt in which they were immersed. The intention is not only regarding the physical departure, but according to this, I explained the verse, "Or has God attempted to go and take for Himself a nation from the midst of a nation," etc., as all that the Lord has done for you, etc., the intention is that the Holy One, Blessed be He, took out from among them and from the innermost of their hearts the impurity of Egypt, which had become rooted within them during the days of their exile. This is "a nation from the midst of a nation," and this was the essence of the Exodus. And this is what our teacher Moses said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, that You are sending me to take the children of Israel out of Egypt in this aspect, to take them out from the impurity of Egypt. But this matter depends on the choice of the heart, and they had already become accustomed and drawn after the impurity of Egypt and their bad traits. And how can I take the children of Israel out of Egypt? It is not that he was accusing them, Heaven forbid, to ask by what merit, but he wanted to know how and in what manner he would do this, to take them out from their impurity and to remove the impurity of Egypt from within them.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' hesitation to confront Pharaoh and lead the Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing that the true essence of the Exodus was not merely physical liberation but the spiritual removal of the impurities and negative traits that had become ingrained in the Israelites during their time in Egypt. It highlights that this transformation requires a choice of the heart, as the people had become accustomed to the corrupt influences of their environment. Moses seeks to understand how he can facilitate this profound inner change, rather than questioning their worthiness. Ultimately, the focus is on the necessity of spiritual redemption alongside physical freedom.

passage_content: ואפשר שחשב בגודל ענותנותו שהוא אינו כדאי וראוי, ולא ישיג להביאם לידי פעולה זו, ע"כ אמר מי אנכי וגו' וכי אוציא את בנ"י ממצרים, ובאיזה אופן אוכל להשיג דבר זה שתלוי בבחירתם, וע"ז השיב לו הקב"ה כי אהיה עמך, וע"י סייעתא דשמיא תוכל להוציאם מכחות הטומאה ולהוציא הטומאה מקרבם, וכן יהיה לעתיד כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל דלפני ביאת המשיח יחזרו כל ישראל בתשובה עיי"ש, ועוד אמר לו השי"ת בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, דהיינו מתן תורה, וכל ישראל ישמעו מפי הגבורה אנכי ד' אלקיך אשר הוצאתיך מארץ מצרים, ובכח קדושת דיבורו ית ' אשר ישמעו מאמר אשר הוצאתיך מאמ"צ , יצאו לגמרי מטומאת מצרים, וטומאת מצרים יצא מקרבם, דדיבורו של הקב"ה מכרחת הבחירה כידוע.
translation: And it is possible that he thought, due to the greatness of his humility, that he is not worthy or deserving, and that he would not be able to bring them to this action. Therefore, he said, "Who am I..." and "How will I bring the children of Israel out of Egypt?" And in what manner can I achieve this, which depends on their choice? To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "I will be with you," and through heavenly assistance, you will be able to take them out from the forces of impurity and remove the impurity from among them. And so it will be in the future, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, states that before the coming of the Messiah, all of Israel will return in repentance, as mentioned there. Furthermore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you will serve God on this mountain," meaning the giving of the Torah. And all of Israel will hear from the mouth of the Almighty, "I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt," and by the power of the holiness of His speech, which they will hear in the statement "who brought you out of Egypt," they will completely emerge from the impurity of Egypt, and the impurity of Egypt will be removed from among them, for the speech of the Holy One, Blessed be He, compels choice, as is known.
summary: The passage discusses the humility of Moses, who doubts his ability to lead the Israelites out of Egypt, feeling unworthy of such a task. God reassures him with the promise of divine assistance, emphasizing that through heavenly support, Moses can help the Israelites overcome their spiritual impurities. The text also highlights the future redemption, where all of Israel will return to repentance before the coming of the Messiah, and the significance of the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, which will further elevate the people and cleanse them from the impurities of Egypt through the power of God's word.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לבאר מה ששאל משה רבינו ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ומה שהקשה הרמב"ם ז"ל בספר המורה כי איך יהיה זה אות על אמיתת נבואתו, (עיין לעיל קושיא י"ב) ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמרא פסחים (נ' ע"א) והיה ד' למלך על כל הארץ ביום ההוא יהיה ד' אחד ושמו אחד, אטו האידנא לאו שמו אחד, א"ר נחמן בר יצחק לא כעוה"ז העוה"ב, בעוה"ז נכתב ביו"ד ה"א ונקרא בא' דל"ת, אבל לעוה"ב נכתב ביו"ד ה"א ונקרא ביו"ד ה"א עכ"ד הגמרא, מבואר דכשיתקיים והיה ד' למלך על כל הארץ דהיינו לפני ביאת המשיח. אז יהיה ד' אחד ושמו אחד כמ"ש הפייטן שלעתיד השם יקרא ככתיבתו. והנה הי' שליחותו ית ' למשרע"ה לאמר לבנ"י וגאלתי אתכם בזרוע נטוי' ובשפטים גדולים וידעתם כי אני ד' וגו', ונאמר להלן וידעו מצרים כי אני ד' בנטותי את ידי על מצרים וגו' ובאמת נתרבה כבוד שמים ונתגדל ונתקדש שמו יתברך לעיני כל האומות ע"י הנס של יציאת מצרים, והיו ישראל מצפים שיקויים מיד ההבטחה והיה ד' למלך על כל הארץ ויהיה ד' אחד ושמו אחד, ואלמלי זכו ישראל לעשות תשובה שלימה הי' גאולה נצחית מיד, כמ"ש במכילתא הנ"ל, והי' נתקיים בחי' זו שהשם יקרא ככתיבתו. וז"ש משה רבינו הנה אנכי בא אל בנ"י ואמרתי להם אלקי אבותיכם שלחני אליכם ואמרו לו מה שמו, ר"ל שישאלו ישראל על בשורת הגאולה באיזה בחי' יהיה גאולתינו , האם נזכה להתפלל לפניו יתברך בבחי ' השם יקרא ככתיבתו כבחי' העתיד, או כבחי' הגלות לא כשאני נכתב אני נקרא, וזה פירוש השאלה מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ואין הכוונה על בקשת אות ומתורץ קושית הרמב"ם ז"ל.
translation: And now we will explain what Moshe Rabbeinu asked and said to them, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" And what the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, questioned in the Guide for the Perplexed, how this could be a sign of the truth of his prophecy (see above question 12). It will be clarified by first discussing the words of the Gemara in Pesachim (60a), "And it will be that Hashem will be King over all the earth; on that day Hashem will be one and His name one." Is it not that now His name is not one? Rabbi Nachman bar Yitzchak said, "Not like this world is the World to Come. In this world, it is written with a Yud and a Hei and is called with an Aleph and a Dalet, but in the World to Come, it is written with a Yud and a Hei and is called with a Yud and a Hei." Thus said the Gemara. It is clear that when it will be fulfilled, "And it will be that Hashem will be King over all the earth," meaning before the coming of the Messiah, then Hashem will be one and His name one, as the poet of the future states, "The name will be called as it is written." And behold, His mission to Moshe Rabbeinu was to say to the Children of Israel, "And I have redeemed you with an outstretched arm and with great judgments, and you shall know that I am Hashem," etc. And it is said further, "And Egypt will know that I am Hashem when I stretch out My hand over Egypt," etc. And indeed, the glory of Heaven was increased, and His name, blessed be He, was magnified and sanctified in the eyes of all the nations through the miracle of the Exodus from Egypt. And the Israelites were hoping that the promise would be fulfilled, "And it will be that Hashem will be King over all the earth, and Hashem will be one and His name one." And had Israel merited to do complete repentance, the redemption would have been eternal immediately, as stated in the aforementioned Mekilta, and it would have been fulfilled in this aspect that the name would be called as it is written. This is what Moshe Rabbeinu said, "Behold, I come to the Children of Israel, and I said to them, 'The God of your forefathers has sent me to you,' and they will say to me, 'What is His name?'" Meaning that the Israelites would ask about the good tidings of redemption, in what aspect our redemption will be, whether we will merit to pray before Him, blessed be He, in the aspect of "the name will be called as it is written," like in the future, or in the aspect of exile, not as I am written, I am called. And this is the interpretation of the question, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" And it is not intended as a request for a sign, and the question of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, is resolved.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' inquiry about God's name and the implications of this question regarding the nature of redemption. It highlights the distinction between the current state of divine revelation and the future promise of a unified recognition of God as "one" in the Messianic era. The text emphasizes that the Israelites were seeking assurance of a complete and eternal redemption, where God's name would be fully realized as it is written, contrasting the present experience of divine concealment. Ultimately, it suggests that had the Israelites repented fully, they could have achieved this ultimate redemption immediately.

passage_content: אמנם באמת לא הי' עדיין הזמן לגלות בחי' השם ככתיבתו, כמו שדרשו חז"ל לעלם כתיב העלימהו, ע"כ השיב השי"ת למשה אקי' אשר אקי' ובזה מסר לו סוד שם המפורש כמ"ש בפדר"א הנ"ל. וכדרשת ר' יצחק במדרש אני שהייתי ואני הוא עכשיו ואני הוא לעתיד לבוא, וזהו סוד שם הוי' וכמ"ש ז"ל במסכת ברכות אהיה עמהם בצרה זו ואהיה עמהם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , וכפי הבחי ' זו מסר השי"ת למשה רבינו ידיעת השם הנכבד, ובזה הי' תשובה גם לבנ"י אבל עפ"י בחינה אחרת, כפי שנתפרש במדרש אגדה שהביא הרמב"ן ז"ל, אקי' אשר אקי' כשם שאתה הוו' כך אני הוו' עמך, וכמ"ש במדרש רבה שא"ל הקב"ה למשה שמי אתה מבקש לידע לפי מעשי אני נקרא, כשאני מרחם על הבריות אני נקרא ד' וכו ', ומשתנה השם כפי הויתם וכפי בחינתם, וזהו התשובה אל בנ"י שא"א לגלות להם בחי' השם דלעתיד , כי תלוי בערך בחינתם, אבל לעתיד והיה ד' למלך על כל הארץ, ויהיה הכל על בחי' גבוה ובחי' הרחמים אז יתגלה השם ככתיבתו, וא"ש מ"ש במדרש שאמר הקב"ה לך אני מודיע להם איני מודיע, וכמ"ש ברש"י במוסגר דלמשה לבדו הגיד ולא שיגיד לישראל ול"ק קושית המפרשים דא"כ אין התשובה מעין השאלה, דמשה רבינו שאל מה אומר אליהם והשי"ת השיבו אקי' אשר אקי' והוא הודעה למשה לבדו. ולדרכינו היתה תשובה זו על ב' בחינות, שבאמרו יתברך אקי' אקי' גילה בזה סוד שם המפורש כמ"ש בפדר"א הנ"ל, אבל בחי' זו הי' למשה לבדו ולא לישראל, ולישראל הי' כוונת התשובה דמשתנה השם לפי הבחי ' ולפי המעשים וא"א לגלות להם עדיין.
translation: Indeed, it was not yet the time to reveal the aspect of the Name as it is written, as our Sages have interpreted regarding the word "hidden" (עלם), therefore the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to Moses, "I will be that I will be," and in this He imparted to him the secret of the Ineffable Name, as mentioned in the aforementioned Pederah. And as Rabbi Isaac interpreted in the Midrash, "I was, I am, and I will be," this is the secret of the Name Havayah. And as our Sages said in Tractate Berakhot, "I will be with them in this distress and I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms," and according to this aspect, the Holy One, Blessed be He, imparted to our teacher Moses the knowledge of the esteemed Name. In this, there was also a response to the Children of Israel, but according to a different aspect, as explained in the Aggadic Midrash brought by Ramban, "I will be that I will be," just as you are Havayah, so I am Havayah with you. And as it is said in Midrash Rabbah, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "What name do you seek to know? According to My actions, I am called; when I have mercy on the creatures, I am called 'the Lord,' etc.," and the Name changes according to their existence and according to their aspect. This is the response to the Children of Israel that it is impossible to reveal to them the aspect of the Name that is for the future, for it depends on the value of their aspect. But in the future, "the Lord will be King over all the earth," and everything will be in a higher aspect and in the aspect of mercy; then the Name will be revealed as it is written. And it is understood what is said in the Midrash that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "To you I inform, but I do not inform them," and as Rashi wrote in the parentheses, "He revealed it only to Moses and did not reveal it to Israel." And the question of the commentators is not difficult, for then the response is not in the nature of the question, as our teacher Moses asked, "What shall I say to them?" and the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him, "I will be that I will be," and this was a revelation to Moses alone. And according to our path, this response was regarding two aspects, for in His saying "I will be, I will be," He revealed in this the secret of the Ineffable Name, as mentioned in the aforementioned Pederah, but this aspect was for Moses alone and not for Israel. And for Israel, the intention of the response was that the Name changes according to the aspect and according to the actions, and it is impossible to reveal to them yet.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of God's name and its revelation, emphasizing that the time was not yet right for the full disclosure of God's essence as it relates to the Jewish people. It highlights the idea that God's name changes according to the actions and spiritual states of individuals, and that Moses received a unique understanding of the divine name that was not meant for the Israelites at that time. The text also suggests that in the future, when God's mercy prevails, the true nature of God's name will be fully revealed to all. Ultimately, it reflects on the dynamic relationship between divine revelation and human spiritual readiness.

passage_content: והנה משרע"ה הבין בדברי השי"ת כי בחי' זו אהי ' עמהם בצרה זו ואהי ' עמהם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות נאמרה לו שיאמרה לישראל, ע"כ אמר די' לצרה בשעתה, והשיב לו השי"ת כה תאמר "לבני ישראל" אקי' שלחני אליכם, שתאמר להם כפי הפירוש האחר כמ"ש במדרש, דפירוש אקי' שנשתנה בחי' השם כפי בחינתם וכפי מעשיהם, וזהו תשובה על שאלתם, שא"א למלאות מבוקשתם שידעו השם ככתיבתו עד לעתיד. נמצא שאין כאן חזרה בדברי השי"ת ממ"ש לו בתחלה אקי' אשר אקי', אבל במ"ש לו השי"ת שנית שם אקי' לבד, נתפרש אליו מאמר הראשון כפי הבחינה שיאמרה לישראל, וה"ה השלמה למאמר הראשון ולא חזרה וא"ש.
translation: And behold, Moshe understood from the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, that in this aspect "I will be with them in this trouble" and "I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms" was said to him to tell to Israel. Therefore, He said, "Enough for the trouble at its time," and the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him, "So shall you say to the Children of Israel, 'I am' has sent me to you," to tell them according to the other interpretation as stated in the Midrash, that the interpretation of "I am" has changed according to their aspect and according to their deeds. And this is the answer to their question, that it is impossible to fulfill their request to know the name as it is written until the future. Thus, there is no contradiction in the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, from what was said to him initially "I am that I am," but in what the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him a second time "I am" alone, it was clarified to him the first statement according to the aspect that it should be said to Israel, and this is the completion of the first statement and not a contradiction, and it is understood.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the divine communication between God and Moses, emphasizing that God's name "Ehyeh" (I will be) reflects a dynamic relationship with the Israelites, particularly in times of suffering and oppression. The text highlights that God's response to Moses is tailored to the spiritual state and actions of the people, indicating that the divine presence adapts to their circumstances. This illustrates a profound theological insight into the nature of God’s engagement with humanity, suggesting that divine revelation is contingent upon human behavior and understanding. Ultimately, the passage affirms that God's messages are consistent and progressive, revealing deeper meanings as the situation evolves.

passage_content: ויאמר עוד אלקים אל משה כה תאמר אל בנ"י ד' אלקי אבותיכם אלקי אברהם אלקי יצחק ואלקי יעקב וגו', גם זה השלמה למאמר הראשון שעד שיתגלה להם השם בבחי ' דלעתיד , יזכירו בתפלתם אלקי אברהם יצחק ויעקב כמ"ש במכילתא הנ"ל, ומאמר זה שמי לעלם נאמרה למשה רבינו כפי בחינתו שמסר לו השי"ת סוד שם המפורש ע"כ א"ל השי"ת לעלם העלימהו כמ"ש ז"ל, נמצא שאין בזה שינוי ממ"ש לו בתחלה , אלא השלמה על מאמרו יתברך הקודם, ובזה נתבארו כל הקושיות בענין הנ"ל.
translation: And God said further to Moses, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: 'The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob,' etc. This is also a completion of the first statement, that until His name is revealed to them in the aspect of 'the future,' they will mention in their prayers the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, as stated in the aforementioned Mekilta. And this statement, 'My name is to be eternal,' was said to our teacher Moses according to his level, as the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed to him the secret of the explicit name. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, told him that it would be concealed forever, as our sages of blessed memory have said. Thus, there is no change from what was said to him initially, but rather a completion of His blessed previous statement, and through this, all the questions regarding the aforementioned matter are clarified.
summary: The passage discusses God's instruction to Moses to refer to Him as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, emphasizing that this is a preparatory step for the future revelation of God's name. It highlights the importance of invoking the patriarchs in prayer until the ultimate divine name is revealed. The text suggests that this instruction is not a change but rather a completion of God's earlier message to Moses, clarifying previous questions regarding the nature of God's name and presence. This reflects a deep theological understanding of the relationship between God and the Jewish people, rooted in their ancestral heritage.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר עפימ"ש ז"ל בגמ' סנהדרין (י"א ע"א) יצתה בת קול מן השמים, יש כאן א' שראוי שתשרה עליו שכינה כמשה רבינו עליו השלו' אלא שאין דורו זכאי לכך ע"כ. מבואר דלפעמים נמנע השפעת נבואה ורוה"ק אפילו ממי שהוכן אל הנבואה, לפי שאין הדור ראוי לזה וכן פרש"י (בירמי' מ"ה) שאמר ברוך בן נרי' יגעתי באנחתי ומנוחה לא מצאתי, פי' לא שרתה עלי שכינה להנבא , מלשון ותנח עליהם הרוח. א"ל הקב"ה אם אין צאן רועה למה, איני נגלה על הנביאים אלא בזכותם של ישראל כך שנוי במכילתין עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, ולפעמים כשהדור ראוי אבל המנהיג לא הוכן למדריגת הנבואה, נותנין לו מן השמים השפעה שכלית והשגת נבואה בזכותא דרבים, כמשל הבאר כ"ז שדולין הימנה יתוספו מימיו מן המקור, עכ"פ השפעת המנהיג כפי זכות הדור בין לטוב ובין להפכו.
translation: And even if it is said in another way, as our sages of blessed memory stated in the Gemara Sanhedrin (11a), a heavenly voice went out from the heavens, saying, "There is one here who is worthy of the Divine Presence to rest upon him, like our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, but his generation is not worthy of it." It is clear that sometimes the influence of prophecy and the Holy Spirit is withheld even from one who is prepared for prophecy, because the generation is not worthy of it. Thus, Rashi explains (in Jeremiah 45) that Baruch ben Neriah said, "I have labored in my sighing, and I have found no rest," meaning that the Divine Presence did not rest upon me to prophesy, as it is said, "And the spirit rested upon them." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "If there are no sheep for the shepherd, why should I reveal Myself to the prophets except through the merit of Israel?" This is stated in the Mechilta, thus said Rashi of blessed memory. And sometimes, when the generation is worthy but the leader is not prepared for the level of prophecy, they are given from heaven intellectual influence and the attainment of prophecy through the merit of the masses, like the parable of the well: as long as they draw from it, they will receive additional water from the source. In any case, the influence of the leader is according to the merit of the generation, whether for good or the opposite.
summary: The passage discusses the conditions under which divine inspiration and prophecy can manifest, emphasizing that the worthiness of the generation plays a crucial role. It cites a Talmudic source indicating that even a prepared individual may be denied prophetic influence if the generation is unworthy. Additionally, it suggests that when the generation is deserving but the leader is not adequately prepared, divine wisdom can still be granted to the leader due to the merit of the community. This reflects the interconnectedness of the spiritual state of the people and their leaders in receiving divine guidance.
