passage_content: והנה איתא בגמרא יומא (ס"ט ע"ב) א"ר יהושע בן לוי למה נקרא שמן אנשי כנה"ג שהחזירו עטרה ליושנה, אתא משה ואמר הא"ל הגדול הגבור והנורא. אתא ירמי' ואמר נכרים מקרקרין בהיכלו איה נוראותיו לא אמר נורא. אתא דניאל אמר נכרים משתעבדים בבניו אי' גבורותיו לא אמר גבור אתו אינהו ואמרו אדרבה זו היא גבורותיו שכובש את רצונו ונותן ארך אפים לרשעים, ואלו הן נוראותיו , שאלמלא מוראו של הקב"ה האיך אומה אחת יכולה להתקיים בין האומות עכ"ד הגמרא. ופירשו בספה"ק עד מתי עוזך בשבי, ר"ל עד מתי יהי' גבורותיו של הקב"ה ניכר ע"י שבי הגלות, ותפארתך ביד צר, ר"ל ששבחך מה שישראל ביד צר ויש להם עמידה וקיום בגלות, ובקשתינו שיהיה בחי' שבחיו יתברך נצחיים, כי מדת הגבור והנורא שאנו מזכירין בגלות אינה כפי בחינתה הנצחי, דלעתיד לא יהיה על בחי' זו, וכשיגאלנו השי"ת גאולת עולם יהיו גבורותיו ונוראותיו ניכרים ונראים כפי עצם בחינתם.
translation:
And behold, it is stated in the Gemara Yoma (69b) that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Why is the name of the men of the Great Assembly called so? Because they returned the crown to its former glory. Moses came and said: "He is the great, mighty, and awesome God." Jeremiah came and said: "The nations are trampling in His sanctuary; where are His awesomeness?" He did not say "awesome." Daniel came and said: "The nations are enslaving His children; where are His might?" He did not say "mighty." They came and said: "On the contrary, this is His might, that He conquers His will and grants long-suffering to the wicked, and these are His awesomeness, for were it not for the fear of the Holy One, blessed be He, how could one nation exist among the nations?" Thus far the Gemara. 

And it is explained in the holy books: "Until when will Your strength be in captivity?" meaning, until when will the might of the Holy One, blessed be He, be recognized through the captivity of exile? "And Your glory in the hand of the oppressor," meaning, that Your praise is that Israel is in the hand of the oppressor and they have endurance and existence in exile. And our request is that His praise, blessed be He, should be eternal, for the attribute of "mighty" and "awesome" that we mention in exile is not according to its eternal aspect, for in the future there will be no aspect of this. And when the Holy One, blessed be He, redeems us with an eternal redemption, His might and awesomeness will be recognized and seen according to their true essence.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of God's attributes of strength and awe as reflected in the Jewish experience of exile. It highlights that while God's might is evident in the endurance of the Jewish people during their suffering, this manifestation is not the ultimate expression of His power. The text anticipates a future redemption where God's true greatness will be revealed, transcending the current limitations of His attributes as experienced in exile. Ultimately, it emphasizes the hope for a time when God's might and awe will be fully recognized in a permanent and profound way.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ואלה שמות בנ"י וכו ', הוסיף שבח על השבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה וכו ', ויובן עפימ"ש במדרש ואלה שמות בנ"י ע"ש גאולת ישראל נזכרו כאן ודרשו רז"ל שמות כאו"א ע"ש גאולתם עיי"ש, ויוסף נדרש על בחי' גאולה העתידה, ע"ש שעתיד הקב"ה להוסיף ולגאול את ישראל ממלכות הרשעה. דכתיב והיה ביום ההוא יוסיף ד' שנית ידו וגו' ופירשתי דאע"ג דלעיל בפ ' ויצא מפורש בפסוקים טעמים אחרים על קריאת שמותם, אבל עכשיו שהתחילה השעבוד לאחר מיתת השבטים, והגלות צורך הגאולה, מעתה התחילה השתלשלות גאולתם, וע"כ ניתוסף רמז חדש בשמותיהם כפי בחי' הגאולה, וזהו פי' המדרש ואלה שמות בנ"י וכו' ואלה מוסיף שבח על הראשונים שנזכרו למעלה, דבחינה הרמוז בשמותם כאן מוסיף על הראשונים, וז"ש במדרש ואלה שמות בנ"י זש"ה כי כשמך כן תהלתך , שכפי בחי' השם, כן בחינת שבחיו ותואריו יתברך, שלעתיד יהיה השם יקרא ככתיבתו על בחינתו הנצחית, ואז יהיו גם שבחיו יתברך נצחיים, הגדול הגבור והנורא כפי עצם בחינתם, וע"כ בא הרמז כאן באלה שמות בנ"י , שנתחדש ונתוסף בשמותיהם בחינה חדשה ע"ש הגאולה כנ"ל. ויה"ר שנזכה לגאולה שלימה בקרוב, בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. It adds praise for the seventy souls mentioned above, etc. It will be understood according to what is stated in the Midrash, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," in the name of the redemption of Israel, which is mentioned here, and our Sages of blessed memory expounded that each name is in the name of their redemption, as explained there. And Joseph is expounded upon in the aspect of the future redemption, in the name of the time when the Holy One, blessed be He, will add and redeem Israel from the kingdoms of wickedness. As it is written, "And it shall be on that day that the Lord will again extend His hand," etc. I have explained that although previously in Parashat Vayelech there are explicit reasons in the verses for the naming of them, now that the servitude has begun after the death of the tribes, and the exile is a necessity for the redemption, from now on the unfolding of their redemption has begun. Therefore, a new hint has been added in their names according to the aspect of redemption. This is the explanation of the Midrash, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. And these add praise to the first ones mentioned above, for the aspect hinted at in their names here adds to the first ones. And this is what is said in the Midrash, "And these are the names of the children of Israel," as it is written, "For as Your name, so is Your praise," that according to the aspect of the name, so is the aspect of His praise and His attributes, blessed be He, that in the future the name will be called as it is written, according to His eternal aspect, and then His praises, blessed be He, will also be eternal, the great, the mighty, and the awesome, according to their essential aspect. Therefore, the hint comes here in "And these are the names of the children of Israel," that a new aspect has been renewed and added in their names in the name of the redemption, as mentioned above. May it be His will that we merit a complete redemption soon, with the elevation of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon, amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the names of the Israelites as a reflection of their future redemption, emphasizing that each name corresponds to an aspect of their individual and collective salvation. It highlights that the names mentioned after the death of the tribes signify a new phase in the unfolding of their redemption, as the oppression they faced was a precursor to their eventual liberation. The text connects the concept of names to the divine attributes, suggesting that as the names reflect the essence of the individuals, so too will God's praises be eternal and aligned with His true nature in the future. Ultimately, it expresses a hope for a complete redemption and the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפשר לתרץ הדקדוקים הנ"ל, בהעיר עוד בדברי רבותינו ז"ל במד"ר (פר' א' ס"ט) הובא ברש"י ז"ל עה"פ הבה נתחכמה לו וגו', אמר בואו ונתחכמה לאלקיהם של אלו נדונם בחרב כבר כתיב ( ישעי ' ס"ו) ובחרבו את כל בשר, לא נדון אותם אלא במים, שכך נשבע הקדוש ברוך הוא שאין מביא מבול לעולם וכו ', וכן מבואר להלן במדרש רבה (ס' י"ח) העמיקו עצה שלא יפרע הקב"ה מהם במים, לפי שהיו יודעין שאין הקב"ה משלם אלא מדה כנגד מדה, והיו בטוחים שלא יביא מבול לעולם, לכך גזרו להטביעם במים עכ"ל המדרש, מבואר מזה דכל גזרתם לא הי' אלא במים, לפי שסמכו על סברא זו דאין הקב"ה נפרע אלא מדה כנגד מדה וטעם גזרתם הי' פן ירבה כמבואר בפסוק, והקשו היפ"ת והמפורשים דהרי מבואר בפרשה שצוה פרעה למילדות להמית את הזכרים, ואיך לא נתיירא שיענשו ע"ז מדה כנגד מדה בחרב או בחנק.
translation: In another way, one can explain the aforementioned nuances, noting further in the words of our Rabbis, of blessed memory, in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat 1, Section 69), as brought by Rashi, of blessed memory, on the verse "Come, let us outsmart them," etc. He said, "Come, let us outsmart the God of these people; we will judge them by the sword, for it is already written (Isaiah 66:16), 'And by His sword, He will judge all flesh.' We will not judge them except by water, for thus the Holy One, blessed be He, swore that He would not bring a flood upon the world, etc." And it is also explained further in Midrash Rabbah (Section 18) that they deepened their counsel so that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not take retribution against them with water, since they knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, only pays back measure for measure, and they were confident that He would not bring a flood upon the world. Therefore, they decreed to drown them in water. From this, it is clear that their entire decree was only concerning water, as they relied on this reasoning that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not take retribution except measure for measure, and the reason for their decree was lest it increase, as explained in the verse. And the commentators and the interpreters questioned, "But it is clear in the section that Pharaoh commanded the midwives to kill the males, and how did they not fear that they would be punished for this measure for measure with the sword or strangulation?"
summary: The passage discusses the reasoning behind Pharaoh's decree to drown the Hebrew infants, based on the belief that God enacts punishment measure for measure. The Midrash highlights that the Egyptians were confident that God would not bring a flood again, as He had sworn not to do so, leading them to believe they could escape divine retribution. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine justice and the human tendency to misinterpret God's promises, ultimately revealing the limitations of their understanding of God's ways.

passage_content: ב) קשה ממשפרש"י להלן ומבואר במד"ר (סי' כ"ד) ובגמ' סוטה (דף י"ב) יום שנולד משה אמרו לפרעה אצטגניניו היום נולד מושיען של ישראל וכו ', וסופו ללקות במים, לפיכך גזר אותו היום אף על המצריים וכו ', כיון שהושלך משה למים אמרו כבר מושלך מושיען במים, מיד בטלו הגזירה, והיינו דקאמר משה שש מאות אלף רגלי העם אשר אנכי בקרבו (במדבר י"א), בשבילי נצלתם כולכם עכ"ד המדרש והגמ ', מבואר דגזירת המים בשביל חזיון אצטגנונים הי', ולא בשביל חשבון מדה כנגד מדה, והמהרש"א בחידושי אגדות על מסכת סוטה כתב לתרץ דתחלה גזר להשליכם למים בשביל סברת מדה כנגד מדה ומטעם פן ירבה, ואחר כך גזר עוד אף על המצרים בשביל שראו האצטגנינים וכו' וב' גזירות היו, אמנם הקשה הוא ז"ל, למה לא הספיק לחז"ל גם בגזירה ב' הטעם משום דכבר נשבע הקב"ה שלא יביא מבול וכו ', עד שהוצרכו לומר שאצטגניניו ראו וכו ', ותירץ משום דחזינן דאחר שהושלך משה למים בטלה הגזירה, אלמא דמשום חזיון האצטגנינים הי' הגזירה עכ"ד, אולם הא גופא קשיא דאף אם נתבטל חזיון האצטגנינות אחר שהושלך משה למים, אבל איך נתבטל גזירתם הראשונה מטעם פן ירבה, וסברת מדה כנגד מדה שנשבע הקב"ה שלא יביא מבול עדיין במקומה עומדת, ובגמ' מבואר שנתבטלה הגזירה לגמרי: וראוי להבין מה היתה סברתם של המצריים בזה.
translation: B) It is difficult, as explained by Rashi below and clarified in the Midrash (section 24) and in the Gemara Sotah (12a), that on the day Moses was born, Pharaoh's astrologers said, "Today, the savior of Israel is born," etc., and he would ultimately suffer in the waters. Therefore, he decreed that day also upon the Egyptians, etc. Once Moses was cast into the water, they said, "Already, our savior is cast into the water," and immediately the decree was nullified. This is what Moses meant when he said, "Six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people whom I am in their midst" (Numbers 11), "For my sake, you all were saved." Thus far from the Midrash and the Gemara, it is clear that the decree of the waters was due to the vision of the astrologers, and not because of a measure for a measure calculation. However, the Maharsha in his Chiddushei Aggadot on the tractate Sotah wrote to explain that initially, he decreed to cast them into the water because of the measure for measure reasoning and out of fear that they would multiply, and afterward, he decreed also upon the Egyptians because the astrologers saw, etc., and there were two decrees. However, he questioned why the sages did not suffice with the second decree's reason, since the Holy One, blessed be He, had already sworn not to bring a flood, etc., until they had to say that his astrologers saw, etc. He answered that we see that after Moses was cast into the water, the decree was nullified, which implies that the decree was indeed due to the vision of the astrologers. However, this itself is difficult, for even if the vision of the astrologers was nullified after Moses was cast into the water, how was the first decree nullified due to the fear of multiplication, and the reasoning of measure for measure, which the Holy One, blessed be He, swore not to bring a flood, still stands in its place? And in the Gemara, it is clarified that the decree was completely nullified: It is worth understanding what the Egyptians' reasoning was in this matter.
summary: The passage discusses the dual decrees against the Israelites at the time of Moses' birth, one based on astrological predictions and the other on the principle of measure for measure. It highlights that the decree was initially intended due to fears of population growth, but once Moses was cast into the water, the astrological prediction was nullified, leading to the cancellation of the decree. The text emphasizes the interplay between divine providence and human actions, illustrating that God's promises, such as the oath not to bring a flood, ultimately govern the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ג) הקשה המהרש"א ז"ל על דברי רש"י ז"ל שפי' עה"פ אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, שגזירת המילדות הי' בשביל שאמרו לו אצטגניניו שעתיד להוולד בן המושיע אותם, ומסוגיא דגמ ' משמע דגזירה הראשונה של מילדות לא הי' אלא משום פן ירבה וגו' ונלחם בנו, וכן משמע מהפסוקים וגם רש"י עצמו פי' בתחלה סיבת הגזירה כן וצ"ב .
translation: 3) The Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, questioned the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, who explained the verse "If he is a son, then you shall kill him," that the decree of the midwives was because his astrologers told him that a son who would save them was destined to be born. From the Gemara's discussion, it seems that the initial decree of the midwives was only due to the concern that he might increase and fight against us, and this is also implied by the verses, and even Rashi himself initially explained the reason for the decree this way, and it is puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses a difficulty raised by the Maharsha regarding Rashi's interpretation of the verse "If he is a son, you shall kill him," suggesting that the decree against the midwives was based on the astrologers' prediction of a future savior. It contrasts this with the Talmudic source, which implies that the initial decree was motivated by fear of the Israelites multiplying and potentially waging war against the Egyptians. The text highlights the complexity of divine providence and the interplay between human actions and prophetic insights in the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ד) ויצו פרעה לכל עמו, אריב"ח אף על עמו גזר, ולמה עשה כן, שהיו אסטרולוגין אומרים לו גואל ישראל נתעברה ממנו אמו , ואין אנו יודעין אם ישראל אם מצרי הוא, באותה שעה כנס פרעה כל המצריים וא"ל השאילו לי בניכם ט' חדשים שאשליכם ליאור, הה"ד כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו, ולא רצו המצריים לקבל ממנו, שאמרו בן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם וכו ', עכ"ד המדרש, אמנם רש"י בסוטה (דף י"ב) הביא מדרש ר' תנחומא יום שנולד משה עמד פרעה וקבץ כל עמו וביקש מהם ליתן לו בנים הנולדים בו ביום וגזר אף על עמו, מבואר דגזירת כל הבן הילוד לא הי' אלא על בו ביום בלבד, ושלא כדברי המדרש הנ"ל דעל ט' חדשים גזר, והקשה היפ"ת הלא משה נצפן ג' חדשים. ואם נימא שאחר שעבר היום בטלה הגזירה למה הוצרכו להשליכו ליאור, ותירץ דצריכין אנו לפרש דברי התנחומא דתחלה גזר על אותו היום לבד, וכיון שעבר היום ועדיין ראו האצטגנינים שלא לקה, האריך הגזירה עד היום שהושלך ליאור, עוד קשה דכאן מבואר במדרש דלא רצו המצריים לקבל ממנו ליתן גם ילדיהם ליאור, מפני שאמרו בן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם, אמנם משמע מהפסוקים שגם המצריים הושלכו ליאור, והביא בעיון יעקב ראי' לזה מדאמרה בתי' בת פרעה מילדי העבריים זה, מכלל דגם המצריים הושלכו ליאור.
translation: And Pharaoh commanded all his people, "Even upon his own people he decreed," and why did he do so? Because the astrologers were telling him that the Redeemer of Israel was conceived by his mother, and we do not know if he is an Israelite or an Egyptian. At that time, Pharaoh gathered all the Egyptians and said to them, "Lend me your sons for nine months, and I will cast them into the Nile," as it is said, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the Nile." And the Egyptians did not want to comply with him, for they said, "An Egyptian son will never redeem them," etc. Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. However, Rashi in Sotah (12a) brought a Midrash from Rabbi Tanchuma that on the day Moses was born, Pharaoh stood and gathered all his people and asked them to give him the sons born that day, and he decreed even upon his own people. It is clear that the decree of "Every son that is born" was only on that day alone, contrary to the aforementioned Midrash that he decreed for nine months. And it is difficult to understand, isn't it true that Moses was hidden for three months? And if we say that after the day passed the decree was nullified, why was there a need to cast him into the Nile? And it was answered that we need to explain the words of Tanchuma that initially he decreed only for that day, and since the day passed and the astrologers still saw that he was not afflicted, he extended the decree until the day he was cast into the Nile. Furthermore, it is difficult because here it is explained in the Midrash that the Egyptians did not want to give him their children to cast into the Nile, because they said, "An Egyptian son will never redeem them." However, it seems from the verses that even the Egyptians were cast into the Nile, and the Ayin Yaakov brought a proof to this from what the daughter of Pharaoh said, "This is one of the Hebrew children," implying that also the Egyptians were cast into the Nile.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's decree to throw all newborn Hebrew boys into the Nile, driven by astrological predictions about the future savior of Israel. It highlights the tension between Pharaoh's fear and the Egyptians' reluctance to comply, as they believed that a child of an Egyptian would never redeem them. The text also reflects on the nature of divine providence, suggesting that despite the decree, God's plan for Moses' survival was already in motion, emphasizing the interplay between human actions and divine will in the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ה) צ"ב מה שאמר פרעה למצריים השאילו לי בניכם על ע' חדשים שאשליכם ליאור, איך יתכן שאלה בזה, הלא שאלה הדרא בעינא , ואם ישליכם ליאור ויטבעו איך יחזירם להם, ובידי משה תירץ לפי שהיאור הי' ע"ז של פרעה, וא"ל שישאלו בניהם ליאור והוא יחזירם להם, והמצריים לא הסכימו לזה, לפי שהם עבדו לטלה ופרעה לבדו עבד ליאור לכך לא האמינו בו עכת"ד, ועוד נבאר בזה לדרכנו.
translation: 5) It is puzzling what Pharaoh said to the Egyptians, "Let me borrow your children for forty months, and I will send them to the Nile." How is it possible that he asked this? After all, a loan is a return in the eyes of the lender. And if he sends them to the Nile and they drown, how will he return them to them? Moshe answered that the Nile was an idol of Pharaoh, and he told them that they should lend their children to the Nile, and he would return them to them. The Egyptians did not agree to this, as they worshipped the calf, and Pharaoh alone worshipped the Nile; therefore, they did not believe in him. Thus far the words. Furthermore, we will explain this according to our path.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's request to the Egyptians to lend their children for a period of forty days, with the intention of returning them after they are cast into the Nile, which was an idol of Pharaoh. The text highlights the theological conflict, as the Egyptians, who worshipped the calf, could not accept the idea of entrusting their children to the Nile, which Pharaoh alone revered. This reflects a deeper understanding of idolatry and the struggle between different forms of worship, emphasizing the limitations of faith in false gods. The passage suggests that true belief and trust in God are essential, as reliance on idols leads to spiritual blindness and conflict.

passage_content: ו) קשה בדברי הגמ ' דסוטה הנ"ל כיון דשדיוהו למשה במיא , אמרו תו לא קא חזינן האי סימנא בטלו לגזרתייהו וכו ', והיינו דקאמר משה שש מאות רגלי העם וגו' בשבילי נצלתם כולכם, פרש"י בשבילי בטלו המצרים גזירתם, והקשו בתוס ' אדרבה בשבילו נגזר הגזירות, לפי שראו אצטגניני פרעה שיוולד מושיען של ישראל, ותירצו דהוא הי' הראשון המושלך ליאור, ואחר שהושלך הוא לא נשלכו עוד וניצולו כולם, והקשו המהרש"א והנזה"ק דזה סותר כמה מדרשות שמפורש בהו שכבר הושלכו רבים מבני ישראל ליאור, והוא מ"ש בב"ר פ' ויחי (פר' צ"ז ס"ה) א"ר לוי ס' רבוא תינוקות עיברו נשותיהן של ישראל בלילה זו וכולן הושלכו ליאור, ועלו בזכותו של משה, הוא שמשה אומר שש מאות אלף רגלי העם וגו' כולן לרגלי עלו, וכן איתא בילקוט (רמז קס"ה) ובפדר"א (פ' מ"ב) כל הילדים שהושלכו הי' היאור פולט אותם במדבר, והי' הקב"ה מביא סלע בפי כאו"א וכו' והסלע הי' מניק אותם דבש וחלב וכו ', עוד אמרו שם ג' שנה ושליש שנה השליכום ליאור עד שנולד משה, ומשנולד אמרו לו הרי נולד והוא כמוס מעינינו, א"ל הואיל ונולד מכאן ואילך אל תשליכו הילדים וכו ', וכתב הנזה"ק דהמדרש חולק על דברי הגמ ' דסוטה , וס"ל דכבר הושלכו הרבה מישראל אלא שעלו מן היאור דרך נס בזכותו של משה, והיינו דאמר במדרש עלו בזכותו של משה ר"ל ע"י נס, אבל בגמ' אמרו בשבילי ניצלתם כולכם, שהוא הי' סיבה להצלתם בדרך הטבע שנתבטל הגזירה ע"י השלכתו עכת"ד, אמנם כללא הוא דאפושי פלוגתא לא מפשינן , וצ"ב להשוות דברי חז"ל להדדי.
translation: And it is difficult in the words of the Gemara in Sotah mentioned above, since they cast him into the water, they said, "We no longer see this sign; their decree has been nullified," etc. This is what Moses said, "Six hundred thousand foot of the people, etc., for my sake you have all been saved." Rashi explains, "For my sake the Egyptians' decree was nullified," and Tosafot questions, "On the contrary, it was because of him that the decrees were issued, for the astrologers of Pharaoh saw that the savior of Israel would be born." And they answered that he was the first one cast into the Nile, and after he was cast, they were not cast anymore, and they were all saved. The Maharsha and the Nitzotz HaKodesh questioned that this contradicts several Midrashim which explicitly state that many of the children of Israel were already thrown into the Nile. This is what is stated in Bereishit Rabbah, Parashat Vayechi (Parashat 37, Section 65), Rabbi Levi said that five hundred thousand infants were thrown by the wives of Israel on that night, and they were all cast into the Nile, and they were saved through the merit of Moses. This is why Moses says, "Six hundred thousand foot of the people, etc., all were saved for my sake." And it is also stated in the Yalkut (Remez 165) and in Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer (Chapter 42) that all the children who were thrown in were expelled by the Nile into the desert, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, would bring a stone to the mouth of each one, etc., and the stone would nurse them with honey and milk, etc. They also said there that for three years and a third of a year they were thrown into the Nile until Moses was born, and when he was born, they said, "Behold, he is born, and he is hidden from our eyes." They said to him, "Since he is born, from now on do not throw the children," etc. The Nitzotz HaKodesh wrote that the Midrash disagrees with the words of the Gemara in Sotah, and holds that many from Israel had already been thrown, but they were saved from the Nile through a miracle in the merit of Moses. This is what is said in the Midrash, "They were saved in the merit of Moses," meaning through a miracle. However, in the Gemara, it is said, "For my sake you have all been saved," which he was the cause of their salvation in a natural way, that the decree was nullified through his casting. Thus, it is a general rule that we do not resolve disputes, and it is necessary to compare the words of our Sages to each other.
summary: The passage discusses the complex relationship between divine intervention and natural events in the context of Moses' birth and the salvation of the Israelites from Pharaoh's decree. It highlights the tension between different interpretations of whether Moses' birth was the sole reason for the cessation of the decree against the Hebrew children or if many had already been saved through miraculous means. The text emphasizes that while Moses' existence played a crucial role in the natural unfolding of events, the miraculous nature of their salvation also reflects the profound connection between human actions and divine will. Ultimately, it illustrates the Hasidic belief in the interplay of faith, divine providence, and the significance of righteous individuals in the redemption process.

passage_content: ז) קשה דלפי"ד הב"ר ופרדר"א הנ"ל הי' בזה נס מופלא מאוד שנשלכו ליאור ס' רבוא ילדי ישראל ופלטן הים בדרך נס, ויפלא מדוע העלימה הכתוב ולא נזכר בתורה בפירוש, וכל נסי מצרים מבוארים בכתובים. וטעמא בעי מה שנס גדול כזה השמיטה הכתוב לגמרי, גם לא מצינו שנמנה נס זה בניסי מצרים ליתן שבח לבוי"ת עלי', ובסיפור יצ"מ בליל פסח נזכרו כמה מעלות טובות למקום עלינו, ולא נזכר נס זה ביניהם והוא פלא.
translation: It is difficult according to the words of the Rabbi and the aforementioned Midrash that there was a very wondrous miracle in that 600,000 children of Israel were sent to the sea and were saved by the sea in a miraculous way. It is astonishing why this is concealed in the text and not explicitly mentioned in the Torah, while all the miracles of Egypt are clearly stated in the writings. One seeks to understand why such a great miracle is completely omitted by the text, and we also do not find this miracle counted among the miracles of Egypt to give praise to the Blessed One above. In the recounting of the Exodus on Passover night, several good qualities are mentioned for the Holy One, Blessed be He, and this miracle is not mentioned among them, which is a wonder.
summary: The passage discusses a remarkable miracle where 600,000 children of Israel were sent to the sea and miraculously saved, yet this event is notably absent from the Torah's explicit recounting of the miracles of Egypt. The author questions why such a significant miracle is omitted from the scriptural narrative, especially since other miracles are celebrated and acknowledged during the Passover Seder. This omission raises theological inquiries about the nature of divine intervention and the reasons behind the selective remembrance of certain events in the Jewish tradition.

passage_content: ח) שמעוני פ' בשלח (בשם מדרש אבכיר ) עה"פ וירא ישראל את היד הגדולה וגו', בשעה שביקש הקב"ה להטביע את מצרים, עמד עוזא שר של מצרים לפני הקב"ה, ואמר לפניו רבש"ע נקראת צדיק וישר ואין לפניך לא עולה ולא משוא פנים וכו ', למה אתה רוצה להטביע מצרים, כלום הטביעו בני מבניך או הרגו מהם, בשביל ששעבדו בהן אתה רוצה לטבען וכו ', באותה שעה כנס הקב"ה לכל פמליא של מעלה, וא"ל הוו דנין ביני ובין עוזא שר של מצרים וכו ', שלחתי את משה ואהרן ואמרו למלך שלהם כה אמר ד' שלח עמי וגו', והתחיל מתגאה ואמר מי ד' לא ידעתי את ד' וכו' כיון שכפר בי שלחתי לו עשר מכות ולא הועלתי, וכל כך כפר בי והוסיף לשעבד בבני וכו ', מי עשה כזה ולא הבין אינו ראוי לטבעו בים וכל חילו, השיבו לו כל פמליא של מעלה הדין עמך ועשה מה שאתה חפץ וכו' עיי"ש, לכאורה כל המאמר תמוה איך העיז כ"כ עוזא שר של מצרים לדבר שקר מוחלט לפני הבוי"ת , ולומר כלום הטביעו בני מבניך, והלא מפורש בכתוב שגזר כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו, ומבואר במד"ר הנ"ל דס ' רבוא מישראל הושלכו ליאור ע"י המצרים, אלא שהצילם השי"ת בדרך נס, עכ"פ מגיע למצריים עונשם להיטבע בים מדה כנגד מדה, ואיך החציף לדבר שקר, ומבואר במכילתא בפירוש דנטבעו בי"ס מדה כנגד מדה בשביל שהשליכו ילדי ישראל ליאור, וביותר קשה שהקב"ה לא השיב לו מטעם זה. ולא אמר לו שכל טענתו שקר, וגמולם משתלם מדה כנגד מדה בשביל שהטביעו את ישראל, אלא סתר טענתו מטעם אחר בשביל שכפרו בו ית ', וע"כ ראוי לטבען בים, והאמת שחטא זה לבד מספיק לעונשם, אבל מ"מ צ"ב למה לא אמר לו הקב"ה שעונשם מדה כנגד מדה על שהטביעו את ישראל ולמה לא הכחיש טענתו כלל וצ"ב .
translation: H) Listen to me, Parashat Beshalach (in the name of Midrash Abchir) regarding the verse "And Israel saw the great hand..." At the time when the Holy One, blessed be He, sought to drown the Egyptians, Oza, the minister of Egypt, stood before the Holy One and said, "Master of the Universe, You are called righteous and upright, and before You there is neither sin offering nor favoritism, etc. Why do You want to drown the Egyptians? Did they drown any of Your children or kill any of them? Just because they enslaved them, do You want to drown them?" At that moment, the Holy One gathered all the heavenly hosts and said to them, "Let them judge between Me and Oza, the minister of Egypt, etc. I sent Moses and Aaron and they said to their king, 'Thus says the Lord: Let My people go...' and he began to boast and said, 'Who is the Lord? I do not know the Lord...' When he denied Me, I sent him ten plagues, and it was of no avail. He denied Me so much and increased the enslavement of My children, etc. Who has done such a thing and does not understand? He is not worthy to be drowned in the sea along with all his host." The heavenly hosts replied to Him, "The judgment is with You; do as You wish," etc. Upon first glance, the entire statement is puzzling. How could Oza, the minister of Egypt, so brazenly speak a complete falsehood before the Creator of the Universe and say, "Did they drown any of Your children?" Is it not explicitly written that He decreed, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river"? And it is explained in the aforementioned Midrash that five hundred thousand from Israel were thrown into the river by the Egyptians, yet the Holy One saved them through a miracle. Nevertheless, the Egyptians deserve their punishment to be drowned in the sea, measure for measure. How could he have the audacity to speak a falsehood? It is explained in the Mekilta that they were drowned in the sea measure for measure because they cast the children of Israel into the river. It is even more difficult that the Holy One did not respond to him for this reason. He did not tell him that all his claims are false, and that their punishment is measure for measure for having drowned the Israelites. Rather, He refuted his claim for another reason: because they denied Him, and therefore they are worthy of being drowned in the sea. The truth is that this sin alone is sufficient for their punishment. However, it is still a question why the Holy One did not tell him that their punishment is measure for measure for having drowned the Israelites, and why He did not deny his claim at all.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses a dialogue between God and the angel Uzza, who defends Egypt's actions by questioning why they should be punished for enslaving the Israelites when they had not killed them directly. God convenes the heavenly court to deliberate, ultimately deciding that Egypt's denial of God's sovereignty and their continued oppression justify their punishment. The text highlights the concept of divine justice, emphasizing that while Egypt's actions warranted retribution, their ultimate sin was their rejection of God, which alone was sufficient for their condemnation. The passage raises questions about the nature of justice and the reasons behind divine punishment, illustrating the complexity of moral accountability in the context of faith.

passage_content: ט) מלך מצרים למילדות ויאמר להן מדוע עשיתן הדבר הזה וגו' ותאמרן המילדות וגו' כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנה בטרם תבוא אליהם המילדת וילדו, פרש"י כי חיות הנה בקיאות כמילדות , תרגום מילדות חייתא . ובגמ' דסוטה (דף י"א ע"ב) הקשו ע"ז אטו מילדת מי לא צריכה מילדת אחריתי לאולידה , אלא אמרו לו אומה זו כחי' נמשלה, יהודה גור ארי' יהי דן נחש וכו' מה אמך לביא וגו' (ורש"י ז"ל הביא דרשה זו בשם רבותינו עיי"ש), אמנם על פי' זה קשה בכפילא , דמה נתינת טעם יש בזה שהמשילן הכתוב לחיות וע"כ א"צ מילדות, וכי המשילן הכתוב שיהיו דומים בכל טבעיותם לחיות, והחוש יכחיש זאת דחזינן שטבעיותם דומה לבנ"א , ולא המשילם הכתוב אלא לענין המעלה והמדריגה כמובן, ועוד דלפי"ז הכחישו את כל הענין ואמרו דישראל א"צ למילדות כלל, והרי חזינן דהי ' להם מילדות, ואלמלא כן הו"ל למימר מעיקרא כשגזר עליהם בילדכן את העבריות וגו' אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, הי' להם למימר מיד דא"צ למילדות ובטרם תבוא המילדת וילדו ואין בידם לקיים גזירתו, ומדוע שתקו תחלה ולא ענו אותו דבר, ורק עכשיו אמרו לו דא"צ למילדות , והרי בזה הכחישו דברי עצמן.
translation: 9) The king of Egypt said to the midwives, "Why have you done this thing, etc." And the midwives said, "Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women, for they are lively; before the midwife comes to them, they give birth." Rashi explains that they are lively, skilled like midwives; the translation of midwives is "chayah" (animal). And in the Gemara of Sotah (11b), they questioned this: "Is it not true that a midwife needs another midwife to assist in childbirth?" Rather, they said to him, "This nation is compared to animals; Judah is a lion's cub, Dan is a serpent, etc. What is your mother like a lion, etc." (And Rashi brings this interpretation in the name of our Rabbis, see there). However, according to this interpretation, it is difficult to understand the reasoning behind it, that the verse compares them to animals, and therefore they do not need midwives. Is the verse comparing them to be similar in all their nature to animals? The senses contradict this, for we see that their nature is similar to that of humans, and the verse did not compare them except in terms of their elevation and rank, as is understood. Furthermore, according to this, they denied the entire matter and said that Israel does not need midwives at all, yet we see that they had midwives. If not, it should have been stated from the beginning when he decreed upon them, "When you deliver the Hebrew women, etc., if it is a son, you shall kill him," that they should have said immediately that they do not need midwives, and before the midwife comes to them, they give birth, and they would not be able to fulfill his decree. Why did they remain silent at first and not respond to this matter, and only now did they say to him that they do not need midwives? In this, they contradicted their own words.
summary: The passage discusses the Hebrew midwives' response to Pharaoh, emphasizing their exceptional nature compared to Egyptian women, as they are likened to animals in their ability to give birth swiftly. This comparison highlights the spiritual elevation and unique qualities of the Jewish people, suggesting that their divine connection allows them to transcend natural limitations. The text raises questions about the implications of this analogy, particularly regarding the necessity of midwives, and reflects on the deeper theological significance of the Jewish identity and their relationship with God. Ultimately, it underscores the miraculous aspects of their existence and the divine protection they receive.

passage_content: י) חיות הנה בתרגום אונקלוס תירגמו ארי חכימן אינון, וצ"ב דמה נתינת טעם יש בזה דחכימן אינון, ואם הכוונה כפרש"י ז"ל שהם בקיאות כמילדות , ובלשון משנה נקראת המילדת חכמה, א"כ כמו"כ יקשה על התרגום כקושית הגמ ' אטו מילדת מי לא צריכא מילדת אחריתי, גם ראוי להבין מדוע תיאר המילדות חכימן , והתוי"ט פי' דע"כ נקראת חכמה ע"ש שבקיאים באומנתם, וטעם זה אינו מספיק, דכל אומן בקי באומנתו ולא כינוהו חז"ל לחכם מטעם זה.
translation: 1) The animals, behold, in the translation of Onkelos, they translated "lion" as "wise ones," and it is to be questioned what reasoning there is in this that they are called "wise ones." If the intention is as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains that they are knowledgeable like midwives, and in the language of the Mishnah, the midwife is called "wise," then it would also be difficult on the translation as the Gemara questions, "Is it not necessary for a midwife to have another midwife?" It is also appropriate to understand why the midwives are described as wise ones, and the Tiferet Tzion explains that they are called wise because they are proficient in their craft. However, this reasoning is not sufficient, for every craftsman is proficient in his craft, and the Sages did not call him wise for this reason.
summary: The passage discusses the term "חכימן" (wise ones) used in the translation of "חיות" (midwives) in the context of their expertise. It questions the reasoning behind this designation, suggesting that while midwives are skilled in their craft, this alone does not justify calling them wise, as many artisans are proficient without receiving such a title. The text implies a deeper understanding of wisdom that transcends mere technical skill, hinting at a spiritual or divine insight inherent in the midwives' role. This reflects a Hasidic perspective that values the inner qualities and spiritual dimensions of individuals beyond their practical abilities.

passage_content: יא) צ"ב לפרש"י כי חיות הנה שבקיאות כמילדות , דלא מצינו בשום מקום זולת כאן שהמילדת נקראת חי', ובמשנה נקראת היולדת כן ולא המילדת , גם דבכל הפרשה הזכירן כ"פ בשם מילדות כמ"ש ויקרא מלך מצרים למילדות וגו' ותיראן המילדות וגו' ועוד כ"פ , ורק בפסוק זה קראן חיות, ומיד אח"כ חזר וקראן מילדות, דכתיב בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת וילדו, ולמה שינה הכתוב לשונו לקראן מילדות וחיות ומילדות וצ"ב .
translation: 11) It is difficult to understand Rashi's explanation that the midwives are referred to as "chayot" (living beings), for we do not find anywhere else, except here, that a midwife is called "chaya." In the Mishnah, the term used is "yolelet" (the one giving birth) and not "miyaldot" (midwives). Furthermore, throughout the entire section, they are mentioned repeatedly as "miyaldot," as it is written, "And the king of Egypt spoke to the midwives" and "And the midwives feared," and so on. Only in this verse are they called "chayot," and immediately afterward, they are referred to again as "miyaldot," as it is written, "Before the midwife comes to them, they have given birth." Why did the text change its language to call them "miyaldot" and "chayot" and "miyaldot"? This is difficult to understand.
summary: The passage discusses the unique terminology used in the Torah regarding the midwives, referring to them as "חיות" (living beings) in one instance, which is distinct from their usual designation as "מילדות" (midwives). This shift in language suggests a deeper spiritual significance, highlighting the midwives' role not just in childbirth but as agents of life and divine will. The text raises questions about the implications of this terminology, inviting reflection on the sanctity of life and the spiritual responsibilities of those who assist in its creation. Ultimately, it emphasizes the connection between physical birth and spiritual vitality within the Hasidic framework.

translation: 11. The Yov"ah explains that the creatures are, etc., swift and wise in their understanding; until they do not cease to gaze upon the Divine Presence, their eyes are fixed in prayer, they are silent and seek mercy from before their Father in Heaven, and He hears their prayers, etc. And it is to be pondered that the verse does not depart from its simple meaning, and all this is not clarified in the straightforward interpretation of the texts.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of spiritual beings, referred to as "Chayot," who are characterized by their swiftness and wisdom in understanding divine matters. It emphasizes that these beings direct their gaze towards prayer, seeking mercy from their Father in Heaven, who listens to their supplications. The text raises a question about the interpretation of scripture, suggesting that the literal meaning may not fully capture the deeper spiritual truths conveyed. This reflects a Hasidic perspective that values the mystical dimensions of prayer and divine connection.

passage_content: יג ויאמר אלקים אל משה אקי' אשר אקי' ויאמר כה תאמר אל בנ"י אקי' שלחני וגו' במס' ברכות (דף ט') דרשו ז"ל אמר הקב"ה למשה אהי ' עמהם בצרה זו, ואהי ' עמהם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , אמר לפניו רבש"ע די' לצרה בשעתה וכו' אמר לו יפה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם כבר הבאנו לעיל קושית המפרשים איך יתכן שמשרע"ה שאל קושיא לאלקינו , ומלמד למי שמלמד לאדם דעת, גם צ"ב דבפסוק שלאחריו כתיב ויאמר עוד אלקים אל משה כה תאמר אל בנ"י אלקי אבותיכם אלקי אברהם יצחק ויעקב שלחני אליכם וגו', הרי ג' תשובות שונות על שאלת משרע"ה מה שמו מה אומר אליהם וצ"ב וכבר ביארנו בזה ועוד לאלקי מילין .
translation: 13 And God said to Moses, "I Am that I Am." And He said, "Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I Am has sent me to you.'" In the tractate Berakhot (page 9), our sages taught that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "I am with them in this distress, and I am with them in the servitude of other kingdoms." Moses said before Him, "Master of the Universe, let it be enough for the distress at this time," etc. He replied, "You have spoken well. Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I Am has sent me to you.'" We have already brought above the question of the commentators on how it is possible that Moses asked a question of our God, and it teaches us that He who teaches knowledge to man. It is also to be noted that in the verse that follows, it is written, "And God said further to Moses, 'Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob has sent me to you,'" etc. Here are three different answers to Moses' question about what is His name and what shall I say to them, and it is to be noted, and we have already explained this further in the context of the words.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the divine presence during times of suffering and oppression, emphasizing that God is with the Israelites in their distress. The text explores the significance of God's name "Ehyeh" (I will be) as a reassurance of His eternal support and involvement in their plight. Additionally, it addresses the complexity of Moses' inquiries about God's identity and the varied responses he receives, reflecting the multifaceted nature of divine revelation and the relationship between God and His people. This underscores key Hasidic themes of faith, divine companionship, and the importance of understanding God's essence in the context of human experience.

passage_content: יד) משה מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה וכי אוציא את בנ"י ממצרים, פרש"י ז"ל מה אני חשוב לדבר עם המלכים, ואף אם חשוב אני מה זכו ישראל שתעשה להם נס ואוציאם ממצרים, והשיב לו הבוי"ת בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, פרש"י ז"ל ששאלת מה זכות יש לישראל שיצאו ממצרים, דבר גדול יש לי על הוצאה זו, שהרי עתידים לקבל התורה על ההר הזה לסוף ג' חדשים שיצאו ממצרים עכ"ל, כבר הקשינו לעיל דאיך יתכן למשרע"ה להסתפק בשליחותו, אחרי שהבוי"ת שלחו בודאי יש זכות לגאולתם, ואם לא ראה משרע"ה זכות מספיק לגאולתם, הי"ל לבקש עליהם רחמים, והיכולת בידו ית ' לגאלם אף בלי זכות ע"ש העתיד, כמו שהשיב לו ית ' באמת, וטענת משרע"ה נראה ח"ו כקטרוג על ישראל, גם מבואר בדברי רז"ל שהיו ישראל מצויינים במצרים, ובשביל ד' דברים נגאלו ישראל ממצרים וכו' ובזוה"ק פ' שמות (דף ג') זכאין אינון ישראל דאסתמרו בגלותא דמצרים מכל הני תלתא מנדה ומבת אל נכר ומקטול זרעא ואשתדלו בפו"ר , וא"כ הרי הי"ל זכותים , ומה זה שטען משרע"ה באיזה זכות וצ"ב .
translation: (10) Moses said, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that I should bring out the children of Israel from Egypt?" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "What am I important to speak with kings? And even if I am important, what merit do the Israelites have that You should perform a miracle for them and bring them out of Egypt?" And He replied to him, "When you bring out the people from Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that he asked, "What merit do the Israelites have to be taken out of Egypt?" There is a great merit for this exodus, for they are destined to receive the Torah on this mountain at the end of three months after they leave Egypt. Thus far the text. We have already questioned above how it is possible for Moses to doubt his mission, after the Holy One, blessed be He, sent him; certainly there is merit for their redemption. And if Moses did not see sufficient merit for their redemption, he should have asked for mercy on their behalf, and it is within His power to redeem them even without merit for the future, as He truly replied to him. And Moses' claim seems, Heaven forbid, like an accusation against Israel. It is also clear from the words of our Sages that the Israelites were distinguished in Egypt, and for four reasons the Israelites were redeemed from Egypt, etc. And in the Zohar, Parashat Shemot (page 3), it is stated that the Israelites are worthy because they were preserved in the exile of Egypt from all these three things: from the three plagues, from the daughter of a foreigner, and from the slaughter of offspring, and they exerted themselves in the service of God. Therefore, they should have had merits. What is this that Moses claimed, "By what merit?" And this is a question.
summary: In this passage, Moses questions his worthiness to confront Pharaoh and lead the Israelites out of Egypt, expressing doubt about their merit for such a miraculous redemption. God responds that their liberation is tied to the future giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, highlighting the intrinsic connection between redemption and divine purpose. The text emphasizes that despite Moses' concerns, the Israelites possess inherent merits that justify their redemption, reflecting a deep theological insight into the relationship between divine grace, human action, and the significance of the Torah in the process of salvation.

passage_content: טו) צ"ב שאחר שאמר משרע"ה מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה וכי אוציא את בנ"י , אמר לו השי"ת ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך וגו' ושלחתי את ידי והכיתי את מצרים בכל נפלאותי וגו' ומהמשך הפסוקים נראה שהי' כ"ז מתשובתו ית ' למשרע"ה על שאלתו מי אנכי וגו', וצ"ב הסמיכות ואיך יהי' בזה תשובה על שאלתו באיזה זכות וכו'
translation: 15) It is puzzling that after Moshe Rabbeinu said, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that I should bring out the Children of Israel," the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded, "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go..." and "I will stretch out My hand and smite Egypt with all My wonders..." From the continuation of the verses, it appears that this was all a response from the Blessed One to Moshe's question of "Who am I..." It is puzzling why this is connected and how this serves as an answer to his question of "by what merit..."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between Moses and God highlights the theme of divine empowerment in the face of human inadequacy. When Moses questions his worthiness to confront Pharaoh and lead the Israelites, God's response emphasizes that the success of the mission relies not on Moses' merit but on God's omnipotence and the miraculous signs He will perform. This interaction illustrates the Hasidic concept that true leadership and redemption stem from divine grace rather than human capability, reinforcing the belief in God's active role in guiding and saving His people.

passage_content: ונבוא אל הביאור בהקדם מה דאיתא בספה"ק דפרשיות אלו נקראים ימי השובבים, והמה מסוגלים לתקון חטא הידוע, ובאמת כל יומא ויומא זמני' הוא וכל השנה כולה הקב"ה מקבל תשובתם של ישראל, אבל אלו הימים מסוגלים יותר, וראוי להבין טעמא מאי, ומה התייחסם של פרשיות אלו לתשובת חטא הידוע יותר מכל השנה, ונקדים מה דאיתא בזוה"ק פ' ויחי (דף יר"ט ע"ב) דלא מהני תשובה ר"ל על חטא הידוע, ובמקו"א ( בזוה"ק פ' נח ס"ב ע"א) אמרו דרק תשובה סגי מהני, וכן איתא בזוה"ק ויקהל (רי"ד ע"ב) דרק תיובתא שלימתא , תיובתא דאיהי אתחזייא לחפייא על כל עובדוי וכו' עכ"ל, וראוי שיחרד האדם, ויתחמץ לבב אנוש, כי בעוה"ר רחוקים אנו ממדריגת תשובה גדולה כזו, ואף למדריגת תשובה קלה הימנה לא הגענו, ואי' איפה תקותינו שיתכפר עונינו, ובעוה"ר הנסיונות גדולים וקשים, ואנוסים אנחנו ע"י כוחות היצה"ר וחיילותיו, ותוקף שעבוד הגלות וזרם העולם, וקשה להשיג אף בחי' קטנה של תשובה.
translation: And we will come to the explanation as to what is stated in the holy books that these portions are called the days of the Shovavim, and they are capable of rectifying the known sin. In truth, every day is a time for repentance, and throughout the entire year, the Holy One, blessed be He, accepts the repentance of Israel, but these days are more capable. It is fitting to understand the reason for this, and what the connection of these portions is to the repentance of the known sin more than at any other time of the year. We will begin with what is stated in the Zohar, Parashat Vayechi (page 19b), that repentance does not help, God forbid, for the known sin, and in another place (in the Zohar, Parashat Noach 62a) it is said that only repentance is sufficient. Likewise, it is stated in the Zohar, Parashat Vayakhel (page 214b) that only a complete repentance, which is revealed to the heart for all deeds, etc. Therefore, it is fitting for a person to tremble, and for the heart of man to be pained, for in our times we are far from such a great level of repentance, and even to a level of easy repentance we have not reached. And where is our hope that our iniquity will be atoned? In our times, the trials are great and difficult, and we are compelled by the forces of the evil inclination and its armies, and the strength of the bondage of exile and the currents of the world, and it is hard to attain even a small degree of repentance.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the "Shovavim" period, which is particularly conducive to repentance for a specific sin. It emphasizes that while God accepts repentance throughout the year, these days hold a unique power for atonement. The text references the Zohar, highlighting that true repentance is essential and that many struggle to reach even a basic level of repentance due to the challenges posed by the evil inclination and the hardships of exile. This situation evokes a sense of urgency and despair regarding the ability to achieve genuine atonement.

passage_content: אמנם מצאתי תנחומין בדברי ק"ז זלל"ה בתפלה למשה (כ"ה) עה"פ למען שמך ד' וסלחת לעוני כי רב הוא, ותו"ד עפימ"ש הפרשת דרכים דלטובה הקב"ה דן ע"ש סופו, ומבואר בדרז"ל והרמב"ם ז"ל דכל ישראל יעשו תשובה לפני ביאת המשיח. ואחר ביאת משיח עתידים כל ישראל לעשות תשובה עילאה עיי"ש, ושורש הדבר שראוי לפניו ית ' לדון את ישראל לטובה ע"ש סופם, נצמח משמו הקדוש הי' הו' ויהי', דאצלו ית ' אין השתנות בזמן, ועבר והו ' ועתיד הכל אחד הוא, ומה שעתיד להיות כבר הי' ופי' ק"ז זלל"ה ביאור הכתוב בבחי ' זו, למען שמך ד', המורה כי עבר ועתיד לפניו ית ' אחד הוא, ע"כ וסלחת לעוני אף כי רב הוא, ר"ל דכובד העון רב ועדיין לא שבנו תשובה הגונה, אבל ידון אותנו השי"ת ע"ש העתיד, עיין בדברינו (פ' ויחי) בתוס ' נופך על דב"ק .
translation: Indeed, I found comfort in the words of the holy Rabbi K. Z. Z. L. H. in the prayer of Moses (25) regarding the verse "For the sake of Your name, O Lord, and You forgave my iniquity, for it is great." And further, according to what is stated in the separation of paths for good, the Holy One, blessed be He, judges according to the end. It is explained in the teachings of our sages and in the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, that all of Israel will repent before the coming of the Messiah. After the coming of the Messiah, all of Israel will be destined to do a higher repentance, as mentioned there. The root of the matter is that it is fitting before Him, blessed be He, to judge Israel for good according to their end, which is derived from His holy name, which was, is, and will be, for with Him, blessed be He, there is no change in time; past, present, and future are all one. And what is destined to be has already been, and Rabbi K. Z. Z. L. H. explains the verse in this aspect: "For the sake of Your name, O Lord," indicating that past and future are one before Him, blessed be He. Therefore, "You forgave my iniquity, even though it is great," meaning that the weight of the sin is great, and we have not yet returned with a proper repentance, but the Holy One, blessed be He, will judge us according to the future. See our words (Parashat Vayechi) in the additional commentary on the Talmud.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine judgment in relation to repentance, emphasizing that God judges Israel favorably based on their future potential rather than their current shortcomings. It highlights the idea that time is irrelevant to God, as past, present, and future are unified in His perspective. The reference to the verse "for Your name's sake, O Lord, forgive my iniquity, for it is great" illustrates that despite the weight of sin, God's judgment is rooted in the promise of future repentance and redemption. Ultimately, this reflects a deep theological insight into God's mercy and the transformative power of repentance in the context of the coming of the Messiah.

passage_content: וכעת נראה לומר עוד בחי' בזה, בהקדם מ"ש ק"ז זלל"ה בייטב פנים (אבני זכרון סי' י"ב וכ"ג) ללמד זכות על ישראל, ולהסר התלונה האמור בתיקוני זוה"ק (תיקון ו') ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש, אלא איש לדרכו פונה וכו' כולהו צווחין הב, הב לנא מזונא וסליחה וכפרה וחיי, כתבנו לחיים וכו ', ולכאורה הרי נוסח תפלה זו תקנו אנשי כנה"ג להתפלל כן בימים נוראים, זכרינו לחיים וכו' כתבינו בספר פרנסה וכלכלה, וא"כ קשיא על מתקני התפלות מדוע תקנו להתפלל כן, אמנם ביאור הענין דכוונת אנשי כנה"ג וכן צריך שתהי' כוונתינו בתפלות אלו, לבקש על סליחה וכפרה וחיים ופרנסה הכל למענו ית ' כדי שיהא סיפוק בידינו לעבדו ית"ש בהרחבת הדעת, ויסיר מאתנו המניעות והעיכובים, כעניות ומלחמות וחלאים ורעב וכדומה המרחיקים מעבודתו ית ', וזה מאמרינו זכרנו לחיים וכו' למענך אלקים חיים, ר"ל כדי למלא רצונך לעבדך בכל זה, ועיקר כוונתינו צריך להיות כדי שיתקדש ש"ש על ידינו. בהיות בניו זרע ברך ד' מלאים כל טוב, וז"ש דוהמע"ה צמאה נפשי לאלקים וגו' מתי אבוא ואראה פני אלקים , היתה לי דמעתי לחם יומם ולילה, כלומר מה שאני מוריד דמעות בשביל הלחם ופרנסה יומם ולילה, הוא בשביל באמור אלי כל היום אי' אלקיך יקום ויעזרך והוא העדר כבודו ית ', ע"כ אני מבקש לחם ופרנסה למען כבוד שמו ית ' שיתקדש על ידי, ובזה סרה תלונת התיקו"ז הק ', כי דבריו אמורים על המבקש עניני גשמי לעצמו למלא תאותו , אבל אנן בדידן שכוונתינו לפנימיות הדברים ולכבוד שמו ית ', כך נאה וכך יאה והרי לימוד זכות עלינו עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: And now we shall say further regarding this, by prefacing what is mentioned in Kabbalistic texts (Tikkunei Zohar, Tikkun 6) to teach merit for Israel, and to remove the complaint mentioned therein, that he looked this way and that and saw that there was no man, but each man turned to his own way, etc. All of them are crying out, "Give, give to us sustenance and forgiveness and atonement and life." We have written for life, etc. And seemingly, the wording of this prayer was established by the Men of the Great Assembly to pray this way on the High Holy Days, "Remember us for life," etc. We have written in the Book of Sustenance and Provision. Therefore, it is difficult to understand why the formulators of the prayers established it this way. However, the explanation of the matter is that the intention of the Men of the Great Assembly, and thus our intention in these prayers, should be to request forgiveness and atonement and life and sustenance all for His sake, so that we may have the ability to serve Him, blessed be He, with an expanded mind, and to remove from us the obstacles and delays, such as poverty, wars, sickness, famine, and similar things that distance us from His service. This is the meaning of our saying, "Remember us for life," etc., for Your sake, O living God, meaning in order to fulfill Your will to serve You in all this. Our primary intention should be that His Name be sanctified through us, as His children, the seed blessed by the Lord, filled with all good. And this is what King David, may his memory be blessed, said, "My soul thirsts for God," etc., "When shall I come and see the face of God?" It was for me like the bread of my tears day and night, meaning that the reason I shed tears for bread and sustenance day and night is because of the words that are said to me all day, "Your God will arise and help you," and this is the absence of His honor, blessed be He. Therefore, I request bread and sustenance for the honor of His Name, that it be sanctified through me. And in this, the complaint of the Tikkunei Zohar is removed, for its words are directed at one who seeks material matters for himself to fulfill his desires. But we, in our case, have our intention directed towards the inner aspects of things and for the honor of His Name, and thus it is fitting and proper, and indeed, it is a merit for us, as stated by him, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of intention in prayer, particularly during the High Holidays, where requests for life, sustenance, and forgiveness should be made for the sake of serving God and glorifying His name. It contrasts the superficial pursuit of material needs with a deeper spiritual aspiration, asserting that true prayers should focus on fulfilling God's will and sanctifying His name through one's actions. The author seeks to dispel the notion that such prayers are self-serving, instead framing them as a means to remove obstacles to divine service, thereby aligning personal needs with a higher purpose.

passage_content: ועפ"י דבריו הקדושים הנה יש טענת המלצת זכות על ישראל שיקובל התשובה גם על חטא הידוע ר"ל, אף שמבואר בזוה"ק דצריך לעשות תיובתא שלימתא על חטא זה, ובעוה"ר לא הגענו למידה זו, אמנם כל בקשתינו מהבוי"ת על סליחה מחילה וכפרה לא למענינו ולטובת עצמינו, כ"א רק בעבור כבוד שמו ית ', ועפ"י מ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה ( בפ ' תבא ) וזלה"ק תמהתי על עיכוב הגלות וכו ', וכאשר חקרתי נתוודע לי כי בבחרותם מרבין חבילות חבילות עבירות, עד שדי להם על כל ימי חייהם וכו' וזה הגורם, ולכך אין יכולין שוב להדבק בבוראינו ית"ש וכו' עיי"ש, נמצא שזו סיבת אריכות הגלות בעוה"ר , וכשנזכה שיטהרנו השי"ת מכובד העון הזה נזכה מיד לגאולתינו ופדות נפשינו, ואין לך כבוד שמים גדול מזה, וענין הגאולה תלוי בכפרת חטא זה, גם ידוע מ"ש בספה"ק נוע"א זלל"ה בהנהגותיו כי חטאת נעורים של האדם מסמין עיניו שלא יראה האמת עיי"ש שהאריך, ובעוה"ר חטא זה הוא גורם השפלות הגדול בדורנו, שאין אנו יכולים להתעלות במדרגות עבדות השי"ת, כי חטא זה מסמא עינים ר"ל ומעכב, וכן מה שישראל מתפללין ושופכין את נפשם להבוכ"ע , חטא זה מקטרג ומעכב תפלתם מלהתקבל ח"ו, ומעתה יש לנו טענת זכות לבקש סליחה וכפרה על חטא הידוע לא למענינו, כ"א בעבור כבוד שמו ית ', דבאמת כל אחד מישראל משתוקק לעבוד השי"ת בבחינה יותר גדולה ולהטיב מעשיו, כדי לעשות נחת רוח לבוי"ת , ואילו זכינו לתקן חטא זה ויקבל הקב"ה בחי' תשובתינו ויענה ויאמר סלחתי, כבר נהייתה הגאולה שלימה, ונתרבה כבוד שמים עד אין שיעור ואין ערך, וטעם זה בלבד מספיק לדחות כל קטרוג, ושנזכה למחילת עוונות מיד, כי אם בקשתינו עבור כבוד שמים א"א לומר דלא מהני תשובה, וישתתקו כל המקטריגים , כי מי לא יחוש על כבוד שמו ית '.
translation: According to his holy words, behold, there is a claim of merit on behalf of Israel that the repentance should be accepted even for the known sin, may it be erased, even though it is explained in the Zohar that a complete resolution must be made for this sin, and unfortunately, we have not reached this measure. However, all our requests from the Blessed One for forgiveness, pardon, and atonement are not for our own sake or for our own benefit, but only for the honor of His Name, blessed be He. And according to what is written in the holy words of the Yeshua M'Yisrael, may his memory be for a blessing (in Parashat Ki Tavo), and as he states, I was astonished by the delay of the exile, etc. And when I investigated, it became known to me that in their youth they accumulate bundles upon bundles of sins, to the extent that it suffices for them for all the days of their lives, etc. This is the cause, and therefore they cannot again cleave to our Creator, blessed be He, etc. Thus, it is found that this is the reason for the prolonged exile, unfortunately. And when we merit that the Holy One, blessed be He, purifies us from this heavy sin, we will immediately merit our redemption and the salvation of our souls, and there is no greater honor for Heaven than this. The matter of redemption depends on the atonement for this sin. It is also known what is written in the holy book Nefesh HaChaim, may his memory be for a blessing, in his teachings, that the youthful sin of a person blinds his eyes so that he does not see the truth, as he elaborated there. And unfortunately, this sin is the cause of the great degradation in our generation, that we cannot elevate ourselves in the levels of servitude to the Holy One, blessed be He, because this sin blinds the eyes, may it be erased, and obstructs. Likewise, the fact that Israel prays and pours out their souls before the Blessed Creator, this sin accuses and prevents their prayers from being accepted, Heaven forbid. From now on, we have a claim of merit to ask for forgiveness and atonement for the known sin, not for our own sake, but for the honor of His Name, blessed be He. For in truth, every one of Israel longs to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, in a greater capacity and to improve their deeds, in order to bring pleasure to the Blessed One. And if we were to merit to rectify this sin and the Holy One, blessed be He, would accept our repentance, and He would respond and say, "I have forgiven," then the redemption would already be complete, and the honor of Heaven would be increased to an immeasurable extent, and this reason alone is sufficient to dismiss all accusations. And may we merit the forgiveness of transgressions immediately, for if our request is for the honor of Heaven, it cannot be said that repentance is ineffective, and all accusers should be silenced, for who would not be concerned for the honor of His Name, blessed be He?
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of seeking forgiveness for sins, particularly the known sin that hinders spiritual elevation and connection to God. It argues that the request for atonement should be made not for personal benefit, but out of reverence for God's honor. The text suggests that true repentance can lead to redemption and the elevation of divine glory, countering any accusations against the Jewish people. Ultimately, it asserts that if the intention is for God's glory, sincere repentance will be accepted, silencing all detractors.

passage_content: ואפשר שזה פירוש הפסוק למען שמך ד' וסלחת לעוני כי רב הוא, שאנו מבקשין סליחה ומחילה מלפניך בשביל כבוד שמך ית ', כדי שיתרבה כבוד שמים על ידינו, ואנו בטוחים כי עד"ז תסלח לעונינו אף כי רב הוא ר"ל דכובד העון רב ואין בידינו תשובת המשקל, אבל ראוי שתסלח ותמחול לא למענינו כ"א לכבוד שמך ית ', ואפ"ל עוד בחי' דמאמר כי רב הוא קאי על למען שמך ד', ר"ל דראוי שתסלח לעוננו באשר בקשתינו רק למען שמך ד', כי רב הוא כי כבודו ית ' גדול ורב, ולמען שיתרבה כבודו ית ' ראוי שיענה הבוי"ת ויאמר סלחתי לישראל.
translation: And it is possible that this is the interpretation of the verse "For Your name's sake, O Lord, and You have forgiven my iniquity, for it is great," that we seek forgiveness and pardon before You for the honor of Your name, blessed be He, so that the honor of Heaven may be increased through us. And we are confident that in a similar manner You will forgive our iniquities, even though they are great, meaning that the weight of the sin is heavy and we do not have a response of equivalent measure. However, it is fitting that You should forgive and pardon, not for our sake, but for the honor of Your name, blessed be He. And it may also be that the aspect of "for it is great" refers to "for Your name's sake, O Lord," meaning that it is fitting for You to forgive our iniquities since our request is only for the sake of Your name, for it is great, because Your honor, blessed be He, is great and abundant. And for the sake of increasing Your honor, blessed be He, it is fitting that the Holy One, Blessed be He, should respond and say, "I have forgiven Israel."
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of seeking forgiveness from God not for our own sake, but for the honor of His name. It suggests that despite the weight of our sins, we trust that God will forgive us to enhance His glory. The request for forgiveness is framed as a means to increase the sanctity of His name, highlighting the belief that God's greatness warrants His compassion and mercy towards Israel. Ultimately, the text reflects a deep connection between divine forgiveness and the elevation of God's honor in the world.

passage_content: וכעין בחי' זו איתא במדרש שוח"ט (מזמור כ"ה) עה"פ כחסדך זכר לי אתה למען טובך ד', א"ר אלעזר משל למלך שעשה סעודה גדולה, ואמר לאפטרופס שלו זמין לי בנ"א חכמים תגרים ולא בעלי מלאכה, אמר לו אדוני המלך סעודתך גדולה היא, ותגרים לא יספיקו לך אלא עם בעלי מלאכה, כך אמר דוד כחסדך זכר לי אתה, למה למען טובך ד' שנאמר טוב ד' לכל, ופי' המפרשים שדוהמע"ה ראה והביט בשפלות הדורות שיהי' לעתיד, ע"כ ביקש והתפלל מה רב טובך אשר צפנת ליריאך , ר"ל רב טוב צפון לישראל לעולם הבא, כל הנחמות והטובות שנתנבאו הנביאים על ימות המשיח, אמנם אם תבקש רק אנשי מעלה צדיקים וחכמים למי ינתן כל אלה, כי סעודתך גדולה היא ואנשי מעלה לא יספיקו כ"כ, והשי"ת טוב ומטיב וחפץ ומתענג להטיב, וע"כ ראוי שיתחסד לקרב אליו בנ"י המשתוקקים להתקרב ולהתדבק בו ית ' ולקבל תשובתם, דאל"כ למי הוכן כל אלה, וז"ש דוד המע"ה כחסדך זכר לי, למען טובך ד' בשביל מדת טובך, ובשביל רב טוב אשר צפנת ליריאך לע"ל .
translation: And a similar concept is found in the Midrash Shochar Tov (Psalm 25) on the verse "According to Your kindness, remember me for the sake of Your goodness, O Lord." Rabbi Elazar said: It is like a king who made a great feast and said to his steward, "Prepare for me wise men, merchants, and not laborers." The steward replied, "My lord the king, your feast is great, and merchants alone will not suffice without laborers." Thus, David said, "According to Your kindness, remember me." Why? "For the sake of Your goodness, O Lord," as it is said, "The Lord is good to all." The commentators explain that David, may his memory be blessed, saw and beheld the lowliness of the generations that would be in the future. Therefore, he requested and prayed, "How great is Your goodness that You have stored up for those who fear You," meaning there is great goodness stored for Israel in the World to Come, all the comforts and good things that the prophets prophesied about the days of the Messiah. However, if you only seek the righteous and wise, to whom will all these be given? For Your feast is great, and the righteous alone will not suffice. And the Holy One, blessed be He, is good and does good, and desires and delights in doing good. Therefore, it is fitting that He should show kindness to draw near to His children who long to come close and cling to Him, blessed be He, and to accept their repentance. For otherwise, to whom are all these prepared? And this is what David, may his memory be blessed, meant when he said, "According to Your kindness, remember me, for the sake of Your goodness, O Lord," because of the measure of Your goodness, and for the great goodness that You have stored up for those who fear You in the World to Come.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine kindness and the necessity of including all people, not just the righteous, in God's benevolence. It uses the metaphor of a king's grand feast, emphasizing that while the king desires wise and righteous guests, the feast is too great to be limited to them alone. King David's plea for God's mercy reflects an understanding that God's goodness is vast and meant for all, especially in light of the future redemption and the abundance of blessings promised to the faithful. Ultimately, it highlights God's desire to extend kindness to all who seek closeness to Him.

passage_content: עוד שם במדרש ריב"ח אמר משל למלך שעשה סעודה וזימן את האורחים, הגיעו ארבע שעות ולא באו, לחמש שעות ולא באו, לשש שעות ולא באו, לעתותי הערב התחילו האורחים ממשמשין ובאין אמר להם טובה גדולה אני צריך להחזיק לכם, אילולי שבאתם כל הסעודה הייתי משליך לכלבים שלא הי' מי לאכול, כך אומר הקב"ה לצדיקים טובה גדולה אני מחזיק לכם, שבשבילכם בראתי את עולמי, שאלמלא אתם כל הטובה שהתקנתי לע"ל , למי הייתי נותנה שנאמר מה רב טובך אשר צפנת ליריאך , טוב וישר ד' על כן מורה חטאים בדרך שיעשו תשובה עכ"ל המדרש, ומה מאוד יצדק ענין המשל בדור האחרון ימינו אלה, שאנו עומדין כבר בסוף אלף הששי, לפני פנות היום עת ינטו צללי ערב, ואם נעשה תשובה ונתקרב להיותינו דבוקים בו ית ', בודאי נזכה לרב טוב הצפון לצדיקים לע"ל , והבוי"ת יקבל תשובתינו ויאמר לנו טובה גדולה אני צריך להחזיק לכם, אילולי שבאתם כל הטובה שצפנתי למי הייתי נותנה, וע"כ אף שאין בחי' תשובתינו מעולה כ"כ, ואין בכוחינו לשוב תשובת המשקל כפי כובד העון , אבל הבוי"ת יקבל תשובתינו בשביל כבודו ית ' כי חפץ להטיב ורב חסד הוא, ועכ"פ ראוי שנחשוב חשבונו של עולם דכבר הוא לפנות ערב, וחיש מהר יפנה היום, ואם לא עכשיו אימתי, וע"כ נראה לתקן עד כמה שאפשר ונשמור עצמנו מכל חטא והרהורים, ונהי' דבוקים בתוה"ק ונבקש דרך האמת, והבוי"ת יסלח לנו ויקבל תשובתינו למען כבוד שמו ית '.
translation:
In the Midrash it is stated: Rabbi Yochanan said, it is like a king who made a feast and invited guests. Four hours passed and they did not come, five hours passed and they did not come, six hours passed and they did not come. As evening approached, the guests began to fumble and come. The king said to them, "I have a great favor to bestow upon you; had you not come, I would have thrown the entire feast to the dogs, for there would have been no one to eat." Thus says the Holy One, Blessed be He, to the righteous: "I have a great favor to bestow upon you, for because of you I created My world. For if not for you, all the goodness that I have prepared for the World to Come, to whom would I give it?" As it is said, "How great is Your goodness that You have stored up for those who fear You." The Lord is good and upright; therefore He instructs sinners in the way they should go. Thus concludes the Midrash. 

How very fitting is the matter of this parable in our last generation, in these days, as we stand at the end of the sixth millennium, before the evening approaches, when the shadows of evening begin to stretch. If we repent and draw close to be attached to Him, Blessed be He, we will certainly merit the great goodness stored up for the righteous in the World to Come. The Blessed One will accept our repentance and say to us, "I have a great favor to bestow upon you; had you not come, all the goodness that I have stored up, to whom would I give it?" Therefore, even though our repentance is not so excellent, and we do not have the strength to return a repentance that weighs according to the heaviness of the sin, the Blessed One will accept our repentance for the sake of His honor, for He desires to do good and is abundant in kindness. 

And in any case, it is fitting that we consider the account of the world, for it is already approaching evening, and soon the day will turn. If not now, when? Therefore, let us strive to rectify as much as possible and guard ourselves from all sin and improper thoughts, and let us be attached to the Holy Torah and seek the path of truth. The Blessed One will forgive us and accept our repentance for the sake of the honor of His Name.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel uses a parable of a king inviting guests to illustrate God's relationship with the righteous. It emphasizes that the world was created for the sake of the righteous, and their presence is essential for the fulfillment of divine goodness. As we approach the end of the sixth millennium, there is an urgent call for repentance, with the assurance that even imperfect repentance will be accepted by God out of His desire to bestow kindness. The text encourages believers to strive for closeness to God and to seek truth, as the time for spiritual rectification is pressing.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתורץ קושיא (י"ד) הנ"ל ששאל משרע"ה מה זכו ישראל שתעשה להם נס ואוציאם ממצרים, ואף שידע משרע"ה שהי"ל זכותים כמבואר בדברי רז"ל ובזוה"ק כנ"ל, אמנם חשש משה רבינו פן ישלוט עליהם כח הקטרוג, כמו שהי' באמת שטען ס"מ ושר של מצרים הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז , ושמא לא יספיק זכותם לדחות כח הקטרוג, ואיך יזכו להעשות להם נס, ע"ז השיב לו ית ' דבר גדול יש לי על הוצאה זו. שהרי עתידים לקבל התורה על ההר הזה לסוף ג' חדשים שיצאו ממצרים, וז"ש בהוציאך את העם וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ויש בתשובה זו ב' בחי', א' כמ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה דלטובה הקב"ה דן ע"ש סופו, ולפניו ית ' העבר ועתיד והו ' הכל אחד הוא ומה שעתיד להיות כבר הי', נמצא יש להם מיד זכות קבלת התורה, ולדרכנו הנ"ל עוד יש בחי' בזה, דע"י יציאתם ממצרים יקבלו התורה ויקיימוה בכל הדורות, ויתרבה כבוד שמים בכל דורות ישראל, א"כ תועלת יציאתם בשביל להרבות כבוד שמים, ומעתה זכותם רב ומספיק לדחות כל קטרוג, ויתורץ ג"כ קושיא (ט"ו) הנ"ל שהשיב הקב"ה עוד למשה ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך וגו' ושלחתי את ידי והכיתי את מצרים בכל נפלאותי וגו', וע"י הנסים והנפלאות יתרבה כבוד שמו ית ' בעולם, וישמעו כל העמים גבורותיו ית ', וזה זכות מספיק שיוושעו ישראל ואוציאם ממצרים ושאעשה להם נסים ואין כח לשום מקטרג לעכב ולקטרג עליהם, ואפשר דע"כ פרשיות אלו מסוגלין שיתקבל תשובה על חטא הידוע, דמתעורר כח הקריאה, וכמו שעשה השי"ת אז לפנים מן המידה בשביל כבוד שמו ית ', כן סגולת הימים האלו שיתקבל תשובתינו ונתקרב אליו ית ', אף שאין ידינו משגת לעשות תשובה גדולה כראוי לחטא זה, אבל מפני שבקשתינו רק למען שמך ד', ע"כ וסלחת לעוננו כי רב הוא וכנ"ל.
translation: And according to our path, the question (14) mentioned above, which Moshe Rabbeinu asked, "What merit did Israel have that a miracle would be done for them and they would be taken out of Egypt?" Even though Moshe Rabbeinu knew that they had merits, as explained in the words of our Sages and in the Zohar, nevertheless, Moshe Rabbeinu was concerned that the power of accusation might prevail over them, as indeed it was, when the Satan and the minister of Egypt accused them of idolatry, and perhaps their merits would not be sufficient to repel the power of accusation. How then would they merit to have a miracle done for them? To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "I have a great thing regarding this exodus." For they were destined to receive the Torah on this mountain at the end of three months after they left Egypt, as it is said, "When you bring the people out... you shall serve God on this mountain." In this response, there are two aspects: one, as it is said in the Zohar, that for good, the Holy One, Blessed be He, judges according to the end, and before Him, past and future are all one, and what is destined to be has already been. Thus, they immediately have the merit of receiving the Torah. According to our aforementioned path, there is another aspect in this: that through their exodus from Egypt, they will receive the Torah and uphold it in all generations, and the glory of Heaven will increase throughout all generations of Israel. Therefore, the benefit of their exodus is to increase the glory of Heaven, and from now on, their merit is great and sufficient to repel any accusation. This also resolves the question (15) mentioned above, where the Holy One, Blessed be He, further replied to Moshe, "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go..." and "I will stretch out My hand and strike Egypt with all My wonders..." And through the miracles and wonders, His glory will increase in the world, and all the nations will hear of His mighty deeds. This is a sufficient merit for Israel to be saved and taken out of Egypt and for miracles to be done for them, and no accuser has the power to delay or accuse them. It is possible that these sections are capable of receiving a response for the known sin, as the power of calling forth is awakened, and just as the Holy One, Blessed be He, acted then beyond the measure for the sake of His glory, so too, the merit of these days is that our repentance will be accepted and we will draw closer to Him, even though our hands are not capable of making a great repentance appropriate for this sin. But because our request is only for the sake of Your name, O Lord, therefore, "You will forgive our iniquity, for it is great," as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of the Israelites' redemption from Egypt, emphasizing that their future reception of the Torah grants them a profound merit that can counteract any accusations against them. It highlights that God's plan for the Israelites to receive the Torah shortly after their exodus serves as a justification for the miracles performed during their liberation, thereby increasing God's glory in the world. The text also suggests that the merit of the Torah and the resulting honor for God provide sufficient protection against any adversarial forces, allowing for the possibility of repentance even in the face of significant transgressions. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that sincere pleas for God's sake can lead to forgiveness, regardless of one's shortcomings.
