passage_content: ועתה בא נבוא לתרץ קושיא (י"ג) הנ"ל, באמרו ית ' למשה רבינו ע"ה ויאמר אלקים אל משה אקי' אשר אקי', ודרשו רז"ל אהי ' עמכם בצרה זו ואהי ' עמכם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , והיתכן ששאל משרע"ה קושיא לאלקינו כאמרם ז"ל שטען ואמר רבש"ע די' לצרה בשעתה, גם איך יתכן חזרה לפניו ית ', כאמרז"ל אמר לו הקב"ה יפה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם (עיין הקושיא לעיל ובדברי המפורשים ביתר ביאור), אמנם איכא למידק עוד דהנה טענתו של אדוננו משרע"ה היתה די' לצרה בשעתה, ולמה יודיעם הבוי"ת במוקדם ויצטערו ישראל מהידיעה לבד, ודיים בבוא זמנה, ולכאורה מבואר בגמ' סנהדרין (דף מ"ד ע"ב) להיפך, דתועלת גדול להקדים תפלה לצרה עד שלא תבוא, וז"ל א"ר אלעזר לעולם יקדים אדם תפלה לצרה, שאלמלא הקדים אברהם תפלה לצרה בין בית אל ובין העי, לא נשתייר מרשעי ישראל שריד ופליט, פרש"י שם דנלמד כן ממ"ש באיוב היערוך שועך לא בצר (איוב ל"ו), כך היו אומרים חביריו לאיוב. כלום הקדמת שועך (תפלה) לא בצר, עד לא באה הצרה, אם היית עושה כן היו הכל מאמצים את כוחך עכ"ל, ולכאורה לפי"ז מה היתה טענתו של משרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, שלא יודיעם ית ' גזירת מלכיות העתידה לבוא עליהם, והרי תועלת גדול יהי' במה שיודיעם, כדי שיקדמו להתפלל עליהם, כמבואר בגמ' בפירוש דיותר מועיל התפלה שמקדימים לפני הצרה, ובאמת כל הצרות מחבלי משיח אשר סבלו ישראל בשנים אחרונות ר"ל, הרבה דמעות נשפכו והרבה תפלות ובקשות התפללו ישראל בתוך צרתם, ואפשר דאלמלי היו יודעין כל זאת במוקדם, והיו מקדימין תפלה לצרה, אולי היינו נענים וניצולים, דמסגולת התפלה שתתקבל יותר כשמקדימין אותה לפני צרה שלא תבוא ועכ"פ מוסר השכל יש ללמוד מהגמרא הנ"ל, הן אמת שאנו מצפים ומקוים לחסדי השי"ת, שלא יבואו עלינו עוד כהנה וכיוצא בהנה , אבל אעפ"כ מי יודע מה צריך עוד לעבור מהנסיונות טרם ביאת משיח, וכו"כ מישראל עומדים לע"ע בסכנה גדולה בארבע פינות העולם השי"ת ישמרם ויצילם, ועכ"פ צריך להקדים תפלה לצרה, ולשפוך תחנונים לפני הבוי"ת שישמור את עמו ישראל, וננצל מכל צרה וצוקה ונזכה ונחי' ונראה פני משיח צדקינו כולנו חיים וקיימים הדרן לעניננו דא"כ מה היתה טענתו של משרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, והרי יותר טוב שיודיעם מצרה העתיד לבוא כדי שיתפללו.
translation: And now let us come to resolve the question (13) mentioned above, as He said to our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, "And God said to Moses, 'I will be that I will be.'" The sages interpreted this to mean, "I am with you in this trouble and I am with you in the servitude of other kingdoms." Is it possible that Moses, our teacher, questioned our God, as the sages said, that he argued and said, "Master of the Universe, it is enough for the trouble at the time," and how is it possible to return before Him, blessed be He, as the sages said, "God said to him, 'You have spoken well; thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be that I will be' has sent me to you'" (see the question above and in the words of the commentators in greater detail). However, one can further inquire: behold, the argument of our master Moses was that it is enough for the trouble at the time, and why should the Holy One, blessed be He, inform them in advance, causing Israel to suffer from the knowledge alone? It is enough when the time comes. And seemingly it is explained in the Gemara in Sanhedrin (page 44b) the opposite, that there is great benefit in praying in advance of trouble before it comes. As Rabbi Elazar said, "A person should always pray in advance of trouble, for had Abraham not prayed in advance of trouble between Bethel and Ai, not a remnant or survivor would have remained from the wicked of Israel." Rashi explains there that we learn this from what is written in Job, "Your cry will be arranged not in trouble" (Job 36:15), thus his friends were saying to Job. "Is it not the case that your cry (prayer) should be arranged not in trouble, before the trouble comes? If you had done so, everyone would have strengthened your power." According to this, what was Moses' argument that it is enough for the trouble at the time, that the Holy One, blessed be He, should not inform them of the decree of the future kingdoms that will come upon them? And behold, there would be great benefit in informing them, so that they would pray in advance for themselves, as is explained in the Gemara, that prayer is more effective when it is offered before the trouble. And indeed, all the troubles, the birth pangs of the Messiah, that Israel has suffered in recent years, may God have mercy, many tears have been shed and many prayers and requests have been prayed by Israel in their distress. And perhaps had they known all this in advance and had they prayed in advance for the trouble, maybe we would have been answered and saved, for it is a quality of prayer that it is accepted more when it is offered before trouble comes. And nevertheless, a moral lesson can be learned from the aforementioned Gemara. It is true that we are waiting and hoping for the mercies of the Holy One, blessed be He, that such things will not come upon us again, but who knows what else we must endure from trials before the coming of the Messiah? And so many from Israel are currently in great danger in the four corners of the world; may the Holy One, blessed be He, guard and save them. And nevertheless, we must pray in advance for the trouble and pour out supplications before the Holy One, blessed be He, that He should guard His people Israel, and we should be saved from every trouble and distress, and we should merit to live and see the face of our righteous Messiah, all of us alive and well. Returning to our matter, then what was Moses' argument that it is enough for the trouble at the time, when it would be better for Him to inform them of the future trouble so that they would pray?
summary: The passage discusses a theological tension regarding Moses' plea to God about informing the Israelites of future hardships. It highlights the Hasidic belief in the power of preemptive prayer, suggesting that knowing about impending troubles could motivate the Israelites to pray in advance, potentially averting suffering. The text emphasizes the importance of proactive supplication to God, especially in times of crisis, while also acknowledging the ongoing challenges faced by the Jewish people. Ultimately, it reflects a deep reliance on divine mercy and the necessity of prayer in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר ביאור הענין עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל ( בפ ' ויחי) עה"פ ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו', שפירושו אם תוליד עוד, וכתב המזרחי דבהכרח יתפרש מלת אשר הולדת אם תוליד שהוא מאמר מסופק, ולא כמשמעו שמלת אשר מורה על הודאי , שאילו הי' כמשמעו שהוליד עוד בנים חוץ ממנשה ואפרים, הי' מביא גם אותם לאביו כדי לברך אותם ואע"פ שלא מצאנו אשר במקום אם. אבל מאחר שמצינו אם במקום אשר וכו' יתכן לפרש גם מלת אשר במקום אם עכת"ד, ורבים מהמפורשים חלקו על פרש"י ז"ל ופי' אשר הולדת מלשון ודאי כמשמעו, וכן פי' הרד"ק והרמב"ן ז"ל, מבואר דפשטות משמעותו של מלת אשר הוא ודאי. אלא שלפעמים תשמש במקום אם וכמאמר מסופק כמשפרש"י וביאר הרא"ם ז"ל דבריו.
translation: And it is possible to explain the matter according to what Rashi, of blessed memory, said (in Parashat Vayechi) regarding the verse "and your birthplace, where you were born after them," that its meaning is if you will give birth again. And the Mizrachi wrote that it must be interpreted that the word "asher" (which means "which" or "that") in "asher holidat" (which means "that you gave birth") is a conditional statement, and not as it seems, that the word "asher" indicates certainty. For if it were as it seems, that he had given birth to more children besides Menashe and Ephraim, he would have brought them to his father to bless them, even though we do not find "asher" in the place of "if." However, since we find "if" in the place of "asher," it is possible to interpret the word "asher" in the place of "if," thus he concluded. And many of the commentators disagreed with Rashi, of blessed memory, and interpreted "asher holidat" in the sense of certainty, as it seems, and so did Radak and Ramban, of blessed memory, clarify that the straightforward meaning of the word "asher" is indeed certainty. However, at times it can serve in the place of "if" and as a conditional statement, as Rashi explained, and the Ra'ah, of blessed memory, clarified his words.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the Hebrew word "אשר" (asher) in the context of a biblical verse, suggesting that it can mean "if" rather than "that," indicating a conditional or uncertain statement. This interpretation aligns with the idea that the future is not predetermined, reflecting a Hasidic belief in the dynamic nature of divine providence and human agency. The text highlights the tension between certainty and possibility in theological discourse, emphasizing the importance of interpretation in understanding scripture. Ultimately, it illustrates the complexity of language in conveying deeper spiritual truths.

passage_content: ומעתה אפ"ל דהבוי"ת אמר למשה אקי' אשר אקי' ויאמר כה תאמר אל בנ"י וכו' וכדרשתם ז"ל אשר אהי ' עמכם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , אמנם מלת אשר יתפרש כאן כמאמר מסופק ובמקום אם, דלא הי' גזירת הגליות מוחלטת ודאי, ומילתא דתליא בבחירה הוא, כאמרז"ל במדרש דאילו זכו ישראל היו נגאלו ממצרים גאולה נצחיית שאין אחרי' גלות עוד, אלא לפי שלא זכו היתה רק גאולה לשעה והוצרכו להשלים עוד בשאר גליות, ואמר הקב"ה למשה להודיעם על דרך האפשרות, שאם לא יזכו יסבלו עוד שעבוד בשאר מלכיות : ואהי ' עמהם גם שם להצילם, והודעה זו יש בה תועלת וצורך גדול, שעי"ז ייטיבו ויתקנו מעשיהם ולא יצטרכו לגלות עוד כמבואר במדרש הנ"ל, גם תועלת גדול בו כדי שיקדימו תפלה לצרה כמבואר בגמ' דסנהדרין הנ"ל, דבאופן זו התפלה מסוגלת יותר להתקבל, והבוי"ת ישמע בקול תפלתם להקל מעליהם עול שעבוד הגלות.
translation: And from now on, it can be said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "I will be that I will be," and He said, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel," etc. And as you have interpreted, may their memory be for a blessing, that I will be with you during the servitude of other kingdoms. However, the word "that" should be interpreted here as a statement of uncertainty and in place of "if," for the decree of the exiles was not absolute and certain, and it is a matter that depends on choice, as our sages have said in the Midrash that if Israel had merited, they would have been redeemed from Egypt with an eternal redemption, with no exile afterward. But since they did not merit, it was only a temporary redemption, and they needed to complete it through other exiles. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses to inform them of the possibility that if they do not merit, they will suffer further servitude in other kingdoms: "And I will be with them there to save them." This notification has great benefit and necessity, for through it they will improve and rectify their deeds and will not need to go into exile again, as explained in the aforementioned Midrash. There is also great benefit in it so that they will precede prayer in times of trouble, as explained in the Gemara in Sanhedrin, for in this way the prayer is more capable of being accepted, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, will hear their prayer to lighten the burden of the servitude of exile from them.
summary: The passage discusses the divine message given to Moses, emphasizing that the phrase "I will be" can be interpreted as conditional, suggesting that the Israelites' redemption from Egypt was not predetermined but dependent on their merit. If they had been worthy, their redemption would have been eternal, free from further exiles. However, due to their shortcomings, they experienced a temporary redemption, necessitating future exiles. The text highlights the importance of repentance and prayer, indicating that sincere supplication can lead to divine intervention and relief from the burdens of exile.

passage_content: ואפשר דמשה רבינו הבין דמלת אשר הוא ודאי ומאמר מוחלט כפירושו בכל מקום, ע"כ שאל לפניו ית ' רבש"ע די' לצרה בשעתה. דהן אמת שתועלת להודיעם כדי שיקדימו תפלה לצרה. אבל יספיק להודיעם ע"צ האפשרות, ולמה אודיעם שהגזירה מוחלטת ויצטערו בחנם, דיים שיצטערו בשעתה, והרי עדיין תליא בבחירה וכנ"ל, וע"ז השיב לו הבוי"ת יפה אמרת כה תאמר אל בני ישראל אקי' שלחני אליכם, ואין זה כחזרה בדבריו ית ' הראשונים אלא ביאר לו כוונתו, שלמאמר מוחלט לא יאמר רק אקי' שלחני אליכם, שפירושו אהי ' עמכם בצרה זו, אבל אה"נ שיאמר גם כציווי הראשון אקי' אשר אקי', ויתפרש מלת אשר מלשון אם, ואינו מאמר מוחלט ויש עוד מציאות להנצל ממנה אם יזכו, אבל הצורך להודיעם בהקדם כדי שיקדימו תפלה לצרה כנ"ל, נמצא שאין כאן חזרה ושינוי רצון כלל, וב' המאמרים קיימים, והראשון אמרה ית ' ע"ד האפשרות כדי שיקדימו תפלה לצרה, והשני נאמרה על צד הודאית , וע"כ כתיב ב"פ ויאמר לפי שהם ב' מימרות, ושניהם צוהו הבוי"ת לאמרה לישראל, וז"ש לו יפה דברת שגם אני לא כוונתי למאמר מוחלט אלא ע"צ האפשרות כנ"ל.
translation: And it is possible that Moshe Rabbeinu understood that the word "which" is certainly and absolutely a statement as it is interpreted everywhere. Therefore, he asked before Him, Blessed be He, to inform them of the decree at the time of trouble. Indeed, it is true that there is a benefit in informing them so that they will precede with prayer for the trouble. But it would suffice to inform them in terms of possibility, and why should I inform them that the decree is absolute and they will suffer in vain? It is enough that they will suffer at the time, and it is still dependent on choice, as mentioned above. And to this, the Blessed One responded to him, "You have spoken well; thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will send you to them.'" This is not a contradiction to His earlier words, but rather He clarified His intention, that an absolute statement should only be said as "I will send you to them," which means "I am with you in this trouble." However, it is also true that He can say as in the first command, "I will be that which I will be," and the word "which" can be interpreted in the sense of "if," and it is not an absolute statement, and there is still a possibility to be saved from it if they merit. But the necessity to inform them in advance so that they will precede with prayer for the trouble, as mentioned above, shows that there is no contradiction or change of will at all, and both statements exist. The first was said by the Blessed One in terms of possibility so that they would precede with prayer for the trouble, and the second was said in terms of certainty. Therefore, it is written twice, "And He said," because they are two statements, and both were commanded by the Blessed One to be said to Israel. And this is what He said to him, "You have spoken well," that my intention was also not for an absolute statement but in terms of possibility, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between absolute and conditional statements in the context of divine communication, particularly regarding Moses' understanding of God's messages. It emphasizes that while God may convey a seemingly absolute decree, there remains the possibility of change based on human actions, such as prayer. Moses is instructed to communicate this duality to the Israelites, highlighting that their response can influence their fate. Thus, both the absolute and conditional aspects coexist, reflecting the interplay between divine will and human agency.

passage_content: ויאמר עוד אלקים אל משה כה תאמר אל בנ"י , ד' אלקי אבותיכם אלקי אברהם אלקי יצחק ואלקי יעקב שלחני אליכם, והודיעו ית ' שפעמים לא יהי' להם זכות עצמי ויזכירו בתפלתם זכות אבות, גם הודיעם ית ' זה שמי לעלם ודרשו ז"ל העלימהו לא כשם שאני נכתב אני נקרא, וזה זכרי לדר דר שתלוי כפי בחי' הדור, ולעתיד יהי' השם נקרא ככתיבתו. וגם במקדש היו קורין כן, עכ"פ גם זו היתה הודעה שישתנו בחי' הדורות בכמה מיני בחי', ורמז להם החורבן והגלות והגאולה עתידה, וכ"ז כדי שיקדימו תפלה לצרה כמו שביארנו לעיל, ובזה יבואר הענין קצת וכל המאמרים צדקו יחדיו.
translation: And God said further to Moses, "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.' And He informed them that sometimes they will not have their own merit and they should mention in their prayers the merit of the fathers. He also informed them that this is My name forever, and our sages have taught that it is hidden; not as I am written, I am called. And this is My remembrance from generation to generation, which is dependent on the quality of the generation. In the future, the name will be called as it is written. And also in the Temple, they would read it this way. At the very least, this was also a notification that the qualities of the generations would change in various ways, and He hinted to them about the destruction, the exile, and the future redemption. All this is so that they should precede prayer for trouble, as we have explained above, and in this, the matter will be somewhat clarified, and all the sayings are justified together.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes the importance of invoking the merit of the Patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—especially when individuals lack personal merit. It highlights the concept that God's name and its significance evolve with each generation, reflecting the changing spiritual state of the Jewish people. The text also alludes to the themes of destruction, exile, and future redemption, urging the community to engage in prayer in anticipation of challenges, thereby reinforcing the interconnectedness of faith, history, and divine providence.

passage_content: ועפ"י בחי' הנ"ל נבאר פרשת המילדות להסיר הדקדוקים שבענין הנ"ל, ולכאורה איכא למידק עוד דמאמר כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות מיותר לגמרי, ויספיק בעיקר טענתם כי חיות הנה בטרם תבא המילדת וילדו, ומהו הכוונה באמרם כי לא כנשים המצריות וגו', אמנם נראה כי הם לא הכחישו עצם הענין , לומר דעל כי חיות הנה א"צ למילדות כלל, דודאי הי"ל טבע אנשים והי' להם מילדות, דאל"כ למה לא השיבו כן לפרעה מתחלת הגזירה כקושיתינו הנ"ל (קושיא ט'), אולם טענתם הי' לפני פרעה, הן אמת שיש להם טבע אנשים וצריכין מילדות, אבל כו חיות הנה וכפי' התרגום אונקלס ארי חכימין אינון, איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, ויודעים מהסכנה הגדולה האורב עליהם ע"י גזירת המלך להמית את בניהם, ע"כ הם מקדימים תפלה לצרה, והקב"ה עושה להם נסים ומולידים בשלום טרם תבוא אליהם המילדת , ואין בידינו לקיים גזירתך וכוונה זו מבואר ג"כ בפי' תרגום יוב"ע , ארום לא כנשיא מצריתא יהודייתא , ארום זריזין וחכימין הינון. קדם עד לא תיתי לוותהון חייתא הינון תליין עיניהון בצלוי מצלן ובעיין רחמין מן קדם אבוהן דבשמיא , והוא שמע בקול צלותהון , מן יד הינון מתעניין וילידן ופרקן בשלם.
translation: According to the above explanation, we will elucidate the section of the midwives to remove the nuances regarding the aforementioned matter. At first glance, one might further inquire why the statement "for they are not like the Egyptian women" is entirely superfluous. It would suffice for their main argument that they are alive before the midwife comes and gives birth. What is the intention behind their saying "for they are not like the Egyptian women," however, it seems that they did not deny the essence of the matter, to say that since they are alive, there is no need for midwives at all. Certainly, they would have had the nature of women and would have needed midwives; otherwise, why did they not respond to Pharaoh in this manner from the beginning of the decree, as per our previous question (question 5)? However, their argument was before Pharaoh. It is true that they have the nature of women and need midwives, but the intention is that they are alive, and according to the translation of Onkelos, "for they are wise," which means that a wise person sees what is born and knows of the great danger that lurks upon them due to the king's decree to kill their sons. Therefore, they precede prayer to trouble, and the Holy One, blessed be He, performs miracles for them and they give birth in peace before the midwife comes to them. And we cannot fulfill your decree, and this intention is also clarified in the translation of Yov"an, "for they are not like the Egyptian Jewish women," for they are swift and wise. They precede their cries with prayer and their eyes are directed in supplication before their Father in Heaven, and He hears their voice, and from His hand they are concerned and give birth and are delivered in peace.
summary: The passage discusses the Hebrew midwives' response to Pharaoh, emphasizing their wisdom and spiritual insight. They assert that, unlike Egyptian women, they are able to give birth before the midwives arrive due to their deep faith and prayer, which invokes divine intervention. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that true wisdom lies in recognizing the spiritual dimensions of life and the power of prayer to transcend natural limitations. Ultimately, their actions demonstrate a profound trust in God, who protects them and their children from the decree against them.

passage_content: ועל דרך זה אפשר לפרש ג"כ דרשת חז"ל בסוטה (דף י"א ע"ב) כי חיות הנה, אמרו לו אומה זו כחי' נמשלה יהודה גור ארי' בנימין זאב יטרף , וכתיב מה אמך לביאה וכנס"י נמשלה ללביא, ואפשר הכוונה עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל ( בפ ' בלק) עה"פ הן עם כלביא יקום וכארי יתנשא וגו' כשהן עומדין משינתם שחרית, הן מתגברין כלביא וכארי לחטוף את המצות ללבוש ציצית לקרוא את שמע ולהניח תפילין, והאוהחה"ק פי' ( בפ ' ויחי) עה"פ בנימין זאב יטרף , נתכוין אל שאול שעשה מעשה זאב שטורף במהירות וכו ', כמו"כ עשה הוא ולא המתין לזמן שקבע לו שמואל אלא מיהר לטרוף את עמלק וכו ', מבואר דענין הנמשל שנמשלו ישראל לחיות, הוא על שחוטפין וממהרין בקיומן של מצות.
translation: And in this way, it is also possible to interpret the teaching of our Sages in Sotah (11b) that the nations are like beasts. They said to him, "This nation is like a lion; Judah is compared to a lion cub, Benjamin is a wolf that tears." And it is written, "What is your mother like a lioness?" and the congregation of Israel is compared to a lion. It is possible that the intention is according to what Rashi, of blessed memory, explains (in Parashat Balak) on the verse, "Behold, a people rises up like a lion and like a lioness it lifts itself up," that when they stand from their sleep in the morning, they are strengthened like a lion and a lioness to seize the commandments, to wear tzitzit, to recite the Shema, and to put on tefillin. And the holy Zohar explains (in Parashat Vayechi) on the verse, "Benjamin is a wolf that tears," that it refers to Saul, who acted like a wolf that tears swiftly, etc. Likewise, he acted and did not wait for the time set for him by Samuel, but hurried to seize Amalek, etc. It is clear that the matter of the parable, in which Israel is compared to beasts, is because they are quick and hasty in fulfilling the commandments.
summary: The passage discusses the metaphor of Israel being compared to wild animals, specifically the lion and the wolf, to illustrate their fervor in fulfilling commandments. It highlights the idea that just as these animals are swift and powerful, so too are the Jewish people in their commitment to observe mitzvot, such as wearing tzitzit and praying. The reference to King Saul's hasty actions serves as a parallel, emphasizing the urgency and dedication with which the Jewish people approach their religious duties. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of Jewish identity and the imperative to act swiftly in spiritual matters.

passage_content: ובדרך אגב אזכיר מה שיש לדקדק לכאורה בדברי רש"י ז"ל שהקדים לקרוא את שמע ואח"כ להניח תפילין, והרי אמרז"ל במס' ברכות (י"ד ע"ב) כל הקורא ק"ש בלא תפילין כאילו מעיד עדות שקר בעצמו, וכתבו התוס ' שם דעיקר ק"ש ותפלה שייכי בתפילין, דאל"כ ה"ה מעיד עדות שקר וכו' שהוא קורא והיו לטוטפות ולאות על ידך ואין לו, וכן פסק המחבר (בסי' כ"ה ס"ד) צריך שיהיו תפילין עליו בשעת ק"ש ותפלה עיי"ש, אלא שכתב הלבוש דבדיעבד אינו מעכב זא"ז , ואין לו לאחר זמן ק"ש בשביל ציצית ותפילין, דיל"פ בדברי הגמ ' דאינו כמעיד עדות שקר, רק אם אין מניח תפילין כלל, אבל אם מניחם אח"כ לית לן בה, אבל לד"ה לכתחילה ראוי להקדים תפילין ואח"כ ק"ש, ומ"ט נקט רש"י ז"ל בלשונו להקדים ק"ש ואח"כ תפילין, ובפשטות אפ"ל דלפי שחוטפין המצות מיד כשעומדין משינתם, יכול להיות שעדיין אינו מוכן וראוי להניח תפילין שאין לו גוף נקי עדיין, ע"כ מקדים לקרוא ק"ש טרם יעבור זמנה ואח"כ מניח תפילין, אולם נרמז עוד דברים בגו עפי"מ שביארנו בספרי עה"ג ועה"ת (סי' נ"ח) גודל קדושת תפילין והזהירות שצ"ל בהנחתן, וכתב הב"י ( באו"ח סי' ל"ח) באותן הבחורים אשר מהרהרים ר"ל, דיש לכופם בדברים ולמשוך לבם ליר"ש וכו' ויפנו לבם לקבל עליהם עול מלכות שמים, (עיי"ש בספרי שהארכנו בזה), ומבואר במתני' דברכות (י"ג ע"א) אר"י בן קרחה למה קדמה פרשת שמע לפ ' והי' אם שמוע, כדי שיקבל עליו עול מ"ש תחלה ואח"כ מקבל עליו עול מצות, מבואר דקבלת עמ"ש צריך שיקדים לכל המצות, ומכ"ש למצות תפילין שהם עדות ואות לקבלת מלכותו ית ' עלינו, וידוע מהה"ק מרן בעל דברי חיים זלל"ה כשהי' עומד ממטתו אפי' בלילה קרא ק"ש מיד, ואע"פ שלא הי' זמנה לצאת ידי חובה, אבל קרא ע"ש קבלת עמ"ש , ואפשר שזה נרמז בדברי רש"י ז"ל, ובכוונה שינה הסדר במ"ש דכשהן עומדים משינתם שחרית חוטפין מצות קורין ק"ש ומניחין תפילין, דמקבלין עליהם עול מ"ש תחלה מיד בקומם משינתם, ואה"נ דאח"כ קורין עוה"פ ק"ש בתפילין כדינו לכתחילה, אלא דק"ש ראשונה משום קבלת עול מלכות שמים הוא.
translation: And incidentally, I will mention what seems to require scrutiny in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, who preceded the reading of Shema and afterwards put on tefillin. Yet our sages have said in Berakhot (14b) that anyone who recites Shema without tefillin is as if he is bearing false witness against himself. The Tosafot there wrote that the essence of Shema and prayer is connected to tefillin, for otherwise he is indeed bearing false witness, since he is reading and they are to be for frontlets between his eyes and as a sign on his hand, and he does not have them. And the Shulchan Aruch ruled (in Siman 25, Sif 4) that one must have tefillin on during the recitation of Shema and prayer, as stated there. However, the Levush wrote that post-factum, they do not prevent each other, and one should not delay the recitation of Shema for the sake of tzitzit and tefillin, for it can be explained in the words of the Gemara that it is not like bearing false witness, only if he does not put on tefillin at all. But if he puts them on afterwards, we have no issue with that. However, according to the law, it is preferable to put on tefillin first and then recite Shema. And why did Rashi, may his memory be blessed, use the wording to precede Shema and then tefillin? It can simply be said that since they seize the mitzvot immediately upon rising from their sleep, it could be that he is still not prepared and fit to put on tefillin, as he does not yet have a clean body. Therefore, he precedes the recitation of Shema before its time passes and afterwards puts on tefillin. However, there are hinted further matters in this, as we have explained in our books on the Holy Torah (Siman 58) regarding the great sanctity of tefillin and the caution that must be taken in their placement. And the Beit Yosef (in Orach Chaim, Siman 38) wrote about those young men who have thoughts of distraction, that they should be compelled with words and draw their hearts to fear of Heaven, etc., and they should direct their hearts to accept upon themselves the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven (see there in my books where we elaborated on this). It is explained in the Mishnah of Berakhot (13a) that Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai asked why the section of Shema precedes the section of "And it shall be, if you hearken," in order that one accepts upon himself the yoke of His word first and afterwards accepts upon himself the yoke of the commandments. It is clear that the acceptance of His word must precede all the commandments, and certainly the commandments of tefillin, which are a testimony and a sign of the acceptance of His sovereignty upon us. It is known from the holy Rabbi, the author of Divrei Chaim, may his memory be blessed, that when he would rise from his bed, even at night, he would recite Shema immediately, even though it was not the time to fulfill the obligation, but he recited it for the sake of accepting His word. And it is possible that this is hinted at in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, and intentionally he changed the order in saying that when they rise from their sleep in the morning, they seize the mitzvot, reciting Shema and putting on tefillin, for they accept upon themselves the yoke of His word immediately upon rising from their sleep. And certainly afterwards they recite the Shema with tefillin as is proper, but the first recitation of Shema is for the acceptance of the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven.
summary: The passage discusses the order of reciting the Shema and donning tefillin, emphasizing the importance of accepting the yoke of Heaven before fulfilling commandments. It highlights that while ideally one should put on tefillin before reciting the Shema, the urgency of accepting God's sovereignty takes precedence, especially upon waking. The text also reflects on the sanctity of tefillin and the need for purity when wearing them, suggesting that the initial recitation of the Shema serves as a declaration of faith and commitment to divine authority. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of intention and readiness in performing mitzvot.

passage_content: עכ"פ מבואר בדברי רש"י ז"ל דמה שנמשלו ישראל לחיות, הוא מפני שחוטפין מצות וממהרין לקבל עליהם עומ"ש , ויש בהם מידה זו של חטיפה על צד הטובה ולעבדות השי"ת, וז"ש המילדות כי חיות הנה ואמרז"ל בסוטה (י"א ע"ב) אומה זו לחי' נמשלה מה אמך לביאה וכו ', שחוטפין מצות ופונים אל אביהם שבשמים ומתפללין אליו טרם תבוא הצרה כמ"ש היערוך שועך לא בצר, וע"כ המה נושעים והקב"ה עושה להם נסים וניצולים מגזרתך, ובטרם תבוא אליהם המילדת וילדו, וזה שהקדימו לומר כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות דגם הגוים מתפללין כשהן בצרה כבר, אבל העבריות לא כן המה, אלא בטרם תבוא אליהם המילדת המה מתפללין ופונים אל אביהם שבשמים כי חיות הנה, וכל הפירושים בזה כוונה אחת להם, הן מה שדרשו רז"ל דמשולים לחיות, וכן מ"ש הת"א ארי חכימין אינון איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, וכן מ"ש התרגום יוב"ע דתליין עיניהון בצלוי מצלן ובעיין רחמין מן אבוהון דבשמיא וכו ', תוכן המכוון בכולן דמקדימין תפלה לצרה ובזכות זה נושעים, ואפשר דע"כ נקראו בלשון חז"ל המילדות חכמה, דבימי חכמי המשנה מילדות ישראל צדיקות היו, וידעו דמפתח של חי' בידו של הקב"ה ולא נמסרו לשליח, ותלו עיניהם להקב"ה בתפלה שיצליחו וע"כ קראוהו חז"ל חכמה, ובזה יבואר ג"כ פי' הראשון שברש"י ז"ל כי חיות הנה בקיאות כמילדות , שיש בהם מידה זו של מילדות ותולים עיניהם למרום בתפלה, והקב"ה מושיע אותן, ובזה סרו כל הדקדוקים בענין המילדות והבן.
translation: Nevertheless, it is explained in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that the reason Israel is compared to animals is because they seize commandments and are quick to accept upon themselves the yoke of Heaven. They possess this quality of seizing in a positive sense, to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He. This is what the midwives said, "For they are lively," and our sages of blessed memory said in Sotah (11b), "This nation is compared to animals; just as your mother is to a lioness," etc. They seize commandments and turn to their Father in Heaven, praying to Him before the distress comes, as it is written, "Prepare your cry not in distress." Therefore, they are saved, and the Holy One, Blessed be He performs miracles for them and rescues them from your decree, and before the midwife comes to them, they give birth. This is why it is stated that they are not like the Egyptian women; the Hebrew women, too, pray when they are in distress already, but the Hebrew women are not so. Rather, before the midwife comes to them, they pray and turn to their Father in Heaven because they are lively. All interpretations of this have one intention: both what our sages of blessed memory have said about them being compared to animals, and also what the Targum says, "The wise ones are those who see the future," and likewise what the translation says, "They raise their eyes in prayer and seek mercy from their Father in Heaven," etc. The essence intended in all of them is that they precede prayer to distress, and by virtue of this, they are saved. It is possible that this is why the midwives are referred to in the language of our sages as wisdom, for in the days of the sages of the Mishnah, the midwives of Israel were righteous women, and they knew that the key to life is in the hand of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and it was not given to an agent. They directed their eyes to the Holy One, Blessed be He, in prayer that they should succeed, and therefore our sages of blessed memory called Him wisdom. This also explains the first interpretation in Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that "they are lively" refers to their expertise like midwives, as they possess this quality of midwifery and direct their eyes upward in prayer, and the Holy One, Blessed be He saves them. In this way, all the nuances regarding the midwives are clarified, and understand.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unique spiritual quality of the Jewish people, likening them to animals that swiftly seize opportunities for mitzvot and turn to God in prayer before crises arise. This proactive approach to prayer is contrasted with that of other nations, highlighting the belief that their faith and reliance on God lead to miraculous salvations. The midwives are described as wise, recognizing that the key to life is in God's hands, and their prayers reflect a deep connection to divine assistance. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of preemptive prayer and faith in God's salvation as central tenets of Jewish belief.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לתרץ קושית המהרש"א והמפורשים ז"ל שהבאנו לעיל (קושיא א' ב' וג') בענין גזירת כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו, דמבואר במדרשי חז"ל שהי' סיבת גזירתם מתחילה משום פן ירבה, וסמכו על סברת מדה כנגד מדה שלא יפרע הקב"ה מהם, דכבר נשבע שלא יביא מבול לעולם, ומדוע אח"כ חזרו מהאי סברא , דמבואר בגמ' סוטה (י"ב) ובמד"ר (סי' כ"ד) דהגזירה הי' בשביל האצטגנינים שאמרו היום נולד מושיען של ישראל וכו' וסופו ללקות במים, גם איך לא נתייראו בגזירת המילדות שיענשו מדה כנגד מדה בחרב או בחנק כקושית היפ"ת לעיל, ויתבאר כל הענין בהקדם דברי המד"ר שהבאנו לעיל ויקם מלך חדש אשר לא ידע את יוסף, וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, א"ר אבין משל לאחד שרגם אוהבו של מלך אמר המלך התיזו את ראשו כי למחר יעשה בי כך, לכך כתב עליו המקרא, כלומר היום אשר לא ידע את יוסף למחר הוא עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד', ולכאורה צ"ב ענין המשל ומ"ש למחר הוא עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד', ומאן יימר דעכשיו האמין וידע את ד', ואיך יתכן שהאמין אחרי שהרע והיצר לישראל כ"כ וגזר כל הבן הילוד וגו', אמנם מוכרח ומבואר מדרז"ל שבתחילת הגזירה אף שהרשיע כ"כ עם ישראל בהבה נתחכמה פן ירבה וגו'. מ"מ האמין בסיבה ראשונה ובשכר ועונש, והראי' שביקש עצות ואמר נתחכמה למושיען של ישראל שלא יפרע הקב"ה מהם ומבואר במדרש שהיו יודעין שאין הקב"ה משלם אלא מדה כנגד מדה עיי"ש, ואי לאו שהאמין בזה הי"ל הרבה עצות לאבדם, ולא הי' צריך לגזירת המים דוקא .
translation: And now we will come to explain the question of the Maharsha and the commentators, as we brought above (question 1, 2, and 3) regarding the decree "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river." It is explained in the Midrashim of our Sages that the reason for their decree was initially out of fear that the Israelites would multiply, and they relied on the principle of measure for measure, that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not take revenge on them, for He had already sworn not to bring a flood upon the world. And why then did they later abandon this reasoning? It is explained in the Gemara in Sotah (12) and in the Midrash (section 24) that the decree was because of the astrologers who said, "Today, the savior of Israel is born," and that he would ultimately be punished by water. Also, how did they not fear the decree against the midwives that they would be punished measure for measure by sword or strangulation, as the question of the Yefeh Toar above? The entire matter will be clarified by first addressing the words of the Midrash that we brought above: "And a new king arose who did not know Joseph." And was he not familiar with Joseph? Rabbi Avin said, "This is comparable to someone who killed the beloved of the king. The king said, 'Behead him, for tomorrow he will do the same to me.'" Therefore, the verse states about him, meaning "Today, he who did not know Joseph, tomorrow he is destined to say, 'I do not know the Lord.'" And at first glance, the matter of the parable and what is meant by "tomorrow he is destined to say, 'I do not know the Lord,'" is puzzling. Who can say that now he believed and knew the Lord? And how is it possible that he believed after he had done so much evil and caused such suffering to Israel, decreeing that every son that is born should be cast into the river? However, it is necessary and clear from the Midrash that at the beginning of the decree, even though he was so wicked towards Israel, he still reasoned, "Let us be cunning, lest they multiply," etc. Nevertheless, he believed in the initial cause and in reward and punishment, and the proof is that he sought counsel and said, "Let us be cunning against the savior of Israel, so that the Holy One, blessed be He, will not take revenge on them." It is explained in the Midrash that they knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, only pays back measure for measure, as stated there. And if he did not believe this, he would have had many counsels to destroy them, and he would not have needed the decree of the waters specifically.
summary: The passage discusses the rationale behind Pharaoh's decree to drown all newborn Hebrew boys, highlighting the belief in divine justice and the principle of measure for measure (midah k'neged midah). Initially, Pharaoh feared the Israelites would multiply and sought to prevent this by invoking a divine retribution he believed would not occur due to God's promise not to flood the world again. However, as the decree evolved, it was influenced by astrologers who predicted the birth of a savior for Israel, leading Pharaoh to act against his earlier convictions. The text emphasizes the tension between Pharaoh's acknowledgment of divine principles and his subsequent actions, illustrating the complexity of faith and the consequences of moral choices.

passage_content: ואמרז"ל במד"ר (פ"א ס"ח) שמתחלה לא הסכים פרעה אל המצריים להזדווג לישראל, והורידוהו מכסאו ג' חדשים, עד שא"ל כל מה שאתם רוצים הריני עמכם והשיבו אותו, ואפשר דאף אחר שהסכים לעצתם לגזור גזירות רעות על ישראל, עדיין האמין בד' ומתחילה עשה עמהם מחמת יראה, אבל הי' ירא גם מד', וע"כ חיפש עצות איך להפטר מהעונש, ונתייעץ לדונם במים כאמרז"ל , אמנם אחר שנתרגל במעשה רשעתו , נמשך אחר המינות ואפיקורסת , ולבסוף כפר בד' ולא האמין כלל, כמ"ש מי ד' אשר אשמע בקולו לא ידעתי את ד', וכן הוא דרך הרשעים בכל הדורות כמ"ש המהר"י ששפורט שבזמן הש"ץ ימ"ש היו הרבה שמתחלה לא היו מאמינים בו, ורק מיראת העם הראו לו פנים, ולבסוף נמשכו אחריו לגמרי ונפלו ברשתו, וכמוהו אנו רואים בזמננו בעוה"ר באותן הנמשכים אחרי הע"ז של מלכות המינות, הרבה מהם עושים מתחילה רק מיראת העם ולבם בל עמם, ואח"כ הטבע מחייבת שיצדיקו את מעשיהם בעיני עצמם, דאין אדם עושה עצמו רשע, עד שנהפך לבם בקרבם ונעשים כופרים כמותם ר"ל, וז"ש במד"ר הנ"ל אשר לא ידע את יוסף וכי לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, ובודאי הי' מכיר אותו, אלא דהו' דמי לי' כאילו לא ידע את יוסף כלל, ולא הי' אצלו חסרון ידיעה אלא העלמת ידיעה, ודימה בעצמו להתנכר כאילו לא ידע, אמר הקב"ה היום לא ידע את יוסף, למחר הוא עתיד לומר לא ידעתי את ד' ואף שעכשיו עדיין הי' מאמין בסיבה ראשונה ושכר ועונש כנ"ל, אבל כן דרך הרשעים הולכים מדחי אל דחי עד שכופרים לגמרי באלקות ר"ל.
translation: And our sages said in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 68) that initially Pharaoh did not agree for the Egyptians to intermarry with Israel, and they removed him from his throne for three months, until he said to them, "Whatever you want, I am with you." They responded to him, and it is possible that even after he agreed to their counsel to decree evil decrees upon Israel, he still believed in God and initially acted with them out of fear, but he was also afraid of God. Therefore, he sought counsel on how to escape punishment, and he consulted to drown them in water, as our sages said. However, after he became accustomed to his wicked deeds, he was drawn after heresy and denial, and in the end, he denied God and did not believe at all, as it is said, "Who is the Lord that I should heed His voice? I do not know the Lord." And thus is the way of the wicked in all generations, as the Mahari Shaprot said that in the time of the wicked Shatz, there were many who at first did not believe in him, and only out of fear of the people did they show him favor, and in the end, they were completely drawn after him and fell into his net. And we see the same in our time, woe to us, with those who are drawn after the idolatry of the kingdom of heresy; many of them initially act only out of fear of the people, while their hearts are not with them, and then nature compels them to justify their actions in their own eyes, for no person makes himself wicked until their hearts are turned within them and they become deniers like them, heaven forbid. And this is what is said in the aforementioned Midrash, "And he did not know Joseph," and was it that he did not recognize Joseph? Certainly, he recognized him, but he was like one who did not know Joseph at all. There was not a lack of knowledge on his part, but rather a concealment of knowledge, and he imagined to himself to act as if he did not know. God said, "Today he does not know Joseph; tomorrow he will say, 'I do not know the Lord.'" And even though at that time he still believed in the first cause and in reward and punishment, as mentioned, this is indeed the way of the wicked, who go from one downfall to another until they completely deny divinity, heaven forbid.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's initial reluctance to oppress the Israelites, driven by fear of God, but eventually succumbing to evil and disbelief. It illustrates a progression from fear to outright denial of God, reflecting a common pattern among the wicked throughout history. The text emphasizes that individuals often begin their actions out of societal pressure, but over time, they rationalize their behavior and become fully entrenched in heresy. Ultimately, this leads to a complete rejection of divine authority, as exemplified by Pharaoh's eventual claim of ignorance regarding God.

passage_content: ובזה יתורצו כל הקושיות הנ"ל דמתחלה היתה הגזירה מטעם פן ירבה, וסמכו שלא יפרע הקב"ה מהם במים, לפי שידעו שאין הקב"ה משלם אלא מדה כנגד מדה, ובגזירת המילדות כתבו המפורשים שסמכו שלא יפרע הקב"ה מהם, דאין שליח לדבר עבירה, וע"כ גזר פרעה על המילדות העבריות להמית את הבנים, וחשב שלא יגיע העונש על המצריים, לפי שלא עשו בעצמן כלום, אמנם המשיך בדרך זה רק כל זמן שהאמין בבורא יתברך אבל אחר שנתרגל ברשעתו וכפר בו יתברך, ביטל גזירת כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו, דלא הוצרך עוד לעצה זו דמידה כנגד מידה ולא האמין בו, גם גזירת המילדות נתבטלה , ולא היו מתייראין עוד להרוג ילדי ישראל במו ידיהם, כמבואר בדרז"ל שהיו רומסין אותם בטיט ושקעום בבנין , ובגמ' סוטה (י"א ע"ב) שהיו נשי ישראל הולכות ויולדות בשדה, וכיון שמכירין בהם המצריים באו להורגן, ונעשה להם נס ונבלעין בקרקע והביאו המצריים שוורים וחורשין על גבן וכו' אלא שהצילם הקב"ה עיי"ש, עכ"פ לא חששו עוד לסברת מדה כנגד מדה לדונם במים דוקא , וע"כ נתבטלה אז גזירת כל הבן הילוד: וביקשו להרוג אותם בכל מיני מיתות שיכלו להשיג, ואח"כ נתחדש עוה"פ גזירת כל הבן הילוד לטעם שאמרו האצטגנינים היום נולד מושיען של ישראל ועתיד ללקות במים, ובזה מתורץ קושית המהרש"א על רש"י ז"ל (עיין לעיל קושיא ג'), ואחר שנולד משה אמרו האצטגנינים כבר נולד והוא כמוס מעינינו, א"ל פרעה מכאן ואילך אל תשליכו את הילדים ונתבטלה הגזירה, וגזירה הראשונה כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו, שסמכו על סברת מדה כנגד מדה כבר נתבטלה מקודם כנ"ל, ובזה יבואר סתירת המאמרים בדברי רז"ל וטעם שינוי הגזירות (עיין לעיל קושיא ד').
translation: And with this, all the aforementioned questions are resolved, for initially the decree was due to the fear of increase, and they relied on the fact that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not punish them with water, since they knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, pays back measure for measure. And regarding the decree of the midwives, the commentators wrote that they relied on the fact that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not punish them, for there is no messenger for a transgression. Therefore, Pharaoh decreed upon the Hebrew midwives to kill the boys, thinking that the punishment would not reach the Egyptians, since they themselves did nothing. However, he continued in this way only as long as he believed in the Creator, blessed be He, but after he became accustomed to his wickedness and denied Him, he annulled the decree of "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," for he no longer needed this counsel of measure for measure and did not believe in Him. Also, the decree of the midwives was nullified, and they were no longer afraid to kill the children of Israel with their own hands, as is explained in the teachings of our Sages, that they trampled them in the mortar and buried them in the construction. And in the Gemara Sotah (11b), it is stated that the women of Israel would go and give birth in the fields, and when the Egyptians recognized them, they came to kill them, and a miracle occurred for them, and they were swallowed up in the ground, and the Egyptians brought oxen and plowed over them, etc. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, saved them, as stated there. In any case, they no longer feared the reasoning of measure for measure to judge them specifically with water, and therefore the decree of "Every son that is born" was annulled. And they sought to kill them in every manner of death they could achieve, and afterwards the decree of "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river" was renewed for the reason that the astrologers said, "Today the savior of Israel is born and is destined to be punished with water." And with this, the question of the Maharsha on Rashi, may his memory be blessed, is resolved (see above question 3). And after Moses was born, the astrologers said, "He has already been born and is hidden from our eyes." Pharaoh said to them, "From now on do not throw the children," and the decree was annulled, and the first decree of "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," which they relied on the reasoning of measure for measure, had already been annulled beforehand, as mentioned above. And with this, the contradiction in the statements of our Sages and the reason for the change in the decrees is clarified (see above question 4).
summary: The passage discusses the theological concept of divine justice, emphasizing that God's actions are based on the principle of measure for measure (midah k'neged midah). Initially, Pharaoh believed that the Israelites would not be punished for their actions against the Hebrew children, as he thought he could avoid direct responsibility. However, once he became entrenched in his wickedness and denied God's existence, the original decree to cast the newborns into the Nile was nullified, leading to a shift in the nature of the decrees against the Israelites. Ultimately, the text illustrates how divine providence intervened to protect the Israelites, particularly through the birth of Moses, which was foreseen by astrologers, leading to a change in Pharaoh's approach.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתורץ סתירת הגמ ' והמדרשים שהקשה המהרש"א והנזה"ק הובא לעיל (קושיא ו') דבגמ ' דסוטה (דף י"ב) אמרו ז"ל כיון דהושלך משה במיא בטלו לגזירתייהו , והיינו דקאמר משה שש מאות אלף רגלי העם וגו' בשבילי נצלתם כולכם, מבואר דע"י ביטול הגזירה ניצולו והיתה הצלתם מלובש בטבע, ובמד"ר פר' ויחי ובפרדר"א ( פמ"ב ) מבואר דנשלכו ס' רבוא ילדי ישראל, ועלו מן היאור בדרך נס בזכותו של משה והיא סתירה לכאורה, ומקודם נבאר דברי הילקוט הנ"ל (קושיא ח') שטען עוזא שר של מצרים לפני הקב"ה כלום הטביעו בני מבניך וכו' ואיך יתכן לטעון שקר מוחלט כזה לפני הבוי"ת , ומדוע לא הכחישו ית ' בפניו לומר שמשקר.
translation: And according to our path, the contradiction in the Gemara and the Midrashim that the Maharsha and the Nitzotz HaKodesh raised above (question 6) is resolved. In the Gemara of Sotah (12a), it is stated that once Moshe was thrown into the water, their decree was nullified. This is what Moshe meant when he said, "Six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people, etc., for your sake, you were all saved." It is clear that through the nullification of the decree, they were saved, and their salvation was manifested in a natural way. And in the Midrash on Parashat Vayechi and in Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer (chapter 32), it is explained that 600,000 children of Israel were sent, and they ascended from the Nile in a miraculous way due to Moshe's merit, which seems to be a contradiction. Before that, we will explain the words of the aforementioned Yalkut (question 8) where Uzza, the minister of Egypt, argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Did your children drown my children, etc.?" And how is it possible to make such a complete false claim before the Creator of the world, and why did He not deny him before him, saying that he is lying?
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine decree and human agency, particularly in the context of Moses' role in the salvation of the Israelites. It highlights that the Israelites' deliverance from Egypt was both a natural occurrence and a miraculous event, emphasizing the interplay between God's will and the actions of individuals. The text also raises questions about the nature of truth and falsehood in the divine realm, particularly in relation to accusations made by celestial beings against God's people. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of faith, divine justice, and the power of intercession.

passage_content: ויתבאר כ"ז גם יתר הדקדוקים שבענין , בהקדם מה שאמרתי לתרץ קושית התוס ' בערכין (דף ט"ו ע"א), על מ"ש בגמ' ישראל שבאותו הדור מקטני אמנה היו וכו ', אמרו כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצרים עולים מצד אחר וכו' והקשו התוס ' יש לתמוה איך היו ישראל באותו הדור כ"כ מקטני אמנה, שסברו שכך יעשה הקב"ה נסים למצרים להעבירם מארצם לא"י, עיי"ש תירוצם, ואפ"ל קושית התוס ' עפי"מ דאיתא בילקוט פ' בשלח (רמז רל"ה) שהיו המצריים עושין כשפים ועלו מן הים וכו ', מיד המים רצין אחר כל מצרי ומצרי ומורידן לים שנאמר ומצרים נסים לקראתו וכו' עיי"ש, ומעתה אפ"ל דלא חשבו ישראל שהקב"ה יעשה נס למצריים להוציאם מן הים. אלא שהיו מתייראים שמא יעלו משם בכשפיהם, דכוחם גדול בכשפים, ואמרז"ל במס' חולין (דף ז' ע"ב) כשפים מכחישין פמליא של מעלה, ודבר התלוי במערכת השמים יש כח בכשפים לשנות, אלא שאמרו בגמ' שם שאני ר' חנינא דנפיש זכותי' טובא ולא מסתעי ' להו מילתא. ופרש"י דמשמיא מסרו נפשייהו לאצולי ' עכ"ל, אולם ישראל שבאותו הדור לא היו מאמינים בעצמן שיש להם זכות גדול כזה לדחות כח כשפיהם של המצריים, ולכן היו מתייראין , וז"ש מקטני אמנה היו שלא היו מאמינים בעצמן, וע"כ חשבו כשם שאנו עולין מצד זה כך הם עולין בכשפים מצד אחר, (עיין בדברנו להגש"פ ביאור הענין באריכות).
translation: And it will be explained that also the other grammatical points regarding the matter, by prefacing what I said to resolve the question of the Tosafot in Erchin (15a), on what is stated in the Gemara that the Israelites of that generation were of little faith, etc. They said, just as we ascend from this side, so the Egyptians ascend from another side, etc. And the Tosafot questioned how the Israelites of that generation could be so lacking in faith, as they thought that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would perform miracles for the Egyptians to bring them from their land to the Land of Israel. See there for their resolution. And I could say the question of the Tosafot is according to what is stated in the Yalkut, Parashat Beshalach (Remez 235) that the Egyptians were performing sorcery and ascended from the sea, etc. Immediately the waters ran after each Egyptian and brought them down to the sea, as it is said, "And the Egyptians fled before it," etc. See there. And from now on, it could be said that the Israelites did not think that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would perform a miracle for the Egyptians to take them out of the sea. Rather, they were afraid that they would ascend from there through their sorcery, for their power in sorcery is great. And our Sages of blessed memory said in Chulin (7b) that sorcery can contradict the heavenly entourage, and a matter that depends on the celestial system has the power of sorcery to change it. However, they said in the Gemara there that Rabbi Chanina is different, for he has many merits and does not need to rely on them. And Rashi explained that from Heaven they gave their lives to save him. However, the Israelites of that generation did not believe in themselves that they had such great merit to nullify the power of the Egyptians' sorcery, and therefore they were afraid. And this is what is meant by "they were of little faith," that they did not believe in themselves. And therefore they thought, just as we ascend from this side, so they ascend through sorcery from another side. (See in our discussion on the explanation of the matter at length.)
summary: The passage discusses the doubts of the Israelites in the face of the Egyptians' powerful sorcery during the Exodus. It highlights that the Israelites, described as "small in faith," feared that the Egyptians could use their magical abilities to escape the sea, not believing in their own merit to counteract such powers. The text emphasizes the theological concept that faith and self-belief are crucial for overcoming external challenges, suggesting that the Israelites' lack of confidence in their spiritual standing hindered their trust in divine intervention. Ultimately, it reflects on the tension between human limitations and the potential for divine salvation.

passage_content: ובהקדמה זו אפ"ל דברי המד"ר שכנס פרעה לכל המצריים וא"ל השאילו לי בניכם ט' חדשים שאשליכם ליאור וכו' ולכאורה וכי לזאת יקרא שאלה, דשאלה ה"ה הדרא בעינא , ואם ישליכם ויטביעם איך יחזירם להם (עיין קושיא ה') אמנם פרעה בטח בכח כשפיו, וע"כ הבטיחם שיעלה אותם מן הים ע"י כשפים ויחזירם להם, ורק אותו האחד שהוא גואלן של ישראל יטביע בים, וע"כ אמר השאילו לי בניכם. אלא שהמצריים לא רצו לקבל ממנו, שאמרו בן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם, ואפשר דעל ט' חדשים לא סמכו עליו, ועל יום אחד בלבד הסכימו, ובזה יתורץ סתירת המד"ר ומדרש ר' תנחומא (עיין קושיא ד') דרש"י בסוטה (דף י"ב) הביא מדרש ר' תנחומא דהגזירה על ילדי המצריים לא הי' אלא בו ביום, וא"ש דפרעה רצה על ט' חדשים, אלא שהמצריים לא קבלו אלא לבו ביום, ואפשר דהגזירה על ילדי ישראל נמשכה ע' חדשים, עד שהושלך משה ליאור ואז פסקה, ובזה יתורץ קושית היפ"ת וקושית העיון יעקב (עיין קושיא ד').
translation: In this introduction, one might say the words of the Midrash that Pharaoh gathered all the Egyptians and said to them, "Lend me your children for nine months, and I will cast them into the Nile," etc. At first glance, is this called a request? For a request is something that returns to the eye, and if he casts them and drowns them, how will he return them to them? (See the question in the footnote.) However, Pharaoh trusted in the power of his sorcery, and therefore he promised them that he would bring them up from the sea through sorcery and return them to them, and only that one who is the Redeemer of Israel would be drowned in the sea. Thus, he said, "Lend me your children." Yet the Egyptians did not want to accept from him, for they said, "An Egyptian son will never redeem them." It is possible that they did not rely on him for nine months, and they only agreed for one day. This resolves the contradiction in the Midrash and the Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma (see the question in the footnote) that Rashi brought in Sotah (page 12), which cites the Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma that the decree against the children of the Egyptians was only on that day. It is clear that Pharaoh wanted nine months, but the Egyptians accepted only for one day. It is possible that the decree against the children of Israel lasted for seventy months, until Moses was cast into the Nile, and then it ceased. This resolves the question of the Yefeh Toar and the question of the Ayin Yaakov (see the question in the footnote).
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses Pharaoh's request to borrow the children of the Israelites for nine months, highlighting the underlying belief in the power of sorcery to return them from the sea. The Egyptians, however, rejected this offer, believing that a child of an Egyptian could never be redeemed by a Hebrew. The text suggests that the decree against the Egyptian children was only for that day, while the decree against the Israelite children lasted longer, until Moses was cast into the Nile, reflecting the tension between divine providence and human agency in the context of redemption.

passage_content: ויתבאר בזה דברי הילקוט הנ"ל (קושיא ח') שטען עוזא שר של מצרים כלום הטביעו בני מבניך וכו ', דהנה כשאמרו האצטגנונום היום נולד מושיען של ישראל הושלכו גם ילדי מצרים ליאור, והמצרוום העלום מן היאור בכח כשפיהם כנ"ל, אבל את ילדי ישראל לא הצילו, אלא שהבוי"ת עשה להם נס כמבואר בב"ר (פ' ויחי) ס' רבוא ילדי ישראל הושלכו ליאור ועלו בזכותו של משה, וכן איתא בפרדר"א הנ"ל שהי' היאור פולט אותם למדבר מצרים, והיו ניזונים שם בדרך נס ע"י הקב"ה, ואחר שניצולו כל ילדי ישראל תלו המצריים כ"ז בכח כשפיהם שהם היו המצילים, והעלום מן הים כמו שהעלו לילדי מצרים, או אפשר שטענו שלא הי' כוונתם להטביעם כולם, אלא את אחד מהם שהוא מושיען של ישראל, ואת כולם רצו להעלות מן הים בכשפים כמו שהעלו לילדי מצרים, וזה שטען עוזא שר של מצרים כלום הטביעו בני מבניך וכו' הלא לא נטבעו אף אחד מהם וכולם ניצולו, ומעתה לא עשינו רעה עמהם כלום, ורצוננו הי' להוציאם משם בכשפים, ומן הדין הי"ל להשיב שכל טענתו מוכחש ושקר מוחלט, שהם לא היו מצילים אלא רצו להטביעם, ורק הבוי"ת הצילם בדרך נס, אלא שהבוי"ת השיבו בקצרה שפרעה וכל עמו כפרו בי ואמרו אין אלוה בעולם וכו' וכיון שהם כופרים ואפיקורסים א"א שיהיו מצילים לישראל, ואינכם אלא רוצחים לגוף ולנפש, וכל מגמתכם לא הי' אלא להרע לישראל, וזו תשובה מספקת לדחות כל טענותיו.
translation: And it will be explained here the words of the aforementioned Yalkut (question 8) that Uzzah, the minister of Egypt, claimed, "Did your sons drown?" etc. Behold, when the astrologers said, "Today the savior of Israel is born," the children of Egypt were also thrown into the Nile, and the Egyptians concealed them from the Nile by the power of their sorcery, as mentioned. However, the children of Israel were not saved, except that the Blessed One performed a miracle for them, as explained in Bereishit Rabbah (Parashat Vayechi), that 600,000 children of Israel were thrown into the Nile and were saved through the merit of Moses. And it is also stated in the aforementioned Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer that the Nile expelled them into the desert of Egypt, and they were sustained there miraculously by the Holy One, Blessed be He. After all the children of Israel were saved, the Egyptians attributed all this to the power of their sorcery, claiming that they were the ones who saved them, and they concealed them from the sea just as they had done for the children of Egypt. Or perhaps they argued that their intention was not to drown them all, but rather to drown one of them, who is the savior of Israel, and they wanted to bring all of them up from the sea through sorcery, just as they had brought up the children of Egypt. This is what Uzzah, the minister of Egypt, claimed: "Did your sons drown?" etc. Behold, none of them drowned, and all were saved. From now on, we have done them no wrong at all, and our intention was to bring them out from there through sorcery. Legally, he should have been answered that all his claims are refuted and a complete falsehood, for they were not saving them but rather wanted to drown them, and only the Blessed One saved them through a miracle. However, the Blessed One answered him briefly that Pharaoh and all his people denied Me and said, "There is no God in the world," etc. Since they are deniers and heretics, it is impossible for them to be saviors of Israel, and you are nothing but murderers of body and soul, and your entire intention was only to do evil to Israel. And this is a sufficient answer to dismiss all his claims.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous salvation of the Jewish children during the time of Moses, contrasting it with the intentions of the Egyptians, who sought to drown them. It emphasizes that while the Egyptians claimed they intended to save the children through sorcery, their true aim was to harm them, as evidenced by their denial of God's existence. The text highlights the idea that divine intervention was necessary for the Israelites' survival, underscoring the belief that those who deny God cannot be true saviors. Ultimately, it asserts that the Egyptians' intentions were malicious, and their claims are dismissed as falsehoods.

passage_content: ובזה יתורץ מה שלא נזכר בתורה נס גדול הזה דס ' רבוא ילדי ישראל שהושלכו ליאור כולם פלטם היאור וניצולו, גם לא נמנה בין הנסים בסיפור יצ"מ בסדר הגדה, וטעמא בעי (עיין לעיל קושיא ז), ויבואר עפימ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל ( בסו"פ נח) בטעם מה שלא הזכיר הכתוב הנס של אור כשדים כ"א ברמז, באמרו אנו ד' אשר הוצאתיך מאור כשדים, ולא סיפר הכתוב פרטית הנס הגדול שהשליכו נמרוד לכבשן האש וניצול, לפי שלא הודו האומות בניסו והיו חושבים שע"י מעשה כשפים ניצול משם, ומעתה אין תועלת בסיפור הנס, דעוע"ז יקחו ממנה עוד חיזוק לדעתם הנפסדה , לומר שיש כח בכשפים לעשות נסים גדולים כאלה, וע"כ העלימה הכתוב ולא מסרה אלא ברמז, את"ד ז"ל, וכמו"כ לעניננו לפי שהמצריים אמרו שהם היו המצילים והוציאום מן היאור ע"ו כשפים, ע"כ לא הזכירו הכתוב ולא נצטווינו לספר בשבח הנס הזה, דנס שתולין אותו בכשפים ורשעי ארץ, אין לספר הימנה כלל, וקלקולו יתר על תיקונו, שעוד ינתן להם חיזוק ע"י הסיפור.
translation: And with this, it is resolved why this great miracle was not mentioned in the Torah, that five hundred thousand children of Israel who were thrown into the river all emerged from the river and were saved. It was also not counted among the miracles in the narrative of the Exodus in the order of the Haggadah, and the reason is needed (see above question 7). It will be explained according to what the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote (in Parashat Noach) regarding the reason why the miracle of Ur Kasdim was not mentioned explicitly, but only hinted at, by saying, "I am the Lord who brought you out of Ur Kasdim," and the text did not recount the specific details of the great miracle when Nimrod threw him into the fiery furnace and he was saved, because the nations did not acknowledge His miracles and thought that he was saved through sorcery. Therefore, there is no benefit in recounting the miracle, as the idolaters would take from it further reinforcement for their erroneous beliefs, saying that there is power in sorcery to perform such great miracles. Thus, the text concealed it and only conveyed it in hints, as you have said, of blessed memory. Similarly, in our matter, since the Egyptians claimed that they were the ones who saved them from the river through sorcery, the text did not mention it, and we were not commanded to recount the praise of this miracle, for a miracle that is attributed to sorcery and the wicked of the earth should not be recounted at all, as its corruption outweighs its rectification, for it would further strengthen them through the recounting.
summary: The passage discusses the omission of the miraculous event of the Israelites being saved from the Nile in the Torah, paralleling the Ramban's explanation regarding the subtle mention of the miracle of the fiery furnace. It suggests that since the Egyptians attributed the salvation to their sorcery, recounting such miracles would only reinforce their false beliefs and provide them with a misguided sense of power. Therefore, the text emphasizes that miracles associated with wickedness and idolatry should not be celebrated, as doing so would ultimately cause more harm than good.

passage_content: ומעתה יתורץ סתירת הגמ ' והמדרשים הנ"ל (קושיא ו'), דהנה איתא בב"ר ופ' ויחי) א"ר לוי ס' רבוא תינוקות עיברו נשותיהן של ישראל בלילה אחת וכולן הושלכו ליאור ועלו בזכותו של משה, הוא שמשה אומר שש מאות אלף רגלי העם אשר אנכי בקרבו, כולן לרגלי עלו, מוכח מדברי המדרש דהן היו הששים רבוא אנשי דור המדבר שאמר עליהם משה שש מאות אלף רגלי העם אשר אנכי בקרבו, אמנם כתב בנזה"ק בשם המפרשים דא"א לומר דאילו הס' רבוא הנולדים עם משה היו דור המדבר ממש בגוף ובנפש, דא"כ הגיעו כולם לערך שנותיו של משה שהי' בן פ' בזמן יציאת מצרים. ובאמת דור המדבר נמנו מבן כ' ולמעלה, אלא צ"ל שנפשם הי' משורש ס' רבוא נפשות של דור המדבר, כי כבר התנוצצו לבוא בעולם בזמן לידת משה בהיותם משרשו, ומתו ונתגלגל נפשם שוב בעולם סמוך לזמן הגאולה ונגאלו עם משה עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: And from now on, the contradiction of the Gemara and the aforementioned Midrashim (question 6) will be resolved. Behold, it is stated in Bereishit Rabbah and in Parashat Vayechi: Rabbi Levi said that six hundred thousand children were conceived by the wives of Israel in one night, and all were cast into the Nile and were saved through the merit of Moses. This is what Moses says: "Six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people whom I am in their midst," all of them rose up in merit of me. It is evident from the words of the Midrash that these were the six hundred thousand men of the generation of the desert, of whom Moses said, "Six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people whom I am in their midst." However, it is written in the Zohar in the name of the commentators that it cannot be said that the six hundred thousand who were born with Moses were the actual generation of the desert in body and soul, for then they would all have reached the age of Moses, who was fifty at the time of the Exodus. In truth, the generation of the desert was counted from the age of twenty and above, but it must be that their souls were from the root of the six hundred thousand souls of the generation of the desert, for they had already begun to come into the world at the time of Moses' birth, being from their root, and they died and their souls were reincarnated again in the world close to the time of redemption and were redeemed with Moses, thus said the holy one, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the souls of the 600,000 Israelites born during Moses' time and the generation of the Exodus. It emphasizes that while the physical bodies of the Israelites in the desert were counted from age twenty and above, their souls were rooted in the same spiritual essence as those born with Moses. This suggests a theological belief in the pre-existence of souls and their reincarnation, culminating in their redemption alongside Moses during the Exodus. The text highlights the significance of Moses as a spiritual leader who facilitated the elevation and redemption of these souls.

passage_content: ולפי"ז לא יהי' סתירה בין דברי הגמ ' והמדרש ושניהם צדקו יחדיו, דהנס הראשון הי' שכל הס' רבוא ילדי ישראל שנשלכו ליאור הי' היאור פולט אותם ועלו בזכותו של משה, וזה הי' טרם שנשלך משה למים דאח"כ כבר פסקה הגזירה, ומזה הנס מיירי בב"ר פ' ויחי ובפרדר"א , אמנם נס זה לא נזכר בכתוב ואינו מבואר בפשוטו של מקרא, לפי שתלו אותו המצריים בכח כשפיהם כנ"ל, אלא שחז"ל במדרש למדוהו מקרא דרך דרש מדכתיב שש מאות אלף רגלי העם וגו' כולן לרגלי עלו, ודרשת חז"ל לא נמסרה אלא לישראל, וחז"ל הודיעו לנו בדרשתם מהות הנס אבל אין לספר בה לטעם הנ"ל, וחוץ מזה הי' עוד נס דאחר דשדיוהו למשה במיא , וזה הו' ג' חדשים אחר לידתו דכתיב ותצפנהו ג' ירחים, אז נתן ד' עצה בלבם ובטלו לגזירתם לגמרי, ועי"ז ניצולו כל ישראל גם אלו שבאו לעולם אחר לידת משה דאילולי שנתבטל הגזירה על ידו היו כולם בסכנה, ומזה הנס מיירי בגמ' והוציאוהו מפשוטו של מקרא דכתיב שש מאות אלף רגלי העם אשר אנכי בקרבו, ר"ל בשביל שאנכי בקרבו בשבילי נצלתם כולכם, ולפי שנס זה לא תלו אותו המצריים בכשפים ע"כ נכתבה בפשוטו של מקרא, ומעתה אין כאן סתירה וא"צ לעשות פלוגתא כמ"ש הנזה"ק דהמדרש חולק על דברי הגמ ' (עיין קושיא ו' לעיל) אלא שניהם צדקו יחדיו והמדרש והפרדר"א מיירי מנס הראשון והגמ ' מיירי מנס אחר ושניהם נתקיימו.
translation: According to this, there will be no contradiction between the words of the Gemara and the Midrash, and both are correct together. The first miracle was that all the six hundred thousand children of Israel who were cast into the Nile were expelled by the Nile and ascended due to the merit of Moses. This was before Moses was cast into the water, for afterwards the decree was already lifted. This miracle is referred to in Bereishit Rabbah, Parashat Vayechi, and in Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer. However, this miracle is not mentioned in the text and is not explained in the simple meaning of the Scripture, because the Egyptians attributed it to their sorcery, as mentioned above. Nevertheless, our Sages in the Midrash learned it from the verse that states, "six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people," etc., all of them ascended due to the merit of Moses. And the interpretation of our Sages was not transmitted except to Israel. Our Sages informed us through their interpretation of the essence of the miracle, but it is not to be recounted for the reason mentioned above. Besides this, there was another miracle that after they cast Moses into the water, this was three months after his birth, as it is written, "and she hid him for three months." Then God put advice in their hearts and completely nullified their decree. As a result, all of Israel was saved, even those who came into the world after the birth of Moses, for had the decree not been nullified through him, they would all have been in danger. This miracle is referred to in the Gemara, which takes it out of the simple meaning of the Scripture that states, "six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people who I am in their midst," meaning that because I am in their midst, you are all saved. And since this miracle was not attributed by the Egyptians to sorcery, therefore it is written in the simple meaning of the Scripture. From now on, there is no contradiction, and there is no need to create a dispute, as the Nefesh HaChaim states that the Midrash disagrees with the words of the Gemara (see question 6 above), but both are correct together: the Midrash and Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer refer to the first miracle, and the Gemara refers to another miracle, and both were fulfilled.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events surrounding the birth and early life of Moses, emphasizing that both the Talmud and Midrash can be reconciled in their accounts of these miracles. It highlights that the first miracle involved the survival of the Israelite children cast into the Nile, which was attributed to Moses' merit before he was placed in the water. The second miracle occurred three months later when God nullified the decree against the Israelites, ensuring their safety. Ultimately, the text asserts that both sources are correct, each addressing different aspects of the divine intervention that protected the Jewish people.

passage_content: ולדרכנו הנ"ל יתפרש אלה שמות בני ישראל הבאים מצרימה וגו' הזכיר לשון הו' מפני שחזרו ונתגלגלו , ובאו למצרים הרבה פעמים, וסבלו נסיונות וצרות הרבה בגלגולים וסיבות שונות, שהם היו אשר הושלכו ליאור ועלו בזכותו של משה, ואח"כ מתו ונתגלגלו עוה"פ וסבלו גלות ועבודת הפרך, וז"ש במדרש ואלה מוסיף על הראשונים וכו' הוסיף שבח על השבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה שכולם צדיקים היו, ר"ל דניתוסף בהם שבח שאף שסבלו עינויים קשים ונסיונות הרבה אעפ"כ נשארו בצדקותם, וז"ש מוסיף על הראשונים, על שבעים נפש שנאמרו למעלה, הם אשר באו בגלגולם הראשון את יעקב, כי באלו לא הי' רבותא כ"כ דאת יעקב איש וביתו באו שבאו למצרים עם בתים מתוקנים בקדושה וטהרה, את יעקב שהוא מקור הקדושה, אבל כאן שהזכיר הבאים, היינו הגלגולים שבאים אח"כ בהו', ע"כ הוסיף בהם שבח שאע"פ שסבלו נסיונות ועינויים נשארו בצדקתם, ובעוה"ר גם אנו כבר סבלנו גלגולים שונים ומרעה אל רעה יצאנו, והדור הזה כבר סבל הרבה צרות וחבלי משיח, והבוכ"ע יעזור ויאמר לצרותינו די ונוושע במהרה, שכבר הוא זמן האחרון ובפנות היום, ותחזנה עינינו הישועה שלימה, ונזכה מיד לעשות תשובה שלימה ולתקן את כל מה שפגמנו, ונזכה עוד לעבוד להבוי"ת בשמחה ובנחת בקדושה ובטהרה לעשות רצון הבוי"ת ונחת רוח לפניו ויתקדש ש"ש על ידינו, ונזכה לישועה שלימה בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And according to our aforementioned path, it is explained that these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt, etc. The term "and" is mentioned because they returned and were reincarnated, and came to Egypt many times, and suffered many trials and troubles through various reincarnations and causes. They were those who were thrown into the Nile and were redeemed through the merit of Moses, and afterwards they died and were reincarnated in this world and suffered exile and hard labor. This is what is said in the Midrash, "And these add to the first ones," etc. It adds praise to the seventy souls mentioned above, that they were all righteous, meaning that they were added with praise, for even though they suffered severe tortures and many trials, they nevertheless remained in their righteousness. This is what is meant by "adds to the first ones," regarding the seventy souls mentioned above, who came in their first reincarnation with Jacob, for in these there was not such a great distinction that Jacob, a man and his household, came to Egypt with households that were established in holiness and purity, with Jacob being the source of holiness. But here, when it mentions those who came, it refers to the reincarnations that come afterwards, therefore it added praise to them that even though they suffered trials and tortures, they remained in their righteousness. And in our present time, we too have already suffered various reincarnations and have gone from bad to worse, and this generation has already suffered many troubles and the birth pangs of the Messiah. May the Blessed One help and say enough to our troubles, and may we be redeemed quickly, for it is already the last time and at the turning of the day, and may our eyes behold complete salvation, and may we merit immediately to do complete repentance and rectify all that we have blemished, and may we merit to serve the Creator with joy and tranquility in holiness and purity, to do the will of the Creator and bring Him satisfaction, and may His name be sanctified through us, and may we merit complete salvation with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us quickly in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual journey of the Israelites as they faced numerous trials and reincarnations before their enslavement in Egypt. It emphasizes that despite their suffering, they maintained their righteousness, highlighting the merit of their perseverance through hardships. The text draws a parallel to the current generation, which has also endured significant challenges, expressing hope for divine intervention and ultimate redemption. It concludes with a prayer for complete salvation and the fulfillment of God's will, leading to a sanctification of His name.

passage_content: ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים אשר לא ידע את יוסף: במד"ר (פרשה א' סי' ח') רבנן אמרי למה קראו מלך חדש והלא פרעה עצמו הי', אלא שאמרו המצריים לפרעה בא ונזדווג לאומה זו. אמר להם שוטים אתם, עד עכשיו משלהם אנו אוכלים והאיך נזדווג להם וכו ', כיון שלא שמע להם הורידוהו מכסאו ג' חדשים, עד שאמר להם כל מה שאתם רוצים הריני עמכם והשיבו אותו, לפיכך כתיב ויקם מלך חדש עכ"ד המדרש. ויש סתירה לזה בדברי המדרש רבה להלן (סי' ט') ויאמר אל עמו הבה נתחכמה וגו', הוא התחיל בעצה תחלה דכתיב ויאמר אל עמו, לכך לקה תחלה דכתיב ובך ובעמך ובכל עבדיך. וכתב ביפ"ת דלא כרבנן דלעיל דהמצריים אכפוהו לעשות כן. והראי' שהוא לקה תחלה עכ"ל, אמנם כללא אית לן דאפושי פלוגתא לא מפשינן ובפרט שזהו פלוגתא במציאות וצ"ב להשוות דברי רז"ל
translation: And a new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph: In the Midrash (Parashat 1, Section 8), the Rabbis say, why is he called a new king? Was it not Pharaoh himself? Rather, the Egyptians said to Pharaoh, come, let us join with this nation. He said to them, you fools, until now we have been eating from their produce, how can we join with them, etc. When he did not listen to them, they removed him from his throne for three months, until he said to them, whatever you want, I am with you, and they responded to him. Therefore, it is written, and a new king arose. Thus far the Midrash. There is a contradiction to this in the words of the Midrash Rabbah later (Section 9), and he said to his people, let us be wise, etc. He began with advice first, as it is written, and he said to his people. Therefore, he was struck first, as it is written, and upon you and your people and all your servants. And it is written in Yefeh Toar that it is not according to the Rabbis above, that the Egyptians compelled him to do so. And the proof that he was struck first, thus far. However, we have a general rule that we do not resolve disputes, especially since this is a dispute in reality, and it is necessary to reconcile the words of our Sages.
summary: The passage discusses the emergence of a new king in Egypt who did not recognize Joseph, highlighting the tension between the Egyptians and their previous reliance on Joseph's legacy. It reflects on the idea that the king initially resisted the suggestion to ally with the Israelites, leading to his temporary removal from power. The text emphasizes the consequences of his refusal to heed the advice of his people, illustrating the theme of divine retribution and the complexities of leadership. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of humility and the recognition of past contributions in the face of changing circumstances.
