passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי המדרש באסתר רבתי (פרשה ז' סי' כ"ג) א"ר לוי ארורים הם הרשעים שהם מתעסקים בעצה רעה על ישראל, וכאו"א מהם יועץ לפי דרכו ואומר עצתי טובה מעצתך, עשו אמר שוטה הי' קין וכו ', פרעה אמר שוטה הי' עשו וכו' המן אמר פרעה שוטה הי' שאמר כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו וכו ', ואף גוג ומגוג לעתיד לבוא עתיד לומר שוטים היו הראשונים שהיו מתעסקים בעצות עם מלכיהם של ישראל ולא היו יודעין שיש להם פטרון בשמים, אני איני עושה כן אלא הריני מזדווג עם פטרונן תחלה ואח"כ אני מזדווג להם, הה"ד (תהלים ב') יתייצבו מלכי ארץ וגו' על ה' ועל משיחו עכ"ד המדרש, וביפה ענף בפירושו על המדרש כתב דלא יתפרש זה כפשוטו, כי מי האויל אשר יצא למלחמה נגד ה', וממנ"פ אם יאמינו בהשי"ת הרי יודעין שא"א להלחם עמו כביכול, ואם לא יאמינו מדוע סיכלו עצת הראשונים באמרם שלא היו יודעין שיש להם פטרון בשמים, אמנם הכוונה שיתחכמו גוג ומגוג להפריד הדיבוק האלקי בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, ויתעמלו לבטל התורה והמצות מישראל, ולעקור שורש האמונה המורשה להם מאבותיהם, ובזה ינתקו המוסרות המקשרות את ישראל לפטרונן זה הקב"ה, וכאשר יחטאו יוכלו להרע להם כרצונם ח"ו, והיינו שיזדווגו לפטרונן עיי"ש, וכעי"ז פי' השלה"ק בפרשה זו עיי"ש.
translation:
To clarify the matter, we will precede with the words of the Midrash in Esther Rabbah (Section 7, Paragraph 23): Rabbi Levi said, "Cursed are the wicked who engage in evil counsel against Israel, and each one of them advises according to his own way, saying, 'My counsel is better than yours.' Esau said, 'Cain was a fool,' etc. Pharaoh said, 'Esau was a fool,' etc. Haman said, 'Pharaoh was a fool,' for he said, 'Every son that is born you shall cast into the river,' etc. And even Gog and Magog in the future will say, 'The earlier ones were fools who engaged in counsel with the kings of Israel and did not know that they have a Patron in Heaven. I will not do so; rather, I will first unite with their Patron and then I will unite with them.' As it is said (Psalms 2), 'The kings of the earth set themselves against the Lord and against His anointed.' Thus concludes the Midrash. 

And in Yafeh Anaf, in his commentary on the Midrash, he wrote that this should not be understood literally, for who is the fool that would go to war against the Holy One, Blessed be He? And in any case, if they believe in the Holy One, they know that it is impossible to fight against Him, as it were. And if they do not believe, why did they thwart the counsel of the earlier ones by saying that they did not know they had a Patron in Heaven? However, the intention is that Gog and Magog will seek to separate the divine connection between Israel and their Father in Heaven, and they will strive to nullify the Torah and the commandments from Israel, and to uproot the root of faith that is bequeathed to them from their ancestors. In this way, they will sever the bonds that connect Israel to their Patron, the Holy One, Blessed be He, and when they sin, they will be able to harm them as they wish, Heaven forbid. This is what it means that they will unite with their Patron, as stated there, and similarly, the Shelah HaKadosh explained in this section, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the futility of the wicked who plot against Israel, highlighting that they fail to recognize the divine protection over the Jewish people. It emphasizes that historical adversaries, like Cain, Pharaoh, and Haman, mistakenly believed they could succeed against God's chosen. The text warns that in the future, Gog and Magog will attempt to sever the spiritual connection between Israel and their Heavenly Father by undermining faith and the observance of Torah and commandments. Ultimately, this separation would enable them to harm Israel, but their efforts are rooted in ignorance of God's omnipotence.

passage_content: ולכאורה צריך הסבר איך היו הראשונים שוטים כ"כ, וכי לא ידעו שיש לישראל פטרון בשמים המצילם, והלא פרעה הי' ג"כ חכם להרע וגדול בחכמות החיצונים וכן המן, ועשו הי' הס"מ שרו ומנהיגו, ואיך לא עלה על דעתם מה שיתחכם גוג ומגוג בדרך חדש להרע לישראל, אמנם באמת לא היו טפשים וגם הם השיגו עצת גוג ומגוג וכל א' מהם השתדל בכל חכמתו ויכולתו להרע לישראל, אלא שמנעום מן השמים ונאבד שכלם שלא ישיגו להרע יותר כ"א במדה ידיעה כפי צורך התיקון לאותו הדור, וע"ד שאמרז"ל בגמרא (מגילה דף י"ב ע"א) שאלו תלמידיו את רשב"י מפני מה נתחייבו שונאיהם של ישראל שבאותו הדור כלי', א"ל אמרו אתם, אמרו לו מפני שנהנו מסעודתו של אותו רשע, א"ל א"כ של שושן יהרגו, של כל העולם כולו לא יהרגו: א"ל אמור לנו אתה, אמר מפני שהשתחוו לצלם וכו' עיי"ש, והנה באמת לא נתקיימה בהם גזירת כלי' ר"ל, אך על הגזירה עצמה שאלו תלמידי רשב"י מדוע זה עלתה ביד רשעי הדור לגזור גזירה קשה של כלי', וג"ז צריך להיות במידה ובמשקל כפי גודל החטא וצורך תיקונו, ובאמת רצון הרשעים לגזור כלי' גמורה ר"ל, אלא שנמנע מהם היכולת להרע כ"א במדה ידיעה, וע"כ ביקשו חכז"ל טעם מדוע הניחוהו מן השמים לגזור כלי' על ישראל שבכל העולם, ואין הקושיא על המן מדוע גזר על כל העולם, כי הוא חפצו ורצונו בכך ואין זה תמי', אך הקושיא דלטעם שנהנו מסעודתו של אותו רשע אין מדת חטאם מספיק שירשוהו מן השמים לגזור גזירת כלי' על כל ישראל.
translation: And seemingly, an explanation is needed as to how the earlier generations were so foolish, and did they not know that Israel has a Patron in Heaven who saves them? After all, Pharaoh was also wise in doing evil and great in the external wisdoms, as was Haman, and Amalek was the Sitra Achra, his minister and leader. How did it not occur to them that Gog and Magog would devise a new way to harm Israel? However, in truth, they were not foolish, and they understood the counsel of Gog and Magog, and each of them exerted all their wisdom and ability to harm Israel. Rather, they were prevented from Heaven, and their intellect was lost so that they could not devise harm except to the extent of knowledge necessary for the rectification of that generation, in accordance with what our Sages of blessed memory said in the Gemara (Megillah 12a) that the students of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai asked him why the enemies of Israel in that generation were punished with annihilation. He said to them, "You say," and they replied, "Because they benefited from the feast of that wicked one." He said to them, "Then those of Shushan should be killed, but those of the entire world should not be killed." He said, "You tell us," and he replied, "Because they bowed to the idol," etc. There, it is clear that the decree of annihilation was not fulfilled upon them, but regarding the decree itself, the students of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai asked why it was that the wicked of the generation were able to decree such a harsh decree of annihilation, and this too must be in measure and weight according to the magnitude of the sin and the need for its rectification. In truth, the desire of the wicked was to decree complete annihilation, but they were prevented from having the ability to harm except to the extent of knowledge. Therefore, our Sages sought a reason why they were allowed from Heaven to decree annihilation upon Israel throughout the world, and the question is not on Haman as to why he decreed upon the entire world, for that was his desire and will, and this is not surprising. However, the question regarding the reason that they benefited from the feast of that wicked one is that the measure of their sin is not sufficient for them to be granted from Heaven the decree of annihilation upon all of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent foolishness of earlier generations who failed to recognize that Israel has a divine protector. It emphasizes that while figures like Pharaoh and Haman were wise in their evil intentions, they were ultimately limited by divine intervention, which restricted their ability to harm Israel to what was necessary for the spiritual rectification of that generation. The text reflects on the nature of sin and divine justice, suggesting that the severity of decrees against Israel corresponds to the gravity of their transgressions, and questions why such harsh decrees were allowed to be issued in the first place.

passage_content: ובזה יתורץ סתירת המדרשים הנ"ל וא"ש דרשתם ז"ל דפרעה התחיל בעצה תחלה דכתיב ויאמר אל עמו הבה נתחכמה וגו' לכך לקה תחלה, ולדרכנו נאמר דפרעה השיג עצת גוג ומגוג, שא"א להזדווג לישראל בגזירות רעות עינוי ושעבוד וכלי', כי יש להם פטרון בשמים המצילם, אבל רצה להזדווג לפטרונם ר"ל להפריד הדיבוק האלקי בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, ורצה להשיג מטרה זו ע"י התקרבות ואחו' וריעות , וכאשר יחטאו לא יצילם ד' ויוכלו להרע להם כרצונם, וע"כ ויאמר אל עמו הבה נתחכמה לו, כי שוטים היו הראשונים ואם נלך בדרכם גם עלינו יאמרו כן. ע"כ נתחכמה בעצה אחרת כעצת גוג ומגוג להשיג רעתם בדרך התקרבות ולהזדווג לפטרונם וז"ש במדרש אמר להם שועים אתם עד עכשיו משלהם אנו אוכלים והאיך נזדווג להם, ולא מפני שלא רצה להיות כפוי טובה אמר כן, כי הי' לבו רחוק ממידה טובה זו, אבל רמז להם שדרך זו להזדווג להם בעינוי ושעבוד הוא שטות ועתידים אומה"ע לומר שוטים היו הראשונים ע"כ אמר שוטים אתם שרצונכם להזדווג להם, בגזירות רעות עינוי ושעבוד אלא שלא רצה לגלות להם עיקר טעמו, שנתיירא להודיע להם גדולתן של ישראל שיש להם פטרון בשמים המצילם, שמא יעלה מורך בלבבם להזדווג להם בשום אופן שהוא, ולפי שלא השיגו טעמו לא קיבלו עצתו ובחרו בדרך אחר להיצר לישראל בגזירת עינוי ושעבוד, והורידוהו מכסאו ג' חדשים על שהתנגד לעצתם, ובראותו שבלא"ה לא יועיל בעצתו כלום, בהכרח קיבל עצתם ואמר כל מה שאתם רוצים לעשות הרינו עמכם והושיבו אותו, ולבסוף לא הצליח עצתם, כמ"ש וכאשר יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ.
translation: And with this, the contradiction of the aforementioned Midrashim is resolved, and it is understood what our sages said that Pharaoh began with counsel first, as it is written, "And he said to his people, 'Come, let us deal wisely with them...'" Therefore, he was struck first. And according to our path, it can be said that Pharaoh attained the counsel of Gog and Magog, for it is impossible to unite with Israel through evil decrees, oppression, and servitude, as they have a Patron in Heaven who saves them. However, he wanted to unite with their Patron, meaning to separate the divine connection between Israel and their Father in Heaven, and he sought to achieve this goal through closeness, friendship, and camaraderie. And when they sin, God will not save them, and he will be able to harm them as he wishes. Therefore, he said to his people, "Come, let us deal wisely with him," for the first ones were fools, and if we go in their way, they will say the same about us. Thus, let us deal wisely with another counsel, like the counsel of Gog and Magog, to achieve their evil through closeness and to unite with their Patron. And it is said in the Midrash, "You are fools until now; we eat from their sustenance, and how can we unite with them?" And not because he did not want to be ungrateful did he say this, for his heart was far from this good trait, but he hinted to them that this way of uniting with them through oppression and servitude is foolishness, and the nations of the world are destined to say that the first ones were fools. Therefore, he said, "You are fools for wanting to unite with them through evil decrees, oppression, and servitude," but he did not want to reveal to them his main reason, that he feared to inform them of the greatness of Israel, that they have a Patron in Heaven who saves them, lest fear should arise in their hearts to unite with them in any way. And since they did not grasp his reasoning, they did not accept his counsel and chose another way to afflict Israel with decrees of oppression and servitude, and they removed him from his throne for three months for opposing their counsel. And seeing that regardless, his counsel would not help at all, he was compelled to accept their counsel and said, "Whatever you want to do, we are with you," and they seated him. In the end, their counsel did not succeed, as it is said, "And the more they afflicted him, the more he multiplied and spread."
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's initial strategy to oppress the Israelites by attempting to separate them from their divine protector, God, through cunning and deceit. It highlights the theological belief that the Israelites have a heavenly patron who saves them from oppression, and Pharaoh's fear of this divine protection led him to propose a misguided approach to subjugation. Ultimately, despite his efforts to outsmart the Israelites, Pharaoh's plans backfire, illustrating the futility of opposing God's will and the resilience of the Jewish people in the face of adversity. The text emphasizes the importance of recognizing the divine connection between the Israelites and God, which cannot be severed by human schemes.

passage_content: ויתורץ בזה סתירת המדרשים דבאמת פרעה התחיל בעצה תחלה במ"ש הבה נתחכמה , אך לא בעצתם של המצריים, אלא עצה טובה ממנה, שהתחכם בעצת גוג ומגוג להשיג רעתם בדרך התחברות ולנתקם מפטרונם, ולא הי' שוטה כאשר יחשוב עליו גוג ומגוג, אלא שהי' סיבה מן השמים למנוע היכולת ממנו, כי כל גזירה יש לה זמן ובאה במידה ובמשקל כפי חטא הדור והנסיונות הראויים להם לצורך תקון נפשם, ואז לא הי' זמנה עדיין ע"כ התנגדו המצריים ולא נתקבל עצתו, ואכפוהו לקבל עצתם, ולא הצליחו גם בזה, ומעתה אין סתירה בין המדרשים ושניהם אמיתיים דפרעה התחיל בעצה תחלה, ואעפ"כ אכפוהו המצרים להרע לישראל כנ"ל, ובעוה"ר בדור הזה עיקבתא דמשיחא נתרבו הנסיונות והשיגו רשעי הדור עצת גוג ומגוג לנתק את ישראל מאמונתם ל"ע , וכולהו איתנייהו יסורים וצרות ומלחמות ומינות ע"י התחברות לרשעים, וכמ"ש הה"ק בעל לקוטי מהר"ן זלה"ה שקודם ביאת המשיח מבול של מינות ירד לעולם, ומועטים יהיו המתחזקים באמונתם, וכנראה שכבר התחילו בעצת מלחמת גוג ומגוג, והגמר יהי' בביאת המשיח שאז יכרעו ויפולו לפני מלך המשיח, ואלו רשעי הדורות של זמנינו הם אשר יסייעו לגוג ומגוג במלחמתו נגד מלך המשיח, (כמ"ש בספרי עה"ג סי' ס"א עיי"ש).
translation: And this resolves the contradiction between the teachings, for indeed Pharaoh began with counsel first in saying, "Come, let us be wise," but not with the counsel of the Egyptians, rather with a better counsel, as he became wise through the counsel of Gog and Magog to achieve their evil by way of connection and to sever them from their patron. And he was not a fool as Gog and Magog would think of him, but there was a reason from Heaven to prevent him from having the ability, for every decree has its time and comes in measure and weight according to the sin of the generation and the trials appropriate for them for the purpose of rectifying their souls. At that time, it was not yet their time; therefore, the Egyptians opposed him, and his counsel was not accepted, and they forced him to accept their counsel, and they did not succeed in this either. From now on, there is no contradiction between the teachings, and both are true: Pharaoh began with counsel first, and nevertheless, the Egyptians forced him to do evil to Israel as mentioned above. And in our times, in this generation, the footsteps of the Messiah have increased the trials, and the wicked of the generation have attained the counsel of Gog and Magog to sever Israel from their faith, Heaven forbid. And all of them are afflicted with suffering, troubles, wars, and heresies through connection with the wicked, as it is written by the holy author of Likutey Moharan, may his merit protect us, that before the coming of the Messiah, a flood of heresy will descend upon the world, and few will be those who strengthen themselves in their faith. And it is evident that they have already begun with the counsel of the war of Gog and Magog, and the conclusion will be with the coming of the Messiah, at which time they will bow and fall before the King Messiah. And these wicked ones of our times are those who will assist Gog and Magog in his war against the King Messiah, as it is written in the holy books, section 61, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the conflict between Pharaoh's initial counsel to outsmart the Israelites and the divine intervention that prevented his plans from succeeding. It emphasizes that Pharaoh's strategy was influenced by the counsel of Gog and Magog, aiming to sever the Israelites from their faith. The text draws a parallel to contemporary times, suggesting that the trials and tribulations faced by the Jewish people are reminiscent of Gog and Magog's tactics, with a warning that many will struggle to maintain their faith before the coming of the Messiah, who will ultimately triumph over evil.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפשר להסביר מה שהיו חולקים המצרים על החרטומים והתנגדו לגזירת פרעה בענין הגזירה להשליך ילדיהם ליאור, דמבואר במד"ר (פ' א' סי' י"ח) ויצו פרעה לכל עמו אריב"ח אף על עמו גזר, ולמה עשה כן, שהיו אסטרולוגין אומרים לו גואל ישראל נתעברה ממנו אמו , ואין אנו יודעין אם ישראל אם מצרי הוא, באותה שעה כנס פרעה כל המצריים וא"ל השאילו לי בניכם ט' חדשים שאשליכם ליאור וכו ', ולא רצו המצריים לקבל ממנו שאמרו בן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין דהרי החרטומים השיגו בכח טומאתם אף את העתידות במקצת, אלא שלפעמים נבאו ולא ידעו מה ניבאו, ע"י שמנעו השגתם מן השמים לצורך, ועכ"פ ידעו יותר מהמון המצריים, ואיך אפשר שהי' מסתפק להם אם גואלן של ישראל יהי' מצרי או ישראל, ולהמון המצריים הי' ברירא מילתא שבן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם ושדבר זה נמנע המציאות, ואיך אפשר שיטעו החרטומים כ"כ ובמה הי' נתלה סברת פלוגתתם , וכבר ביארנו בזה ועוד לאלקי מילין .
translation:
And similarly, one can explain why the Egyptians argued with the magicians and opposed Pharaoh's decree regarding the command to cast their children into the Nile, as it is explained in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, Section 18): "And Pharaoh commanded all his people, 'Every son that is born you shall cast into the river.'" And why did he do this? Because the astrologers were telling him that the Redeemer of Israel was conceived from his mother, and we do not know if he is an Israelite or an Egyptian. At that moment, Pharaoh gathered all the Egyptians and said to them, "Lend me your sons for nine months, and I will cast them into the river," etc. But the Egyptians did not want to comply with him, as they said, "An Egyptian son will never redeem them." Thus far the Midrash. 

It is worth understanding that the magicians, through their impurity, grasped some of the future, yet at times they prophesied without knowing what they were prophesying, by preventing their understanding from the heavens for a purpose. Nevertheless, they knew more than the masses of the Egyptians. How could it be that they were uncertain whether the Redeemer of Israel would be Egyptian or Israelite, while for the masses of the Egyptians it was clear that an Egyptian son would never redeem them and that this was an impossibility? How could the magicians be so mistaken, and what was the basis for their dispute? We have already explained this and more in the context of divine matters.
summary: The passage discusses the disagreement between the Egyptians and their magicians regarding Pharaoh's decree to throw the Hebrew children into the Nile. The magicians, despite their knowledge of astrology, were uncertain whether the future redeemer of Israel would be Egyptian or Hebrew, while the common Egyptians firmly believed that a Hebrew could never redeem them. This highlights a key Hasidic concept: the limitations of human understanding and the divine will, suggesting that even those with knowledge can be misled when they are disconnected from divine insight. The text emphasizes the tension between human perception and the hidden workings of divine providence.

passage_content: ואפ"ל דגם החרטומים לא טעו לגמרי אלא שניבאו ולא ידעו מה ניבאו, שמשרע"ה נקרא בן בתי', כמ"ש בגמ' מגילה (י"ג ע"א) ואשתו היהודי' ילדה את ירד וגו', אמאי קרי לי' יהודי' והלא בתי' שמה, על שם שכפרה בע"ז וכו ', ירד זה משה וכו ', והקשו ילדה והא רבויי רביתי ', לומר לך שכל המגדל יתום ויתומה בתוך ביתו, מעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו ילדו וכמו"כ מצינו במאמה"כ בפרשה זו ויהי לה לבן, הרי שחשבו הכתוב לבן בתי', ובכ"מ בגמ' נקרא בן בתי', ובאמת היתה בתי' באותה שעה צדיקת ובאבות דר"נ חשבוהו בין התשעה שנכנסו חיים לג"ע, אבל מ"מ מצד הלידה היתה מצרית שנולדה בבית פרעה, ואולי הי' צורך לזה ע"ד שאמרז"ל בגמ' סנהדרין (ל"ט ע"ב) עובדי' גר אדומי הו', והיינו דאמרי אינשי מני' ובי' אבא ניזל בי' נרגא , פרש"י אבא יער, מעצמו של יער יכנס בתוך הגרזן להיות בית יד ויקצצו בו את היער, וכן עובדי' לאדום ודוד למואב והוא יצא מרות המואבי' עכ"ל, וכמו"כ משה רבינו שעל ידו נלקו המצריים במכות ועונשים ע"כ הי' מיני' ובי' בן בתי' ונתגדל בבית פרעה, וכמו שאמרז"ל במד"ר פרשה זו (א' כ"ו) וכן הקב"ה אמר לחירם (יחזקאל כ"ח) ואוציא אש מתוכך הוא וגו', וכן בת פרעה מגדלת מי שעתיד ליפרע מאבי', ואף מלך המשיח שעתיד ליפרע מאדום יושב עמהם במדינה וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: And even though the magicians did not err completely, they prophesied without knowing what they were prophesying, for Moshe Rabbeinu is called the son of Batya, as it is written in the Gemara Megillah (13a), and her Jewish wife gave birth to Yered, etc. Why is she called a Jewess, and is not her name Batya? Because she denied idolatry, etc. Yered is Moshe, etc. And they asked, "She gave birth," and yet it is a great abundance, to tell you that anyone who raises an orphan boy or girl in their home, the Scripture considers it as if they gave birth to them. Likewise, we find in the Torah in this section, "And she had a son," thus the Scripture considered him the son of Batya. And everywhere in the Gemara, he is called the son of Batya. And in truth, at that time, Batya was righteous, and in Avot de-Rabbi Natan, they considered him among the nine who entered alive into Gan Eden. However, from the perspective of birth, she was Egyptian, having been born in Pharaoh's house. And perhaps there was a need for this, as our Sages said in the Gemara Sanhedrin (39b), "They were converts from Edom," and this is what people say, "From it and by it, my father went down to the fire," Rashi explains, "Father of the forest," from the essence of the forest, he enters into the axe to be a handhold, and they cut down the forest with it. Likewise, they were converts to Edom, and David from Moab, and he came from Ruth the Moabite. Thus, Moshe Rabbeinu, through whom the Egyptians were struck with plagues and punishments, was therefore from it and by it, the son of Batya, and he was raised in Pharaoh's house. As our Sages said in Midrash on this section (1:26), and so the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Hiram (Ezekiel 28), "And I will bring forth fire from within you," etc. Likewise, Batya raised one who would eventually take vengeance on her father, and even the King Messiah, who is destined to take vengeance on Edom, sits with them in the land, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the complex identity of Moses, who is referred to as the son of Batya, Pharaoh's daughter, despite her being a convert and a righteous individual. It highlights the idea that raising an orphan is akin to giving birth, emphasizing the spiritual significance of nurturing and the divine plan that intertwines the destinies of the oppressor and the liberator. The text also draws parallels between Moses and future redemptive figures, suggesting that those who appear to be part of the oppressor's household may ultimately play a crucial role in their downfall. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interconnectedness of redemption and the transformative power of divine providence.

passage_content: אמנם הי' הכרח שתהי' השתלשלות הענינים בדרך הסתר והעלמה שלא ירגישו פרעה ויועציו מקדושתו, ומשרע"ה לא רצה לינק מן המצריות, כי פה שעתיד לדבר עם הקב"ה א"א שינק מן המצריות ומכ"ש לאחר שנתגדל שלא נתגעל במאכלם ומשתיים, והנה לחד דיעה במד"ר (פ' א' סי' ל') הי' משה בן מ' כשהרג את המצרי, נמצא הי' צורך לנס עצום להסתיר ולהעלים מהם איכות קדושתו בזמן רב כזה, דמבואר במד"ר (פ' א' סי' כ"ו) שחשדוהו החרטומים כי הוא העתיד להושיע את ישראל ומהם אמרו לשורפו מהם אמרו להרגו , והי' יתרו יושב ביניהם ויעץ לבחנו בקערה של זהב וגחלת, ובא גבריאל ודחף את ידו ותפש הגחלת ועי"ז ניצול בדרך נס, ואולי גם מה שנתגיירה בתי' וכפרה בגילולי אבי' הי' בהסתר והעלמה מהם שלא ירגישו בכל הענין .
translation: Indeed, it was necessary for the unfolding of events to occur in a manner of concealment and hiddenness, so that Pharaoh and his advisors would not perceive his holiness. And since Moshe Rabbeinu did not want to nurse from the Egyptians, for the mouth that was destined to speak with the Holy One, Blessed be He, could not nurse from the Egyptians, and certainly after he had grown up, he should not be defiled by their food and drink. Now, according to one opinion in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, Section 30), Moshe was 40 years old when he killed the Egyptian, thus there was a need for a tremendous miracle to conceal and hide from them the quality of his holiness for such a long time. It is explained in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, Section 26) that the magicians suspected him, for they said he was destined to save Israel; some said to burn him, and others said to kill him. And Yitro was sitting among them and advised them to test him with a bowl of gold and a coal. Then Gavriel came and pushed his hand, and he grasped the coal, and through this he was saved in a miraculous way. And perhaps also the fact that his daughter converted and atoned for the idols of her father was done in concealment and hiddenness from them, so they would not perceive the entire matter.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of concealing Moses' holiness from Pharaoh and his advisors, emphasizing that Moses could not partake in Egyptian nourishment, as he was destined to communicate with God. It highlights the miraculous events surrounding Moses' early life, including the need for divine intervention to protect him from being discovered as the future savior of Israel. Additionally, it suggests that the conversion of Jethro's daughter was also shrouded in secrecy to prevent the Egyptians from recognizing the significance of these events.

passage_content: ומעתה נבין בטעם מחלקותם, ואפשר דהחרטומים וגם המון מצרים כולם השיגו שא"א שיהי' גואלם של ישראל כ"א הפרוש מדרכי ע"ז ומופלג בקדושתו, ולא כרשעי זמננו שאומרים שאפשר שתהי' גאולה ע"י רשעים וכופרים, ומ"ש החרטומים אין אנו יודעים אם ישראל אם מצרי, לא הי' ספיקותם אם יהי' מצרי ועושה מעשה מצרי, כי השיגו, שבן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם כמ"ש המצרים, אמנם הם השיגו ג"כ שלאהבת ד' את ישראל, עושה עמהם נסים גם שלא כדרך הטבע ואם רצונו שיהי' גואלם בן מצרי ואעפ"כ יתנהג בקדושתו וראוי להיות גואלם, קוב"ה ירחיש לי' ניסא ולא ירגישו בו המצרים, וכמו שהי' באמת שאף שהי' משרע"ה ביניהם מ' שנה ומתנהג בדרכי הפרישות והקדושה לא הרגישו בו כלל, וע"כ לא הכחישו את האצטגנינות שיהי' בן מצרי ע"ד האפשר, ועדיין עמדו בספיקותם אם ישראל אם מצרי הוא, ואולם לא גילו להמצריים טעמם ונימוקם, שלאהבת ד' את ישראל עושה להם נסים שלא כדרך הטבע, כי חששו שאם יודיעו להם גדולתן של ישראל לא ישמעו לעצתם ויעלה מורך בלבבם להרע להם, ובבעה"ת פ' מקץ הביאו מדרש שע"כ צוה נבוכדנצר להרוג החרטומים, לפי שא"ל החרטומים האיך אתה סבור שנאמר לך החלום, וכי נביאים אנחנו, ואהרן איננו הנושא אורים ותומים להגיד הנעלמים, א"ל נבוכדנצר הזכרתני אורים ותומים, ובעצתכם הרגתי הכהנים שנושאים אותה, חייכם שתאבדו מן העולם עכ"ל, ועד"ז היתה יראתם גם כאן לגלות גדולת ישראל, ולפי שלא גילו טעמם ע"כ החליטו המצריים שבן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם, והיתה סיבה מאת ד' שירחיקו מלבם אפשרות זו שבן מצרי יהי' הגואל, ועי"ז ניצול משרע"ה מחשדתם .
translation: And from now on we will understand the reason for their disputes, and it is possible that the magicians and also the multitude of Egypt all realized that it is impossible for the Redeemer of Israel to be anything other than one who is separated from the ways of idolatry and exalted in his holiness, and not like the wicked of our time who say that it is possible for redemption to come through the wicked and the heretics. And what the magicians said, "We do not know if he is an Israelite or an Egyptian," their doubt was not whether he would be an Egyptian and act like an Egyptian, for they understood that a son of an Egyptian would never redeem them, as the Egyptians said. However, they also understood that out of love for God for Israel, He performs miracles for them even contrary to the natural order, and if it is His will for the Redeemer to be a son of an Egyptian, and nevertheless he would conduct himself in holiness and be worthy of being their Redeemer, the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform miracles for him and the Egyptians would not perceive it, just as it was indeed that even though Moses was among them for forty years and conducted himself in the ways of separation and holiness, they did not perceive him at all. Therefore, they did not deny the astrology that he could be a son of an Egyptian, and they still stood in their doubts whether he was an Israelite or an Egyptian. However, they did not reveal to the Egyptians their reasoning and argument, that out of love for God for Israel, He performs miracles for them contrary to the natural order, for they feared that if they informed them of the greatness of Israel, they would not heed their counsel and fear would rise in their hearts to do them harm. And in the Talmud, Parashat Miketz, it is brought that Nebuchadnezzar commanded to kill the magicians, for they said to him, "How do you think we can tell you the dream? Are we prophets? And Aaron is not the one who bears the Urim and Thummim to reveal the hidden." Nebuchadnezzar said to them, "You reminded me of the Urim and Thummim, and by your counsel, I killed the priests who bear it; I swear that you will be lost from the world." Thus, their fear was also here to reveal the greatness of Israel, and because they did not reveal their reasoning, the Egyptians concluded that a son of an Egyptian would never redeem them, and it was a reason from God to distance from their hearts this possibility that a son of an Egyptian would be the redeemer, and thereby Moses was saved from their suspicion.
summary: The passage discusses the understanding of the Egyptian magicians regarding the nature of Israel's redemption, emphasizing that a true redeemer must be holy and separate from idolatry, unlike the wicked of their time who believe redemption can come from the sinful. The magicians recognized that God's love for Israel allows for miracles beyond natural laws, and they feared revealing Israel's greatness would lead to their own downfall. Consequently, they concluded that a son of an Egyptian could never redeem them, which was part of God's plan to protect Moses from their suspicions. This reflects the Hasidic belief in divine providence and the unique sanctity of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים אשר לא ידע את יוסף, ובגמרא (סוטה י"א) רב ושמואל ח"א חדש ממש וח"א שנתחדשו גזירותיו מ"ד חדש ממש דכתיב חדש, ומ"ד שנתחדשו גזירותיו דלא כתיב וימת וימלוך, אשר לא ידע את יוסף דהוה דמי כמאן דלא ידע לי' כלל, ויל"ד למ"ד שנתחדשו גזירותיו והמלך הראשון עמד במקומו הא כתיב חדש ואם לטעם שנתחדשו גזירותיו אינו ראוי לקראו חדש, ואין משמעות הפשוטו סובל זה, גם אומרו אשר לא ידע את יוסף אינו מובן איך אפשר שלא הי' מכיר את יוסף, ואפילו למ"ד חדש ממש הרי הי' מאותו הדור שחי בו יוסף, ומי באותו הדור לא הי' מכיר את יוסף, ומה שדרשו עשה עצמו כאילו לא ידע את יוסף צ"ב, דהרי מה שעשה עצמו הי' דמיון כוזב ומדוע יכתוב התוה"ק דבר שאינו אמת, וכל הענין צ"ב מה צורך להודעה זו שהודיענו הכתוב ויקם מלך חדש ומנפק"מ אם הי' חדש או לא, ועיקר הרצון להודיענו סיבות השתלשלות הגזירות והגלות, ומהותו ואיכותו של פרעה לא מעלה ומוריד.
translation: And a new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph. And in the Gemara (Sotah 11), Rav and Shmuel argue: one says it was truly new, and one says that his decrees were renewed. One says it was truly new, as it is written "new," and one says that his decrees were renewed, for it is not written "and he died and reigned." The phrase "who did not know Joseph" is like one who does not know him at all. And it can be understood according to the opinion that his decrees were renewed, that the first king remained in his place. However, it is written "new," and if it is for the reason that his decrees were renewed, it is not fitting to call him "new." The simple meaning does not support this. Also, the statement "who did not know Joseph" is not understood; how could it be that he did not recognize Joseph? Even according to the opinion that it was truly new, he was from the same generation in which Joseph lived, and who in that generation would not recognize Joseph? And what they expounded, that he made himself as if he did not know Joseph, is puzzling, for what he did was a false pretense, and why would the Holy Torah write something that is not true? The entire matter is puzzling; what is the need for this notification that the text informed us, "And a new king arose"? What is the practical difference if he was new or not? The main intention is to inform us of the reasons for the unfolding of the decrees and the exile, and the essence and quality of Pharaoh do not elevate or diminish.
summary: The passage discusses the emergence of a new king in Egypt who did not recognize Joseph, exploring the implications of this ignorance. It raises questions about the nature of the king's new decrees and the theological significance of his actions, suggesting that his refusal to acknowledge Joseph symbolizes a deeper spiritual disconnection from the past. The text emphasizes the importance of understanding the reasons behind the oppression and exile of the Israelites, highlighting the king's role in the unfolding of divine providence and the historical continuity of the Jewish experience. Ultimately, it reflects on the tension between historical reality and spiritual truth within the context of Jewish suffering and redemption.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר מאמרם ז"ל חגיגה (דף ט"ו ע"א) יצתה בת קול ואמרה שובו בנים שובבים חוץ מאחר, ולפי פשוטו הכוונה על אלישע בן אבוי' שכינוהו חז"ל אחר עיי"ש בגמ ', ומבואר בספה"ק דאף שנטרד ע"י בת קול מ"מ אם הי' דוחק א"ע לעשות תשובה היו מקבלים אותו, ופי' השלה"ק ברמז אמרם ז"ל (פסחים פ"ו ע"ב) כל מה שאומר לך בעה"ב עשה חוץ מצא הכוונה על הבוי"ת , שאף היכא דלא מהני תשובה: מ"מ אם דוחקין א"ע לעשות תשובה בוודאי נתקבל, והנה גם בחטא הידוע אמרו רז"ל בזוה"ק דלא מהני תשובה כלל, ובמקום אחד אמרו דמהני רק תיובתא סגי, וכבר האריכו בזה בספה"ק דאיך אפ"ל דלא מהני תשובה ואין לך דבר העומד בפני התשובה.
translation: And we will explain in advance the statement of our Sages, of blessed memory, in Chagigah (15a) that a heavenly voice went out and said, "Return, wayward children, except for Acher." According to its simple meaning, this refers to Elisha ben Abuyah, who was called Acher by our Sages, as explained there in the Gemara. It is clarified in the holy books that even though he was driven away by the heavenly voice, if he had exerted himself to repent, he would have been accepted. And the explanation of the holy Zohar regarding the saying of our Sages (Pesachim 86b) "Whatever the master of the house tells you to do, do, except for the matter of the Ba'alei Teshuvah," indicates that even in a case where repentance does not help, if one exerts oneself to repent, he will certainly be accepted. And behold, even regarding the known sin, our Sages said in the Zohar that repentance does not help at all, while in one place they said that only a refutation is sufficient. And they have elaborated on this in the holy books, how can it be said that repentance does not help, when there is nothing that stands before repentance.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of repentance (teshuva) in relation to the Talmudic figure Elisha ben Abuyah, known as "Acher." It emphasizes that even though a divine voice declared that Acher could not return, if he had made a genuine effort to repent, he would have been accepted. The text also references the idea that certain sins may not be rectified through repentance, yet it asserts that the potential for repentance remains powerful and significant, highlighting the tension between divine judgment and the possibility of redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"ל דמ"ש דלא מהני תשובה כוונו בזה לתועלת בעלי תשובה ולטובת נפשם, דבאמת כל אדם צריך לעשות חשבון עם נפשו, כי ע"י החטא נתרחק ונטרד ח"ו בזה ובבא, ובפרט בחטא הידוע שנבראים מזה מקטריגים ר"ל שטורדים את האדם ונתרחק על ידם משורש הקדושה, וע"ז עצמו צריך לבכות ולהתאונן שנזכה להתקרב להבוכ"ע , וכעין שפי' ק"ז זלה"ה בייט"פ עה"פ שפכי כמים לבך נוכח פני ה', עפי"מ שפי' טעם על שנוהגין לילך לנהר לומר ותשליך במצולות ים כל חטאתם, דאיתא במד"ר שהמים התחתונים היו בוכים על שנתרחקו משמי מרום, וניחם ה' אותם ליקח מהם מלח לקרבנות וניסוך המים בחג, וזה ענין גלי הים שמתנשאים שרצונם לשוב למעלה למקומם, ומזה יקח האדם מוסר השכל איך ירד אחורנית להתרחק מאת ה', וישוב לישא נפשו אל ה' להתדבק בו, ואם מים התחתונים היו בוכים אנן בעינן למיהוי קמי מלכא . איך יבכה אדם שיש בו נשמת רוח חיים, וזה שהולכין למים לישא ק"ו האמור, והיינו דכתיב שפכי כמים דייקא לבך נוכח פני ה' ר"ל כמו שמים בוכים שרוצים להיות נוכח פני ה', כמו"כ גם האדם ישפוך לבו נוכח פני ה' להיות דבוק בו כל עת ובכל רגע וכו' עכדה"ק , אמנם הזוכה לבחי ' יותר גבוה אף זה הוא דבר קטן בעיניו, והעיקר אצלו בכוונת התשובה רק למלאות רצון הבוי"ת , ואינו מביט על תועלת עצמי כלל, וכל כוונתו אך ורק לעשות נחת רוח להבוכ"ע , וכנודע דברי ק"ז זלה"ה היש"מ זלה"ה בדרשתו להושענא רבה שהפציר מאוד בתפלתו הקדושה שיהי' הגאולה שלימה מיד, ואמר שלא לתועלת עצמו מתכוין ואף אם לא יראה אור לעולמים ניחא לי' רק שיתגדל ויתקדש שמי' רבא, ובחינה תשובה כזו הוא חוץ לדרך הטבע ממש, ואפ"ל שע"י שהודיעו רז"ל חומר החטא הזה דלא מהני עלי' תשובה כלל, וע"כ המתאמץ לעשות תשובה ע"ז, בזה גילה דעתו שלא בשביל עצמו הוא עושה תשובה, דהרי לא מהני בלא"ה , אך בשביל רצונו ית ' וזה הוא בחי' גדולה ומעולה מאוד ויתקבל בודאי , ובזה יובן שפיר מ"ש רז"ל דלא מהני תשובה.
translation: And even though it was said that repentance does not help, this was intended for the benefit of the penitent and for the good of their soul, for in truth, every person needs to take account with their soul, because through sin one becomes distant and is disturbed, Heaven forbid, in this world and the next, especially with the known sin from which accusers are created, Heaven forbid, that disturb a person and cause them to be distanced from the root of holiness. For this alone, one should weep and lament that we merit to draw close to the Blessed One, and as it is explained in the Zohar on the verse "Pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord," according to the explanation that it is customary to go to the river to say, "And cast all their sins into the depths of the sea," as it is stated in the Midrash that the lower waters were weeping because they were distanced from the heights of heaven, and the Holy One, blessed be He, comforted them by taking salt from them for the offerings and the water libation on the festival. This is the matter of the waves of the sea that rise up, desiring to return above to their place, and from this, a person should take a lesson in how they have fallen backward to distance themselves from the Lord, and they should return to lift their soul to the Lord to cleave to Him. If the lower waters were weeping, how much more so should a person who has a soul of living spirit weep. This is why they go to the waters to express the a fortiori mentioned, and this is what is written, "Pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord," meaning just as the waters weep desiring to be before the face of the Lord, so too should a person pour out their heart before the face of the Lord to be attached to Him at all times and every moment, etc. However, one who merits a higher level, even this is a small matter in their eyes, and the main thing for them in the intention of repentance is only to fulfill the will of the Creator, and they do not look at their own benefit at all, and all their intention is only to bring pleasure to the Blessed One. As is known from the words of the Zohar, the Holy One, blessed be He, in his sermon for Hoshana Rabbah, who implored very much in his holy prayer that the redemption should be complete immediately, and he said that he does not intend for his own benefit, and even if he does not see light forever, it is pleasing to him only that the great name of the Blessed One be exalted and sanctified. Such a level of repentance is truly beyond the natural order, and it can be said that by informing him of the severity of this sin, that repentance does not help for it at all, therefore, one who strives to repent for this reveals that they are not doing repentance for themselves, for it does not help anyway, but for His will, and this is a very great and exalted level and will certainly be accepted. And in this, it will be understood well what our Sages said that repentance does not help.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of sincere repentance (teshuva) as a means for individuals to reconnect with the Divine, particularly in light of the spiritual dangers posed by sin. It highlights the need for self-reflection and the emotional expression of longing for closeness to God, akin to the tears of water seeking to return to their heavenly source. True repentance should be motivated by the desire to fulfill God's will rather than personal benefit, reflecting a higher spiritual aspiration. This selfless approach to teshuva is seen as a profound and elevated form of devotion that transcends natural inclinations.

passage_content: וע"ד הרמז פירשו בספה"ק שובו בנים שובבים חוץ מאחר עפ"י מאמרם ז"ל (ע"ז י"ט ע"א) אשרי איש ירא את ה' אשרי איש ולא אשרי אשה , אר"ע א"ר אשרי מי שעושה תשובה כשהוא איש, ופירש"י כשהוא בחור בכוחו, כלומר ממהר להכיר בוראו קודם ימי הזקנה עכ"ל, האמנם שגם התשובה שעושין בימי הזקנה מועלת, כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (פ"ב מהל' תשובה) שאפי' עשה תשובה ביום מיתתו כל עונותיו נמחלין . אולם תשובה המעולה כשהאדם שב בבחרותו כשהוא איש, וז"פ שובו בנים שובבים חוץ מאחר, ר"ל טרם הגיעו ימי הזקנה שכבר נחלש כחו ונעשה כאיש אחר, ויזדרז האדם ולא יאחר זמנו רק יעשה תשובה כשהוא עדיין בכוחו והחי יתן אל לבו. ונ"ל להוסיף נופך עפ"י דרכם, דהנה בכל עון שהאדם עושה נעשה פגם בנפש ונשתנה בחינת נפשו לגריעותא , ורואין זאת בחוש שכל מה שהאדם משוקע ר"ל בעונותיו יותר משתנים השקפותיו ורצונותיו ודיעותיו , ומתמעט חשקו ורצונו לענייני קדושה ממה שהי' לו תחילה קודם החטא, ונשתנה לאיש אחר ממש בכל חפצו ורצונותיו, וז"פ שובו בנים שובבים חוץ מאחר, שיעשו תשובה קודם שיתהפך ע"י הרגל החטאים לאיש אחר ממש, אמנם ע"י שחוזרין בתשובה יהפך לאיש אחר לטיבותא וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (פ"ב מה' תשובה הלכה ד') יעיי"ש .
translation:
And regarding the hint, they explained in the holy book "Return, wayward children," except for Acher, according to their saying (Avodah Zarah 19a), "Blessed is the man who fears the Lord, blessed is the man, and not blessed is the woman." Rabbi Eliezer said: "Blessed is he who repents while he is a man," and Rashi explained: "when he is a youth in his strength," meaning he hastens to recognize his Creator before the days of old age. Indeed, even the repentance that one does in the days of old age is effective, as the Rambam wrote (Hilchot Teshuvah 2:1) that even if one repents on the day of his death, all his sins are forgiven. However, the superior repentance is when a person returns in his youth while he is a man, as it is said: "Return, wayward children," except for Acher, meaning before he reaches the days of old age when his strength has already weakened and he has become like another man. And a person should hasten and not delay his time, but rather do repentance while he is still in his strength, and the living should take it to heart. 

And I think it is appropriate to add a nuance according to their way, for behold, in every sin that a person commits, a blemish is made in the soul, and the quality of his soul changes for the worse. This is evident, for the more a person is immersed, so to speak, in his sins, the more his perspectives, desires, and opinions change. His yearning and desire for matters of holiness diminish compared to what he had before the sin, and he truly becomes like another man in all his desires and wishes. Therefore, it is said: "Return, wayward children," that they should repent before they are transformed by the habit of sins into a completely different man. However, by returning in repentance, he will be transformed into another man for the better, as the Rambam wrote (Hilchot Teshuvah 2:4), see there.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of repentance (teshuva) occurring in one's youth, as it is believed to be more effective and transformative than repentance in old age. It highlights that sin causes a deterioration of the soul, altering one's desires and perspectives, leading to a state of spiritual decline. The text encourages individuals to return to their Creator before they become entrenched in sinful habits that fundamentally change their character. Ultimately, through sincere repentance, one can experience a profound transformation for the better, restoring their spiritual essence.

passage_content: עוד נרמז במאמר רז"ל שובו בנים וכו' חוץ מאחר, עפימ"ש המקובלים שע"י החטא לפעמים נתחלף נשמתו בלילה ונדבק בו נשמת עכו"ם או עבד, הביאו המג"א להלכה (סימן מ"ו) שע"כ יכול גם גר לברך ברכת שלא עשני גוי, והכוונה על יציאת נשמתו בלילה שלא נדבק בה נשמת עכו"ם עיי"ש, והנה אם ח"ו נתחלף נשמתו הטהורה חלק אלוקי בנשמת עכו"ם או עבד, אז קשה מאוד לחזור בתשובה מפנימיות הלב, כי אותה הנשמה אינה מסוגלת להשפעת קדושה כזה, וע"כ צריך האדם שיזדרז לחזור בתשובה טרם שיתהפך לאיש אחר בסיבת עונותיו וז"פ שובו בנים שובבים חוץ מאחר, ר"ל קודם שנתחלף לאיש אחר ע"י התחלפות נשמה, וצריך לשום אל הלב ולהרבות בתפלות ותחנונים לפני הקב"ה, ובפרט בימים הללו המסוגלין לתיקון חטא הידוע צריך כ"א להתאמץ שלא יעברו הימים הללו בלא תשובה ותיקון המעשים שנזכה להתקרב לפני הבוכ"ע .
translation: It is also hinted in the saying of our Sages, "Return, O children," etc., except for Acher. According to what the Kabbalists say, that through sin, sometimes a person's soul is exchanged at night, and a soul of a gentile or a servant attaches to him. The Magen Avraham brought this to halacha (Orach Chaim 46) that therefore a convert can also recite the blessing "Who has not made me a gentile," and the intention is regarding the departure of his soul at night so that a gentile soul does not attach to it, as explained there. Now, if, Heaven forbid, his pure soul, a part of God, is exchanged for a soul of a gentile or a servant, then it is very difficult to return in true repentance from the depths of the heart, for that soul is not capable of receiving such holiness. Therefore, a person must hasten to return in repentance before he is transformed into another person due to his sins, as it is said, "Return, O wayward children," except for Acher, meaning before he is transformed into another person through the exchange of souls. One must pay attention to the heart and increase prayers and supplications before the Holy One, Blessed be He, especially in these days which are conducive to the rectification of the known sin. Each person must strive so that these days do not pass without repentance and rectification of deeds, so that we merit to draw closer before the Blessed Creator.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of repentance and the potential danger of a person's soul becoming intertwined with impure influences due to sin. It suggests that if a person's pure soul is replaced by that of a non-Jew or a servant, true repentance from the heart becomes exceedingly difficult. Therefore, individuals are urged to return to repentance before such a transformation occurs, particularly during auspicious times for atonement. The text highlights the necessity of heartfelt prayers and efforts to rectify one's actions to draw closer to God.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל ברמז אמרם ז"ל חוץ מאחר, בהקדם לבאר מאמה"כ ויקם מלך חדש שנחלקו בו חכמז"ל ח"א חדש ממש וח"א שנתחדשו גזירותיו, ובמד"ר יש עוד דעה שלישית רבנן אמרו למה קראו מלך חדש והלא פרעה עצמו הי' אלא שאמרו המצריים לפרעה בא ונזדווג לאומה זו, א"ל שוטים אתם עד עכשיו משלהם אנו אוכלים והאיך נזדווג להם, אילולא יוסף לא היינו חיים, כיון שלא שמע להם הורידוהו מכסאו ג' חדשים, עד שאמר להם כל מה שאתם רוצים הריני עמכם והשיבו אותו לפיכך כתיב ויקם מלך חדש עכ"ד המדרש, ויש סתירה לזה מדברי המד"ר עה"פ ויאמר אל עמו הבה נתחכמה וגו' הוא התחיל בעצה תחלה לכך לקה תחלה, הוא התחיל בעצה תחלה דכתיב ויאמר אל עמו וגו' והוא לקה תחלה דכתיב ובכה ובעמך ובכל עבדיך וגו' ובמאמר הנ"ל דרשו רז"ל שלא רצה להרע לישראל עד שהורידוהו מכסאו ג' חדשים, והוא סתירה למ"ש הוא התחיל בעצה תחלה, גם צ"ב דלא יעלה על הדעת שהי' פרעה הרשע אוהב את ישראל, ואיך פתאום הי' לו מסנ"פ כזה שסבל בשביל הצלתם הורדה ממשלתו על ג' חדשים.
translation:
It can also be said in a hint, as our sages of blessed memory said, aside from Aharon, to first explain from the verse, "And a new king arose." There is a dispute among the sages: some say it was a completely new king, and others say it was the same king whose decrees were renewed. In the Midrash, there is a third opinion; the Rabbis said, "Why was he called a new king? Wasn't it Pharaoh himself?" Rather, the Egyptians said to Pharaoh, "Come, let us join with this nation." He replied, "You fools! Until now we have been eating from their produce, and how can we join with them? If it weren't for Joseph, we would not be alive." Since he did not listen to them, they removed him from his throne for three months, until he said to them, "Whatever you want, I am with you," and they returned him. Therefore, it is written, "And a new king arose." Thus far is the Midrash. 

There is a contradiction to this from the words of the Midrash on the verse, "And he said to his people, 'Come, let us be wise...'" He began with counsel first; therefore, he was struck first. He began with counsel first, as it is written, "And he said to his people..." and he was struck first, as it is written, "And I will weep over you and your people and all your servants..." And in the aforementioned statement, our sages derived that he did not want to do evil to Israel until they removed him from his throne for three months, and this contradicts the statement that he began with counsel first. It is also difficult to understand that it would not enter one's mind that the wicked Pharaoh loved Israel, and how suddenly he had such a change of heart that he suffered for their salvation, leading to the removal of his government for three months.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of a "new king" arising in Egypt, with differing interpretations among the sages regarding whether this refers to a completely new ruler or a change in Pharaoh's decrees. It highlights the tension between Pharaoh's initial reluctance to harm the Israelites and his eventual oppressive actions, suggesting that his temporary humility was a façade. The text emphasizes the complexity of divine providence and the interplay of human agency, illustrating how even a wicked ruler can be influenced by higher spiritual forces for the sake of the Jewish people. Ultimately, it reflects on the paradox of Pharaoh's character and the unfolding of God's plan for Israel's redemption.

passage_content: עוד איתא במד"ר (שם) רבנן פתחין פתחא להאי קרא (הושע ב') בה' בגדו כי בנים זרים ילדו עתה יאכלם חדש את חלקיהם, ללמדך כשמת יוסף הפרו ברית מילה אמרו נהי' כמצריים, וכיון שעשו כן הפך הקב"ה האהבה שהיו המצריים אוהבין אותן לשנאה שנאמר (תהלים ק"ה) הפך לבם לשנוא עמו וכו' וצריך ביאור להבין ענין אהבת ישראל זו שהיו המצריים אוהבין אותן מה טיבו, ולא יצוייר שהרשעים יאהבו את ישראל אהבה גמורה, וכבר אמרתי בזה שלא הי' כוונת פרעה לטובת ישראל במה שלא רצה לשעבד עמהם, אבל התחכם וחשב שעל ידי דרך של התקרבות ואהבה ירחקם יותר משורש הקדושה, וכמבואר בזוהר הקדוש פרשה זו דקשוי השיעבוד וההתרחקות מהמצרים הי' טובה גדולה לישראל, שעי"ז לא נתערבו בין המצריים וזכו לקבל התוה"ק , ע"כ הלך פרעה בדרך זו לקרב אותם והכניס אהבת ישראל בלב המצריים, ופעל בעצתו שרוב גדול מישראל לא רצו לצאת ממצרים ע"י שנתן להם פרעה פטרונים והי' להם כל טוב, וא"ש אמרם ז"ל שפרעה התחיל בעצה תחלה, אך לא בעצת השעבוד אלא עצה יותר רעה ממנה דהיינו דרך אהבה והתקרבות, וידע הבוי"ת שאם ימשכו בדרך הזה לא ישאר ח"ו שריד ופליט לבית ישראל, וע"כ הפך לבם לשנוא עמו וניצולו עי"ז עכ"פ ס' רבוא שיצאו ממצרים.
translation: It is also stated in the Midrash (there) that the Rabbis opened a discussion on this verse (Hosea 2): "For they have dealt treacherously against Me; now they shall eat their children." This teaches us that when Joseph died, they violated the covenant of circumcision and said, "Let us be like the Egyptians." And when they did this, the Holy One, blessed be He, turned the love that the Egyptians had for them into hatred, as it is said (Psalms 105): "He turned their heart to hate His people," etc. It requires explanation to understand the nature of this love of Israel that the Egyptians had for them; what was its essence? It cannot be imagined that the wicked would have a complete love for Israel. I have already said regarding this that Pharaoh's intention was not for the good of Israel when he did not want to enslave them, but he was cunning and thought that through a path of closeness and love, they would be distanced even more from the root of holiness. As is explained in the holy Zohar, this matter of the difficulty of servitude and the distancing from the Egyptians was a great benefit for Israel, for through this they did not mix with the Egyptians and merited to receive the Torah. Therefore, Pharaoh went this way to draw them close and instilled love for Israel in the hearts of the Egyptians, and by his counsel, a large majority of Israel did not want to leave Egypt because Pharaoh provided them with comforts and they had all good things. And it is understood what our Sages said that Pharaoh began with counsel first, but not with the counsel of servitude, rather with a counsel worse than that, namely the way of love and closeness. And the Blessed One knew that if they were drawn along this path, Heaven forbid, there would not remain a remnant or survivor of the House of Israel. Therefore, He turned their hearts to hate His people, and through this, at least six hundred thousand were saved who left Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Egyptians' initial love for the Israelites, which was a strategic ploy by Pharaoh to distance them from their spiritual roots through false affection rather than outright oppression. This approach aimed to keep the Israelites comfortable and complacent, ultimately leading to their spiritual degradation. However, God intervened by transforming the Egyptians' hearts to hatred, which ultimately facilitated the Israelites' liberation and preservation of their identity. This reflects the Hasidic belief in divine providence, where even negative circumstances can lead to positive outcomes for the Jewish people.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד לבאר במאמה"כ (פ' וירא) וה' אמר המכסה אני מאברהם וגו' כי ידעתיו למען אשר יצוה את בניו ואת ביתו אחריו ושמרו דרך ה' וגו' פירש"י ז"ל כי ידעתיו לשון חבה וכו' ולמה ידעתיו למען אשר יצוה , לפי שהוא מצוה את בניו עלי לשמור דרכי, ואם תפרשהו כתרגומו ארי גלי קדמי, יודע אני בו שיצוה את בניו וגו' אין למען נופל על הלשון עכ"ל, ולכאורה צריך להבין פי' התרגום שהוא מפי ר"א ור"י ואמרז"ל שניתנה מסיני, ואיך יתפרש הפסוק לפי' התרגום. ויתבאר ע"ד הכתוב בפרשה זו וירא אלקים את בנ"י וידע אלקים , פירש"י נתן עליהם לב ולא העלים עיניו עכ"ל, והכוונה כי סר מעליהם הסתרת פנים שהי' עד עכשיו, וכן פי' תרגום אונקלוס וגלי קדם ה' שעבודא דבנ"י , ובתרגום יונתן פי' באופן אחר וגלי קדמוי ית תיובתא דעבדו בטומרא דלא ידעו אנש בחברי' וכן דרשו במד"ר וירא אלקים שעשו תשובה וכו' וידע אלקים שאפי' אחד בחבירו לא הי' יודע אלא הקב"ה לבדו, ואף שהיו משוקעים מאד מהשיעבוד אעפ"כ הי' להם הרהורי תשובה ולא היו מכירין בהם ורק הבוכ"ע ידע פנימיות לבם, עכ"פ ידיעת אלקים מורה על ידיעה הפנימיות שבלב שאין זולתו יודע כ"א הבוי"ת הבוחן כליות ולב.
translation:
And we will further explain in the verse (Parashat Vayera) "And the Lord said, 'Shall I hide from Abraham... for I have known him, in order that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord...'" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "I have known him" is a term of affection, etc. And why "I have known him" in order that he may command? Because he commands his children to keep My ways. And if you interpret it according to its translation, "for I know that he will command his children," the term "in order that" does not apply to the language. Thus far the text. 

And at first glance, one must understand the interpretation of the translation, which is from the mouths of Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua, and our sages of blessed memory said that it was given from Sinai, and how the verse can be interpreted according to the translation. 

And it will be explained according to the verse in this section, "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew." Rashi explains that He gave them a heart and did not hide His eyes from them. Thus far the text. The intention is that He removed the concealment of His face that had been until now. Similarly, the translation of Onkelos states, "And He revealed before the Lord the servitude of the children of Israel." And in Jonathan's translation, it is explained differently: "And He revealed before Him the toil of those who did not know one another." And so it is expounded in the Midrash, "And God saw that they repented," etc., and "God knew that even one among his fellow would not know, but only the Holy One, blessed be He, alone." And even though they were very sunk in the servitude, nevertheless they had thoughts of repentance and did not recognize them, and only the Holy One, blessed be He, knew the innermost of their hearts. In any case, God's knowledge indicates an inner knowledge of the heart that no one else knows except for the Creator, who examines the kidneys and the heart.
summary: The passage discusses God's intimate knowledge of Abraham, emphasizing that this knowledge is rooted in love and is linked to Abraham's commitment to instruct his descendants in God's ways. It contrasts different interpretations of divine knowledge, highlighting that while others may not perceive the inner thoughts of individuals, God alone understands the true intentions of the heart. This reflects a central Hasidic concept of God's omniscience and the importance of inner spiritual awareness, even amidst external struggles and challenges. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true repentance and connection to God are known only to Him.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר מאמה"כ כי ידעתיו למען אשר יצוה את בניו וגו' ושמרו דרך ה' וגו' למען הביא ה' על אברהם את אשר דבר עליו, דלכאורה מה רבותי' דאברהם אבינו שכך הוא מצוה את בניו ושמרו דרך ה' ומצוי גם בסתם בנ"א אם לא נפסדו עדיין בדיעות נפסדות, גם הם מצווים ומדריכים את בניהם שישמרו דרך ה', ואף אם הם בעצמם לא יוכלו שליט ביצרם מ"מ יש להם תשוקה ורצון להדריך בניהם שישמרו התורה ומצות, ומהו הרבותא שמשבח הכתוב לאאע"ה בכך. אך נראה שיש בזה ענין עמוק, כי מי שחפץ באמת שבניו ילכו בדרך ה', צריך מקודם לקשר לבב עצמו להבוכ"ע ביראת ה' כל היום, וכעין שפי' ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה (פ' נח) הכתוב יראת ה' טהורה עומדת לעד, עפי"מ שכתבו בספה"ק ההבדל בין יראת עונש ליראת הרוממת, כי הירא מכח סיבת העונש אותה יראה אינו יכול להורישה לבניו כי איננה קנין עצמי, אבל הירא מרוממותו יתעלה, אותה יראה מוריש ומנחיל לבניו אחריו, והיינו דכתיב מי יתן והי' לבבם זה להם ליראה אותי וגו' דייקא כל הימים יראה תמידית, למען ייטב להם ולבניהם לעולם, וז"ש מתהלך בתומו צדיק אשרי בניו אחריו עכ"ד, וז"ש יראת ה' טהורה עומדת לעד כלומר לדורותיו אחריו, עיי"ש. וכמו"כ אברהם אבינו הי' מקשט ומטהר את נפשו לא בשביל תועלת עצמי, אדרבה הפקיר נפשו וכל מאודו בשביל לעשות רצון קונו, וזהו אשר נשאר לדורותיו שיתקיימו לעד ולא תשכח מפי זרעו, ואף בגודל השפלות כל הקיום שלנו רק בזכות האבות הקדושים ובכח עבודתם שעבדו הבוי"ת בכל לבם ונפשם, וז"פ הכ ' כי ידעתיו שהקב"ה נתן לב עליו לידע פנימיות לבבו איך הוא מטהר ומקדש עצמו וכח זה ישאר נצחי לדורות, והכוונה באומרו כי ידעתיו ע"ד שאמה"כ וידע אלקים , שהי' גלוי וידוע לפניו ית ' פנימיות לבבו, מה שעבד השי"ת במסנ"פ והשתוקקות גדולה עד להפליא כדי שיהי' בטוח בדורות הבאים אחריו שישמרו דרך ה' וגו', ולפי"ז שפיר נופל לשון למען אף לפי' התרגום, כי אין כוונת הידיעה על מה שהוא מצוה את בניו וביתו אחריו, רק על בחינת העבודה שלו בפנימית הלב, איך הוא מוסר נפשו בעבדות השי"ת, והכל למען אשר יצוה את בניו וביתו אחריו שיהי' בטוח בבניו אחריו שילכו בדרך השי"ת, וזהו יסוד גדול בענין חינוך הבנים לקשט את עצמו תחילה בפנימיות הלב ואז ישאר השפעת הקדושה אחריו לדורותיו.
translation:
And similarly, it will be explained from the verse, "For I have known him, so that he will command his children..." that they should keep the way of the Lord, in order that the Lord may bring upon Abraham what He has spoken about him. It seems, my friends, that Abraham our father commands his children to keep the way of the Lord, and it is also common among ordinary people, if they have not yet been corrupted by erroneous beliefs; they too command and guide their children to keep the way of the Lord. Even if they themselves cannot control their own desires, they still have a longing and desire to guide their children to observe the Torah and commandments. What is the greatness that the scripture praises our father Abraham for this? However, it appears that there is a deep matter here, for one who truly desires that his children walk in the way of the Lord must first connect his own heart to the Creator with the fear of the Lord all day long. This is similar to what is explained in the verse, "The fear of the Lord is pure, enduring forever," as it is written in the holy books about the difference between the fear of punishment and the elevated fear. The one who fears due to the cause of punishment cannot pass that fear on to his children, as it is not a personal acquisition. But the one who fears His exaltedness, that fear he can inherit and bequeath to his children after him. This is what is written, "Oh, that they had such a heart as this, to fear Me..."—specifically a constant fear, so that it may be well with them and their children forever. This is what is meant by "The righteous walks in his integrity; blessed are his children after him." Thus, the fear of the Lord is pure, enduring forever, meaning for his generations after him. 

And likewise, Abraham our father adorned and purified his soul not for his own benefit; on the contrary, he devoted his soul and all his might to fulfill the will of his Creator. This is what remains for his generations, to be established forever and not to be forgotten from the mouths of his descendants. Even in the greatest lowliness, all our existence is only by virtue of the holy patriarchs and through the power of their service, which they served the Blessed One with all their heart and soul. Therefore, it is written, "For I have known him," that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him a heart to know the inner workings of his heart, how he purifies and sanctifies himself. This power will remain eternal for generations. The intention in saying "For I have known him" is in the manner of "And God knew," that it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, the inner workings of his heart, what he served the Holy One with great yearning and longing, to the point of wonder, so that he would be assured that the generations coming after him would keep the way of the Lord. According to this, the phrase "for" fits well, even according to the translation, for the intention of the knowledge is not about what he commands his children and household after him, but rather about the nature of his service in the inner heart, how he gives his soul in the service of the Holy One. All this is for the purpose of commanding his children and household after him, that he may be assured that his children after him will walk in the way of the Holy One. This is a great principle regarding the education of children: to first adorn oneself in the inner heart, and then the influence of holiness will remain with him for his generations.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of a parent's inner spiritual connection to God as a prerequisite for effectively guiding their children in the ways of the Lord. It distinguishes between two types of fear of God: one based on punishment, which cannot be inherited, and a higher, reverent fear that can be passed down. Abraham's dedication to serving God selflessly ensured that his spiritual legacy would endure through his descendants. Ultimately, the text underscores that true education of children begins with the parent's own spiritual refinement and devotion.

passage_content: עכ"פ מלת ידיעה משמש ב' לשונות לשון אהבה וחיבה כפירש"י , ולשון ידיעה והכרה כפי' התרגום, ובזה יתפרש לשון הכתוב ויקם מלך חדש אשר לא ידע את יוסף. דהנה מתחלה היו פרעה והמצריים אוהבים את ישראל כמבואר במדרש הנ"ל ואח"כ הפך הקב"ה אהבתם לשנאה, מגודל רחמנותו על ישראל שלא יתערבו ח"ו בין המצריים, ולז"א ויקם מלך חדש אשר לא ידע את יוסף, ויתפרש ידיעה מלשון חיבה שלא הרגיש אהבה ליוסף ולישראל שכולם היו גידולי יוסף, וזה לא הי' דמיון כ"א באמת לא ידע את יוסף, ושפיר כתבה התוה"ק אשר לא ידע את יוסף לפרש"י בפ ' וירא שפי' מלשון חיבה, אמנם בחיצוניותו עדיין הי' בוש להראות שנאה כבושה כ"כ נגד ישראל, מפני כבודו של יוסף שבזכותו היו חיים עד עכשיו, לזה עשה את עצמו כאילו אינו יודע ואינו מכיר את יוסף. נמצא דמאמה"כ אשר לא ידע את יוסף יתפרש בשני הפירושים כפי' רש"י ופי' התרגום, לפי פירש"י הי' אמת גמור שלא הי' לו אהבה וחיבה ליוסף ומה"ט נכתב בתורה שהאמת כן הי', גם מרומז בה הדרש שעשה א"ע כאילו לא ידע את יוסף ויתפרש מלת ידע כפי' התרגום, וזה הי' דמיון כוזבת, אלא שהשנאה הכבושה בלבו הביא אותו לכך, ושני הפירושים איתנייהו ותלויים זב"ז .
translation: In any case, the word "knowledge" serves two meanings: the language of love and affection, as Rashi explains, and the language of knowledge and recognition, as the translation interprets. With this, the language of the verse "And a new king arose who did not know Joseph" can be explained. Initially, Pharaoh and the Egyptians loved Israel, as is clarified in the aforementioned Midrash, and afterwards, God turned their love into hatred, out of great compassion for Israel, so that they would not mix, Heaven forbid, with the Egyptians. Therefore, it says, "And a new king arose who did not know Joseph," and the term "knowledge" is interpreted in the sense of affection, meaning he did not feel love for Joseph and for Israel, who were all descendants of Joseph. This was not merely a pretense; he truly did not know Joseph. Thus, the Torah correctly states "who did not know Joseph" according to Rashi's interpretation in the context of "and he saw," which is interpreted as a language of affection. However, outwardly, he was still ashamed to show such a deep-seated hatred against Israel, due to the honor of Joseph, by whose merit they had survived until now. For this reason, he acted as if he did not know and did not recognize Joseph. It follows that from the phrase "who did not know Joseph," it can be interpreted in both ways according to Rashi's interpretation and the translation's interpretation. According to Rashi's interpretation, it was entirely true that he had no love or affection for Joseph, and for this reason, it is written in the Torah that the truth was indeed so. It is also hinted in the interpretation that he acted as if he did not know Joseph, and the word "knowledge" can be interpreted according to the translation, which was a false pretense, but the concealed hatred in his heart led him to this. Both interpretations are valid and interconnected.
summary: The passage discusses the dual meanings of the Hebrew word "knowledge," which can signify both love and recognition. It explains that initially, Pharaoh and the Egyptians loved the Israelites, but God transformed their love into hatred to protect the Israelites from assimilation. The phrase "a new king who did not know Joseph" indicates that Pharaoh genuinely lacked affection for Joseph and the Israelites, despite outwardly pretending ignorance due to his respect for Joseph's legacy. This dual interpretation highlights the complex interplay between genuine feelings and the facade of ignorance driven by concealed animosity.

passage_content: א"י עפי"מ שפירשתי (פ' בהעלותך) מה דאיתא במדרש רבה (פרשת לך פ' מ"ב סי' ג') ויהי בימי אחז מה צרה היתה שם וכו' כך אמר אחז אם אין גדיים אין תיישים וכו' אם אין קטנים אין תלמידים אם אין תלמידים אין חכמים וכו' למה נקרא שמו אחז שאחז בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות ע"כ, ובפשטות הכוונה שביטל בתי מדרשות ולא הניח שילמדו תורה, אם כן לכאורה אין שייך לקרותו אחז על שם שאחז בתכנ"ס דאדרבה ביטל אותם. ומילת אחז משמעותו להיפוך שאחז בהם להחזיקם ולקיימם, ופירשתי דלפי שרצה בביטול בתכנ"ס , התחכם שאם ילך בכח כפי' וגזירות לא יועילו מעשיו, שבנ"י ילמדו תורה במסנ"פ , לזה הלך בדרכו של פרעה להראות התקרבות ואהבה, ופיזר ממון להחזיק ישיבות ובתי מדרשות, ובזה יכניס שיטתו בלב לומדי תורה, ומעצמם יבטלו אח"כ בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות, כמו שרואין דרך הזה בדורינו , שהרשעים עוקרי הדת מתאמצים ורוצים בהחזקת ישיבות ובתי ת"ת, ויודעים שזהו ביטולה של תורה ר"ל, מה שרשעים מחזיקים בקיומם של בתי מדרשות, ובזה יובן דברי התרגום דמתחלה כשהלך פרעה בדרך של התקרבות ואהבה, שזה לא הי' לטובת ישראל וכנ"ל, רק אדרבה להרחיק אותם עי"ז מן הקדושה, הי' פרעה עצמו מחזיק בתי מדרשות במצרים שיוכלו ישראל ללמוד שם תורה ולקיים גזירת יוסף, היינו גזירת אורייתא שגזרו יוסף והשבטים הק ', וכמ"ש ואת יהודה שלח לפניו אל יוסף להורות לפניו גושנה ופירש"י לתקן לו בית תלמוד שמשם תצא הוראה, ופרעה עצמו הי' מחזיק בידם מכיס המלוכה שעי"ז יתרחקו מן הקדושה, אבל אח"כ שינה את דרכו דרך התקרבות, כנ"ל במדרש שהמצריים לא רצו בזה ונקטו להם דרך של שנאה גלוי', ומאז לא קיימו עוד גזירת יוסף.
translation: Eretz Yisrael, according to what I explained (in Parashat Beha'alotecha), regarding what is stated in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Lech Lecha, Parashah 42, Section 3): "And it was in the days of Ahaz, what trouble was there?" etc. Thus said Ahaz: "If there are no kids, there are no rams," etc. "If there are no small ones, there are no students; if there are no students, there are no sages," etc. Why is he called Ahaz? Because he held onto synagogues and houses of study. Therefore, in simple terms, the intention is that he abolished the houses of study and did not allow the Torah to be learned. If so, it seems inappropriate to call him Ahaz for holding onto the synagogues, for on the contrary, he abolished them. The word "Ahaz" means to hold onto, to support, and to maintain. I explained that since he desired the abolition of the synagogues, he cunningly thought that if he acted with force, as per the interpretations and decrees, his actions would not help, for the Jewish people would learn Torah in secret. Therefore, he followed the path of Pharaoh to show closeness and love, and he dispersed money to support yeshivas and houses of study, and through this, he would instill his approach into the hearts of the Torah learners, and they would subsequently abolish the synagogues and houses of study themselves, as we see this way in our generation, where the wicked, uprooters of the faith, strive and desire to support yeshivas and houses of Torah, knowing that this is the abolition of the Torah, Heaven forbid. What the wicked support in the existence of houses of study, thus the words of the translation will be understood: Initially, when Pharaoh went the way of closeness and love, this was not for the benefit of Israel, as mentioned above, but rather to distance them from holiness. Pharaoh himself held onto the houses of study in Egypt so that Israel could learn Torah there and fulfill the decree of Joseph, which is the decree of the Torah that Joseph and the holy tribes decreed, as it is written: "And he sent Judah before him to Joseph to instruct before him a house of study," and Rashi explains: "to establish for him a house of learning from which instruction would come forth." And Pharaoh himself was holding them with the royal treasury, so that they would distance themselves from holiness. But afterwards, he changed his path to one of closeness, as mentioned in the Midrash, that the Egyptians did not want this and took a path of open hatred, and since then they no longer upheld the decree of Joseph.
summary: The passage discusses the character of King Ahaz, who is portrayed as undermining the study of Torah by appearing to support synagogues and schools while secretly seeking their destruction. It highlights the deceptive strategy of using outward support to lead the Jewish people away from holiness, similar to Pharaoh's initial approach of fostering closeness to the Israelites while ultimately aiming to distance them from their spiritual roots. The text emphasizes the danger of false support that can mask a deeper intent to weaken religious observance and the importance of remaining vigilant against such tactics.

passage_content: ומה שקורא אותו מלך חדש נל"פ עפי"מ דאיתא בגמ' (סנהדרין ק"ה ע"א) אר"נ חוצפא אפי' כלפי שמיא מהני, מעיקרא כתיב (בבלעם) לא תלך עמהם ולבסוף כתיב קום לך אתם, ולכאורה הוא פלא, התינח לגבי בנ"א יתכן לומר שחוצפא מועלת להיעשות רצונו מפני היראה. אבל כלפי שמיא איך שייך שחוצפה ישנה דעתו ורצונו ית ' חס מלהזכיר ובאמת יש טעם אחר בגמ' (מכות י') מדוע בתחלה אמר לו הקב"ה לא תלך עמהם ואח"כ קום לך אתם, דבדרך שאדם רוצה לילך בה מוליכין אותו דכתיב לא תלך עמהם וכתיב קום לך אתם, ונקדים עוד מאמרז"ל שם אמר רב ששת חוצפא מלכותא בלא תאגא , דכתיב ואנכי היום רך ומשוח מלך והאנשים האלה בני צרוי ' קשים ממני וגו', פירש"י מלכותא בלא תגא כלומר שררה גדולה ואינו חסר אלא כתר מלכות, אנכי היום רך וגו' כלומר איני גדול מהם אלא משיחת מלכות עכ"ל וצ"ב הכוונה.
translation: And what is meant by the phrase "a new king arose"? It seems to be in accordance with what is stated in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 105a) that Rabbi Nachman said, "Chutzpah even before Heaven is effective." Initially, it is written (regarding Balaam) "Do not go with them," and in the end, it is written, "Get up and go with them." At first glance, this is a wonder. This can be understood regarding human beings; it is possible to say that chutzpah is effective in fulfilling one's will due to fear. But how does chutzpah apply before Heaven? How can it change His will, may He be spared from mention? In truth, there is another reason in the Gemara (Makkot 10) why at first the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Do not go with them," and afterwards, "Get up and go with them." It is because "In the way that a person wishes to go, they lead him," as it is written, "Do not go with them," and it is written, "Get up and go with them." We will also introduce another teaching of our Sages there, where Rav Sheshet said, "Chutzpah is a kingdom without a crown," as it is written, "And I today am soft and anointed king, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too harsh for me," etc. Rashi explains that "a kingdom without a crown" means a great authority, and it lacks only the crown of kingship. "I today am soft," etc., means that I am not greater than them, but rather from the anointing of kingship. Thus, the intention is to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chutzpah" (audacity) in relation to divine will, referencing a Talmudic discussion about Balaam's changing directives from God. Initially, God instructs Balaam not to go with the people, but later permits him to do so, illustrating that one's desires can influence their path. The text also highlights the idea that audacity can lead to authority, suggesting that even in the face of divine command, human determination can alter outcomes. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay between human agency and divine will.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי המהרש"א במס' מכות (דף י') לפרש אמרם ז"ל בדרך שאדם רוצה לילך מוליכין אותו, וז"ל הכוונה הוא שידוע שכל מחשבה דיבור ומעשה האדם הנה הוא בורא לו מלאך לפי עניינו אם לטוב אם לרע, ולכן כפי רצונו ודעתו של האדם מוליכין אותו אותן המלאכים הנבראים מאותו רצון ומחשבה אשר בו עיי"ש שהאריך, וכוונתו דאותו המלאך רע שנברא מרצונו הרע, הוא שאמר לו קום לך אתם היפך רצון הבוב"ה , דלא יתכן שנוי רצון לפניו ית ', אבל לפי שברצונו של בלעם הי' לילך להרע לישראל נבראו ממחשבתו זאת מלאכים רעים. והם שאמרו לו קום לך אתם, ועד"ז יתפרש הכוונה בדברי ר"נ חוצפא כלפי שמיא מהני, אינו ר"ל דמהני לנגד הקב"ה לשנות דעת עליון ח"ו ע"י חוצפא , אלא ר"ל שנבראים ע"י חוצפא מלאכים רעים והם הגומרים ענינו ועושים את רצונו, וכמו שאמרו לבלעם קום לך אתם היפוך רצון השי"ת שאמר לו לא תלך עמהם, נמצא שדרש זה מכוון עם מה שאמרו במס' מכות בדרך שאדם רוצה לילך מוליכין אותו, ושני הדרשות בקנה א' עולים.
translation: And we will explain, at the outset, the words of the Maharsha in Masechet Makkot (page 10) regarding their statement, "In the way that a person wishes to go, they lead him." The intention is that it is known that every thought, speech, and action of a person creates an angel for him according to his nature, whether for good or for evil. Therefore, according to the will and understanding of the person, those angels that are created from that will and thought lead him. As it is elaborated there, and the intention of that evil angel created from his evil will is to say to him, "Get up and go with them," contrary to the will of the Blessed One, for it is impossible to change His will. However, since it was Balaam's desire to go and harm Israel, evil angels were created from that thought of his. They are the ones who said to him, "Get up and go with them." Similarly, the intention in the words of Rabbi Nachman regarding chutzpah towards Heaven is not to say that it is effective against the Holy One, Blessed be He, to change the mind of the Supreme One, Heaven forbid, but rather to say that through chutzpah, evil angels are created, and they fulfill his matter and do his will. Just as they said to Balaam, "Get up and go with them," contrary to the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, who told him not to go with them, it turns out that this interpretation aligns with what they said in Masechet Makkot, "In the way that a person wishes to go, they lead him," and both interpretations are in harmony.
summary: The passage discusses the Hasidic concept that a person's thoughts, words, and actions create angels that reflect their intentions, whether good or bad. It emphasizes that while God's will remains unchanged, individuals can generate negative forces through their desires, as illustrated by the story of Balaam, who was led by his evil intentions despite divine opposition. The text connects this idea to the notion that one's approach to God can influence the creation of these angels, reinforcing the belief that human agency plays a significant role in spiritual dynamics. Ultimately, it highlights the interplay between divine will and human choice in shaping one's spiritual path.
