passage_content: ובזה יובן גם מאמר הסמוכה אליו א"ר ששת חוצפא מלכותא בלא תגא , והכוונה דע"י החוצפא בורא מלאכים רעים והם נותנים בידו כח שררה להרע נגד רצונו ית ', והן הן המחוצפים ועזי פנים שבדור שיש להם שררה ומלוכה ואינו חסר להם אלא כתר מלכות, ומולכין נגד רצון השי"ת שכך היתה רצון הבריאה שיהי' הבחירה חפשית וביד האדם לברוא לו מלאכים רעים ולהעמיד בכוחם מלכותא בלא תגא . וזה ירמוז אמרם ז"ל שובו בנים שובבים חוץ מאחר ר"ל עד שלא ימשלו בו מלאכים רעים מסטרא אחרא בחי' אלהים אחרים. דאז כבר קשה התשובה וכמעט נתבטל בחירתו כמו שאמרו רז"ל בדרך שאדם רוצה לילך מוליכין אותו, היינו אפי' נגד רצונו.
translation: And with this, it will be understood the statement that is adjacent to it: Rabbi Sheshet said, "The audacity of the kingdom is without a crown." The intention is that through audacity, one creates evil angels, and they give him the power of dominion to do evil against His will, blessed be He. These are the audacious and brazen-faced ones of the generation who have dominion and kingship, and they lack nothing but a royal crown. They rule against the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, for such was the will of creation that free choice would exist, and it is in the hands of man to create for himself evil angels and to establish through their power a kingdom without a crown. This hints at what our sages, of blessed memory, said: "Return, wayward children," except for Acher, meaning until evil angels from the other side do not rule over him as if they were other gods. For then, repentance becomes difficult, and his choice is almost nullified, as our sages, of blessed memory, said: "In the way that a person wishes to go, they lead him," meaning even against his will.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chutzpah" (audacity) in relation to the authority of evil forces, suggesting that such audacity can create harmful angels that empower individuals to act against God's will. It highlights the idea that the existence of free choice allows people to generate negative influences, which can lead to a form of dominion that opposes divine intent. The text also emphasizes the importance of repentance, noting that when individuals are overtaken by these negative forces, their ability to return to God becomes significantly more challenging, as their choices may lead them astray even against their own desires. Ultimately, it reflects on the tension between free will and the influence of evil in the world.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ד בתנא דבי אלי' ( א"ז פ"ג) הכל ברא הקב"ה בעולמו חוץ ממדת שקר ומדת עולה שנאמר הצור תמים פעלו וכו ', עושה אדם עצמו לדבר אמת מוסרין לו מלאך שמתנהג עמו בדרך צדיקים ומדבר אמת, ואם עושה אדם עצמו רשע לכחש ולשקר, מוסרים לו מלאך שיתנהג עמו בדרך רשעים ומכחש ומשקר וכו' ע"כ, והנה גם המזיקים ומקטריגים הם בריאה מהקב"ה שכך היתה רצון הבריאה שיהי' עולם הנסיון ולכולם יש שורש מתחלת הבריאה חוץ מאותן המלאכים הנבראים ממדת השקר והעולה אין להם שורש בבריאה רק האדם בעצמו בורא אותם במעשיו. ובזה יובן מה שקראו חכז"ל את היצה"ר בשם מלך זקן וכסיל, ובפשטות נקרא מלך מפני שהוא מושל על האדם וזקן מפני שבא מתחלת לידתו, משא"כ היצ"ט רק כשנעשה בן י"ג שנה, ונקרא כסיל מפני שמכניס רוח כסילות בבנ"א כמשז"ל אין אדם חוטא אא"כ נכנס בו רוח שטות, ולדרכינו נאמר עוד דע"כ נקרא היצה"ר בשם זקן מפני שהוא עומד על שירותו מתחלת הבריאה, שהכל ברא הקב"ה בעולמו גם את היצה"ר והמקטריגים , ולזה נקרא זקן, משא"כ אותן המקטריגים שנבראים מהשקר ועולה הם בריאה חדשה ואינם ראויים להקרא בשם מלך זקן אלא מלך חדש, שיש להם מלכות ושררה על האדם כמו שפירשנו חוצפא מלכותא בלא תגא אבל הם חדשים מקרוב באו, ולא היו מתחלת הבריאה וגם אינם משעת לידה כמו היצה"ר , וז"ש הכתוב ויקם מלך חדש על מצרים, שנתחדשו גזירותיו על ישראל וע"י מדת העולה ברא מלאך רע לפי ענינו והוא חדש ממש שאין לו שורש מתחלת הבריאה, והמלאך הרע נעשה מלך על מצרים כי כל תהלוכות המדינה ע"י המלך, והוא עצמו הי' מתנהג ע"י המלאך הרע שנברא מרצונו, ושפיר אמר ויקם מלך חדש חדש ממש, ומ"ש אשר לא ידע את יוסף קאי ג"כ על אותו המלאך שהוא מלך החדש אשר קם על מצרים, ובאמת לא ידע את יוסף כי לא הי' עדיין בעולם בחייו של יוסף, ומה שדרשו ז"ל עשה א"ע כאילו לא ידע את יוסף הכוונה על פרעה שהי' מרכבה אליו והוא ידע את יוסף אלא שעשה א"ע כאילו לא ידע והלך בדרך כוזב, נמצא דב' הדרשות שדרשו חז"ל במאמה"כ ויקם מלך חדש אשר לא ידע את יוסף שניהם קיימים ואמיתיים ותליין חדא בחבירתא דע"י שעשה עצמו כאילו לא ידע את יוסף וחידש גזירותיו ברא לו מלאך ממדת השקר ועולה ואותו המלאך לא ידע את יוסף באמת, שלא הי' עוד בעולם בחייו של יוסף ושפיר אמר אשר לא ידע את יוסף.
translation:
And we will further precede with the words of the Tanna from the house of Eliyahu (A.Z. P.G. 3): Everything was created by the Holy One, Blessed be He, in His world, except for the attribute of falsehood and the attribute of deceit, as it is said, "The Rock, His work is perfect," etc. If a person makes himself to speak the truth, a righteous angel is assigned to him who conducts himself in the ways of the righteous and speaks the truth. But if a person makes himself wicked, to deny and lie, an angel is assigned to him who conducts himself in the ways of the wicked and denies and lies, etc. Thus, the harmful spirits and accusers are also a creation from the Holy One, Blessed be He, for such was the will of creation that there should be a world of trial, and all have a root from the beginning of creation, except for those angels created from the attribute of falsehood and deceit; they have no root in creation, but a person himself creates them through his actions. 

And with this, we can understand why our sages referred to the evil inclination as an old and foolish king. It is simply called a king because it rules over a person, and old because it has been present since the beginning of his birth, whereas the good inclination only comes when one reaches the age of thirteen. It is called foolish because it instills a spirit of folly in people, as our sages said, "No person sins unless a spirit of folly enters him." And according to our path, we can also say that the evil inclination is called old because it has been standing in its service since the beginning of creation, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, created everything in His world, including the evil inclination and the accusers, and therefore it is called old. 

In contrast, those accusers created from falsehood and deceit are a new creation and are not worthy of being called an old king, but rather a new king, as they have dominion and authority over a person, as we explained, "A crown of authority without a crown," but they are new and have come recently, and they were not from the beginning of creation, nor are they from the time of birth like the evil inclination. 

And this is what the verse means when it says, "And a new king arose over Egypt," that his decrees against Israel were renewed, and through the attribute of deceit, he created an evil angel according to its nature, and it is truly new, having no root from the beginning of creation. The evil angel became a king over Egypt because all the affairs of the state are through the king, and he himself was conducted by the evil angel that was created from his will. Thus, it is rightly said, "And a new king arose, truly new," and when it says, "who did not know Joseph," it also refers to that angel who is the new king that arose over Egypt. And indeed, he did not know Joseph because he was not yet in the world during Joseph's lifetime. 

And what our sages expounded, "He made himself as if he did not know Joseph," refers to Pharaoh, who was a chariot to him, and he knew Joseph, but he made himself as if he did not know and went in a false way. It turns out that both interpretations that our sages expounded on the verse "And a new king arose who did not know Joseph" are both valid and true, and they are connected to one another, for by making himself as if he did not know Joseph, he renewed his decrees and created for himself an angel from the attribute of falsehood and deceit, and that angel truly did not know Joseph, for he was not yet in the world during Joseph's lifetime, and thus it is rightly said, "who did not know Joseph."
summary: The passage discusses the creation of the world by God, emphasizing that everything was created except for the attributes of falsehood and deceit. It explains that individuals create their own angels based on their actions—those who pursue truth are accompanied by a righteous angel, while those who engage in deceit are accompanied by an angel of wickedness. The text also contrasts the evil inclination (yetzer hara), which has existed since creation, with the newly created angels of falsehood, illustrating how these forces influence human behavior and governance, as exemplified by the "new king" in Egypt who acted in ignorance of Joseph. Ultimately, it highlights the interplay between divine creation and human agency in shaping moral and spiritual realities.

passage_content: ולדרכינו י"ל בכוונת דבריהם ז"ל (סוף מסכת סוטה מ"ט ע"ב) בעקבות משיחא חוצפא יסגא שיתרבה החוצפה ויהי' להם מלוכה וממשלה כמו שאמרז"ל חוצפא מלכותא בלא תגא , ובעוה"ר הקימו לעצמם מלכות ישראל נגד התוה"ק , ומפיצין כפירה ומינות בכל העולם ויש להם שררה על ישראל והם הנקראים חוצפא מלכותא בלא תגא ועליהם נתנבאו חכז"ל ברוח קדשם, ה' ישמרינו מהם ומהמונם והשי"ת יציל את עמו ישראל מרעיונות של כפירה, והמודה להם רח"ל ה"ה כופר בהשי"ת ובתורתו הק ', וידוע שק"ז הייטב לב אמר בנוסח התפלה ושבור עול הגוים ועול הגליות מעל צוארינו . ואמר שהכוונה על שני בחי' של גלות גלות של גוים ומה שסובלין גלות מרשעי ישראל וז"ש ועול הגליות, ובדורינו עכשיו נרגש הרבה עול הגלות הזה וכוונתינו בתפלה שיעזור לנו השי"ת וישבור מעלינו עול הגלות של רשעי ישראל, ומקושר אל מ"ש אח"כ ותוליכנו מהרה קוממיות לארצינו , שע"י שיתבערו הרשעים מן הארץ נוכל לבוא לארץ הקדושה קוממיות בשמחת הלב בקדושה ובטהרה ברצון הבוב"ה ע"י ביאת המשיח בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And according to our path, it can be said with the intention of their words, may their memory be blessed (end of Tractate Sotah 49b), that in the days of the Messiah, chutzpah will increase, and there will be much chutzpah, and they will have kingship and governance, as our sages have said, chutzpah is kingship without a crown. And in our times, they have established for themselves a kingdom of Israel against the Holy Torah, and they spread heresy and sectarianism throughout the world, and they have authority over Israel, and they are called chutzpah is kingship without a crown. Concerning them, our sages prophesied with their holy spirit, may the Lord protect us from them and from their wealth, and may the Holy One, blessed be He, save His people Israel from heretical ideas, and one who acknowledges them, Heaven forbid, is indeed a heretic against the Holy One, blessed be He, and His Holy Torah. It is known that this is what the Baal Shem Tov said in the prayer text, "And break the yoke of the nations and the yoke of the exiles from our necks." And he said that the intention is regarding two aspects of exile: the exile of the nations and what we suffer from the wicked of Israel, and this is what is meant by "the yoke of the exiles." In our generation now, we feel greatly the burden of this exile, and our intention in prayer is that the Holy One, blessed be He, should help us and break from us the yoke of the exile of the wicked of Israel. This is connected to what is said afterwards, "And lead us speedily upright to our land," that through the eradication of the wicked from the land, we will be able to come to the holy land upright, with joy of heart, in holiness and purity, with the will of the Blessed One, through the coming of the Messiah, with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the increasing audacity and rebellion against divine authority in the context of the Messianic era, highlighting the rise of false leadership and heretical beliefs among the Jewish people. It emphasizes the need for divine intervention to free Israel from the dual oppression of foreign nations and the corrupt elements within their own ranks. The text expresses a prayerful hope for the redemption and return to the Holy Land, which will be achieved through the removal of the wicked and the coming of the Messiah, bringing joy and purity to the people.

passage_content: עוד יתבאר על דברי המדרש ויקם מלך חדש וכו' ללמדך כשמת יוסף הפרו ברית מילה, אמרו נהי' כמצרים וכו ', וכיון שעשו כן הפך הקב"ה האהבה שהיו המצריים אוהבין אותן לשנאה שנא' הפך לבם לשנוא עמו להתנכל בעבדיו וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה הרי היו משוקעים גם בעון ע"ז כמבואר בדברי רז"ל, ומדוע אך בשביל הפרת בריתם הפך לבם לשנוא עמו, ואיך יהי' מדת העונש שוה למידת החטא מדה כנגד מדה. אמנם יתבאר לפי"ד הזוה"ק הנ"ל דהפיכת אהבתם לשנאה לא ע"צ העונש היתה , אדרבה לטובתן והצלתן של ישראל, דעי"ז ניצולו ישראל מתערובתן ולא נכשלו בעריות על ידן כנ"ל, אולם כ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים הי' כח ההתגברות נגד יצרא דעריות חזקה אצלם, לא היו צריכים לסיבה זו שע"י שנאת המצריים יגדרו מעריות, כי הי' קדושת הברית שמורה אצלם מהשפעת יוסף הצדיק בלא"ה , ע"כ היו המצריים אוהבין אותם ומכבדים להם. אבל אחר שמת יוסף הפרו ברית מילה, ומאז נגרע מהם כח שמירת הברית שהי' מוחזקת בידם מיוסף הצדיק, ועפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בטעם מצות מילה שהוא להחליש תאות המשגל, והאריז"ל כתב דע"י מצות מילה מציצה ופריעה ניצולין מן העריות אם מקיימין אותם כדבעי ובכוונה הראוי' עיי"ש, וע"כ לפי שהפרו ברית מילה הוצרכו לגדר אחר להנצל מן העריות ולטעם זה הפך הקב"ה האהבה שהיו המצריים אוהבין אותם לשנאה כדי שלא יכשלו על ידם בעריות, ובשורש הענין ניצולו ישראל מעריות ומהתחברותם של המצריים ע"י כח הקדושה שהי' מושרש בהם מיוסף הצדיק כאמרז"ל יוסף גדר עצמו מן הערוה בזכותו נגדרו כל ישראל וכו '.
translation:
It will be further explained regarding the words of the Midrash, "And a new king arose," etc., to teach you that when Joseph died, they (the Egyptians) broke the covenant of circumcision, saying, "Let us be like the Egyptians," etc. And since they did this, the Holy One, blessed be He, turned the love that the Egyptians had for them into hatred, as it is said, "He turned their hearts to hate His people, to deal craftily with His servants," etc. Thus far the Midrash. 

At first glance, they were also steeped in the sin of idolatry, as explained in the words of our Sages, so why was it only because of the breach of their covenant that their hearts were turned to hate His people? And how can the measure of punishment be equal to the measure of sin, a measure for a measure? 

However, it can be explained according to the aforementioned teaching of the Zohar that the turning of their love into hatred was not due to punishment; rather, it was for the benefit and salvation of Israel. For through this, Israel was saved from their mixture and did not stumble in immorality through them, as mentioned. 

As long as Joseph was alive, there was a strong power of resistance against the evil inclination of immorality among them; they did not need this reason that through the hatred of the Egyptians they would be guarded from immorality, for the sanctity of the covenant was preserved among them due to the influence of Joseph the Righteous without any other reason. Therefore, the Egyptians loved them and honored them. 

But after Joseph died, they broke the covenant of circumcision, and since then, the power of safeguarding the covenant that was held by them through Joseph the Righteous diminished. And according to what Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote regarding the reason for the commandment of circumcision, which is to weaken the desire for sexual relations, and as the Arizal wrote that through the commandments of circumcision, sucking, and tearing, they are saved from immorality if they fulfill them properly and with the appropriate intention, as stated there. 

Therefore, since they broke the covenant of circumcision, they needed another fence to be saved from immorality, and for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, turned the love that the Egyptians had for them into hatred so that they would not stumble in immorality through them. And at the root of the matter, Israel was saved from immorality and from the association with the Egyptians through the power of the holiness that was rooted in them from Joseph the Righteous, as our Sages said, "Joseph guarded himself from immorality; through his merit, all of Israel was guarded," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of the Egyptians' love for the Israelites into hatred after the death of Joseph, emphasizing that this shift was not merely punitive but served to protect the Israelites from moral corruption. The text explains that while Joseph was alive, his sanctity helped the Israelites maintain their purity and resist temptation, but after his death, the Egyptians' breach of the covenant of circumcision necessitated a divine intervention to prevent the Israelites from falling into immorality. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the protective power of holiness and the importance of maintaining spiritual boundaries to safeguard one's integrity. Ultimately, the narrative illustrates how divine providence operates to ensure the spiritual survival of the Jewish people.

passage_content: הבה נתחכמה לו פן ירבה והי' כי תקראנה מלחמה ונוסף גם הוא על שונאינו ונלחם בנו ועלה מן הארץ. יל"ד דהול"ל וילחם בנו לשון יפעיל, משא"כ אומרו ונלחם בנו משמעותו נפעל מאחרים וצ"ב הכוונה.
translation: "Let us be wise against him, lest he multiply, and it will be when war is called, he will also join our enemies and fight against us and rise from the land. It should have said 'and he will fight against us' in the active form, whereas here it says 'and he will fight against us,' which implies a passive meaning from others, and the intention is unclear."
summary: The passage discusses the concern of potential enemies uniting against Israel, emphasizing the need for wisdom in addressing such threats. The use of the term "וילחם" (and he will fight) suggests a passive role, indicating that the conflict may arise from external forces rather than direct aggression. This highlights a theological insight into the nature of divine protection and the importance of spiritual preparedness in the face of adversity. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interplay between human action and divine intervention in the unfolding of events.

Ultimately, it underscores the transformative power of divine communion in the pursuit of holiness.

passage_content: ג) יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ, בגמ' (סוטה י"א) הקשו כן רבו וכן פרצו מיבעי ' לי', אר"ל רוה"ק מבשרתן כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ עכ"ד הגמ ', לכאורה עדיין צ"ב דלא הודיע הכתוב כי אם ההבטחה שירבו ויפרצו, וכל הבטחה אפשר שיתבטל ע"י גרמת החטא, ונוסף על ההבטחה הול"ל כן רבו וכן פרצו. וכעין קושיא זו שהקשו בגמ' כן רבו וכן פרצו מיבעי ' לי', קשה גם על אומרו וכאשר יענו אותו לשון עתיד הרי באמת עינו אותם בפועל כמ"ש וירעו אותנו המצרים ויענונו וכו' וא"כ היל"ל וכאשר עינו אותם וגו' ומדוע לא הקשו בגמ' גם על זה.
translation: 3) They will answer him, "So shall they increase and so shall they break forth." In the Gemara (Sotah 11), they asked, "Is it not sufficient to say, 'So shall they increase and so shall they break forth'?" This means that the Holy Spirit announces to them, "So shall they increase and so shall they break forth." Thus far the Gemara. At first glance, it is still difficult to understand why the scripture only informed us of the promise that they will increase and break forth, as any promise could be nullified by the cause of sin. In addition to the promise, it should have said, "So they increased and so they broke forth." And similar to this question that they asked in the Gemara, "So shall they increase and so shall they break forth," it is also difficult regarding the phrase "And when they afflict him," which is in the future tense, when in truth they afflicted him in action, as it is written, "And the Egyptians evil-entreated us and afflicted us," etc. Therefore, it should have said, "And when they afflicted them," and why did they not ask in the Gemara also about this?
summary: The passage discusses the promise of growth and expansion ("כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ") in the context of the Jewish people's suffering and oppression in Egypt. It raises a theological question about the nature of divine promises, suggesting that such assurances could be nullified by sin. Additionally, it questions the use of future tense in the phrase "וכאשר יענו אותו," highlighting the tension between past suffering and future hope. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the interplay of divine promise, human action, and the enduring faith in redemption despite adversity.

passage_content: ד) טפלו עלי שקר זדים שאמרו הבה נתחכמה לו פן ירבה. אני בכל לב אצור פקודיך וכאשר יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ וצ"ב .
translation: D) They have laid upon me the falsehood of the wicked who said, "Come, let us outsmart him, lest he multiply." I will with all my heart treasure Your commandments, and as they afflict him, so shall he multiply and so shall he break forth, and the question remains.
summary: The passage reflects a struggle against falsehood and opposition, emphasizing the importance of steadfastness in faith and adherence to divine commandments. It suggests that despite challenges and attempts to undermine belief, a sincere commitment to God's teachings will lead to growth and expansion of spiritual understanding. The phrase "as they afflict him, so he will increase" highlights the idea that adversity can ultimately strengthen one's faith and resolve. This encapsulates a core Hasidic belief in the transformative power of trials in the journey of spiritual development.

passage_content: ה) בפרשה הנה אנכי בא אל בנ"י ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ויאמר אלקים אל משה אהי ' אשר אהי ' ויאמר כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי ' שלחני אליכם, בגמ' (ברכות ט':) א"ל הקב"ה למשה לך אמור לישראל אני הייתי עמכם בשעבוד זה ואני אהי ' עמכם בשעבוד מלכיות , אמר לפניו רבש"ע די' לצרה בשעתה, א"ל הקב"ה לך אמור להם אהי ' שלחני אליכם עכ"ד הגמ ' כבר התפלאו המפרשים ז"ל איך התחכם מרע"ה על דברי השי"ת, וברש"י במוסגר כתב כי לא הבין מרע"ה דברי השי"ת, שמאז כך היתה דעתו באמרו ית ' אהי ' אשר אהי ', למשה לבדו הגיד ולא שיגיד לישראל וכו ', אבל קשה דהרי מרע"ה שאל מה אומר אליהם: וא"כ מדוע השיב לו הקב"ה מה שלא יאמר לישראל ואינו מענין שאלתו כלל.
translation: In the section, "Behold, I come to the children of Israel, and they will say to me, 'What is His name? What shall I say to them?' And God said to Moses, 'Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh.' And He said, 'Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'Ehyeh has sent me to you.' In the Gemara (Berakhot 9:), the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, 'Go and tell Israel, I was with you during this servitude, and I will be with you during the servitude of kingdoms.' Moses said before Him, 'Master of the Universe, it is enough to suffer in its time.' The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, 'Go and tell them, 'Ehyeh has sent me to you.' Thus far the Gemara. The commentators have already wondered how Moses was clever regarding the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And Rashi noted in parentheses that Moses did not understand the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, for since that was His intention in saying, 'Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh,' it was revealed only to Moses and not to be told to Israel, etc. However, it is difficult, for Moses asked what he should say to them; and if so, why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, respond to him with something that he would not say to Israel and is not related to his question at all?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the profound concept of divine presence and support during times of suffering. God instructs Moses to convey to the Israelites that "I am that I am" signifies His eternal and unchanging nature, assuring them of His presence during their enslavement and future hardships. The text reflects on the complexity of Moses' understanding of God's message, emphasizing the importance of faith and the assurance of divine companionship in times of distress. This interaction underscores the theological insight that God's essence transcends human comprehension, yet His commitment to His people remains steadfast.

passage_content: ו) צ"ב מה ששאל ואמרו לו מה שמו מה אומר אליהם והרי מרע"ה ידע בשם המפורש, וכמ"ש רז"ל עה"כ הלהרגני אתה אומר שהרג את המצרי בשם המפורש, גם מה צורך בזה לשליחותו בענין הגאולה להודיעם שמו ית ', וידעו והאמינו במציאות הבוית"ש שהרי שמרו מצות גם במצרים ומי שאינו מאמין ח"ו במציאות השי"ת, אפי' יגלו לו כל השמות הק ' לא יתחזק אמונתו בשביל זה, ומי שמאמין באמונה פשוטה גם בלא זה יאמין ומה צורך להודיעם שמותיו ית '.
translation: 5) It is difficult to understand what he asked and they told him what is His name, what should I say to them, when surely Moshe Rabbeinu knew the Ineffable Name, as our Sages have said regarding the verse, "You say that you will kill me," that he killed the Egyptian with the Ineffable Name. Also, what need is there for this in his mission regarding the redemption to inform them of His Name, so that they will know and believe in the existence of the Blessed One, since they kept the commandments even in Egypt? And one who does not believe, Heaven forbid, in the existence of the Holy One, even if all the Holy Names are revealed to him, his faith will not be strengthened because of that. And one who believes with simple faith, even without this, will believe, so what need is there to inform them of His Names?
summary: The passage discusses the question of why Moses needed to inform the Israelites of God's name when he already possessed the ineffable name. It emphasizes that true belief in God does not depend on knowing His names, as those who lack faith will not be strengthened by such knowledge. Conversely, those with simple faith will believe in God regardless of the names revealed to them. The text highlights the importance of intrinsic faith over intellectual understanding in the context of divine revelation and redemption.

passage_content: ז) (סוטה י"ב.) אריב"ח ב' גזירות גזר פרעה, בתחלה אם בן הוא והמיתן אותו. ולבסוף כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשלכהו . ולבסוף אף על עמו גזר, ובמד"ר איתא עה"כ ויצו פרעה לכל עמו אריב"ח אף על עמו גזר, ולמה עשה כן, שהיו אסטרולוגין אומרים לו גואל ישראל נתעברה ממנו אמו , ואין אנו יודעים אם ישראל הוא או מצרי הוא, באותה שעה כנס פרעה כל המצריים וא"ל השאילו לי בניכם ט' חדשים שאשליכם ליאור וכו ', ולא רצו לקבל ממנו שאמרו בן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם אלא מן העבריות, והיפ"ת כתב שיש מדרשים חלוקים בזה דבמקו"א נראה שיום א' הי' נוהג גזירה זו על כל המצריים משמע שקבלו אותו, ועוד הביא ראי' ממ"ד במד"ר עה"כ ותאמר מילדי העברים זה, מנין הכירה בו אריב"ח שראתה אותו מהול וכו ', ואם נאמר שהמצריים לא השליכו בניהם ליאור למה צריך לטעמא שהכירה בו ממה שראתה אותו מהול, הרי ודאי בן ישראל הוא, כיון שהמצריים לא קבלו הגזרה, ע"כ מסיק דמדרשים חלוקים הם אם קבלו גזירתו או לא, אמנם כללא אית לן דאפושי בפלוגתא לא מפשינן . וכל כמה דאפשר למעט בפלוגתא עדיף, וכיון שכל המאמרים האלו נאמרו בסתם, מה"ת נעשה פלוגתא ביניהן, ובפשטות אפשר ליישב דשניהם אמת דהמצריים לא רצו לקבל ממנו, אבל פרעה הכריחן בגזירת מלך ונתקיים גזירתו בכפי' ואפ"ל עוד דהנה ראוי להבין איך חלקו המצריים על דעת החרטומים. שהחרטומים היו מסופקים בדבר אם הגואל יהי' מצרי או ישראל, ומהיכן ידעו המצריים בבירור שכן מצרי לא יגאל אותם לעולם, והרי נביאת עתידות זו שעתיד לילד מושיען של ישראל א"א לידע כ"א ברוה"ק או להבדיל ע"י כח הכשפים, והפשוטי עם לא ידעו מעצמן דבר זה כ"א ע"י הודעת החרטומים, ואיך השכילו מהם יותר שבן מצרי לא יגאול אותם.
translation: 7) (Sotah 12.) Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai said: Pharaoh decreed two decrees, initially that if it is a son, he should be killed. And finally, every son that is born should be thrown into the river. Ultimately, he also decreed against his own people. In the Midrash, it is stated regarding the verse "And Pharaoh commanded all his people," Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai said that he also decreed against his own people. Why did he do this? Because the astrologers were telling him that the Redeemer of Israel was conceived from his mother, and we do not know if he is an Israelite or an Egyptian. At that moment, Pharaoh gathered all the Egyptians and said to them, "Lend me your sons for nine months so that I may throw them into the river," etc. They did not want to accept this from him, as they said, "An Egyptian son will never redeem them, only one from the Hebrews." And Yefet wrote that there are differing Midrashim on this matter, for in some places it seems that on the first day this decree was enacted on all the Egyptians, implying that they accepted it. Furthermore, he brought a proof from the Midrash regarding the verse "And she said, 'This is one of the Hebrew children,'" from where did Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai recognize him? Because she saw that he was circumcised, etc. If we say that the Egyptians did not throw their sons into the river, why is it necessary to explain that she recognized him from seeing that he was circumcised? Surely he is a son of Israel, since the Egyptians did not accept the decree. Therefore, it concludes that there are differing Midrashim on whether they accepted his decree or not. However, we have a general rule that we do not resolve disputes. As much as possible, it is better to minimize the dispute, and since all these statements were made in general, from the Torah a dispute arose among them. Simply, it is possible to reconcile that both are true: the Egyptians did not want to accept it from him, but Pharaoh forced them with the decree of the king, and his decree was fulfilled as he intended. And it may also be understood how the Egyptians disagreed with the opinion of the magicians. The magicians were uncertain about whether the redeemer would be Egyptian or Israelite, and how did the Egyptians know for certain that an Egyptian would never redeem them? This prophetic knowledge of the future, that one who will give birth to the savior of Israel, cannot be known except through the Holy Spirit or, conversely, through the power of sorcery, and the common people did not know this on their own except through the announcement of the magicians. How did they understand from them more that an Egyptian son would not redeem them?
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's decrees against the Israelites, highlighting the tension between his astrologers' predictions of a future savior and the Egyptians' refusal to accept that a Hebrew could redeem them. It reflects on the complexities of divine prophecy and human understanding, suggesting that while the astrologers were uncertain about the savior's identity, the Egyptians instinctively rejected the notion that a non-Hebrew could be their redeemer. This illustrates a deeper theological insight into the nature of redemption and the inherent connection between the Jewish people and their savior, emphasizing the belief that true salvation can only come from within their own lineage.

passage_content: ונקדים לבאר הכתוב וכאשר יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ, ועפ"י פשוטו שעינו אותם בעבודה קשה המפרכת הגוף ומשברתו , אולם בעל הגדה פירשו באופן אחר וירא את ענינו זו פרישות דרך ארץ כמ"ש וירא אלקים את בנ"י וידע אלקים , ולכאורה יש להבין הרי גזרו עליהם הרבה גזירות רעות, כמו שדורש בעל הגדה ואת עמלינו אלו הבנים שנא' כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו ואת לחצינו זה הדחק, ולמה דוקא על פרישות ד"א דרשו הכתוב וירא אלקים את בנ"י וידע אלקים , והי' שם הרבה גזירות וגם אותם ראה השי"ת, וכמבואר במד"ר שהשליך הקב"ה המצריים לתוך הים מדה כנגד מדה לפי שגזרו להטביע את בנ"י במים ובקדירה שבישלו בה נתבשלו, וכן כל העשר מכות היו מדה כנגד מדה במה שציערו את ישראל, א"כ לאו דוקא פרישות ד"א ראה הקב"ה, אלא גם שאר הגזירות והצרות ראה, ומדוע דרשו דייקא על פרישות ד"א פסוק זה וירא אלקים את בנ"י וידע אלקים .
translation: And we will begin to explain the verse, "And the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and grew." According to its simple meaning, they afflicted them with hard labor that crushed the body and broke it. However, the Ba'al Haggadah interprets it differently, seeing this affliction as a separation from the ways of the world, as it is written, "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew." At first glance, one must understand that they decreed many evil decrees upon them, as the Ba'al Haggadah expounds, "And our labor, these sons," as it is said, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," and "And we oppressed them," this is the pressure. So why specifically on the separation from the ways of the world did they interpret the verse, "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew"? There were many decrees there, and God saw them as well, as explained in Midrash Rabbah, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, cast the Egyptians into the sea measure for measure, because they decreed to drown the children of Israel in water, and in the pot in which they cooked, they were cooked. Likewise, all the ten plagues were measure for measure for the suffering they caused Israel. Therefore, it is not specifically the separation from the ways of the world that God saw, but also the other decrees and troubles He saw. And why did they specifically interpret this verse, "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew," regarding the separation from the ways of the world?
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the verse "the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and grew," highlighting a Hasidic perspective on suffering and divine awareness. It contrasts the literal understanding of oppression with a deeper spiritual insight that emphasizes the importance of maintaining a separation from worldly concerns (prishut). The text questions why God specifically noted the Israelites' separation when there were numerous other afflictions, suggesting that their spiritual resilience in the face of hardship was particularly significant to God. Ultimately, it reflects on the idea that divine observation and understanding are intricately linked to the spiritual state of the oppressed.

passage_content: ונל"פ ע"ד רמז מוסר, הנה ידוע מספה"ק דימי השובבים המה מסוגלים לתיקון חטא הידוע, לעשות גדרים וסייגים שלא יכשלו ח"ו בעבירה להבא, ולהרבות בתפלות ותחנונים להקב"ה שהשי"ת יציל את עמו ישראל מחטא זה, ונזכה לתקן בעוד מועד ונשמור עצמינו ואת בנינו מחטא זה, וכל איש ישראל צריך להשגיח על עצמו ועל בניו מנעוריהם קודם שיבואו לכלל דעת להזהירם על חומר העון , ונזכה להיות חלקנו מנוטרי הברית, והנה כח הזה שעמדו ישראל בנסיון והיו גדורים בעריות, הי' להם מכוחו של יוסף הצדיק שהי' לו נסיונות גדולים בענין קדושת הברית ונתגבר עליהם, והרגיל מדה זו על הכלל ישראל והשפיע עליהם שבזכותו נגדרו כל ישראל בעריות, והנה חרטומי מצרים הי' להם השגה גדולה מכח הסט"א וראו העתידות עד סוף כל הדורות, וכמ"ש ז"ל באאע"ה שקודם שנולד אמרו החרטומים שעתיד להוליד בן שיירש עוה"ז ועוה"ב, והשיגו שמאאע"ה תצא אומה ישראלית והם ישארו נצחיים כמ"ש כי אעשה כלה בכל הגוים וגו' ולא ישארו בעולם כ"א בנ"י בכח התורה ודביקותם בהקב"ה, ע"כ כיון שראו כל זאת התגברו בכל כוחם להחטיא את ישראל בטומאת מצרים, וכמו שפי' השלה"ק עה"פ וירעו אותנו המצריים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים
translation: And we will explain regarding the hint of moral teaching, behold it is known from the holy books that the days of the Shovavim are capable of rectifying the known sin, to establish fences and boundaries so that they will not stumble, Heaven forbid, in sin in the future, and to increase in prayers and supplications to the Holy One, Blessed be He, that the Blessed One should save His people Israel from this sin, and may we merit to rectify in due time and guard ourselves and our children from this sin. Every man of Israel must be vigilant over himself and his sons from their youth before they come to the age of understanding, to warn them about the severity of the sin, and may we merit to be part of those who guard the covenant. Behold, this strength that Israel stood firm in the trial and were guarded from immorality was due to the power of Joseph the Righteous, who had great trials regarding the sanctity of the covenant and overcame them, and he instilled this trait in all of Israel and influenced them that through his merit all of Israel were guarded from immorality. And behold, the magicians of Egypt had great insight from the power of the evil inclination and saw the future until the end of all generations, as our sages of blessed memory said that before he was born, the magicians said that a son would be born who would inherit this world and the next. They understood that from our forefather Abraham a nation of Israel would emerge, and they would remain eternal, as it is said, "For I will make an end of all the nations," and there will remain in the world only the children of Israel by the power of the Torah and their attachment to the Holy One, Blessed be He. Therefore, when they saw all this, they strengthened themselves with all their might to cause Israel to sin with the impurity of Egypt, and as explained by the holy teacher on the verse "And the Egyptians made us evil and sinful."
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of spiritual vigilance and the need for individuals to guard themselves and their children against sin, particularly the sin of immorality. It highlights the role of Joseph the Righteous, whose triumph over temptation serves as a model for the Jewish people, enabling them to maintain their sanctity. The text also reflects on the prophetic insights of the Egyptian magicians, who foresaw the future prominence of the Jewish nation, prompting them to intensify their efforts to lead Israel astray through the impurities of Egypt. Ultimately, it underscores the necessity of prayer and repentance to protect the sanctity of the covenant.

passage_content: ובפשטות נראה שהפרישו את ישראל מדרך ארץ בשביל שלא יפרו וירבו, כמ"ש במדרש שגזרו עליהם שלא יהיו ישינים בבתיהם כדי למעטם מפרי' ורבי', אולם עוד הי' כוונתם בזה להחטיא את ישראל בחטא הידוע, וע"ד שאמרז"ל רווק הדר בעיר ואינו חוטא הוא נסיון גדול, ומצינו במלחמת מדין אע"פ שהיו צדיקים אמרו אם מידי עבירה יצאנו מידי הרהור לא יצאנו, כמו"כ במצרים ע"י שהפרישו אותם מבתיהם הגם שלא היו משוקעים בטומאה כמותם, עכ"ז כיון שהיו מסורים בידיהם באו לידי מחשבות והרהורים ר"ל, והעין רואה והלב חומד וכלי המעשה גומרים ונכשלו בחטא הידוע ועי"ז הי' להם עינוי כפול דפרישות ד"א נקרא עינוי, ונוסף לזה הי' להם עינוי גדול מידיעת חומר העון ופגם החטא, דחטא הידוע ענף מן איסור עריות שדרשו אותה חכמז"ל מהפסוק לא תנאף, ושורש החטא זה מהנקבה של הס"מ ולשם הולך עד שזוכין ללקט הניצוצות ההם ולהעלותם מתוך הקליפה, וחטא הנורא הזה מסמא העינים מלראות האמת, וקשה מאוד להגיע לנקודה של אמת הן בתורה הן בתפלה, ובכל עובדא טבא עומד חטא זה לנגדו ולעכבו, וע"כ כל הכנופיות שעומדין על ישראל משורש הסט"א , התחלה שלהם הוא בתערובות בחורים ובתולות, וזהו כלי מלחמתו הראשונה של הס"מ ללחום עם הקדושה להכשיל בחורי ישראל, וזה הי' העינוי הגדול לבנ"י במצרים והשי"ת ראה צערם הגדול איך שישראל מצטערים על שאין יכולים לשמור קדושת הברית כראוי, וכואב לבם ורצונם לתקן כל זה אבל תוקף הגלות גדול מאד והתגברות הסט"א וכוחות הטומאה חזקים מאוד, וז"א וירא את עניינו שהקב"ה ראה גודל העינוי שהי' לבנ"י שנסבב מגזירת פרישות ד"א, וזה גרם את עמלינו אלו הבנים, שע"י שנכשלים בחטא זה קשה להדריך הבנים בדרך התורה והיראה ולהשריש בלבם דרך התורה, וכל הצרות שורשם מחטא זה, שאלמלא הי' להם לישראל רק הרהורים ומחשבות טובות הי' כח יותר בתפלות ישראל להתקבל ברחמים וברצון לפני הבורא כל עולמים, ובעוה"ר גם בדורינו גדול העינוי בענין זה, שבנ"י פזורים בארצות מזוהמים ומוקפים במסיתים ומדיחים, וכוחות הטומאה והיצר לוחמים עם בנ"י , וקשה מאד להתגבר עליהם, ואין עצה אחרת רק לבקש מהבוית"ש שירחם על עמו ישראל וישפיע רוח טהרה בלבות בנ"י שנזכה לתקן כל אשר פגמנו, ומעתה יובן דברי המגיד דעל עינוי זה של פרישות ד"א דרשו הפסוק וירא אלקים את בנ"י וידע אלקים , מפני שזהו סיבה כוללת לכל העינויים והצרות ובזכות שנצטערו ישראל על שנכשלו בחטא זה ריחם השי"ת עליהם.
translation: And simply it seems that they separated Israel from the way of the world so that they would not multiply and increase, as it is said in the Midrash that they decreed upon them that they should not sleep in their homes in order to diminish them from fruitfulness and multiplication. However, their intention in this was also to cause Israel to sin with the known sin, and as our Sages said, a single man who dwells in a city and does not sin is a great trial. And we find in the war against Midian that even though they were righteous, they said, "If we have escaped from sin, we have not escaped from thoughts." Likewise, in Egypt, by separating them from their homes, even though they were not immersed in impurity like them, nevertheless, since they were in their hands, they came to thoughts and reflections, so to speak. And the eye sees and the heart covets, and the instruments of action complete and they stumbled into the known sin. And as a result, they had a double suffering: the separation from the way of the world is called suffering, and in addition to this, they had great suffering from the knowledge of the gravity of the sin and the blemish of the sin. For the known sin is a branch of the prohibition of illicit relations, which our Sages derived from the verse "You shall not commit adultery," and the root of the sin comes from the female of the evil inclination, and it goes there until they merit to gather those sparks and elevate them from the klipah. And this terrible sin blinds the eyes from seeing the truth, and it is very difficult to reach the point of truth, both in Torah and in prayer, and in every good deed this sin stands before him and hinders him. Therefore, all the groups that stand against Israel from the root of the evil inclination, their beginning is in the mixing of young men and young women. This is the first weapon of the evil inclination to wage war against holiness to cause the young men of Israel to stumble. And this was the great suffering for the Children of Israel in Egypt, and the Holy One, blessed be He, saw their great pain, how Israel suffers because they cannot properly guard the sanctity of the covenant, and their hearts ache and their desire is to rectify all this, but the strength of the exile is very great and the power of the evil inclination and the forces of impurity are very strong. And this means that God saw the great suffering that was to the Children of Israel that arose from the decree of separation from the way of the world. This caused our toil, these children, that by stumbling in this sin it is difficult to guide the children in the way of Torah and fear and to instill in their hearts the way of Torah. And all the troubles have their root in this sin, for if Israel had only good thoughts and reflections, there would be more strength in the prayers of Israel to be accepted with mercy and goodwill before the Creator of all worlds. And in our times, even in our generation, the suffering in this matter is great, as the Children of Israel are scattered in polluted lands and surrounded by seducers and misleaders, and the forces of impurity and the evil inclination are fighting against the Children of Israel, and it is very difficult to overcome them. There is no other advice except to ask from the Holy One, blessed be He, to have mercy on His people Israel and to inspire a spirit of purity in the hearts of the Children of Israel so that we may merit to rectify all that we have blemished. And from now on, the words of the Maggid will be understood, that regarding this suffering of separation from the way of the world, they derived the verse "And God saw the Children of Israel, and God knew," because this is a comprehensive cause for all the sufferings and troubles, and in the merit that Israel suffered for having stumbled in this sin, the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy on them.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual challenges faced by the Jewish people, particularly the dangers of separation from their homes and the resulting temptations that lead to sin, specifically the sin associated with immorality. It emphasizes that this struggle is a significant source of suffering for the Israelites, as their desire to maintain holiness is thwarted by the overwhelming forces of impurity and temptation. The text highlights that God's awareness of their suffering and their sincere yearning for repentance ultimately leads to divine compassion and the hope for spiritual redemption. The author connects these themes to the broader struggles of the Jewish people throughout history, particularly in the context of exile and moral challenges.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מה שאמר הפסוק כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ ולא אמר כן רבו וכן פרצו. דהנה כל אותן הניצוצות הק ' שאבדו ישראל במצרים היו צריכים תיקון להעלותם מעומקי הקליפות ולתקנם, וזה הי' עינוי גדול לישראל, ע"כ בישר אותם הרוה"ק שכשיצאו ממצרים יזכו להעלות כל הניצה"ק ע"י שהרבו בתשובה, כמבואר במדרש עה"פ וירא אלקים את בנ"י , שעשו תשובה הבינונים וגם הרשעים הרהרו לעשות תשובה, וידע אלקים שאפילו אחד בחבירו לא הי' יודע אלא הקב"ה לבדו. וזה מכוון את לבו וזה מכוון את לבו ועושין תשובה והשי"ת קבל תשובתם, האמנם שיש דעות שעל חטא זה אינו מועיל תשובה, אולם כבר הבאנו לעיל בשם א"ז ישמח משה זלה"ה דתשובת הרבים הוא כמו תשובה מאהבה, את"ד , ובחי' תשובה כזו מועיל גם על חטא הזה, ושם הי' תשובת הרבים שכל ישראל יחד הרהרו בתשובה, רק שלא ידעו אחד מחבירו והקב"ה צירף תשובתם ונחשב להם כתשובת הרבים ע"כ וירא אלקים את בנ"י וידע אלקים שראה צערם הגדול וקיבל תשובתם ברחמים, ודבר זה לא השיגו במצרים שיהי' תיקון לאלו הנשמות העשוקות והניצה"ק שנאבדו ע"י החטא, וזה הי' להם עינוי גדול כנ"ל, ע"כ רוה"ק מבשרתן שאם יקבלו ע"ע עול התורה ומלכות שמים, יזכו להעלות כל הנצה"ק מעמקי הקליפות, ולז"א וכאשר יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ בלשון עתיד.
translation: And with this, it will be understood what the verse says, "So shall they increase and so shall they burst forth," and it did not say, "So they increased and so they burst." Behold, all those holy sparks that Israel lost in Egypt needed rectification to elevate them from the depths of the klipot and to rectify them, and this was a great suffering for Israel. Therefore, the Holy Spirit announced to them that when they would leave Egypt, they would merit to elevate all the holy sparks by increasing in repentance, as explained in the Midrash on the verse "And God saw the children of Israel," that the average ones repented and even the wicked contemplated repenting, and God knew that even one among his fellow would not know, only the Holy One, blessed be He, alone. This one directs his heart and that one directs his heart, and they repent, and the Holy One, blessed be He, accepted their repentance. However, there are opinions that for this sin, repentance is not effective. Nevertheless, we have already brought above in the name of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, that the repentance of the masses is like repentance out of love, as you have said, and such a form of repentance is effective even for this sin. And there was the repentance of the masses, for all of Israel together contemplated repentance, only that they did not know one from another, and the Holy One, blessed be He, combined their repentance and it was considered for them as the repentance of the masses. Therefore, "And God saw the children of Israel," and God knew that He saw their great suffering and accepted their repentance with mercy. This matter was not understood in Egypt, that there would be a rectification for those oppressed souls and the holy sparks that were lost due to sin, and this was a great suffering for them, as mentioned above. Therefore, the Holy Spirit announces to them that if they accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah and the kingdom of Heaven, they will merit to elevate all the holy sparks from the depths of the klipot. And this is to say, "And when they afflict him, so shall they increase and so shall they burst forth," in the future tense.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption and the elevation of lost divine sparks (nitzotzot) that the Israelites suffered in Egypt. It emphasizes that through sincere repentance, even those who were not fully righteous could contribute to the collective atonement, which God accepted as a genuine return to Him. The text highlights that the suffering in Egypt was a result of the lost souls needing rectification, and the promise of future growth and expansion ("yeshivah" and "yifrotz") signifies the potential for spiritual elevation through the acceptance of the yoke of Torah and divine sovereignty. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope and divine mercy in the face of collective repentance.

passage_content: וכן אנו מצפים בדור השפל הזה שהנסיונות הם גדולים יותר ממה שהיו במצרים וכוחות הטומאה חזקים ביותר, כי במצרים הי' להם לישראל נביאי אמת משה אהרן ומרים עמרם וכל שבט לוי צדיקים וקדושים, ובדור הזה אין לנו כל זה, דנבואה כבר בעלה בימי החורבן אבל עכ"ז נשאר עוד רוה"ק, ובעוה"ר דור האחרון הזה בעיקבא דמשיחא חסרנו גם את זאת, וכמו"ש האוהחה"ק (פ' עקב) עה"פ כגוים אשר ד' מאביד מפניכם כן תאבדון, כי מלבד אבדתם שאמר למעלה במאמר אבד תאבדון, עוד צרה אחרת להם אחר שיאבדו. הנשארים בהם יהיו כגוים אשר וגו', פי' שיכרת מהם נבואה ורוה"ק וכו ', ועל זאת יחרד לב עם ד' שאין קללה בעולם כזו, אוי לדורות שטעמו כוס המר הזה וכו' וכל זה הוא בחטא הדור כמאמה"כ עקב לא תשמעון, ועי"ז נעשה גודל ההסתרה. אמנם דבר א' יש לנו עכשיו מה שלא הי' לישראל במצרים, שלא הי' להם עדיין התוה"ק ע"כ הי' קשה להם לעמוד ולהתגבר על הנסיונות , דאין ההרהור מצוי אלא בלב פנוי מן החכמה, והיום יש לנו התוה"ק , אבל בעוה"ר אם לומדין התוה"ק שלא בדרך האמת אז גרוע הרבה יותר ממה שהי' במצרים, ואנו מצפים שיעזור לנו הבוכ"ע וישפיע בלבות בנ"י לעשות תשובה שלימה ולתקן כל אשר פגמנו ונזכה להיות דבוקים בבוכ"ע ולראות בישועה שלימה, ואז נזכה ללקט את אשר פזרנו וכמו שנתקיים בנו כאשר יענו אותו, כ"כ נזכה לכן ירבה וכן יפרוץ להוציא כל הניצה"ק שפזרנו ע"י חטאינו, שהבטחה זו נצחיות, וע"כ אמר הכתוב בלשון עתיד ולא אמר כן רבו וכן פרצו, שקאי על הדורות העתידים שיזכו בביאת המשיח לתקן ולהוציא הניצה"ק ויתקיים כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ.
translation: And so we await in this lowly generation, where the trials are greater than they were in Egypt and the forces of impurity are exceedingly strong. For in Egypt, the Israelites had true prophets: Moses, Aaron, Miriam, Amram, and all the righteous and holy members of the tribe of Levi. In this generation, we have none of this, for prophecy has already ceased since the time of the destruction. Nevertheless, there still remains some degree of the Holy Spirit. However, in our current times, the last generation, in the footsteps of the Messiah, we are also lacking this. As it is stated in the holy Torah (Parashat Ekev) regarding the verse "like the nations that the Lord will destroy before you, so shall you perish," for besides their destruction mentioned above in the statement "you shall surely perish," there is another trouble for them after they perish. The remnants among them will be like the nations, meaning that prophecy and the Holy Spirit will be cut off from them, etc. For this, the heart trembles before the Lord, for there is no curse in the world like this. Woe to the generations that have tasted this bitter cup, etc. All this is due to the sins of the generation, as it is written, "because you did not listen," and through this, the concealment becomes great. However, there is one thing we have now that the Israelites did not have in Egypt: they did not yet have the Torah, and therefore it was difficult for them to stand and overcome the trials, for thoughts of sin are only found in a heart devoid of wisdom. Today we have the Torah, but in our current times, if we learn the Torah not in the way of truth, it is much worse than it was in Egypt. And we await that the Blessed One will help us and inspire the hearts of the Jewish people to make complete repentance and rectify all that we have blemished, and we will merit to be attached to the Blessed One and see complete salvation. Then we will merit to gather what we have scattered, as it has been fulfilled in us, "when they oppress him, so shall he increase." Thus, we will merit that it will increase and break forth to bring out all the sparks of holiness that we have scattered through our sins, for this promise is eternal. Therefore, the scripture is written in the future tense and does not say "so they increased" and "so they broke forth," which refers to the future generations that will merit, with the coming of the Messiah, to rectify and bring out the sparks of holiness, and it will be fulfilled "so it will increase and break forth."
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the heightened spiritual challenges faced in the current generation compared to those in Egypt, emphasizing the absence of prophetic guidance and the strength of impurity. Despite the loss of prophecy, the presence of the Torah offers a means to overcome trials, though misinterpretation of its teachings can lead to greater difficulties. The text expresses hope for divine assistance in achieving true repentance and restoration, ultimately leading to the redemption of scattered spiritual sparks and the fulfillment of prophetic promises in the Messianic era.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר מ"ש כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ עפימ"ד במדרש מובא ברבינו בחיי וירבו ויעצמו במאד מאד, שני פעמים א' בעוה"ז וא' בעוה"ב, שנאמר ויאמר מי ילד לי את כל אלה, ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המדרש לא נסתלק יע"א מעולם עד שראה ס' רבוא מיוצאי חלציו. והנה אחר הסתלקות יע"א נתרבו עוד ריבוי עצום ומופלג שהרי מאמר וירב העם ויעצמו במאד מאד, נאמרה אחר מיתת יוסף ואחיו וכל הדור ההוא שאז התחילה השעבוד וכתיב כאשר יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ שע"י העינוי בא הרבוי , וכמו"ש הרמב"ן הק ' (פ' במדבר) שע"כ הי' שבט לוי ממועט באוכלוסין, לפי שלא היו בכלל גזירת העינוי לא היו בכלל הברכה של כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ, עכ"פ הריבוי הי' ע"י העינוי שזה הי' אחר מיתת יוסף וכל הדור, ולבסוף לא יצאו ממצרים רק ס' רבוא , ומספר זה כבר הי' להם בימי יע"א , ומה נעשה בריבוי העצום שנתרבה אחר מיתת יעקב, ולפי הנראה כל אלו מתו בג' ימי אפילה שיש דעה בגמ' שיצאו רק א' מס' רבוא והשאר נשארו במצרים, א"כ לכאורה יקשה כיון שמתו ונשארו במצרים, מה תועלת בברכה של כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ, ולא נשאר ממנו כלום כשיצאו ממצרים.
translation: And even if it can be said in another way, as it is written "may he increase and may he burst forth" (as brought in the Midrash cited by Rabbeinu Bachaye), "and they multiplied and became very mighty," twice—once in this world and once in the World to Come, as it is said, "And he said, who has borne me all these?" It will be explained in advance the words of the Midrash that he did not depart from this world until he saw six hundred thousand from his loins. And behold, after his departure, there was still an immense and extraordinary increase, for the saying "and the people multiplied and became very mighty" was said after the death of Joseph and his brothers and all that generation, when the oppression began. And it is written, "As they afflicted them, so they multiplied and so they burst forth," that through the affliction came the increase. And as the Ramban explains (in Parashat Bamidbar), therefore the tribe of Levi was few in number, since they were not included in the decree of affliction, they were not included in the blessing of "may he increase and may he burst forth." Nevertheless, the increase was through the affliction, which was after the death of Joseph and all that generation. In the end, only six hundred thousand left Egypt, and this number was already theirs in the days of the righteous one. What then happened to the immense increase that occurred after the death of Jacob? According to what appears, all of these died during the three days of darkness, as there is an opinion in the Gemara that only one out of six hundred thousand left, and the rest remained in Egypt. Therefore, it would seem difficult, since they died and remained in Egypt, what benefit is there in the blessing of "may he increase and may he burst forth," and nothing remained of them when they left Egypt?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of growth and multiplication in the Jewish people, emphasizing that this increase occurs both in this world and the next. It highlights that the suffering endured during slavery in Egypt paradoxically led to their significant growth, as noted in the teachings of the Ramban. The text raises a theological question about the apparent futility of this blessing of multiplication if many died in Egypt, suggesting a deeper understanding of divine providence and the continuity of the Jewish people despite hardships. Ultimately, it reflects on the enduring nature of God's promises and the mysterious ways in which they manifest.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ש בילקוט ראובני (פ' בא) בשם הרמ"ע מפאנו זלה"ה וז"ל לא ראו איש את אחיו בימי אפלה שמתו רבים מן הרשעים, וכתיב לכל בנ"י הי' אור במושבותם : בא הריבוי להורות כי אפילו הבלתי ראויים לגאול, כיון שמתו מתוך תשובה הי' להם אור במושבותם בגן עדן עכ"ל. עוד כתב בשם ס' יונת אלם בזה"ל אותם שמתו במצרים בימי אפלה כדי שיתוקנו אח"כ ע"י הצדיקים, שיצאו חפשי מכור הברזל, וכחם יפה על הגאולה ועל התמורה של אלה בסוד הייבום עכ"ל. מבואר שאותם שמתו במצרים בג' ימי אפלה מתוך תשובה בצירוף המיתה נתמרק עונם, גם יתוקנו אח"כ בדורות הבאים ע"י הצדיקים, עכ"פ אבידתם לא הי' אלא לשעה ויזכו גם הם לעוה"ב. ובזה יובן דברי המדרש וירבו ויעצמו במאד מאד שני פעמים שכן הן עתידין לפרות ולרבות לע"ל דכתיב ואמרת בלבבך מי ילד לי את כל אלה, דאל"ה לא הי' ברכה מה שנתרבו בריבוי עצום במצרים, שהרי לא יצאו משם ומתו בג' ימי אפילה, אמנם ע"י הבטחה זו שיזכו לחיי העוה"ב יש תועלת בריבוי העם, ובזה יובן שבישרתן רוה"ק כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ בלשון עתיד, דאם הי' אומר כן רבו וכן פרצו אין זה ברכה כלל כיון שמתו בימי אפילה ולא יצאו ממצרים, גם כיון שחטאו בנפשותם ולא רצו לצאת א"כ לכאורה לא הי' שום תועלת בברכה זו של ריבוי העם, ע"כ בישרה הרוה"ק בלשון עתיד כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ שכולם יתוקנו לע"ל ויזכו לחיי העוה"ב.
translation:
And even though it is stated in the Yalkut Reuveni (Parashat Bo) in the name of the Ram"ah of Pano, may his memory be blessed, that it is written: "No man saw his brother during the days of darkness, for many of the wicked died," and it is written, "But for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings": The abundance comes to teach that even those who were unworthy of redemption, since they died out of repentance, had light in their dwellings in the Garden of Eden. Thus far the quote. He also wrote in the name of the book Yonat Elam, as follows: "Those who died in Egypt during the days of darkness were to be rectified later by the righteous, who would go free from the iron furnace, and they have great power over the redemption and the transformation of these in the secret of levirate marriage." Thus far the quote. It is clear that those who died in Egypt during the three days of darkness, out of repentance combined with death, had their sins atoned for, and they will also be rectified later in future generations by the righteous. At least, their loss was only temporary, and they too will merit the World to Come. 

And with this, the words of the Midrash will be understood: "And they multiplied and grew exceedingly," two times, for they are destined to bear fruit and multiply in the future, as it is written, "And you will say in your heart, 'Who bore me these?'" For otherwise, there would have been no blessing in their tremendous multiplication in Egypt, since they did not leave there and died during the three days of darkness. However, through this promise that they will merit the life of the World to Come, there is benefit in the multiplication of the people. And thus it will be understood that the Holy Spirit announced in the future tense, "So shall they multiply and so shall they burst forth," for if it had said, "They multiplied and they burst forth," it would not be a blessing at all, since they died during the days of darkness and did not leave Egypt. Also, since they sinned with their souls and did not want to leave, it seems that there would be no benefit in this blessing of the multiplication of the people. Therefore, the Holy Spirit announced in the future tense, "So shall they multiply and so shall they burst forth," that all of them will be rectified in the future and will merit the life of the World to Come.
summary: The passage discusses the fate of those who died during the three days of darkness in Egypt, emphasizing that even the unworthy who repented before their death received a form of light in the afterlife. It suggests that their deaths served a purpose, as they would be rectified by the righteous in future generations, ultimately allowing them to attain a place in the World to Come. The text highlights the idea that the increase in the Israelite population during this time was a divine blessing, as it foreshadowed their future redemption and restoration. Thus, the promise of future rectification and eternal life provides meaning to their suffering and loss.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר עוד באופן אחר עפי"מ דאיתא בתנדב"א (פרק ז') ולא עשו כאשר דיבר אליהן מלך מצרים, דלאוה"ע חושבין מחשבה הרעה למעשה, אע"פ שלא עשו מעלה עליהם הקב"ה כאילו עשו, אבל לטובה לא נחשב להם כאילו עשה משא"כ בישראל הוי להיפוך, ע"כ אע"פ שהם לא עשו כאשר דיבר אליהן מלך מצרים, אעפ"כ מגיע עונש לפרעה כאילו היו עושין , וכן פי' הת"א עה"פ כי בדבר אשר זדו עליהם ארי בפתגמא די חשיבו מצראי למידן ית ישראל בי' דנינון , שהרי באמת לא נתקיים גזירת פרעה במה שצוה להשליך את הזכרים ליאור, רק לפי שחשבו לעשות נענשו על המחשבה בלבד, ואפשר שע"כ אמר הפסוק וכאשר יענו אותו בלשון עתיד ולא אמר כאשר עינו אותו, דגם על מה שרצו לענות אותם ג"כ נענשו ולהורות שגם לענין הברכה נחשב לישראל מה שרצו לענות אותם, כפרש"י ז"ל שנתנו לב עליהם לענות אותם אע"פ שלא נתקיים מחשבתם, לעומת זה נתברכו ישראל בכן ירבה וכן יפרוץ.
translation: And it can be said in another way according to what is stated in Tana Devei Eliyahu (Chapter 7) that they did not do as the King of Egypt spoke to them, for the nations of the world consider an evil thought as an action, even though they did not carry it out, the Holy One, blessed be He, treats it as if they did. However, for good, it is not considered as if they did, unlike Israel, where it is the opposite. Therefore, even though they did not do as the King of Egypt spoke to them, nevertheless, punishment comes to Pharaoh as if they were doing it. And so explains the Targum on the verse "For in the matter that they plotted against them," for the Egyptians thought to throw the Israelites into the river, and indeed the decree of Pharaoh was not fulfilled in that he commanded to throw the males into the river, but because they thought to do so, they were punished for the thought alone. And perhaps that is why the verse says "And as they will afflict him" in the future tense and does not say "as they afflicted him," for even for what they wanted to afflict them, they were punished, to teach that also regarding blessing, it is considered for Israel what they wanted to afflict them, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that they intended to afflict them even though their thought was not fulfilled. In contrast, Israel was blessed with "may He increase and may He break forth."
summary: The passage discusses the difference in how intentions are judged between the nations and Israel, emphasizing that while the nations are held accountable for evil thoughts as if they were actions, Israel is viewed favorably even for their good intentions. It highlights that Pharaoh was punished for his malicious thoughts against the Israelites, despite not carrying out his decree, illustrating that intentions matter significantly in divine judgment. The text also notes that the blessings for Israel are linked to their positive aspirations, reinforcing the idea that good intentions are recognized and rewarded by God.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד דהנה החרטומים באצטגנינות שלהם ראו עד סוף כל הדורות, כמו שראו מתחלה שיולד אאע"ה ומשה רבינו וכמשרז"ל עה"פ הבה נתחכמה לו נתחכם למושיען של ישראל, ורצו למנוע ולעכב ישועת ישראל לנצח, וכמ"ש המגיד אילו לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ממצרים הרי אנו ובנינו ובני בנינו משועבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים, עפ"י אמרם ז"ל שאם היו ישראל שוהין שם עוד רגע אחת היו נכנסין לשער הנו"ן שבטומאה ולא הי' עוד מציאות לצאת משם לעולם, נמצא שהם רצו למנוע מישראל כל הברכות העתידים לבוא עליהם, גם הריבוי עם שיזכו ישראל לעתיד כמ"ש עתידה אשה שתלד בכל יום, וכן שאר כל הברכות שיהי' לעתיד כולן רצו החרטומים למנוע מישראל, וכל זה נכלל באומרו וכאשר יענו אותו, ועפי"מ שפירש"י בכל מה שהם נותנין לב לענותן וכו' ולכאורה הרי עינו אותם בפועל ולא רק במחשבה לבד, והול"ל כאשר עינו אותו, ולדרכינו הכוונה על מה שרצו למנוע מהם כל הברכות דלעתיד שלא יגיעו לישראל, ובזה לא יכלו לענות אותם בפועל, אבל נתנו לב לענות אותם, ולעומת זה בישר אותם רוה"ק כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ ולא אמר כן רבה וכן פרץ והכוונה ג"כ על העתיד שאז יהי' הכל בבחינה גבוה יותר מכמו שהי' במצרים, ע"כ לא ניחא לי' לומר כן רבה וכן פרץ, ואמר בלשון עתיד כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ לעתיד שאז יהי' הריבוי בבחינה יותר גבוה כנ"ל.
translation: And even so, behold, the magicians with their astrology saw until the end of all generations, just as they saw from the beginning the birth of our forefather Abraham and Moses our teacher, as our sages of blessed memory explained on the verse "Come, let us outsmart him," they sought to prevent and delay the salvation of Israel forever. As the Maggid said, had the Holy One, blessed be He, not taken our ancestors out of Egypt, we and our children and our children's children would have been enslaved to Pharaoh in Egypt, according to what they said, that if Israel had remained there for even one more moment, they would have entered the gate of the letter "Nun" of impurity, and there would have been no possibility of ever leaving. Thus, they wanted to prevent Israel from all the blessings that were to come upon them, including the increase of people that Israel would merit in the future, as it is said, "In the future, a woman will give birth every day," and likewise all the other blessings that will be in the future, all of which the magicians sought to prevent from Israel. All this is included in the statement "And as they afflicted him," and according to the explanation of Rashi, in all that they gave their hearts to afflict him, etc. And seemingly, they afflicted him in action and not just in thought alone, and it should have said, "As they afflicted him." But according to our way, the intention is that they wanted to prevent them from all the blessings of the future that would not reach Israel, and in this, they could not afflict them in action, but they gave their hearts to afflict them. In contrast, the Holy Spirit assured them, "So shall it increase and so shall it burst forth," and did not say, "So shall it be great and so shall it break forth," and the intention is also regarding the future, when everything will be on a higher level than it was in Egypt. Therefore, it was not pleasing to him to say, "So shall it be great and so shall it break forth," and he said in the future tense, "So shall it increase and so shall it burst forth," for in the future, the increase will be on a higher level, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the attempts of the Egyptian magicians to foresee and prevent the future redemption of the Israelites, emphasizing their desire to obstruct all future blessings for the Jewish people. It highlights the idea that had the Israelites remained in Egypt even for a moment longer, they would have been irreversibly trapped in spiritual impurity. The text contrasts this with the divine promise of future abundance and blessings, indicating that the future growth and prosperity of the Jewish people will be of a higher spiritual quality than their past experiences in Egypt. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that despite opposition, God's plans for Israel's redemption and blessings will prevail.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר מה שאמר משה להשי"ת ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, דהנה איתא בגמ' (קידושין ע"א.) כתיב זה שמו וכתיב זה זכרי, אמר הקב"ה לא כשאני נכתב אני נקרא. נכתב אני ביו"ד ה"א ונקרא באל"ף דל"ת, ולכאורה מדוע הודיע הקב"ה דבר זה למשה בשליחות זו דייקא , ואפ"ל דהנה לעתיד אחר ביאת המשיח יהיו ישראל בבחי ' להגות את השם באותיותיו והשם יקרא ככתיבתו, וזה הי' שאלתו של משרע"ה ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם: דהנה ישראל היו מצפים שיהי' הגאולה שלימה מיד והי' אפשר להיות כן אלא שהחטא גרם לאחרו, וחשש משרע"ה שאם יבא לישראל ויזכיר להם שמו של הקב"ה וישמעו שעדיין אינו הוגה את השם באותיותיו, ישיגו מזה שעדיין אין זה גאולה שלימה, וז"ש ואמרו לי מה שמו ולא אמר וישאלו לי מה שמו, והכוונה בזה דהיו ביניהם הרבה שידעו שמותיו של הקב"ה, עמרם זקן ויושב בישיבה וכל שבע לוי עסקו בתורה ובמצות וידעו מזה דלא כשאני נכתב אני נקרא ולזה יאמרו לי מה שמו וישיגו שעדיין שמו של הקב"ה הוא בהעלם ואין זה גאולה נצחית, ויהי' להם לישראל צער גדול מזה ומה אומר אלהם לנחם אותם.
translation: And we will explain what Moses said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, and they said to me, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" Behold, it is written in the Gemara (Kiddushin 71a), "This is My name" and "This is My remembrance." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "Not as I am written, am I called. I am written with a Yud and a Heh and am called with an Aleph and a Dalet." And seemingly, why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, inform Moses of this specifically in this mission? One could say that in the future, after the coming of the Messiah, Israel will be in a state of pronouncing the name with its letters, and the name will be called as it is written. This was the question of Moses: "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" For behold, Israel was expecting that the redemption would be complete immediately, and it could have been so, but the sin caused it to be delayed. Moses was concerned that if he came to Israel and reminded them of the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and they heard that the name is still not pronounced with its letters, they would conclude that this is not a complete redemption. Therefore, it is written, "And they said to me, 'What is His name?'" and it does not say, "And they will ask me, 'What is His name?'" The intention here is that there were many among them who knew the names of the Holy One, Blessed be He. Amram was an elder and sat in the study hall, and all the Levites were engaged in Torah and commandments and knew that "Not as I am written, am I called." And thus they would say to me, "What is His name?" and they would understand that the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is in concealment, and this is not an eternal redemption. And it would be a great sorrow for Israel because of this, and what shall I say to them to comfort them?
summary: The passage discusses Moses' inquiry to God about His name, highlighting the distinction between how God's name is written and pronounced. It suggests that in the future, during the Messianic era, the name of God will be pronounced as it is written, signifying a complete redemption. Moses feared that if he revealed God's name to the Israelites and they perceived it as still being in a concealed form, it would lead them to despair, as it would indicate that the ultimate redemption had not yet been achieved. Thus, the emphasis is on the hope for a future where God's presence is fully revealed and experienced.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הזוה"ק פ' זו (דף ב' ע"ב) כד נחתו לבבל אתפתחו שמיא ושראת רוח נבואה קדישא על יחזקאל וחמא כל מה דחמא , ואמר לון לישראל הא מאריכון הכא וכל חילי שמיא ורתיכו דאתו למידר ביניכון , לא הימנוהו עד דאצטריך לגלאה כל מה דחמא , וארא כך וארא כך וכו' כיון דחמא ישראל כך חדו, וכד שמעו מלין מפומי ' דיחזקאל לא חיישו על גלותהון כלל, דהא ידעו דקוב"ה לא שביק לון וכו' ותנינן בכל אתר דישראל גלו תמן שכינתא גלתה עמהון עכ"ד הזוה"ק , וזאת נחמתינו בכל דורות הגלות שהבוי"ת כביכול עמנו בגלות ואל יעזבנו ואל יעשנו לנצח, ולדרכינו היתה שאלתו של משרע"ה מה אומר אליהם במה אוכל לנחם אותם על בשורה זו שיהי' עוד גלות, והשיב לו השי"ת אהי ' אשר אהי ' שהייתי עם ישראל במצרים ואני אהי ' עם ישראל גם בגלות האחר, וזה הוא נחמה גדולה לישראל, וכיון שאמר לו הקב"ה כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי ' אשר אהי ', חשב משה שמוכרח לומר כן לכל ישראל כל עוד שלא פירש לו הקב"ה אופן הציווי באופן אחר, וכמו שמצינו שהוצרך הקב"ה לומר למשה אחר מתן תורה לך אמור להם שובו לכם לאהליכם . דאל"כ הי אסור להם לחזור לביתם, אע"פ שכבר אזיל טעם האיסור שכבר הי' אחר מ"ת , ולמדו חז"ל מזה דכל דבר שבמנין צריך מנין אחר להתירו.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Zohar, Parashat Zu (page 2b), that when they descended to Babylon, the heavens opened, and the holy spirit of prophecy rested upon Ezekiel, and he saw all that he saw. And he said to the Israelites, "Here is the place of your exile, and all the hosts of heaven are gathered to measure between you." They did not believe him until it was necessary to reveal all that he saw. And I saw this way and I saw that way, etc. When the Israelites saw this, they rejoiced. And when they heard words from the mouth of Ezekiel, they did not worry about their exile at all, for they knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not abandon them, etc. And it is taught in every place that when Israel was exiled, the Shechinah was exiled with them. Thus is our comfort in all the generations of exile, that the Holy One, blessed be He, as it were, is with us in exile and will not abandon us and will not make us desolate forever. And to our path was the question of Moshe Rabbeinu, "What shall I say to them? How can I comfort them with this news that there will be another exile?" And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him, "I will be that which I will be," that I was with Israel in Egypt, and I will be with Israel also in the last exile. And this is a great comfort for Israel. And when the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "So shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I will be that which I will be,'" Moshe thought that he must say this to all of Israel as long as the Holy One, blessed be He, did not explain to him the manner of the command in another way, just as we find that the Holy One, blessed be He, had to tell Moshe after the giving of the Torah, "Go say to them, 'Return to your tents.'" For otherwise, it would have been forbidden for them to return to their homes, even though the reason for the prohibition had already ceased since it was after the giving of the Torah. And the Sages learned from this that anything that is counted requires another count to permit it.
summary: The passage discusses the profound comfort found in the belief that God's presence accompanies the Jewish people even during their exiles, as highlighted in the Zohar. It emphasizes that despite the hardships of galut (exile), the Shechinah (Divine Presence) remains with Israel, providing solace and assurance. The dialogue between God and Moses illustrates that God's promise of presence ("I will be who I will be") serves as a source of hope for the Israelites, reinforcing the idea that divine support persists through all trials. This theological insight underscores the enduring relationship between God and the Jewish people, even in times of suffering.

passage_content: וכמו"כ לעניננו דהנה לא ידעו כל ישראל מזה דלא כשאני נכתב אני נקרא ורק יחידי סגולה ידעו מזה, אבל ההמון עם לא יבינו ממה שלא יהגה משה את השם באותיותיו שעדיין אינו גאולה נצחיות, וא"כ יותר טוב שלא יגלה להם כלל שיהי' עוד גלות אחרת דדי' לצרה בשעתה, נמצא ששני המימרות הם אמת ויציב, שלבני עלי' שהשיגו שעדיין אין זה גאולה נצחית, להם יאמר אהי ' אשר אהי ' כדי לנחם אותם שהשי"ת יהי' עם ישראל בכל גלותם, אבל לההמון עם שלא ידעו השגה זו. להם יאמר אהי ' שלחני אליכם ולא לגלות להם שאר גליות דדי' לצרה בשעתה, נמצא שלא הי' חזרה ח"ו בדברי השי"ת מדבריו הראשונים, רק שלא הבין משרע"ה דכוונת הקב"ה שלבני עלי' בלבד יאמר כן, וז"ש לו הקב"ה כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי ' שלחני אליכם, דהיינו לפשוטי עם תאמר אהי ' שלחני וגו', ונרמז זה במלת כה תאמר, עפי"ד ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה בפ ' מטות בהקדם אמרם ז"ל כל הנביאים נתנבאו בכה מוסיף עליהם משה שהתנבא בכה ובזה הדבר, ונחזה אנן בעת שאמר בבחינת כה בדיבור של עצמו היה ע"י שליח, אבל בעת שאמר בבחינת זה הדבר ששכינה הי' מדברת מתוך גרונו, א"כ הו"ל ע"י עצמו כביכול, והנה קיי"ל אין בעה"ב עובר בבל תלין אא"כ תובעו, לא תבעו אינו עובר עליו, וקיי"ל דהשוכר פועלים ע"י שליח ואמר להם שכרכם על בעה"ב, אין שום אחד מהם עובר בבל תלין, ולפי"ז נראה דלבני עלי' אמר משה בבחינת זה הדבר, ואי דהוה ע"י עצמו וצריך ליתן להם שכר מיד וכו' אמנם הם לא יתבעו חלקם בעוה"ז ותו ליכא בל תלין, אבל המון עם שאין יודעין מעלת עוה"ב, יש לחוש פן יתבעו חלקם בפיהם לתת שכרם מיד בעוה"ז ובכה"ג איכא בל תלין, והקב"ה חפץ חסד לתת להם שארית בארצות החיים בעוה"ב, לזאת הודיעו ית ' דרכיו למשה לומר להם בבחינת כה, ואז הוי ע"י שליח וליכא בל תלין עכת"ד ז"ל עיי"ש, וז"א כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי ' שלחני אליכם, היינו להמון עם שאמירתך אליהם בבחינת כה תאמר אהי ' לבד ולא תגלה מגליות העתידים.
translation: And likewise regarding our matter, behold, all of Israel did not know this, that as I am written, I am called, and only a select few knew this. However, the masses do not understand why Moshe did not pronounce the name with its letters, for it is still not an eternal redemption. Therefore, it is better not to reveal to them at all that there will be another exile, which is sufficient for the suffering at that time. Thus, both statements are true and stable: for the elevated ones who have attained that this is still not an eternal redemption, to them it is said, "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh," to comfort them that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will be with Israel in all their exiles. But for the masses who do not understand this attainment, to them it is said, "Ehyeh sent me to you," and not to reveal to them the other exiles, which are sufficient for the suffering at that time. Thus, there was no reversal, Heaven forbid, in the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, from His initial words, only that Moshe did not understand that the intention of the Holy One, Blessed be He, was to say this only to the elevated ones. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "So shall you say to the children of Israel, 'Ehyeh sent me to you,'" meaning to the simple folk you shall say, "Ehyeh sent me," etc. This is hinted at in the words "So shall you say," according to the teaching of the holy Zohar in Parashat Matot, as our sages said, all the prophets prophesied with "So," but Moshe added to them, for he prophesied with "So" and with "this thing." And we see that at the time he said "So," in his own speech, it was through a messenger, but at the time he said "this thing," the Shechinah was speaking from his throat, thus it was as if by himself, so to speak. And behold, we hold that a master of a house does not transgress "You shall not let it remain overnight" unless he is demanded, if they do not demand, he does not transgress it. And we hold that one who hires workers through a messenger and tells them their wages are on the master of the house, none of them transgress "You shall not let it remain overnight." According to this, it seems that Moshe spoke to the elevated ones in the aspect of "this thing," and if it were by himself and he needed to give them their wages immediately, etc., however, they would not demand their share in this world, and thus there would be no "You shall not let it remain overnight." But the masses, who do not know the merit of the World to Come, there is concern that they might demand their share with their mouths to give them their wages immediately in this world, and in such a case, there is "You shall not let it remain overnight." And the Holy One, Blessed be He, desires kindness to give them a remnant in the lands of the living in the World to Come. For this reason, He made known His ways to Moshe to say to them in the aspect of "So," and then it would be through a messenger, and there would be no "You shall not let it remain overnight." Thus, it is said, "So shall you say to the children of Israel, 'Ehyeh sent me to you,'" meaning to the masses that your saying to them is in the aspect of "So shall you say, 'Ehyeh'" alone, and you shall not reveal the future exiles.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the understanding of the elite and the masses regarding divine revelation and redemption. It emphasizes that while the elite may grasp the concept of a non-eternal redemption, the general populace should not be burdened with knowledge of future exiles, as it could lead to despair. Therefore, God instructs Moses to communicate a message of hope ("I am that I am") to the people in a way that does not reveal the complexities of future exiles, ensuring that the divine promise remains intact and accessible. This reflects a theological insight into God's desire to provide comfort and maintain faith among the masses while reserving deeper truths for those capable of understanding them.
