passage_content: או"י באופן אחר קצת דהי ' הכרח לגלות לבני עלי' שאין זה גאולה נצחיות, דלפי שהשיגו בחינת השם יקרא ככתיבתו, ע"כ הי' צורך אליהם ידיעה זו להלכה, דעדיין לא הגיע הזמן להגות את השם באותיותיו, ואף אם יתודע להם גלויות העתידים לא יתייאשו בשביל זה מן הגאולה, כי המאמין לא יחוש ואף יתמהמה חכה לו בכל יום שיבא, משא"כ המון בית ישראל, לא הי' להם נפק"מ בידיעה זו להלכה, כי בלא"ה לא השיגו להגות השם בבחינה דלעתיד , ולגביהם איכא חששא שעי"ז יתייאשו ח"ו מן הגאולה אם יתוודע להם אריכת הגלות, ע"כ טוב יותר שלא לגלות להם, וז"ש כה תאמר לבנ"י היינו להמון בנ"י שדיבר אליהם בבחינת כה. תאמר להם אהי ' שלחני ולא תודיעם מגליות העתידים.
translation: In another way, it is necessary to reveal to the sons of Eli that this is not an eternal redemption, for since they have attained the aspect of the name as it is written, therefore it was necessary for them to have this knowledge in halacha, that the time has not yet come to pronounce the name with its letters. And even if they were to be informed of the future exiles, they would not despair of the redemption because the believer does not feel it and even waits for it every day to come. However, for the multitude of the House of Israel, this knowledge in halacha would not be significant, for they have not attained to pronounce the name in the aspect of the future, and for them, there is a concern that through this they might despair, Heaven forbid, from the redemption if they were to be informed of the length of the exile. Therefore, it is better not to reveal it to them. And this is what is meant by "So shall you say to the children of Israel," referring to the multitude of the children of Israel to whom He spoke in this aspect of "So." Tell them, "I am that I am" has sent me, and do not inform them of the future exiles.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of revealing to the descendants of Eli that their redemption is not eternal, emphasizing that they have not yet reached the level of understanding the Divine Name as it will be in the future. It suggests that while the faithful may remain hopeful for redemption despite knowledge of future exiles, the broader Jewish community might despair if they were aware of the prolonged exile. Therefore, it is deemed better not to disclose this information to them, highlighting a distinction between the spiritual awareness of the few and the potential despair of the many.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר מה שחלקו המצריים על החרטומים ואמרו שבן מצרי לא יגאל את ישראל לעולם, נראה ששניהם כוונו אל האמת ולא טעו, דזה וודאי שגאולת ישראל א"א להיות רק מצד הקדושה, כמו שמפורש בתנדב"א במי הקב"ה מושיע את ישראל במי שמשכים ומעריב בבתי כנסיות וכו ', וא"א שתהי' ישועה רק ע"י עובדי ד' באמת, ומה שהחרטומים היו מסופקים בדבר אם מושיען של ישראל יהי' מצרי או ישראל, לא טעו לגמרי אלא שניבאו ולא ידעו מה ניבאו, ויובן עפי"מ דאיתא בגמ' (מגילה י"ג ע"א) ואשתו היהודית ילדה את ירד ואת חבר ואת יקותיאל, (עיי"ש שדרשו רז"ל כל אלה השמות על משרע"ה , היהודית זה בתי' בת פרעה), והקשו בגמ' ילדה והא רבויי רביתי ', אלא לומר לך שכל המגדל יתום ויתומה בתוך ביתו מעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו ילדו, למה נקרא שמה יהודית מפני שכפרה בע"ז, ובאבות דר' נתן חושב אותה בין הט ' שנכנסו בחיים לג"ע, אולם מצד התולדה היתה מצרית שנולדה בבית פרעה, ובאמת היתה משורש קדושה שורש ישראל, וכתב הרמ"ע מפאנו איך מותר לנו לקבל גרים מאוה"ע , הרי כתיב יצב גבולות עמים נמצא שהוא השגת גבול ותירץ דגרים מנן נדחו, שבאמת הם נשמות ישראל בשרשן רק שנדחו, וממילא אין כאן השגת גבול, וכמו"כ להיפוך נמצא גם בין ישראל נשמות עמלקים מזרע ערב רב, וכמו שכ' הרמב"ן הק ' עה"פ פן יש בכם שורש פורה ראש ולענה וזלה"ק ואמר פורה ראש לרמוז כי משורש מתוק לא יצא מר, וכל אשר לבבו שלם עם השם ולא הרהר כלל בע"ז לא יוליד מודה בה, ואל תקשה עלי בזה מן הכתוב והוליד בן פריץ, כי אמת הדבר וסוד גדול לא אוכל לפרש בו עכ"ל, והש"ך על התורה והרקנטי גילו סודו, שבגלגול הקדום הי' בן רשע ע"כ נצמח מזה היותו רשע, וחכמת הגלגול הי' בדורות הקודמים סוד עצום רק אחר שנתגלה ספר הזוה"ק וכתבי האריז"ל נתגלה דבר זה.
translation: And we will explain what the Egyptians divided regarding the magicians and said that a son of an Egyptian will never redeem Israel. It seems that both of them were directed towards the truth and did not err, for it is certain that the redemption of Israel can only come from holiness, as it is explicitly stated in the Tana D'Bei Eliyahu that the Holy One, Blessed be He, saves Israel through one who rises early and prays in synagogues, etc. It is impossible for there to be salvation except through true servants of God. And the fact that the magicians were in doubt about whether the redeemer of Israel would be Egyptian or Israeli, they did not err completely, but rather they prophesied without knowing what they were prophesying. This can be understood according to what is stated in the Gemara (Megillah 13a) that his Jewish wife bore Yared, and Chaver, and Yekutiel (see there that our Sages expounded all these names on Moshe Rabbeinu; the Jewish one refers to Batya, the daughter of Pharaoh). The Gemara asks, "She bore, but I have many children," rather to tell you that anyone who raises an orphan boy or girl in their home is considered by the Scripture as if they gave birth to them. Why is she called Jewish? Because she denied idolatry. And in Avot de-Rabbi Natan, she is counted among the ten who entered alive into the Garden of Eden. However, from the perspective of lineage, she was Egyptian, born in the house of Pharaoh, but in truth, she was from the root of holiness, the root of Israel. The Ram"ah of Pano wrote how it is permissible for us to accept converts from the nations of the world, for it is written, "He set the boundaries of the nations," which indicates that it is a matter of boundary transgression, and he explained that converts are indeed rejected, for they are truly souls of Israel at their root, only that they were rejected. Therefore, there is no boundary transgression here. Likewise, conversely, it is found among Israel that there are souls of Amalek from the mixed multitude, as the Ramban wrote in his commentary on the verse "Lest there be among you a root bearing poisonous and bitter fruit," and he said that "bearing fruit" hints that from a sweet root, bitter cannot emerge. And anyone whose heart is whole with the Holy One and does not even contemplate idolatry will not give birth to one who acknowledges it. And do not challenge me on this from the verse "and he bore a son of a tyrant," for it is true and a great secret that I cannot explain here. Thus, the Shach on the Torah and the Rekanti revealed his secret, that in the previous incarnation, he was a son of a wicked one, and therefore it sprouted from his being wicked. The wisdom of reincarnation was a tremendous secret in previous generations, only after the revelation of the Zohar and the writings of the Arizal was this matter revealed.
summary: The passage discusses the belief that the redemption of Israel can only come from holiness, emphasizing that true salvation must be through genuine servants of God. It reflects on the ambiguity of the Egyptian magicians' prophecy regarding a potential Egyptian savior, suggesting they were partially correct but lacked full understanding. The text also explores the concept of souls, indicating that even those from non-Jewish backgrounds may have roots in Israelite holiness, while also acknowledging the presence of negative souls among the Jewish people. Ultimately, it highlights the intricate relationship between lineage, spiritual essence, and the potential for redemption.

passage_content: ובזה א"ש דמה שאמרו המצריים בן מצרי לא יגאל את ישראל לעולם, הוא אמת ויציב דא"א שתהי' גאולתן של ישראל כ"א ע"י עובד ד', ולא יכלו החרטומים לחלוק ע"ז כי דבר זה הי' ברור בעיניהם. אמנם החרטומים הי' להם חשבון אחר ואולי השיגו ענין גלגולי הנשמות, א"כ יצוייר שיהי' בן מצרי ואעפ"כ יהי' קדוש וצדיק וכמו בתי' שהיתה מצרית מצד התולדה ואעפ"כ נעשית צדיקת , ובשורש היתה נשמתה מישראל וע"ד מ"ש הרמ"ע מפאנו זלל"ה , ע"כ חששו שאפשר שיהי' בן מצרי מצד הלידה ואח"כ יתדבק בשורש הקדושה, אבל זה הי' ברור להם שבשעת הגאולה בהכרח שיהי' דבוק אל מקור הקדושה ורק אז יוכל להיות הגאולה על ידו, וניבאו ולא ידעו מה ניבאו כי משרע"ה מושיען של ישראל נקרא בנה של בתי' שהיתה מצרית מצד התולדה.
translation: And in this, I understand that what the Egyptians said, "A son of an Egyptian shall not redeem Israel forever," is true and certain, for it is impossible for the redemption of Israel to be through anyone other than a servant of God, and the magicians could not dispute this because this matter was clear in their eyes. However, the magicians had a different calculation, and perhaps they grasped the concept of the transmigration of souls. Therefore, it could be imagined that there would be a son of an Egyptian, and yet he could be holy and righteous, just as the daughter of Pharaoh was Egyptian by birth and yet became righteous, and in her root, her soul was from Israel, according to what the Ram"a of Pano, may his memory be blessed, wrote. Thus, they were concerned that it was possible for there to be a son of an Egyptian by birth and then he would attach himself to the root of holiness. But it was clear to them that at the time of redemption, it was necessary for him to be connected to the source of holiness, and only then could the redemption come through him. They prophesied and did not know what they were prophesying, for Moshe Rabbeinu, the Redeemer of Israel, is called the son of the daughter of Pharaoh, who was Egyptian by birth.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that the redemption of the Jewish people can only be achieved through a true servant of God, emphasizing that a "son of an Egyptian" cannot redeem Israel. The Egyptian magicians understood this principle, recognizing that true holiness must be rooted in divine origin. However, they speculated about the possibility of a soul's reincarnation, suggesting that a person could be born of Egyptian lineage yet still possess a holy essence. Ultimately, it is asserted that during the time of redemption, one must be connected to the source of holiness to fulfill the role of a redeemer, as exemplified by Moses, who was considered the son of an Egyptian woman yet was divinely chosen.

passage_content: ולזה יעצו לפרעה שישליכו גם את בניהן של המצריים ליאור, מפני שאפשר שיהי' מושיען של ישראל נולד בבית מצרי, וז"ש אין אנו יודעין אם ישראל הוא או מצרי, אמנם המון המצריים לא ידעו סוד זה לכן לא רצו לקבל דברי החרטומים, כיון שזה ידעו בבירור שא"א שתהי' גאולה לישראל רק ע"י איש קדוש, ואולי אח"כ גילו להם החרטומים את סודם ולבסוף קיבלו מהם. ממילא אין סתירה בדברי חכז"ל , כי מקודם לא רצו לקבל אבל אח"כ שגילו להם סודם קבלוהו, רק חכז"ל קיצרו במעשה כמו שקיצרו בלשונם בכמה ענינים ובפרט בענין זה שהי' סוד עצום וכמוס, ע"כ העלימו אותה חכז"ל ולא האריכו בדבר, ולפי"ז מ"ד במדרשים שיום א' נתקיים הגזירה גם על ילדי המצריים אינו חולק ע"ד המדרש הנ"ל ואלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים.
translation: And for this reason, they advised Pharaoh to also cast the children of the Egyptians into the Nile, because it is possible that the Redeemer of Israel would be born in an Egyptian home. Therefore, it is said, "We do not know if he is an Israelite or an Egyptian." However, the masses of the Egyptians did not know this secret, and thus they did not want to accept the words of the magicians, since they knew for certain that there could be no redemption for Israel except through a holy man. Perhaps later the magicians revealed their secret to them, and in the end, they accepted it from them. Consequently, there is no contradiction in the words of our Sages, for initially, they did not want to accept, but afterward, when the secret was revealed to them, they accepted it. Our Sages abbreviated the account, just as they abbreviated their language in several matters, especially in this matter, which was a profound and hidden secret; therefore, they concealed it and did not elaborate on it. According to this, the opinion in the Midrashim that on the first day the decree was also enacted upon the children of the Egyptians does not contradict the aforementioned Midrash, and both these and those are the words of the living God.
summary: The passage discusses the advice given to Pharaoh to throw the Egyptian children into the Nile, highlighting the belief that a potential savior for Israel could arise from within Egypt. It emphasizes that the Egyptians were initially unaware of this possibility, leading them to reject the magicians' counsel. However, once the secret was revealed to them, they accepted it, illustrating the profound idea that redemption for Israel must come through a holy individual. The text also notes that the sages intentionally condensed their teachings on this complex and hidden matter, affirming that both perspectives in the midrash are valid and reflect divine truth.

passage_content: ועכ"פ זה ברור שא"א שתהי' ישועה לישראל רק מצד הקדושה, ולא ח"ו ע"י רשעים, וכ"ש ע"י אותן המפיצים מינות והפרת הדת רח"ל , וה' ישמרינו מלחשוב ההיפך אפילו רגע א', ולא יאומן כי יסופר שיחשבו עליהם שהם גואלי ישראל רח"ל מהאי דעתא , מי הי' יכול לצייר כזאת בדורות הקודמים, שברבות הימים ימצאו אנשים מישראל שיחשבו מחשבות און כאלו, ואסור לשכוח ענין זה אפילו רגע, ורואין בעוה"ר בזמן שנדמה לקצת בנ"א שנעשו על ידם נסים מדומים, הגם שאח"כ נתברר לכל שלא הי' נסים כלל, אעפ"כ כמה מינות ואפיקורסות נשאר בעולם, וכמה אלפים ורבבות מישראל נשאר בלבם טינא וארס המינות מאותה הרגע שחשבו שנעשה להם נס וכח המינות נצח רח"ל , שעי"ז באו לידי קירוב הדעת למינים ואפיקורסים, פוק חזי עד כמה חששו חכז"ל שלא ישאר זכר למינים כדי שלא יבואו בנ"א להימשך אחריהם, ואפילו להתרפאות ממינים אסור כדאי' בגמ' (ע"ז כ"ז:) מעשה בבן דמא בן אחותו של ר' ישמעאל שהכישו נחש ובא יעקב איש כפר סכניא לרפאותו , ולא הניחו ר' ישמעאל וכו' ולא הספיק לגמור את הדבר עד שיצתה נשמתו ומת, קרא עליו ר' ישמעאל אשריך בן דמא שגופך טהור ויצתה נשמתך בטהרה ולא עברת על דברי חבירך שהיו אומרים ופורץ גדר ישכנו נחש, הרי שאפילו במקום סכנת נפשות אסור להתרפאות מהם ודוחה אף פקנ"פ החמור, מטעם שלא יבואו לימשך אחריהם כמו שאמרו שם שאני מינות דמשכא , וחלילה להעלות על הדעת שתהי' על ידיהם גאולה וישועה לישראל, כמה אלפים ורבבות מישראל השמידו והעבירו מדרך התוה"ק רח"ל , ואנו צריכים להיות מוכנים ומזומנים על כל צרה שלא תבוא, כי א"א לידע מה יולד יום, וצריך להתחזק באמונה שלא להתפעל מכל אותות ומופתים ונסים ואפילו אם יעמידו חמה באמצע הרקיע, רק נתחזק באמונת השי"ת כיתד שלא תמוט,
translation: And nevertheless, it is clear that there cannot be salvation for Israel except through holiness, and not, Heaven forbid, through the wicked, and certainly not through those who spread heresy and violate the faith, may the Lord protect us from thinking the opposite even for a moment. It is unbelievable that they would think of themselves as redeemers of Israel, Heaven forbid, from such a mindset. Who could have imagined such a thing in previous generations, that in the course of time there would be people from Israel who would entertain such false thoughts? And one must not forget this matter even for a moment. We see, unfortunately, in our times, when it seems to some people that miracles have been performed through them, even though it later becomes clear to all that there were no miracles at all, nevertheless, how much heresy and apostasy remain in the world, and how many thousands and tens of thousands of Israel remain with the poison and venom of heresy in their hearts from the moment they thought a miracle had been done for them, and the power of heresy has prevailed, Heaven forbid. As a result, they have come to a closer understanding of heretics and apostates. Come and see how much our sages were concerned that no trace of heretics should remain so that people would not be drawn after them. And even to be healed by heretics is forbidden, as stated in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 27b) regarding the story of Ben Dama, the nephew of Rabbi Ishmael, who was bitten by a snake, and Yaakov from the village of Sakhneya came to heal him, but Rabbi Ishmael did not allow it, etc., and he did not have time to complete the matter before his soul departed and he died. Rabbi Ishmael exclaimed about him, "Blessed are you, Ben Dama, that your body is pure and your soul departed in purity, and you did not transgress the words of your friend who said, 'One who breaks a fence, a snake will bite him.'" Thus, even in a situation of life-threatening danger, it is forbidden to be healed by them, and it overrides even the severe danger to life, for the reason that one should not be drawn after them, as they said there that heresy draws one in. And it is a disgrace to even entertain the thought that redemption and salvation for Israel could come through them. How many thousands and tens of thousands of Israel have they destroyed and led away from the path of the holy Torah, Heaven forbid. And we must be prepared and ready for any trouble that may come, for one cannot know what the day will bring. We must strengthen our faith not to be swayed by any signs, wonders, or miracles, even if they were to stand the sun in the middle of the sky, but rather we should strengthen ourselves in the faith of the Holy One, blessed be He, like a peg that does not falter.
summary: The passage emphasizes that true salvation for Israel can only come from holiness and not through the actions of the wicked or heretics. It warns against the dangerous belief that miracles performed by such individuals could be seen as redemptive, highlighting the historical concern of the sages to avoid any association with heresy. The text stresses the importance of maintaining unwavering faith in God, regardless of apparent signs or wonders, and encourages vigilance against the influence of heretical thoughts that can lead many astray from the true path of Torah. Ultimately, it calls for readiness and strength in faith to withstand any challenges that may arise.

passage_content: וכמו שפירשתי על מה שאמר הרן אם אברם נוצח אני משלו, ואם נמרוד נוצח אני משלו, ונענש ולא נעשה לו נס להנצל בשביל שלא הי' חזק באמונתו, אעפ"י שהי' לו להרן נסיון גדול מאד, כי אלמלי נמרוד נוצח הי' נשאר יחידי בעולם ואולי לא הי' אפשר לו להתקיים ולהתחזק באמונתו אעפי"כ לפי שהי' לו מעיקרא מחשבה זו שאם ישרף אברהם יהי' משל נמרוד, לא הי' נחשב עוד למאמין, כי המאמין האמיתי צריך להיות חזק באמונתו ואיך שיהי' לא יזוז זיז כ"ש מאמונתו ולידע שהכל הבל וריק מה שהוא נגד אמונת השי"ת ותורתו הקדושה. לא יאומן כי יסופר שיהי' דור כזה שיטעו באמונתם כ"כ עד שאפילו אם אברם נוצח הם משל נמרוד, רק שאין מגלים מחשבתם זה מחמת הבושה, וכל שכן אם נדמה להם שנמרוד נוצח אז צווחין ככרוכיא משל נמרוד אני, ובעוה"ר הצדיקים מדור הקדום נאבדו ונשרפו במחנות השמד ואנו נשארנו לאנחה, אולם אף אם אברהם נשרף ח"ו לומר משל נמרוד אני, ובכל זאת אנו מאמינים בהשי"ת ובתורתו הקדושה וח"ו להודות לדברי המינים והאפיקורסים.
translation: And as I explained regarding what the Rav said, if Avram is victorious, he is from his own, and if Nimrod is victorious, he is from his own, and he is punished and no miracle is done for him to be saved because he was not strong in his faith, even though he had a very great trial. For had Nimrod been victorious, he would have remained alone in the world, and perhaps it would not have been possible for him to exist and strengthen himself in his faith. Nevertheless, since he had this thought from the beginning that if Avraham is burned, he will be from Nimrod, he would no longer be considered a believer. For the true believer must be strong in his faith, and no matter what happens, he should not budge even a little from his faith, and he must know that everything is vanity and emptiness that is against the faith in the Blessed Creator and His holy Torah. It is unbelievable that there would be a generation that would be so misled in their faith that even if Avram is defeated, they would say they are from Nimrod, only they do not reveal this thought out of shame. All the more so if they imagine that Nimrod is defeated, then they scream like a dog, "I am from Nimrod." And woe to us, the righteous from the previous generation were lost and burned in the camps of destruction, and we remain as a sigh. However, even if Avraham were to be burned, Heaven forbid, to say "I am from Nimrod," nonetheless we believe in the Blessed Creator and His holy Torah, and Heaven forbid to acknowledge the words of the heretics and the apikorsim.
summary: The passage discusses the unwavering faith of the true believer, exemplified by the character of Avraham, in contrast to the doubts that may arise in the face of persecution or adversity. It emphasizes that even if Avraham were to be defeated or harmed, a true believer would not waver in their faith or align themselves with the beliefs of the wicked, represented by Nimrod. The text warns against the dangers of losing faith and succumbing to the ideologies of those who oppose the sanctity of God and His Torah, highlighting the importance of steadfastness in belief despite external challenges. Ultimately, it reaffirms the commitment to faith in God and His teachings, regardless of circumstances.

passage_content: ובזה נבוא לביאור הפסוק הבה נתחכמה לו פן ירבה, גם לבאר דברי המדרש טפלו עלי שקר זדים, דהנה פרעה חשש שמא ילחמו ישראל עמהם, אבל באמת ישראל המאמינים בתוה"ק אין לוחמים נגד האומות, ורק התורה ותפלה הוא כלי זיינם של בנ"י , וכמו שפי' התרגום עה"פ אשר לקחתי מיד האמורי בחרבי ובקשתי בצלותי ובעותי , ואם היו הולכין בדרך הזה תמיד כבר היינו אחר הישועה שלימה, אם לא צרה הזאת אשר תפס הסט"א להטעות הכלל ישראל בגאולה מרה כזו, ד' ישמרנו מהם ומהמונם, וז"פ דברי המדרש טפלו עלי שקר זדים שאמרו הבה נתחכמה לו פן ירבה וגו' ונלחם בנו, דזהו שקר שהרי בנ"י אין לוחמים נגד האומות שהוא איסור גמור, וע"כ כתבה התוה"ק לשון ונלחם בלשון נפעל ולא אמר וילחם בנו, לרמז שהמלחמה לישראל נעשית מאלי' ומן השמים. כמו שאמר משה לישראל ד' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, וכן אמר דוד המלך אם תקום עלי מלחמה בזאת אני בוטח וגו' ע"כ אמר ונלחם בנו פיו הכשילו לומר כן שהמלחמה לישראל נעשית מן השמים.
translation: And with this, we will come to explain the verse "Come, let us be wise against him, lest he multiply," and also to clarify the words of the Midrash "They have laid falsehoods upon me, O wicked ones." Behold, Pharaoh feared that the Israelites would fight against them, but in truth, the Israelites who believe in the Torah and commandments do not fight against the nations. Only the Torah and prayer are the weapons of the Children of Israel, as the translation explains regarding the verse "which I took from the Amorite with my sword and with my prayer." And if they would always walk in this way, we would already be after complete redemption, were it not for this trouble that the evil inclination has seized to mislead the entire Israel in such a bitter redemption. May God protect us from them and from their multitude. Thus, the words of the Midrash "They have laid falsehoods upon me, O wicked ones," who said "Come, let us be wise against him, lest he multiply, and fight against us," is indeed a falsehood, for the Children of Israel do not fight against the nations, which is a complete prohibition. Therefore, the Holy Torah wrote the term "and we will fight" in the passive form and did not say "and he will fight against us," to hint that the war for Israel is done from above and from the heavens. As Moses said to Israel, "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall be silent," and so King David said, "If a war rises against me, in this I trust." Therefore, it is said "and we will fight against us," their mouths have caused them to stumble by saying so, for the war for Israel is done from the heavens.
summary: The passage discusses the verse "Let us be wise against him, lest he multiply," highlighting that Pharaoh feared the Israelites would fight against him. However, it emphasizes that true believers do not engage in physical combat; rather, their weapons are prayer and Torah. The text asserts that any conflict faced by the Israelites is divinely orchestrated, as indicated by the language used in the Torah, which suggests that God fights for them. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in divine intervention and the power of spiritual practices over worldly struggles.

passage_content: וז"פ דברי המדרש ועלה מן הארץ זה משה שנאמר ומשה עלה אל האלקים , היינו ע"י כח התוה"ק יעשו ישראל מלחמה ולא בלי רשות התורה, ומ"ש פרעה הבה נתחכמה לו וגו' ונלחם בנו זה הוא שקר, אני בכל לב אצור פקודיך וכאשר יענו אותו כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ עפי"מ שפרשתי לעיל שהעינוי הי' מה שנכשלו בהרהורים רעים, ועל זה הבטיח אותם רוה"ק כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ שביציאתם ממצרים יוציאו משם את הנצה"ק שנתפזרו שמה, ומקור חטא זה הוא בלב, כמו שדרשו רז"ל עה"פ ונשמרת מכל דבר רע שלא יהרהר אדם ביום ויבא לידי טומאה בלילה, וז"ש אני בכל לב אצור פקודיך, לשמור לבי מכל הרהור חטא, ולהרהר רק מחשבות של תורה וקדושה ועי"ז יתקיים כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ ויתוקנו הנצה"ק ויצאו מעמקי הקליפות, וזהו כלי מלחמתם של ישראל, ועד"ז ירמוז הכתוב כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ בלשון עתיד, דהנה כל יעודי ברכות הכתובים בתוה"ק המה נצחיים לדורות עולם וכן אנו מצפים בימינו אלה, שבנ"י בעינוי בעוני בצרות ובשעבוד, וכאשר יענו אותו כבר נתקיים בנו, ואנו מאמינים באמונה שלימה שהשי"ת יעזור לנו שיקויים בנו גם הבטחת כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ ובעוה"ר נשארנו מעט מהרבה הכשרים עובדי ד' נהרגו, ורבבות מישראל העבירו לשמדיות ר"ל כמוהו לא נהייתה מימות עולם בשום מדינה, ועכשיו נעשה מקור השמד בארצינו הקדושה, ובעוה"ר אין לנו מסייעין לדבר שבקדושה ולדרך התוה"ק , אבותינו הלכו למנוחות ואנו נשארנו לאנחות ונשארנו מעט מהרבה וגם מאותו המעט, מועטים הם המרגישים את כבוד שמים המחולל בעוה"ר ע"י מינים ואפיקורסים, ואנו מצפים שנזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקינו ואז יאמרו מי ילד לי את אלה, שיקום דור גדול עובדי ד' ויהי' בנים וב"ב עוסקים בתורה, ע"כ אמרה הרוה"ק כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ ולא אמר כן רבה וכן פרץ שלא נחשוב שהברכה הי' רק במצרים, ע"כ אמר כן ירבה וכן יפרוץ ל' עתיד שגם בגלות האחרון יתקיימו בנו כל אותן הברכות ואנו מאמינים בזה באמונה שלימה, השי"ת יעזור שנזכה לאותם הברכות ולא נהי' מהנדחים ע"י רוב עונינו כי רחוקים אנחנו מאד מדרך האמת, טפלו עלי שקר זדים, הדביקו עלינו את כח השקר, אבל אני בכל לב אצור פקודיך, דכל ישראל יש בלבו נקודה של אמת, ועי"ז יכול לצאת מכחות השקר, אלא שבעוה"ר משוקעין כ"כ עד שנאבד הרגשת נקודה זו מלבם, ונזכה במהרה לותחזינה עינינו בשובך לציון ברחמים דודאי יתקיים ויבוא הישועה לישראל, אלא שאנו צריכים לבקש ולעורר רחמים להשי"ת שנזכה לראותה ולא נהי' ח"ו מהנדחים , ומי יודע עד כמה גרמו מעשים הרעים לעכב הגאולה ח"ו, ונזכה לעשות תשובה שלימה ולילך בדרך האמת, ולהיות דבקים דיבוק אמיתי בתורתו ית"ש , ובמהרה נזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And the Midrash says, "And he ascended from the land," this refers to Moses, as it is said, "And Moses ascended to God." This means that through the power of the Torah, Israel will wage war, and not without the authority of the Torah. And what Pharaoh said, "Come, let us be wise against him," and so on, and "and fight against us," this is false. "I will treasure Your commandments with all my heart," and as they are oppressed, so they will multiply and spread, as I explained above that the oppression was due to their falling into evil thoughts. And for this, the Holy Spirit assured them, "So they will multiply and spread," that upon their exodus from Egypt, they will take out from there the sparks of holiness that were scattered there. The source of this sin is in the heart, as our Sages expounded on the verse, "And you shall guard yourself from any evil thing," that a person should not entertain evil thoughts during the day and come to impurity at night. Therefore, I say, "I will treasure Your commandments with all my heart," to guard my heart from any sinful thoughts, and to think only thoughts of Torah and holiness, and through this, "So they will multiply and spread" will be fulfilled, and the sparks of holiness will be rectified and will emerge from the depths of the klipot. This is the weapon of Israel's warfare. Similarly, the verse hints at "So they will multiply and spread" in the future tense, for all the promises of blessings written in the Torah are eternal for all generations, and thus we hope in these days that the children of Israel, in oppression, poverty, troubles, and servitude, and as they are oppressed, it has already been fulfilled in us. And we believe with complete faith that the Holy One, blessed be He, will help us that the promise of "So they will multiply and spread" will also be fulfilled in us. And unfortunately, we have remained few from the many, the righteous servants of God have been killed, and tens of thousands of Israel have been forced into heresy, God forbid, such as has not happened since the days of the world in any nation. And now the source of heresy has become in our holy land, and unfortunately, we have no supporters for anything holy and for the path of the Torah. Our forefathers have gone to rest, and we have been left in despair, and we have remained few from the many, and even from that few, few are those who feel the honor of Heaven that is desecrated, unfortunately, by heretics and skeptics. And we hope to merit to greet the Messiah, our Righteous One, and then they will say, "Who has borne me these?" That a great generation of servants of God will arise, and there will be sons and grandsons engaged in Torah. Therefore, the Holy Spirit said, "So they will multiply and spread," and did not say, "So they will be many and break through," so that we do not think that the blessing was only in Egypt. Therefore, it says, "So they will multiply and spread" in the future tense, that even in the last exile, all those blessings will be fulfilled in us, and we believe in this with complete faith. May the Holy One, blessed be He, help us to merit those blessings and not be among the castaways due to our many sins, for we are very far from the path of truth. They have laid upon me the falsehood of the wicked, they have stuck to us the power of falsehood, but I will treasure Your commandments with all my heart, for all Israel has in their heart a point of truth, and through this, they can emerge from the forces of falsehood. However, unfortunately, they are so submerged that they have lost the feeling of this point from their hearts. May we merit soon to see our eyes in Your return to Zion in mercy, surely the salvation will be fulfilled and come to Israel. However, we need to ask and awaken mercy from the Holy One, blessed be He, that we merit to see it and not be among the castaways, God forbid. And who knows how much the evil deeds have caused the redemption to be delayed, God forbid. May we merit to make complete repentance and walk in the path of truth, and to be truly attached to His holy Torah, and may we soon merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy, and the revelation of the honor of Heaven upon us speedily in our days. Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of adhering to the Torah as a means of spiritual warfare and redemption for the Jewish people, highlighting that true strength comes from a sincere commitment to divine commandments. It reflects on the struggles faced by the Jewish community, asserting that despite the challenges and the prevalence of falsehood, every individual possesses a "point of truth" within their heart that can lead to liberation from negativity. The text expresses a deep faith in the eventual fulfillment of God's promises, particularly the blessing of "may it increase and expand," which is seen as a future assurance of growth and redemption even in times of exile. Ultimately, it calls for sincere repentance and a return to the path of truth to hasten the coming of the Messiah and the restoration of divine honor.

passage_content: הבה נתחכמה לו פן ירבה וגו' פירש"י ז"ל רבותינו דרשו נתחכם למושיען של ישראל לדונם במים שכבר נשבע שלא יביא מבול לעולם, הקשו המפורשים דלפי"ד משמע דמאמר הבה נתחכמה נמשך על גזירת כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו, שזה הי' התחכמותם לדונם במים מפני שכבר נשבע שלא יביא מבול לעולם, ובפסוק עצמו מבואר שאינו כן. שמיד סמוך אליו כתיב וישימו עליו שרי מסים וגו', מוכח שהי' תחלת התחכמותם לשעבד בהם שעבוד קשה המפרכת את הגוף, ואח"כ גזר פרעה על המילדות אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, ולבסוף גזר כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו
translation: "Let us be wise against him, lest he multiply, etc." Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains that our sages interpreted this as a counsel to the Redeemer of Israel to judge them in water, since He had already sworn not to bring a flood upon the world. The commentators question that according to this interpretation, it seems that the statement 'let us be wise' refers to the decree 'every son that is born you shall cast into the river,' as this was their cunning to judge them in water because He had already sworn not to bring a flood upon the world. However, the verse itself clarifies that this is not the case. Immediately following it, it is written, "And they set taskmasters over them," etc., which proves that their initial cunning was to enslave them with hard labor that breaks the body, and afterwards Pharaoh decreed upon the midwives that if it is a son, they should kill him, and finally he decreed that every son that is born you shall cast into the river.
summary: The passage discusses the cunning of the Egyptians in their oppression of the Israelites, particularly in relation to God's promise not to bring another flood. It highlights that their initial strategy was to impose harsh labor on the Israelites, which was a form of subjugation, before escalating to the decree against the newborn boys. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of oppression and the lengths to which tyrants will go, as well as the resilience of the Jewish people in the face of such challenges.

passage_content: ב) ויצו פרעה לכל עמו אריב"ח אף על עמו גזר, ולמה עשה כן שהיו אסטרולוגין אומרים לו גואל ישראל נתעברה ממנו אמו , ואין אנו יודעים אם מישראל הוא או מצרי הוא. באותה שעה כנס פרעה כל המצריים, וא"ל השאילו לי את בניכם ט' חדשים שאשליכם ליאור הה"ד כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו וכו' ולא רצו לקבל ממנו שאמרו בן מצרי לא יגאול אותן לעולם אלא מן העבריות עכ"ד המדרש, וכבר דקדקנו לעיל איך אפשר שהאסטרולוגין וחכמי פרעה היו מסופקים בדבר אם הגואל יהי' מצרי או ישראל, והמון עם המצריים עמדו נגדם בטענה ברורה שבן מצרי לא יגאול את ישראל לעולם, ולא מצינו בדברי רז"ל שפרעה והחרטומים הכחישו דבריהם, ונראה שהסכימו לטענתם שבן מצרי לא יגאול את ישראל לעולם, וצ"ב איך השיגו העם יותר מפרעה והחרטומים.
translation: And Pharaoh commanded all his people, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," and why did he do this? Because the astrologers were telling him that the Redeemer of Israel was conceived from his mother, and we do not know if he is from Israel or if he is Egyptian. At that time, Pharaoh gathered all the Egyptians and said to them, "Lend me your sons for nine months, and I will cast them into the river," as it is said, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," etc. And they did not want to accept this from him, for they said, "An Egyptian son will never redeem them, only one from the Hebrews." Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. And we have already noted above how it is possible that the astrologers and the wise men of Pharaoh were in doubt about whether the Redeemer would be Egyptian or Israeli, while the masses of the Egyptians stood against them with a clear argument that an Egyptian son will never redeem Israel. And we do not find in the words of our Sages that Pharaoh and the magicians denied their words, and it seems that they agreed with their claim that an Egyptian son will never redeem Israel. It is puzzling how the people understood this more than Pharaoh and the magicians.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses Pharaoh's decree against the Israelites, prompted by astrologers who were uncertain whether the future redeemer would be an Israelite or an Egyptian. The Egyptians collectively argued that an Egyptian could never redeem the Israelites, a claim that Pharaoh and his magicians did not refute, suggesting a deeper understanding among the masses than their leaders. This highlights a key Hasidic concept of divine providence and the belief that true redemption can only come from within the Jewish people, emphasizing the unique spiritual role of the Israelites in the unfolding of their destiny.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"פ הבה נתחכמה לו, וז"ל כל הבה לשון הכנה והזמנה לדבר הוא כלומר הזמינו עצמכם לכך עכ"ל, וצ"ב הכוונה דמה צורך בהכנה והזמנה לדבר זה, תינח לשון נתחכמה יובן כמו שפירש"י נתחכם למושיען של ישראל לדונם במים שכבר נשבע שלא יביא מבול שידעו שמידתו של הקב"ה מדה כנגד מדה. אבל הכנה והזמנה מה צורך בו.
translation: And it is appropriate to explain the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "Come, let us be wise against him." He writes that "all 'come' is a language of preparation and invitation to a matter," meaning "prepare yourselves for this." However, the intention is questioned: what is the need for preparation and invitation for this matter? It is acceptable for the term "let us be wise" to be understood as Rashi explained, that we should be wise in the matter of the Redeemer of Israel, to judge them with water, since He has already sworn not to bring a flood, so that they should know that the measure of the Holy One, blessed be He, is measure for measure. But what is the need for preparation and invitation?
summary: The passage discusses Rashi's interpretation of the phrase "let us be wise against Him," emphasizing the idea of preparation and invitation to engage in a dialogue with God. It questions the necessity of this preparation, particularly in the context of God's justice, which operates on the principle of measure for measure. The text suggests that while the call to wisdom is clear, the need for readiness and invitation remains ambiguous, prompting deeper reflection on the relationship between humanity and the divine. This highlights key Hasidic themes of divine justice and the human role in spiritual engagement.

passage_content: אמנם כלל גדול הוא שלכל דבר בעולם צריך הכנה והזמנה, ולהיות עובד השי"ת ולעשות רצונו ית"ש צריך הכנה רבה, דא"א להגיע בפ"א למדריגת עובד ה', כדאיתא בזוה"ק (פ' חיי קכ"ט ע"א) עה"פ ואברהם זקן בא בימים, ת"ח אברהם אתקריב לגבי' וכו ', ולא אתקריב אברהם ביומא חדא או בזמנא חדא , אלא עובדוי קריבו לי' בכל יומוי מדרגא לדרגא עד דאסתלק בדרגוי וכו' וזה לעומת זה אין אדם נעשה רשע בבת אחת כ"א ע"י הכנה, הגם שבוודאי ניקל יותר להעשות רשע ר"ל מלהגיע למדריגת צדיק אמת, אבל מ"מ גם זה בא בהדרגה ולא בב"א, כ"א מעט מעט נשקע ר"ל בכוחות הטומאה ע"י מחשבה דיבור ומעשה, ובכל יום יותר עד שנעשה ח"ו רשע גמור שעבירה גוררת עבירה, וכמו שפירשתי אמרינו בתפלה אל תזכור לנו עונות ראשונים, לכאורה מדוע מתפללין רק על עונות הראשונים, והרי גם האחרונים צריכים כפרה, אבל מפני שעיקר הפגם הוא עון הראשון. ומה שעשו אח"כ הי' בסיבת עון הראשון שהוא גרמה עון השני וכן לעולם, ע"כ מתפללין שהקב"ה לא יזכור עונות הראשונים וממילא יתבטלו גם האחרונים, ולכן צריך להשגיח מאוד על ימי הנעורים ועל הילדים בעוד שהם קטנים שלא יכשלו ח"ו בעון חטא הידוע, שאם נכשל האדם פ"א קשה אח"כ להשמר עוד, כי עבירה גוררת עבירה ועיקר ההשגחה צריך להיות בההתחלה , עכ"פ לכל דבר בעולם צריך להיות הכנה וכמו שצריך הכנה להיות עובד ה' שא"א להגיע בפ"א למדריגה זו כנ"ל, כן בהיפוך להעשות ח"ו רשע ג"כ א"א רק ע"י הכנה.
translation: Indeed, it is a great principle that everything in the world requires preparation and invitation, and to be a servant of the Blessed One and to fulfill His will, one needs much preparation. For it is impossible to reach the level of a servant of God in one moment, as it is stated in the Zohar (Parashat Chayei Sarah 129a) regarding the verse "And Abraham was old, and well stricken in age," that Abraham was drawn close to Him, etc. And Abraham was not drawn close in one day or at one time, but rather his service was brought closer to Him every day, from level to level, until he departed in his level, etc. This is in contrast to the fact that a person does not become wicked all at once, but rather through preparation. Although it is certainly easier to become wicked, God forbid, than to reach the level of a true righteous person, nonetheless, this too comes gradually and not all at once, but rather little by little one sinks, God forbid, into the forces of impurity through thought, speech, and action, and each day more until he becomes, Heaven forbid, a complete wicked person, for one sin leads to another. And as we have explained, we say in prayer, "Do not remember to us the sins of the early ones." At first glance, why do we pray only for the sins of the early ones, when the later ones also need atonement? But because the main flaw is the first sin. And what was done afterwards was due to the first sin, which caused the second sin, and so on forever. Therefore, we pray that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will not remember the sins of the early ones, and consequently, the later ones will also be nullified. Therefore, one must be very vigilant over the days of youth and over children while they are still small, so that they do not stumble, Heaven forbid, in the known sin, for if a person stumbles once, it is difficult afterwards to guard oneself. For one sin leads to another, and the main vigilance must be at the beginning. Thus, for everything in the world, there must be preparation, and just as one needs preparation to be a servant of God, for it is impossible to reach this level in one moment, so too, conversely, to become wicked, Heaven forbid, is also only possible through preparation.
summary: The passage emphasizes the necessity of preparation and gradual progression in both serving God and falling into sin. It highlights that one cannot achieve the level of a true servant of God instantly; rather, it requires consistent effort and elevation over time, as illustrated by Abraham's spiritual journey. Conversely, the descent into wrongdoing also occurs gradually, with each sin leading to another, underscoring the importance of vigilance, especially during one's youth. The text calls for careful attention to early influences to prevent the initial sin that can lead to a cycle of transgressions.

passage_content: וע"כ פרעה שרצה לגזור על ישראל כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשלכהו . שזהו אכזריות גדול ורשעות שאין דומה אליו, והשיג שא"א להגיע בפ"א למידה זו, ע"כ התחכם להתחיל בגזירה אחרת קטנה ממנה, וישימו עליו שרי מסים לבנות ערי מסכנות פיתום ורעמסס שיש בו צורך המלוכה, ואח"כ גזר גזירה שני' על המילדות להמית הזכרים, וגם בזה לא הי' מעשה הרציחה מפורסמת כ"כ, ועי"ז נתרגל העם ברשעות ואכזריות, ואז יכול לגלות מצפוני לבבו וגזר כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו, נמצא ששתי גזירות הקודמים היו הכנה לגזירה השלישית, שחשש פרעה שלא יקבלו המצריים גזירה זו להשליך ילדי ישראל ליאור, אם לא שיעשה מקודם הכנה להרגיל את העם ברשעות ואכזריות, ומעתה בתחלה כשאמר הבה נתחכמה לו נתחכם למושיען של ישראל לדונם במים, התכוין על גזירת על הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו: אלא שהי' צורך לזה הכנה והזמנה כדי להרגיל את העם ברשעות, ולזה התחיל מקודם בגזירת שרי מסים למען ענותו בסבלותם , ואח"כ השלים הגזירה שחשב עלי' מתחילה לדונם במים, וזהו אומרו הבה לשון הכנה והזמנה לדבר, ויש ללמוד מזה מוסר השכל, איך שצריך האדם להשגיח על מעשיו ומדותיו , ולא יעשה כ"א מה שהוא רצון הבוי"ת וע"פ התורה, ולא ישמע בעצת יצרו המפתהו לאמר , כי אך דבר קטן הוא זה ומדת חסידות שנו כאן דכך דרכו של יצה"ר היום אומר לו עשה כך וכו ', עד שמסיתו לעבירות חמורות ולעבוד ע"ז, ואף הרשעים המפורסמים ברשעתם לא הגיעו לכך בפעם אחת, כ"א מעט מעט הורגלו ברשעתם , כמ"ש בפרעה שאמר הבה נתחכמה , ומאויבי תחכמני לעשות הכנה לתורה ויראה וקדושה, וכל תנועה קלה שעושים למען כבוד שמו ית ' הוא חשובה מאוד וה"ה הכנה והזמנה שיגיע האדם על ידו למדריגת עובד ה'.
translation: And therefore Pharaoh, who wanted to decree upon Israel that every son born should be cast into the river, this is a great cruelty and wickedness unlike any other. He realized that it was impossible to reach this level of evil all at once; therefore, he cunningly began with a smaller decree. He appointed taskmasters to build the store cities of Pithom and Raamses, which were necessary for the kingdom. Afterwards, he decreed a second decree upon the midwives to kill the male children, and even in this, the act of murder was not so publicly known. Through this, the people became accustomed to wickedness and cruelty, and then he could reveal the intentions of his heart and decree that every son born should be cast into the river. Thus, the two previous decrees were a preparation for the third decree, for Pharaoh feared that the Egyptians would not accept this decree to throw the children of Israel into the river unless he first prepared them to be accustomed to wickedness and cruelty. Therefore, at the beginning, when he said, "Come, let us be wise against him," he intended the decree of casting every son born into the river. However, there was a need for preparation and invitation to accustom the people to wickedness, and for this, he first began with the decree of taskmasters to oppress them with their burdens. Afterwards, he completed the decree he had initially thought of, to drown them in water. This is what he meant by saying "Come," which is a term of preparation and invitation to the matter. One should learn from this a moral lesson on how a person must be vigilant over his actions and character traits, and should only do what is the will of the Creator and according to the Torah, and should not listen to the counsel of his evil inclination that tempts him to say, "This is but a small matter," and the trait of piety is mentioned here, for thus is the way of the evil inclination: today it tells him to do this, etc., until it leads him to severe transgressions and idolatry. Even the notorious wicked did not reach this point all at once, but rather little by little they became accustomed to their wickedness, as it is said about Pharaoh who said, "Come, let us be wise." And from my enemies, let me be wise to prepare for the Torah, fear, and holiness. Every small action done for the honor of His Name is very significant, and this is also the preparation and invitation that will lead a person to the level of a servant of God.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's gradual approach to oppressing the Israelites, illustrating how he first implemented smaller, less severe decrees to acclimate the Egyptian people to cruelty before enacting the ultimate decree of throwing newborns into the Nile. This serves as a warning about the dangers of moral desensitization and the importance of vigilance in one's actions and character. It emphasizes that even seemingly minor transgressions can lead to greater sins, highlighting the need for individuals to align their actions with divine will and Torah teachings. Ultimately, it conveys that every small act done for the sake of God is significant and can lead one to a higher spiritual level.

passage_content: והנה מה דאיתא במדרש הנ"ל שאמרו החרטומים גואל ישראל נתעברה ממנו אמו ואין אנו יודעין אם ישראל הוא או מצרי, כבר בארנו לעיל שא"א לפרשו כפשוטו, שהיו מסופקין אם גואל ישראל יהי' מצרי דאין בזה צד ספק, ואמרז"ל בתנא דבי אלי' (פ' י') במי הקב"ה נפרע להם לישראל בבני אדם שמשכימין ומעריבין לבית הכנסת ולביהמ"ד ועונין אמן ומברכין את הקב"ה בכל יום תמיד, עכ"ד, מבואר דא"א שיבוא גאולה לישראל ע"י רשעים, והחרטומים לא היו מסופקים בזה, אולם לפי שראו באצטגנותם צד ספק שמא יהי' הגואל מן המצריים, חשבו שיתגייר א' מהם ויהי' נעשה לצדיק גמור והוא יגאול את ישראל וינקום נקמתם מן המצריים, וכמו שמצינו בעובדי' שהי' גר אדומי והוא התנבא על פורעניות של אדום.
translation: And behold, what is stated in the aforementioned Midrash, that the magicians said, "The Redeemer of Israel's mother was impregnated by him, and we do not know if he is an Israelite or an Egyptian," we have already explained above that it cannot be interpreted literally, that they were in doubt whether the Redeemer of Israel would be Egyptian, for there is no room for doubt in this matter. And our Sages of blessed memory said in the Tanna d'Bei Eliyahu (Chapter 20) that with whom does the Holy One, blessed be He, take vengeance on Israel? With human beings who rise early and go to the synagogue and to the house of study and respond "Amen" and bless the Holy One, blessed be He, every day continuously. Thus it is clear that redemption cannot come to Israel through wicked ones, and the magicians were not in doubt about this. However, since they saw in their astrology a possibility that the Redeemer might be from the Egyptians, they thought that one of them might convert and become a complete righteous person, and he would redeem Israel and take vengeance on the Egyptians, just as we find regarding Obadiah, who was an Edomite convert and prophesied about the calamities of Edom.
summary: The passage discusses the uncertainty expressed by the Egyptian magicians regarding the identity of the future redeemer of Israel, suggesting that they believed he might be a convert from among them. It emphasizes that redemption cannot come through wicked individuals, as true salvation must arise from the righteous. The magicians' speculation reflects a deeper theological insight that even those from the oppressor's camp could potentially transform and become instruments of divine redemption, akin to the example of a righteous convert prophesying against their own nation. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the potential for spiritual transformation and the ultimate triumph of good over evil.

passage_content: וע"כ אמר פרעה להם השאילו לי את בניכם ט' חדשים וכו' כדי לבחון כל א' מהנולדים, במי ביניהם ימצאו סימן ורושם של קדושה, שהם היו בעלי השגה וידעו להכיר על הילדים בעוד שהם קטנים אם יש בהם בחינה קדושה או לא, והמצריים השיבו לו שזה דבר שא"א שיוולד אצלם בן שיש לו נשמה קדושה כזה שיהי' ראוי לגאול את ישראל, לפי שהם צייתו לגזירת פרעה שאמר הבה נתחכמה , ועשו הכנה והזמנה להתרגל בדרך הרשעות, ע"כ ידעו בעצמם שהם משוקעים כ"כ בכוחות הטומאה עד שא"א שיהי' נולד אצלם בן שיש לו בחי' קדושה, והחרטומים קבלו דבריהם, כי גם הם עצמם לא אמרו כ"א ע"צ הספק, אבל אחר שהמצריים הודיעו להם גודל טומאתם, האמינו לדבריהם שא"א שיצא מהם בן ראוי לגאול את ישראל.
translation: And therefore Pharaoh said to them, "Borrow me your sons for nine months," etc., in order to examine each of the newborns, to see among them who would have a sign and mark of holiness. They were wise and knew how to recognize in the children while they were still small whether there was a holy aspect in them or not. The Egyptians replied to him that it was impossible for a son to be born among them who had a holy soul, one that would be worthy to redeem Israel, for they complied with Pharaoh's decree when he said, "Let us deal wisely," and they prepared and habituated themselves to the ways of wickedness. Therefore, they knew themselves to be so deeply entrenched in the forces of impurity that it was impossible for a son to be born among them with a quality of holiness. The magicians accepted their words, for they too only spoke out of doubt, but after the Egyptians informed them of the magnitude of their impurity, they believed their words that it was impossible for a son worthy of redeeming Israel to come forth from them.
summary: Pharaoh's request to the Egyptians to identify which of their newborns possess a sign of holiness reflects a deep understanding of spiritual discernment among the leaders. The Egyptians, aware of their own moral corruption and adherence to Pharaoh's decree, believed that no child born among them could possess a holy soul capable of redeeming Israel. This acknowledgment of their spiritual impurity highlights the Hasidic concept of the profound impact of one's environment and actions on the potential for holiness. Ultimately, the Egyptians' recognition of their own depravity reinforces the idea that true redemption can only arise from a place of purity and divine favor.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה שכולם פה אחד השיגו דבר זה, והחרטומים וכל עם מצרים הודו ואמרו שגואל ישראל צריך להיות איש צדיק וקדוש, ובעוה"ר בדורינו זה נמצאים הרבה מישראל ואף שומרי תורה ומצות שאין יודעין דבר זה שאף המצריים ידעו, וחושבין ר"ל שע"י דרך כפירה ומינות יוכל להיות גאולה וישועה לישראל, ה' ישמרינו מדעות כאלו, והשי"ת יגאל אותנו בגאולה שלימה בב"א.
translation: What emerges from this is that everyone unanimously achieved this understanding, and the magicians and all the people of Egypt acknowledged and said that the Redeemer of Israel must be a righteous and holy man. Yet, unfortunately, in our generation, there are many among Israel, even those who observe the Torah and commandments, who do not know this truth that even the Egyptians recognized. They mistakenly believe, Heaven forbid, that through heretical and apostate ways, redemption and salvation for Israel can be attained. May the Lord protect us from such beliefs, and may the Holy One, Blessed be He, redeem us with a complete redemption, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes that both the magicians and the people of Egypt recognized that the Redeemer of Israel must be a righteous and holy individual. It highlights a troubling reality in the current generation, where many among Israel, including those who observe the Torah and commandments, are unaware of this truth, mistakenly believing that redemption can come through heretical or unfaithful means. The author expresses a prayer for protection against such misguided beliefs and hopes for a complete and true redemption from God.

passage_content: ויעבידו מצרים את בנ"י בפרך, בגמ' סוטה (י"א ע"ב) פליגו בה ר"א ורשב"נ , ר"א בפרך בפה רך, ר' שמואל ב"נ אמר בפריכה, בעבודה קשה המפרכת את הגוף ומשברתו , ובמדרש ויעבידו מצרים את בני ישראל בפרך חד אמר בקל וחומר, וח"א בגז"ש וצ"ב .
translation: And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor. In the Gemara Sotah (11b), there is a dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon ben Nanas. Rabbi Eliezer says "with rigor" refers to soft speech, while Rabbi Shimon ben Nanas says it refers to harsh labor, work that breaks the body and crushes it. And in the Midrash, "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor," one opinion says it is derived through a kal vachomer (a fortiori argument), and another says it is derived through a gezeirah shavah (a verbal analogy), and the matter is to be considered.
summary: The passage discusses the harsh labor imposed by the Egyptians on the Israelites, highlighting differing interpretations among the sages. Rabbi Eliezer suggests that "with a soft mouth" indicates a deceptive form of oppression, while Rabbi Shmuel ben Nachmani emphasizes the physical brutality of the labor that breaks the body. Additionally, the Midrash presents various approaches to understanding this oppression, suggesting a deeper theological reflection on the nature of suffering and divine justice. These insights underscore the complexity of human suffering and the spiritual resilience of the oppressed.

summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing the harshness of their labor through various forms of work, symbolizing both physical and spiritual struggles. The mention of "hard work" and "bitter lives" highlights the duality of their experience, where physical oppression parallels spiritual challenges. This serves as a reminder of the resilience of the Jewish spirit in the face of adversity, suggesting that even in suffering, there is a deeper purpose and connection to divine providence. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of faith and perseverance amidst trials, a key theme in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי הגמ ' ברכות (ה' ע"א) יסורין ממרקין כל עונותיו של אדם ר' חייא בר אבא אר"י ק"ו משן ועין, מה שן ועין שהוא א' מאבריו של אדם, יוצא בהם לחירות, יסורין שממרקין כל גופו של אדם לא כ"ש, והיינו דרשב"ל דאמר רשב"ל נאמר ברית במלח ונאמר ברית ביסורין וכו ', מה ברית האמורה במלח, מלח ממתקת את הבשר, אף ברית האמורה ביסורין , יסורין ממרקין כל עונותיו של אדם, וכתב בעיון יעקב מדקאמר והיינו דרשב"ל , משמע דלא פליגי כלל, ומר אמר חדא ומר אמר חדא עיי"ש לדרכו, ולדרכנו אפ"ל דאהני ק"ו ואהני גז"ש ותרווייהו צריכי ולא פליגי, דאילו נלמד מהק"ו לחודי', הי' סברא לצדד, דכל כמה שיתרבו היסורים ח"ו, נתחזק כח לימוד הק"ו , דמה שן ועין וכו' כש"כ ביסורים גדולים שממרקין כל גופו של אדם עאכו"כ, לזה מועיל לימוד הגז"ש מה מלח ממתקת את הבשר וכו' להקל עונש היסורים , כמו דמיתוק הבשר במלח, הוא רק אם נמלח במדה ידוע, אבל הרבוי בו אינו מוסיף למתקו אדרבה מקלקלתו, כמו"כ היסורין הבאים למירוק עונות ר"ל, אינו ראוי שיהיו גדולים וקשים ח"ו, כ"א במידה וע"ד המתקה, ואהני ק"ו ללמוד משן ועין דעבד יוצא בהן לחירות, וכמו"כ ע"י היסורין שסובלין ישראל בגלות יצאו לחפשי ויגאלו גאולת עולם.
translation: And we will explain in advance the words of the Gemara in Berakhot (5a) that suffering purifies all the sins of a person. Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, "A fortiori from tooth and eye: just as tooth and eye, which are one of a person's limbs, one can be freed from them, suffering that purifies the entire body of a person, how much more so!" And this is the teaching of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who said: "Just as a covenant is mentioned with salt, so too a covenant is mentioned with suffering," etc. Just as the covenant mentioned with salt, salt sweetens the flesh, so too the covenant mentioned with suffering, suffering purifies all the sins of a person. And it is written in the Iyun Yaakov that since it says "and this is the teaching of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish," it implies that they do not disagree at all, and one said one thing and the other said another, as explained there according to his way. And according to our way, it can be said that the a fortiori reasoning is beneficial and the analogy is beneficial, and both are necessary and do not disagree. For if we were to learn from the a fortiori reasoning alone, one might think that the more suffering increases, Heaven forbid, the stronger the reasoning would be, that just as tooth and eye, etc., how much more so with great suffering that purifies the entire body of a person. Therefore, the teaching of the analogy is beneficial, for just as salt sweetens the flesh, etc., it is only if it is salted in a known measure, but an excess does not add to its sweetness; rather, it spoils it. Similarly, the suffering that comes to purify sins, Heaven forbid, should not be great and severe, but rather in measure and in the manner of sweetening. And the a fortiori reasoning is beneficial to learn from tooth and eye, that a servant is freed through them, and likewise through the suffering that the Jewish people endure in exile, they will be freed and redeemed with an eternal redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of suffering (יסורין) as a means of atonement for a person's sins, drawing a comparison between the suffering endured and the liberation it can bring, similar to how a tooth or an eye can lead to freedom. It emphasizes that just as salt enhances and sweetens meat, suffering should be measured and not excessive, as too much suffering can be detrimental rather than beneficial. The text highlights the importance of understanding suffering in a balanced way, suggesting that the trials faced by the Jewish people in exile ultimately lead to redemption and spiritual freedom.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר טעם פלוגתתם ז"ל בגמ' דסוטה ובמדרש הנ"ל, דהנה מבואר שם בגמ' סוטה הנ"ל, דפלוגתתם רק בפסוק ויעבידו מצרים את בנ"י בפרך האמור בתחילת השעבוד, איכא למ"ד שהתחילה בפה רך ואיכא למ"ד בפריכה, אבל בפרך בתרא דכתיב אחר וימררו את חייהם וגו' ובכל עבודתם אשר עבדו בהם בפרך, כ"ע מפרשי לי' בפריכה, ואפי' למ"ד התם בפה רך, הכא ודאי בפריכה פרש"י דהא כתיב וימררו, ואפ"ל דר"א ורשב"נ דפליגי בגמ' אם היתה התחלת השעבוד בפה רך או בפריכה ובעבודה קשה, טעם פלוגתתם תליא בפלוגתת תנאי דפליגי במדרש ח"א בק"ו וח"א בגז"ש . דהנה ודאי שלא ידעו המצריים למגמר ק"ו ולא גז"ש , ולאו מכח ק"ו באו לשעבד בישראל, אולם השר של מצריים שמכחו באו, הוא ידע לטעון ק"ו, וכמ"ש ששר של ים טען הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז וכו ', וס"ל לחד מ"ד שבא בטענת ק"ו, ולפי טענה זו ראוי שיסבול החוטא יסורים גדולים וקשים ר"ל, והוא כמ"ד דס"ל בפרך בפריכה בעבודה קשה המפרכת את הגוף. וח"א בגז"ש מברית האמור במלח ולפי"ז מדת היסורים ע"ד המתקה, והוא כמ"ד דס"ל בפה רך, וזהו בהתחלת השעבוד אבל להלן דכתיב וימררו את חייהם כ"ע מפרשי בפרך בפריכה, דלבסוף חזרו מדרכם והכבידו עולם עליהם, וז"ש בזוה"ק וימררו את חייהם וגו' בחומר בקל וחומר.
translation: And this will clarify the reason for their dispute, may their memory be blessed, in the Gemara of Sotah and in the aforementioned Midrash. Behold, it is explained there in the Gemara of Sotah that their dispute is only regarding the verse "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor," which is mentioned at the beginning of the servitude. There is one opinion that it began with soft words, and there is another opinion that it began with rigor. However, regarding the latter rigor, which is written after "And they made their lives bitter," etc., and "in all their service which they made them serve with rigor," all agree that it refers to rigor. And even for the one who says there was a beginning with soft words, here it is certainly understood as rigor, as it is written "And they made their lives bitter." And it can be said that Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon ben Nanas, who argue in the Gemara whether the beginning of the servitude was with soft words or with rigor and hard work, their dispute depends on the dispute of the Tannaim who argue in the Midrash, one with a fortiori reasoning and one with a verbal analogy. For certainly, the Egyptians did not know how to derive a fortiori reasoning or a verbal analogy, and they did not enslave Israel through a fortiori reasoning. However, the minister of Egypt, from whose power they came, knew how to argue a fortiori, as it is said that the minister of the sea argued, "These are idol worshippers, and those are idol worshippers," etc. And he holds according to one opinion that came with a fortiori reasoning. And according to this argument, it is fitting that the sinner should suffer great and difficult pains, so to speak, and this is like the opinion that holds that it is rigor in the sense of hard work that breaks the body. And the other opinion with the verbal analogy is from the covenant mentioned in salt, and according to this, the measure of suffering is in the manner of sweetening, and this is like the opinion that holds it was with soft words. And this is at the beginning of the servitude, but later, as it is written, "And they made their lives bitter," all agree that it refers to rigor in the sense of hard work, for in the end, they returned from their way and made the world heavy upon them. And this is what is said in the Zohar, "And they made their lives bitter," etc., with severity in a fortiori reasoning.
summary: The passage discusses the debate among the sages regarding the nature of the Israelites' suffering in Egypt, specifically whether it began with gentle oppression or harsh labor. It highlights that while the initial oppression may have been subtle, the subsequent intensification of their suffering was universally understood as severe. The text emphasizes the theological implications of this suffering, suggesting that the Egyptian oppressors, influenced by their spiritual leaders, justified their actions through logical arguments, leading to a greater burden on the Israelites. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the transformation of the oppression from a softer approach to a more brutal reality, illustrating the complexities of divine justice and human suffering.

passage_content: ובזה נל"פ במאמה"כ (פ' וארא ) וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי, דלכאורה קשה מה טעם אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם לזכירת הברית, והבוי"ת יקיים בריתו לגאלם אף לולי הכבדת עולם של מצרים עליהם, ולדרכנו אפ"ל דלפי ששר מצרים בא להכביד עינויים מכח הק"ו כנ"ל, לז"א וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם בעינויים קשים, ע"כ ואזכור בריתי ר"ל ברית האמורה במלח, וראוי שיהיו היסורים ע"ד המתקה כנלמד בגז"ש שם.
translation: And in this, we can learn from the verse (Parashat Va'era) "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel whom Egypt is enslaving," and I will remember My covenant. It is seemingly difficult to understand why the enslavement by Egypt is connected to the remembrance of the covenant, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, would fulfill His covenant to redeem them even without the heavy oppression of Egypt upon them. According to our approach, it can be said that since the minister of Egypt came to intensify the afflictions based on the a fortiori reasoning mentioned above, it is said, "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel whom Egypt is enslaving with harsh afflictions," therefore, "I will remember My covenant," meaning the covenant mentioned in salt. It is fitting that the sufferings should be in the manner of sweetening, as learned from the scriptural analogy there.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on God's promise to remember His covenant with the Israelites amidst their suffering in Egypt. He questions the rationale behind God's remembrance of the covenant in light of their oppression, suggesting that the severity of their afflictions serves as a catalyst for divine intervention. The text emphasizes the concept of suffering as a means of spiritual refinement and transformation, aligning with the Hasidic idea that hardships can lead to redemption and the fulfillment of God's promises. Ultimately, it highlights the relationship between divine mercy and the enduring covenant with the Jewish people.

passage_content: ומה שדרשו בזוה"ק הנ"ל כל הפסוק על העסק בתורה משנה וברייתא ליבון הלכתא וכו' נל"פ עפ"י המבואר בספה"ק כי הסט"א יונקים מישראל העובר ר"ל, שפעת הקדושה אשר בו, והוא להם למחי', וכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה ( בר"פ תצא) וז"ל כבר אמרו חז"ל מתוך שלא לשמה בא לשמה, והנה באמת מה שנעשה שלא לשמה שובת הסט"א , רק אח"כ שבא לשמה הוחזר הכל עיי"ש, והנה במצרים למדו ישראל תורה כמ"ש בגמ' (יומא כ"ח) גלו למצרים ישיבה עמהם וכו' עמרם זקן ויושב בישיבה הי', וע"י שנתגברו עליהם הס"מ והמצריים להחטיאם, אף שעמדו בנסיונם ולא נכשלו בפועל מ"מ אולי ע"י גודל הלחץ של טומאת מצרים, נפלו ממדריגתם ובאו לבחי ' לימוד תורה שלא לשמה, וזהו שדרשו בזוה"ק וימררו את חייהם וגו' בקושיא בליבון הלכתא ברייתא ומשנה, שע"י לימוד שלא לשמה ינקו הסט"א מכח תורתם וחיות דקדושה וזהו וימררו את חייהם.
translation: And what they expounded in the aforementioned Zohar, that the entire verse refers to engaging in Torah, Mishnah, and Beraita, clarifying the halacha, etc., we can learn according to what is explained in the holy books, that the sitra achra draws sustenance from Israel who transgress, so to speak, the flow of holiness that is within them, and it serves as their sustenance. And it is written by the Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Tetzaveh), and he said: Our sages have already said, "From not for its own sake, one comes to for its own sake." And indeed, what is done not for its own sake causes the sitra achra to rest, but afterwards, when one comes to do it for its own sake, everything is returned, as explained there. And behold, in Egypt, the Israelites learned Torah, as it is stated in the Gemara (Yoma 28), "They were exiled to Egypt and sat with them," etc., Amram was old and sitting in the study hall. And due to the fact that the sitra achra and the Egyptians strengthened themselves to lead them astray, even though they stood firm in their trials and did not fail in action, perhaps due to the great pressure of the impurity of Egypt, they fell from their level and came to a state of learning Torah not for its own sake. And this is what they expounded in the Zohar, "And they made their lives bitter," etc., with difficulty in clarifying halacha, Beraita, and Mishnah, that through learning not for its own sake, the sitra achra draws from the power of their Torah and the vitality of holiness, and this is "And they made their lives bitter."
summary: The passage discusses the concept that engaging in Torah study, even when done for ulterior motives (not for its own sake), can inadvertently empower the forces of impurity (Sitra Achra) that draw from the holiness of Israel. It references the idea that during their time in Egypt, the Israelites faced immense spiritual pressure, which may have led them to study Torah without the proper intention. Despite their resilience against temptation, this "learning not for its own sake" allowed the Sitra Achra to draw vitality from their sacred teachings, resulting in their suffering. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the transformative potential of returning to genuine intention in Torah study.

passage_content: או אפשר ע"ד שכתב בספה"ק נועם אלימלך זלה"ה (בהנהגת האדם) כי החטאת נעורים מסמין עיני האדם ועי"ז א"א לברר הלכה לאמיתתה של תורה, וז"ש וימררו את חייהם בעבודה קשה בקושיא שהי' להם קשיות ופרכות בתוה"ק, ובלבנים בליבון הלכתא, שלא יכלו לברר הלכתא ולאוקומי גרסא ע"י שהיו המצרים מתגברים עליהם להחטיאם, וזהו מרירות גדול אם אין משיגים דרך האמת בתוה"ק וזהו וימררו את חייהם.
translation: Or it is possible, as written in the holy book Noam Elimelech, may his merit protect us (in the guidance of man), that the sin of youth darkens a person's eyes, and as a result, it is impossible to clarify the halacha according to the truth of the Torah. And this is what is meant by "and they made their lives bitter with hard work," with the difficulty they had in the challenges and contradictions in the Holy Torah, and with the bricks, in the clarification of halacha, that they could not clarify the halacha and establish the text because the Egyptians were overpowering them to lead them astray. And this is a great bitterness if one does not attain the path of truth in the Holy Torah, and this is "and they made their lives bitter."
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of "chata'at ne'urim" (sins of youth) as a factor that clouds a person's understanding, making it difficult to grasp the true essence of Torah law. It highlights the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt, where their harsh labor and the challenges posed by the Egyptians prevented them from clarifying and understanding the Torah properly. This inability to attain the truth in Torah is described as a profound bitterness in their lives, emphasizing the importance of spiritual clarity and the struggle against distractions that lead one away from authentic understanding.

passage_content: במסיבה מלך מצרים למילדות העבריות וגו' בילדכן את העבריות וראיתם על האבנים אם בן הוא והמתן אותו ואם בת הוא וחי' ותראנה המילדות את האלקים ולא עשו כאשר דבר אליהן מלך מצרים ותחיין את הילדים, הקשה האוהחה"ק צריך להבין טעמו למה לא גזר על הכל , ואין להאמין כי במדת הרחמים נהג כי שורשו אכזרי הוא, גם למה הוצרך לומר אם בת היא וחי', כיון שלא גזר אלא על הזכרים פשיטא שלא יבקשו המילדות לעקור את הכל ועיי"ש תירוצו ועוד לאלקי מילין .
translation: In the decree of the King of Egypt to the Hebrew midwives, it was said, "When you deliver the Hebrew women and see them upon the stones, if it is a son, you shall kill him; but if it is a daughter, she shall live." And the midwives feared God and did not do as the King of Egypt had spoken to them, but they kept the children alive. The holy and exalted one asks why he did not decree upon all, and it cannot be believed that he acted out of mercy, for his root is cruel. Also, why did he need to say, "If it is a daughter, she shall live," since he only decreed against the males? It is obvious that the midwives would not seek to uproot everything, and there is a resolution there, and also to the God of words.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the actions of the Hebrew midwives who defied Pharaoh's decree to kill male infants, highlighting their fear of God as a driving force behind their resistance. The text questions why Pharaoh's edict was not more comprehensive and suggests that the midwives' choice to spare female infants reflects a deeper understanding of divine mercy and justice. The discussion emphasizes the tension between human authority and divine command, illustrating the midwives' moral courage and the theological principle that true righteousness often requires standing against oppressive power. Ultimately, the passage underscores the belief that divine providence guides the actions of the faithful in challenging circumstances.

passage_content: ב) עשו כאשר דבר אליהן הקשו בגמ' (סוטה י"א) להן מבעי' לי' אלא מלמד שתבען לדבר עבירה וכן איתא במד"ר , והקשה היפ"ת שהוא נגד השכל דיוכבד הי' בת ק"ל ומרים בת ה' ואיך יתכן שתבען. גם מה שייכות הודעה זו לסיפור גזירת הבנים, ואיך יתקשר לפי דרשתם מאמר ולא עשו לותחיין את הילדים, גם איך הותר להן למסור נפשם במה שלא שמעו לו, והי' סכנה ברורה בדבר, ואין אשה מחוייבת למסור נפשה ע"ז כמ"ש בגמ' אסתר קרקע עולם היתה .
translation: B) They did as He spoke to them; the Gemara (Sotah 11) asks why it was necessary for them to be told this, but it teaches that they were compelled to commit a transgression. Thus it is stated in the Midrash. The question arises: how is it possible that Yocheved was 130 years old and Miriam was 5, and how could they be compelled? Also, what is the relevance of this announcement to the story of the decree against the boys, and how does it connect to their interpretation of the statement that they did not deliver the children? Furthermore, how were they permitted to sacrifice their lives for something they were not commanded to do, when there was a clear danger involved, and no woman is obligated to give her life for this, as it is stated in the Gemara that Esther was a ground of the world?
summary: The passage discusses the tension between the actions of the midwives, who defied Pharaoh's orders to kill the Hebrew boys, and the theological implications of their choices. It raises questions about the nature of their courage, given their lineage—Yocheved, a daughter of Levi, and Miriam, a daughter of Amram—and the moral obligation to resist evil. The text also explores the concept of self-sacrifice in the face of danger, suggesting that while women are not typically obligated to risk their lives, the midwives' actions were a profound expression of faith and commitment to preserving life. Ultimately, it highlights the interplay between divine command, human agency, and the sanctity of life in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ג) המילדות לפרעה כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות וגו', צ"ב הקדמה זו מה צורך בו, ויספיק במה שאמרו בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת וילדו, גם איך יכלו להכחיש המציאות שא"צ למילדת והם היו מילדות העבריות.
translation: 3) The midwives to Pharaoh, for they were not like the Hebrew women of Egypt, etc. This introduction is puzzling; what need is there for it? It would suffice with what was said, "Before the midwife comes to them, they have given birth." Also, how could they deny the reality that there was no need for a midwife, as they were the Hebrew midwives?
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the Hebrew midwives and the Egyptian women, emphasizing the unique spiritual and moral qualities of the Hebrew midwives. It questions the necessity of highlighting this difference, suggesting that the midwives' faith and divine assistance allowed them to defy Pharaoh's orders. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the power of faith and the ability to transcend earthly constraints through spiritual conviction. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true life and creation are guided by divine will rather than mere physical processes.

passage_content: ד) את הילדים פירש"י ז"ל שהיו מספקות להם מים ומזון ויל"ד דכמו"כ בשאלת פרעה מדוע עשיתן וגו' ותחיינה נכלל ג"כ משמעות זה, וא"כ מה השיבו באמרם כי לא כנשים המצריות וכו ', ועדיין לא יספיק התנצלותם על שהיו מספקות להם מים ומזון היפך גזירת המלך.
translation: 4) Regarding the children, Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that they provided them with water and food, and it can be understood similarly in the question of Pharaoh, "Why have you done this?" and "You have kept them alive," which also includes this meaning. Therefore, what did they respond by saying that they were not like the Egyptian women, etc.? Still, their excuse for providing them with water and food does not suffice against the king's decree.
summary: The passage discusses the actions of the Hebrew midwives who provided sustenance to the children despite Pharaoh's decree. It highlights the tension between their moral duty to preserve life and the oppressive command of the king. The midwives' response, emphasizing that they were not like the Egyptian women, suggests a deeper commitment to their faith and the sanctity of life. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine providence and the importance of righteous actions in the face of tyranny.

passage_content: ה) להם בתים פליגי בה רב ולוי ח"א בתי כהונה ובתי לוי' וח"א בתי מלכות, בתי כהונה ולוי' משה ואהרן, וח"א בתי מלכות ממרים לפי שדוד בא ממרים וכו ', ראוי להבין דהרי בוודאי כולהו איתנייהו ויצאו מיוכבד משה ואהרן ודהמע"ה ממרים וצ"ב טעם פלוגתתן .
translation: 5) They have houses; Rabbi and Levi argue about this: some say the houses of the priesthood and the Levites, and some say the houses of royalty. The houses of the priesthood and the Levites are from Moshe and Aharon, and some say the houses of royalty are from Merari, since David came from Merari, etc. It is fitting to understand that certainly all of them are from Yocheved, Moshe, and Aharon, and that the matter of the Holy One, blessed be He, is from Merari, and the reason for their dispute is to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the distinctions between the houses of the Kohanim (priests), Levites, and the royal lineage, highlighting the roles of Moses and Aaron in the priestly and Levitical houses, and King David's lineage from Miriam. It emphasizes the theological significance of these lineages, suggesting that all these houses ultimately trace back to Yocheved, the mother of Moses and Aaron. The text invites contemplation on the reasons behind these divisions and their implications for understanding the spiritual heritage and responsibilities of each lineage within the Jewish tradition.
