passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה עה"פ וייטב אלקים למילדות וגו' וירב העם ויעצמו מאוד וגו', ותו"ד בקיצור דעצום נאמר פעם על הפלגת הריבוי כמ"ש וירבו ויעצמו במאוד וכו ', פעם על הפלגת העושר, פעם על הפלגת זכיות ומע"ט כמ"ש כי עצום עושי דברו, והנה כאן נאמר ותחיין את הילדים פירש"י שהיו מספקות להם מים ומזון, ובסוטה (דף י"א ע"ב) פירש"י ותחיין את הילדים משמע שהיו מסייעין להחיותן , שהיו מטמינות אותן בבתיהן ומגדלין אותן עכ"ל, והנה הדעת נותן כי יותר שמתרבין הילדים הם יותר מתדלדלים, כי לא יספיק להם כל הון. אבל זה הי' מהשגחת השי"ת להשגיח עליהם ולהשפיע להם ברכה, וכל מה שהיו יותר מפזרין לריבוי הילדים היו יותר מתעשרין ע"ד יש מפזר ונוסף עוד, והיינו וייטב אלקים למילדות כל כך עד שאפי' וירב העם והי' ראוי שיתדלדלו מרוב הפיזור, עכ"ז לא כן הי' אלא אדרבה ויעצמו מאוד בעושר, וזה ויעש להם בתים דמבואר לעיל שהיו טומנין אותם בבתיהם, וא"כ היו צריכים לבתים וחדרים הרבה, ויעש להם בתים קאי על אלקים שהשי"ת השפיע להם שלא כדרך הטבע עד שקנו ובנו בתים כפי הצורך להם. עוד פי' ז"ל בסיגנון אחר קרוב לפשוטו, דהא המילדות קיימו נפשות רבות מישראל, וכל המקיים נפש מישראל כאלו קיים עולם מלא, ולפי"ז אם היו ישראל פרים ורבים רק בדרך הטבע ולא היו המילדות מקיימים נפשות כ"כ, לא היו נחשבין לצדקניות וטובים כ"כ, כמו עתה שפרו ורבו שלא כדרך הטבע, ועי"ז נעשו המילדות עצומים מאוד בזכיות ומע"ט שהרי קיימו נפשות הרבה מאוד, וגם דהנפשות שקיימו כל המעשים טובים שעשו נחשב עליהם, דהם הגורמים, א"כ בהריבוי עצמו הם מאוד, וז"פ וירב העם שלא כדרך הטבע, עי"ז ויעצמו מאוד המילדות עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: And we will explain in advance the words of K"Z, that Moshe, may his memory be blessed, said on the verse "And God was good to the midwives, etc., and the people multiplied and became very strong, etc." And further, in short, the term "very strong" is sometimes said regarding the abundance of increase, as it is written "and they multiplied and became very strong," etc.; sometimes regarding the abundance of wealth; sometimes regarding the abundance of merits and good deeds, as it is written "for great are the doers of His word." And behold, here it is said "and you shall give life to the children," Rashi explains that they provided them with water and food, and in Sotah (11b) Rashi explains "and you shall give life to the children" means that they were helping to sustain them, that they were hiding them in their homes and raising them. Now, reason dictates that the more children multiply, the more they become impoverished, for they will not have enough wealth. But this was due to the supervision of the Blessed One, to watch over them and to bestow upon them blessing, and the more they were generous in increasing the children, the more they became wealthy, as it is said "there is one who scatters and yet increases more." And this is "and God was good to the midwives" to such an extent that even though the people multiplied and it would have been fitting for them to become impoverished due to the great scattering, nevertheless, it was not so, but rather they became very strong in wealth. And this "and He made them houses" is explained above that they were hiding them in their homes, and thus they needed many houses and rooms, and "He made them houses" refers to God, that the Blessed One bestowed upon them in a way that is not natural, until they acquired and built houses according to their needs. Furthermore, our sages explained in another style close to its simple meaning, that the midwives sustained many souls of Israel, and anyone who sustains a soul of Israel is as if they sustained a whole world. According to this, if the Israelites were fruitful and multiplied only in a natural way and the midwives did not sustain so many souls, they would not be considered so righteous and good as they are now, who multiplied and became fruitful in a way that is not natural. And through this, the midwives became very great in merits and good deeds, for they sustained many souls, and also the good deeds that the souls they sustained performed are credited to them, for they are the causes. Thus, in the very increase itself, they are very great, and this is the meaning of "and the people multiplied" in a way that is not natural, and through this "they became very strong," the midwives, thus concludes our sages.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous growth of the Israelite population during their time in Egypt, emphasizing that this increase was a result of divine intervention rather than natural circumstances. It highlights the role of the midwives, who not only provided sustenance but also actively preserved life, thus earning immense merit and blessings from God. The text illustrates the Hasidic belief that acts of kindness and the preservation of life can lead to spiritual and material abundance, demonstrating that divine providence can transcend natural limitations. Ultimately, the midwives' actions contributed to the flourishing of the community, reinforcing the idea that those who sustain life are akin to creating a whole world.

passage_content: ועפ"י דרכו אפשר לרמוז עוד במאה"כ ותחיין את הילדים בתוס ' נופך על דבה"ק , עפימ"ד במדרש ילקוט ובפסיקתא עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא ובנ"י פרו וישרצו וגו' ותמלא הארץ אותם א"ר יוחנן שמלאו את מצרים, דבר אחר שנתמלאו בתי טרטיאות ובתי קרקסיאות מהם, מיד גזר עליהם שיפרשו מהן עכ"ד המדרש, והנה מאז נדלדלו ישראל מאוד ברוחניות והתגברו עליהם כוחות הטומאה של מצרים להחטיאם, דעד שהי' יעקב אבינו והדור הראשון חיים, היו ישראל מובדלים ומופרשים לגמרי מן המצריים, והיו שרויים רק בארץ גושן ובנו להון בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות ולמדו שם תורה כמבואר בדברי רז"ל, אבל אחר מיתת כל הדור ההוא מלאו את כל ארץ מצרים ונתמלאו מהם בתי טרטיאות ובתי שחוק, ואלמלי נמשך ירידה זו ימים רבים, היו ישראל משוקעים לגמרי ח"ו בטומאת מצרים וגלוליהם , אלא שהי' סיבה מאת ד' שגזר פרעה על המצריים שיפרשו מהן כמבואר במדרש, ונמאסו בעיני המצריים כמשה"כ ויקוצו מפני בנ"י , ובזוה"ק גוברין געלין בהון נוקבין געלין בהון ועי"ז נשארו בקדושתן ולא נתערבו עם המצריים, אמנם אין ספק שירידה זו הי' סכנה עצומה לקיום קדושתן של ישראל, דמה שמילאו את כל ארץ מצרים ומילאו בתי טרטיאות , השפיע עליהם לרוע בדיעותיהם והשקפותיהם ר"ל, ובפרט נשים שדעתן קלות וקרובים להתפתות לעצת יצרן, ומובן שזה גרם קלקול וחולשא בחינוך הבנים והבנות. ולא הי' אפשר להיות החינוך בבחי ' שהי' בזמן שהדור הראשון קיים, כי אם האבות אכלו בוסר שיני בנים תקהנה , וכשהאבות מתערבים בין המצרים בבתי טרטיאות שלהם, מכניסים רוח זה גם בבתיהם ונרגש החסרון בחינוך, ולזאת התחכמו המילדות הצדקניות יוכבד ומרים, שהיו מטמינות הבנים הנולדים בבתיהם תחת רשותם, ושם נתנו להם חינוך כשר על טהרת הקודש, מעולה ומשובח על מה שהי' אפשר להם להתחנך בבית הוריהם, וזה נרמז בדברי קודש רש"י ז"ל (במס' סוטה י"א ע"ב) ותחיין את הילדים משמע שהיו מסייעין להחיותן , שהיו מטמינות אותן בבתיהן ומגדלין אותן עכ"ל, ועי"ז הי' להם חלק בכל המצות ומעשים טובים שעשו כל אלה שנתגדלו על ידם, דהם היו הגורמים, ונחשב להם כאלו עשו וקיימו בכל המצות ההם, וכמו שפי' ק"ז זלה"ה ויעצמו מאוד המילדות בזכיות.
translation: According to its path, it is possible to hint further in the verse "and you shall keep the children alive" with an additional nuance on the Holy Land, as explained in the Midrash Yalkut and in the Pesikta on the verse "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," and "the children of Israel were fruitful and multiplied, and the land was filled with them." Rabbi Yochanan said that they filled Egypt, and another explanation is that the theaters and circuses were filled with them. Immediately, he decreed upon them that they should separate from them, thus concludes the Midrash. And behold, since then, Israel has greatly diminished in spirituality, and the forces of impurity of Egypt have strengthened against them to lead them astray, for until our father Jacob and that first generation were alive, Israel was completely separated and distinct from the Egyptians, and they dwelled only in the land of Goshen, building synagogues and houses of study, and they learned Torah there, as is explained in the words of our Sages. But after the death of that entire generation, they filled all the land of Egypt, and the theaters and places of amusement were filled with them. Had this decline continued for many days, Israel would have been completely immersed, Heaven forbid, in the impurity of Egypt and its idols. However, there was a reason from God that Pharaoh decreed upon the Egyptians to separate from them, as explained in the Midrash, and they became loathsome in the eyes of the Egyptians, as it is written, "and they were distressed because of the children of Israel." And in the Zohar, it is said that the men were repulsive to them, and thus they remained in their sanctity and did not mix with the Egyptians. However, there is no doubt that this decline was a tremendous danger to the preservation of the sanctity of Israel, for the fact that they filled all the land of Egypt and filled the theaters influenced them negatively in their opinions and perspectives, Heaven forbid, especially the women, whose minds are more susceptible and close to being swayed by their inclinations. It is understood that this caused corruption and weakness in the education of the sons and daughters. And it was not possible for the education to be in the manner that it was during the time when the first generation was alive, for if the fathers ate sour grapes, the children's teeth would be set on edge. And when the fathers intermixed among the Egyptians in their theaters, they brought this spirit into their homes, and the deficiency in education was felt. For this reason, the righteous midwives, Yocheved and Miriam, devised a plan, hiding the newborns in their homes under their authority, and there they provided them with proper education in purity, superior and excellent to what they could have received in their parents' homes. This is hinted at in the holy words of Rashi, of blessed memory (in Sotah 11b), "and you shall keep the children alive" means that they were assisting in keeping them alive, for they were hiding them in their homes and raising them. Thus, they had a share in all the commandments and good deeds that all those who were raised by them performed, for they were the causes, and it is considered as if they had done and fulfilled all those commandments, as explained by the holy Rabbi Zvi Elimelech, and the midwives greatly increased in merits.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual decline of the Israelites in Egypt after the death of the first generation, highlighting their increasing assimilation into Egyptian culture and the dangers this posed to their sanctity. It emphasizes the role of the righteous midwives, Yocheved and Miriam, who protected and educated the children in a manner that preserved their holiness, allowing them to maintain a connection to their faith despite the surrounding corruption. The text illustrates the importance of intentional spiritual upbringing and the impact of external influences on faith and values, suggesting that the midwives' efforts contributed to the merit of the entire community. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that even in dire circumstances, divine providence can guide individuals to uphold their spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ועד"ז נבין עצת פרעה מה שנזדקק למילדות עבריות שיסייעו בידו להשלים גזירתו להמית ילדי העבריים, ולכאורה הי' יאות לו יותר לבקש סיוע זו ממילדות מצריות, ובכח המלך והמושל להכריח שיכניסו לבית היולדות מילדות מצריות דוקא , והם ימלאו רצונו וגזירתו בוודאי, אמנם השיג פרעה דכל זמן שיתנהגו ישראל בקדושתן ויחנכו דורות כשרים במצות ומע"ט , לא יוכל להרע להם לעולם, ולזה התחכם להעבירם מני הדרך. ואף אותן שימלטו ממיתה ע"י שיולדו בטרם תבוא המילדת , עכ"פ ינתן להם חינוך מקולקל להשריש בהם טומאת מצרים ר"ל, וחשב שאם המילדות העבריות ישמעו אליו ויכנעו לכוחות הטומאה שלו, כאמרז"ל שתבען לדבר עבירה, הם מסוגלים יותר ממילדות המצריות להסית ולהדיח בנ"י , וע"ד הכתוב מהרסיך ומחריביך ממך יצאו, וכמו"ש רש"י בשם ת"כ (פ' בחקתי ) עה"פ ורדו בכם שנאיכם מכם ובכם, שבשעה שאוה"ע עומדים על ישראל אינם מבקשים אלא מה שבגלוי וכו ', אבל בשעה שאעמיד עליכם מכם ובכם הם מחפשים אחר המטמוניות שלכם עכ"ל, ובתחבולה זאת משתמשים רשעי אומה"ע בכל דור ודור, ליקח לעזרתם רשעי ישראל, ובעוה"ר מצליחים תמיד להשיג מכם ובכם, ועד"ז חשב פרעה הרשע לקלקל יסודות החינוך ע"י סיוע העבריות דייקא , אלא שלא עלתה בידו כי המילדות צדקניות היו, ועשו ההיפך מגזירתו שהטמינו אותן בבתיהם ומגדלין אותן כפירש"י , ונתנו להם חינוך טוב כאשר יאתה לצדקניות אלה.
translation: And similarly, we will understand Pharaoh's counsel regarding why he needed Hebrew midwives to assist him in fulfilling his decree to kill the Hebrew children. It would seem more appropriate for him to seek this assistance from Egyptian midwives, and with the power of the king and ruler, he could compel them to bring in Egyptian midwives specifically, who would certainly fulfill his will and decree. However, Pharaoh understood that as long as the Israelites conduct themselves with their sanctity and educate generations in the commandments and good deeds, he would not be able to harm them forever. Therefore, he devised a plan to lead them astray. Even those who would escape death by being born before the midwife arrives would, at the very least, receive a corrupted education to instill in them the impurity of Egypt, G-d forbid. He thought that if the Hebrew midwives would listen to him and submit to his forces of impurity, as our Sages have said, they would lead them to sin, they would be more capable than the Egyptian midwives of enticing and misleading the children of Israel. This aligns with the verse, "Your destroyers and devastators will come from you," and as Rashi explains in the name of the Tanchuma (Parashat Bechukotai) regarding the verse "Your enemies will rule over you," that when the nations of the world stand against Israel, they only seek what is revealed, etc. But when I stand against you, they search for your hidden impurities. Thus, through this cunning, the wicked of the nations of the world use it in every generation to take wicked Israelites to their aid, and unfortunately, they always succeed in obtaining from you and within you. Similarly, Pharaoh the wicked thought to corrupt the foundations of education specifically through the assistance of the Hebrew midwives. However, he did not succeed because the midwives were righteous and acted contrary to his decree, hiding the children in their homes and raising them, as Rashi explains, and they provided them with a good education as befits such righteous women.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's strategy to use Hebrew midwives to carry out his decree to kill Hebrew infants, believing that their influence could corrupt the children and undermine their sanctity. It highlights the idea that as long as the Israelites maintain their holiness and proper education, they cannot be harmed. The text emphasizes the danger of internal betrayal, where wicked individuals from within the community can be manipulated to assist external oppressors. Ultimately, the midwives defy Pharaoh's orders, demonstrating their righteousness and commitment to preserving the moral and spiritual integrity of the next generation.

passage_content: ואפשר לתרץ עפ"י דרכנו קושית האוהחה"ק הנ"ל, דמדוע לא גזר פרעה אף על הבנות, גם למה הוצרך לומר וכל הבת תחיון דפשיטא שלא יבקשו המילדות לעקור את הכל , אמנם אפשר שחש פרעה אולי א"א לסמוך על העבריות שישלימו גזירתו ויסייעו לדרכי הסתתו, ואפשר שיעשו עוד ההיפך שימסרו נפשם ליתן להם חינוך על טהרת הקודש כאשר עשו כן באמת, ע"כ לא רצה להכניס בספק זה גם הבנות, וגזר בפירוש וכל הבת תחיון בשב ואל תעשה, ובלא"ה לא יתקיימו ח"ו הבנות אם הבנים ידחו, כי הנשים דעתן קלות ונוחים להתפתות, ע"כ הי' מוטב לו שלא יזדקקו להם כל עיקר לא להרע ולא להטיב.
translation: It is possible to explain according to our approach the question of the holy Baal Shem Tov mentioned above, why Pharaoh did not decree against the daughters as well, and why it was necessary to say "and every daughter you shall let live," as it is obvious that the midwives would not seek to uproot everything. However, it is possible that Pharaoh feared that he could not rely on the Hebrew women to fulfill his decree and assist in his devious ways, and perhaps they would do the opposite, sacrificing themselves to provide them with education in purity, as they indeed did. Therefore, he did not want to include the daughters in this uncertainty, and explicitly decreed "and every daughter you shall let live" as a passive command, and in any case, the daughters would not survive, Heaven forbid, if the sons were cast aside, for women are of light mind and easily swayed. Therefore, it would have been better for him not to rely on them at all, neither for harm nor for good.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's decree against the Hebrew boys, noting that he did not include the girls, possibly due to a fear that the Hebrew midwives might defy his orders and instead nurture the girls in holiness. It suggests that Pharaoh recognized the potential for the women to resist his decree and instead promote a sacred upbringing, which could undermine his intentions. The text emphasizes the belief that if the boys are lost, the girls would also ultimately be at risk, as women are seen as more easily swayed. Thus, Pharaoh opted to exclude the girls from his decree to avoid any uncertainty regarding their fate.

passage_content: אולם הצדקניות הללו לא שמעו לדבריו אף בזה, ואף שהבנות לא היו בכלל הגזירה, מ"מ היו מכניסים אותם לבתיהם ומגדלין אותו בדרך הקודש, ולז"א ותחיין את הילדים ולא אמר ותחיין את הבנים, שעשו כן בכל הנולדים ואף הבנות, ובעוה"ר אין הכל משיגים נחיצת חינוך הבנות ואולי הוא יותר מחינוך הבנים, כי הבנים יש להם כח התורה המציל אותם ומשפיע עליהם לשמר קדושתן, אבל הבנות אסור להם ללמוד תורה, ובמה זכיין אם לא ינתן להם חינוך על טהרת הקודש מקטנותן, ויסוד בית ישראל תלוי' בחינוך הבנות, כי א"א לבנות בית נאמן ולהעמיד דורות כשרים זולתי אם הבנות מחונכות ע"ד ישראל סבא, וזה נרמז באמרם ז"ל ביתו זו אשתו דיסוד הבית נסמך עליהם, ובמד"ר (פ' יתרו) כה תאמר לבית יעקב אלו הנשים, למה לנשים תחלה כדי שיהיו מנהיגות את בניהן לתורה, ופי' המפרשים דהדרכת הבנים לחנכן בקטנותם לתורה תלוי' בנשים כמ"ש ואל תטוש תורת אמך , ואפשר שזה ירמוז הכתוב ויהי כי יראו המילדות את האלקים ויעש להם בתים, דלפי שהקימו יסוד הבנין ע"י חינוך הבנים והבנות להעמיד בתים בישראל, ומדה כ"מ עשה הקב"ה להם להעמיד מהם בתי כהונה לוי' ומלכות כמו שיבואר.
translation: However, these righteous women did not heed his words even in this matter, and although the daughters were not included in the decree, nonetheless they would bring them into their homes and raise them in the way of holiness. This is to say, "and you shall give life to the children," and it does not say "and you shall give life to the sons," for they did so with all the newborns, including the daughters. And in our unfortunate times, not everyone understands the necessity of educating the daughters, and perhaps it is even more important than educating the sons, for the sons have the strength of the Torah that saves them and influences them to preserve their sanctity. But the daughters are forbidden to learn Torah, and what merit do they have if they are not given an education in purity from their youth? The foundation of the House of Israel depends on the education of the daughters, for it is impossible to build a faithful home and establish righteous generations unless the daughters are educated according to the ways of our forefathers. This is hinted at in the saying of our sages, "His house is his wife," for the foundation of the home is dependent upon them. And in the Midrash (Parashat Yitro), it says, "So shall you say to the House of Jacob," these are the women. Why to the women first? So that they may lead their children to the Torah. And the commentators explain that the guidance of the sons to educate them in their youth in the Torah depends on the women, as it is written, "And do not forsake the teaching of your mother." And it is possible that this is hinted at in the verse, "And it was that when the midwives saw the God, He made them houses," for since they established the foundation of the building through the education of the sons and daughters to establish homes in Israel, and measure for measure, the Holy One, blessed be He, made for them to establish from them houses of priesthood, Levites, and kings, as will be explained.
summary: The passage emphasizes the critical role of women in the education and spiritual upbringing of children within the Jewish community. It highlights that while boys have the Torah to guide them, girls must receive a pure and holy education from a young age to ensure the foundation of a faithful household. The text underscores that the strength of the Jewish home and the continuity of future generations depend on the proper nurturing of daughters, as they are seen as the backbone of a stable and righteous family. Ultimately, it conveys that the divine reward for fostering such homes is the establishment of priestly, Levitical, and royal lineages.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר טענת התנצלותם אל פרעה באמרם בטרם תבוא אליהם המילדת וילדו, ולכאורה אינו מספיק התנצלות זה על מה שהיו מספיקות להם מים ומזון ומגדלין אותן, ואפ"ל לדרכינו עפימ"ד במדרש וייטב אלקים למילדות מהו הטובה שקיבל דבריהם מלך מצרים ולא הזיק להן, ובוודאי שהי' זה מחסדי הבוי"ת להטיב להם לפי מעשיהם, שעפ"י הטבע לא הי' דבריהם מתקבלים על השכל מ"ש שאין ישראל צריכים למילדות , אלא שהמשיך הבוי"ת חסדו עליהם וקיבל פרעה דבריהם, ולדרכנו אפשר להסביר הענין גם בדרך הטבע, דהנה כבר אמר החכם אין לך משוחד יותר ממי שמשוחד לתאותיו ורצונותיו, ופרעה הרשע הי' כל תשוקתו ותאותו אך להשריש בישראל טומאת מצרים ולהרגילם בתועבת מצרים ר"ל, ולזאת הטעו המילדות אותו בכך ונטעה לדבריהם מפני שהי' משוחד לדבר זה, ואמרו לו דע"כ מטמינות אותן בבתיהן ומגדלין אותם, כדי לחנך אותם על דעתו הרשעה ולא יתחנכו בבתי אבותיהם ע"ד הישן דרך ישראל סבא, וטענה זו היתה נשמעת אצלו כי הי' משוחד ברצונו לזה, וע"כ קיבל דבריהם ולא הזיק להן על מה שלא הרגו הילדים ועוד החיו וחינכו אותם.
translation: And this will clarify their excuse to Pharaoh when they said before the midwives came to them and they gave birth. At first glance, this excuse does not suffice for what they needed in terms of water and food and raising them. And it can be said according to our way, as explained in the Midrash, that God favored the midwives. What is the good that the king of Egypt accepted their words and did not harm them? Certainly, this was from the kindness of the Blessed One to do good to them according to their deeds, for according to nature, their words would not be accepted by reason, saying that the Israelites do not need midwives. Rather, the Blessed One continued His kindness towards them and Pharaoh accepted their words. According to our way, it is also possible to explain the matter in a natural way. Behold, the wise one has already said that there is no one more biased than one who is biased towards his desires and wants. And the wicked Pharaoh had all his desire and lust only to instill the impurity of Egypt in Israel and to accustom them to the abominations of Egypt, so to speak. Therefore, the midwives misled him in this and planted in his words because he was biased towards this. And they said to him, "Know that we are hiding them in their homes and raising them, in order to educate them according to his wicked opinion and not to educate them in their fathers' homes according to the old way of Israel's ancestors." This argument was acceptable to him because he was biased in his desire for this. Therefore, he accepted their words and did not harm them for not killing the children, and moreover, he allowed them to live and educate them.
summary: The passage discusses the justification of the midwives' actions before Pharaoh, emphasizing that their excuse for not killing the Hebrew babies was accepted due to divine intervention and the nature of Pharaoh's desires. It suggests that Pharaoh, driven by his own corrupt inclinations, was misled by the midwives' claims, which aligned with his wish to instill Egyptian values in the Israelites. This reflects the Hasidic concept of divine providence, where God's kindness influences human affairs, allowing the midwives to act righteously despite the oppressive circumstances. Ultimately, it illustrates how one's desires can shape perceptions and decisions, leading to unexpected outcomes in the divine plan.

passage_content: ואפשר שנרמז גם טענה זו באמרם כי לא כנשים המצריות וגו' בטרם תבוא אליהם המילדת וילדו, עפימ"ש בספה"ק סידורו ש"ש בביאור אמרם ז"ל מי הקדימני ואשלם, מי מל עד שלא נתתי לו בן, מי עשה מזוזה עד שלא נתתי לו בית וכו' לכאורה הרי א"א במציאות למול עד שלא נולד לו בן וכו ', ופי' שאם מקדים האדם במחשבתו שאם יזכהו ד' להוליד בן יקיים בו מצות מילה, נחשב לו כאילו קיים מצות מילה עד שלא נולד לו בן, ועד"ז אפשר לקיים מצות מזוזה טרם שיהי' לו בית עייש"ד , ודבר זה א"א במציאות כ"א לעם בנ"י המשתוקקים וחפצים לקיים מצות ד' עוד טרם הגיע אליהם, וזה שאמרו לפרעה כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות וגו' בטרם תבא אליהם המילדת וילדו, שגדלה כ"כ השתוקקותם לקיים מצות ד' בפרי הבטן, היינו מצות מילה וחינוך הבנים לתורה ומצות, ע"כ בטרם תבא אליהם המילדת וילדו, ה"ה כאילו כבר ילדו וקיימו בהם כל המצות, ומובן שעם כזה שמשתוקקים כ"כ אל המצות יחנכו בניהם על טהרת הקודש, ולזאת לקחנו בניהם לבתינו לגדל אותם על דעתנו, וקיבל דבריהם מלך מצרים לפי שהי' משוחד אל הרצון הזה ולא הזיק להם, והי' מחסדי הבוי"ת שהאמין להם ונפתה בדבריהם.
translation: And it is possible that this claim is hinted at in their statement that they are not like the Egyptian women, etc., before the midwife comes to them and they give birth. As explained in the holy book, in his prayer book, in the explanation of their words, may their memory be blessed: "Who preceded me and I completed, who circumcised before I gave him a son, who made a mezuzah before I gave him a house," etc. It seems that it is impossible in reality to circumcise before a son is born, etc. The explanation is that if a person anticipates in his thoughts that if God grants him a son, he will fulfill the commandment of circumcision, it is considered as if he has fulfilled the commandment of circumcision before the son is born. Similarly, it is possible to fulfill the commandment of mezuzah before he has a house, as explained there. This is something that is only possible in reality for the people of Israel who are eager and desire to fulfill God's commandments even before they come to them. This is what they said to Pharaoh, that they are not like the Hebrew women of Egypt, etc., before the midwife comes to them and they give birth, that their eagerness to fulfill God's commandments regarding the fruit of the womb has grown so much, namely the commandment of circumcision and educating the children in Torah and commandments. Therefore, before the midwife comes to them and they give birth, it is as if they have already given birth and fulfilled all the commandments in them. It is understood that a people like this, who are so eager for the commandments, will educate their children in purity and holiness. For this reason, we took their children to our homes to raise them according to our understanding, and the king of Egypt accepted their words because he was biased towards this desire and did not harm them, and it was by the kindness of the Creator that he believed them and was swayed by their words.
summary: The passage discusses the profound spiritual yearning of the Jewish people to fulfill God's commandments even before the actual circumstances allow for it, exemplified by their desire to perform circumcision and educate their children in Torah. It emphasizes that such intentions are considered as if the commandments have already been fulfilled, reflecting a deep commitment to holiness and divine service. The text highlights the unique spiritual status of the Jewish people, whose fervent desire to observe the commandments leads to divine favor, as seen in their interactions with Pharaoh. Ultimately, it illustrates the concept that sincere intentions and aspirations towards fulfilling God's will hold significant spiritual merit.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר אמרם ז"ל שתבען לדבר עבירה (וסרה קושית היפ"ת הובא לעיל קושיא ג') עפימ"ש החוו"ד זלה"ה (בפי' תעלומות חכמה על מגילת אסתר) שעל כן צוותה אסתר וצומו עלי וגו', שיתפללו עלי' שלא תכשל בחטא שאם תכשל לא יוכל להיות הישועה על ידי', דא"א שיבא ישועה לישראל ע"י בעל עבירה עיי"ש (הובא בדברינו לעיל) והנה חשש פרעה אולי לא ישמעו המילדות להשלים גזירתו, ועוד יהי' נעשה נס על ידן להציל ילדי ישראל כאשר הי' באמת, ע"כ רצה לטמאן ותבען לדבר עבירה, ואז הי' בטוח שלא תעשה נס על ידן, גם ישלימו גזירתו לפועל ע"ד מהרסיך ומחריביך ממך יצאו, אלא שלא נתקיים עצתו והצדקניות האלו מסרו נפשם על קדושתם של ישראל ולא שמעו לו, ובזה יובן דאף שעפ"י דינא אין אשה מחוייבת למסור נפשה לקטלא באיסור עריות, כמ"ש אסתר קרקע עולם היתה , אמנם הם השיגו כי בזה תלוי' קיומם של ישראל, ואם ישמעו להטמא אליו לא יעשה להם נס להציל ילדי ישראל ע"כ מסרו נפשם על הדבר, וא"ש הקישור ולא עשו כאשר דבר אליהם מלך מצרים שתבען לדבר עבירה, וע"כ ותחיין את הילדים שנסתייע להם מן השמים להציל ילדי ישראל ולגדלם על דרך התורה על טהרת הקודש.
translation: And this will explain their statement, may their memory be blessed, that they were drawn to commit a transgression (and this resolves the difficulty of the previous question brought above, question 3) according to what is stated in the Chavot Da'at, blessed be his memory (in the commentary Taalumot Chochmah on the Book of Esther), that is why Esther commanded, "And fast for me," etc., that they should pray for her not to stumble in sin, for if she were to stumble, salvation could not come through her, for it is impossible for salvation to come to Israel through a transgressor, as stated there (brought in our discussion above). Now, Pharaoh feared that perhaps the midwives would not heed to complete his decree, and a miracle would be performed through them to save the children of Israel, as indeed happened. Therefore, he wanted to defile them and draw them to commit a transgression, and then he was sure that no miracle would be performed through them, and they would also fulfill his decree in accordance with "Your destroyers and those who ruin you will come out from you." However, his counsel did not come to fruition, and these righteous women risked their lives for the sanctity of Israel and did not listen to him. And this will be understood that even though according to the law a woman is not obligated to risk her life for the prohibition of illicit relations, as it is said, "Esther was the foundation of the world," nevertheless, they understood that the existence of Israel depended on this, and if they listened to defile themselves to him, no miracle would be performed for them to save the children of Israel. Therefore, they risked their lives for this matter, and this clarifies the connection: they did not do as the king of Egypt spoke to them to be drawn to commit a transgression, and therefore they kept the children alive, as they were assisted from Heaven to save the children of Israel and raise them in the way of the Torah in purity and holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of maintaining spiritual purity in the face of temptation, as exemplified by the midwives who defied Pharaoh's orders to kill the Israelite children. It emphasizes that true salvation for Israel cannot come through those who engage in sin, and the midwives' refusal to comply with Pharaoh's decree was a matter of life and death for the Jewish people. Their self-sacrifice was rooted in the understanding that their actions directly impacted the survival of Israel, leading to divine assistance in preserving the children. Ultimately, their commitment to holiness ensured that they could fulfill their role in the miraculous salvation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפ"י דרכינו פלוגתא דרב ושמואל הנ"ל ויעש להם בתים חד אמר בתי כהונה ולוי' ממשה ואהרן, וח"א בתי מלכות דוד וכו ', דבודאי תרווייהו מודי דכולהו איתנייהו בהו ויצאו מהם כהונה ולוי', אמנם הסבר פלוגתתם עפימ"ד בגמרא (מגילה כ"ט ע"א) ר"א הקפר אומר עתידין בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות שבבבל שיקבעו בארץ ישראל שנא' כי כתבור בהרים וככרמל בים יבא, והלא דברים ק"ו ומה תבור וכרמל שלא באו אלא לפי שעה וכו' נקבעים בארץ ישראל, בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות שמרביצין בהם תורה עאכו"כ עכ"ד הגמרא, ואיתא במדרש ילקוט ( ישעי ' רמז רנ"ח) ובספרי עה"פ והי' באחרית הימים נכון יהי' הר בית ד' בראש ההרים, ר"פ בש"ר ראובן אמר עתיד הקב"ה להביא סיני ותבור וכרמל ולבנות ביהמ"ק על גביהן, מה טעם והי' באחרית הימים נכון יהי' הר בית ד' בראש ההרים והם אומרים שירה עכ"ד המדרש, ומעתה לפי דרשת הק"ו שעתידין בתי כנסיות ובתמ"ד שיקבעו בא"י ק"ו מתבור וכרמל, א"כ יקבעו במקום המקדש בק"ו מתבור וכרמל.
translation: And we will explain according to our way the dispute of Rav and Shmuel mentioned above, and He made for them houses; one said houses of priesthood and Levites from Moshe and Aharon, and the other said houses of the kingship of David, etc. For certainly both agree that all of them are included in it, and from them emerged priesthood and Levites. However, the explanation of their dispute is according to the teaching in the Gemara (Megillah 29a) where Rabbi Eliezer the Kappar says that the synagogues and study houses in Babylonia will be established in the Land of Israel, as it is said, "For like Tabor among the mountains and like Carmel by the sea, it will come." And is it not a fortiori? If Tabor and Carmel, which only came temporarily, are established in the Land of Israel, how much more so the synagogues and study houses where Torah is disseminated! Thus concludes the Gemara. And it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Isaiah, Remez 258) and in the Sifrei on the verse, "And it will be in the end of days, the mountain of the House of the Lord will be established at the top of the mountains." Rabbi Pinchas in the name of Rabbi Reuven said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will bring Sinai, Tabor, and Carmel and build the Holy Temple upon them. What is the reason? "And it will be in the end of days, the mountain of the House of the Lord will be established at the top of the mountains," and they will sing a song. Thus concludes the Midrash. And from now on, according to the a fortiori reasoning that the synagogues and study houses will be established in the Land of Israel, a fortiori from Tabor and Carmel, then they will be established in the place of the Temple, a fortiori from Tabor and Carmel.
summary: The passage discusses the future significance of synagogues and study houses in Babylon, asserting that they will ultimately be established in the Land of Israel, as indicated by a Talmudic source. It emphasizes the idea that just as Mount Tabor and Mount Carmel, which are temporary, will be fixed in Israel, so too will the places of Torah learning, which are of greater importance. The text also references a Midrash that foretells the rebuilding of the Holy Temple on these mountains, highlighting the theological belief in the ultimate redemption and the centrality of Israel in Jewish worship and learning. This reflects a deep connection between physical locations and spiritual significance in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: אולם אינו מבורר באיזה מקום במקדש יקבעו, אם במקום חצר המקדש או העזרה או ההיכל וקודש הקדשים, ועד"ז יל"פ פלוגתת הקדושים הללו דהנה אמרו ז"ל אין ישיבה בעזרה אלא למלכי בית דוד בלבד, לפי"ז מקום העזרה ירמוז לבתי מלכות בית דוד כי שם ביתם, וניכר גדולתם יותר מכהנים ולוים שלא הורשה הישיבה שם לזולתם, ומקום ההיכל ירמוז לבתי לוי' כי שם ביתם להתייחס על הדוכן, וקדשי קדשים ירמוז לבתי כהונה אהרן הכהן, שלא נכנס לשם כ"א הכ"ג ביוכ"פ , ומעתה תרווייהו אמת דיצאו מהם כהונה לוי' ומלכות היינו משה אהרן ודוד, אלא דפליגי במאמר הכתוב ויעש להם בתים, דלפי שהעמידו בתי חינוך במצרים לחנך ילדי ישראל לתורה, כנרמז בדברי רש"י ז"ל (סוטה י"א) שהיו מטמינות אותן בבתיהן ומגדלין אותן. ע"כ עתידין אותן הבתים שיקבעו בא"י במקום המקדש, ופליגי בזה אם יהיו הבתים האלו בתי כהונה ולוי', ר"ל שיקבעו בהיכל ובק"ק או בתי מלכות ויקבעו במקום העזרה.
translation: However, it is not clarified in which place in the Temple they will be established, whether in the courtyard of the Temple, the Azarah, the Heichal, or the Holy of Holies. Similarly, one can discuss the dispute regarding these holy places. For our Sages have said that there is no sitting in the Azarah except for the kings of the House of David alone. According to this, the place of the Azarah hints at the royal houses of the House of David, for that is their home, and their greatness is more evident than that of the Kohanim and Leviyim, who are not permitted to sit there except for them. The place of the Heichal hints at the houses of the Leviyim, for that is their home to be related to the platform, and the Holy of Holies hints at the houses of the priesthood of Aaron the priest, for only the High Priest enters there on Yom Kippur. From now on, both are true that from them came the priesthood, Leviyah, and kingship, namely Moshe, Aaron, and David. However, they disagree regarding the verse "and he made them houses," for since they established houses of education in Egypt to educate the children of Israel in the Torah, as hinted in the words of Rashi (Sotah 11) that they would hide them in their homes and raise them. Therefore, those houses are destined to be established in Eretz Yisrael in the place of the Temple, and they disagree on whether these houses will be houses of priesthood and Leviyah, meaning that they will be established in the Heichal and the Holy of Holies, or royal houses that will be established in the place of the Azarah.
summary: The passage discusses the debate regarding the placement of sacred houses within the Temple, specifically whether they will be established in the courtyard, the altar, the sanctuary, or the Holy of Holies. It highlights the distinction between the roles of the Davidic monarchy, the Levites, and the priesthood, emphasizing that only the kings of David's lineage could sit in the altar area, symbolizing their unique status. The text also references the educational efforts in Egypt to raise Jewish children in Torah, suggesting that these foundational teachings will influence the future establishment of these sacred houses in the Land of Israel. Ultimately, the disagreement centers on whether these houses will represent the priestly and Levitical lineages or the royal lineage of David.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה לענינינו דע"י שמקימים ומקיימים בתי חינוך על טהרת הקודש, נחשב להמסייעים כל המע"ט והמצות שיעשו כל אלה הנפשות כאלו עשו הם, כיון שהם הגורמים, וע"ד שפי' ק"ז זלה"ה וירב העם ויעצמו מאוד המילדות בזכיות כנ"ל, וחלילה הגורם אל ההיפך יש לו חלק בעבירות ח"ו, ויעזור השי"ת שיתקיים בנו וירב העם ואעפ"כ ויעצמו מאוד בהפלגת העושר והפלגת זכיות ומע"ט , והשי"ת יעזור לכל ישראל בהשפעת ברכה והצלחה במהרה עם כל מיני ישועות טובות, ונזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקינו בנחת ובשמחה ומתוך הרחבה, וננצל מכל צרה וצוקה, ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: What emerges for us from this, regarding our matters, is that by establishing and maintaining educational institutions on the purity of holiness, all those who assist in this endeavor, through the merits and commandments performed by these souls, are considered as if they themselves have done them, since they are the cause. And as explained in the verse, "And the people multiplied and became very strong, the midwives in merits as mentioned above," God forbid, the one who causes the opposite has a share in transgressions, may it be spared from us. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, help that we will be sustained and that the people will multiply, and nevertheless, they will become very strong in the abundance of wealth and the abundance of merits and commandments. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, assist all of Israel with the outpouring of blessing and success speedily, with all kinds of good salvations, and may we merit to greet the righteous Messiah with ease and joy and in abundance, and may we be saved from all trouble and distress, with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of establishing and maintaining educational institutions rooted in holiness, suggesting that those who contribute to such efforts share in the spiritual merits of the students. It highlights the idea that positive actions lead to blessings and growth, while negative influences can result in transgressions. The author prays for divine assistance in increasing both material and spiritual wealth for the Jewish people, ultimately expressing hope for the imminent arrival of the Messiah and the redemption from all suffering, accompanied by a revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בענין הנ"ל עפימ"ש רז"ל במס' שבת (דף ל"א) אמר רבה בר רב הונא כל אדם שיש בו תורה ואין בו יר"ש, דומה לגזבר שמסרו לו מפתחות הפנימיות ומפתחות החיצונות לא מסרו לו בהי עייל, פרש"י יראת שמים דומה לפתחים החיצונים, שדרך להם נכנסין לפנימיים וכו ', עוד אמרו שם מכריז ר' ינאי חבל על דלית לי' דרתא ותרעא לדרתא עביד, פרש"י במס' יומא (ע"ב ע"ב) שהתורה אינה רק שער ליכנס ליראת שמים. לכך צריך שתקדים לו יראת שמים, והקשה הרי"ף בעין יעקב דב' מימרות אלו נראין כמהופכות וסותרות זא"ז , דרבה המשיל יר"ש לפתחים החיצונים ותורה לפנימיים, ור' ינאי המשיל התורה לשער ויר"ש לפנימי, ודוחק לומר דפליגי בזה עכ"ל.
translation: And although it can be said further regarding the aforementioned matter, as our Sages of blessed memory stated in Tractate Shabbat (page 31), Rabbi Bar Rav Huna said: "Any person who has Torah but does not have the fear of Heaven is like a treasurer to whom the keys to the inner chambers were given, but the keys to the outer chambers were not given." Rashi explains that the fear of Heaven is likened to the outer doors, through which one enters the inner chambers, etc. They also said there that Rabbi Yannai proclaims: "Woe to one who does not have a dwelling, and a dwelling is made for the dwelling." Rashi explains in Tractate Yoma (page 72b) that the Torah is only a gate to enter into the fear of Heaven. Therefore, one must precede with the fear of Heaven. The Rif in Ein Yaakov questions that these two statements seem to be contradictory and opposing to one another, for Rabbi Bar Huna compared the fear of Heaven to the outer doors and the Torah to the inner ones, while Rabbi Yannai compared the Torah to a gate and the fear of Heaven to the inner. It is difficult to say that they disagree on this matter.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between Torah study and the fear of Heaven (Yirat Shamayim) within Hasidic thought. It emphasizes that while Torah is essential, it must be accompanied by Yirat Shamayim, which serves as a gateway to deeper spiritual understanding. The contrasting interpretations of these concepts highlight the necessity of both elements in achieving true spiritual fulfillment, suggesting that one cannot access the inner sanctum of divine wisdom without first cultivating a reverent fear of God. This interplay underscores the holistic approach to spiritual growth in Hasidic philosophy.

passage_content: וכבר תירצתיו באופנים שונים (עי' בדברנו פ' לך עמוד רס"ג) ולעניננו אפ"ל דבמשל הראשון רמזו לנו חז"ל דכל הלומד תורה בלי יר"ש אפילו תורה אין לו, דלכווין לאמיתה של תורה צריך סייעתא דשמיא, ואינו כשאר החכמות שבעולם שאם יעמיק אדם מחשבתו ימצאנה ע"י יגיעתה, אמנם בלימוד התורה אינו כן, שהלומד תורה ואין בו יר"ש אינו רואה דרך האמת ולא ישיג עריבותה , וטועה ונתעה ח"ו בדרך התורה וזה שהמשילו אותו לגזבר שמסרו לו מפתחות הפנימיות והחיצונות לא מסרו לו, שא"א לו לעייל כלל, ואף זה אינו תופס בהשגת התוה"ק כלום.
translation: And I have already explained it in various ways (see our discussion in Parashat Lech Lecha, page 263). Regarding our matter, it can be said that in the first parable, our Sages hinted to us that anyone who studies Torah without fear of Heaven, even Torah, has none. To align with the truth of the Torah, one needs divine assistance, and it is not like other wisdoms in the world, where if a person deepens his thought, he can find it through his own effort. However, in the study of Torah, it is not so; one who studies Torah without fear of Heaven does not see the path of truth and will not attain its sweetness, and he is mistaken and misled, Heaven forbid, in the way of the Torah. This is why they compared him to a treasurer to whom the keys of the inner and outer chambers were given, but he was not given the keys to enter at all, and even this does not allow him to grasp anything of the Holy Torah.
summary: The passage emphasizes that studying Torah without fear of Heaven (Yirat Shamayim) is fundamentally flawed, as true understanding and connection to the Torah require divine assistance. Unlike other fields of knowledge where one can achieve understanding through personal effort, Torah study demands a spiritual foundation. The analogy of a treasurer lacking access to the inner keys illustrates that without reverence, one cannot truly grasp the essence of the Torah. Thus, the text underscores the necessity of a sincere spiritual disposition for authentic engagement with sacred teachings.

passage_content: ובמשל השני שאמר ר' ינאי רמזו לנו חז"ל עוד בחי' אחרת בענין התורה ויר"ש, דהנה ישנם בנ"א שבבית המדרש מתנהגים בדרך התורה והמוסר, לקבוע עתים לתורה ולהתפלל בכוונה, אבל בביתם מתנהגים ר"ל בלי יר"ש ובלי תורה כשפלים ומגושמים, אבל באמת צריך האדם לקיים שויתי ד' לנגדי תמיד, וישים אל לבו שהמלך הגדול הקב"ה אשר מלא כל הארץ כבודו עומד עליו ורואה במעשיו שנאמר אם יסתר איש במסתרים ואני לא אראנו , גם בשכבו על משכבו ידע לפני מי הוא שוכב, ואמרז"ל מגיד לאדם מה שיחו אפילו שיחה קלה שבין איש לאשתו מגידין לו לאדם בשעת מיתתו, וצריך להשים נגד עיניו בכל פסיעה ובכל פעולה שיש בורא עולם המשגיח ורואה במעשיו, ויעשה הכל רק לרצון ולנחת רוח להבוי"ת , ואם ככה יתנהג יתקיים בקדושתו לנצח, וגם ביתו יהי' לו קדושה נצחיות, כמ"ש הקדושת לוי זלל"ה דכמ"ש במס' מגילה (דף כ"ט ע"א) עתידין בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות שבבבל שיקבעו בא"י, כמו"כ מי שמתנהג בביתו בקדושה ובטהרה, והולך בדרכי ד' ומצותיו לעשות רצונו ית ', הרי יש בביתו ג"כ קדושת ביהכנ"ס , וק"ו שעתידה ליקבע בא"י ותשאר נצחיות, שהרי ביהכנ"ס וביהמ"ד אינם עוסקין בה בתורה אלא לשעה, ובביתו ה"ה עושה רצון הבוי"ת יום ולילה תמיד, וזה נרמז במשל ר' ינאי שהתאונן ואמר חבל על דלית לי' דרתא , שאין לו דירה ובית שמתנהגים בו בקדושה וטהרה וביראת שמים, ותרעא לדרתא עביד, שלומד תורה ויודעה, ויש לו שער ליכנס ולהרגיל קדושה ויר"ש בביתו, אבל אין לו דעת להתגבר על יצרו וכשיושב בביתו מתנהג כשפלים ומגושמים ר"ל, א"כ מה הועיל בתורתו ובמה שיש לו תרעא אם אין לו בית.
translation: In the second parable that Rabbi Yanai said, our Sages hinted to us another aspect regarding the Torah and the fear of Heaven. Behold, there are people in the study hall who conduct themselves according to the way of the Torah and ethics, setting times for Torah study and praying with intention, but at home they conduct themselves, Heaven forbid, without fear of Heaven and without Torah, like lowly and coarse individuals. But in truth, a person must fulfill "I have set the Lord always before me," and he should place in his heart that the great King, the Holy One, blessed be He, who fills the whole world with His glory, stands over him and sees his deeds, as it is said, "If a man hides in secret places, will I not see him?" Even when lying on his bed, he should know before whom he lies. And our Sages have said that a person is informed of his conversation, even a light conversation between a man and his wife, at the time of his death. He must keep before his eyes with every step and every action that there is a Creator of the world who is watching and seeing his deeds, and he should do everything only for the will and pleasure of the Creator. If he conducts himself this way, he will maintain his sanctity forever, and his home will also have eternal holiness, as the Kedushas Levi, may his memory be blessed, said, as it is written in Megillah (29a), that the synagogues and study halls in Babylon will be established in the Land of Israel. Likewise, one who conducts himself at home with holiness and purity, and walks in the ways of the Lord and His commandments to do His will, indeed has in his home the sanctity of a synagogue, and certainly it will be established in the Land of Israel and remain eternal, for synagogues and study halls are not engaged in Torah only for a time, but in his home he is doing the will of the Creator day and night always. This is hinted at in Rabbi Yanai's parable, who lamented and said, "Woe to me that I have no dwelling," that he has no home where he can conduct himself with holiness and purity and fear of Heaven. And he who learns Torah and knows it, has a gate to enter and accustom holiness and fear of Heaven in his home, but he lacks the understanding to overcome his evil inclination, and when he sits at home, he conducts himself like lowly and coarse individuals, Heaven forbid. Therefore, what benefit is there in his Torah and in what he has, if he has no home?
summary: The passage discusses the importance of maintaining a consistent level of reverence and holiness in both public and private life, emphasizing that true devotion to God should permeate all aspects of a person's existence. It highlights the idea that one must always be aware of God's presence and oversight, which should inspire actions that align with divine will. The text also suggests that a home infused with sanctity and adherence to God's commandments can attain a lasting spiritual significance, akin to that of synagogues and study halls. Ultimately, it warns against the futility of scholarly pursuits if one's personal life lacks the same commitment to holiness and reverence.

passage_content: והנה איתא בזוה"ק ( סו"פ ויגש ) וישב ישראל באמ"צ בארץ גושן ויאחזו בה ויפרו וירבו מאוד, ויאחזו בה אחסנת עלמין וכו ', ולכאורה איך אפ"ל אחסנת עלמין והלא יצאו משם ונגאלו, ופירשתי עפי"מ שתירגם ביוב"ע הפסוק הנ"ל ויתיב ישראל בארעא דמצרים ובנוי להון בתי מדרשין וכו ', ומעתה א"ש דעתידין בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות שיקבעו בא"י, נמצא שהי' אחסנת עלמין ונצחי ואף לאחר שנגאלו ויצאו משם אחזו בה לעולם, שאלו הבתי מדרשות שבנו הלכו עמהם, ולדרכנו עפי"ד הקדושת לוי אפ"ל דקאי גם על ביתם, שהי' להם קדושת ביהכנ"ס שהתנהגו בהם בקדושה וטהרה, וע"כ גם בתיהם הלכו עמהם כשיצאו משם, וא"ש שאמרו בזוה"ק שנתיישבו במצרים ויאחזו בה אחסנת עלמין, שנשאר נצחי לעולם, ובזה אפ"ל ויהי כי יראו המילדות את האלקים ויעש להם בתים, עי"ז זכו לבתים נצחיים לאחסנת עלמין ולבניהם עד עולם, ומהם יוצא קדושה וטהרה ותורה, והם הן בתי כהונה ולוי' ומלכות כאמרז"ל .
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Zohar (Parashat Vayigash) that Israel settled in the land of Goshen and they took hold of it and multiplied greatly, and they took hold of it as an eternal dwelling, etc. At first glance, how can it be said that it was an eternal dwelling when they left from there and were redeemed? I explained according to the translation of the above verse in the Targum Onkelos that Israel sat in the land of Egypt and built for themselves houses of study, etc. From now on, it is understood that the synagogues and houses of study that will be established in the Land of Israel are considered an eternal dwelling, and even after they were redeemed and left from there, they held onto it forever, for those houses of study that they built went with them. And according to our path, according to the Kedushat Levi, it can be said that it also applies to their homes, which had the sanctity of a synagogue, where they conducted themselves with holiness and purity. Therefore, their homes also went with them when they left from there. It is understood that the Zohar said they settled in Egypt and took hold of it as an eternal dwelling, which remained eternal forever. In this, it can be said, "And it was when the midwives saw the Divine, and He made for them houses," through this they merited eternal houses for an eternal dwelling for their children forever, from which holiness, purity, and Torah emerge, and they are the houses of the priesthood, Levites, and kings, as our sages have said.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "Achsant Almin," or eternal dwelling, as derived from the Zohar, emphasizing that the spiritual essence of the Jewish people's connection to their places of worship and study remains intact even after their physical departure from Egypt. It suggests that the sanctity of synagogues and study houses, as well as their homes, accompanied them into the Promised Land, signifying a lasting spiritual legacy. The text highlights the importance of these sacred spaces in fostering holiness, purity, and the transmission of Torah, ultimately linking them to the priestly and royal lineage within the Jewish tradition.

translation: And the king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, of whom the name of one was Shifra and the name of the second was Puah, it is fitting to understand the reason for the length of the wording, for it could have simply said to the Hebrew midwives, Shifra and Puah.
summary: The passage discusses the Egyptian king's address to the Hebrew midwives, Shifra and Puah, emphasizing the significance of their names and the deliberate choice of language. This reflects a deeper understanding of the roles of these midwives, symbolizing the nurturing and protective aspects of divine providence. The mention of their names serves to highlight the importance of individual identity and purpose within the broader narrative of redemption. Ultimately, it underscores the theme of faith and resilience in the face of oppression, illustrating how divine intervention often operates through seemingly ordinary individuals.

translation: They (the sages) expounded that Shifra, who improved her deeds before God, and Puah, who caused Israel to appear before God, and the question remains as to how, for this reason, His statement is related to them.

The text raises a question about the deeper meaning behind this connection and the implications of their actions in relation to divine favor. This reflects key Hasidic themes of the importance of individual righteousness and the impact of one's deeds on the divine relationship.

passage_content: ג) המילדות את האלקים ולא עשו כאשר דיבר אליהם מלך מצרים, בגמ' (סוטה י"א ע"ב) כאשר דיבר אליהם להן מבעי' לי' אר"י בר חנינא מלמד שתבען לדבר עבירה ולא נתבעו, וצ"ב דאין זה מענין הגזירה, ומדוע רמז הכתוב ע"ז כאן, גם הקשה היפ"ת שהוא דבר שהשכל מנגדו , דהרי יוכבד היתה אז בת ק"ל שנה ואיך יתבע אותה פרעה מלך מצרים, ומרים היתה בת ה' שנים ואין סברא שיתבע אותה והיא עדיין ילדה, גם דרשו רז"ל (שם י"ב ע"א) עזובה זו מרים ולמה נקרא שמה עזובה שהכל עזבוה ולא רצו לישא אותה, ואיך יובן שהמלך דייקא תבע אותה לדבר עבירה.
translation: 3) The midwives of the gods did not do as the king of Egypt spoke to them. In the Gemara (Sotah 11b), it is stated that when he spoke to them, it was necessary for Rabbi Yochanan ben Chanina to teach that they were compelled to transgress and were not held accountable. It is puzzling why this is related to the decree, and why the verse hints at this here. The Yefeh Toar also questions this, as it is something that contradicts reason; for Yocheved was then 130 years old, and how could Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, demand from her? And Miriam was five years old, and it is unreasonable that he would demand from her while she was still a child. Additionally, our Sages have taught (there, 12a) that "Azuvah" refers to Miriam, and why was she called Azuvah? Because everyone abandoned her and did not want to marry her. How can it be understood that the king specifically demanded her to transgress?
summary: The passage discusses the midwives who defied Pharaoh's orders, highlighting the tension between divine command and earthly authority. It raises questions about the nature of their actions, particularly regarding the age of Yocheved and Miriam, and the implications of their refusal to comply with immoral demands. The text emphasizes the concept of divine protection and moral integrity, suggesting that true righteousness may sometimes require standing against oppressive power, even when it seems illogical or impossible. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound spiritual strength found in adhering to one's ethical convictions in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ד) שהכניסו א"ע לסכנה ע"י שלא רצו לשמוע אליו, ולא היו מחוייבין מדינא למסור עצמן להריגה, וכמו שאמרו חכז"ל באסתר קרקע עולם היא. ומדוע מסרו נפשן, ובפרט שהי' תלוי בזה הצלת ישראל, דאפשר שאם היו נשמעין אליו הי' מבטל גזרתו לעשות רצונם, והובא בשו"ת נודע ביהודא ( מה"ת יו"ד סי' קס"א) מעשה באנשים ונשים שהלכו בדרך וקם עליהם ארכיליסטים עם חבורת ליסטים כמותו להרוג את כולם, ואשה אחת מהם השתדל עם ראש הלסטים בדברים עד שפתתו בחלקת לשונה ונבעלה לו, ועי"כ הצילה את בעלה עם כל הנפשות, והביא דעת גאונים דס"ל דשפיר עבדה להציל בזה נפשות ישראל, והנוב"י ז"ל מסיק לאיסור דלאו שפיר עבדה, דא"א ללמוד מאסתר שהזמינה עצמה לאחשורוש דשאני התם שהי' הצלת כל ישראל, אבל כשהיא אינה ממציאה עצמה לדבר רק תובעין אותה מודה גם הנוב"י שמותרת, א"כ קשה מדוע מסרו נפשן לקטלא , ובפרט שהי' תלוי בזה הצלת ישראל.
translation: 4) That they put themselves in danger by not wanting to listen to him, and they were not obligated by law to surrender themselves to be killed, as our sages said regarding Esther, "The world is a foundation." And why did they give up their lives, especially since the salvation of Israel depended on it? For it is possible that if they had listened to him, he would have annulled his decree to do their will. It is brought in the responsa of the Noda B'Yehuda (Yoreh De'ah, Siman 161) about men and women who were traveling on the road and were attacked by archers along with a group of robbers like them to kill them all. One woman among them pleaded with the head of the robbers with words until she seduced him with her charm and was violated by him, and thereby she saved her husband and all the souls. The opinion of the Geonim is brought that it is permissible to act in this way to save Jewish lives. However, the Noda B'Yehuda concludes that it is forbidden, as one cannot learn from Esther who presented herself to Ahasuerus, for there it was the salvation of all Israel. But when she does not present herself for this purpose, only when they demand her, the Noda B'Yehuda agrees that it is permitted. Therefore, it is difficult to understand why they gave up their lives, especially since the salvation of Israel depended on it.
summary: The passage discusses the dilemma faced by individuals who chose to sacrifice their lives rather than comply with a decree that threatened the Jewish people, despite not being legally obligated to do so. It references the story of Esther, highlighting the tension between self-preservation and the greater good of saving Israel. The text raises questions about the nature of sacrifice and the moral implications of risking one's life for the sake of communal salvation, ultimately emphasizing the profound commitment to Jewish survival and faith in divine intervention.

passage_content: ה) קשה ממה דאיתא בזוה"ק (פ' שמות ט"ו ע"א) כד חמא הקב"ה חדוותא סגיאה דהאי עלמא תתאה דאשתכלל כגוונא דלעילא , אמר דילמא ח"ו יתערבון בין שאר עממין, וישתאר פגימותא בכולהו עלמין, מה עביד קוב"ה טלטל לכולהו מהכא להכא , עד דנחתו למצרים למידר דיוריהון בעם קשי קדל , דמבזין נימוסיהון ומבזין להון לאתחתנא בהו ולאתערבא בהדייהו , וחשיבו להון עבדו, גוברין געלן בהון נוקבתא געלן בהון. עד דאשתכלל כלא בזרעא קדישא וכו' וכד נפקו נפקו זכאין קדישין דכתיב שבטי י"ה עדות לישראל, עכ"ל. הרי מבואר שהמצריים מיאנו להתחתן בישראל שהיו מאוסין ונבזים בעיניהם ואיך יצוייר שהמלך דייקא תבע אותם לדבר עבירה.
translation: 5) It is difficult regarding what is stated in the Zohar (Parashat Shemot 15a) that when the Holy One, blessed be He, saw the great joy of this lower world, which is included in the likeness of the upper world, He said, perhaps, Heaven forbid, they will intermingle with the other nations, and there will remain blemishes in all the worlds. What did the Holy One do? He moved them all from here to there, until they descended to Egypt to dwell among a stiff-necked people, who despised their customs and looked down upon them, to intermarry with them and to mingle with them, and they considered them as servants, and they were taken by them, and they were taken by them. Until all were included in the holy seed, etc., and when they went out, the holy ones went out, as it is written, "The tribes of YH are a testimony to Israel." Thus it is clear that the Egyptians refused to marry the Israelites, who were despicable and contemptible in their eyes, and how could it be imagined that the king specifically demanded them to commit a transgression.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the divine concern that the Jewish people might become assimilated among the nations, leading to spiritual degradation. To prevent this, God orchestrated events that brought the Israelites to Egypt, where they were viewed as lowly and despised, thus preserving their distinct identity. The text emphasizes that despite the Egyptians' disdain, the Jewish people remained pure and were ultimately redeemed, highlighting the significance of their holy lineage and the divine protection over them. This reflects a key Hasidic theme of the importance of maintaining spiritual integrity amidst external challenges.

passage_content: ו) קשה על דברי הזוה"ק מכמה מאמרי חכמז"ל שמגדילין זכותן של ישראל במה שהיו גדורין בעריות במצרים ולא נתערבו עמהם, ולפי דברי הזוה"ק המצריים לא רצו להתערב עמהם א"כ לא הי' לישראל נסיון בדבר.
translation: It is difficult regarding the words of the Zohar based on several teachings of our Sages, of blessed memory, who emphasize the merit of Israel in that they were guarded from immorality in Egypt and did not intermingle with them. According to the words of the Zohar, the Egyptians did not wish to intermingle with them; therefore, Israel did not have a trial in this matter.
summary: The passage discusses a tension between the Zohar's interpretation and the teachings of the sages regarding the moral conduct of the Israelites in Egypt. It highlights that the Israelites maintained their purity and did not engage in immoral behavior, which is seen as a significant merit. However, the Zohar suggests that the Egyptians did not desire to intermingle with the Israelites, raising questions about the nature of the Israelites' trials. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine providence, human agency, and the challenges faced by the Jewish people.

passage_content: ז) מלך מצרים למילדות וגו' ותאמרן המילדות לפרעה כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנה בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת וילדו, יל"ד מה צורך להקדמה זו לא כנשים המצריות העבריות, ויספיק בטענה זו כי חיות הנה בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת וילדו, ומדוע הוצרכו להוסיף בטענה זו לא כנשים המצריות וגו', ותו קשה איך יכלו להכחיש המציאות ולומר שהעבריות אינן צריכין מילדות הרי ידע פרעה דזה הי' אומנות שלהם ולטעם זה קרא להן ואיך יכלו להכחיש את הידוע.
translation: 7) The king of Egypt said to the midwives, etc. And the midwives said to Pharaoh, "Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women, for they are vigorous; before the midwife comes to them, they give birth." What is the need for this introduction, "not like the Egyptian women"? It would suffice with the claim that "they are vigorous; before the midwife comes to them, they give birth." And why did they need to add to this claim, "not like the Egyptian women," etc.? Furthermore, it is difficult how they could deny reality and say that the Hebrew women do not need midwives, for Pharaoh knew that this was their profession, and for this reason, he called them. How could they deny what was known?
summary: The passage discusses the Hebrew midwives' response to Pharaoh, emphasizing their assertion that Hebrew women are vigorous and give birth before the midwives arrive. This raises questions about the necessity of distinguishing Hebrew women from Egyptian women and how the midwives could deny the need for their services, given Pharaoh's awareness of their role. Theological insights suggest a deeper understanding of divine providence and the strength of the Hebrew women, reflecting a theme of faith and resilience in the face of oppression. The midwives' cleverness in navigating Pharaoh's decree highlights the interplay between human agency and divine intervention.

passage_content: ח) בילדכן את העבריות וראיתן על האבנים אם בן הוא והמיתן אותו ואם בת היא וחי', הקשה האוהחה"ק וז"ל, צל"ד טעמו למה לא גזר על הכל , ואין להאמין עליו כי במדת הרחמים נהג לשום להם שארית בארץ, כי שורשו שורש אכזרי הוא, עוד למה הוצרך לומר ואם בת הוא וחי', כיון שפרעה לא גזר אלא על הזכרים פשיטא שלא יבקשו המילדות לעקור את הכל , ותירץ דרשע זה נתחכם כדי שתעלה בידו העצה, כי מי זאת האשה אשר תזמין עצמה למילדת להרוג בניה, לזה נתחכם ואמר להם שיתנהגו בסדר זה ויעשו בהעלם דבר, ולא ירגישו היולדות וכו' עכ"ל, ובאמת קושיא זו מתורץ במד"ר עה"פ וכל הבת תחיון מה צורך לפרעה לקיים הנקבות, אלא כך היו אומרים נמית הזכרים ונקח הנקבות לנשים, לפי שהיו המצריים שטופים בזימה, ופלא שהאוהחה"ק לא הביא מדרש זה, והנה מזה המדרש יקשה על דברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל דמזה מוכח שרצו להתערב עם ישראל, ולפי דברי הזוה"ק לא שייך טעם זה שהרי היו מאוסין בעיניהם ולא רצו להתחתן בהם כלל.
translation: (8) When you give birth to the Hebrew women and see on the stones if it is a son, you shall kill him; and if it is a daughter, she shall live. The holy teacher asked, and said: What is the reason that he did not decree upon all? And it cannot be believed that he acted with mercy to leave them a remnant in the land, for his root is a cruel root. Furthermore, why did he need to say, "and if it is a daughter, she shall live," since Pharaoh only decreed against the males? It is obvious that the midwives would not seek to uproot everything. And he answered that this wicked one was clever in order to devise a plan, for who is this woman who would volunteer as a midwife to kill her children? Therefore, he devised that they should act in this manner and do it secretly, so that the mothers would not notice, etc. Thus far his words. And indeed, this question is answered in the Midrash on the verse "And every daughter shall live." What need did Pharaoh have to preserve the females? Rather, they would say, "We will kill the males and take the females for wives," because the Egyptians were immersed in immorality. It is wondrous that the holy teacher did not bring this Midrash, and behold, from this Midrash it is difficult on the words of the Zohar mentioned above, for it is evident that they wanted to intermingle with Israel, and according to the words of the Zohar, this reason does not apply, for they were repulsive in their eyes and did not want to marry them at all.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's decree against Hebrew male infants, questioning why he did not extend this decree to females and suggesting that his intent was to cunningly manipulate the midwives into compliance. It highlights the tension between mercy and cruelty, emphasizing that Pharaoh's actions stemmed from a cruel nature despite a facade of mercy. The text also references a Midrash that suggests the Egyptians desired to take Hebrew females as wives, contrasting with the Zohar's assertion that the Egyptians found the Hebrews repulsive and had no interest in intermarriage. This reflects deeper themes of identity, survival, and the complexities of divine providence in the face of oppression.

passage_content: ואפשר ליישב קושיא זו עפ"י פשוטו עפי"מ דמבואר במדרש פ' בא (פ' י"ד ס"ג) שהיו פושעים בישראל שהי' להן פטרונין מן המצריים, והי' להם עושר וכבוד, ולא היו רוצים לצאת וכו' לפיכך הביא על המצריים חושך ג' ימים כדי שיהיו קוברין מתיהם ולא יהיו רואין אותם שונאיהם עכ"ד המדרש, ומבואר בדברי רז"ל שהיו מרובין על ישראל הכשרים כמו שפרש"י עה"פ וחמשים עלו בנ"י , אחד מחמשה יצאו ממצרים והשאר נשארו שם לחד דעה בגמרא א' מחמשים. ונחד מ"ד א' מס' רבוא יצאו והשאר נשארו שם, ולכאורה הרי לפי דברי הזוה"ק היו שפלים ונבזים בעיניהם והאיך עשו אותם פטרונין , וצ"ל שאותם הפושעים לא היו מאוסין בעיניהם, לפי שהתדמו להם בכל עניניהם והלכו בדרכיהם אכלו מפיתם ושתו מיינם ועי"ז נעשו פטרונים, משא"כ בנ"י הכשרים שלא שינו שמם ואת לשונם ולא רצו להדמות להם הם היו נבזים ושפלים בעיניהם ולפי"ז אתי שפיר דשניהם אמת, דאותם שהיו פטרונים הם היו חשובים בעיני המצריים ועמהם היו רוצים להתחתן, וא"ש דברי המדרש שלטעם זה צוה להחיות הנקבות לפי שהיו המצריים שטופי זמה , דגזירת אם בן הוא והמיתן אותו הי' נוהג בכלם כי לא ידעו אצל מי נולד מושיען של ישראל, ומ"ש בזוה"ק שהיו ישראל נבזים ושפלים בעיניהם הכוונה על אותם שלא רצו להתדמות לדרכי המצריים, ושפיר מתייחס הזכות לישראל מה שהיו גדורים מן העריות, ואף שהמצריים מאסו בהון, אבל זה בא ע"י בחירתם הטובה, דהרי הי' לכולם עצה זו להדמות להם ויהיו חשובים בעיני המצריים ועל שעמדו בנסיון נחשב להם לזכות גדול מה שהיו גדורין מן העריות.
translation: It is possible to resolve this question according to its simple meaning based on what is explained in the Midrash Parashat Bo (Parashat 14, Section 63) that there were sinners in Israel who had patrons from the Egyptians, and they had wealth and honor, and they did not want to leave, etc. Therefore, He brought upon the Egyptians darkness for three days so that they would be burying their dead and their enemies would not see them, thus concludes the Midrash. It is explained in the words of our Sages that they were numerous compared to the righteous Israelites, as Rashi explains on the verse "And fifty went up from the children of Israel," one out of five went out of Egypt and the rest remained there, according to one opinion in the Gemara, one out of fifty. And according to another opinion, one out of five hundred went out and the rest remained there. And at first glance, according to the words of the Zohar, they were lowly and despicable in their eyes, so how did they make them patrons? It must be that those sinners were not despised in their eyes, for they resembled them in all their matters and walked in their ways, ate from their bread, and drank their wine, and through this, they became patrons. In contrast, the righteous Israelites did not change their names or their language and did not want to resemble them; they were despised and lowly in their eyes. According to this, it comes out well that both are true, that those who were patrons were considered important in the eyes of the Egyptians, and they wanted to marry them. And this explains the words of the Midrash that for this reason He commanded to keep the females alive because the Egyptians were immersed in immorality, for the decree was that if a son was born, the one who killed him acted in this manner with all of them because they did not know where the savior of Israel was born. And what is stated in the Zohar that the Israelites were despicable and lowly in their eyes refers to those who did not want to resemble the ways of the Egyptians. And it is fitting to attribute the merit to Israel for being guarded from immorality, and even though the Egyptians despised wealth, this came about through their good choice, for indeed, all of them had this advice to resemble them and be important in the eyes of the Egyptians, and for standing firm in the test, it is considered a great merit for them that they were guarded from immorality.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the righteous Israelites and the sinful ones who assimilated into Egyptian culture, gaining status and wealth. It highlights that those who chose to remain faithful to their identity and values, despite being viewed as lowly by the Egyptians, were ultimately rewarded for their integrity. The text emphasizes the importance of maintaining one's spiritual and moral boundaries, suggesting that true honor comes from adherence to divine principles rather than societal acceptance. This choice to resist assimilation is portrayed as a significant merit for the righteous, contrasting their fate with that of the assimilated Israelites.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר בהקדם דברי העטרת חכמים בהקדמתו וז"ל, וכל המרבה לספר ביציאת מצרים הרי זה משובח, כאן הראה בעל המגיד עוצם כוחו להגדיל הנס של סיפור יצי"מ ופתאום הננו כסותר את דבריו, ומביא ראיות להקטין הנס של יצי"מ , לבעבור שהי' לנו כמה ניסים אחרים גדולים יותר, באמרו צא ולמד מה בקש לבן הארמי לעשות שפרעה לא גזר אלא על הזכרים ולבן בקש לעקור את הכל , וליישב דברי בעל הגדה, בהקדם לבאר דברי הפסוק לכה נא אתי אל מקום אחר, לכאורה מה ראה בלק תועלת במקום אחר, אולם יוכל להיות, אחרי שראה בלק שלא הי' ביד בלעם לקלל את ישראל, חשב בדעתו אולי הוא מפאת שלא הי' בידו לקלל בשום קללה אחרת זולת בתיבת "כלם" כמאמר הגמרא אל זועם בכל יום, וכמה זעמו רגע, ובתוס ' כתבו שבלעם לא הי' יכול לומר בשעה מועטת כזאת רק תיבת כלם, וקללה כזו מבלתי אפשרי שיחול על ישראל, כי השי"ת הבטיח לאבותינו שלא לעשות עמנו כלה, לכן הערים בלק לומר לבלעם לכה נא אתי אל מקום אחר וכו' וכולו לא תראה וכו' כוונתו בזה, אולי כשישים את נפשו לקלל רק מקצת ישראל, יהי' מקום שיחול קללתו, ועתה מובן דכוונת המגיד גם בזה להגדיל הנס של יצי"מ על כל שארי הניסים, כי אף שבכל דור ודור עומדים עלינו לכלותינו, אין בזה רבותא כ"כ שהקב"ה מצילנו מידם: בעבור שהבטיח לנו שלא לכלותינו, אבל פרעה שלא גזר רק על הזכרים, והי' מקום שיקויים גזירתו, לכן הנס שעשה הקב"ה והציל אותנו מיד פרעה, הי' גדול יותר מכל הניסים האחרים עכ"ל. ובזה יובן מדוע הוכרח פרעה לומר אם בת היא וחי' דאם הי' גוזר על כולם להמית, לא הי' מקום להתקיים גזירתו שהרי כלי' א"א להיות, ופרעה השיג דבר זה, וע"כ הוצרך לומר אם בת היא וחי', ומתורץ קושית האוהחה"ק .
translation: And I can also explain in another way, by prefacing the words of the crown of sages in his introduction, and he said: "Whoever increases the telling of the Exodus from Egypt, it is praiseworthy." Here, the Maggid demonstrated the strength of his power to magnify the miracle of the telling of the Exodus, and suddenly we find ourselves contradicting his words, bringing proofs to diminish the miracle of the Exodus, because we had several other miracles that were greater, by saying: "Go and learn what the Aramean wanted to do, that Pharaoh only decreed against the males, while the Aramean wanted to uproot everything." And to reconcile the words of the owner of the Haggadah, we must first explain the words of the verse: "Come now, let us go to another place." At first glance, what did he see that was of benefit in another place? However, it could be that after he saw that Balaam was unable to curse Israel, he thought to himself that perhaps it was because he was unable to curse with any other curse except for the word "all of them," as the Gemara states: "He is angry every day," and how much did he rage for a moment. And in the Tosefta, it is written that Balaam could not say in such a short time anything other than the word "all of them," and such a curse cannot possibly take effect on Israel, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised our forefathers not to destroy us completely. Therefore, Balak devised to say to Balaam: "Come now, let us go to another place," etc., and "you will not see" etc. His intention in this was that perhaps if he puts his soul into cursing only part of Israel, there would be a place where his curse could take effect. And now it is understood that the intention of the Maggid in this is also to magnify the miracle of the Exodus over all other miracles, for even though in every generation they rise up against us to annihilate us, there is not so much of a wonder that the Holy One, Blessed be He, saves us from their hands, because He promised us not to annihilate us. But Pharaoh, who only decreed against the males, had a place where his decree could be fulfilled; therefore, the miracle that the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed and saved us from Pharaoh was greater than all the other miracles. Thus, it is understood why Pharaoh was compelled to say: "If she is a daughter, she will live," for if he had decreed to kill everyone, there would be no place for his decree to be fulfilled, since annihilation cannot be. And Pharaoh understood this, and therefore he had to say: "If she is a daughter, she will live," and the question of the holy author is resolved.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the miracles surrounding the Exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that while there are many great miracles, the deliverance from Pharaoh's decree was uniquely profound. It highlights that Pharaoh's limited decree against only the male children created a potential for his plan to succeed, making God's intervention more remarkable. The text also reflects on the idea that God's promise to the patriarchs ensures that Israel cannot be completely destroyed, thus elevating the miracle of the Exodus above other miracles. Ultimately, it underscores the theological concept that divine protection is particularly evident in the face of threats that could have led to total annihilation.
