passage_content: או"י עפ"י המבואר בדברינו לעיל שאותן ס' רבוא ילדים שהושלכו ליאור עם משה רבינו הם היו אותן ס' רבוא שעמדו במעמד הנבחר לקבל את התוה"ק , שחזרו בגלגוליהם לעוה"ז, ועל כי היו אותן הנשמות בעצמן העתידים לקבל התוה"ק , השגיחו עליהם מן השמים בשמירה יתירה שלא יארע להם שום קלקול ופגם, כמבואר בדברי חכמז"ל שהרבה ניסים נעשה להם שהים פלט אותם למדבר וניזונו בדרך נס כחיות השדה, ועד"ז היתה מענת המילדת לפרעה שלא תועיל בעצתך הזה כלום, כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנה, ואף אם תכריח אותנו להרוג את הילדים בשעת לידתן לא תתקיים גזירתך כי בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת וילדו, פי' שיארע להם נס וינצלו ע"י שיוקדם לידתן בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת , ולא היתה כוונתם לומר שהעבריות א"צ למילדות לעולם כי לא יכלו להכחיש המציאות שהם היו מילדות נשי ישראל וזה אומנתם, אלא שאמרו לו שלא יועיל גזירתו כלום, כי הם מושגחים בפרטיות מן השמים ואם תגזור להרוג ילדיהם יולידו בטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת , וכמו שנמשלו לחיות השדה בשאר ענינים שנתגדלו במדבר וניזונו שלא כדרך הטבע כמו חיות השדה, כמו"כ יתדמו לחיות בענין זה שלא יהיו צריכין מילדות ובטרם תבוא אליהן המילדת וילדו.
translation: According to what we have explained above, those six hundred thousand children who were cast into the river with Moshe Rabbeinu were the same six hundred thousand who stood at the chosen moment to receive the Torah. They returned in their reincarnations to this world, and because those souls themselves were destined to receive the Torah, they were watched over from the heavens with special protection so that no blemish or defect would occur to them. As explained in the words of our Sages, many miracles were performed for them: the sea expelled them into the desert, and they were sustained in a miraculous way like the beasts of the field. Similarly, the midwife's response to Pharaoh was that your counsel would not help at all, for the Hebrew women are like animals; and even if you force us to kill the children at the time of their birth, your decree will not be fulfilled, for before the midwife comes to them, they will give birth. This means that a miracle will occur for them, and they will be saved by having their births occur before the midwife arrives. Their intention was not to say that the Hebrew women do not need midwives at all, for they could not deny the reality that they were midwives for the women of Israel, and this was their profession. Rather, they told him that his decree would not help at all, for they are specifically watched over from the heavens, and if you decree to kill their children, they will give birth before the midwife comes to them. Just as they were compared to the beasts of the field in other matters, having grown in the desert and being sustained in a way that is not natural like the beasts of the field, so too they would resemble beasts in this matter, that they would not need midwives, and before the midwife comes to them, they will give birth.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual significance of the 600,000 children thrown into the Nile during the time of Moses, asserting that they were the same souls destined to receive the Torah. It emphasizes that these souls were under divine protection, ensuring they would not suffer any harm, as evidenced by the miracles that occurred for them, such as being nourished in the wilderness like wild animals. The midwives' defiance of Pharaoh's decree is portrayed as a reflection of their unique spiritual status, indicating that divine intervention would allow the Hebrew women to give birth before the midwives could arrive, thus safeguarding the children. This highlights the theme of divine providence and the special relationship between the Jewish people and God.

passage_content: במדרש (הובא בישמח משה) בשביל שראו אבותיו של משה תוארו כמלאך אלקים , מלו אותו לשמנה עכ"ד המדרש והוא פלאי, ויתבאר בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה ( בפ ' לך) לפרש דברי הגמרא (ברכות י' ע"ב) חתן פטור מק"ש וכו ', ומעשה בר' גמליאל שנשא אשה וקרא וכו ', ולכאורה קשה על ר' גמליאל האיך החמיר על עצמו במה שפטרתו התורה להדיא , ואין בו שום חולק, והלא על כזה אמרי' דהפטור מן הדבר ועושהו נקרא הדיוט וכו' גם קשה על מה שדרשו רז"ל בגמ' שם ובלכתך בדרך פרט לעוסק במצוה , מאי משמע, בשבת דידך ובלכת דידך הוא דמחייבת הא דמצוה פטירת, דנראה מזה דצורכי הגוף הוי שלו משא"כ דבר מצוה, ואדרבה נהפוך הוא לפי האמת וכו' שצורכי הגוף אינו שלו, כענין זה שיש לו אינו שלו, משא"כ צורכי הנפש וכו' ההליכה הוא שלו לעדי עד, וקנו למעלה במקום שאין היד שולטת בו, וא"כ אדרבה זאת נקראת הליכתו, עוד הקשה דבכ"מ דאמרינן דברה תורה בלשון בנ"א צ"ב, דאיך בתורת אמת יעדר האמת, והנ"ל לבאר דרך כלל בכל מקום וכו ', דהתוה"ק ניתן לכל המון ישראל וכו' וכולל כ"א לפי מדריגתו וכו ', דהנה יש בנ"א שהם בעלי הנפש ונפשם עיקר והם בני עלי', משא"כ ההמון הם בעלי חומר ומלאכתם עיקר, והנה אצלם יקרא צורכי הגוף צרכם בלא שם לווי, והם בעצמם לשונם כך, משא"כ צרכי הנפש, ולהיפך בבעלי הנפש, וא"כ אלו ההמון פטרה התורה וכו' משא"כ בבני עלי', וא"כ מדבר לכל אחד לפי מדריגתו וכו' והיינו כלשון בני אדם והבן, רק פשט הדין על הרוב ידבר וכו ', וזה תשובת ר"ג איני שומע לכם לבטל הימנו, הימנו דייקא , עייש"ד כי נעמו .
translation: In the Midrash (brought in Yismach Moshe), it is stated that because Moses' ancestors saw his appearance as that of an angel of God, they circumcised him on the eighth day, as the Midrash says, and this is wondrous. It will be explained by first clarifying the words of K"Z in Yismach Moshe, z"l (in Parashat Lech), to interpret the words of the Gemara (Berakhot 10b) that a groom is exempt from the Shema, etc., and the story of Rabbi Gamliel who married a woman and read, etc. At first glance, it is difficult to understand how Rabbi Gamliel was stringent upon himself in a matter from which the Torah explicitly exempts him, and there is no dissenting opinion. For concerning such a case, it is said that one who is exempt from a matter and performs it is called a commoner, etc. It is also difficult regarding what our Sages derived in the Gemara there, "and when you walk on the way" specifically for one engaged in a mitzvah. What does this mean? On your Sabbath and in your walking, it is that which obligates the mitzvah to exempt, for it seems from this that bodily needs are his, unlike matters of mitzvah. On the contrary, according to the truth, bodily needs are not his, as in the matter that what he has is not his, unlike the needs of the soul, etc. The walking is his forever, and he acquires above in a place where the hand does not rule. Therefore, on the contrary, this is called his walking. Furthermore, it is difficult that wherever we say the Torah speaks in the language of human beings, it is puzzling how in the Torah of truth the truth would be absent. The above is to explain generally everywhere, etc., that the Holy Torah was given to the entire multitude of Israel, etc., and includes each person according to his level, etc. For there are human beings who are masters of the soul, and their soul is primary, and they are the sons of Eli, while the masses are materialistic, and their work is primary. And among them, bodily needs are called their needs without a name of accompaniment, and they themselves speak this way, unlike the needs of the soul, and conversely among the masters of the soul. Therefore, these masses are exempted by the Torah, etc., unlike the sons of Eli. Thus, it speaks to each one according to his level, etc., and this is in the language of human beings, and understand. Only the simple law will speak for the majority, etc. And this is Rabbi Gamliel's response: I do not listen to you to exempt him, specifically from him, as it is written, "for it is pleasant."
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the spiritual and physical needs of individuals, emphasizing that while the Torah provides exemptions for certain obligations, these are context-dependent based on one's spiritual level. It highlights that for those who are spiritually elevated, like the "Bnei Ali," their primary focus is on the needs of the soul, whereas the general populace prioritizes physical needs. The text illustrates that the Torah speaks in a manner relatable to all, addressing each according to their spiritual status, and underscores the importance of personal commitment to spiritual obligations despite exemptions. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper connection between one's actions and their spiritual essence.

passage_content: והנה הך הלכתא דהעוסק במצוה פטור מן המצוה ילפינן מקרא בשבתך ובלכתך כמבואר בגמ' הנ"ל, ובסוכה (כ"ה ע"ב) אמרז"ל דאיכא עוד ילפותא מהפסוק ולא יכלו לעשות הפסח ביום ההוא, ותרווייהו צריכי עיי"ש, נמצא לדעת דלולא האי קרא א"א למפטר העוסק במצוה , ולפי"ד ק"ז זלה"ה לבני עלי' ליכא קרא למפטרינהו בעוסק במצוה , דלפי מדריגתם ובחי' לשונם עסק המצוה יקרא אצלם שבת דידך ולכת דידך ומחייבי, ובזה יתבאר לנו דברי הגמרא נדרים (ל"א ע"ב) תניא ריב"ק אומר גדולה מילה שכל זכיות שעשה משה רבינו לא עמדו לו כשנתרשל מן המילה שנא' ויפגשהו ה' ויבקש המיתו: אמר ר"י ח"ו שמשה רבינו נתרשל מן המילה, אלא כך אמר אמול ואצא סכנה היא שנא' ויהי ביום השלישי בהיותם כואבים וגו', אמול ואשהא ג' ימים, הקב"ה אמר לי לך שוב מצרימה, אלא מפני מה נענש משה מפני שנתעסק במלון תחילה, ופי' רש"י ור"ן דהי ' לו להתעסק במילה תחלה, דאותו מלון סמוך למצרים הי' ובאורחא פורתא ליכא סכנה עכ"ד ז"ל, ולכאורה לפי"ז מאי הי' ס"ד דמשרע"ה שלא נזדרז במילתו כיון דליכא חשש סכנה: גם לפירושם דברי ר' יוסי סותרים זא"ז , במ"ש כך אמר משה אמול ואצא סכנה היא וכו ', אמול ואשהא ג' ימים, הקב"ה אמר לי לך שוב מצרימה, ולבסוף סיים מפני מה נענש משה מפני שנתעסק במלון תחלה, ולא הי' חשש סכנה כלל דהי ' המלון קרובה למצרים, וא"כ נתבטלו ב' הטענות הנ"ל דלא הי' צורך להמתין ג' ימים ולא הי' סכנה אף אם יצא לדרך מיד. ואפ"ל כי חש משרע"ה לטעם דהעוסק במצוה פטור מן המצוה שהקב"ה צוהו לך שוב מצרימה והנה בכל מילה איכא סכנתא , כמו שדרשו ז"ל כי עליך הורגנו כל היום זו מילה, וכתב החת"ס זלה"ה דחזינן דאפי ' א' מני אלף אינו מת מחמת המילה, אלא דהמצוה מגינא ומצלת עייש"ד , נמצא לפי"ז היכא דליתא חיובא דמצוה , חזרה חששת סכנה למקומה, וע"כ אף דבאורחא פורתא ליתא לסכנה כמ"ש רש"י והתוס ' ז"ל, אבל בכה"ג דפטור מן המצוה מטעם העוסק במצוה חש משרע"ה לסכנתא , ואפשר דאעפ"כ נענש דלפי מדריגת קדושתו עסק המצוה יקרא צרכו ובלכת דידך וכו' והוי בגדר חיובא , ובכח המצו' להיות מגינא ומצלת מן הסכנה והי"ל להתעסק במילה תחלה.
translation: And behold, this halacha that one who is engaged in a mitzvah is exempt from another mitzvah, we learn from the verse "when you sit" and "when you walk," as explained in the aforementioned Gemara, and in Sukkah (25b) our sages said that there is another teaching from the verse "and they could not perform the Passover on that day," and both are necessary, as explained there. It turns out that without this verse, one cannot exempt the one engaged in a mitzvah. According to the opinion of K'z, there is no verse to exempt them from being engaged in a mitzvah, for according to their level and the nature of their language, the engagement in the mitzvah is called "your Sabbath" and "your walking," and they are obligated. And with this, we can clarify the words of the Gemara in Nedarim (31b): It was taught that Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai says that circumcision is great, for all the merits that Moshe Rabbeinu did did not stand for him when he neglected the circumcision, as it is said, "and the Lord met him and sought to kill him." Rabbi Yochanan said, Heaven forbid that Moshe Rabbeinu neglected the circumcision, rather he said, "I will circumcise and I will delay; it is a danger," as it is said, "and it was on the third day when they were in pain," etc. "I will circumcise and I will delay three days; the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to me, 'Go, return to Egypt.'" But why was Moshe punished? Because he was engaged in the inn first. And Rashi and the Ran explain that he should have engaged in the circumcision first, for that inn was close to Egypt, and on the way, there was little danger. Thus far, their words. And at first glance, according to this, what was Moshe's thought that he did not hasten with his circumcision since there was no concern for danger? Also, according to their explanation, the words of Rabbi Yosi contradict each other, in saying, "Thus said Moshe, 'I will circumcise and I will delay; it is a danger,' etc. 'I will circumcise and I will delay three days; the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to me, 'Go, return to Egypt.'" And in the end, he concluded, "Why was Moshe punished? Because he was engaged in the inn first," and there was no concern for danger at all, for the inn was close to Egypt. And if so, the two claims mentioned above are nullified: there was no need to wait three days, and there was no danger even if he set out immediately. And it can be said that Moshe was concerned about the reason that one engaged in a mitzvah is exempt from the mitzvah, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded him to go back to Egypt, and behold, in every circumcision there is danger, as our sages have taught, "For you are being killed all day long; this is circumcision." And the Chasam Sofer wrote that we see that even one in a thousand does not die because of the circumcision, rather the mitzvah protects and saves. Therefore, according to this, where there is no obligation of a mitzvah, the concern for danger returns to its place. And therefore, even though on the way there is little danger, as Rashi and the Tosafot wrote, in such a case where one is exempt from the mitzvah due to being engaged in a mitzvah, Moshe was concerned about danger. And it is possible that nevertheless he was punished because according to the level of his holiness, the engagement in the mitzvah is called "your need" and "your walking," etc., and it is within the realm of obligation, and the power of the mitzvot is to be a protector and a savior from danger, and he should have engaged in the circumcision first.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that one engaged in a mitzvah (commandment) is exempt from other mitzvot, as derived from scriptural sources. It highlights the case of Moses, who was punished for prioritizing lodging over the circumcision of his son, illustrating the importance of fulfilling mitzvot promptly. The text emphasizes that even in situations where there seems to be no immediate danger, the obligation to perform a mitzvah takes precedence, reflecting a deeper understanding of divine command and the protective nature of mitzvot. Ultimately, it suggests that the sanctity and urgency of mitzvot are paramount, especially for individuals of high spiritual stature.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה בפ ' זו דמשרע"ה נולד בשבת, וראייתו מדברי הש"ס עיי"ש, נמצא שחל מילתו בשמיני ביום השבת, ודרשו רז"ל במדרש (שמו"ר פ"א סי' כ"ד) עה"פ ותרא אותו כי טוב שמרע"ה נולד מהול, ובגמ' שבת (קל"ה ע"א) פליגי ב"ש וב"ה בנולד מהול אם צריך להטיף ממנו דם ברית, ואם הטפת בריתו דוחה שבת, ומסקנת דברי הגמ ' שם דלא נחלקו ב"ש וב"ה בדבר זה, ולהלכה אין מחללין את השבת בנולד מהול, אולם במד"ר ר"פ תצא ובירושלמי יבמות (ר"פ הערל) אמרז"ל דתינוק שנולד מהול חייב למולו מן התורה שנא' המול ימול, ודריש בי' המול כבר שנולד כך יהא נמול, ומאחר שחייב למולו מה"ת דוחה את השבת עיי"ש בדברי המפרשים ז"ל, אמנם בגמ' ע"ז (דף כ"ז ע"א) איכא למ"ד דליכא למילף מהמול ימול שום דרשא דדברה תורה כלשון בנ"א, ובירושלמי הנ"ל נמי פליגי בהא ר"ע ור' ישמעאל, דר"ע ס"ל די לשונות ריבויין הן, פי' כל לשונות כפולין שבמקרא אתיין לדרשא : ור' ישמעאל ס"ל דו לשונות כפולין הן, התורה דיברה כדרכה פי' כדרך לשון בנ"א, ולפי"ד המול ימול לית לן למילף מיני' מידי עיי"ש, ולפי"ז לית לן ילפותא לנולד מהול דחייב למולו ולחלל שבת על מילתו, ואפשר דאבותיו של משרע"ה היו מסופקים בהך הלכתא, אם נולד מהול חייב למולו שנא' המול ימול, או אמרי' דברה תורה בלשון בנ"א וליכא למילף מהמול ימול מידי, או אפשר שחששו לטעם הסכנה, דאם אמרינן נולד מהול אין חייב למולו , א"כ אין המצוה מגנת , ובכל מילה איכא סכנתא כנ"ל, אבל בשביל שראו תוארו כמלאך אלקים , ובבני עלי' לא דברה תורה כלשון בנ"א ההמונים למכפל בכדי, וע"כ לדרשא אתיא ונלמד מינה דחייב למולו וא"כ ליכא סכנא וגם מחללין את השבת וע"כ מלו אותו לשמונה בשבת דייקא , אבל פשטות הדין על הרוב ידבר, ולפי מדריגתם דיברה תורה בלשון בנ"א, וע"כ לענין הלכתא בסתם בנ"א אין מחללין את השבת בכה"ג כמ"ש בגמרא דשבת הנ"ל, ויתבאר לדרכינו דברי המדרש הנ"ל.
translation: And we will also precede with what is mentioned in K'z (Kitzur) of the holy Rabbi Yisrael Meir Kagan in this section that Moshe Rabbeinu was born on Shabbat, and his proof is from the words of the Talmud, as mentioned there. It is found that his circumcision fell on the eighth day, which was on Shabbat, and our Sages expounded in the Midrash (Bereishit Rabbah, Parashat 1, Section 24) on the verse "And she saw that he was good" that Moshe Rabbeinu was born circumcised. And in the Gemara Shabbat (135a), there is a dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel regarding a child born circumcised, whether he needs to have blood drawn from him for the covenant, and whether the drawing of his covenant would override Shabbat. The conclusion of the Gemara there is that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree on this matter, and according to halacha, one does not desecrate Shabbat for a child born circumcised. However, in the Midrash, Parashat Tetzaveh, and in the Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot (Parashat HaOral), our Sages said that a child born circumcised is obligated to be circumcised according to the Torah, as it is stated "the one who is circumcised shall be circumcised," and it is interpreted that since he was born this way, he shall be circumcised. And since he is obligated to be circumcised according to the Torah, it overrides Shabbat, as explained there by the commentators. However, in the Gemara Avodah Zarah (27a), there is an opinion that one cannot derive any teaching from "the one who is circumcised shall be circumcised," as the Torah spoke in the language of human beings. And in the aforementioned Jerusalem Talmud, there is also a dispute between Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael, as Rabbi Akiva holds that these are expressions of abundance, meaning all expressions that are doubled in the Scripture come for teaching. And Rabbi Yishmael holds that the expressions are doubled, the Torah spoke in its way, meaning in the manner of human language, and according to his opinion, "the one who is circumcised shall be circumcised" does not provide us with any teaching. Therefore, according to this, we do not have a teaching for a child born circumcised that he is obligated to be circumcised and to desecrate Shabbat for his circumcision. And it is possible that the ancestors of Moshe Rabbeinu were in doubt about this halacha, whether a child born circumcised is obligated to be circumcised, as it is stated "the one who is circumcised shall be circumcised," or do we say that the Torah spoke in the language of human beings and we cannot derive anything from "the one who is circumcised shall be circumcised." Or it is possible that they were concerned for the reason of danger, that if we say a child born circumcised is not obligated to be circumcised, then the commandment does not protect, and in every circumcision there is danger, as mentioned. But because they saw his form as an angel of God, and regarding the children of Eli, the Torah did not speak in the language of the common people to double for the sake of abundance, therefore it comes for teaching, and we learn from it that he is obligated to be circumcised, and thus there is no danger, and we desecrate Shabbat. Therefore, they circumcised him on the eighth day specifically on Shabbat. However, the simplicity of the law generally speaks, and according to their level, the Torah spoke in the language of human beings. Therefore, regarding halacha in general, one does not desecrate Shabbat in such a case, as stated in the aforementioned Gemara of Shabbat, and we will clarify according to our path the words of the aforementioned Midrash.
summary: The passage discusses the birth of Moses, who was born circumcised on Shabbat, and the implications of this for Jewish law regarding circumcision. It explores the debate between the schools of Hillel and Shammai on whether a circumcised newborn requires a bloodletting and whether this act can override Shabbat. The text emphasizes the theological significance of Moses's birth, suggesting that his angelic nature influenced the decision to circumcise him on the eighth day, even on Shabbat, while also reflecting on the broader principles of divine command and human interpretation in Jewish law. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between strict legal adherence and the recognition of unique circumstances in the context of holiness and divine purpose.

passage_content: ויהי בימים ההם ויגדל משה ויצא אל אחיו וירא בסבלותם וירא איש מצרי מכה איש עברי מאחיו, יל"ד על כפל מלת איש ב' פעמים, ויספיק לומר מצרי מכה עברי, ובכל מקום מלת איש לדרשה אתי' כמ"ש אין איש אלא משה, אין איש אלא הקב"ה ועוד בכ"מ וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: And it came to pass in those days that Moses grew up and went out to his brethren and saw their burdens, and he saw an Egyptian striking a Hebrew, one of his brethren. It is asked why the word "man" is mentioned twice, and it could have sufficed to say "an Egyptian striking a Hebrew." And in every place, the word "man" is brought for interpretation, as it is said, "there is no man but Moses," "there is no man but the Holy One, blessed be He," and so on in other places. The intention of this is questioned.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the repetition of the word "איש" (man) in the context of Moses witnessing the Egyptian beating the Hebrew emphasizes the unique significance of both Moses and God. The text suggests that "איש" refers not only to the individuals involved but also to a deeper connection to divine presence, indicating that Moses embodies a reflection of God's attributes. This duality highlights the idea that true humanity is intertwined with divine qualities, prompting further exploration of the implications of this relationship in the context of suffering and redemption.

passage_content: ב) צ"ב מ"ש מאחיו ובאומרו עברי ידענא שהוא מאחיו, ובאוהחה"ק פי' דקדק לומר מאחיו ירמוז כי הביט שהי' מהצדיקים שבישראל וכו ', ותמצא שכאשר אמר בסמוך ב' אנשים עברים נצים , לא אמר מאחיו לטעם שהיו רשעים כי הם דתן ואבירם עכ"ל, אמנם במד"ר (פ' א' ס"ס כ"ח) איתא שזה המוכה הי' דתן. והמצרי בא על אשתו של דתן שלומית בת דברי, ואחר שידע המצרי שהרגיש בו בעלה רצה להרגו , עיי"ש במפרשי המדרשים דיש רוצים למחוק אשתו של דתן, אולם בספרים שלפנינו כך הוא הגירסא , ולפי"ז הי' המוכה רשע וצ"ב מ"ש מאחיו.
translation: B) It is puzzling what is meant by "from his brothers" and in saying "Hebrew, we know he is from his brothers." In the holy teachings, it is emphasized to say "from his brothers" to hint that he looked to be one of the righteous among Israel, etc. You will find that when it was said shortly thereafter, "two Hebrew men were fighting," it did not say "from his brothers" for the reason that they were wicked, as they were Datan and Aviram, etc. However, in the Midrash Rabbah (Parashat 1, section 28), it is stated that the one who was struck was Datan. And the Egyptian came upon Datan's wife, Shlomit, the daughter of Divri, and after the Egyptian realized that her husband was aware of him, he wanted to kill him. See there in the commentaries on the Midrashim; some wish to erase the mention of Datan's wife, but in the texts before us, this is the version, and according to this, the one who was struck was wicked, and it is puzzling what is meant by "from his brothers."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of identifying the Hebrew as "his brother," emphasizing the connection to the righteous among Israel. It contrasts this with the mention of Datan and Aviram, who are described as wicked, highlighting the complexity of moral character within the community. The text also references a Midrash that elaborates on the circumstances surrounding Datan's wife and the conflict with the Egyptian, suggesting a deeper exploration of familial and communal ties in the face of wrongdoing. Ultimately, it reflects on the intricate relationship between identity, righteousness, and the challenges faced by individuals within the broader community.

translation: 3) And he went out to his brothers and saw their burdens, as it is said, "And he saw an Egyptian striking a Hebrew man," we know that he went out to his brothers and saw their suffering.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the moment when Moses leaves the palace to witness the suffering of his fellow Hebrews. The sight of the Egyptian beating a Hebrew symbolizes the deep connection and empathy Moses feels for his people. This act of seeing their suffering highlights the importance of compassion and solidarity in the face of oppression, emphasizing a key Hasidic teaching about the necessity of engaging with the struggles of others. Ultimately, it illustrates the divine call to action that arises from recognizing the pain of one's community.

passage_content: ד) כה וכה וירא כי אין איש וגו' במד"ר ר' יהודא אומר וירא כי אין איש שיקנא להקב"ה ויהרגנו וכו ', ורבנן אמרי ראה שאין תוחלת של צדיקים עומדת הימנו ולא מזרעו עד סוף כל הדורות, ולכאורה צ"ב מה שתמה מרע"ה ואמר אין איש שיקנא להקב"ה וכו ', והרי גם מרע"ה לא הרגו עד שצפה בסוף כל הדורות שאין תוחלת של צדיקים עומדת ממנו, ומי כמוהו ידע להתבונן ולהבחין בזה, ובאבות דר"נ ( פ"כ ) איתא שהושיב משה סנהדראות של מלה"ש , וא"ל אהרוג את זה ואמרו לו הרוג והרגו בשם המפורש, א"כ לא הי' חיובא זו רמיא על כל ישראל כי לא הי' ראוים למעשה זו זולתו, גם שהי' צ"ל בהסתר ובצינעא מפני הסכנה וצ"ב .
translation: D) And he saw that there was no man, etc. In the Midrash, Rabbi Yehuda says: He saw that there was no man who would be jealous for the Holy One, Blessed be He, and would kill him, etc. And the Rabbis say: He saw that there was no hope for the righteous standing by him, nor for his descendants until the end of all generations. And at first glance, it is difficult to understand what Moshe Rabbeinu wondered and said, "There is no man who would be jealous for the Holy One, Blessed be He," etc. For even Moshe Rabbeinu was not killed until he foresaw at the end of all generations that there was no hope for the righteous standing from him. And who, if not he, knew how to contemplate and discern this? And in the Avot deRabbi Natan (Chapter 2), it is stated that Moshe established the Sanhedrin of the spoken word, and he said to them, "Kill this one," and they said to him, "Kill him," and they killed him in the Name of the Ineffable. Therefore, this obligation was not applicable to all of Israel, for they were not worthy of this act except for him, and it had to be done in secrecy and discreetly due to the danger, and it is difficult to understand.
summary: The passage discusses the profound realization of Moses, who perceives that there is no one among the people who would be jealous for God's honor, leading him to question the lack of righteous individuals. The text contrasts this with the understanding that even Moses, despite his greatness, foresaw that the legacy of the righteous would not endure through his lineage. It highlights the unique responsibility placed upon Moses, suggesting that such actions could not be taken lightly or publicly, as they were reserved for exceptional individuals. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine jealousy, the continuity of righteousness, and the hidden nature of spiritual leadership.

passage_content: ה) זוה"ק (תיקון ו') דרשו ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש, אלא איש לדרכו פונה וכו' איש לבצעו לירתא האי עלמא וכו' כולהו צווחין הב הב לנא מזונא וסליחה וכפרה וכו' וצ"ב שהוציאו המקרא מפשוטו לגמרי, דמיירי בהריגת מצרי שרצה להרוג ישראל, ואין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו לעולם.
translation: 5) Zohar (Tikkun 6) interpreted: "And he turned this way and that and saw that there was no man, but each man turned to his own way, etc. A man to fulfill his fear of this world, etc. All of them were crying out, 'Woe, woe to us for sustenance and forgiveness and atonement,' etc. And it is difficult to understand why they took the verse completely out of its simple meaning, for it is speaking about the killing of the Egyptian who wanted to kill Israel, and a verse never departs from its simple meaning."
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the Zohar's interpretation of a biblical verse, emphasizing the spiritual and moral implications of the actions of individuals in the world. It highlights the idea that while people may be preoccupied with their own paths, there is a collective cry for sustenance, forgiveness, and atonement. The text critiques the tendency to deviate from the plain meaning of scripture, asserting that the literal interpretation should always be upheld, particularly in the context of the struggle between the Israelites and their oppressors. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the interconnectedness of individual and communal spiritual needs.

passage_content: ונראה בביאור הענין דהנה מרע"ה בהכאתו המצרי הביט עד סוף כל הדורות כמבואר בדברי המדרש, והנה אמרז"ל שכל הגליות הם להשלים גלות מצרים שלא נשלם אז, ושורש כולם גלות מצרים, ובש"ך עה"ת פ' זו כתב שכל אלו הנשמות המגולגלים עד סוף כל הדורות, היו כולם שם בגלות מצרים, ויע"א ראה לפניו ס' רבוא מבני בניו וכו' ודור הראשון שנסתלקו אז במצרים הם הסובלים עתה החבלי משיח וכו ', וכולנו יוצאי מצרים, וכל אלו שיגאלו בביאת המשיח כולם היו שם וכו ', והראי' דעל שאר הנסים מברכים שעשית לאבותינו, אבל ביצי"מ כתיב אשר הוצאתיך מארץ מצרים בלשון יחיד, שהבוכ"ע הוציא משם כל נשמות ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, ועמדו כולן במעמד הנבחר ולכאו"א אמר הבוי"ת אשר הוצאתיך מארמ"צ וכולנו יוצאי מצרים וכו' יעיי"ש באריכות, וע"כ מרע"ה כשהביט עד סוף כל הדורות השיג ברוה"ק השתלשלות כל הדורות וגלגלותיהם, ויובן בזה אריכות לשון הכתוב ויצא אל אחיו וירא בסבלותם , ע"ד שאמה"כ ויוצא אותו החוצה שדרז"ל הוציאו למעלה מכיפת הרקיע, וכמו"כ ויצא אל אחיו שיצא למעלה מגלגל העולם לראות אחיו, וירא בסבלותם שראה בסבלות ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, ולז"א וירא "איש" מצרי מכה "איש" עברי מאחיו, כי אז מצרי הכה יהודי, אולם ראה עד סוף כל הדורות והשיג אף בחי' הגלות של עכשיו, שבעוה"ר הגענו עד כדי כך שלא המצרי בלבד מכה עברי, אבל גם איש מצרי מכה איש עברי מאחיו, ר"ל שהוא מאחיו וישראל כמוהו אלא שעושה מעשה מצרי ומתדמה אליו, ונקרא איש מצרי ע"ש שהוא מאנשיהם ונטפל לדרכיהם ושיטתם, והוא מכה איש עברי המתרחק מדרכי הרשעים, שנקרא איש עברי ע"ד שאמרו ז"ל באאע"ה למה נקרא שמו עברי שכל העולם עומד בעבר האחד והוא בעבר השני, ואמר "איש" עברי ע"ד שכתב ק"ז זלה"ה ביש"מ (פ' בלק) דאף מי שאינו צדיק גמור רק שמתחבר לצדיקים והולך בדרכם הוא ג"כ שנוא בעיני הרשעים, והוא שומה מאת ה' שיהי' שנאה כבושה בין צדיק לרשע יעיי"ש .
translation: And it is seen in the explanation of the matter that Moses, when he struck the Egyptian, looked until the end of all generations, as explained in the words of the Midrash. And our sages of blessed memory said that all the exiles are to complete the Egyptian exile which was not completed then, and the root of them all is the Egyptian exile. And in the Shach on the Torah, in this portion, it is written that all these souls that are reincarnated until the end of all generations were all there in the Egyptian exile. And it is said that he saw before him 600,000 from his descendants, etc., and the first generation that departed then in Egypt are the ones suffering now the birth pangs of the Messiah, etc. And we are all those who went out of Egypt, and all those who will be redeemed with the coming of the Messiah were all there, etc. And the proof is that for other miracles we bless "You did for our forefathers," but for the Exodus from Egypt it is written "that I brought you out of the land of Egypt" in the singular, for the Blessed One brought out from there all the souls of Israel until the end of all generations, and they all stood in the chosen assembly, and to each one He said, "I brought you out of Egypt," and we are all those who went out of Egypt, etc. See there at length. Therefore, when Moses looked until the end of all generations, he grasped in the Holy Spirit the unfolding of all generations and their reincarnations. And this will be understood in the length of the language of the verse, "And he went out to his brothers and saw their burdens," in the manner of what is written, "And he brought him out," which our sages of blessed memory explained that he brought him above the firmament. Likewise, "And he went out to his brothers" means he went above the wheel of the world to see his brothers, and "he saw their burdens" means he saw the burdens of Israel until the end of all generations. And thus it is said, "And he saw an Egyptian man striking a Hebrew man, one of his brothers," for then an Egyptian struck a Jew. However, he saw until the end of all generations and grasped even the state of the exile of now, that in our evil days we have reached such a point that not only does the Egyptian strike the Hebrew, but also an Egyptian man strikes a Hebrew man, one of his brothers, meaning he is one of his brothers and a Jew like him, except that he acts like an Egyptian and resembles him. And he is called an Egyptian man because he is one of their people and clings to their ways and their system, and he strikes a Hebrew man who distances himself from the ways of the wicked, who is called a Hebrew man, in the manner that our sages of blessed memory said regarding Abraham our father, "Why is he called a Hebrew? Because the whole world stands on one side and he is on the other side." And he said "a Hebrew man" in the manner that it is written in the Zohar, that even one who is not a complete righteous person, but who connects to the righteous and walks in their ways, is also hated in the eyes of the wicked. And it is decreed by the Blessed One that there should be a concealed hatred between the righteous and the wicked. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the profound connection between the Exodus from Egypt and the ongoing suffering of the Jewish people throughout history. It emphasizes that all Jewish souls were present during the Egyptian exile, and that the trials faced by the Jewish people today are a continuation of that original suffering. The text highlights the idea that even those who identify as Jewish can sometimes act against their own, reflecting a deeper spiritual struggle between righteousness and wickedness. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that the redemption from this suffering is tied to the collective experience of the Jewish people throughout all generations.

passage_content: והנה אמרז"ל (סנהדרין ק"ט) דתן שעבר על דת אל אבירם שאיבד עצמו מעשות תשובה, וראוי להבין למה פלגינהו זה לדת וזה לתשובה, והצד השוה שבהן לא טוב, ופירשתי עפ"י מאמה"כ (תהלים ק"ו) תפתח ארץ ותבלע דתן ותכס על עדת אבירם, וצ"ב למה פלגינהו קרא דאצל דתן כתיב ותבלע וגם לא כתיב עדת דתן, ואצל אבירם כתב ותכס והזכיר גם עדת אבירם, ומדוע לא כיילינהו יחדיו תפתח ארץ ותבלע או ותכס עדת דתן ואבירם, ויבואר עפי"ד הגמ ' (סנהדרין ק"ט:) און בן פלת אשתו הצילתו , דישבה בפתח ביתה וסתרה לשערות ראשה, אמרה ידענא כי כל העדה כולם קדושים וכל דאתא חזי' הדר, והרחוקו עצמן מפתח ביתה ועי"ז ניצול בעלה מחבורתם, מבואר מזה כי בדור ההוא אפי' הגרועים שבישראל לא נכנסו לבית שהתנהגו בו בפריצות והתרחקו מחבורתם ולא הי' אפשר להתעות את ישראל במתי שוא כמו בדורינו , והנה לפי גירסת המדרש הנ"ל שאחת קילקלה ופירסמה הכתוב היתה אשתו של דתן, א"כ הרי נתגדל הנוקב שם ה' בביתו של דתן וכיון שבביתו נתגדל נוקב שם ה' בודאי הי' בית פרוץ ומקולקל, ע"כ דתן לא הי' ביכלתו להמשיך אליו עדה, משא"כ אבירם שלא הי' אצלו כ"ז הוא הי' יכול להמשיך אחריו עדה, ממילא דתן שלא הי"ל עדה ע"כ תפתח ארץ ותבלע דתן, וזה יספיק להרחיק הנזק, אבל " ותכס " על "עדת" אבירם, כי הוא המשיך אליו בנ"א והאמינו בו, ע"כ לא יספיק מה שיבלעהו הארץ כי עדיין ישארו בעולם דיעותיו מה שהכניס בלב ההמון דיעות נפסדות, ע"כ אמר ותכס על עדת אבירם שהי' צורך שיתכסה ויתעלם מן העולם גם עדתו נושאי שיטתו ודיעותיו , ובזה יובן דברי הגמ ' סנהדרין הנ"ל, כי דתן הי' רק עזב דת קל שהרשיע לעצמו, משא"כ אבירם חטא והחטיא את הרבים עמו, ואמרז"ל כי אחד מן הכ"ד דברים המעכבים את התשובה המחטיא את הרבים, ואיתא בספר חסידים באחד שהחטיא את הרבים וביקש לסדר לו תשובה, א"ל החכם הביא חזרה כל הנשמות שקלקלת, ואם אינך יכול להחזירם א"א לסדר לך תשובה, כי מה בצע בתשובתך כ"ז שהם אינם שבים וע"כ באבירם שהמשיך אחריו עדה וגרם לקילקולם א"א לו לעשות תשובה, ובזה יונח כי בדתן דרשו ז"ל שעזב דת קל, ובאבירם שאיבד עצמו מן התשובה, ע"י שהמשיך אליו בנ"א והחטיא את הרבים.
translation:
And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 109) that Datan, who transgressed the law, lost himself from repenting, and it is appropriate to understand why they divided this into law and this into repentance, and the common aspect between them is not good. I explained according to the verse (Psalms 106) "The earth opened and swallowed Datan and covered the congregation of Abiram." It is puzzling why it is divided; regarding Datan it is written "and swallowed" and it is not written "the congregation of Datan," while regarding Abiram it is written "and covered" and also mentions "the congregation of Abiram." Why were they not aligned together as "the earth opened and swallowed" or "and covered the congregation of Datan and Abiram"? This will be clarified according to the Gemara (Sanhedrin 109) that On ben Pelet's wife saved him, for she sat at the entrance of her house and uncovered her hair, saying, "I know that the entire congregation is holy, and whoever comes to see will return," and she distanced herself from the entrance of her house, and through this, her husband was saved from their company. It is clear from this that in that generation, even the worst among Israel did not enter a house that was conducted with immorality and distanced themselves from their company, and it was not possible to mislead Israel with falsehoods as in our generation. 

Now, according to the version of the aforementioned Midrash, that one who caused corruption and publicized it was Datan's wife, then the name of the Holy One was indeed magnified in Datan's house, and since the name of the Holy One was magnified in his house, it was certainly a house of immorality and corruption. Therefore, Datan was not able to draw a congregation to himself, whereas Abiram, who did not have such a situation, was able to draw a congregation after him. Consequently, since Datan did not have a congregation, it was sufficient for the earth to open and swallow Datan, which would suffice to distance the damage. However, "and covered" refers to "the congregation of Abiram," for he drew people to him and they believed in him. Therefore, it was not sufficient for the earth to swallow him, as there would still remain in the world his corrupt ideas that he instilled in the hearts of the masses. Thus, it said "and covered the congregation of Abiram," as it was necessary for them to be concealed and hidden from the world, including his congregation who carried his doctrine and ideas. 

In this, the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin will be understood, for Datan only abandoned a light law that he transgressed for himself, whereas Abiram sinned and caused many to sin with him. Our Sages of blessed memory said that one of the twenty-four things that prevent repentance is one who causes the many to sin. It is stated in the Book of the Pious that one who caused the many to sin and sought to arrange repentance for himself, the wise man said to him, "You must bring back all the souls you have corrupted, and if you cannot bring them back, it is impossible to arrange repentance for you, for what benefit is your repentance as long as they do not return?" Therefore, in the case of Abiram, who drew a congregation after him and caused their corruption, it is impossible for him to repent. Thus, it is established that regarding Datan, our Sages said that he abandoned a light law, while regarding Abiram, he lost himself from repentance by drawing people to him and causing the many to sin.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between Datan and Abiram in terms of their spiritual failures and the consequences of their actions. Datan is described as having abandoned a "light" faith, leading to his inability to influence others negatively, resulting in his being swallowed by the earth. In contrast, Abiram, who led others astray, is seen as having lost the ability to repent because he caused the spiritual downfall of many, highlighting the Hasidic concept that those who lead others into sin bear a greater burden and face more severe consequences in their quest for redemption. This reflects the theological insight that communal responsibility and the impact of one's actions on others are critical in the process of repentance.

passage_content: ולפי"ז אפ"ל דעפ"י פשוטו מלת מאחיו קאי על המצרי, שהשיג משרע"ה שהמוכה דתן רשע כמותו ואחיו לו בדיעה , וע"ד הרמז ראה בדורות העתידים שיהי' איש מצרי מכה איש עברי מאחיו, ישראל כמוהו אלא שעושה מעשה מצרי כנ"ל, וירדוף אחריו להכהו בהכאה גשמיות ורוחניות, וכל כוונתו להמשיכו לדיעותיו ולעשוק את נפשו כדרך המסיתים בדורנו שמנסים בכלי קרב ובדרך מלחמה להכניע, ואח"כ באים בחלקלקות לשון לפתות ר"ל לדעתם ושיטתם, וע"ד שכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל עה"פ כל כלי יוצר עליך לא יצלח וכל לשון תקום אתך למשפט תרשיעי, דהכוונה על ב' דרכי הסתה הנ"ל עיי"ש וכל זה ראה משרע"ה ברוה"ק והתפלל על הצלתינו מידם ועשה פועל דמיוני לזה, וז"א ויך את המצרי ויטמנהו בחול, וע"ד שאמר דוהמע"ה תפתח ארץ ותבלע דתן ותכס על עדת אבירם, וכמו שפירשנו לעיל שיתעלם ויתכסה מן העולם הם ועדתם ונושאי שיטתם, ולא ירעו ולא ישחיתו וגו'
translation: According to this, it can be said that according to its simple meaning, the word "from his brother" refers to the Egyptian, who confronted Moshe Rabbeinu, that the one struck, Datan the wicked, is like him and his brother in opinion. And according to the hint, he saw in future generations that there would be an Egyptian man striking a Hebrew man from his brothers, Israelites like him, except that he acts in a manner of an Egyptian as mentioned. He will pursue him to strike him with physical and spiritual blows, and all his intention is to draw him to his opinions and to oppress his soul, like the instigators in our generation who try with weapons and through warfare to subdue, and afterwards come with smooth speech to entice, so to speak, to their opinions and methods. And as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote on the verse "No weapon formed against you shall prosper, and every tongue that rises against you in judgment you shall condemn," the intention is on the two ways of instigation mentioned above, as seen there. And all this Moshe Rabbeinu saw in the Holy Spirit and prayed for our salvation from them and made a symbolic act for this, and thus it is said, "And he struck the Egyptian and hid him in the sand," and as it is said, "And the earth opened its mouth and swallowed Datan and covered over the assembly of Abiram," and as we explained above, they will be concealed and hidden from the world, they and their assembly and bearers of their opinions, and they will not harm or destroy, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual struggle between Moses and the Egyptian oppressor, symbolizing the broader conflict between Israel and those who seek to lead them astray. It highlights the dual nature of this conflict, where physical violence is accompanied by spiritual seduction, echoing the tactics of contemporary adversaries. Moses, through divine insight, foresaw these future challenges and prayed for deliverance, leading to a metaphorical act of burying the oppressor, representing the desire to conceal and eliminate harmful ideologies. This reflects a deep Hasidic understanding of the need for spiritual vigilance and the importance of divine protection against both physical and spiritual threats.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ( בקושיא ד') ר' יהודה אומר וירא כי אין איש שיקנא להקב"ה וכו ', ומ"ש בתיקונים וירא כי אין איש אלא לדרכו פונה וכו ', ועפ"י דרשתם ז"ל ירמוז הכתוב לדורות וז"א ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש, ע"ד שהתפלל משרע"ה יפקוד ד' אלקי הרוחות וגו' איש על העדה וגו', ונענה על אותה שעה וא"ל הקב"ה קח לך את יהושע וגו' איש אשר רוח בו, אמנם צפה משרע"ה בסוף הדורות שיהיו ישראל כצאן בלא רועה ובלא מנהיג, וע"ז מקונן הנביא (יחזקאל ל"ד) הוי רועי ישראל וגו' את החלב תאכלו וגו' הצאן לא תרעו וגו' ישגו צאני בכל ההרים וגו' ועל כל פני הארץ נפוצו צאני ואין דורש ואין מבקש כה אמר ד' הנני אל הרועים ודרשתי צאני מידם והשבתים מרעות צאן ולא ירעו עוד הרועים אותם והצלתי צאני מפיהם וגו' אני ארעה צאני ואני ארביצם נאם ד' וגו' והקימותי עליהם רועה וגו' את עבדי דוד הוא ירעה אותם והוא יהי' להם לרועה, וכל הנבואה הזו התנבא יחזקאל על הדור האחרון עיקבתא דמשיחא , ונתקיימה במלואה בעוה"ר , שאין מי יגדור גדר ומי יעמוד בפרץ, ואמרו חז"ל (סנהדרין צ"ז ע"א) דור שבן דוד בא העזות תרבה והיוקר יעוות פרש"י היוקר יעוות מכובד שבהן יהא עוותן ורמאי, ולכאורה הרי אמרז"ל (פסחים ג') בגנות בהמה טמאה לא סיפר הכתוב וכו' עיי"ש, ומדוע יאריך הכתוב לספר בגנות רועי ישראל ואף חז"ל תיארו גנותם, אמנם הי' הכרח לזה מפני הצלת הדורות, ולהודיע לנו שאין לנו על מי להשען אלא על אבינו שבשמים, ולא נניח להתעות עצמינו, וכמ"ש רש"י ז"ל בשה"ש עה"פ אם לא תדעי לך היפה בנשים צאי לך בעקבי הצאן. וזלה"ק אם פסק הרועה מלהנהיגך , צאי לך בעקבי הצאן תסתכלו בפסיעות שבו הלכו הראשונים והעקביים נכרים, ואם נבקש דרך האמת דרך אבוה"ק לא יעזוב ד' את ישראל וירחם עלינו להנחינו בדרך האמת.
translation: And similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be clarified (in the question D') Rabbi Yehuda says, "And he saw that there was no man to be zealous for the Holy One, blessed be He," etc., and what is stated in the Tikkunim, "And he saw that there was no man, but each one turns to his own way," etc. According to their interpretation, may their memory be blessed, the verse hints to the generations, and thus it says, "And he turned this way and that way and saw that there was no man," in the manner that Moshe prayed, "May the Lord, God of the spirits, appoint a man over the congregation," etc., and he was answered at that moment, and the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Take for yourself Joshua," etc., "a man in whom is the spirit." However, Moshe foresaw at the end of the generations that Israel would be like sheep without a shepherd and without a leader, and for this, the prophet laments (Ezekiel 34), "Woe to the shepherds of Israel," etc., "You eat the fat," etc., "but the sheep you do not shepherd," etc. "My sheep have gone astray on all the mountains," etc., "and upon all the face of the earth, my sheep are scattered, and there is no one to seek or inquire." Thus says the Lord, "Behold, I am against the shepherds, and I will require my sheep at their hand, and I will remove them from shepherding the sheep, and they will no longer shepherd them, and I will save my sheep from their mouth," etc. "I will shepherd my sheep, and I will cause them to lie down," says the Lord, etc., "and I will set up over them a shepherd," etc., "my servant David, he will shepherd them, and he will be to them for a shepherd." And all this prophecy was prophesied by Ezekiel about the last generation, the footsteps of the Messiah, and it has been fully realized in our times, as there is no one to set a boundary and no one to stand in the breach. And our sages said (Sanhedrin 97a), "In the generation when the son of David comes, audacity will increase, and the price of food will become distorted," Rashi explains that the price will become distorted, the most esteemed among them will be deceitful and fraudulent. And seemingly, our sages said (Pesachim 3) regarding the disgrace of the impure animal, the scripture did not recount, etc., see there. And why does the scripture prolong to recount the disgrace of the shepherds of Israel, and our sages also described their disgrace? However, this was necessary for the salvation of the generations, to inform us that we have no one to rely upon except our Father in Heaven, and we should not allow ourselves to be misled, as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the Song of Songs on the verse, "If you do not know, O fairest among women, go forth in the footsteps of the flock." And thus it is said: if the shepherd has ceased to lead you, go forth in the footsteps of the flock; look at the steps that the earlier ones walked, and the footprints are foreign. And if we seek the path of truth, the path of our holy ancestors, the Lord will not forsake Israel and will have mercy on us to guide us in the way of truth.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic insights of Rabbi Yehuda regarding the lack of true leadership among the Jewish people, particularly in the context of the end of days. It highlights the concern that Israel will be like sheep without a shepherd, as expressed by the prophet Ezekiel, and emphasizes the need for reliance on God as the ultimate guide. The text underscores the importance of following the paths of the righteous ancestors when earthly leaders fail, assuring that God will not abandon His people and will guide them in truth. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope and divine oversight amidst spiritual challenges.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו דברי התקונים ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש, אלא איש לדרכו פונה וכו' איש לבצעו לירתא האי עלמא, כולהו צווחין הב הב לנא מזונא וסליחה וכפרה, ולכאורה הרי אנשי כנה"ג תיקנו להתפלל על כל אלה, אמנם הזוה"ק אין תרעומתו על בקשת מזונא פרנסה חיי סליחה וכו ', כי בני ישראל צריכים לכל זה בשביל להרבות כבוד שמים בעולם, ועד"ז תיקנו אנשי כנה"ג להתפלל על אלה שיתכווין האדם בתפלתו בשביל כבוד שמים ובשביל שיתרחב דעתו לעבוד ד' בכל לבבו, ויהי' לו די מחסורו להחזקת תלמוד תורה ולקיים מצות התלויים בממון. אולם החסרון הוא שאין בנ"א מכוונים כ"א להנאתן, וז"ש צווחין ככלבין הב לנא מזונא וכו' כי הכלבים ג"כ צועקין רק להנאת עצמן. וזהו כל החסרון שצווחין ככלבין בדומה להם, וצריך לכווין בעד כבוד שמים.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the regulations, and he looked here and there and saw that there was no man, but a man turns to his own way, etc. A man to fulfill his desire in this world, all of them are crying out, "Give us food and forgiveness and atonement." And seemingly, the men of the Great Assembly established to pray for all these things. However, the Zohar does not express its complaint about the request for sustenance, livelihood, forgiveness, etc., because the children of Israel need all this in order to increase the honor of Heaven in the world. Similarly, the men of the Great Assembly established to pray for these things so that a person should intend in his prayer for the honor of Heaven and so that his mind should be expanded to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He, with all his heart, and that he should have enough for his needs to support the study of Torah and to fulfill the commandments that are dependent on money. However, the shortcoming is that people do not intend except for their own benefit, and this is what is meant by "crying out like dogs," for the dogs also bark only for their own pleasure. And this is the entire shortcoming that they cry out like dogs, similar to them, and one must intend for the honor of Heaven.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of intention in prayer, emphasizing that while the Jewish people pray for sustenance, forgiveness, and other needs, their requests should ultimately aim to glorify God's name in the world. It critiques the tendency of individuals to focus solely on their personal desires, likening them to dogs that bark for their own benefit. The text highlights that true prayer should be directed towards serving God with a sincere heart, ensuring that one's needs are met to support the study of Torah and the fulfillment of commandments. The underlying message is the necessity of aligning one's intentions with the greater purpose of honoring God.

passage_content: וע"ז ירמזו דברי רז"ל במדרש וירא כי אין איש שיקנא להקב"ה וכו' שידרוש בשביל כבוד שמו ית ' להכניע כוחות הטומאה, כמו שעשה משרע"ה בהריגת המצרי, וק"ז הייט"ל זלה"ה פי' מ"ש פניתי לימין ואין עוזר ולשמאל ואין סומך, כי התוה"ק נקראת ימין עדה"כ מימינו אש דת למו, ובדורות האחרונים אין לנו עוזר וסומך מבלעדו ית"ש , וז"א פניתי לימין לבקש עזר וסעד בעבדות ד' ודרך התוה"ק , ואין עוזר, כי אפסו מנהיגי ישראל האמיתיים, ולשמאל לבקש טובה בהשפעה גשמיות ע"ד הכתוב בשמאלה עושר וכבוד ואין סומך, וזה ירמוז הכתוב ויפן כה וכה כבחי' הנ"ל וירא כי אין איש. שראה משרע"ה בשפלות דורנו האחרון שלא יהי' לנו לא מנהיג ולא מנהל וירא בסבלותם עד סוף כל הדורות, והתפלל על הצלתינו.
translation: And regarding this, our Sages allude in the Midrash that he saw there was no man to be jealous for the Holy One, blessed be He, etc., that he would seek for the honor of His Name, blessed be He, to subdue the forces of impurity, as Moshe Rabbeinu did with the killing of the Egyptian. And thus it is explained in the holy teachings, what is meant by "I turned to the right and there was no helper, and to the left and there was no supporter," for the Torah is called the right, as it is written, "From His right hand went a fiery law for them." And in the last generations, we have no helper or supporter besides Him, blessed be He. And thus it is said, "I turned to the right to seek help and support in the service of the Master of the Universe and through the Torah," and there is no helper, for the true leaders of Israel have ceased. And to the left, to seek goodness in material influence, as it is written, "On her left hand are riches and honor," and there is no supporter. And this alludes to the verse, "And he turned this way and that way," as mentioned above, and he saw that there was no man. Moshe Rabbeinu saw the lowliness of our last generation, that we would have neither leader nor guide, and he saw their suffering until the end of all generations, and he prayed for our salvation.
summary: The passage reflects on the absence of true leadership and support in the last generations, emphasizing the need for divine assistance in the face of spiritual and physical challenges. It draws parallels to Moses' actions in defending the honor of God and highlights the futility of seeking help from earthly leaders, as they have diminished. The text underscores the importance of turning to the Torah, referred to as the "right hand," for guidance and support, while lamenting the lack of genuine leaders who can provide spiritual direction. Ultimately, it conveys a deep yearning for divine intervention and salvation amidst the suffering of the Jewish people throughout history.

passage_content: ויהי בימים הרבים ההם וימת מלך מצרים ויאנחו בני ישראל מן העבודה ויזעקו ותעל שועתם אל האלקים מן העבודה, פרש"י ז"ל נצטרע והי' שוחט תינוקות של ישראל ורוחץ בדמם, וכן מבואר במד"ר (פר' א' סי' ל"ד) למה נתאנחו , לפי שאמרו חרטומי מצרים אין לך רפואה אם לא נשחוט מקטני ישראל ק"נ בערב וק"נ בבוקר ורחוץ בדמיהם שתי פעמים ביום, כיון ששמעו ישראל גזירה קשה התחילו מתאנחים וקוננים, ראוי להבין דלכאורה דרש זה סותר משמעות הפשוטו שאנחתם הי' מן העבודה, דכתיב ויאנחו בנ"י מן העבודה, ואם כדרשתם שנתאנחו על איבוד הנפשות מדוע כתיב מן העבודה, גם אין טעם בעצה זו לרחוץ בדמם של תינוקות דבר שלא נשמע מעולם, ואם הי' צריך לדם תינוקות הי' יכול להקיז מהם דם, ומדוע דוקא בבוקר ובערב.
translation: And it came to pass in those many days that the king of Egypt died, and the children of Israel sighed because of the work, and they cried out, and their cry ascended to God from the work. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that he was afflicted with leprosy and would slaughter the children of Israel and wash in their blood. And it is also explained in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, section 34) why they sighed, for the Egyptian magicians said, "You will have no remedy unless we slaughter 250 of the infants of Israel in the evening and 250 in the morning, and wash in their blood twice a day." When the Israelites heard this harsh decree, they began to sigh and lament. It is fitting to understand that, seemingly, this interpretation contradicts the simple meaning, for their sighing was from the work, as it is written, "And the children of Israel sighed because of the work." If, according to their interpretation, they sighed over the loss of lives, why is it written "from the work"? Furthermore, there is no reason for this advice to wash in the blood of infants, a thing that has never been heard of, and if blood from infants was needed, they could have drawn blood from them. Why specifically in the morning and in the evening?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing their anguish not only from the harsh labor but also from the cruel decree to sacrifice their infants. The text highlights the paradox of their cries, which stemmed from both physical oppression and the moral horror of losing innocent lives. The discussion raises profound questions about divine justice and the nature of suffering, suggesting that the Israelites' anguish was a response to both their immediate plight and the deeper spiritual implications of their situation. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of human suffering and the interplay between physical and spiritual dimensions in the context of faith.

passage_content: ונל"פ בדרך רמז מוסר בהקדם דברי הגמ ' (נדה י"ג ע"א) ואמר ר' יוחנן כל המוציא ש"ז לבטלה חייב מיתה וכו' ר' יצחק ור' אמי אמרו כאילו שופך דמים שנאמר ( ישעי ' נ"ז) הנחמים באלים תחת כל עץ רענן שוחטי הילדים בנחלים תחת סעיפי הסלעים, אל תקרי שוחטי אלא סוחטי עכ"ד הגמ ', ורש"י ז"ל בישעי ' שם פי' שוחטי הילדים לקרבן עכו"ם, וכן פירשו רוב מפרשים שוחטי הילדים לע"ז, שבימיהם הי' יצרא דע"ז תקיפא וגם את בניהם ואת בנותיהם ישרפון באש לאלהיהם , ובגמ' דרשוהו על חטא הידוע, עוד שם בגמרא אר"א מ"ד גם כי תרבו תפלה אינני שומע ידיכם דמים מלאו ( ישעי ' א'), אלו המנאפים ביד, פרש"י מוציא זרע לבטלה, וכ' המהרש"א יש לפרש דלפי פשוטו שהוא שפיכת דמים ממש למה תלה בו גם כי תרבו תפלה איננו שומע יותר מבשאר עבירות, אבל הרהור עבירה הוא ודאי ביטול תפלה, וביותר במוציא שז"ל שאסור להתפלל עד שיטבול עכ"ד, ולכאורה יש להבין מה שכתב דהרהור עבירה הוא ודאי ביטול תפלה, דא"כ יהי' בכל הרהור עבירה כן ולמה דוקא בחטא זה, ואולי דבהרהור שאר עבירות אינו מפסיד כ"כ כוונת התפלה כמו בהרהור זה, או אפשר עפי"מ דאיתא שם בגמרא אר"א כל המביא עצמו לידי הרהור אין מכניסין אותו במחיצתו של הקב"ה, כתיב הכא וירע בעיני ה' וכתיב התם כי לא אל חפץ רשע אתה לא יגורך רע עכ"ד הגמ ', וכמו שהוא עצמו נדחה ממחיצתו של הקב"ה, גם תפלתו לא יעלה לפניו ית ', ולז"א הכתוב גם כי תרבו תפלה אינני שומע וגו'
translation: And we will explain in a hint of moral teaching, in advance of the words of the Gemara (Niddah 13a) where Rabbi Yochanan said: "Anyone who emits seed in vain is liable to death," etc. Rabbi Yitzchak and Rabbi Ami said: "It is as if he spills blood," as it is stated (Isaiah 57): "Those who comfort themselves with idols under every leafy tree, slaying the children in the valleys under the clefts of the rocks." Do not read "slaying" but "squeezing." Thus concludes the Gemara. And Rashi, of blessed memory, in Isaiah there explains that "slaying the children" refers to a sacrifice to idols, and so most commentators interpret "slaying the children" as referring to idolatry, for in their days the evil inclination for idolatry was strong, and they would also burn their sons and daughters in fire to their gods. And in the Gemara, it is expounded regarding the known sin. Furthermore, there in the Gemara, Rabbi Elazar said: "Even if you increase prayer, I do not listen; your hands are full of blood" (Isaiah 1). These are those who commit adultery with their hands. Rashi explains that "emitting seed in vain" is included. And the Maharsha writes that it can be interpreted according to its simple meaning as actual spilling of blood. Why does it also mention "even if you increase prayer, I do not listen" more than other transgressions? But surely, a thought of sin is certainly a nullification of prayer, especially in the case of one who emits seed in vain, who is forbidden to pray until he immerses. Thus, it is necessary to understand what he wrote that a thought of sin is certainly a nullification of prayer, for if so, it should be the case with every thought of sin, and why specifically in this sin? Perhaps in the thought of other sins, it does not so much detract from the intention of the prayer as in this thought, or it is possible, according to the explanation that is stated there in the Gemara, Rabbi Elazar said: "Anyone who brings himself to a thought of sin is not admitted into the Divine Presence." It is written here: "And it was evil in the eyes of the Lord," and it is written there: "For You are not a God who delights in wickedness; evil shall not dwell with You." Thus concludes the Gemara. And just as he himself is pushed away from the Divine Presence, so too his prayer will not ascend before Him, blessed be He. Therefore, the verse says: "Even if you increase prayer, I do not listen," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the severe consequences of engaging in the sin of wasting seed, equating it to the act of murder and idolatry, as highlighted by various rabbinic interpretations. It emphasizes that such actions not only lead to spiritual disconnection from God but also render one's prayers ineffective. The text suggests that the gravity of this sin lies in its ability to corrupt one's intentions during prayer, making it a unique case among other transgressions. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of purity in thought and action to maintain a connection with the Divine.

passage_content: והנה אם יתבונן האדם בחומר עונש הזה רעדה יאחזהו ותסמר שערות אנוש, דהלא כל ישראל צריכים לרחמי שמים בכל עת ועונה ומתחננים להבוית"ש בתפלות ותחנונים וכל קיומם ותקותם שיקובלו לרצון לפניו ית"ש , והבוי"ת שומע תפלת כל פה ואף תפלת החוטאים, וכמשרז"ל (ר"ה י"ז ע"ב) נתעטף הקב"ה כשליח ציבור והראה לו למשה סדר תפלה, א"ל כל זמן שישראל חוטאין יעשו לפני כסדר הזה ואני מוחל להם, ואיך אפשר להעלות על הדעת שתפלות ישראל לא יחשבו לכלום ח"ו, עד שאפילו מרבים בתפלות לא יתקבלו כמאמר הכתוב גם כי תרבו תפלה אינני שומע, ואי' איפה תקותינו בדור השפל הזה שאין אתנו יודע מה היא תפלה ותחנה, אולם מצינו רמז נחמה בפסוק שלאחריו דכתיב הזכו הסירו רוע מעלליכם מנגד עיני, פרש"י י' אזהרות של לשון תשובה יש כאן כנגד עשי"ת, וכנגד עשרה מלכיות זכרונות ושופרות, הרי מבואר שמועיל תשובה אף לחטא הידוע דבי' מיירי הכתוב, גם בזוה"ק פרשה זו מבואר דמהני תשובה וז"ל מאן דמשקר בברית וכו' לית לי' חולקא באלקי ישראל אי לא בחילא דתיובתא תדיר עכ"ל, ומ"ש בתיובתא תדיר אפ"ל ע"ד שאה"כ וחטאתי נגדי תמיד, דהנה בשאר עוונות אם התודה עליהם ביוה"כ שעבר ולא שנה באולתו איכא פלוגתא אם צריך להתודות עליהם עוה"פ , (עיי' בגמ' ובטור או"ח סי' תר"ז) אבל על חטא הידוע צריך לעשות תשובה ולהתוודות עליו תמיד כמאה"כ וחטאתי נגדי תמיד.
translation: And behold, if a person contemplates the severity of this punishment, a shudder will seize him and the hair of man will stand on end, for all of Israel needs the mercy of Heaven at all times and in all situations, and they plead before the Blessed One with prayers and supplications, and all their existence and hope is that they should be accepted favorably before Him, Blessed be He. And the Blessed One hears the prayer of every mouth, even the prayer of sinners, as our Sages of blessed memory have said (Rosh Hashanah 17b) that the Holy One, blessed be He, wrapped Himself like a prayer leader and showed Moses the order of prayer, saying to him, "As long as Israel sins, they should pray before Me in this manner, and I will forgive them." And how can it be conceived that the prayers of Israel would be considered as nothing, Heaven forbid, to the extent that even if they increase in prayers, they will not be accepted, as the verse states, "Even if you increase prayer, I do not listen"? And where is our hope in this lowly generation, where no one knows what prayer and supplication are? However, we find a hint of comfort in the verse that follows, which states, "You have been zealous; remove the evil of your deeds from before My eyes." Rashi explains that there are ten warnings of the language of repentance here, corresponding to the Ten Days of Repentance, and to the ten kings, remembrances, and shofars. Thus, it is clear that repentance is effective even for the known sin that the verse is discussing. Also, in this section of the Zohar, it is explained that repentance is beneficial, and it says, "Whoever lies in the covenant, etc., has no share in the God of Israel unless he is in the strength of repentance always." And what is meant by "in the strength of repentance always" can be understood in the manner of the verse, "And I have sinned before You always." For in other transgressions, if one has confessed them on Yom Kippur that has passed and has not repeated his sin, there is a dispute whether he needs to confess them in the future (see in the Gemara and in the Tur, Orach Chaim, Siman 577). But for the known sin, one must always repent and confess for it, as the verse states, "And I have sinned before You always."
summary: The passage emphasizes the necessity of divine mercy for all of Israel, highlighting that even the prayers of sinners are heard by God. It references the tradition that God, as a congregation leader, instructed Moses on the prayer order to be recited during Israel's transgressions, assuring forgiveness. The text underscores the importance of repentance, suggesting that even in a lowly state, sincere return to God can lead to redemption, as indicated by scriptural allusions to the power of repentance and the continuous need for atonement.

passage_content: ראה מש"כ בספה"ק דברי חיים (פ' נח) לפרש הכתוב קץ כל בשר בא לפני וגו' וזל"ק , דהנה מבואר שחטא של דור המבול הי' ששחתו זרעם ולזה לא מהני תשובה וכו ', וכן באמת דור המבול לא הי' מהני להו תשובה וכו ', ואך עיקר הדבר למסור נפשו להקב"ה בהשתוקקות רב עד דכדוכה של נפש, ומתוקן בזה מה שחרבו העולמות ובא עד הקץ, ולזה אמר הכתוב שפיר קץ כל בשר וגו' עיי"ש, וכתב שם עוד הטעם מדוע לא מהני תשובה על חטא הזה, עפ"י מה דמבואר בספרים דבחטא פוגם האדם במדותיו , ובמדה שחוטא מסיר עצמו משרשי הקדושה וכו ', אבל לא נעקר ח"ו משרשו ולכן בעשותו תשובה מביא חיות חדש משרשו אל האבר והצינור שנחלש וכו ', אך בחטא חמור הנ"ל ר"ל הוא כמסיר שרשו לגמרי כמבואר בספה"ק , ולכן כמעט אין לו תרופה, ואך בקושי תשובה מעורר אדם הנהגה רצונית למעלה מהטבע, יחון ונעתר לה' גם בשובו מחטא זה וכו ', והיינו כנ"ל ע"י מסנ"פ ממש להקב"ה עכת"ד.
translation: See what is written in the holy book Divrei Chaim (Parshat Noach) to explain the verse "The end of all flesh has come before Me," etc. It is stated that it is clear that the sin of the generation of the Flood was that they corrupted their offspring, and therefore repentance was not effective for them, etc. Indeed, for the generation of the Flood, repentance was not effective, etc. The main thing is to give one's soul to the Holy One, blessed be He, with great longing, to the point of the soul's distress, and through this, what caused the worlds to be destroyed is rectified, and it has come to the end. Therefore, the verse states appropriately, "The end of all flesh," etc. It is also written there the reason why repentance is not effective for this sin, according to what is explained in the books that in sinning, a person damages his character traits, and in the trait in which he sins, he removes himself from the roots of holiness, etc. However, he is not uprooted, Heaven forbid, from his root, and therefore, when he repents, he brings new life from his root to the limb and the channel that has weakened, etc. But in the serious sin mentioned above, it is as if he completely removes his root, as explained in the holy books, and therefore he has almost no remedy. Only with difficulty does repentance awaken a person to a voluntary conduct that is above nature, and may he be gracious and answered by the Lord even when returning from this sin, etc. This is as mentioned above, through a true self-sacrifice to the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the sin of the generation of the Flood, emphasizing that their transgression involved corrupting their offspring, which rendered repentance ineffective. It explains that while ordinary sins can be rectified through repentance by reconnecting to one's spiritual roots, this particular sin severed the connection entirely, making it nearly impossible to remedy. The text highlights the necessity of a profound self-sacrifice and intense longing for God to invoke divine mercy, suggesting that even in such dire circumstances, a sincere return to God can elicit a response beyond natural limitations.

passage_content: ובזה יל"פ הפסוק הסירו רוע מעלליכם מנגד עיני וגו' דלכאורה מאמר מנגד עיני צ"ב, דאף שזה ודאי רק לסבר את האוזן, כי אצל הקב"ה לא יתכן שום בחי' גשם כלל, אבל עם כל זה צ"ב מה צורך לומר מנגד עיני ומהו הכוונה בזה, ונל"פ דהנה יש חושבין בלבם , כי בזה שעבר עליהם רוח חרטה פעם אחת ולעתים נשבר לבו בקרבו, כבר יצא ידי חובת תשובה כראוי ונמחק החטא, ע"כ השמיענו הפסוק שלא די בזה, כי אם רחצו הזכו הסירו רוע מעלליכם מנגד עיני, כלומר שתהי' התשובה כ"כ עד שיוסר העון גם מנגד עיני, וע"ד שכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל בה' תשובה עד שיעיד עליו יודע תעלומות שלא ישיב לכסלה עוד.
translation: And in this, the verse "Remove evil from your deeds from before My eyes" can be explained. At first glance, the phrase "from before My eyes" is puzzling, for although this is certainly only to please the ear, since with the Holy One, blessed be He, no physical aspect is possible at all, nevertheless, it is puzzling what the need is to say "from before My eyes" and what the intention is in this. We can explain that there are those who think in their hearts that by having experienced a fleeting moment of regret and occasionally having a broken heart within them, they have fulfilled their obligation of repentance properly and their sin has been erased. Therefore, the verse teaches us that this is not enough, for it says, "Wash yourselves, make yourselves clean, remove the evil of your deeds from before My eyes," meaning that the repentance should be such that the sin is removed even from before My eyes, in accordance with what the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the laws of repentance, that one should testify about him, the Knower of Secrets, that he will not return to his folly anymore.
summary: The passage discusses the verse "Remove evil from before My eyes," questioning the necessity of the phrase "before My eyes" in relation to God's perception, as He is beyond physicality. It emphasizes that mere feelings of remorse or a fleeting moment of regret are insufficient for true repentance. Instead, genuine repentance must be profound enough to remove the sin entirely from God's sight, aligning with the Rambam's teaching that true repentance is recognized by God, ensuring that the individual will not return to their previous sins.

passage_content: או"י עפי"מ שפירשו בספה"ק אמרינו בתפלת ר"ה כי זוכר כל הנשכחות אתה, ר"ל דאם אדם עושה מצוה וזוכרו להתפאר בו אז נשכח זכותו למעלה, ורק אם אינו מתפאר בו וה"ה בבחי ' שכחה אצלו אז מזכירין זכותו למעלה, וכמו"כ בעבירות מי שחטאתו נגדו תמיד ומתאונן ע"ז כל ימי חייו אז אין מזכירין חטאו למעלה, אבל אם שוכח עוונותיו אז נזכר החטא ח"ו למעלה, וז"ש זוכר כל הנשכחות שהקב"ה זוכר מה שנשכח מלב האדם, ואפ"ל בכוונת הפסוק מ"ש הסירו רוע מעלליכם מנגד עיני ולא אמר מנגד עיניכם כי צריך שיהיו לזכרון בין עיניך תמיד ויהי' לבו נשבר בקרבו, מה נאמר ומה נדבר ורחוקים אנחנו מבחי ' זו הרבה מאוד, אבל עכ"ז כל נקודה של תשובה מועיל קצת להחליש כובד החטא, וידוע פתגם הרה"ק הר"ר זושא זלה"ה כי מעולם לא ראה מלאך הנברא מעבירות ישראל שיהי' שלם בגופו ואבריו, כי האדם החוטא מתאנח על העבירה שעשה, והאנחה שוברת גופו של המלאך הנברא ממעשה החטא ונעשה מחוסר אברים, ועד"ז י"ל לענין תפלה, דמ"ש רז"ל דהמוציא זרע לבטלה נדחה תפלתו ר"ל, היינו שהמקטריגים מונעים ומעכבים תפלתו מלעלות, אבל כ"ז רק בשלא עשה תשובה, אבל ע"י תשובה מחליש כח המקטריגים והבוי"ת ברוב רחמיו וחסדיו חותר חתירה ומקבל אותם, כי קרוב ה' לכל קוראיו לכל אשר יקראוהו באמת.
translation:
In the name of God, as explained in the holy books, we say in the prayer of Rosh Hashanah that "You remember all that is forgotten," meaning that if a person performs a mitzvah and remembers it to boast about it, then his merit is forgotten above. Only if he does not boast about it, and similarly in the aspect of 'forgetfulness' on his part, then his merit is remembered above. Likewise, regarding sins, one who has his sin constantly before him and laments it all his days, then his sin is not mentioned above. But if he forgets his transgressions, then the sin is remembered above, Heaven forbid. And this is what is meant by "You remember all that is forgotten," that the Holy One, blessed be He, remembers what has been forgotten from the heart of man. 

And it can also be said regarding the intention of the verse, "Remove evil from your deeds from before My eyes," and it does not say "from before your eyes," because it is necessary that they be a remembrance between your eyes always, and that his heart be broken within him. What can we say and what can we speak? We are very far from this aspect, but nevertheless, every point of repentance helps somewhat to lessen the weight of sin. 

And it is known the saying of the holy Rabbi Zusha, may his merit protect us, that he never saw an angel created from the sins of Israel that was whole in its body and limbs, for the sinful person sighs over the sin he has committed, and the sigh breaks the body of the angel created from the act of sin, and it becomes lacking in limbs. 

And similarly, it can be said regarding prayer, that which our sages of blessed memory said that one who emits seed in vain, his prayer is rejected, meaning that the accusers prevent and delay his prayer from ascending. But all this is only if he has not repented. However, through repentance, the power of the accusers is weakened, and the Blessed One, in His abundant mercy and kindness, makes an effort and accepts them, for the Lord is close to all who call upon Him, to all who call upon Him in truth.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine remembrance and forgetfulness in relation to human actions, emphasizing that when a person boasts about their good deeds, those merits are forgotten in the heavenly realm. Conversely, if one forgets their sins, those transgressions are remembered. It highlights the importance of sincere repentance, which can weaken the power of accusers and allow prayers to ascend despite past wrongdoings. Ultimately, it conveys that God is close to those who call upon Him sincerely, reflecting the transformative power of genuine remorse and the potential for redemption.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר דבריהם ז"ל במדרש הנ"ל שיעצו החרטומים לשחוט ילדי ישראל וכו ', ואפ"ל הכוונה עפימ"ש בספה"ק דבחטא זה מוסיפים כח להסט"א רח"ל , וכהמשל שהביא ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה , לאחד שיצא ללחום והוליך אתו כלי זיינו. וכשנשבה ביד האויב נלקה באותו כלי זיין עצמו שהוא מסר לידם, וענין המשל דכלי זיינם של ישראל המה ניצה"ק ענפי הקדושה לכ"א מישראל משורש נשמתו, ואם ח"ו פוגמין בחטא הזה נמסר הכח להסט"א רח"ל , ובאותו הכח מכים את ישראל ח"ו, וכתב השלה"ק (במאמר מצה עשירה) וירעו אותנו המצריים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים לה' עיי"ש, וחטא זה נקרא רע כנודע, ולז"א אין לך רפואה אא"כ תרחץ בדמיהם דזהו סם מרפא לפרעה שהוא הסט"א , ועי"ז הם מתגברים להחטיא את ישראל עוד, וזהו הכוונה שהי' שוחט ילדי ישראל, כלומר שהחטיאו את ישראל בעון הנורא הזה, וחכז"ל רמזו זאת במתק לשונם כדרך אגדות הש"ס בכ"מ , שהלבישו חז"ל בפנימותן רמזים וסודות נפלאים עד אין חקר.
translation: And we will explain their words, may their memory be blessed, in the aforementioned Midrash, that the sorcerers advised to slaughter the children of Israel, etc. And it can be said that the intention is according to what is stated in the holy books, that through this sin they give strength to the Other Side, Heaven forbid. And as the parable brought by Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Gur, to one who went out to battle and took his weapons with him. And when he was captured by the enemy, he was struck by that very weapon he had handed over to them. And the matter of the parable is that the weapons of Israel are the holy sparks, the branches of holiness for each Jew from the root of his soul. And if, Heaven forbid, they are blemished by this sin, the power is given to the Other Side, Heaven forbid, and with that power they strike Israel, Heaven forbid. And the Shlah HaKadosh wrote (in the essay on matzah ashira) that the Egyptians made us evil and sinners before the Lord, see there. And this sin is called evil, as is known. And therefore it is said, there is no remedy unless you wash in their blood, for this is a healing potion for Pharaoh, who is the Other Side. And through this, they strengthen themselves to cause Israel to sin even more. And this is the intention that they were slaughtering the children of Israel, meaning that they caused Israel to sin with this terrible sin. And our sages, may their memory be blessed, hinted at this in a sweet manner, as is the way of the Agadot of the Talmud everywhere, that the sages clothed within them hints and wondrous secrets to an unfathomable extent.
summary: The passage discusses the grave sin of the Egyptians in their attempt to harm the children of Israel, emphasizing that such actions empower the forces of evil (the "Sitra Achra"). It draws a parallel to a soldier who, by surrendering his weapons, ultimately harms himself, illustrating that when Jews sin, they inadvertently give strength to these negative forces. The text highlights that the Egyptians' oppression led to Israel's spiritual degradation, and the only remedy lies in confronting and purifying the sin, which is symbolically represented by the shedding of blood. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the interconnectedness of sin, spiritual warfare, and redemption.
