passage_content: או אפ"ל בפשטות שהיו שוחט ילדי ישראל לע"ז, ע"ד שאמרז"ל בגמרא שם אמר רב המקשה עצמו לדעת וכו' נקרא עבריין שכך אומנתו של יצה"ר היום אומר לו עשה כך ולמחר אומר לו לך עבוד ע"ז והולך ועובד: ולכאורה גם בשאר עבירות כך הוא המדה דעבירה גוררת עבירה, אך אפשר מפני שע"י חטא זה נחשכו עיני האדם מלראות האמת, כמו שכתב הרה"ק הר"ר אלימלך זי"ע בהנהגת האדם, שחטאת נעורים מסמין עיני האדם שלא יראה האמת, וע"י סמיות עינים עלול להכשל בעבירות עוד עד שילך ויעבוד ע"ז, וע"כ אחר שהצליח פרעה להחטיאם בחטא הנורא הזה, נגררו לעבוד ע"ז ממש ולשחוט ילדיהם לע"ז, ולז"א שהיו שוחטין בערב ובבוקר כי אז הוא זמן עבודה, וישראל מתפללין באותה שעה להבוכ"ע , וזה לעומת זה גם הם עובדין לאלילים באותו הזמן, ומפני שפרעה גרם זאת שהרי הוא החטיאם לכן נקרא על שמו שהוא שחט ילדי ישראל, והחרטומים יעצוהו שזה יהי' רפואתו, שעי"ז יתוסף כח להסט"א כנ"ל.
translation: Or it can be simply that they were slaughtering the children of Israel for idolatry, as our sages said in the Gemara there, that Rav said, one who challenges himself to know, etc., is called a transgressor, for such is the nature of the evil inclination: today it tells him to do this, and tomorrow it tells him to go serve idols, and he goes and serves. And seemingly, it is the same with other transgressions, for the measure is that one sin leads to another. However, it is possible that because of this sin, the eyes of a person become darkened from seeing the truth, as the holy Rabbi Elimelech of Lizhensk, may his merit protect us, wrote in the conduct of man, that youthful sin blinds a person's eyes so that he does not see the truth. And through this blindness, he may stumble into further transgressions until he goes and serves idols. Therefore, after Pharaoh succeeded in causing them to sin with this terrible sin, they were led to serve idols directly and to slaughter their children for idolatry. And this is why it is said that they were slaughtering in the evening and in the morning, for that is the time of service, and Israel prays at that hour to the Blessed One, and correspondingly, they too are serving idols at that time. And because Pharaoh caused this, for he led them to sin, he is therefore called by his name, as he slaughtered the children of Israel, and the magicians advised him that this would be his remedy, for through this, strength would be added to the other side, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the grave sin of idol worship and its progression, illustrating how one transgression leads to another, ultimately resulting in the horrific act of sacrificing children to idols. It emphasizes that such sins can blind individuals to the truth, as noted by Rabbi Elimelech, suggesting that youthful transgressions can obscure one's vision of reality. The text highlights Pharaoh's role in leading the Israelites into this sin, indicating that his influence caused them to engage in idol worship, particularly during prayer times, which reflects a profound spiritual conflict. Ultimately, it suggests that Pharaoh's actions were seen as a means to empower the forces of evil, as advised by his magicians.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יובן מאמר הכתוב ויאנחו בנ"י מן העבודה, ע"ד הכ ' ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה ודרשו רז"ל שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, וז"ש ויאנחו בנ"י מן העבודה על שנתפסו לע"ז, וכ"ז נגרם ע"י פרעה שהחטיא את ישראל, ולדרכינו לא פרעה בעצמו הי' שוחט הילדים אלא שהביא את ישראל לעשות כך וע"כ נקרא על שמו, וזה שאמר פרעה הבה נתחכמה לו למושיען של ישראל ר"ל להחטיא את ישראל בחטא הנורא הידוע, ובזה נתחכם למושיען של ישראל לעכב את גאולתם דבזה תליא הגאולה כידוע מספה"ק .
translation: And according to this, we can understand the statement of the verse, "And the children of Israel sighed from the work," as follows: they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. The sages explained that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, and thus it is said, "And the children of Israel sighed from the work" because they were caught up in idolatry. All this was caused by Pharaoh, who led Israel astray. According to our understanding, it was not Pharaoh himself who slaughtered the children, but he caused Israel to do so, and therefore he is called by his name. This is what Pharaoh said, "Let us be cunning against their Redeemer," meaning to lead Israel astray with the known terrible sin, and in this way, he outsmarted their Redeemer to delay their redemption, for the redemption is dependent on this, as is known from the holy books.
summary: The passage discusses the suffering of the Israelites under Pharaoh's oppression, emphasizing their anguish as a result of being ensnared by idolatry. It highlights that Pharaoh, rather than directly harming the children, influenced the Israelites to stray from their faith, thus bearing responsibility for their spiritual downfall. The text suggests that Pharaoh's cunning was aimed at delaying the redemption of the Israelites by leading them into grave sin, which is a key factor in the timing of their eventual salvation. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay between human actions and divine redemption.

passage_content: ויאמר ד' ראה ראיתי את עני עמי אשר במצרים וגו' כי ידעתי את מכאוביו. במד"ר ראיתי לא נאמר אלא ראה ראיתי, א"ל הקב"ה למשה אתה רואה ראי' אחת, ואני רואה ב' ראיות, אתה רואה אותן באין לסיני ומקבלין תורתי, ואני רואה אותן מקבלין תורתי זהו ראה, ראיתי זו מעשה העגל וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה ענין להזכיר ראיית מעשה העגל לכאן, ואין ספק שהבוי"ת רואה ויודע כל העתידות, אמנם מפני שאבותינו במצרים לא הספיק זכותם להגאל , כמאמה"כ ואת ערום וערי', וגאלם הקב"ה ע"ש העתיד שעתידין לקבל את התורה כמ"ש בהוציאך את העם וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, וא"כ הי' ראוי להזכיר זכותם ראיית קבלת התורה, אבל מ"ל להזכיר חובתם ראיית מעשה העגל, גם צ"ב איך לא ראה משרע"ה גם ראיית מעשה העגל כמו שהשיג ראיית קבלת התורה, שהי' כמו"כ עתידות ותליא בבחירה.
translation: And the Lord said, "I have surely seen the affliction of My people who are in Egypt..." for I have known their pain. In the Midrash, it is stated that it does not say "I have seen" but "I have surely seen." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "You see one vision, and I see two visions. You see them coming to Sinai to receive My Torah, and I see them receiving My Torah; this is 'I have seen,' and 'I have surely seen' refers to the sin of the Golden Calf," etc. Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. It is appropriate to understand why the mention of the sight of the Golden Calf is brought here. There is no doubt that the Blessed Creator sees and knows all future events. However, because our forefathers in Egypt did not have sufficient merit to be redeemed, as it is written, "And they were naked and bare," the Holy One, Blessed be He, redeemed them for the sake of the future, that they would receive the Torah, as it is said, "When you bring the people out, you shall serve God on this mountain." Therefore, it would have been appropriate to mention their merit of the sight of receiving the Torah, but instead, it mentions their obligation of the sight of the Golden Calf. It is also puzzling why Moses did not see the sight of the Golden Calf as he perceived the sight of receiving the Torah, which was also a future event and dependent on choice.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses God's dual vision regarding the Israelites in Egypt, highlighting both their potential for receiving the Torah and their future sin with the Golden Calf. The distinction between God's foresight of their redemption and their shortcomings emphasizes the complexity of divine knowledge and human free will. The text suggests that while the Israelites' merits were insufficient for immediate redemption, God's awareness of their future acceptance of the Torah ultimately motivated their salvation. This interplay between divine foresight and human choice is central to the theological insights presented.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ש בספה"ק עבודת ישראל (פ' בלק) עפ"י הקדמת הגאון החסיד מו"ה לוי יצחק זלה"ה (בעל קדושת לוי זי"ע), שאמר בפי' הפסוק וביום פקדי ופקדתי עליהם חטאתם וגו' אשר עשו את העגל, וקשה הנה אבינו אב הרחמן הסולח ומוחל ומעביר אשמתינו בכל שנה ושנה, ס"ד שיכתוב בתורתו דבר קשה כזה, שיזכור לעולם את חטא העגל, ותוכן תירוצו עפ"י משל דאם אחד מגזע טובים וישרים הולך בדרך תמים ועובד את יוצרו, אין זה דבר נפלא כי התורה מחזרת על אכסניא שלה. אבל אם אדם בזוי משפחה יעשה הטוב בעיני ד', יתהלל יותר מבן משפחה הנכבדת בעבור עזבו שרשו הרע ונטה אל הטוב, והנה ישראל קדושים הם, הגם שקבלו את התורה במעמד הר סיני לא הי' הדבר נפלא ומהולל, כי קדושת אבותיהם אשר הורישו לבניהם הוא הנותנת שיהיו עובדי ד', אבל כיון שעשו את העגל אח"כ, והעיזו את פניהם נגד יוצרם, ניכר שהי' בם משורש הרע שלא ניתקן עדיין וכו ', אז גדלה ונפלאה בעיני ד' מעלתם בקבלת התורה, וזהו פי' דברי רז"ל גם אלה תשכחנה זה מעשה העגל, שיהי' נשכח לגמרי כיון שעשו תשובה, אבל ואנכי לא אשכחך זה מעשה סיני, כלומר בעת שאני זוכר מעשה סיני אז אזכור ג"כ בחטא העגל, בגודל קשיות ערפם אשר להם, כדי להגדיל זכותם במה שעשו מלפנים במעמד הר סיני, וז"פ וביום פקדי כשאזכור בם להטיב להם, ופקדתי את העגל, את כח הרע אשר בקרבם, ואז יגדיל ויאדיר זכותם, במה שהם נוטים מהרע הזה לנטות אל הטוב עכלה"ק .
translation: And even though it is said in the holy book Avodat Yisrael (Parashat Balak) according to the introduction of the holy and pious Gaon, Rabbi Levi Yitzchak, may his memory be blessed (the author of Kedushat Levi, may his merit protect us), who explained the verse "And on the day I visit, I will visit upon them their sin" etc., which they committed with the calf, it is difficult to understand: our Father, the Merciful One, who forgives and pardons and removes our guilt every year, how could it be that He would write in His Torah such a harsh thing, that He would remember forever the sin of the calf? The essence of his explanation is based on the parable that if a person from a good and upright lineage walks in a straightforward path and serves his Creator, it is not a wondrous thing because the Torah returns to its own host. However, if a person of a lowly family does good in the eyes of the Lord, he is praised more than a noble family member for having abandoned his bad roots and turned to good. And behold, Israel is holy; even though they received the Torah at Mount Sinai, it was not a wondrous and praiseworthy thing, for the sanctity of their ancestors, which they inherited, is what enables them to be servants of the Lord. But since they made the calf afterwards and brazenly turned their faces against their Creator, it is evident that there was in them a root of evil that had not yet been rectified, etc. Therefore, their elevation in receiving the Torah is great and wondrous in the eyes of the Lord. This is the meaning of the words of our Sages: "Even these shall be forgotten," meaning the act of the calf shall be completely forgotten because they repented. But "And I will not forget you," refers to the act of Sinai, meaning that when I remember the act of Sinai, I will also remember the sin of the calf, due to the great stubbornness of their necks, in order to magnify their merit for what they did previously at Mount Sinai. And this is the meaning of "And on the day I visit," when I remember them to do good for them, "I will visit the calf," the power of evil that is within them, and then their merit will be magnified and exalted because they are inclined from this evil to turn to good. Thus concludes the holy words.
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of the sin of the Golden Calf in relation to the inherent holiness of the Jewish people. It emphasizes that despite their transgression, the act of repentance and their subsequent acceptance of the Torah at Sinai highlights their elevated status before God. The text suggests that God's remembrance of both the sin and the merit of Sinai serves to enhance the righteousness of the Jewish people, illustrating the transformative power of returning to goodness from a place of wrongdoing. Ultimately, it conveys that the struggle against inherent flaws can lead to greater spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפשר לפרש לעניננו דכדי להגדיל זכותם של ישראל בקבלת התורה, הזכיר להם הקב"ה ראיית מעשה העגל דהנה הקב"ה דן ע"ש העתיד לטובה, ואינו דן ע"ש העתיד לרע (עיין בפרשת דרכים שהאריך בזה והביא ראי' מדברי המדרש עיי"ש), ולדרכנו הזכרת מעשה העגל כאן הוא ג"כ לטובת ישראל, ולכך דנם הקב"ה בו ע"ש העתיד כדי להגדיל זכותם עי"ז , ואולי שמשרע"ה השיג ג"כ מעשה העגל בבחי ' ידיעה, אלא שלא הראהו הקב"ה בבחי ' ראי' כדי שלא להחליש דעתו, דאינו דומה ראי' לשמיעה, וע"ד שאמרו רז"ל במתני' (פ"א דיומא), ערב יוכ"פ שחרית היו מעבירין לפני הכ"ג פרים ואלים וכבשים, כדי שיהא מכיר ורגיל בעבודה, ובגמ' תנא דידן מ"ט לא תנא שעירים, כיון דעל חטא קא אתו חלשא דעתי' עכ"ד הגמ ', ואף דידע כ"ג שהקרבת השעירים מעבודת היום הוא, וזקני ב"ד היו קורין לפניו בסדר היום ומזכירין אותו מ"מ אינו דומה שמיעה וידיעה לראי', ויותר חלשא דעתי' ע"י ראי' משמיעה וידיעה, ולטעם זה לא ראה משרע"ה עשיית העגל בבחי ' ראי' כ"א בבחי ' השגת ידיעה, והצדיקים בדורות הקודמים השיגו כולם הנסיונות והצרות והשפלות של דור האחרון עיקבתא דמשיחא , אבל רק בבחי ' השגת ידיעה ולא בראי' כדי שלא להחליש דעתם, ואני הגבר ראה עני, בעוה"ר בדור הזה הגענו לכך לראות עין בעין שפלות ופירצות הדור והירידה הנוראה, כמה גדולים היסורים וחלישת הדעת, השי"ת ירחמנו וישמחנו כימות עיניתנו.
translation: And similarly, it is possible to explain in our context that in order to increase the merit of Israel in receiving the Torah, the Holy One, Blessed be He, reminded them of the incident of the Golden Calf, for behold, the Holy One, Blessed be He, judges for the future for good, and does not judge for the future for bad (see in the Parashat Derachim where he elaborated on this and brought proof from the words of the Midrash, see there). And according to our way, the mention of the incident of the Golden Calf here is also for the benefit of Israel, and therefore the Holy One, Blessed be He, judged them regarding the future in order to increase their merit through this. And perhaps Moshe Rabbeinu also perceived the incident of the Golden Calf in the aspect of 'knowledge,' but the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not show it to him in the aspect of 'sight' so as not to weaken his mind, for sight is not like hearing. And as our Sages said in the Mishnah (Yoma 1:1), on the eve of Yom Kippur in the morning, they would bring before the High Priest bulls, rams, and sheep, so that he would be familiar and accustomed to the service. And in the Gemara, our Tanna asks, "Why did he not teach about the goats?" Because they were coming for the sin, it weakens the mind, thus concludes the Gemara. And even though the High Priest knew that the offering of the goats was part of the service of the day, and the elders of the court would read before him the order of the day and remind him of it, nevertheless, hearing and knowledge are not like sight, and the mind is weakened more by sight than by hearing and knowledge. And for this reason, Moshe Rabbeinu did not see the making of the calf in the aspect of sight, but only in the aspect of the attainment of knowledge. And the righteous ones in previous generations all perceived the trials, troubles, and humiliations of the last generation, the footsteps of the Messiah, but only in the aspect of the attainment of knowledge and not in sight, so as not to weaken their minds. And I, the man, have seen the poverty, in our bad days in this generation, we have reached the point of seeing eye to eye the lowliness and breaches of the generation and the terrible decline, how great are the sufferings and the weakening of the mind. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, have mercy on us and bring us joy as in the days of our affliction.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that God, in order to enhance the merit of the Jewish people in receiving the Torah, reminds them of the sin of the Golden Calf, emphasizing that God judges for the future positively rather than negatively. It suggests that Moses was aware of the sin but was shown it only as knowledge, not as a direct vision, to prevent weakening his faith. The text reflects on the trials and tribulations faced by previous generations, who perceived their challenges as knowledge rather than direct sight, contrasting this with the current generation's painful visibility of moral decline and suffering, while expressing a hope for divine mercy and joy amidst adversity.

passage_content: ואפשר לרמוז עוד בכפל הכתוב ראה ראיתי את עני עמי, כי בכל מקום הכפל בכתוב מורה על הריבוי והתמידות כידוע, וירמוז הכתוב על העינוי והצרות של גלותנו האחרון, וכל הגלויות נרמזו בשם מצרים שהוא שורש לכולם כידוע, ובעוה"ר השקענו בכור הגלות כ"כ עד שאין מרגישים ואין רואים העינוי והצרות והנסיונות , ע"ד שאמרז"ל אין בשר המת מרגיש באזמל, וישראל נתונים בצרה בכל ד' פינות העולם בגשמיות ועוד יותר ברוחניות, ואין רואה ואין מרגיש, והבוי"ת בלבדו רואה בענינו ומביט בשפלותנו וזה ראה ראיתי את עני עמי הכפל ירמוז על ראיות הרבה עד סוף כל הדורות, וזהו ג"כ ביאור הכתוב כי ידעתי את מכאוביו, שנסתמו הלבבות בעוה"ר , ומרוב הרגלם בנסיונות הגלות גם מכאוביהם לא ידעו ולא ירגישו, ע"כ אמר הקב"ה כי ידעתי את מכאוביו שהבוי"ת יודע ונותן לב על מכאוביו ואין זולתו, ולכך וארד להצילו כי כבר כלו כל הקיצין.
translation: And it is possible to hint further at the repetition in the verse "I have surely seen the affliction of My people," for in every place, repetition in the text indicates abundance and continuity, as is known. The verse hints at the suffering and troubles of our final exile, and all exiles are hinted at by the name Egypt, which is the root of them all, as is known. And in our generation, we have sunk so deeply into the crucible of exile that we do not feel or see the affliction, troubles, and trials, as our sages have said, "The flesh of the dead does not feel the scalpel." And Israel is in distress in all four corners of the world, both physically and even more so spiritually, and no one sees or feels. Only the Blessed One alone sees with His own eyes and looks upon our lowliness, and this is "I have surely seen the affliction of My people," the repetition hints at many observations until the end of all generations. This is also the explanation of the verse "For I know his pain," that the hearts have been sealed in our generation, and from their great habituation to the trials of exile, they do not know or feel their pain. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "For I know his pain," that the Blessed One knows and pays attention to his pain, and no one else does. And for this reason, "And I have come down to rescue him," for all the ends have already been completed.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound suffering of the Jewish people during their exile, symbolized by the repeated phrase "I have seen the affliction of my people," which indicates both the intensity and continuity of their pain. It suggests that the hardships of exile, particularly rooted in the experience of Egypt, have become so overwhelming that the people are often unaware of their own suffering. Despite this, God is fully aware of their afflictions and is attentive to their plight, promising to descend and rescue them as the end of their suffering approaches. This reflects a deep theological insight into God's compassion and the enduring connection between the Divine and the suffering of His people.

passage_content: ובמד"ר (פ' ג' סי' ב') דרשו רז"ל כי ידעתי את מכאוביו, יודע אני כמה עתידים להכאיבני במדבר כמה דתימא כמה ימרוהו במדבר יעציבוהו בישימון, ואף על פי כן איני נמנע מלגאלם עכ"ד המדרש, ואפשר לומר שירמוז הכתוב בזה לימוד זכות על ישראל, על פי מה שכתב האוהחה"ק (פ' תבוא) וירעו אותנו המצרים, שעשו אותנו רעים כמותם, וירא את ענינו הוא אפיסת כח הלוחם, שאין בנו כח המספיק להלחם נגד היצה"ר ולהתגבר עליו וכו ', ואת לחצנו זו הדחק, שדוחק היצה"ר את האדם לחטוא בע"כ , ואין אדם שליט ברוחו להנצל ממנו, ולולי הקב"ה עזרו אין יכול לו עכדה"ק , ובזה פירשנו (בדברנו להלן) מאמר הכתוב ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו , דזהו נתינת טעם על שמעתי דעל כן שמעתי מפני שהי' הגורם לחטאם על ידי נגשיו , היינו כוחות היצר וטומאת מצרים הלוחצים אותם וכאונס נחשבו, וע"כ אף שלא היתה תשובתם שלימה ומספיק לגאולתם, אעפ"כ צעקתם שמעתי וארד להצילו וגו' ועד"ז אפ"ל במאה"כ כי ידעתי את מכאוביו. שדרשו רז"ל יודע אני כמה עתידים להכאיבני במדבר וכו ', ואעפ"כ איני נמנע מלגאלם , ונרמז במאמר השם גם לימוד זכות על ישראל שבאמת מה שהכעיסו להקב"ה במדבר ובישימון, לא עשו רק מחמת דוחק היצר, ואח"כ מיד התחרטו וכאב לבם מאוד על שהמרו רצונו ית ' וז"א כי ידעתי את מכאוביו יודע אני כמה עתידים להכאיבני וכו ', אבל כי ידעתי את מכאוביו שמתחרטים וכואב לבבם על מעשה הרע, ומעיקרא יעשו אותו באונס ומתוך לחץ היצר, וע"כ איני נמנע מלגאלם כי רצונם של ישראל לעשות רצונו ית ', אלא שאפס הכח לעמוד בנסיונות והתגברות היצה"ר , ולכך וארד להצילו וגו'.
translation: In the Midrash (Parashat G'doshim, section 2), our sages expounded that I know their pain; I know how much they are destined to cause me pain in the wilderness, how they will provoke me in the desert and sadden me in the wasteland. And even so, I do not refrain from redeeming them. Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. It can be said that the verse hints at a merit for Israel, according to what the holy Ohr HaChaim wrote (Parashat Ki Tavo), "And the Egyptians mistreated us," that they made us wicked like them. And He saw our affliction, which is the exhaustion of the fighting spirit, that we do not have the strength to fight against the evil inclination and to overcome it, etc. And our pressure is this distress, that the evil inclination forces a person to sin against his will, and no person has control over his spirit to escape from it. And were it not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping him, he would not be able to withstand it. And in this, we explained (as we will discuss below) the statement of the verse, "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," that this is the reason for "I have heard," for it was the cause of their sin through their taskmasters, meaning the forces of the evil inclination and the impurity of Egypt that press upon them, and they are considered as if coerced. Therefore, even though their repentance was not complete and sufficient for their redemption, nevertheless, "I have heard their cry, and I will come down to save them," etc. Similarly, it can be said regarding the verse, "For I know their pain," that our sages expounded, "I know how much they are destined to cause me pain in the wilderness," etc. And even so, I do not refrain from redeeming them. And it is hinted in the statement of the Name also as a merit for Israel, that indeed, what they angered the Holy One, blessed be He, in the wilderness and in the wasteland, they did only because of the pressure of the evil inclination. And afterwards, they immediately regretted and their hearts ached greatly for having rebelled against His will. And this means, "For I know their pain," knowing that they regret and their hearts ache over their evil deeds, and initially, they do it out of coercion and under the pressure of the evil inclination. Therefore, I do not refrain from redeeming them, for the will of Israel is to do His will, but they have no strength to withstand the trials and the overpowering of the evil inclination. And thus, "I will come down to save them," etc.
summary: The passage discusses God's awareness of the suffering and struggles of the Israelites, particularly in relation to their sins and the pressures of the evil inclination (yetzer hara). It emphasizes that their transgressions in the wilderness stemmed from the overwhelming influence of external forces, likening their actions to those done under duress. Despite their shortcomings, God remains committed to redeeming them, recognizing their genuine remorse and desire to fulfill His will, even when they falter due to the challenges they face. This reflects a deep theological insight into divine compassion and the understanding of human frailty in the context of spiritual struggle.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' ראה ראיתי את עני עמי אשר במצרים ואת צעקתם שמעתי וגו' ועתה הנה צעקת בנ"י באה אלי וגם ראיתי את הלחץ אשר מצרים לוחצים אותם וגו', יל"ד באריכות וכפילת הלשון. דכבר אמר ראה ראיתי וגו' ואת צעקתם שמעתי ולמה כפל לומר עוה"פ ועתה הנה צעקת בנ"י באה אלי: גם יל"ד בתיבת ועתה דמיותר , ובאוה"ח הק ' דקדק כן, ומפרש כי מודיע ה' למשה כי אז בעודו מדבר עמו באה צעקת בנ"י מחדש, ולזה דקדק לומר ועתה וכו ', ואמר וגם ראיתי את הלחץ לפי דברי התנא שאמר זה הדחק, הוא פרט שלא נרשם בדברי ה' הקודמים וכו ', והכוונה בהודעת כל זה לומר ועתה לכה וגו' פי' תיכף ומיד וכו' לצד הדחק אשר הם נדחקים אין להמתין שום זמן עכ"ל, אמנם גם לפי"ד קשה דאי משום הא לא הי' צורך עוד הפעם להאריך ולכפול, והי"ל להזכיר בתחלה הכל ראה ראיתי וגו' ואת הלחץ וגו'.
translation: And the Lord said, "I have surely seen the affliction of My people who are in Egypt, and I have heard their cry, etc. And now, behold, the cry of the children of Israel has come to Me, and I have also seen the oppression with which the Egyptians oppress them, etc." There is much to discuss at length regarding the repetition of the language. For it has already been said, "I have surely seen" and "I have heard their cry," and why does He repeat to say, "And now, behold, the cry of the children of Israel has come to Me"? It is also noteworthy regarding the word "And now," which seems superfluous. The Ohr HaChaim explains this, stating that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is informing Moses that while He is still speaking with him, the cry of the children of Israel has come anew. Therefore, He is careful to say, "And now," etc. He also said, "And I have seen the oppression" according to the words of the Tanna who said, "This oppression," which is a detail not recorded in the previous words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, etc. The intention in conveying all this is to say, "And now, go," etc., meaning immediately and without delay, etc., due to the oppression they are experiencing; there is no time to wait at all. However, according to this explanation, it is still difficult, for if this is the case, there would be no need to elaborate and repeat again, and it should have been mentioned at the beginning, "I have surely seen" and "the oppression," etc.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the repetition of God's observations about the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt emphasizes His deep awareness and immediate response to their plight. The phrase "and now" signifies a new urgency in God's call to Moses, indicating that the cries of the Israelites have reached a critical point that demands immediate action. The text highlights the importance of divine timing and the necessity of responding to human suffering without delay, reflecting key Hasidic themes of compassion and the active involvement of God in the world.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפ"י דרכו בהקדם דברי התויו"ט אמתני' דאבות (פ"ה מ"ה) ולא אירע קרי לכה"ג ביום הכיפורים וז"ל, יש מי שהקשה ולמה יארע לו קרי אחר שהי' מזרזין אותו וכו ', והתשובה כי יצ"ט והיצה"ר מתקוטטים זה עם זה כשני אויבים, וכשאחד מהם קרוב להיות מנוצח יתחזק על עמדו בראותו כי כלתה אליו הרעה וכו' ולזה הי' קרוב מאוד הכהן להיות בעל קרי וכו' עיי"ש, ועד"ז אפ"ל לענינינו דהנה במצרים הי' התאבקות קשה מצד כוחות הטומאה שהתגברו מאוד להחטיא את ישראל ולמנוע תשובתם על כי בזה תליא גאולתם, וז"ש ראה ראיתי את עני עמי וגו' ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו , היינו כח הלוחץ של כוחות הסט"א הנוגשים בהם להחטיאם, וכמעט שנמנע הבחירה מהם, כי אין כח בדרך הטבע לאדם לעמוד נגד התגברות הסט"א , מכ"ש אם מתחזק עליו בכל כוחותיו, ע"כ אמר הקב"ה וארד להצילו מיד מצרים וגו', ומיד כשאמר הקב"ה דיבור זה של וארד להצילו, הרגישו כוחות הסט"א כי קרובה קיצם להיות מנוצחים, ואז התחזקו בהתגברותם יותר, בראותם כי כלתה אליהם הרעה, וכהמשל שהובא בתוי"ט הנ"ל, וזשה"כ ועתה הנה צעקת בנ"י באה אלי וגם ראיתי את הלחץ וגו' פי' "ועתה" שעכשיו אחר דיבור וארד להצילו וגו' ניתוסף צעקתם אלי ע"י הלחץ אשר מצרים לוחצים אותם בהתגברות יותר, ע"כ ועתה לכה ואשלחך תיכף ומיד בלי איחור, וכמו"כ בדורינו עיקבתא דמשיחא כוחות הסט"א מתגברים מאוד, מפני שקרובה קיצם ומפלתם, ובקרוב תתקיים וכל הרשעה כולה כעשן תכלה, וע"כ הם מתחזקים בהתגברותם מאוד להחטיא את ישראל באופנים שונים ר"ל, והגם שמלחמה זו נוהגת מדור דור כל ימות עולם, אבל עכשיו אנו עומדים בסוף המלחמה וא"א שיתארך עוד הרבה, שהרי קץ המוגבל של בעתה לא יאוחר בשום פנים, ובלי ספק אנו קרובים לזה מאוד, וע"כ התגברות הסט"א נורא מאוד שלא הי' כמוהו מעולם הן בענין האמונה שמתעמלים לנתק את ישראל מאמונתם. והן בשמירת העינים והמחשבות ע"י גודל הפריצות השורר ר"ל בעולם, וכבדה מלחמה זו ממלחמת כל הדורות שלפנינו, והוטל על בנ"א חלושי כח ואינם מלומדי מלחמה כלל, אמנם לה' המלחמה והוא ית ' רואה שפלותינו , ואת הלחץ זו הדחק שכוחות הטומאה דוחקים אותנו, ויתקיים גם בנו וארד להצילו מיד בלי איחור, והשי"ת יהי' בעזרינו שנוכל להתגבר על כל הנסיונות ויוציאנו מאפילה לאורה בב"א.
translation: And it can be explained according to his way by prefacing the words of the Tzav V'Tziv (Mishna Avot, Chapter 5, Mishnah 5) that it did not happen to such a person to have a seminal emission on Yom Kippur, and it is written: There are those who ask why a seminal emission would occur to him after he was being urged, etc. The answer is that the good inclination and the evil inclination are contending with each other like two enemies, and when one of them is close to being defeated, it strengthens its position upon seeing that evil is approaching it, etc. Therefore, the priest was very close to having a seminal emission, etc. See there. Similarly, it can be said regarding our matter that in Egypt there was a severe struggle from the forces of impurity that greatly intensified to lead Israel astray and prevent their repentance, for their redemption depends on this. Hence it is said, "I have surely seen the affliction of My people... and I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," meaning the pressing force of the forces of the Other Side that are oppressing them to lead them astray, and they were almost prevented from choosing, for it is not in the nature of a person to stand against the intensification of the Other Side, how much more so if it strengthens itself with all its might. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I have come down to save them from the hand of Egypt," and immediately when the Holy One, blessed be He, spoke this word of "I have come down to save them," the forces of the Other Side felt that their end was near to being defeated, and then they strengthened themselves in their intensification even more, seeing that evil was approaching them, just as the parable brought in the Tzav V'Tziv. And this is the meaning of "And now, behold, the cry of the children of Israel has come to Me, and I have also seen the oppression," meaning "And now," that now, after the word "I have come down to save them," their cry has been added to Me through the pressure that Egypt is pressing them with even more intensification. Therefore, "And now, come, I will send you immediately and without delay." Likewise, in our generation, in the footsteps of the Messiah, the forces of the Other Side are greatly intensifying because their end is near and their downfall is imminent, and soon it will be fulfilled that "all wickedness will be consumed like smoke." Therefore, they are strengthening themselves in their intensification very much to lead Israel astray in various ways, G-d forbid. And although this war has been ongoing from generation to generation throughout the ages, now we stand at the end of the war, and it cannot be prolonged much longer, for the limited end of their fear will not be delayed in any way, and without a doubt we are very close to this. Therefore, the intensification of the Other Side is exceedingly terrible, such as has never been in the world, both in the matter of faith, as they strive to sever Israel from their faith, and in the guarding of the eyes and thoughts due to the great immorality that prevails in the world, and this war is heavier than the wars of all the generations before us. And it has been placed upon weak people who are not at all trained for battle. However, to G-d belongs the battle, and He sees our lowliness and the pressure of this distress that the forces of impurity are pressing us, and may it be fulfilled also for us, "I have come down to save them immediately and without delay," and may the Holy One, blessed be He, help us that we may overcome all the trials and bring us out of darkness into light, with the help of Heaven.
summary: The passage discusses the intense spiritual struggle faced by the Jewish people, particularly in the context of their redemption from Egypt and the current challenges in the era preceding the Messiah. It emphasizes the fierce battle between the forces of holiness and the forces of impurity, which intensify as redemption approaches. The text reassures that despite the overwhelming pressure from these negative forces, God is aware of their plight and will intervene to save them, echoing the promise of divine assistance in overcoming trials and emerging from darkness into light.

passage_content: וארד להצילו מיד מצרים ולהעלותו מן הארץ ההוא אל ארץ טובה ורחבה אל ארץ זבת חלב ודבש אל מקום הכנעני וגו', ראוי להבין טעם הכפילות וחילוק מקומות בשמות שונות, באמרו להצילו מיד מצרים ולהעלותו מן הארץ ההוא, וכן אל ארץ טובה ורחבה אל ארץ זבת חלב ודבש אל מקום הכנעני, ואם להשמיעני בא מעלת ושבח א"י, ליכללנהו יחדיו אל ארץ טובה ורחבה זבת חלב ודבש מקום הכנעני וגי ' ומ"ט חלקינהו הכתוב.
translation: "And I will descend to save him from the hand of Egypt and to bring him up from that land to a good and spacious land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanite, etc. It is fitting to understand the reason for the repetition and the division of places with different names, in saying to save him from the hand of Egypt and to bring him up from that land, and likewise to a good and spacious land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanite. And if it is to inform me of the greatness and praise of the Land of Israel, they should be included together as a good and spacious land flowing with milk and honey, the place of the Canaanite, etc. And why does the text divide them?"
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the repeated phrases and the distinct names used to describe the land of Israel, emphasizing the divine intention behind the liberation from Egypt and the promise of a prosperous land. It highlights the transition from oppression to redemption, illustrating the multifaceted nature of the land, which is characterized by abundance and spiritual richness. The separation of these descriptions serves to deepen the understanding of Israel's unique qualities and the importance of its divine promise. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic appreciation for the spiritual and physical dimensions of the land as integral to the Jewish faith.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפ"י הידוע דגלות מצרים שורש כל הגליות, וגאולת מצרים שורש כל הגאולות וכתב האריז"ל בשער המצות (פ' ראה) דטרם ביאת המשיח צריכין ישראל להיות בגולה בכל הארצות ללקט משם הניצה"ק , ויש מקומות שצ"ל עם רב מישראל לריבוי הניצה"ק הנמצאים שם, ויש מקומות דתסגי אף בא' מישראל להוציא משם הניצה"ק השייכים לשורש נשמתו, גם מבואר בנבואת יחזקאל (סי' כ) ובדברי רז"ל שלעתיד בביאת המשיח כשיגאלו ישראל ויתקבצו מן הגליות לא יכנסו מיד לא"י, אבל יוליך אותם למדבר העמים ושם יהי' הבירור, וכדרך שהי' בצאתם ממצרים שיצאו למדבר ולא נכנסו לארץ עד דורו של יהושע, ואולי ירמזו הכפילות על כל אלה הבחי ' גאולת מצרים וגאולה העתידה, ולז"א וארד להצילו מיד מצרים ה"ה הבטחה על גאולת מצרים, ולהעלותו מן הארץ ההוא ירמוז על גאולת גלויות אחרים, וע"כ אמר מן הארץ ההוא לשון נסתר. דא"א לפרט כי רבים המה, וישראל יהיו גולים בכל הארצות לטעם בירור ניצה"ק כמבואר בדברי האריז"ל , והבוי"ת יקבץ נידחנו מארבע כנפות הארץ, אמנם לא בניקל זוכים לכניסת הארץ, כי צורך לזה הכנת קדושה גדולה, כמבואר במכילתא (פ' בשלח) דע"כ הקיפם הקב"ה לישראל מ' שנה במדבר ואכלו את המן ושתו מי באר כדי שתהי' התורה נבללת בגופן, וכמו"כ יהי' בגאולה העתידה שיוליך ד' את ישראל למדבר העמים ויוריד להם מן ובאר עד שיזדככו ויהיו ראויים לכניסת הארץ, ולז"א ולהעלותו מן הארץ ההוא אל ארץ טובה ורחבה, אין טוב אלא תורה, אל ארץ זבת חלב ודבש ירמוז על תורה שבע"פ כמו שדרשו רז"ל דבש וחלב תחת לשונך על תושבע"פ, ואחר כל אלה יגיעו אל מקום הכנעני היינו מקום הארץ, וכל זמן שישראל בגולה נעקרה קדושת הארץ משם ונקרא מקום הכנעני, וכשיהיו ישראל ראויין ישכון הקב"ה שכינתו בתוכו ויחזור קדושת הארץ למקומה, ועל זה ירמזו כל אלה לשונות הכפולות ואלה המדמים לזכות לכניסת הארץ מלוכלך בעונות ופשעים, אינם אלא טועים ומטעים, כי לא הם ראויים לכניסת הארץ, וגם קדושת הארץ אזלה לה ע"י המחטיאים בה, כמבואר בדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל פ' וירא דא"י אינה סובלת עוברי עבירה והבן.
translation: And although it is known that the exile of Egypt is the root of all exiles, and the redemption from Egypt is the root of all redemptions, the Ari"zal wrote in the Gate of the Commandments (Parashat Re'eh) that before the coming of the Messiah, the Jewish people must be in exile in all the lands to gather from there the holy sparks. In some places, there must be a large number of Jews to increase the holy sparks found there, and in other places, it suffices even with one Jew to extract from there the holy sparks that are connected to the root of his soul. It is also explained in the prophecy of Ezekiel (Chapter 20) and in the words of our Sages that in the future, at the coming of the Messiah, when Israel will be redeemed and gathered from the exiles, they will not immediately enter the Land of Israel, but will be led to the wilderness of the nations, and there will be the clarification, just as it was when they left Egypt, that they went to the wilderness and did not enter the land until the generation of Joshua. Perhaps the repetition hints at all these aspects: the redemption from Egypt and the future redemption. Therefore, it is said, "And I have come down to save them from the hand of Egypt," which is the promise of the redemption from Egypt, and "to bring them up from that land" hints at the redemption from other exiles. Thus, it is said "from that land" in a concealed manner, for it cannot be specified as there are many. The Jewish people will be exiled in all the lands for the purpose of clarifying the holy sparks, as explained in the words of the Ari"zal. The Holy One, Blessed be He, will gather the dispersed from the four corners of the earth; however, they will not merit entry into the land easily, for great preparation of holiness is required for this, as explained in the Mechilta (Parashat Beshalach) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, surrounded Israel for forty years in the wilderness, and they ate the manna and drank from the well, so that the Torah would be absorbed in their bodies. Likewise, in the future redemption, the Holy One will lead Israel to the wilderness of the nations and will provide them with manna and a well until they are purified and worthy of entering the land. Therefore, it is said, "and to bring them up from that land to a good and spacious land," for there is no good except the Torah, "to a land flowing with milk and honey" hints at the Oral Torah, as our Sages have interpreted, "honey and milk under your tongue" refers to the Oral Torah. After all this, they will arrive at the place of the Canaanite, meaning the place of the land. As long as Israel is in exile, the holiness of the land is uprooted from there and it is called the place of the Canaanite. When Israel is worthy, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will dwell His Shechinah among them, and the holiness of the land will return to its place. All these repeated phrases and those who imagine they are worthy of entering the land while being defiled by sins and transgressions are merely mistaken and misleading, for they are not worthy of entering the land, and the holiness of the land has departed because of those who cause others to sin in it, as explained in the words of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, in Parashat Vayera, that the Land of Israel cannot tolerate transgressors. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Egyptian exile and redemption as foundational to all future exiles and redemptions. It emphasizes that before the coming of the Messiah, the Jewish people must gather sparks of holiness from various exiles, with some needing many Jews to achieve this, while others can be redeemed by a single individual. The text highlights the necessity of spiritual preparation and purification through experiences in the wilderness before entering the Holy Land, asserting that true worthiness for the land requires a deep connection to Torah and holiness, as the sanctity of the land is compromised by sin. Ultimately, it conveys that only those who are spiritually prepared will merit the return to the land, restoring its holiness.

passage_content: ויאמר משה אל האלקים מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה וכי אוציא את בני ישראל ממצרים במדרש (הובא ברשיז"ל עה"פ גם מתמול גם משלשום ) אמרו חכמים שבעה ימים קודם הי' הקב"ה מפתה למשה לילך בשליחותו וכו' וביום הז ' אמר לו שלח נא ביד תשלח עד שחרה בו וקבל עליו עכ"ל, ראוי להתבונן איך יתכן שסירב משה רבינו ע"ה לילך בשליחותו ית ' לבשר לבנ"י שהקב"ה עומד לגאלם מהשעבוד הקשה, ומצינו בדרז"ל שהי' מיצר ומצטער מאוד על היסורים שסבלו בני ישראל ואמרז"ל במדרש וירא בסבלותם שהי' רואה בסבלותם ובוכה ואומר חבל לי עליכם, והי' נותן כתפיו ומסייע לכל אחד ואחד מהן, והי' עומד ומצפה בכליון עינים לגאולתן של ישראל ולהקל את סבלם, ואיך כאשר אמר לו הקב"ה לך ואספת וגו' לאמר פקד פקדתי אתכם וגו' מיאן ואמר בי ה' שלח נא ביד תשלח והוא פליאה נשגבה.
translation: And Moses said to God, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that I should bring out the children of Israel from Egypt?" In the Midrash (as brought in Rashi's commentary on the verse "also yesterday and the day before"), the sages said that seven days prior, the Holy One, blessed be He, was enticing Moses to go on His mission, etc. And on the seventh day, He said to him, "Please send by the hand of whom You will send," until He became angry with him and accepted upon himself. It is worthy to contemplate how it is possible that our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, refused to go on the mission of the Holy One, blessed be He, to announce to the children of Israel that the Holy One, blessed be He, is about to redeem them from the harsh servitude. And we find in the teachings of our sages that he was very distressed and pained over the sufferings that the children of Israel endured, and our sages said in the Midrash, "And he saw their burdens," that he was seeing their burdens and weeping, saying, "Woe to me for you!" And he would give his shoulder and assist each and every one of them, and he would stand and wait with longing eyes for the redemption of Israel and to alleviate their suffering. And how, when the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Go and gather," etc., to say, "I have surely visited you," did he refuse and say, "Please, my Lord, send by the hand of whom You will send," and this is a wondrous perplexity.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' reluctance to accept God's mission to free the Israelites from slavery, despite his deep empathy for their suffering. It highlights the paradox of Moses, who is deeply pained by the Israelites' plight and actively supports them, yet hesitates to be the messenger of their redemption. This tension illustrates the profound connection between divine will and human agency, emphasizing the complexity of spiritual leadership and the weight of responsibility that comes with it. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of faith and the challenges faced by those chosen to fulfill God's purposes.

passage_content: ב) ( פ"מ ) אמר לפניו רבון כל העולמים שלח נא ביד תשלח, ביד אותו האיש שאתה עתיד לשלוח דהוא אליהו, כמ"ש הנה אנכי שולח לכם את אלי' הנביא, א"ל הקב"ה לאותו האיש שאתה אומר אני שולח לעתיד לבא אל ישראל וכו' וכ"כ בתרגום יוב"ע שלח נא ביד תשלח, ביד פנחס דעתיד למשתלחא בסוף יומיא ע"כ, והם מתאימים עם דברי המדרש הנ"ל ע"ד שאמרז"ל פנחס זה אלי', לכאורה ראוי להבין כוונת משרע"ה בטענה זו, ומדוע תלה שליחותו באחר, ולפניו ית ' נגלו כל תעלומות שאלי' עתיד למשתלח בסוף יומיא , ואעפ"כ צוהו להיות הוא השליח בגאולה הזאת, וצ"ב כוונת הטענה.
translation: B) (P"M) He said before Him, Master of all worlds, send please by the hand of the one You will send, by the hand of that man whom You are destined to send, that is Elijah, as it is written, "Behold, I send you Elijah the prophet." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to that man whom you say I will send in the future to Israel, etc. And so it is also written in the Targum of Yov"ah, "Send please by the hand of the one You will send, by the hand of Pinchas who is destined to be sent at the end of days." Therefore, they align with the words of the aforementioned Midrash regarding what our Sages said, "Pinchas is Elijah." It seems appropriate to understand the intent of Moshe Rabbeinu in this claim, and why he linked his mission to another. Before Him, Blessed be He, all the mysteries were revealed that Elijah is destined to be sent at the end of days, and yet he commanded him to be the one to be the messenger in this redemption, and the intent of the claim is unclear.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, Moses appeals to God to send Elijah as the messenger for the redemption, highlighting the connection between Elijah and Pinchas, who is also seen as a future redeemer. The text raises a theological question about why Moses insists on another's involvement in the mission, despite God's foreknowledge of Elijah's role in the ultimate redemption. This reflects a deeper understanding of the dynamics of divine mission and human agency in the process of salvation. The discussion emphasizes the significance of chosen individuals in fulfilling God's plans, illustrating the interplay between divine will and human action in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי רש"י ז"ל פ' בחוקתי עה"פ וזכרתי את בריתי יעקוב וז"ל בחמשה מקומות נכתב (יעקוב) מלא ואלי' חסר, בחמשה מקומות יעקב נטל אות משמו של אלי' ערבון שיבוא ויבשר גאולת בניו עכ"ל, ומעודי תמהתי על דברי רש"י הנ"ל, מדוע הוצרך יעקב אע"ה ליטול משכון מאלי' הנביא שיבוא לבשר הגאולה, אטו בלא כך ימאן בשליחותו, והלא אלי' הנביא חפץ בטובתן של ישראל וסובל יסורים עבורם, ותמיד הוא ממליץ טוב ומתפלל על ישועתן של ישראל, ואיך תיסק אדעתין שלא ירצה לילך לבשר הגאולה לבני ישראל, עד שהוכרח יעקב אע"ה ליטול ממנו ערבון, וכ"א מישראל אילו הי' ביכולתו לבשר בשורה טובה זאת, שהקב"ה נתמלא עלינו רחמים להוציאנו מאפלה לאורה בגאולה שלימה ונצחיות, בלי ספק הי' מדלג על ההרים ומקפץ על הגבעות במסנ"פ ממש לבשר לישראל בשורה זו, ומכ"ש אלי' הנביא זל"ט שזהו תפקידו לבשר בשורות טובות לישראל, כמ"ש הפייטן איש עתיד להשתלח משמי ערבות איש פקיד על כל בשורות טובות, איך יעלה על הדעת שימאן לבשר הגאולה עד שהי' הצורך ליטול ממנו משכון שילך בשליחות זו.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, in Parshat Bechukotai on the verse "And I will remember My covenant with Jacob," and he said: "In five places, Jacob is written full, and in five places, Jacob takes a letter from the name of Eliyahu as a pledge that he will come and announce the redemption of his children." Thus far the quote. And I have long wondered about Rashi's words above, why did Jacob, our forefather, need to take a pledge from Eliyahu the prophet to come and announce the redemption? Is it that without this he would refuse his mission? But surely Eliyahu the prophet desires the good of Israel and suffers for them, and he is always advocating for them and praying for their salvation. How can it be that we should think he would not want to go and announce the redemption to the children of Israel, to the point that Jacob, our forefather, was compelled to take a pledge from him? And every one of Israel, if he had the ability to announce this good tidings, that the Holy One, blessed be He, has filled Himself with mercy to take us out of darkness to light in a complete and eternal redemption, without a doubt would leap over the mountains and skip over the hills, literally to announce this tidings to Israel. How much more so Eliyahu the prophet, may his memory be blessed, whose role it is to announce good tidings to Israel, as the poet says, "A man destined to be sent from the heavens of the plains, a man appointed for all good tidings." How can it be conceived that he would refuse to announce the redemption to the point that it was necessary to take a pledge from him to go on this mission?
summary: The passage discusses a commentary by Rashi on the verse "And I will remember My covenant with Jacob," highlighting the paradox of Jacob needing to take a guarantee from the prophet Elijah to announce the redemption of Israel. The author questions why Elijah, who is deeply committed to the welfare of the Jewish people and constantly prays for their salvation, would refuse to deliver the good news of redemption without a pledge. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme that emphasizes the inherent desire of every Jew, and especially prophets like Elijah, to bring messages of hope and redemption, suggesting that the reluctance to announce such news is inconceivable.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפי"ד הרמב"ן ז"ל הסבה למשה בכל הסרבנות הזאת, ענותנותו הגדולה מכל האדם אשר על פני האדמה, שלא הי' מוצא את לבו להתגדל ולדבר אל המלך ושיתפאר לאמר ה' שלחני, ולא על ישראל להוציאם ממצרים ולהיות עליהם מלך עכל"ק , והסבר הענין נראה כי להיות שליח להביא ישועה לישראל או לבשר גאולתם, לאו כל אדם זוכה לכך, אלא מי שכל תנועותיו ופעולותיו בתורה ובמצוות ובמעשים טובים בקדושה וטהרה, והוא מלא רוח חכמה וגבורה רוח דעת ויראת ה', ורק אדם כזה ראוי לשליחות נשגבה ורוממה כזאת. ולכן סירב משה רבינו בשליחותו, כי הוא הי' עניו מכל אדם, ולבו נשבר בקרבו כדרך הצדיקים, והחזיק את עצמו לשפל אישים ומחוסר זכותים , עד שאמר מי אנכי כי אלך אל פרעה וכי אוציא את בני ישראל ממצרים, מה אני חשוב לדבר עם המלכים ומה זכות יש בידי שאהי ' אני השליח להוציא את בני ישראל, כי כן הוא דרך הצדיקים להקטין עצמם ולאחוז במדת הענוה ושפלות רוח, ומכ"ש משרע"ה שהעיד עליו התוה"ק והאיש משה ענו מאוד מכל האדם, ולפיכך אמר להקב"ה שלח נא ביד תשלח ופי' בת"א ביד מן דכשר למשלח, כי הוא לא החזיק את עצמו כשר והגון לתפקיד נעלה הזאת.
translation: And it appears according to the opinion of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, the reason for Moses in all this refusal is his great humility, greater than any man on the face of the earth, that he could not bring himself to elevate himself and speak to the king and boast to say, "The Lord has sent me," nor to take Israel out of Egypt and be their king, as is known. The explanation of the matter seems to be that to be a messenger to bring salvation to Israel or to announce their redemption, not every person is worthy of this, but only one whose every movement and action is in Torah, mitzvot, and good deeds with holiness and purity, and who is filled with the spirit of wisdom and strength, the spirit of knowledge and the fear of God. Only such a person is fit for such a lofty and exalted mission. Therefore, our teacher Moses refused the mission, for he was the most humble of all men, and his heart was broken within him like the way of the righteous, and he considered himself lowly and lacking in merit, until he said, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that I should bring out the children of Israel from Egypt? What am I worth to speak with kings, and what merit do I have that I should be the messenger to bring out the children of Israel?" For it is indeed the way of the righteous to diminish themselves and to hold on to the trait of humility and lowliness of spirit, and all the more so for Moses, who was testified about in the Torah, "And the man Moses was very humble, more than any man." Therefore, he said to the Holy One, blessed be He, "Send, please, by the hand of someone else," and it is explained in Targum that "by the hand of someone who is fit to be sent," for he did not consider himself worthy and suitable for this exalted task.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' profound humility and self-effacement, highlighting that true greatness in spiritual leadership comes from recognizing one's own unworthiness. It emphasizes that only those who are deeply rooted in Torah, mitzvot, and possess qualities like wisdom, strength, and fear of God are fit for the exalted role of delivering Israel. Moses' reluctance to accept his mission stems from his awareness of his own shortcomings, embodying the Hasidic ideal of humility and the belief that the righteous often diminish their own stature. Ultimately, this reflects the notion that divine missions are entrusted to those who maintain a humble spirit.

passage_content: ואולי לטעם זה הוצרך יעקב ליטול משכון מאלי', עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר (סוף פרשת עקב) א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך כשם שנתת את נפשך עליהן בעולם הזה, כך לעתיד לבוא כשאביא לכם את אלי' הנביא שניכם באין כאחת עכ"ד המדרש, גם יהיו שם האבות הקדושים אברהם יצחק ויעקב, כמבואר בדרז"ל שיקומו בתחי ' הראשונה לפני הגאולה, ואולי מחמת ענוה יסרב אלי' הנביא לילך לבשר גאולתן של ישראל וישלח את הגדולים ממנו אברהם יצחק ויעקב ומשרע"ה , אמנם אליבא דאמת הוא נקבע לתפקיד זה, כי הוא אשר עתיד להשתלח משמי ערבות לבשר בשורות טובות, ואם יסרב אליהו ולא ילך נמצא שתתעכב ישועתן של ישראל, ומשום כך נטל יעקב אבינו ממנו ערבון אות ו' משמו, שבבוא עת המקווה יסלק מדת ענוותנותו ויזדרז בזריזות לבשר גאולתן ואל יתמהמה אפילו רגע אחת, רק מיד כשיתעורר רצון העליון ימהר ויחיש להודיע ולבשר לבני ישראל
translation: And perhaps for this reason Jacob needed to take a pledge from Elijah, as it is stated in the Midrash (at the end of Parashat Ekev): The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, just as you gave your soul for them in this world, so in the future, when I bring you Elijah the prophet, you will both come together." Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. The holy patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob will also be there, as explained in the teachings of our sages that they will rise in the first resurrection before the redemption. And perhaps out of humility, Elijah the prophet will refuse to go to announce the redemption of Israel and will send those greater than him, Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and Moses. However, according to the truth, he is appointed for this role, for he is the one who is destined to be sent from the heavenly heights to announce good tidings. If Elijah refuses and does not go, it will result in the delay of Israel's salvation. Therefore, Jacob our father took from him a pledge, the letter 'Vav' from his name, so that when the time of hope arrives, he will remove his attribute of humility and hasten eagerly to announce their redemption and not delay even for a moment, but immediately when the supreme will awakens, he will hurry and hasten to inform and announce to the children of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for Jacob to take a pledge from Elijah, emphasizing the importance of humility and the role of the patriarchs in the redemption of Israel. It highlights a Midrashic teaching that Elijah, despite his humility, is destined to announce the redemption, and if he hesitates, it could delay Israel's salvation. Jacob's act of taking a pledge symbolizes the urgency required for the fulfillment of divine promises, urging Elijah to overcome his modesty and act swiftly when the time for redemption arrives. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay between divine will, human agency, and the anticipation of redemption in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שלח נא ביד תשלח ביד אלי' שהשיג משרע"ה שהגאולה העתידה תהי' ע"י אלי' זל"ט והוא מוכן לשליחות זו, כמ"ש בתרגום יונתן (פ' פנחס) עה"פ הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום ויחי לעלמא למבשרא גאולתא בסוף יומיא , ולפי שרצה משרע"ה לעורר גאולה הנצחית ע"כ אמר שלח נא ביד תשלח וע"ד שפי' התרגום יוב"ע ביד פנחס דחמי למשתלחא בסוף יומיא שהוא אלי' וכמ"ש בפרד"א הנ"ל.
translation: And similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be clarified: "Send now by the hand of whom You will send," referring to Eliyahu, who was appointed by Moshe Rabbeinu, that the future redemption will be through Eliyahu, may his memory be blessed, and he is prepared for this mission, as it is stated in the Targum Yonatan (Parshat Pinchas) on the verse "Behold, I give him My covenant of peace, and he shall live forever to announce the redemption at the end of days." And since Moshe Rabbeinu wished to awaken the eternal redemption, he therefore said, "Send now by the hand of whom You will send," in accordance with the interpretation of the Targum that it refers to Pinchas, who will be sent at the end of days, which is Eliyahu, as stated in the aforementioned Pardes.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption in Hasidic thought, emphasizing that the future redemption will be facilitated by Elijah the Prophet, who is prepared for this mission. It references the Midrash and the Targum Yonatan, highlighting that Moses sought to invoke an eternal redemption by requesting that Elijah be sent to herald the final redemption at the end of days. This reflects a deep theological belief in the interconnectedness of prophetic roles and the ultimate fulfillment of divine promises.

passage_content: ועל פי בחינה הנ"ל אפ"ל במאמה"כ וכי אוציא את בנ"י וגו' ופרש"י מה זכו ישראל שתעשה להם נס ואוציאם ממצרים, דאין הכוונה למעט ח"ו זכותם של ישראל, אבל מקושר למאמר מי אנכי וגו' ומקרא נדרש לפניו וע"ז אמר וכי אוציא, וטענת משרע"ה הי' שאין זכותו מספקת להיות ראוי להוציאם דצריך לזה זכותים רבים כמ"ש הכתוב (פ' פנחס) יפקוד ה' אלקי הרוחות וגו' איש על העדה וגו' אשר יוציאם ואשר יביאם פירש"י בזכיותיו, ונוסף לזכיותיו צריך להכניס כח תשובה בישראל, כדי שיהי' זכותם מספקת להגאל , ומשרע"ה הי' עניו ושפל מאוד בעיני עצמו ולגודל ענוותנותו חשב שאינו ראוי לכל זה, וזאת טען לפני הבוי"ת מי אנכי שאין לו זכותים אף לעצמי, ובאיזה כח אוכל להרבות זכיותיהם של ישראל, וזה שפרש"י מה זכו ישראל וכו' פירוש איך יזכו ישראל על ידי שתעשה להם נס ואוציאם וכו '.
translation: According to the aforementioned examination, it can be said in the Holy Scriptures, "And if I bring out the children of Israel," and Rashi explains what merit did Israel have that a miracle would be done for them and they would be taken out of Egypt. This is not meant to diminish, Heaven forbid, the merit of Israel, but it is connected to the statement "Who am I" and the verse that precedes it. And to this, he said, "And if I bring them out," and Moshe's argument was that his merit was not sufficient to be worthy of bringing them out, for many merits are needed for this, as the verse states (in Parshat Pinchas), "Hashem, God of the spirits, will appoint a man over the congregation," who will bring them out and who will bring them in, Rashi explains, in his merits. In addition to his merits, he needs to instill the power of repentance in Israel, so that their merit will be sufficient for redemption. And Moshe was very humble and lowly in his own eyes, and due to his great humility, he thought he was not worthy of all this. And this he argued before the Blessed One, "Who am I," that he has no merits even for himself, and with what power can I increase the merits of Israel? And this is what Rashi explains, "What merit did Israel have," meaning how will Israel merit that a miracle be done for them and they be taken out, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the humility of Moses, who questioned his own merit in being chosen to lead the Israelites out of Egypt, believing he lacked sufficient righteousness. It emphasizes that the redemption of the Israelites required not only Moses' merits but also the need for the people to possess their own merits, particularly through the power of repentance. The text highlights the interconnectedness of divine assistance and human responsibility in achieving redemption, illustrating a key Hasidic concept of humility and the importance of collective merit in spiritual elevation.

passage_content: העולה מהנ"ל שמרע"ה סירב בשליחותו לסיבת ענותנותו הגדולה וע"כ אמר שלח נא ביד תשלח ביד מי שראוי לשלוח, והבוי"ת לא רצה להתנגד לבחינת ענוה שלו אבל השיבו לדעתו ולשיטתו שאינו כדאי והגון לשליחות הזאת אעפי"כ אם תלך בשליחות השי"ת תצליח בדרכך וז"ש כי אהי ' עמך וזה לך האות כי "אנכי" שלחתיך בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ואם תעשה שליחותי בודאי תצליח ועל ידך יזכו ישראל לקבלת התורה.
translation: The conclusion drawn from the above is that Moshe Rabbeinu refused the mission due to his great humility, and therefore he said, "Send, please, by the hand of whom You will send." The Blessed One did not want to oppose his humility but responded according to his opinion and his approach, that he is not worthy and fit for this mission. Nevertheless, if you go on the mission of the Holy One, blessed be He, you will succeed in your way. And this is what is meant by "I will be with you," and this shall be the sign for you that "I have sent you" — when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain. If you fulfill My mission, you will surely succeed, and through you, Israel will merit the receiving of the Torah.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' reluctance to accept his divine mission due to his profound humility, leading him to suggest that God send someone more worthy. However, God reassures Moses that despite his feelings of inadequacy, he will succeed in his mission to lead the Israelites out of Egypt and that this success will culminate in their receiving the Torah. This highlights the Hasidic themes of humility, divine selection, and the transformative power of fulfilling one's spiritual purpose. Ultimately, it emphasizes that true success in spiritual endeavors comes from obedience to God's will, regardless of personal feelings of worthiness.

passage_content: ויאמר כי אהי ' עמך וזה לך האות כי אנכי שלחתיך בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, הרמב"ם ז"ל ( בפ"ח מה' יסודי התורה) ביאר ענין האות הזה וז"ל משה רבינו לא האמינו בו ישראל מפני האותות שעשה, שהמאמין עפ"י האותות יש בלבו דופי שאפשר שיעשה האות בלאט וכשוף, אלא כל האותות שעשה משה במדבר לפי הצורך עשאם , לא להביא ראי' על הנבואה וכו ', ובמה האמינו בו במעמד הר סיני שעינינו ראו ולא זר ואזנינו שמעו ולא אחר וכו' וכן הוא אומר פנים בפנים דבר ה' עמכם וכו ', ומנין שמעמד הר סיני לבדו הוא הראי' לנבואתו שהוא אמת שאין בו דופי שנאמר הנה אני בא וגו' וגם בך יאמינו לעולם, מכלל שקודם דבר זה לא האמינו בו נאמנות שהיא עומדת לעולם וכו ', כך משה רבינו כל ישראל עדים לו אחר מעמד הר סיני ואינו צריך לעשות להם אות, וזהו שאמר לו הקב"ה בתחלת נבואתו בעת שנתן לו האותות לעשותן במצרים, ואמר לו ושמעו לקולך, ידע משה רבינו שהמאמין עפ"י האותות יש בלבבו דופי ומהרהר ומחשב והי' נשמט מלילך, ואמר והן לא יאמינו לי, עד שהודיעו הקב"ה שאלו האותות אינן אלא עד שיצאו ממצרים, ואחר שיצאו ויעמדו על ההר הזה יסתלק הרהור שמהררין אחריך, שאני נותן לך כאן אות שידעו שאני שלחתיך באמת מתחלה ולא ישאר בלבם הרהור, והוא שהכתוב אומר וזה לך האות כי אנכי שלחתיך בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה עכ"ל.
translation: And he said, "This shall be the sign for you that I have sent you: when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." The Rambam, may his memory be blessed (in chapter 8 of the laws of the foundations of the Torah), explained the matter of this sign, and said: Our teacher Moses was not believed by Israel because of the signs he performed, for one who believes based on signs has doubt in his heart that perhaps the sign was done through trickery or sorcery. Rather, all the signs that Moses performed in the desert were done as needed, not to provide proof of his prophecy, etc. And how did they believe in him at the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai? For our eyes saw and not a stranger, our ears heard and not another, etc. And so it is said, "Face to face, the Lord spoke with you," etc. And from where do we know that the event at Mount Sinai alone is the proof of his prophecy, which is true and without doubt? As it is said, "Behold, I come to you," etc., and "And also in you they will believe forever." This indicates that prior to this event, they did not believe in him with a faith that stands forever, etc. Thus, our teacher Moses had all of Israel as witnesses after the event at Mount Sinai, and he did not need to perform signs for them. And this is what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him at the beginning of his prophecy when He gave him the signs to perform in Egypt, and He said to him, "And they will listen to your voice." Moses knew that one who believes based on signs has doubt in his heart and is hesitant and calculating, and he was afraid to go. And he said, "But behold, they will not believe me," until the Holy One, blessed be He, informed him that these signs are only until they leave Egypt. And after they leave and stand on this mountain, the doubts that arise in their hearts will be removed, for I am giving you here a sign so that they will know that I truly sent you from the beginning, and no doubt will remain in their hearts. And this is what the verse says, "This shall be the sign for you that I have sent you: when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the signs given to Moses and the Israelites, emphasizing that true faith should not rely on miracles, which can lead to doubt. Instead, the ultimate proof of Moses' prophecy and divine mission is the revelation at Mount Sinai, where the people directly experienced God's presence. This event solidified their belief in Moses as a true prophet, eliminating any lingering doubts. The text highlights that the signs were meant to facilitate their departure from Egypt, but the real assurance of faith came from the direct encounter with the divine.

passage_content: ותמהו עליו המפרשים דאין סידור הפסוקים מורים כדבריו, דהלא מאמר וזה לך האות וגו' תעבדון את אלקים על ההר הזה, מוקדם הוא לפסוק והן לא יאמינו לי. וא"כ קשה ממנ"פ אם בזה האות דמתן תורה נתקררה דעתו והלא כבר נאמר לו זה מתחלה ומדוע ביקש עוד אות ואמר והן לא יאמינו לי, ואם גם בזה לא נתקררה דעתו, א"כ במה נתקררה דעתו יותר לבסוף, גם אם עד מתן תורה אין ראי' מהאותות ומופתים להאמין לו, א"כ למה צוהו השי"ת לעשות עוד אותות ומופתים אם אין בהם תועלת.
translation: And the commentators wondered about him, for the arrangement of the verses does not indicate his words. For behold, the statement "And this shall be the sign to you... you shall serve God on this mountain" is earlier than the verse "And they will not believe me." Therefore, it is difficult to understand: if with this sign of the giving of the Torah his mind was calmed, how could it be that it was already told to him from the beginning, and why did he ask for another sign and say "And they will not believe me"? And if even with this his mind was not calmed, then what ultimately calmed his mind more? Even if until the giving of the Torah there is no proof from signs and wonders to believe him, then why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, command him to perform more signs and wonders if they are of no benefit?
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction in Moses' request for signs to prove his mission, despite already being given assurances by God. It questions why Moses, after receiving the sign of the burning bush, still doubts the people's belief in him and seeks further signs. The text highlights the Hasidic concept of faith and the struggle between divine assurance and human doubt, emphasizing that even with miraculous signs, true belief requires a deeper spiritual understanding. Ultimately, it suggests that the signs serve a purpose in strengthening faith rather than merely convincing others.

passage_content: ונראה לבאר דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל בהקדם לבאר במאמה"כ דלהלן והי' אם לא יאמינו לך וגו' לקול האות הראשון והאמינו לקול האות האחרון והי' אם לא יאמינו גם לשני האותות האלה וגו' ולקחת ממימי היאור ושפכת היבשה וגו' והיו לדם, והקשה האברבנאל ז"ל דאיך יתאמת להם באות השלישי יותר מן הראשונות, ואם יהיו מפקפקים בב' אותות הראשונות איך יאמינו במופת הדם שלא הי' חזק כמותם, ע"כ קושיתו , גם קשה אומרו והי' אם לא יאמינו, דאין והי' אלא לשון שמחה, ולשמחה מה זו עושה, אך הענין הוא עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (פ"ז מה' יסוה"ת ) וז"ל ולא כל העושה אות ומופת מאמינים לו שהוא נביא, אלא אדם שהיינו יודעים בו מתחלתו שהוא ראוי לנבואה בחכמתו ובמעשיו, שנתעלה בהן על כל בני גילו, והי' מהלך בדרכי הנבואה בקדושתה ובפרישתה, ואח"כ בא ועשה אות ומופת ואמר שהאל שלחו מצוה לשמוע ממנו שנאמר אליו תשמעון. ואפשר שיעשה אות ומופת ואינו נביא, וזה האות יש לו דברים בגו ואעפי"כ מצוה לשמוע לו הואיל ואדם גדול וחכם וראוי לנבואה הוא מעמידים אותו על חזקתו, שבכך נצטוינו כמו שנצטוינו לחתוך את הדין ע"פ שני עדים כשרים, ואעפ"י שאפשר שהעידו בשקר, הואיל וכשרים הם אצלינו מעמידין אותן על כשרותן, ובדברים האלו וכיוצא בהן נאמר הנסתרות לה' אלקינו והנגלות לנו ולבנינו, ונאמר כי האדם יראה לעינים וה' יראה ללבב עכ"ל. המורם מדבה"ק כי רק שני הסימנים כאחד טובים וברורים ונוסף על האותות והמופתים צריך שיהי' ראוי לנבואה בחכמתו ובמעשיו ומהלך בדרכי הנבואה בקדושתה ופרישותה, וזולת זה אפשר שיעשה האות בלאט וכישוף.
translation: And it seems necessary to explain the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, by first clarifying the verse below: "And it shall be, if they will not believe you..." regarding the first sign, and they will believe the voice of the last sign. "And it shall be, if they will not believe even these two signs..." and "You shall take from the waters of the river and pour them on the dry land..." and they shall become blood. The Abarbanel, may his memory be blessed, asked how it can be that they will be more convinced by the third sign than by the first ones. If they are doubting the first two signs, how will they believe in the miracle of the blood, which was not as strong as the first ones? This is his question. It is also difficult to say, "And it shall be, if they will not believe," for "and it shall be" is only a term of joy, and what joy does this bring? However, the matter is as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, states (in chapter 7 of the laws of the foundations of Torah): "Not everyone who performs a sign and a wonder is believed to be a prophet, but a person whom we know from the beginning is worthy of prophecy through his wisdom and his deeds, by which he has elevated himself above all his peers, and he walks in the ways of prophecy in its holiness and separation. Then he comes and performs a sign and a wonder and says that God has sent him a command to listen to him, as it is said to him, 'You shall listen.' And it is possible that he may perform a sign and a wonder and not be a prophet. This sign has things within it, and nevertheless, it is a command to listen to him, since he is a great and wise person and worthy of prophecy. We uphold him based on his standing, just as we are commanded to judge according to two valid witnesses, even though it is possible that they testified falsely, since they are valid in our eyes, we uphold them in their validity. And in these matters and similar ones, it is said, 'The hidden things belong to the Lord our God, and the revealed things are for us and our children.' And it is said, 'For man looks at the eyes, but the Lord looks at the heart.' From this we learn that only two signs together are good and clear, and in addition to the signs and wonders, one must be worthy of prophecy through his wisdom and deeds and walk in the ways of prophecy in its holiness and separation; otherwise, it is possible to perform the sign through sorcery and trickery.
summary: The passage discusses the criteria for recognizing a true prophet, emphasizing that belief in miracles alone is insufficient; one must also consider the prophet's wisdom and righteous conduct. It references the Rambam's assertion that a prophet must demonstrate a consistent path of holiness and separation before performing signs. The text highlights the importance of both miraculous signs and the prophet's character, suggesting that without this moral and spiritual foundation, miracles could be deceptive or the result of sorcery. Ultimately, it underscores the need for discernment in matters of faith, as true understanding lies beyond mere appearances.

passage_content: ומעתה אפ"ל דמשרע"ה לגודל ענותנותו חש שיחשדו אותו בכך שאין נבואתו אמת ולא נראה אליו ד', וז"ש והן לא יאמינו לי ולא ישמעו בקולי, והנתינת טעם לזה כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד' ואינך מוכן וראוי לנבואה, ויתורץ בזה קושית האברבנאל הנ"ל, דאותן שלא האמינו בצדקתו אין האותות ראי' לגביהם כלל, וע"כ לא יאמינו לב' אותו הראשונים, אמנם יאמינו לאות הדם עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל דרמז להם במכת הדם, שהקב"ה נפרע מאלהותם שהיו עובדים לנילוס והפכה לדם, נמצא כי בזה השפיל וביטל משרע"ה את כח הע"ז , ומעתה אין עוד מקום לחשדא שמא יש דברים בגו ונעשו האותות מכוחם ע"י כישוף וכוחות הטומאה, דהוא עצמו מחזר אחריהם להשפילם א"א שיהי' האות מכוחם, ע"כ ויאמינו לקול האות האחרון בודאי , וזה אומרו והי' אם לא יאמינו והי' לשון שמחה, על שלא יאמינו לאותות כי אם באותן שיש בהם ביטול ע"ז, גם אפ"ל כי ידעו ישראל שלא יגאל אותם הקב"ה בעוד שהם משוקעים בע"ז, וע"כ לא יאמינו בבשורת הגאולה בב' אותות הראשונים, כי היו ישראל עדיין משוקעים בע"ז של מצרים, אבל באות השלישי השריש בלבם ביטולו של ע"ז, וע"כ האמינו על ידו בבשורת הגאולה.
translation: And from now on, it can be said that due to Moshe Rabbeinu's great humility, he felt that they would suspect him of not having true prophecy and that G-d did not appear to him. And this is what is meant by, "And they will not believe me and will not listen to my voice," and the reason for this is that they will say, "G-d did not appear to you, and you are not prepared and worthy of prophecy." This resolves the question of the Abarbanel mentioned above, that those who did not believe in his righteousness, the signs are not a proof for them at all. Therefore, they will not believe the first two signs. However, they will believe the sign of the blood, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that it hinted to them in the plague of blood, that the Holy One, blessed be He, took vengeance on their idolatry, which was the worship of the Nile, and turned it into blood. Thus, through this, Moshe Rabbeinu humiliated and nullified the power of idolatry. From now on, there is no longer a place for suspicion that perhaps there are things behind it, and the signs were done through sorcery and the forces of impurity, for he himself is pursuing them to humiliate them; it cannot be that the sign is through them. Therefore, they will certainly believe the voice of the last sign. This is what is meant by, "And it will be, if they do not believe," which is a language of joy, for they will not believe in the signs except for those that involve the nullification of idolatry. It can also be said that the Israelites knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not redeem them while they were still immersed in idolatry. Therefore, they would not believe in the tidings of redemption with the first two signs, as the Israelites were still immersed in the idolatry of Egypt. But with the third sign, it rooted in their hearts the nullification of idolatry, and therefore they believed through it in the tidings of redemption.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' humility and his concern that the Israelites would doubt his prophetic legitimacy, as they had not witnessed God's presence. It emphasizes that the initial signs would not convince those who doubted his righteousness, but the third sign, which symbolized the nullification of idolatry, would instill faith in the Israelites regarding their redemption. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the necessity of spiritual purity and the rejection of idolatry for divine intervention and salvation. Ultimately, the text illustrates that true faith arises when one recognizes the futility of false gods in the face of God's power.

passage_content: ובזה יתורצו דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל, דאף שאמת הדבר דמאמר וזה לך האות וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה מוקדם למאמר והן לא יאמינו לי, אולם עדיין היו ישראל עוע"ז באותה שעה כמבואר בדברי רז"ל, וע"כ הי' מרע"ה עומד ומהרהר איך אפשר שיזכו לקבלת התורה אם הם אדוקים עדיין בע"ז. וכמ"ש ז"ל (שבת פ"ז ע"א) דדריש משרע"ה ק"ו ושבר את הלוחות, ומה פסח שהוא אחד מתרי"ג מצות אמרה תורה כל בן נכר לא יאכל בו, התורה כולה כאן וישראל מומרים עאכו"כ, וע"כ אמר משרע"ה והן לא יאמינו לי, ואף שכבר א"ל הקב"ה האות של קבלת התורה לא נתקררה דעתו בזה, דעד שלא נתבטל ונשתרש הע"ז מלבם א"א שיזכו לקבלת התורה, אמנם הרגיעה רוחו ונתקררה דעתו אחרי שצוהו הקב"ה לעשות אות הדם שיש בו ביטול ע"ז, ועי"ז יתאמת האות של מתן תורה, והבוי"ת מגיד מראשית אחרית שעתידים ישראל לפרוש מע"ז לפני קבלת התורה, וע"כ א"ל למשרע"ה וזה לך האות וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, כי יהי' בזה בירור אמיתי להאמין בנבואתו, אולם משרע"ה לא נתקררה דעתו עד אות השלישי שנתאמת אצל ישראל ביטולו של ע"ז, וא"ש דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל שהי' משה נשמע מלילך ואמר והן לא יאמינו לי עד שהודיעו הקב"ה וכו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה. כי עי"ז בלבד נתברר לישראל האמנת נבואתו, ונתבאר לו פירושו ע"י הודעת אות השלישי, ואז הרגיעה רוחו באות דמ"ת .
translation: And with this, the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, are clarified, for although it is true that the statement "And this shall be the sign for you..." (Exodus 3:12) precedes the statement "And they will not believe me," nonetheless, at that moment, the Israelites were still idolaters, as explained in the words of our Sages. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu was standing and pondering how it would be possible for them to merit the acceptance of the Torah if they were still attached to idolatry. As our Sages have said (Shabbat 87a), he derived a fortiori reasoning and broke the tablets, for regarding Passover, which is one of the 613 commandments, the Torah states that no foreigner may eat of it; the entire Torah is here, and the Israelites are apostates, all the more so. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu said, "And they will not believe me," and even though the Holy One, blessed be He, had already told him the sign of the acceptance of the Torah, his mind was not at ease about this, for until idolatry was nullified and uprooted from their hearts, it would be impossible for them to merit the acceptance of the Torah. However, his spirit was calmed and his mind was set at ease after the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded him to perform the sign of the blood, which signifies the nullification of idolatry, and through this, the sign of the giving of the Torah would be confirmed. The Blessed One reveals from the beginning what will happen at the end, that the Israelites will distance themselves from idolatry before the acceptance of the Torah. Therefore, He said to Moshe Rabbeinu, "And this shall be the sign for you... you shall serve God upon this mountain," for this would provide a true clarification to believe in his prophecy. However, Moshe Rabbeinu's mind was not at ease until the third sign confirmed for the Israelites the nullification of idolatry. And this explains the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, that Moshe was hesitant to go and said, "And they will not believe me," until the Holy One, blessed be He, informed him, "You shall serve God upon this mountain." For through this alone was the belief in his prophecy clarified to the Israelites, and its meaning was explained to him through the announcement of the third sign, and then his spirit was calmed with the sign of the giving of the Torah.
summary: The passage discusses the challenges faced by Moses in ensuring the Israelites' readiness to receive the Torah, particularly their lingering adherence to idolatry. It emphasizes that despite God's assurance of signs, Moses remained concerned about the Israelites' faith and their ability to fully abandon idolatry before accepting the Torah. The text highlights the importance of divine signs, particularly the sign of blood, which symbolizes the rejection of idolatry and serves to confirm the authenticity of Moses' prophecy. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological concept that true acceptance of the Torah requires a complete renunciation of false beliefs.
