passage_content: ונחזור לבאר במה שהתחלנו, במאמר הבוי"ת למשרע"ה אקי' אשר אקי' והשיב משה רבינו רבש"ע די' לצרה בשעתה ומה אני מזכיר להם צרה אחרת, וא"ל הקב"ה יפה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י אקי' שלחני אליכם, והקושיא מפורסמת דאיך יתכן שהתחכם משרע"ה על אמירתו ית ', והקב"ה הודה לדבריו ואמר לו יפה אמרת, ותירצו המפורשים שהיתה אמירה זו אקי' אשר אקי' למשה לבדו ולא שיאמרה לישראל, וכן תירץ האריז"ל בשער הפסוקים שלא היתה כוונתו יתברך שיגלה משרע"ה הדבר הזה לישראל, וע"כ לא אמר תחלה כה תאמר לבני ישראל אקי' אשר אקי' עייש"ד , אמנם עדיין יקשה לפי תירוצם דא"כ לא היתה תשובתו ית ' מענין השאלה שאמר משרע"ה מה שמו מה אומר אליהם. והשיבו ית ' אקי' אשר אקי' שהוא הודעה למשה לבדו, גם קשה קושיתנו הנ"ל דא"כ למה הודיע וגילה הקב"ה לישראל מאמר אקי' אשר אקי' במתן תורה ולא חש לטענת משרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, (עיין קושיא א' וב' הנ"ל).
translation: And we will return to clarify what we began with, in the statement of "I will be" to Moshe Rabbeinu, "I will be" and Moshe our teacher said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, "What shall I say to them in their time of trouble, and why should I mention to them another trouble?" And the Holy One, Blessed be He said to him, "You have spoken well; thus you shall say to the Children of Israel, 'I will be' has sent me to you." And the well-known question arises: how could Moshe Rabbeinu have outsmarted the Holy One, Blessed be He, with his statement, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with his words and said to him, "You have spoken well"? The commentators have answered that this statement of "I will be" was for Moshe alone and not to be said to Israel, and so the Arizal explained in the Gate of Verses that it was not the intention of the Blessed One that Moshe should reveal this matter to Israel. Therefore, He did not initially say, "Thus you shall say to the Children of Israel, 'I will be,'" as is known. However, it is still difficult according to their explanation, for if so, then His response was not related to the question that Moshe asked, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" And He answered him, "I will be," which is a message to Moshe alone. It is also difficult regarding our previous question: if so, why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, inform and reveal to Israel the statement "I will be" at the giving of the Torah, and did not heed Moshe's claim that "it is enough to mention their trouble at the time"? (See the first and second questions above).
summary: The passage discusses the dialogue between Moses and God regarding the revelation of God's name, "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh" (I Am Who I Am). It highlights the tension between Moses' concern for the Israelites' immediate suffering and God's response, which acknowledges Moses' insight while indicating that this revelation was meant for Moses alone, not for the people. The text raises questions about why God later revealed this name at the giving of the Torah, suggesting a deeper theological understanding of divine communication and the timing of revelations in relation to human suffering. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of God's relationship with humanity and the nuances of divine instruction.

passage_content: אמנם יש במדרש חז"ל עוד פי' על מאמר אקי' אשר אקי' שהבוי"ת בישר להם לישראל ע"י משה רבינו שאהי ' עמהם בגאולה זו של מצרים, ואהי ' עמהם לגאלם בגאולה העתידה, ואז יהי' הגאולה בבחי ' גבו', ובאמת מיד בליל יציאת מצרים נתעלו ישראל במדריגה גדולה כמבואר בדרז"ל , ומאז הלכו ונתגדלו ממדריגה למדריגה , ובקרי"ס אמרז"ל דראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל בנבואה, ואח"כ במתן תורה זכו למדריגה גדולה יותר ואח"כ זכו להשראת שכינה במשכן, ואילולי לא חטאו ישראל היו זוכין לתיקון השלם ולגאולה נצחיות, כי הי' נשלם התיקון מיד ולא היו צריכים לסבול עוד צרות הגליות, ואז הי' נתקיים הפירוש אקי' אשר אקי' על בחי' הגאולה לבד, ולא על בחי' השעבוד.
translation: Indeed, there is in the Midrash of our Sages another interpretation of the saying "I will be" which refers to the fact that the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured Israel through our teacher Moses that He would be with them in this redemption from Egypt, and He would be with them to redeem them in the future redemption. Then the redemption would be in the aspect of "His back." And truly, immediately on the night of the Exodus from Egypt, Israel was elevated to a great level, as explained in the teachings of our Sages. From then on, they went and grew from level to level. And in the Song of the Sea, our Sages said that a maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel did not see in prophecy. Then, at the giving of the Torah, they merited an even greater level, and afterwards they merited the Divine Presence in the Tabernacle. Had Israel not sinned, they would have attained the complete rectification and eternal redemption, for the rectification would have been completed immediately, and they would not have needed to suffer further troubles of exile. Then the interpretation of "I will be" would have been fulfilled solely in the aspect of redemption, and not in the aspect of servitude.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine presence and redemption in Jewish thought, emphasizing that God assured the Israelites through Moses of His presence during their redemption from Egypt and in the future redemption. It highlights the spiritual elevation of the Israelites from the moment of the Exodus, noting their progression through significant events such as the splitting of the sea and the giving of the Torah. The text suggests that had the Israelites not sinned, they would have achieved complete redemption and a permanent state of divine connection, fulfilling the promise of redemption without the need for further suffering or exile.

passage_content: אולם הי' גלוי וידוע לפניו ית ' שעתידים ישראל להכעיסו במדבר, כמו שדרשו ז"ל עה"פ כי ידעתי את מכאוביו, שאמר הקב"ה יודע אני כמה עתידים להכאיבני במדבר, כמה דתימא (תהלים ע"ח) כמה ימרוהו במדבר יעציבוהו בישימון, ומדת הדין מקטרגת עליהם על העגל שהיו עתידין לעשות והיתה גלוי וידוע לפניו ית ' שלא יזכו ישראל לגאולה נצחיות מיד, ויצטרכו עוד לשאר גליות להשלמת תיקון החטא, וע"כ התכוין הבוי"ת וגילה למשרע"ה במחזה הנבואה, שיש עוד הבטחה במאמר אקי' אשר אקי' על בחי' הגלות, שאהי ' עמהם בצרה זאת אשר אהי ' עמהם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , כי לפי מצב הדור מוכרח שיהי' עוד שעבוד מלכיות , אבל לא היתה כוונתו ית ' שיגלה משרע"ה הבחי ' הזו לישראל עכשיו בעודם במצרים דדי' לצרה בשעתה, ולמשה לבדו היתה הודעה זו ולא שיאמרה לישראל, ומה שאמר לו הקב"ה למשה על שאלתו מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, והשיבו ית ' אקי' אשר אקי', היתה כוונת ההבטחה על בחי' הגאולה ולא על בחי' השעבוד כנ"ל, ועל דרך זה הודיע ית ' שיאמרה לבני ישראל.
translation: However, it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that Israel would provoke Him in the desert, as our Sages expounded on the verse "For I know his pain," that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I know how many will cause Me pain in the desert," as it is stated (Psalms 78) "How often they provoked Him in the wilderness and grieved Him in the desert." And the attribute of justice accuses them for the calf they were destined to make, and it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that Israel would not merit eternal redemption immediately, and they would need further exiles to complete the rectification of the sin. Therefore, the Blessed One intended and revealed to Moses in a prophetic vision that there is another promise in the phrase "I will be," which refers to the aspect of exile, that "I will be with them in this distress," which means "I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms." For according to the state of the generation, it is necessary that there be further servitude of kingdoms. However, His intention, blessed be He, was not to reveal this aspect to Moses for Israel now while they were still in Egypt, as it was sufficient for the distress at that time, and this message was for Moses alone and not to be conveyed to Israel. And what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses in response to his question about His name, "What shall I say to them?" and He answered him, "I will be that I will be," was intended as a promise regarding the aspect of redemption and not regarding the aspect of servitude, as mentioned above. In this way, He made it known that it should be said to the Children of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses God's foreknowledge of Israel's future transgressions in the desert, particularly their sin of the Golden Calf, which would delay their ultimate redemption. It emphasizes that despite this knowledge, God assures Moses of a future promise of redemption, symbolized by the phrase "I will be," indicating His presence with them during their suffering and subsequent exiles. This revelation was intended solely for Moses and not for the Israelites at that moment, highlighting the distinction between the immediate challenges they faced and the eventual hope of salvation. Ultimately, it reflects the tension between divine justice and mercy in the context of Israel's journey toward redemption.

passage_content: אולם משה רבינו טען ואמר דאעפ"כ כל זמן היותם בגלות מצרים ועדיין לא נגאלו, אם יבוא ויאמר להם הבטחתו ית ' אקי' אשר אקי', אף אם יפרשה להם על בחי' הגאולה, דאהי ' עמהם בגאולה זו ואהי ' עמם בגאולה העתידה, מ"מ יצטערו ישראל ויבינו שיהי' עוד גליות, ולא יהי' מיד גאולה נצחיות, דאל"כ למה צורך לגאולה שנית, ולמה אודיעם דבר זה ויצטערו ודי' לצרה בשעתה, השיב לו הקב"ה יפה אמרת ועכשיו תאמר לישראל רק אקי' שלחני אליכם, וז"ש לו ית ' כה תאמר לבני ישראל, ר"ל שעכשיו בעודם בגלות תאמר להם אקי' לבד, ומלת כה פירושו עכשיו, כמ"ש והנה לא שמעת עד כה (שמות ו' ט"ז), ובאמת היתה רצונו ית ' שיגלה משה רבינו לישראל הבטחת אקי' אשר אקי' על בחי' הגאולה, אבל לא יאמרה להם מיד בעודם בגלות, ובמתן תורה מסר להם משרע"ה לישראל התורה מבראשית ועד פרשת מתן תורה, ונתגלה להם הבטחת אקי' אשר אקי' המפורש בכתוב, אבל אז לא הי' לחשוש עוד לטענת די' לצרה בשעתה, כי כפי מדריגתן של ישראל באותה שעה, שזכו ונתעלו ממדריגה למדריגה מעת צאתם ממצרים, היו מצפים ומקוים שיזכו לגאולה העתידה מיד, מבלי שיצטרכו לסבול עוד צרות ושעבוד, וא"כ הי' נתקיים אצלם הבטחת אקי' אשר אקי' על צד הטובה ועל בחינת הגאולה.
translation: However, Moshe Rabbeinu argued and said that nevertheless, as long as they were in the exile of Egypt and had not yet been redeemed, if He were to come and tell them His promise, "I will be," even if He were to explain to them regarding the aspect of redemption, that "I am with them in this redemption and I will be with them in the future redemption," nonetheless, Israel would be distressed and understand that there would still be further exiles, and that there would not be an immediate eternal redemption. For otherwise, what is the need for a second redemption, and why should I inform them of this and cause them distress? It is sufficient for the suffering to be at the time. The Holy One, blessed be He, replied to him, "You have spoken well, and now you shall say to Israel, 'I will be' has sent me to you." And this is what He said to him: "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel," meaning that now, while they are still in exile, you shall tell them "I will be" alone, and the word "thus" means now, as it is said, "And behold, you have not heard until now" (Exodus 6:16). And indeed, it was His will that Moshe Rabbeinu reveal to Israel the promise of "I will be" regarding the aspect of redemption, but it should not be said to them immediately while they are still in exile. And at the giving of the Torah, Moshe Rabbeinu transmitted to Israel the Torah from the beginning until the portion of the giving of the Torah, and revealed to them the promise of "I will be" which is explicitly written. But then there was no longer a concern for the claim of "sufficient for the suffering to be at the time," for according to the level of Israel at that time, as they merited and ascended from level to level from the moment they left Egypt, they were expecting and hoping to merit the future redemption immediately, without needing to endure further suffering and servitude. Therefore, the promise of "I will be" was fulfilled for them in a good way and in the aspect of redemption.
summary: Moses argued that even if he were to convey God's promise of redemption to the Israelites while they were still in Egyptian exile, it would cause them distress, as they would realize that further exiles awaited them and that the redemption would not be eternal. God agreed with Moses and instructed him to tell the Israelites only the assurance of "I will be" (אֵהְיֶה), emphasizing the present moment of their suffering. Although God's intention was for Moses to reveal the full promise of redemption, it was deemed inappropriate to do so while they were still in bondage. Ultimately, during the giving of the Torah, the Israelites were elevated to a level where they could fully embrace the promise of future redemption without the burden of current suffering.

passage_content: ומעתה סרו כל הקושיות שבענין שלא היתה השתנות רצון ולא חזרה בדבריו ית ', ומעיקרא היתה כוונת הרצון שיאמר לישראל אקי' אשר אקי' על בחינת הגאולה, אבל לא יאמרה להם מיד, כי לא ביאר לו הקב"ה למשה הזמן אימתי שיאמרנה להם, ונתקיימה אמירתו ית ', ומשה רבינו גילה בחי' זו לישראל בשעה שמסר להם התורה כנ"ל, והבטחה זו דאהי ' עמהם בשעבוד זה וכו' למשה לבדו היתה ההודעה ולא שיאמרה לישראל אלא שחז"ל גילו לנו הבטחה זו בדורות הגלות, ובאותה שעה לא גילהו משרע"ה לישראל, וא"ל הבוי"ת יפה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י שעכשיו תאמר להם אקי' בלבד כנ"ל.
translation: And from now on, all the questions regarding the matter that there was no change in the will and no retraction in His words, blessed be He, are resolved. Initially, the intention of the will was to say to Israel "I will be" which refers to the aspect of redemption, but it was not to be said to them immediately, for the Holy One, blessed be He, did not clarify to Moses the time when he should say it to them. And His statement was fulfilled, and our teacher Moses revealed this aspect to Israel at the time he gave them the Torah, as mentioned above. And this promise of "I will be" was with them during this servitude, etc., the notification was only to Moses alone, and it was not to be said to Israel, but our sages revealed this promise to us in the generations of exile. And at that time, Moses did not reveal it to Israel, and the Blessed One said to him, "You have spoken well; thus you shall say to the children of Israel that now you shall say to them 'I will be' alone, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the unwavering nature of God's will and the timing of His revelations to Moses regarding the redemption of Israel. It emphasizes that God's intention was for Moses to convey the message of redemption, but not immediately, as the specific timing was not revealed to him. This assurance of eventual redemption was known only to Moses at that time, while later generations learned of it through the teachings of the sages during the periods of exile. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of faith in God's promises, even when their fulfillment is not immediately apparent.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל עפ"י מה דאיתא בגמ' ( ב"ק דף נ' ע"א) מעשה בבתו של נחוניא חופר שיחין שנפלה לבור הגדול ובאו והודיעו לר ' חנינא בן דוסא , שעה ראשונה אמר להם שלו' שני' וכו' שלישית אמר להם עלתה, אמר לה בתי מי העלך, אמרה לו זכר של רחלים נזדמן לי וזקן מנהיגו אמרו לו נביא אתה, אמר להם לא נביא אנכי וכו ', אלא כך אמרתי דבר שאותו צדיק מצטער יכשל בו זרעו, אמר ר' אבא אעפי"כ מת בנו בצמא וכו' ע"כ, וכתב בשיטה מקובצת ואע"ג דמת בנו בצמא וכו' ולרבינו נראה לפרש, אמרתי כלומר השמעתי דבר זה לפני הקב"ה דבר שנצטער וכו' והסכים הקב"ה לדברי, שכן דרכו של הקב"ה שמסכים לסברת הצדיקים שבדור וכשמת בנו בצמא כבר מת ר' חנינא ע"כ, ועד"ז פי' בעץ יוסף וז"ל והא דמת בנו בצמא י"ל משום דהא דאמר רחב"ד דבר שהצדיק מצטער בו וכו' לא מדת השי"ת קאמר , דא"כ למה מת בנו בצמא, אלא דרך תפלה אמר כן, ולפי שעל בתו התפלל לכן ניצולה בתו ע"י מלאך וכו' אבל על בנו לא התפלל ומת ע"כ, ובמד"ר רות (פרשה ו' סי' ד') ויאמר ברוכה את לה' ר"י אמר לעולם אל ימנע אדם עצמו מלילך אצל זקן לברכו, בועז הי' בן פ' שנה ולא נפקד, וכיון שהתפללה עליו אותה צדיקת מיד נפקד וכו ', ר"ל אמר רות בת מ' שנה היתה ולא נפקדה וכו' וכיון שהתפלל עלי' אותו צדיק נפקדה וכו ', ורבנן אמרי שניהם לא נפקדו אלא מברכותיהן של צדיקים עכ"ד המדרש ואמרז"ל ( מו"ק ט"ז ע"ב) מי מושל בי צדיק, שהקב"ה גוזר גזירה והצדיק מבטלה, והבוי"ת מסכים לגזירתם ע"ד ותגזר אומר ויקם לך.
translation: According to what is stated in the Gemara (Baba Kamma 50a), there was a story about the daughter of Nachunia the digger of trenches who fell into a large pit, and they came and informed Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa. In the first hour, he told them, "She is fine," in the second hour, he said, "She is fine," and in the third hour, he said, "She has risen." He asked her, "My daughter, who raised you?" She replied, "A male lamb came to me, and an elder shepherd said to me, 'You are a prophet.'" They said to him, "You are a prophet." He replied, "I am not a prophet," etc. Rather, I said something that the righteous one is suffering from, his offspring will stumble in it. Rabbi Abba said, "Nevertheless, his son died of thirst," etc. Thus, it is written in the Shita Mekubetzet, and although his son died of thirst, etc., our Rabbi seems to explain, "I said," meaning I presented this matter before the Holy One, Blessed be He, something that the righteous one is suffering from, etc., and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with my words, for it is the way of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to agree with the reasoning of the righteous of the generation, and when his son died of thirst, Rabbi Chanina had already died. Thus, the same is explained in the Etz Yosef, and the statement that his son died of thirst can be said because what Rabah bar bar Chanah said, "Something that the righteous suffers from," etc., is not a measure of the Holy One, Blessed be He, for if so, why did his son die of thirst? Rather, he said this in the manner of prayer, and since he prayed for his daughter, therefore his daughter was saved by an angel, etc., but he did not pray for his son, and he died. Thus, in the Midrash Rabbah on Ruth (Chapter 6, Section 4), it says, "And he said, 'Blessed are you to the Lord.'" Rabbi Yochanan said, "A person should never refrain from going to an elder to bless him." Boaz was fifty years old and was not remembered, and when that righteous woman prayed for him, he was immediately remembered, etc. This means that Ruth was forty years old and was not remembered, etc., and when that righteous one prayed for her, she was remembered, etc. And the Rabbis say that neither were remembered except through the blessings of the righteous. Thus, the Midrash concludes, and our sages said (Moed Katan 16b), "Who rules over me? A righteous person, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, decrees a decree, and the righteous nullifies it, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agrees with their decree, as it is said, 'And you shall decree a thing, and it shall be established for you.'"
summary: The passage discusses the power of the righteous (tzaddikim) in influencing divine decrees, as illustrated by the story of Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa and his daughter's miraculous rescue. It emphasizes that the suffering of a tzaddik can lead to the downfall of their descendants, yet their prayers can also bring about salvation. The text highlights the belief that God aligns with the reasoning of the tzaddikim, allowing them to alter divine judgments through their prayers. Additionally, it underscores the importance of seeking blessings from the righteous, as their intercession can lead to significant changes in one's fate.

passage_content: והנה גזירת הגלות הי' על ד' מאות שנה כמ"ש ועבדום ועינו אותם ארבע מאות שנה, וישראל יצאו ממצרים לסוף רד"ו שנה, ויש בזה תירוצים שונים, ולחד דיעה שאר גליות משלימן, כי הי' הכרח להקדים יציאתם לטעם כי לא יכלו להתמהמה, ובעוד רגע היו נופלים ח"ו לשער הנו"ן כמ"ש האריז"ל , אמנם לפי שנגזר עליהם שיסבלו צער ועינוי ד' מאות שנה טרם יציאתם משם וכמ"ש ואח"כ יצאו וגו', ע"כ מצד מדת הדין הי' ראוי שעכ"פ יסבלו בערך צער זה ע"י ידיעתם שעליהם להשלים הד' מאות שנה בשאר גליות, וזשה"כ ויאמר אלקים למשה אהי ' אשר אהי ' וכדרשתם ז"ל אהי ' עמהם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות וצוהו שכן יאמר לישראל כדי שיסבלו עכ"פ צער ידיעה זו, אמנם התפלל משה רבע"ה לבטל את הגזירה ואמר לפניו רבש"ע מה אני מזכיר להם צרה אחרת, ולמה יסבלו צער ידיעה זו, ויספיק במה שישלימו בשעבוד שאר מלכיות ודייה לצרה בשעתה, והקב"ה הי' ממתין ומתאוה לתפלתו של מרע"ה והועילה תפלתו של צדיק להמתיק מדה"ד ונתבטל הגזירה וא"ל הקב"ה יפה אמרת כה תאמר וגו' ואינך צריך להזכירם צרה אחרת.
translation: And behold, the decree of exile was for four hundred years, as it is written, "And they shall serve them, and they shall afflict them four hundred years." And Israel left Egypt at the end of two hundred and ten years. There are various explanations for this, and according to one opinion, the other exiles completed them, for it was necessary to hasten their departure because they could not delay, and at any moment they would have fallen, Heaven forbid, into the gate of the Nun, as the Arizal writes. However, since it was decreed upon them that they would suffer pain and affliction for four hundred years before their departure from there, as it is written, "And afterward they shall go out," therefore, from the perspective of the attribute of judgment, it was fitting that they should at least suffer in relation to this pain by knowing that they had to complete the four hundred years through the other exiles. This is the meaning of the verse, "And God said to Moses, 'I AM that I AM,'" and as the Sages have interpreted, "I AM with them in the servitude of the other kingdoms," and He commanded him to say so to Israel so that they would at least endure the pain of this knowledge. However, Moses, our teacher, prayed to annul the decree and said before Him, "Master of the Universe, why should I remind them of another suffering, and why should they endure the pain of this knowledge? It is sufficient that they complete through the servitude of the other kingdoms; it is enough to suffer at that time." And the Holy One, blessed be He, was waiting and longing for the prayer of Moses, our teacher, and the prayer of the righteous was effective to sweeten the attribute of judgment, and the decree was annulled. And the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "You have spoken well; thus you shall say..." and you do not need to remind them of another suffering.
summary: The passage discusses the decree of exile for the Israelites, originally set for 400 years, and their eventual departure from Egypt after 210 years. It highlights the tension between divine justice and mercy, as the Israelites were meant to endure suffering to fulfill the decree, yet Moses interceded on their behalf, questioning the need for additional suffering through the awareness of their plight. God responded favorably to Moses' prayer, indicating that the acknowledgment of further suffering was unnecessary, thus demonstrating the power of a righteous person's prayer to mitigate divine judgment.

passage_content: או אפשר דהכלל הוא דגזירה שלא נמסרה לישראל ולא יצאה לבחי ' דיבור, עדיין יש מציאות לבטלה, ומשה רבינו הי' מצפה שיכנס לארץ והוא יבנה את ביהמ"ק ולא יחרב לעולם כמבואר בגמרא סוטה (דף ט' ע"א) שהאויבים לא שלטו במעשה ידיו של משה רבינו, וממילא לא יהי' עוד גלות ושעבוד, ועל כן התפלל משה רבינו שלא יודיעם לישראל מיד כדי שיהי' עוד אפשרות לבטלה, ושמע הקב"ה תפלתו ואמר לו יפה אמרת כה תאמר וגו', מפני שהקב"ה מתאוה לתפלתן של צדיקים, ועי"ז התפלל מרע"ה תקט"ו תפלות שיכנס לארץ עד שאמר לו הקב"ה רב לך, ע"כ עשה השי"ת רצונו של משה וא"ל יפה אמרת שלא להודיע לישראל גזירת שאר גליות.
translation: Or it is possible that the principle is that a decree that was not communicated to Israel and did not come to the level of 'speech' still has the potential to be nullified. And Moses our Rabbi was hopeful that he would enter the Land and build the Holy Temple, which would never be destroyed, as explained in the Gemara Sotah (page 9a) that the enemies did not have dominion over the works of Moses our Rabbi. Consequently, there would be no more exile and servitude. Therefore, Moses our Rabbi prayed that they should not inform Israel immediately so that there would still be a possibility for nullification. And the Holy One, blessed be He, heard his prayer and said to him, "You have spoken well; thus shall you say, etc.," because the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous. Through this, Moses our Rabbi prayed 316 prayers to enter the Land until the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "It is enough for you." Thus, the Holy One, blessed be He, fulfilled the will of Moses and said to him, "You have spoken well" not to inform Israel of the decree of the other exiles.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that certain divine decrees were not revealed to Israel, allowing for the possibility of their nullification. Moses anticipated entering the Promised Land to build the Temple, which would remain standing forever, thus preventing further exile and oppression. He prayed to God not to inform the Israelites of the decree regarding their future exiles, and God, valuing the prayers of the righteous, agreed with Moses' request. This highlights the power of prayer and the potential for change in divine plans through the intercession of the righteous.

passage_content: ועדיין נשאר עלינו חובת ביאור, מדוע אחר שגילה לו הקב"ה למשה שמותיו ית ' אקי' אשר אקי' אמר עוד שלח נא ביד תשלח, וסירב ומיאן ללכת, ואם לא הי' בדעתו לקבל השליחות, מדוע שאל מה שמו מה אומר אליהם (עיין קושיא ג' הנ"ל) ואפ"ל עפי"מ שפי' בתרגום יוב"ע שלח נא ביד תשלח, ביד פנחס דחמי למשתלחא בסוף יומיא . דפנחס זה אליהו והוא עתיד לבשר גאולה העתידה לישראל, ומבואר בדברינו לעיל דכל טענותיו של משרע"ה היו בקשות ותפלות להבוי"ת , ורצה לפעול בתפילותיו שתהי' גאולה הנצחי מיד, וע"כ ביקש שיהי' השליח פנחס זה אליהו, שהוא עתיד להיות השליח בסוף יומיא , ומרוב ענותנותו חשש שהחסרון מצידו שהוא אינו ראוי לכך, וביקש שיהי' פנחס השליח, (עיין בדברינו לעיל באריכות), אמנם מעיקרא לא ביקש משרע"ה על זה שהי' חושב ומצפה שיהי' גאולה נצחי מיד, אבל אחר שגילה לו הקב"ה הבטחת אקי' אשר אקי', והשיג גם בחי' הגלות המרומז בו, אהי ' עמכם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות , אז ידע כי לא יהי' בשליחותו גאולה נצחי ע"כ ביקש והתפלל שלח נא ביד תשלח ביד פנחס, ואולי יזכה הוא להיות השליח לגאולה נצחיות.
translation: And still, we have the obligation to explain why, after the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed to Moses His names, "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh," he further said, "Please send by the hand of whom You will send," and he refused and was reluctant to go. If he did not intend to accept the mission, why did he ask what His name is and what shall I say to them (see the third question above)? And it can be said that according to the translation of "Please send by the hand of whom You will send," it refers to Pinchas, who is destined to be the messenger at the end of days. This Pinchas is Elijah, and he is destined to announce the future redemption for Israel. It is explained in our previous words that all of Moses' arguments were requests and prayers to the Blessed One, and he wanted to effect through his prayers that there would be an immediate eternal redemption. Therefore, he requested that this messenger be Pinchas, who is destined to be the messenger at the end of days. Out of his great humility, he feared that the shortcoming on his part, that he was not worthy of it, and he requested that Pinchas be the messenger (see our previous discussion at length). However, initially, Moses did not request this, as he thought and anticipated that there would be an immediate eternal redemption. But after the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed to him the promise of "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh," and he also grasped the aspect of the exile hinted at in it, "I will be with you in the servitude of the other kingdoms," then he knew that there would not be an immediate eternal redemption through his mission. Therefore, he requested and prayed, "Please send by the hand of whom You will send," by the hand of Pinchas, and perhaps he would merit to be the messenger for the eternal redemption.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' reluctance to accept God's mission despite being revealed the divine name "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh." It suggests that Moses, in his humility, preferred that Elijah (identified with Pinchas) be the messenger for the ultimate redemption, believing he was unworthy of such a role. Initially, Moses anticipated an immediate and eternal redemption, but after understanding the implications of the divine revelation, he recognized that his mission would not lead to an immediate salvation. Thus, he prayed for Elijah to be the one to herald the future redemption.

passage_content: אמנם לא פעל משרע"ה בתפלתו באותה שעה, כי לא הי' עדיין זמנה של גאולה נצחי, והוכרח להיות השליח לגאלם על גאולה זמנית, ולא הי' אפשר בענין אחר, אבל קצת המתקה בודאי פעל משרע"ה בתפלתו, להקל מעלינו עול הצרות ועול השעבוד, וכל מה שיש לנו כח לעמוד ולהתקיים בתוקף הגלות, הוא רק ע"י זכות תפלת משרע"ה והאבות הקדושים, שהכינו בכח קדושתם ישועה לדורות ישראל, אבל עכשיו כבר הגיע הזמן שתתקיים תפלת משה רבינו שלח נא ביד תשלח ביד פנחס זה אלי', ואין בנו כח להמתין עוד, ונבקש על רחמי שמים שנזכה לראות בישועתן של ישראל, ולראות רגלי המבשר, ונהי' מאותם שיזכו לתקן הכל ולסייע אל הגאולה שלימה ע"י עובדא טבא ותשובה שלימה, והשי"ת ירחם על נפשות העלובות שנשתלחו לעולם בדור הזה וצריכין לעבור נסיונות גדולות כאלה, השי"ת יקרב אותנו אליו ואז נשיג ונדע שהכל הי' לטובה, ויהי' זכיה גדולה למי שיעבור בשלום ויעמוד בכל אלה הנסיונות הקשים, ונזכה להתדבק אל הקדושה ולקבל עול מלכות שמים באמת, ושיתקדש ש"ש על ידינו ונזכה לתקן כל אשר פגמנו, ולעורר התעוררות רחמים ורצון העליון, ויתעורר כח תפלת משרע"ה שהתפלל שלח נא ביד תשלח, ונזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקנו בנחת ובשמחה ובאמת ובישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: Indeed, Moshe Rabbeinu did not act in his prayer at that time, for the time for eternal redemption had not yet arrived, and he was compelled to be the messenger to redeem them with a temporary redemption, and it was not possible in any other way. However, some degree of sweetening was certainly accomplished by Moshe Rabbeinu in his prayer, to lighten the burden of the troubles and the yoke of servitude upon us. All that we have the strength to endure and to exist with the intensity of the exile is only through the merit of the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu and the holy forefathers, who prepared through their holiness a salvation for the generations of Israel. But now the time has already come for the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu to be fulfilled: "Send now by the hand of him whom You will send," and we no longer have the strength to wait. We will beseech the mercy of Heaven that we merit to see the salvation of Israel, to see the feet of the messenger, and to be among those who will rectify everything and assist in the complete redemption through good deeds and complete repentance. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, have mercy on the wretched souls that have been sent into the world in this generation and must undergo such great trials. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, draw us close to Him, and then we will understand and know that everything was for the good. It will be a great merit for whoever passes through peacefully and stands firm in all these difficult trials. May we merit to cling to holiness and to accept the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven in truth, and may the Name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, be sanctified through us. May we merit to rectify all that we have blemished, to awaken a stirring of mercy and the supreme will, and may the power of the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu, who prayed "Send now by the hand of him whom You will send," be aroused. May we merit to greet the Messiah, our righteous one, with ease, joy, truth, and the salvation of all Israel and their joy, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, speedily in our days.
summary: The passage emphasizes that although Moses' prayer did not immediately bring about the eternal redemption, it did mitigate the suffering and oppression of the Jewish people. It highlights the importance of the prayers of Moses and the patriarchs, which have prepared a path for future salvation. The text expresses a yearning for the fulfillment of Moses' prayer and the arrival of the Messiah, urging the community to engage in repentance and good deeds to hasten this redemption. Ultimately, it conveys a deep faith in divine mercy and the belief that all trials serve a greater purpose leading to spiritual elevation and the ultimate redemption of Israel.

passage_content: והיה אם לא יאמינו וגו' ולקחת ממימי היאור וגו' והיו המים אשר תקח מן היאור והיו לדם ביבשת, פרש"י ז"ל והיו והיו ב' פעמים, נראה בעיני אלו נאמר והיו המים אשר תקח מן היאור לדם ביבשת, שומע אנו שבידו הם נהפכים לדם, ואז כשירדו לארץ יהיו בהווייתן, אבל עכשיו מלמדנו שלא יהיו דם עד שיהיו ביבשת עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, ראוי להבין מנפק"מ בהודעה זו אם נעשו לדם בידו או ביבשת, ומדוע הוצרך הכתוב לטעם זה לכפול עוה"פ והיו, ואפ"ל דהנה תכלית האות הזה להראות ביטולה של ע"ז שאין בו ממש כי המצריים היו עובדים ליאור, וע"כ אם אחר שיתבטל ונהפך לדם יהי' עדיין בידו, עלול הדבר לטעות כי גם זה נחשב ביטול ע"ז אף אם יש עוד אחיזה בו, לזה הורה לנו הכתוב כי אין זה ביטולה, ואף אם קורא בקול שהוא בטלה ומבוטלת אינו מועיל כלל, רק אחר שישליך הע"ז מידו אז מהני ביטולה.
translation: And it will be that if they do not believe, etc., and you shall take from the waters of the Nile, etc., and the waters that you take from the Nile shall be blood on the dry land. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "and they shall be" is mentioned twice. It seems to me that if it were said, "and the waters that you take from the Nile shall be blood on the dry land," we would understand that they are transformed into blood in his hand, and then when they come down to the land, they will be in their essence. But now it teaches us that they will not be blood until they are on the dry land. It is appropriate to understand the practical difference in this teaching, whether they become blood in his hand or on the dry land, and why the text needed to repeat the phrase "and they shall be." And I could say that the purpose of this sign is to demonstrate the nullification of idolatry, which has no substance, for the Egyptians were serving the Nile. Therefore, if after it is nullified and turned into blood it still remains in his hand, it could lead to a misunderstanding that this is also considered the nullification of idolatry, even if there is still a hold on it. For this, the text teaches us that this is not its nullification, and even if he calls out loudly that it is null and void, it is of no benefit at all, only after he casts the idolatry from his hand will its nullification be effective.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of water from the Nile into blood as a sign of the futility of idolatry, particularly the Egyptians' worship of the Nile. It emphasizes that the miracle's significance lies in the complete nullification of the idol's power, which only occurs when the water is in the land and not merely in the hands of the performer. The repetition of "and they will be" serves to highlight that true nullification of idolatry requires a total severance from its influence, rather than a mere demonstration of power while still holding onto it. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of faith and the necessity of complete detachment from false beliefs for genuine spiritual transformation.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל דלכאורה יל"ד אף לפי פרש"י ז"ל, למה נכתב והיו קמייתא ומיותר הוא, דיספיק לדרשה זו אם יאמר הכתוב והמים אשר תקח מן היאור והיו לדם ביבשת, וכן דקדקו המפרשים (עיין בהרא"ם והגו"א ) עוד יל"ד על יתור ב' לקיחת שבפסוק באומרו ולקחת ממימי היאור וגו' והיו המים אשר תקח מן היאור ויספיק בחדא, גם צ"ב טעם השינוי שהזכיר בתחלה "ממימי'' היאור וגמר אומר המים אשר תקח "מן" היאור.
translation: It can also be said that seemingly, according to the explanation of Rashi, why is it written "and they will be" and it is superfluous, as it would suffice for this interpretation if the text said "and the water that you will take from the Nile will be blood on the dry land," and thus the commentators have clarified (see the Rema and the GRA). Furthermore, one must question the redundancy of the two instances of "taking" in the verse when it says "and you shall take from the waters of the Nile" and "and the water that you will take from the Nile," which would suffice with one. Additionally, it is puzzling why there is a change in wording, initially mentioning "from the waters of the Nile" and concluding with "the water that you will take from the Nile."
summary: The passage discusses the seemingly redundant phrasing in the biblical text regarding the transformation of water from the Nile into blood, questioning why it states "and the waters which you take from the Nile will be blood" instead of a more concise version. It highlights the importance of precise language in scripture, suggesting that every word carries significant meaning. The text also reflects on the theological implications of the distinction between "from the waters of the Nile" and "the waters which you take from the Nile," emphasizing the depth of divine communication and the layers of interpretation within Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ויתבאר עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל רמז להם שבמכה ראשונה נפרע מאלהותם , שהיו עובדים לנילוס המחי' אותם והפכם לדם עכ"ל והנה עיקר ביטולה של ע"ז במקומה ובשורשה, ששם כוחות הטומאה מתחזקים יותר, ולהראות שאין בהם יכולת להציל את עצמן אף במקומם ושורשם, כדמצינו שנצטוו ישראל לשחוט טלה לפסח בניסן דייקא בזמן שליטת מזל טלה שהמצריים עבדו אלי', ומעתה אם הי' משרע"ה בעצמו לוקח מים מן היאור וישליכם לארץ ויהפכם לדם, היו עובדי ע"ז אומרים שכבר נתבטלה מהיות ע"ז ע"י שלקחם משרע"ה מעיקרא לשם בזיון, וע"כ שלטה בו המכה ונהפך לדם, והגם דקיי"ל ישראל אינו יכול לבטל ע"ז של עכו"ם, אולי יהיו תולין לומר דדין ב"נ להם קודם מ"ת , בכל אופן ימצאו אמתלא לתלות בו טפשותם דבע"ז עצמו לא הי' המכה שולטת, ע"כ לקח משה רבינו מן המים שנשאבו מן היאור ע"י מצרי לשם ע"ז, ואותו המים של ע"ז הפך לדם, אמנם גם בזה ימצאו עוע"ז אמתלא , דלפי שנעתקו מן היאור שהוא שורשו, ע"כ שלטה בו המכה, לזה לקח משה רבינו עוד מים מן היאור עצמו ע"מ לבטלה וע"ד בזיון, להראות ביטולה של ע"ז שאין בו יכולת להציל את עצמו בשום פנים, ובזה יבואר כפל הלקיחות, וכפל והיו, וטעם השינוי בכתוב, וז"א ולקחת "ממימי'' היאור, היינו המים שנשאבו מן היאור ע"י מצרי ושפכת היבשה, ולקיחה הב' והיו המים אשר תקח "מן" היאור, שמשרע"ה בעצמו לקחם מן היאור, והיו לדם ביבשת ששניהם יהפכו לדם כשיהיו ביבשה כדברי רש"י ז"ל.
translation: And it is explained according to the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that he hinted to them that in the first plague, retribution was taken for their idolatry, as they were serving the Nile which sustained them and turned it to blood. Thus, the essence of the nullification of idolatry is in its place and root, where the forces of impurity are strengthened more, to show that they have no ability to save themselves even in their place and root. As we find that Israel was commanded to slaughter a lamb for Passover specifically in Nissan, at the time of the dominion of the constellation of the lamb, which the Egyptians served as a deity. Therefore, if Moshe Rabbeinu himself had taken water from the Nile and cast it to the ground and turned it to blood, the idolaters would say that it had already been nullified from being an idol because it was taken by Moshe Rabbeinu initially for the purpose of disgrace. And therefore, the plague ruled over it and it turned to blood. And although we hold that Israel cannot nullify the idolatry of the nations, perhaps they would argue that the law of the sons of Noah applied to them before the giving of the Torah. In any case, they would find a justification to attribute their foolishness to the fact that the plague did not rule over the idolatry itself. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu took water that was drawn from the Nile by an Egyptian for the purpose of idolatry, and that water of idolatry turned to blood. However, even in this, the idolaters would find a justification, that since it was drawn from the Nile, which is its root, therefore the plague ruled over it. For this reason, Moshe Rabbeinu took more water from the Nile itself in order to nullify it and for the purpose of disgrace, to show the nullification of idolatry, that it has no ability to save itself in any way. And this will clarify the double taking, and the double "and it was," and the reason for the change in the text. And it says, "and you shall take from the waters of the Nile," meaning the water that was drawn from the Nile by an Egyptian and poured onto the dry land, and the second taking is "and the waters which you shall take from the Nile," that Moshe Rabbeinu himself took from the Nile, and they became blood on the dry land, that both will turn to blood when they are on the dry land, as the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of the first plague in Egypt, where Moses turns the Nile's waters into blood. It emphasizes that the Egyptians' reliance on their gods, particularly the Nile, is rendered powerless, demonstrating that even their source of life cannot save them. The act of taking water from the Nile, both by the Egyptians and by Moses, serves to highlight the futility of idolatry, as the water becomes a symbol of their inability to protect themselves. This duality in the act of taking water underscores the complete nullification of the Egyptian deities' power.

passage_content: ויאמר משה אל ה' בי אד' לא איש דברים אנכי וגו' כי כבד פה וכבד לשון אנכי, ויאמר ה' אליו מי שם פה לאדם וגו' הלא אנכי ה' ועתה לך ואנכי אהי ' עם פיך והורתיך אשר תדבר, ויאמר בי אד' שלח נא ביד תשלח ויחר אף ה' במשה ויאמר הלא אהרן אחיך הלוי וגו' ודבר הוא לך אל העם והי' הוא יהי' לך לפה וגו' יל"ד הרי כבר הבטיחו ית ' ואנכי אהי ' עם פיך והורתיך וגו', ומדוע סירב עוד ואמר שלח נא ביד תשלח, ואיך נתרצה יותר בהבטחה שני' שאהרן יהי' לו לפה ולמליץ, והבטחה הראשונה טובה ממנה שהבטיחו ית ' ואנכי אהי ' עם פיך.
translation: And Moses said to the Lord, "Please, my Lord, I am not a man of words, etc., for I am heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue." And the Lord said to him, "Who has made man's mouth, etc.? Is it not I, the Lord? And now go, and I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you shall speak." And he said, "Please, my Lord, send by the hand of someone else." And the anger of the Lord was kindled against Moses, and He said, "Is not Aaron your brother the Levite? He will speak for you to the people, and he shall be your mouth, etc." Behold, He has already assured him, "And I will be with your mouth and will teach you," and why did he still refuse and say, "Please, send by the hand of someone else"? And how was he more appeased by the second assurance that Aaron would be his mouth and interpreter, when the first assurance was better than it, that He assured him, "And I will be with your mouth"?
summary: In this passage, Moses expresses his reluctance to speak on behalf of God due to his speech impediment, prompting God's assurance that He will be with Moses' mouth and instruct him what to say. Despite this divine promise, Moses continues to plead for someone else to be sent, leading to God's decision to appoint Aaron as his spokesperson. This interaction highlights the tension between divine assurance and human hesitation, emphasizing the importance of faith in God's support and the role of intermediaries in fulfilling divine missions. The passage reflects key Hasidic themes of trust in God's guidance and the necessity of community in spiritual leadership.

passage_content: ב) בסוף הפרשה ויאמר אליהם מלך מצרים למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו לכו לסבלותיכם, פירש"י לכו למלאכתכם שיש לכם לעשות בבתיכם, אבל מלאכת שעבוד מצרים לא היתה על שבטו של לוי וכו ', ראוי להבין מדוע קרא למלאכת הבית סבלותוכם , ואין זה טורח ומשא מה שהאדם עושה לעצמו ולרצונו בלי כפי', גם מדוע ציום פרעה על ככה ומאי אהניא לי' בזה.
translation: At the end of the parasha, the king of Egypt said to them, "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb the people from their work? Go to your burdens." Rashi explains, "Go to your work that you have to do in your homes," but the labor of the servitude of Egypt was not upon the tribe of Levi, etc. It is fitting to understand why he referred to the work of the home as "your burdens," and it is not a toil or burden that a person does for himself and according to his will. Also, why did Pharaoh command this, and what benefit is it to him?
summary: In this passage, the Pharaoh questions Moses and Aaron about their interference with the people's work, referring to their domestic tasks as "your burdens." Rashi notes that the labor of the Israelites was not imposed on the tribe of Levi, prompting a deeper reflection on the nature of work and servitude. The text suggests that work done for oneself, driven by personal will, is not a burden in the same way as oppressive labor, highlighting a key Hasidic concept of the spiritual significance of one's intentions in their actions. This distinction emphasizes the importance of understanding the divine purpose behind one's labor and the freedom found in fulfilling one's own desires in alignment with God's will.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפימ"ד במד"ר (ר"פ דברים) אמר הקב"ה ראה לשונה של תורה מה חביבה שמרפא את הלשון, הרי משה עד שלא זכה לתורה כתיב בו לא איש דברים אנכי, כיון שזכה לתורה נתרפא לשונו והתחיל לדבר דברים מנין ממה שקרינו בענין אלה הדברים אשר דיבר משה עכ"ד המדרש, והנה ישראל בעודם במצרים כבר הי' להם זכות וכח התוה"ק , כמ"ש הקב"ה למשרע"ה וזה לך האות וגו' בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, פירש"י ז"ל וששאלת מה זכות יש לישראל שיצאו ממצרים, דבר גדול יש לי על הוצאה זו, שהרי עתידים לקבל התורה על ההר הזה וכו' וכתב הפר"ד זלה"ה (דרך מצרים דרוש א') דזה ממדת טובו ית ' שדן את ישראל לטובה ע"ש העתיד. וע"כ חישב הקב"ה לישראל זכות התורה אף טרם שקבלוהו עכת"ד, וק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה כתב דלא צריכנא לטעם זה, אלא מכיון שקבלו עליהם לקבל את התורה כשיצאו ממצרים, נחשבת להם הקבלה כמעשה והי' להם זכות התורה בעודם במצרים עכת"ד, ואולי נרמז זה בהבטחתו ית ' ואנכי אהי ' עם פיך שבזכות "אנכי" שקיבלו עליהם ישראל י' הדברות המתחלת באנכי, יתרפא לשונך מיד ותסור ממך כבדות הפה והלשון, ואולי היתה השפעה זו רק בשביל ישראל כדי שישמעו ויבינו מפיו דברי תורה, שהרי משרע"ה כל ימיו עסק בתורה ואעפ"כ הוכיחו חז"ל שנתרפא לשונו ממ"ש אלה הדברים אשר דבר משה אל כל ישראל, ואפשר שזה היתה טענת משרע"ה במ"ש הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים ר"ל דאם בנ"י לא שמעו אלי יעדר ממנו רפואת הלשון שהוא בזכותן, ומעתה איך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, שחזרה כבדות הפה והלשון למקומה, ולפי שלא היו ישראל בתמידית על בחינתם הרוממה, ע"כ הוצרך באותו זמן להיות אהרן נטפל עמו להיות לו לפה ולמליץ, ובזה יובן המשך הכתובים שהבטיח הקב"ה למשרע"ה ואנכי אהי ' עם פיך והורתיך אשר תדבר, וזהו בזמן שיהיו ישראל משימין על לבם לשמוע דבריו שהם דברי ד' ועצם התורה, אבל כשאינם על בחי' זו אז הוצרך לאהרן והוא יהי' לך לפה וגו'.
translation: And it is said in the Midrash (Parashat Devarim) that the Holy One, blessed be He, said: "Look at the language of the Torah, how beloved it is, for it heals the tongue." Behold, concerning Moses, before he merited the Torah, it is written about him, "I am not a man of words." Once he merited the Torah, his tongue was healed, and he began to speak words, as we read in the matter of "These are the words that Moses spoke to all Israel." Thus said the Midrash. And behold, Israel, while still in Egypt, already had the merit and power of the Holy Torah, as the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe: "And this shall be the sign to you... when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that when you ask what merit Israel had to go out of Egypt, there is a great thing I have regarding this exodus, for they are destined to receive the Torah on this mountain, etc. And the Pardes, of blessed memory, wrote (in the Way of Egypt, Drush 1) that this is from His goodness, that He judged Israel favorably concerning the future. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, considered for Israel the merit of the Torah even before they received it. Thus far the text. And the Hayei Adam, of blessed memory, wrote that we do not need this reason, but since they accepted upon themselves to receive the Torah when they left Egypt, this acceptance is considered an action, and they had the merit of the Torah while still in Egypt. Thus far the text. And perhaps this is hinted at in His promise: "And I will be with your mouth," that by the merit of "I am" which Israel accepted upon themselves, the Ten Commandments beginning with "I am," your tongue will be healed immediately, and the heaviness of the mouth and tongue will depart from you. And perhaps this influence was only for Israel, so that they would hear and understand from his mouth the words of the Torah, for Moshe devoted all his days to the Torah, and yet our Sages proved that his tongue was healed from what is said: "These are the words that Moses spoke to all Israel." And it is possible that this was Moshe's argument when he said: "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me? For I am of uncircumcised lips," meaning that if the children of Israel did not listen to me, the healing of the tongue, which is by their merit, will be withheld from me. And from now on, how shall Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips? The heaviness of the mouth and tongue returned to its place. And since Israel were not constantly in their elevated state, therefore at that time, Aaron needed to be attached to him to be his mouth and spokesman. And this will clarify the continuation of the verses where the Holy One, blessed be He, promised Moshe: "And I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you shall speak." This is at a time when Israel will set their hearts to hear His words, which are the words of God and the essence of the Torah. But when they are not in this state, then Aaron needed to be with him as a mouth, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the transformative power of the Torah, emphasizing that even before the Israelites received it, they possessed a merit for its future acceptance, which was a reflection of God's goodness. It highlights that Moses, initially described as "not a man of words," was healed of his speech impediment upon receiving the Torah, enabling him to communicate divine teachings. The text suggests that the Israelites' commitment to accept the Torah during their exodus from Egypt granted them a spiritual merit, and when they faltered in their spiritual state, Aaron was appointed to assist Moses in speaking. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the deep connection between the acceptance of the Torah, divine communication, and the healing of speech.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יתבאר דברי המדרש שאמר פרעה אתם למה ודבריכם למה, ולדרכנו אפ"ל שהשיג גם פרעה שא"א שיגאלו ישראל כ"א בזכות התורה, ולפי דעתו וידיעתו לא הי' להם זכותים , כי הוא אשר עשה אותם רעים וחטאים, וע"כ טען טענת ממנ"פ , אתם למה איך באתם בשליחות ד' לגואלם ואין להם זכות, וא"ת שיש להם זכות התורה כנ"ל, א"כ אתם למה מדוע באתם שניכם ויספיק במשה לבדו והוא ידבר, ואם אין להם זכות התורה ולכך הוצרך אהרן להיות לפה, א"כ דבריכם למה להוציא את ישראל ממצרים, וא"א מבלי זכות התורה.
translation: And according to this, the words of the Midrash will be clarified, where Pharaoh said, "You, why have you come?" and "What is your reason?" According to our approach, it can be said that Pharaoh also understood that the Israelites could only be redeemed through the merit of the Torah. In his opinion and knowledge, they had no merits, for he was the one who made them wicked and sinful. Therefore, he argued a claim of "Mimnafshach" (from one perspective to another): "You, why have you come in the mission of G-d to redeem them when they have no merit?" And if you say that they have the merit of the Torah, as mentioned, then "You, why have you both come? It would suffice for Moses alone, and he would speak." And if they have no merit of the Torah, and therefore Aaron needed to be the mouthpiece, then "What is your reason for taking the Israelites out of Egypt?" And it is impossible without the merit of the Torah.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's skepticism regarding the redemption of the Israelites, emphasizing that he believed they lacked the merit necessary for salvation, particularly the merit of the Torah. Pharaoh questions why both Moses and Aaron are needed for the mission if the Israelites have no rights to the Torah, suggesting that one should suffice if they did. The text highlights the Hasidic idea that redemption is intrinsically linked to the Torah, and without it, the Israelites cannot be freed from their bondage. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound connection between divine instruction and the spiritual elevation required for liberation.

passage_content: או אפ"ל בדרך אחר קצת, שהשיג פרעה דגאולתן של ישראל א"א שתהי' כ"א בדבר ד' וחוץ לדרך הטבע, וא"א שיחול בשליחות זו כבדות הפה והלשון שהם מאורעי טבעיים, וע"כ טען טענת ממנ"פ אתם למה, ר"ל מדוע באתם שניכם ויספיק במשה לבדו והוא ידבר בשליחות ד', ואם לצד שהוא כבד פה ולשון, א"כ דבריכם למה כי לא יאמנו דבריכם שאתם שלוחי ד' לגאול את ישראל, כי אם צריכים אתם לדרך הטבע אין זה גאולה אמיתית, אמנם מצינו לפעמים שהי' ציווי השי"ת שמשה רבינו ידבר אל פרעה, ופעם צוה שיצרף את אהרן עמו, וקמי שמיא גליא באיזה זמן היו ישראל ראויים בזכות התורה להתנהג עמהם למעלה מן הטבע, וסוף דבר היתה גאולתם רק בזכות התורה.
translation: Or alternatively, in a slightly different way, Pharaoh understood that the redemption of Israel cannot occur except through the word of God and outside the natural order. It is impossible for this mission to be accompanied by the heaviness of the mouth and tongue, which are natural occurrences. Therefore, he argued a strong point: why are you both here? It would suffice for Moses alone, and he would speak on behalf of God. If it is because he is heavy of mouth and tongue, then why do you speak, for they will not believe your words that you are messengers of God to redeem Israel? If you need to rely on the natural order, this is not true redemption. However, we find at times that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded Moses to speak to Pharaoh, and at times He commanded him to include Aaron with him. And before Heaven, it was clear that at certain times Israel was worthy, by virtue of the Torah, to be conducted above the natural order, and ultimately, their redemption was only by virtue of the Torah.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's understanding that the redemption of the Israelites must occur through divine intervention rather than natural means, questioning why both Moses and Aaron were needed if Moses could speak for God alone. It emphasizes that the presence of natural limitations, such as Moses' speech impediment, undermines the authenticity of their mission if it relies on human capabilities. The text highlights that at times, God commanded Moses to speak to Pharaoh alone, while at other times, He instructed him to include Aaron, indicating that the Israelites' worthiness, particularly through the merit of the Torah, allowed for a redemption that transcended natural law. Ultimately, their redemption was achieved through the divine connection to the Torah.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתבאר במאמה"כ לכו לסבלותיכם וגו' ופרש"י שם (עיין קושיא ב') בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק (בראשית כ"ז ע"א) עה"פ ויקח ד"א את האדם, כגוונא דא אמרו מארי מתניתין וימררו את חייהם בעבודה קשה בקושיא , בחומר בקל וחומר, ובלבנים בלבון הלכתא, ובכל עבודה בשדה דא ברייתא את כל עבודתם וגו' דא משנה וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק , וצ"ב איך דרשו רז"ל כל זה על לימוד התוה"ק דכתיב בי' הנחמדים מזהב ומפז ומתוקים מדבש ונופת צופים, ומי שטעם טעם התורה מימיו לא יצוייר לפניו מתיקות ועריבות טובה הימנה, ואיך אפ"ל שמרירות חייהם הי' בלימוד התורה משנה וברייתא וכו ', גם יל"ד באמרו וימררו את חייהם, מהו הכוונה במלת חייהם והיל"ל וימררו אותם, אמנם הענין הוא שאם יזכה האדם לנפש מטוהרה ודעת צלולה, אין עריבות ונעימות יותר מעסק התוה"ק , כי הוא העונג הנשגב והנעלה מכל חמדי תבל, ואז זוכין להבין ולהשכיל עמקי סודותי ', אך ע"י החטא ר"ל נעשה מסך המבדיל והדעת הוא בשבי' וצריך לעמל ויגיעה ומיץ אפים להשיג ידיעת התוה"ק , ונקדים דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה ( בפ ' בשלח) לפרש אמרם ז"ל (במס' אבות פ"ג מ"ה) כל המקבל עליו עול תורה מעבירין ממנו עול מלכות ועול ד"א, וכל הפורק ממנו עול תורה נותנין עליו עול מלכות ועול ד"א, ותו"ד דהגזירה בזעת אפך תאכל לחם משמעו עמל ויגיעה, וכפשוטו קאי על לחם הגשמי, ובאמת קאי ג"כ על לחם התורה שנא' לכו לחמי בלחמי וגו', והכרח היגיעה בתורה נתחדש ע"י החטא, כי מקודם הי' כתנות אור וכו' ונתעצם בעצמית התורה ולא הי' צריך ליגיעה וכו ', וא"כ אף שהגזירה והקנס של בזעת אפך וגו' נקנס על כל בנ"א, הנה אותן שתורתן אומנתן אין צריכין לשום השתדלות לטרפם, לפי שנתקיים בהו הגזירה בעמל התורה, וזהו אמרם ז"ל כל המקבל עליו עול תורה מעבירין ממנו וכו' לגמרי, וההיפך בהפורק עול תורה צריך להשתדלות מכח הגזירה והקנס הקדום, והבינונים זה משלים את זה עכת"ד עיי"ש.
translation: And it will be explained according to our way in the verse, "Go to your burdens," etc. And Rashi explains there (see the question in B') by prefacing the words of the Zohar (Bereshit 27a) on the verse "And He took from the earth the man," similar to what our teachers of the Mishnah said, "And they made their lives bitter with hard work," with a question, with material and light, and with bricks in the white of the law, and with all work in the field, as this is the Beraita, "All their work," etc., as this is the Mishnah, etc. Thus said the Zohar. And it is difficult to understand how our sages derived all this regarding the study of the Torah, which is written, "More desirable than gold and fine gold, sweeter than honey and the honeycomb." And whoever has tasted the taste of the Torah from his days, it cannot be imagined before him that there is sweetness and pleasantness better than it. And how can it be said that the bitterness of their lives was in the study of the Torah, Mishnah, and Beraita, etc.? It is also to be understood in the statement "And they made their lives bitter," what is the intention of the word "their lives," and it should have said "And they made them bitter." However, the matter is that if a person merits a purified soul and a clear mind, there is no pleasantness and delight greater than engaging in the Torah, for it is the sublime and exalted pleasure above all the delights of the world. And then they merit to understand and comprehend the depths of secrets. But through sin, heaven forbid, a separating screen is created, and the mind is in captivity, and one must toil and exert effort and sweat to attain knowledge of the Torah. And we will preface the words of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Beshalach), to explain their statement, may their memory be blessed (in Pirkei Avot 3:5), "Anyone who accepts upon himself the yoke of the Torah, they remove from him the yoke of the kingdom and the yoke of worldly matters," and the opposite, "Anyone who removes from himself the yoke of the Torah, they place upon him the yoke of the kingdom and the yoke of worldly matters." And further, the decree "By the sweat of your brow you shall eat bread" implies toil and effort, and literally refers to physical bread, but in truth it also refers to the bread of the Torah, as it is said, "Come, eat my bread," etc. The necessity of effort in Torah was renewed through sin, for beforehand there were garments of light, etc., and it was concentrated in the essence of the Torah, and there was no need for effort, etc. Therefore, even though the decree and the penalty of "By the sweat of your brow" is imposed on all people, those whose Torah is their profession do not need any effort to sustain themselves, as the decree is fulfilled in them through the toil of the Torah. And this is what they said, may their memory be blessed, "Anyone who accepts upon himself the yoke of the Torah, they completely remove from him," and the opposite, in the case of one who removes the yoke of the Torah, he needs to exert effort due to the decree and the ancient penalty, and the intermediates complete each other. Thus is the conclusion, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the burdens of life and the study of Torah, emphasizing that true sweetness and joy come from engaging with Torah when one's soul is pure and mind clear. It contrasts the bitterness of life experienced through sin with the profound pleasure derived from Torah study, which is seen as the ultimate delight. The text also highlights that the obligation to toil in Torah study arose as a consequence of sin, yet those who embrace the yoke of Torah are relieved from other burdens, while those who reject it face additional hardships. Ultimately, it underscores the transformative power of Torah in alleviating life's struggles and providing spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל בגזירת שעבוד ועינוי שסבלו ישראל במצרים, הנגזר עליהם בברית בין הבתרים ועבדום ועינו אותם וגו', לא היתה חלק כולם שוה בזה, אבל בני לוי שקבלו עליהם עול תורה כמ"ש כי שמרו אמרתך ובריתך ינצורו , ע"כ נתקיים בהם גזירת העמל ויגיעה וגלות הדעת בלימוד התוה"ק , ויתבארו בזה דברי הזוה"ק וימררו את חייהם בעבודה קשה בחומר ובלבנים וגו' שדרשו כ"ז על לימוד התוה"ק , שכל זמן משך גלותם היתה הדעת בגלות ובקישויים רבים עלתה להם להשיג נקודת האמת בתוה"ק, ובעמל ויגיעה בא להם ההתעסקות בתורה, וכ"כ הרמב"ם ז"ל אין לך שמחה כהתרת הספיקות, ולפי שהי' קשה להם להגיע ללבון הלכתא ולהתרת הספיקות בבירור שמעתתא , סבלו מזה מרירות רב ועינוי קשה יותר מכל עינוי הגוף. והנה בני עלי' כל חיותם רק בתוה"ק, וזולתו כמו שנפסק חיותם וכמ"ש דוהמע"ה לעולם לא אשכח פיקודיך כי בם חייתני, וז"ש וימררו את חייהם, היינו התוה"ק שהוא עצמית חייהם, וע"י כובד הגלות נתמרר להם עיונה והשגתה, והדר ומפרש בלבנים זו ליבון הלכתא וכו' וברייתא ומשנה, וכ"ז עלה להם בעמל ומרירות.
translation: And similarly, one can say regarding the decree of servitude and suffering that the Israelites endured in Egypt, which was decreed upon them in the covenant between the pieces, "and they shall enslave them and afflict them," etc. Not all of them had an equal share in this, but the children of Levi, who accepted upon themselves the yoke of the Torah, as it is written, "for they kept Your word and Your covenant they shall guard," therefore the decree of toil and labor and the exile of knowledge in the study of the Holy Torah was fulfilled in them. This is explained in the words of the Zohar, and they embittered their lives with hard work in mortar and bricks, etc., which they expounded all this regarding the study of the Holy Torah. For as long as their exile lasted, their knowledge was in exile, and with many difficulties, they sought to grasp the point of truth in the Holy Torah. Through toil and labor, they engaged in the Torah, and thus the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, said, "There is no joy like the resolution of doubts." And because it was difficult for them to reach the clarification of the halacha and the resolution of doubts in the clear understanding of the teaching, they suffered great bitterness and a hardship greater than any physical suffering. Behold, the children of elevation draw all their vitality only from the Holy Torah, and without it, as it is stated, "I will never forget Your commandments, for through them You have given me life." And this is what is meant by "and they embittered their lives," meaning the Holy Torah, which is their very life. And through the heaviness of the exile, their suffering and understanding became bitter to them, and the explanation of "in bricks" refers to the clarification of halacha, etc., and to the Beraita and Mishnah, and all this came to them through toil and bitterness.
summary: The passage discusses the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that their experiences were not uniform, particularly highlighting the Levites who embraced the yoke of Torah. Their commitment to studying Torah amidst oppression led to a deep struggle for understanding and clarity, which was more painful than physical suffering. The text connects their spiritual toil to the concept that true life and vitality come from the Torah, illustrating that their hardships were ultimately tied to their pursuit of divine truth and understanding. The suffering they endured was a means to achieve a deeper connection with the essence of their faith.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתפרש מ"ש פרעה למשה ואהרן לכו לסבלותיכם, ופרש"י למלאכתכם שיש לכם לעשות בבתיכם, והכוונה על עסק התורה שזה נקרא מלאכת ביתם של עובדי ד' הצדיקים העמלים באהלה של תורה, וע"ד שאמרז"ל במדרש (והובא בילקוט שמעוני פ' וישב רמז קמ"ו) ויבא הביתה לעשות מלאכתו, מה מלאכה הי' עושה קורא ושונה מה שלמדו אביו, והנה טענת ותלונת פרעה הי' שעדיין לא הגיע זמנם של ישראל להגאל , כמו שפירשנו לעיל במאמר רז"ל אתם למה ודבריכם למה, לז"א למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, שהפשוטי עם עליהם להמשיך השעבוד והעבודה בגוף, ואתם בני לוי שאין עליכם שעבוד מלאכה, עכ"פ לכו לסבלותיכם למלאכתכם שבבית, ושם תסבלו צער הגלות והמרירות, ותמצית טענתו הי' כי לא הגיע עדיין זמן גאולתם כנ"ל.
translation: And similarly, it can be explained what Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron, "Go to your burdens," and Rashi explains, "to your work that you have to do in your homes," and the intention is regarding the study of Torah, which is called the work of their homes for the servants of God, the righteous who toil in the tent of Torah. This is in accordance with what our Sages said in the Midrash (as brought in Yalkut Shimoni, Parashat Vayeshev, Remez 136) "And he came home to do his work," what work was he doing? He was reading and reviewing what he had learned from his father. And behold, Pharaoh's claim and complaint was that the time for the redemption of Israel had not yet arrived, as we explained above in the saying of our Sages, "Why are you doing this to the people?" to say, "Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb the people from their work?" The simple folk are to continue the servitude and labor with their bodies, and you, the children of Levi, who are not under the burden of labor, at least go to your burdens, to your work at home, and there you will suffer the pain of exile and bitterness. The essence of his claim was that the time for their redemption had not yet come, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's command to Moses and Aaron to return to their work, interpreted by Rashi as a reference to the study of Torah, which is considered the true labor of the righteous. It highlights the idea that the Israelites were not yet ready for redemption, as Pharaoh argued that the common people should continue their physical labor while the Levites, who were free from such burdens, should endure the suffering of exile through their spiritual work at home. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between physical labor, spiritual devotion, and the timing of divine redemption. Ultimately, Pharaoh's complaint underscores the belief that the Israelites' redemption was not yet due.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתיישבו סתירת דרז"ל בענין התחלת זמן שעבודם של ישראל במצרים, דאיתא במד"ר (וברש"י ז"ל ר"פ ויחי) דמשמת יע"א נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, ובמד"ר (פ' שמות) עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא, ללמדך שכל זמן שהי' קיים א' מאותן ע' נפש שירדו למצרים לא שעבדו המצריים בישראל, ובסדר עולם איתא שכ"ז שהי' לוי קיים לא נשתעבדו , וכבר ביארנו בזה ולדרכנו אפ"ל דכ"ז שהי' יע"א קיים זכו ישראל בזכותו להארה גדולה בהשגת התורה, ע"י שלמדו מפיו והמשיך להם השפעת החכמה, ואחר שנפטר יע"א נסתמו מהם מעיינות החכמה בתוה"ק והרגישו בצרת השעבוד בבחי ' השגתה, וע"ד שאמרז"ל (תמורה ט"ז ע"א) ג' אלפים הלכות נשתכחו בימי אבלו של משה וכו' במתניתא תנא אלף ושבע מאות קל וחומר וגזירות שוות ודקדוקי סופרים נשתכחו בימי אבלו של משה, א"ר אבהו אעפ"כ החזירן עתניאל בן קנז מתוך פלפולו עכ"ד הגמ ', ואמרז"ל (סוכה כ' ע"א) בתחלה כשנשתכחה תורה מישראל עלה עזרא מבבל ויסדה, חזרה ונשתכחה עלה הלל הבבלי ויסדה, חזרה ונשתכחה עלו ר' חייא ובניו ויסדוה פרש"י לא נשתכחה כולה קאמר , אלא הלכות שכוחות מבני בתירא וכו' ועד"ז יתיישבו סתירת דרז"ל וכולהו איתנייהו , דשעבוד הגוף לא התחילה כ"ז שהי' א' מן הדור ההוא קיים אבל משמת יעקב הרגישו בצרת השעבוד רוחני, ע"י שכחת התורה שנגרם להם במיתתו, ואולי החזירה יוסף הצדיק להם והוריד השפעה חדשה בזכותו, ואחר מיתת יוסף באו עוה"פ לידי שכחת התורה, וחזרו השבעים הקדושים ויסדוה, ובהסתלקות השבטים הק ' הרגישו עוה"פ התחלת שעבוד הרוחני עד שהגיעו לוימררו את חייהם וגו' כדרשתם ז"ל בזוה"ק הנ"ל, וככה אירע לנו דור אחר דור שנחלש כח התורה והשגתה בערך דור הקדום, ואף האמוראים הק ' לא היו יכולים לחלוק על התנאים, שלא הי' כח התוה"ק בתוקפו כמו בדור שלפניהם, ובעוה"ר בדור הזה ירדנו פלאים עד דיוטא התחתונה, מי יורה דיעה ומי יבין שמועה, ואין מרגישים עוד הכאב והמרירות באבדונה וכמו בחולי הגוף כשנחלה מאוד ר"ל אינו מרגיש הכאב עוד.
translation: And similarly, the contradiction of our Sages regarding the beginning of the time of the servitude of Israel in Egypt can be resolved. It is stated in the Midrash (and in Rashi's commentary on Parashat Vayechi) that from the time of the passing of Yaakov, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed to the distress of the servitude. And in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot) on the verse "And Yosef died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," it teaches us that as long as one of those seventy souls who descended to Egypt was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel. And in the Seder Olam, it is stated that as long as Levi was alive, they were not enslaved. We have already explained this, and according to our approach, it can be said that as long as Yaakov was alive, Israel merited a great illumination in their understanding of the Torah, through which they learned from his mouth and he continued to impart to them the influence of wisdom. After Yaakov passed away, the springs of wisdom in the Holy Torah were closed to them, and they felt the distress of the servitude in the aspect of their understanding, in accordance with what our Sages said (Temurah 16a) that three thousand halachot were forgotten during the days of mourning for Moshe, etc. In the Tannaitic source, it states that one thousand seven hundred kal vachomers, gezeirot shavot, and the nuances of the scribes were forgotten during the days of mourning for Moshe. Rabbi Abahu said, nevertheless, Otniel ben Kenaz restored them through his pilpul. And our Sages said (Sukkah 20a) that initially, when the Torah was forgotten from Israel, Ezra ascended from Babylon and established it; it was forgotten again, and Hillel the Babylonian ascended and established it; it was forgotten again, and Rabbi Chiya and his sons established it. Rashi explains that it was not forgotten entirely, but rather the laws that were weakened by the descendants of Beitar, etc. And similarly, the contradiction of our Sages can be resolved, for all of them agree that the physical servitude did not begin as long as one of that generation was alive. But once Yaakov passed away, they felt the distress of the spiritual servitude due to the forgetting of the Torah that was caused by his death. Perhaps Yosef the Righteous restored it to them and brought down a new influence in his merit. After the death of Yosef, they came to forget the Torah, and the seventy holy ones returned and established it. With the passing of the holy tribes, they felt the beginning of the spiritual servitude until they reached the point of making their lives bitter, as your Sages have expounded in the aforementioned Zohar. And thus it has happened to us from generation to generation that the strength of the Torah and its understanding has weakened compared to the previous generation. Even the Amoraim could not dispute the Tannaim, for the strength of the Holy Torah was not as powerful as in the generation before them. And in our times, in this generation, we have descended tremendously to the lowest level, who will teach knowledge and who will understand a message, and we no longer feel the pain and bitterness of its loss, just as in a severe illness, when one is very ill, he does not feel the pain anymore.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual decline of the Jewish people during their enslavement in Egypt, emphasizing that their suffering began with the death of Jacob and the subsequent loss of divine wisdom and Torah knowledge. It highlights that as long as significant figures like Joseph and Levi were alive, the Israelites were shielded from complete subjugation, both physically and spiritually. The text reflects on the cyclical nature of Torah knowledge being forgotten and restored throughout history, illustrating a continuous struggle to maintain spiritual integrity amidst adversity. Ultimately, it conveys a sense of despair regarding the current state of Torah understanding, likening it to a deep spiritual malaise where the community no longer feels the pain of their loss.

passage_content: ואפ"ל במאמה"כ ( ישעי ' כ"ט) לכן הנני יוסיף להפליא את העם הזה הפלא ופלא, ודרשו רז"ל (שבת קל"ח ע"ב) הפלאה זו שכחת התורה, אולי נרמז כן בכפל הלשון. שמורה בכ"מ על הפלגת הריבוי כמ"ש נתן תתן . שלח תשלח, הוכח תוכיח שדרשו רז"ל אפי' מאה פעמים, וכן בשכחת התורה חזרה ונשנית בעוה"ר בכל דור ודור בערך בחי' דור הקדום, הבוי"ת יאיר עינינו בתורתו הקדושה ונשוב אליו באמת, ונזכה לישועה שלימה בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And even though it is written in the Holy Scriptures (Isaiah 29), "Therefore, behold, I will continue to astonish this people with wonder upon wonder," our Sages of blessed memory have interpreted (Shabbat 138b) that this astonishment refers to the forgetting of the Torah. Perhaps it is hinted at in the repetition of the phrase, which indicates an abundance, as it is said, "You shall surely give," "You shall surely send," "You shall surely reprove," which our Sages have interpreted even a hundred times. And so it is with the forgetting of the Torah, which has returned and repeated itself in our times in every generation, similar to the generation of old. May the Blessed One illuminate our eyes with His holy Torah, and may we return to Him in truth, and merit complete salvation with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine wonder and the repeated forgetting of the Torah, as indicated by the phrase "wonder upon wonder." It references the idea that this forgetting occurs in every generation, paralleling the experiences of earlier generations. The author expresses a hope for divine illumination through the sacred Torah, leading to a genuine return to God and the ultimate redemption marked by the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: ( בי ה' שלח נא ביד תשלח, איתא במדרש ביד מי ביד ר' עקיבא והוא פליאה, ורשיז"ל פי' שלח נא ביד תשלח ביד אחר שתרצה לשלוח, שאין סופי להכניסם לארץ ולהיות גואלם לעתיד וכו' עכ"ל, וצ"ב מדוע תלה זה בזה, וכי בשביל שאין סופו להכניסם לארץ אין ראוי שיגאל אותם גם מתחלה.
translation: In the Hebrew text: "In You, Hashem, send now by the hand You will send," it is stated in the Midrash, "by the hand of whom? By the hand of Rabbi Akiva," and this is a wonder. And Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that "send now by the hand You will send" means by another hand that You wish to send, for there is no end to bringing them into the land and being their Redeemer in the future, etc. Thus far the quote. And it is puzzling why this is dependent on that, for is it not that because there is no end to bringing them into the land, they are not worthy of being redeemed from the beginning?
summary: The passage discusses the request made by Moses to God to send someone else to lead the Israelites, referencing a Midrash that connects this to Rabbi Akiva's interpretation. It highlights the idea that the ultimate redemption and entry into the Promised Land are not guaranteed, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention and human agency. The text raises a question about the relationship between the initial act of redemption and the eventual fulfillment of the promise, emphasizing the complexity of God's plans for the Jewish people.

translation: 3) (Parashat Bereishit, Parashat 22, Verse 13) And Cain went out, etc. He went out and was happy. Adam HaRishon encountered him and said to him, "What has been done regarding your judgment?" He replied, "I have repented and reached a compromise." Adam HaRishon began to slap his face and said, "Such is the power of repentance, and I did not know this." Immediately, Adam HaRishon stood up and said, "A psalm, a song for the Sabbath day." Everyone was astonished, "What is the connection of a psalm, a song for the Sabbath day to this?"
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the interaction between Cain and Adam reveals profound insights about repentance (teshuvah) and its transformative power. Adam, initially shocked by Cain's claim of having repented and reached a compromise, expresses his astonishment at the efficacy of teshuvah, which he had not fully understood. This leads Adam to recite a psalm, highlighting the connection between repentance and spiritual elevation, suggesting that true repentance can lead to a state of joy and sanctity, even amidst grave circumstances. The unexpected recitation of a psalm emphasizes the idea that moments of spiritual awakening can arise from the depths of human experience.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר עפי"ד הגמ ' (ר"ה דף ל"א ע"א) תניא ר' יהודא אומר משום ר' עקיבא בראשון מה היו אומרים לה' הארץ ומלואה וכו' בשביעי היו אומרים מזמור שיר ליום השבת ליום שכולו שבת, אמר ר' נחמי' מה ראה ר' עקיבא לחלק בין הפרקים, פי' רש"י ז"ל שכל ששת ימים נאמרין הפרקים הללו ע"ש שעבר, ושל יום שבת ע"ש להבא, וע"כ פליג ר' נחמי' וס"ל דשיר של שביעי ע"ש ששבת, וקמיפלגי בדרב קטינא דאמר רב קטינא שיתא אלפי שנה הוה עלמא וחד חרוב וכו' אביי אמר תרי חרוב, פרש"י ז"ל ר' נחמי' לית לן דר' קטינא אלא דאביי , הילכך ליכא למימר על שם יום אחד שכולו שבת דהא תרי נינהו .
translation: And it is possible to say according to the words of the Gemara (Rosh Hashanah 31a) that it teaches: Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Akiva, on the first [day] they would say to Hashem, "The earth and its fullness," etc. On the seventh, they would say, "A psalm, a song for the Sabbath day, for a day that is entirely Sabbath." Rabbi Nachman said, what did Rabbi Akiva see to differentiate between the sections? Rashi explains that all six days the sections are said in reference to what has passed, and for the Sabbath day in reference to what is to come. Therefore, Rabbi Nachman argues and holds that the song of the seventh is in reference to the fact that it has rested. And they argue regarding Rav Katina, who said that the world existed for six thousand years and then it was desolate, etc. Abaye said two desolations. Rashi explains that Rabbi Nachman does not hold from Rabbi Katina, but from Abaye. Therefore, one cannot say in the name of one day that is entirely Sabbath, for there are two [days].
summary: The passage discusses a debate between Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Nehemiah regarding the significance of the Psalms recited on the Sabbath compared to the weekdays. Rabbi Akiva suggests that the Psalms for the weekdays reflect past experiences, while the Sabbath Psalm represents a future state of rest. Rabbi Nehemiah counters this by asserting that the Sabbath song is rooted in the present experience of rest, emphasizing the ongoing sanctity of the Sabbath. This dialogue highlights the Hasidic concept of the interplay between time, spiritual elevation, and the nature of divine rest.
