passage_content: איברא אליבא דאמת לענין זה להצטרף לחשבון צערן של ישראל, כל ישראל מצטרפים חוץ ממינים ואפיקורסים שאינם מן המנין כלל, אבל בוודאי שכל בני ישראל מצטרפים למנין הזה, שכולם סבלו גלות וצרות רק בשביל שהם ישראל, אלא שלענין לצרף הכרעת דעתם למנין הרוב אין מצטרפים רק אלו שכוונתם לש"ש כמ"ש הרמ"א ( בשו"ע חו"מ סי' קס"ג) עיי"ש, ומכ"ש אם דעתם ח"ו היפך דעת התורה שאין מצטרפין , אלא שפרעה בגודל רשעתו טען לילך אחר הרבים גם לענין זה שלא יצאו ישראל ממצרים מפני שהרוב אינם רוצים לצאת כנ"ל, וכן הוא טענת אוה"ע וטענת כל הרשעים, ובאמת אין דעתם מצטרף להכרעת הרוב כנ"ל.
translation: However, according to the truth regarding this matter of joining the count of the suffering of Israel, all of Israel joins except for heretics and apostates who are not counted at all. But certainly, all the children of Israel join this count, for they all suffered exile and troubles solely because they are Israel. However, regarding the matter of joining their opinion to the majority, only those whose intention is for the sake of Heaven join, as the Rema writes (in Shulchan Aruch, Choshen Mishpat, Siman 163), see there. And certainly, if their opinion is, Heaven forbid, contrary to the opinion of the Torah, they do not join. However, Pharaoh, in his great wickedness, claimed to follow the majority also in this matter, that Israel should not leave Egypt because the majority do not wish to leave, as mentioned above. And so it is the claim of the nations of the world and the claim of all the wicked. And in truth, their opinion does not join the decision of the majority, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of collective suffering among the Jewish people, emphasizing that all Jews share in the pain of exile and hardship due to their identity as Israelites, except for heretics and those outside the faith. It highlights that only those whose intentions align with the divine will, as outlined in Jewish law, are counted in this collective. The text contrasts this with the arguments of the wicked, who claim that the majority's will should dictate actions, such as the Exodus from Egypt, asserting that true divine intent does not conform to the majority's opinion. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of aligning one's intentions with Torah values to be part of the collective Jewish experience.

passage_content: ועתה לכו עבדו ותבן לא ינתן לכם: בספרי (פ' בהעלותך) הקשו מכאן עה"פ זכרנו את הדגה אשר נאכל במצרים חנם, וכי יש בענין שהיו המצרים נותנין להם דגים חנם, והלא כבר נאמר ועתה לכו עבדו ותבן לא ינתן לכם, אם תבן לא היו נותנים להם בחנם, דגים היו נותנים להם חנם, ומה אני אומר חנם חנם מן המצות עכ"ד הספרי, ולכאורה הרי זה מוציא מפשוטו, וכללא אית לן דאין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו לעולם.
translation: And now go, serve; straw will not be given to you. In the Sifrei (Parashat Beha'alotecha), they questioned from here regarding the verse, "We remember the fish that we ate in Egypt for free." Is there a matter where the Egyptians would give them fish for free? But it has already been said, "And now go, serve; straw will not be given to you." If they did not give them straw for free, would they give them fish for free? And what do I say? Free, free from the commandments. Thus concludes the Sifrei. And at first glance, this seems to take it out of its simple meaning, and we have a general rule that a verse never departs from its simple meaning.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction between the Israelites' complaint about the free fish they ate in Egypt and the statement that the Egyptians would not even provide them with straw for their labor. It highlights a Hasidic interpretation that emphasizes the spiritual significance of the Israelites' yearning for the past, suggesting that their desire for the fish symbolizes a longing for the spiritual nourishment found in the commandments. The text underscores the principle that scriptural interpretations should not dismiss the plain meaning, yet it invites deeper reflection on the relationship between physical sustenance and spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר על פי מה שכתבנו לעיל מדברי רז"ל דהערב רב ורשעי ישראל שהיו מתדמים במעשיהם להמצריים עשו אותן פטרונין , ולא הי' חסר להם מאומה. ורק הכשרים שבישראל סבלו צער השעבוד, ולפי"ז א"ש והדרש והפשט יתאחדו, וכוונת הכתוב א"ש אף לפי פשוטו שניתן להם חנם ממש, ומה שהקשו תבן לא היו נותנים להם בחנם, דגים היו נותנים להם חנם, ע"ז תירצו בספרי חנם בלא מצות, ר"ל לאלו שפרקו מעליהם עול מצות נתנו בחנם, כדי להמשיך גם אחרים לרשעתם בראותם טובת הרשעים בעוה"ז, ומ"ש תבן לא ינתן לכם, נאמר על הכשרים שבישראל שסבלו צער השעבוד ואעפ"כ עמדו באמונתם, ובעוה"ר נסיונות כאלו ישנם גם בדורינו כנודע, השי"ת יצילינו מהם ונזכה לילך בדרך האמת ולהתדבק אל הבוית"ש ותורתו הקדושה, ונזכה לראות בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And it is possible to say according to what we wrote above from the words of our Sages, that the mixed multitude and the wicked of Israel, who were resembling the Egyptians in their deeds, made them patrons, and they lacked nothing. Only the righteous among Israel suffered the pain of servitude. According to this, the simple meaning and the interpretation will unite, and the intent of the text is clear even according to its simple meaning, that they were given to them for free, truly. And regarding the straw, they were not given to them for free; fish were given to them for free. To this, it was answered in the Sifrei that it was for free without commandments, meaning to those who cast off the yoke of commandments, they were given for free, in order to draw others to their wickedness by seeing the goodness of the wicked in this world. And what is said, "straw will not be given to you," is said about the righteous among Israel who suffered the pain of servitude and nevertheless stood firm in their faith. And in the future world, such trials also exist in our generation, as is known. May the Holy One, blessed be He, save us from them, and may we merit to walk in the path of truth and to cling to the Blessed One and His holy Torah, and may we merit to see the upliftment of the crown of the Torah and Israel and the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the righteous and the wicked among the Jewish people, emphasizing that while the wicked (referred to as the "mixed multitude") prospered materially, the righteous suffered under oppression yet remained steadfast in their faith. It highlights the idea that the rewards given to the wicked serve to tempt others into sin, contrasting this with the suffering of the righteous who endure trials for their commitment to God's commandments. The text calls for divine protection from such trials and expresses a hope for the ultimate redemption and the revelation of God's glory in the world.
